name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The first item is the debate on the report on the monitoring of the application of EU legislation in the annual reports 30 and 31 prepared by Kostas Chrysogonos on behalf of the Committee on Legal Affairs (2014/2253(INI)(A8-0242/2015)

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: , (rapporteur). Madam President, in July we voted in the Committee on Legal Affairs and by a large majority the report on the application of European law for the years 2012-2013. The report also served as a tool for our Commission's dialogue with the Committees on Petitions, Constitutional Affairs, the Environment and Individual Rights. Through this creative process of exchanging views with Members from different political areas and with different parliamentary powers, we have been led to the text before you today.  This report is added to a series of previous corresponding reports which each year reflect Parliament's response to the Commission's official opinion on how European law was applied or not applied, at a given time period, in the Union. Traditionally, these reports have emphasised the way in which Member States apply European law and the mechanisms and tools that can be used to comply with their obligations.  This dimension of the application of Union law, we develop it in detail in our report with evidence, so that it can be understood by every citizen who identifies the difficulties and problems. But for the first time, we dared to go one step further. For the first time in this report, we dared to say the obvious, namely that the application of EU law is not only a requirement for the Member States but also binds the Union itself, its institutions and bodies. It should be noted in particular that, in the context of the recent financial crisis, Member States were obliged to take measures that undermine the primary law of the European Union and in particular its provisions relating to the protection of social and economic rights. The report urges the Institutions of the Union, the Council, the Commission, the European Central Bank, to respect primary Union law, the Treaties and the Charter of Fundamental Rights when adopting provisions of secondary law and when adopting policies on economic and social issues affecting human rights. The report also expresses concern that the austerity measures imposed on heavily indebted Member States of the Union, which were subsequently incorporated into acts of secondary European Union law, before being transposed into domestic law, during the period covered by the two reports under consideration, and in particular the drastic cuts in public expenditure, have resulted in a significantly reduced capacity of Member States to comply with their obligations to properly apply its law. European Union.  The report considers that Member States under economic adjustment programmes should continue to be able to fulfil their obligations to respect social and economic rights and recalls that all the institutions of the European Union, even when acting as members of groups of international lenders (see Troika or Quaretta), are bound by the Treaties and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the Union.  Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I ask you to vote in favour of the report, because I believe that this is a comprehensive and balanced report, which builds on what has already been built but also dares to introduce new dimensions of the problem, in a way that ultimately strengthens and honours the competences of our Parliament as the voice of the peoples of Europe. Thanks.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Chrysogonos, and all the Members involved, for the important work on the draft resolution on the monitoring of the application of EU law. The Commission highly appreciates Parliament’s increased interest in implementation issues. I believe our debate today could not have come at a more crucial point for the EU. The European Union is a union based on law. We have built this body of law together. It is the basis for our actions. It is not enough to merely pass legislation: what matters is its application on the ground. If it is not applied, the EU foundation weakens. The importance of the correct application of EU law cannot have been made clearer than by the current migration crisis. With the current unprecedented flows of people coming to Europe in search of refuge, the correct application of our legislation on asylum is vitally important. EU law provides that all those entitled to asylum and protection are received in humane conditions and have their case dealt with efficiently and quickly. We certainly do not apply EU law in all Member States at this stage. EU law also requires that all those who have no right to stay must be returned to their countries of origin rapidly and efficiently. This is why, in addition to the measures that we have adopted this week, we will make the correct application of EU asylum law the priority of our actions. We have already started with infringement procedures. The Treaties entrust the Commission, together with the Court of Justice, with ensuring the correct application of EU law. We take this role as guardian of the Treaties very seriously indeed. If Member States are not respecting the rule of law or are breaching EU law, we will not hesitate to launch formal infringement proceedings and take the case to the European Court of Justice where necessary. The Treaties also give us the possibility to impose financial penalties where judgements of the court are not respected and where directives are not transposed on time, and we use those possibilities systematically. This unique and essential role of the Commission is an integral and indispensable part of our legal system. In the report Members have expressed concern about the handling of complaints before they reach the stage of infringement proceedings and have called for this to be regulated in a European administrative law under Article 298 of the Treaty. I would like to stress that the Commission views complaints as an invaluable source for carrying out its task as guardian of the Treaties.  This is why the Commission has created a strong framework to protect complainants. The Code of Good Administrative Behaviour and the Communication on relations with the complainant offer a number of guarantees that safeguard complainants’ rights throughout the entire procedure. These include the right to be informed about any decision on his or her complaint, the right to be heard, prior notice before closing a case and a timeframe for a final decision on complaints.  Against this background, I am not convinced that there is a necessity to regulate this matter in a legislative act based on Article 298 of the Treaty. The Commission will continue to fully respect its commitments in the framework agreement to provide information concerning infringement procedures to the European Parliament. Moreover, it will also continue its current practice to inform the public at the latest when a letter of formal notice is issued.  Some of you have expressed concerns about the Commission’s Better Regulation Agenda, in particular the REFIT Programme, including an alleged deregulatory effect. In this respect, I want to make clear, first of all, that REFIT is not about deregulation. Rather, it aims at making sure that legislation remains effective and fit for purpose. It has a focus on transparency and openness, collecting views and suggestions from a wide variety of stakeholders, thereby reinforcing the protection of public interest. The REFIT Platform offers a forum for dialogue between the Commission, businesses, SMEs, social partners, civil society organisations and Member States.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Behind each environmental law lies a great effort by civil society, organisations, politicians and citizens. But what is really happening in the next stage? The statistics speak for themselves. We see that most of the new delayed transposition cases initiated by the Commission were environmental- as many as 168 cases. I find it distressing, it is dangerous for the environment and it is an insult to all the people who have put a lot of energy into improving environmental policy. These are the problems that we pinpoint in our report. Firstly, we criticise the fact that environmental legislation is far too often implemented too late. Secondly, we are calling for the Commission to be stricter on those Member States that do not behave. Thirdly, we clearly show that the large number must not lower the level of ambition. I would also like to mention that we are clear about REFIT, and that we do not want it to lead to lower ambitions.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Petitions. – Madam President, deficiencies in, and differences between, standards are a result of the fact that Member States transpose EU legislation in different ways. They hinder the delivery of tangible benefits for our citizens and pose problems for those wishing to live, work or do business across borders.  It is time to put people at the heart of EU policy-making by identifying problematic areas, dismantling barriers to citizens and improving implementation in ways which result in concrete benefits in the daily lives of our citizens. The Commission should push for a better mechanism for reviewing how EU rules are applied in practice and how citizens and businesses are empowered to exercise their rights.  So I was very pleased to hear the Commissioner express the same opinions in his speech. Inconsistent transportation hinders not only citizens but also Member States. Countries such as Malta which have a low rate of transposition infringement cases are competitively disadvantaged by other Member States which often maintain lower regulatory standards rather than transposing EU legislation. This is not acceptable.

name: Traian UNGUREANU
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. – Madam President, the data published by the Commission in its 30th and 31st annual reports show that, although many efforts have been made over the years to improve the implementation process, we are still far from a balanced result. The measures taken by the Commission to assist Member States in the implementation process are to be welcomed, but should be intensified. The Commission should put more emphasis on overseeing and ensuring the concrete application of EU law. Information on the implementation of EU law in the area of freedom, security and justice and other policy areas should be more structured, transparent and accessible. The annual monitoring report could and should be supplemented by other measures that would allow Parliament to be kept regularly and effectively informed. To conclude, I would like to recall that there cannot be a truly European area of justice without the correct and timely implementation of EU legislation.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Chrysogonos, for his very rich report, thanks in part to the contribution of the opinions. Our AFCO Committee has mainly focused on legal certainty, which must be guaranteed to all citizens of the Union. That is why we have wanted to call on the Member States to avoid practices such as gold plating that undermine it from within, and we have stressed that it is certainly a step forward that the Treaty of Lisbon already allows the Court of Justice to impose sanctions with the first judgment of non-compliance.  A strong call is also made to the EU institutions to respect primary law in establishing rules of secondary legislation, to adopt policies on economic and social issues – and here I would also say that reference to the fiscal compact is a must. Unfortunately, however, Parliament is complaining that it has not yet received information on pre-conflict situations in a sufficiently appropriate manner. The online platform You payd it is yes, certainly, a useful advance, but not yet fully accessible and usable by us. We also call for Parliament's role as a full co-legislator, and that is why we are calling for an autonomous ex-post impact assessment system that will also help us to close the policy cycle better.

name: Tadeusz ZWIEFKA
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Colleagues, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. One of the reasons why the European Parliament looks at the process of implementing European law in the Member States every year is to determine whether there has been an improvement, whether it is already better, or whether we still have a lot of problems. Statistics say it's better, but statistics are just statistics. We are still seeing many areas where the implementation of EU law into national legal systems is, firstly, delayed and, secondly, inefficient and inefficient.  The problem is that, too often, Member States apply specific legislative overlays, preparing an additional network of different legislative restrictions on what has been prepared at Community level. This makes the law less readable for those who are supposed to use it: for citizens, for companies operating in the European Union, and that is what we need to counteract.  It seems that timeliness is not the most important element here, but the quality of transposition. It should be the most important objective that we are aiming for, which is why I fully support colleague Chrysogos, who says that particular attention should be paid to the functioning of small and medium-sized enterprises when we are talking about the legislative process.  I also support it in stating that there should be better cooperation between the European institutions at all stages of law-making, at the initial stage of legislation, at the very stage of legislation, but also later when we assess it. The link between our work and national parliaments should also be stronger in order to prepare them for proper transposition of European law.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr President, Ladies and Gentlemen, Mr President-in-Commissioner, I would like to thank the As President Juncker said yesterday, the European Union is not in a good position. But where would we be if we did not have this European Union? And this certainly also applies to our legislation, which must be monitored and implemented. And that is why this report is not a technical one, but a question of what is being done: what is actually being complied with? What we are seeing, however, is that social issues are being pushed aside in implementation. We see that fundamental and human rights exist in the European Union, but are not sufficiently respected in this crisis situation. And that is, of course, an important credit to the rapporteur's attention to this. We know that the Commission should be the guardian of the Treaties.  We are now seeing interference with fundamental rights, such as the human right to housing, medical care and social security. However, citizens accordingly expect a simple, predictable, effective and reliable regulatory framework. It is clear to me that EU legislation must be formulated as simply as possible on the one hand and as detailed as necessary on the other. Social, environmental and consumer protection standards must not be softened under the pretext of cutting red tape. And the question of whether legislation is good and of high quality should not be tied to cost issues, but to whether it can fulfil its purpose permanently and for the benefit of citizens and workers.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, let me first of all congratulate the rapporteur on the comprehensive report he has presented to us. I welcome the fact that its report also highlights a number of challenges to the common application of law in the European Union. Despite the positive feedback in terms of the lower number of recorded violations, we must not fail to keep the focus of our attention on the overall picture. We still face numerous challenges, especially with regard to the general and correct application of European Union law on the territory of the Member States. For a well-functioning single market, in order to maintain the legal order in the territory of the Member States of the European Union, further support must be improved for national services, which are fundamentally responsible when it comes to including and implementing new rules and new guidelines. We also need to further improve EU legislation to prevent excessively complex legal structures that will provide greater clarity and legal stability. This will further stimulate economic growth and employment.

name: António MARINHO E PINTO
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, I was shadow rapporteur on this dossier and i was able to follow the work that was done by your rapporteur. I would therefore like to congratulate Mr Kostas Chrysogonos on the quality and rigour of the work produced.  In October 2014, the European Commission published the annual Monitoring Report on European Law Enforcement in the Member States for 2013. There is still much to be done in each Member State for the effective transposition of European directives into national law and also with citizens so that they know the advantages of the correct application of European law and can fully exercise European citizenship, with perfect knowledge of their rights and obligations.  The conclusions of this report include a decrease in the time for transposition of directives, the reduction of infringement procedures, and an increase in citizens' complaints, which also reflects an increase in their civic awareness. The report is balanced and I reaffirm that European citizens have the right to be informed in a transparent and timely manner about which national laws have been adopted as a result of the transposition of European law. Europe cannot impose very strict austerity measures on some Member States and, at the same time, to require internal institutions to be exemplary in the effective transposition... (The President withdraws the floor to the speaker)

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, currently it seems that there are huge differences in the application of EU law between Member States. This may be caused by excessive bureaucracy, lack of knowledge or lack of transparency, and it all causes problems for citizens and businesses alike. But let me emphasise this: are we any better here inside the EU? We should lead by example and we should first clean up the mess in our own backyard.  The application of EU law in EU institutions is indeed far from consistent and I am very glad that Mr Timmermans mentioned the law on administrative procedure which Parliament is calling for, but I would very much like you, Mr Timmermans, to consider that rules binding all institutions would create a solid foundation for better application of EU laws and regulations. It would also reduce the need for ad hoc actions and would instead create a long-lasting system and generate foreseeability and stability which would benefit both citizens and businesses.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, legal certainty is an indispensable principle of our legal system, the high ethical value of which, even before legal value, must be pursued by the European Union and the Member States in order to guarantee the freedom of the individual and the equality of citizens before the law.  Having mentioned in the Chrysogonos report the centrality of this principle deserves particular appreciation, and I would also like to thank Mr Chrysogonos for mentioning another important point, namely that the austerity measures imposed on the Member States should never adversely affect respect for social and economic rights, because the institutions of the European Union, even when they participate in the so-called troikas, are bound by the Treaties and the Charter of Fundamental Rights.  It is a serious matter that most infringement proceedings in the area of internal affairs concern the delayed transposition of the directive on the prevention and repression of trafficking in human beings, as well as the fact that many complaints concern the area of asylum. All this must be overcome immediately, and it is up to President Juncker and the Commission to follow up what was said yesterday in this House, ensuring in practice the implementation and respect of EU law.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, this report on the application of EU law is reprehensible because it refuses to see the great failure of the European Union.  At point 9, however, it acknowledges that "the Union does not correspond to the expectations of the citizens", but it draws an absurd consequence from it. It calls on the Commission to step up its procedures in breach in order to overcome the reluctance of States to transpose the European directives. This is Europe in the schlague.  Worse, in point 39, he states that "the effective implementation of the European asylum system is a top priority". In the face of the migratory submersion we are experiencing, it is urgent for States to regain their sovereignty and send the Brussels Commission to the dustbin of history.  The European Union must be replaced by a Europe of nations.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: – The report on the application of European Union law shows that unfortunately all of us, as representatives of our peoples and preachers of the Republic, have failed miserably in consolidating our sense of justice, legal meritocracy and the rule of law. Many times we Golden Dawn MEPs have denounced the illegal and unconstitutional persecution of our party's MPs by the Greek government. We have presented evidence of manipulation of justice by the political leadership. We spoke of a flagrant violation of the Charter of Fundamental Rights in matters of personal data protection, respect for privacy, freedom of expression and freedom of assembly. The greatest illegality and injustice of all is that the party I represent, the third-largest parliamentary force, is being prosecuted as a criminal organisation, deliberately, because Greece has not recognised the Palermo Convention in its national legislation to include it. Unfortunately, within the Union, justice and democracy apply a la carte, so the citizens of our countries have every reason to no longer trust their institutions. Thanks.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: – Madam President, it is true that we monitor the application of European law into the national legal order to ensure respect for the rule of law, legal certainty and predictability of law. However, effective, efficient and timely implementation by Member States is not only there to serve legal concepts but more so to ensure those freedoms the enjoyment of which is fundamental to European citizenship.  As citizens of the Union, we expect to be able to move freely amongst Member States and to live, work and do business in other Member States. In doing so, citizens rightly expect not to get entangled in legislative webs created by either late implementation, or inaccurate or incomplete application of European law.  While recognising the Commission’s efforts in monitoring the application of EU law, citizens need to see stronger and less time-consuming procedures. In today’s challenges there is, for example, no time to waste in assuring that Member States correctly and timely apply European law on migration as well as that on human trafficking and the environment. We can only deliver results to our citizens if legislation that has been lawfully passed is applied.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, I think this is a very important topic. Firstly, I think we should be looking at how we actually make European law. In that regard, I welcome the new Commission’s ambition to have less red tape and to be more relevant to our treaties; and that can dovetail with Mr Cameron’s desire for reform. I think one thing we should look at is when amendments or proposals are put down that are matters of subsidiarity, no matter how popular or desirable they are, we should have a mechanism that would allow us to strike them out straightaway. That would improve matters a lot.  Secondly, in the application of European law, as some of my colleagues have said, there is too much gold-plating going on and, of course, the European Union gets blamed as a result. That is something we should try and avoid as well.  Finally, the cost of application and implementation is far too high. I believe in the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) it is something like EUR 4 billion per year. That is something we should certainly look at.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Madam President, first of all congratulations to the rapporteur on his report. I will start with something very correct that the Vice-President said, that if we legislate but this does not apply in the European Union, then this legislation is as if it does not exist. There is therefore a place within the European Union where basic human rights are not applied. The right to property does not apply. The right to exercise religious worship does not apply. The installation right does not apply. The basic human rights of voting and voting do not apply. The Republic - its function - does not apply. This place is the occupied part of the Republic of Cyprus, the place illegally occupied by Turkish troops. I want each of us to think about what the interests of the European Union are, to think about whether the interests of the European Union are also its values, to think about whether we can tolerate such a situation within the European Union. Thank you.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur on his report and agree in turn that the question of the application of European Union law is very important. I, as Professor of Institutions of the European Union at the University, have given and continue to attach great importance to the role of the Commission, because the Commission is the guardian of the application of Community law. However, there are now a number of serious issues, which arise mainly from the Memoranda applied in certain countries and which result in important elements of European Union law being infringed and, above all, rights relating to social issues being infringed. On these issues, therefore, we have called for the Commission to intervene but, because the Commission is also a member of the Troika, it is in a conflict of interest. The Commission does not apply Community law correctly because it is itself involved, since it is a member of the Troika, in the infringement of Community law. This is a very important issue, which I highlighted the other day when I spoke about the reply given to me by Mr Moscovici, who said that the European Social Charter is not binding within the European Union! Please consider this matter. Thank you.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Madam President, it is true that the Union is based on rights, on the treaty of founding, on regulations and it is true that this is precisely what guarantees the unity of the Union and guarantees this order that we create together. It is also true that much should be simplified. However, what is problematic is that many member states behave as if we are in a market or in some à la carte restaurant and everyone takes what suits him or her, and tries not to take what does not suit him from certain regulations and individual laws. And there is an important role for the Commission to monitor the application of all these regulations and laws, otherwise we will have the same laws and different application, and this definitely cannot be a security for citizens, for businesses and for our system. I support what our fellow MP wrote in the report and hope this is a good way to deal with such problems.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, first of all let me pick up on the last point that was made and let me quote the great Greek philosopher Socrates about this: in the rule of law, if it is to work, all laws need to be applied. It is not an à la carte menu. If you want the rule of law to function and be respected by everyone, it should apply equally to everyone in all cases. That is what the Commission’s role is: to make sure that EU law is applied according to what was agreed by the legislators, including when it is transposed into national legislation. One Member raised the issue of the application of environmental law: the issue here is, indeed, partly one of late application but, unfortunately, in a larger number of cases it is about the wrong application of EU directives. The Commission then has to start infringement procedures – and we do start infringement procedures because I strongly believe that, if we do not, you undermine the very principle Socrates referred to, namely the application of all laws to everyone, regardless of their position, or regardless of the Member State. I insist on this because I believe this Commission will need to intensify its operations in making sure that EU law is applied correctly in all Member States. Secondly, I would like to pick up on a point about REFIT. Better regulation makes an immediate contribution to the better enforcement of EU law. By carefully assessing the impact of new legislation – and Mr Kelly referred to this as well – and by consulting widely, we ensure that the legislation we produce will be clear, workable and proportionate to the aims we pursue. By producing legislation of the highest quality and by ensuring that our acquis remains fit for purpose, we will also ensure that problems of enforcement are reduced. To make that clearer: in the beginning, if you are sure that you are not just looking for a compromise in this House but you are also looking for something that can be applied in a transparent and efficient way, you will create fewer problems afterwards. All three institutions involved – Parliament, Council and Commission – have a shared responsibility. I hope that we will soon conclude a new interinstitutional agreement on better law making, which will help us together to produce legislation that will serve the European citizen in the best possible way. A lot of complaints about red tape are not about the amount of legislation but rather about the quality of legislation which leads to undue administrative burdens. In his oral presentation, the rapporteur went deeply into the issue of austerity programmes. I did not see much of that in the report, but I did see it very much in his presentation. So let me go into that briefly: I strongly believe that economic adjustment programmes do not reduce the capacity of Member State authorities to comply with EU law. On the contrary, if you do not observe fiscal discipline over a longer period of time, you will fatally undermine the capacity of the state to provide social programmes to ensure the possibility of a welfare state. It is the triangle of fiscal responsibility, structural reform and investment. You cannot pick and choose. You cannot just say that you will only invest and will disregard fiscal responsibility – which is sometimes what people on parts of the left are saying – and you cannot just say that it is all about fiscal responsibility and we do not need investment – which parts of the right are saying. You need a balance in this triangle, as was stressed again by President Juncker last night. The Greek and Cypriot memoranda of understanding were not part of EU law, because they led to intergovernmental financial support – in contrast, by the way, to the Irish and Portuguese ones, which received support from the Union budget. The Greek and Cypriot MoUs were formally agreed only between the lenders and the beneficiary Member State. The Court of Justice confirmed that, when adopting and implementing measures under such an intergovernmental adjustment programmes, the national authorities of the Member State concerned are not implementing EU law. I think this point needs to be assessed carefully when Members discuss the report.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: , (rapporteur). Thank you, Madam President. I would like to express my thanks for all the positive comments that have been made about the report here. It seems to be concluded that, with the exception of Members on the mountain benches of parliament's extreme right wing, all wings of this Chamber agree that we need more Europe and agree that we need to take the clock of history forward, not back, to a Europe of nations and national confrontations. But to do this, as the President of the Commission admitted yesterday, the European Union must, firstly, become more European and, secondly, more united. More European means that it must show greater respect for fundamental rights and the value of man, which is, in accordance with Article 2 of the Founding Treaty, the foundation of the Union. Let me once again insist that the concept of fundamental rights also includes social rights, which we must treat as rules of law and not as wishful speeches or mere declarations of a political nature. The Union must, of course, become more united, which means that greater coherence and solidarity must be shown both between the Member States and within societies. The issue of migration, and in particular the issue of refugees that we are so concerned about these days, is an issue that requires precisely practical solidarity between the Member States, greater coherence and a unified attitude to dealing with it, because otherwise the Member States of first entry are burdened with a burden which they are unable to cope with on their own. Thank you very much.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The debate is over. The vote will take place on Thursday, 10 September 2015. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Emil RADEV
text: in writing. – Dear Colleagues, the results of the reports show that the untimely and incorrect transposition of european directives remains a major problem in the application of European Union law. We cannot help but note the active role of citizens and the European institutions in ensuring that Member States comply with EU law. The complaints they make are key. However, the overall decrease in the number of formal infringement procedures over the last five years (from 2 900 to 1 300) shows that a solution has been found. We cannot help but note the positive role of the EU Pilot preliminary procedure. In this respect, more transparency is needed in order for the European Parliament and citizens to be properly informed. We know that the primary responsibility for the proper application and enforcement of European Union law is held by the Member States, but this must not relieve the EU institutions of their obligation to respect primary law when adopting legislation. There is therefore a great need for rules generally applicable to the European institutions in administrative procedures. This will reduce red tape, ensure full respect for citizens' right to good administration and make the European Union more accessible.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The next item is the debate on the oral question referred to the Commission by Iratxe García Pérez and Catherine Bearder on behalf of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality on the gender ag of trafficking in human beings (O-000079/2015 - B8-0568/2015)

name: Catherine BEARDER
text: author. – Madam President, let me start by thanking the Commissioner for coming to speak to us today. As one of the rapporteurs for Parliament’s implementation report on the Anti-trafficking Directive to be drafted later this year, I am very happy, Commissioner, to hear from you.  The EU actually has a good record on action to protect victims of human trafficking. In 2011, the Anti-trafficking Directive was held up globally as the gold standard in protection of victims because it adopts a gender-specific approach. Although the very nature of this crime makes it difficult to get reliable data on the numbers of victims, the Eurostat report earlier this year estimated that between 2010 and 2012 there were over 30 000 victims registered in 28 Member States, 80% of which were women. These figures do not, of course, include the huge numbers of victims who are not identified by authorities as victims of human trafficking.  Although victims are varied, held and controlled for a variety of reasons, we cannot dismiss the significant gender dimension of this crime. The majority, which is 69% of identified victims, were trafficked for sexual exploitation and 95% of that number were women. These numbers show that however good the EU is at tackling this issue, we cannot rest on our laurels. So whilst this crime constitutes a huge abuse of fundamental rights, it continues and is hugely profitable for the traffickers. Our work to protect victims must be vigilant and ongoing. Why, then, do we tolerate the lack of engagement by national authorities? How come, Commissioner, they are not pursued for the figures that they have committed to feed to your officers? It is clear that some countries have achieved a great deal and are cracking down on trafficking, whilst others have still to implement the directive fully and are dragging their feet in recognising this crime. What more evidence do they need to take real action, to which their governments have already committed themselves, in order to rescue the victims and pursue the perpetrators? How much longer do these people, who are controlled and sold as so much baggage, have to wait to get justice?  The evidence shows that human trafficking is an issue that European people want to see tackled with coordinated European action. When asked which forms of violence against women the EU should prioritise, trafficking in human beings comes out very high. The transnational nature of these crimes means that we can only address both the root causes, the rescue and care of victims, and the punishment of perpetrators, if we work together at both source and destination countries.  The Commission must come forward quickly with its post-2016 strategy towards the eradication of human trafficking. We in Parliament look forward to receiving these proposals so that we can work closely with you to crack down on this vile trade. The Commission must also ensure that they are monitoring and implementing the Anti-trafficking Directive in every single Member State. We hope that Parliament’s upcoming work on this will help feed into this work. Trafficking is a crime committed upon the most vulnerable and those victims deserve better protection, but we cannot do that effectively unless we know the state of play in each and every Member State. However, it is important to remember as we debate migration and human smuggling this week that human trafficking is a different, truly vile trade that abuses victims’ human rights. Commissioner, we look forward to working with you in the coming months to tackle this crime.

name: Catherine BEARDER
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, let me start by expressing my thanks to Mrs Bearder for having taken this initiative and submitted this question. First of all, I would like to thank all Members of this House for your constant and keen interest in addressing trafficking in human beings and keeping it high on the European Union’s political agenda. Let us be clear, trafficking in human beings is about the buying and selling of people and their services. Trafficking in human beings is expressly prohibited in the European Union’s Charter of Fundamental Rights and addressing trafficking means upholding fundamental rights.  At the same time, this is a serious form of organised crime as clearly stipulated in the European Union’s Treaties. This deplorable crime would not exist without the huge profits for traffickers and the demand that drives all forms of exploitation. If we want to prevent more victims falling prey to traffickers we must follow the money, both in the legal and the illegal sectors, and we must stop the flows. Trafficking in human beings is now an integral part of the European Agenda on Migration and also of the European Agenda on Security. Indeed, it is a phenomenon with clear links to many policy areas within and outside the European Union.  Eurostat data indicate that for 2010-2012 the 28 Member States registered 30 146 victims. Eighty per cent of the victims were female and 70% of traffickers were male. Sixteen per cent of registered victims were children: girls and boys. Data prove that the most widespread form of exploitation is sexual exploitation – up to 69%, of which women and girls form the vast majority of the victims: 95%. Over 1 000 child victims were trafficked for sexual exploitation. These data clearly demonstrate a strong gender dimension to trafficking in human beings.  Let me be clear, the European Union has recognised that trafficking in human beings is a structural form of violence against women. It seriously inhibits women’s ability to enjoy rights and freedom on an equal basis with men. Gender plays a role at every stage of the trafficking process by increasing vulnerability to trafficking, by fuelling exploitation and influencing the effectiveness of assistance and support.  I am proud to say that the Commission has delivered a great deal and my services continue to deliver very ambitiously on work in this direction. We have a comprehensive legal and policy framework guided by the European Union’s Anti-trafficking Directive and the EU Strategy towards the Eradication of Trafficking in Human Beings 2012-2016.  The Anti-trafficking Directive is human-rights based and victim-centred. It is gender specific and child-sensitive. The deadline for transposition of this Directive expired on 6 April 2013. The Commission, as guardian of the European Union Treaties, initiated procedures without delay and I am pleased to inform you that, to date, 25 Member States have officially informed the Commission that they have fully transposed the Directive at national level. Only two Member States have not notified the Commission yet.  My services are currently analysing the information provided by all Member States and we will not hesitate to take all necessary steps to ensure full transposition and application of the European Union’s law.  The Commission will be submitting the following reports to Parliament and to the Council. First, in early 2016, the first European Union report on the progress made in addressing trafficking in human beings, as per Article 20 of the Directive, will be presented. Member States and civil society, as represented in the European Union’s Civil Society Platform, have submitted information to the EU Anti-Trafficking Coordinator as per Article 20 and the report is being prepared with my services. This report will address the gender dimension and relevant considerations. Secondly, the Commission will submit a unified report under Article 23 of the Directive in 2016. This report will assess the measures taken by Member States to comply with the Anti-trafficking Directive. It will also assess the impact existing national laws criminalising those who use the services of victims of trafficking have on prevention of this crime, accompanied if necessary by appropriate proposals. This report will equally address the gender dimension of trafficking in human beings, including, particularly, the measures to reduce the demand that drives all forms of exploitation.  The European Union’s Anti-trafficking Directive sets forth the legal obligation to reduce the demand that fuels exploitation, including by considering criminalising those who knowingly use the services of victims. The Employers Sanctions Directive already criminalises those who knowingly employ victims of trafficking who are third-country nationals.  My services have commissioned a study on the gender dimensions of trafficking in human beings from a renowned academic institution to examine the gender dimensions of trafficking for the purpose of sexual exploitation and measures to reduce the demand that fuels this exploitation. The study also took into consideration the recommendation of this Parliament in its resolution of 26 February 2014 on sexual exploitation and prostitution and its impact on gender equality. The study will be finalised by the end of this year.  The European Union Anti-trafficking Strategy comes to an end in 2016. As stipulated in the European Agendas for security and for Migration, we will adopt a post-2016 strategy. We will ensure that we consult old stakeholders and ensure that Parliament is kept abreast of developments. The gender dimension must be present in our post-2016 approach. Ladies and gentlemen, it is imperative to continue delivering. We owe this to the victims and, of course, to our societies, to our children and to the future generations.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, trafficking of human beings has become the new slavery of our time. The figures mentioned by the Commissioner are stunning and the human stories are heart-breaking. Commissioner, the EPP Group really welcomes your determination to ensure full compliance with a clear gender perspective. We are all concerned. This is serious organised crime with a cross-border dimension and it should be treated as such by all Member States. The network requires a common European response, with increased police cooperation and increased judiciary cooperation with Europol, Eurojust and Frontex.  It is really time to break the circle of impunity. There should be no hiding place for these criminals in and around Europe. We are calling on you, Commissioner, to present as soon as possible the report on compliance, ensuring a clear gender perspective because, as you said, sexual exploitation is one of the biggest causes of trafficking, as are the protection of victims (girls, women and people with special needs), reducing demand and supply and holding the users responsible.  The majority of victims of trafficking in human beings continue to be women and girls, and now increasingly migrants. Therefore, your new strategy against trafficking should, as you said, have a clear gender perspective: criminalise, strengthening cooperation and tracking funds. The EPP Group continues to be committed to zero tolerance against trafficking of human beings and keeping gender rights on the agenda. No one should be mistreated, abused or exploited on their way to safety in Europe.

name: Mary HONEYBALL
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, I too very much welcome what the Commissioner has said, and the action that is going to be taken, and particularly, Commissioner, that you are intending to make sure that responsibility is on the users of sexual services and not on the victims. As we have all said, trafficking is primarily a gender issue for women. It is so important that we work across Europe to deal with trafficking and that we acknowledge the emerging tactics of the traffickers themselves, who seem always to be one step ahead in this issue of modern slavery.  I also think it is important because I represent London, which is a major destination for traffickers, and as the EU goes into a period where we are preparing for a referendum on EU membership, I believe that the issue of human trafficking will be an important debate in that. It is women and girls who are being trafficked who are some of the most vulnerable people that we have to deal with. This is a European problem, and I believe that it has European solutions.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, I am happy to hear that the Commissioner will be focusing on addressing demand, but what is demand in this area? It is brothel owners and pimps, of course, but it is also men buying sex, and as in all other areas we have to address and target the market.  As the Honeyball report voted here last year concluded, the Nordic model criminalising both the pimps and the buying of sex services has been very effective in addressing the demand. So, what should the Commission be doing in targeting the demand for buying women and girls in the sex industry? So far, not enough has been done. I have read about the piece of research that has been awarded to a group of lobbyists and under-qualified researchers. I am very worried about this, and I think it is not serious. To put it bluntly, we do not need more police officers and border controls in this struggle. We need fewer brothels. So we look forward to a constructive dialogue with you to see what actions we can improve in order to make a difference for women and girls in Europe.

name: Louise BOURS
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President. It is the freedom of movement between countries that is enabling and encouraging this criminality, whether it is perpetrated against men, women, boys or girls. Having no possibility of any checks at any border obviously makes it easier than ever for people to be trafficked across our continent. The UK Government admits that EU free movement rules are helping organised criminal gangs to traffic and move not only illegal goods, but also people.  In a report from 2014 on the balance of competences, they say: ‘free movement within the EU is extensively exploited by organised criminals to bring illicit commodities including drugs, human trafficking victims, illegal immigrants and counterfeit goods to the UK.’ Europol admits that the free movement of people and goods across the EU’s internal borders reduces the chances of detection.  Eurostat asserts that 68% of people trafficked are women, and this is indeed a shocking percentage. However, surely the aim should be to end trafficking altogether – not worry about what gender-specific measures the Commission should take.  Free movement rules make trafficking easier for those who deal in human exploitation. We have to take steps to make this crime logistically impossible, we have to punish the criminals, and we have to punish them in such a way that it acts as an effective deterrent. Only then will this modern—day form of slavery be at an end.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, talking about this important subject, in front of 15 people, is humiliating, it is not humiliating for me, but I believe it is humiliating for the European Parliament that I, we, represent, also because trafficking in human beings in all its forms is an unacceptable horror. It should be so for this hypocritical Europe, I feel so much hypocrisy in here, so false buonismo, that it only serves to hide a bloodstained conscience.  It is undeniable that there is a monetary tragedy involving Africa and the Middle East, just as it is clear that there is a criminal system that speculates on the suffering of so many people. In 2015, 250 000 migrants arrived in Europe, many crossed the Mediterranean, and at least 3 000 people died. We cannot, as we know, welcome millions of people from Africa – I do not want to, because I do not want Africa depopulated and full of ISIS flags – and we cannot even leave these murderers and death traffickers to continue making these death journeys to give hope to men, women and children. We need to create humanitarian corridors there, near where there is war. (The Speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card question. – Ms Bizzotto, would you agree with me that the best common-sense way to deal with this awful crime – which for me as a man is a very emotional thing to hear about – is to firm up border controls so that we can properly check who comes and goes between our countries?

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: blue card answer – Definitely yes. We have to control our borders. Our citizens are asking us to do this, but above all we must prevent people, illegal immigrants, from leaving these lands, we must help the refugees – those who start with the war – but we cannot take in all the refugees. If we are people who have to defend the African people, we must certainly help them there. Europe should do this, it must not depopulate the African continent, it must help the African continent.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: – Ladies and gentlemen, there can be no doubt that trafficking in human beings is a despicable and repugnant phenomenon that is a bomb at the foundations of Europe's merit system. Our non-negotiable attitude must be the constant effort, not to limit the phenomenon but to completely eliminate it. The fact is that, in modern times, it is women who are most affected by these practices, for reasons we all know. Unfortunately, too many cases have come to light, in which there has been tacit tolerance or even complicity of state officials. We must take decisive action to combat the circuits that benefit from trafficking in human beings. We must not come up with another moralistic text, beautiful in words but without a real impact. We must exhaust all means of pressure on the Member States so that there is no tolerance for traffickers. When one offends the values and principles of the Peoples of Europe in such a brutal way, one must face the harshest possible penalties. The Union must commit itself to its people that it will break down this international mafia and break down all obstacles until the network is completely eliminated, whether it concerns trafficking in women or trafficking and exploitation of any human being. Thank you.

name: Anna HEDH
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for The Trafficking In Human Beings Directive adopted in 2011 directly addresses the fact that trafficking in human beings is gender-specific and affects men and women differently. What this means in reality is that women are affected to a much greater extent than men by trafficking in human beings. In particular, with regard to trafficking in human beings for sexual purposes, which is also the most common form of trafficking in human beings, women and girls represent a clear majority. This fact means that women and girls are threatened with being sold in a market where their bodies are considered a commodity that men have the right to buy and exploit. We can no longer turn a blind eye to this kind of oppression and exploitation of people. Indeed, it is now time for the Commission to live up to its promise to evaluate the implementation of the directive adopted in 2011 by the Member States. It is time for the Commission to take a strong approach to this issue, and then a review of the measures taken by the Member States is the least I would ask for. Sex is not a human right. On the other hand, trafficking in human beings is the most heinous crime of our time, which is destroying the lives of women and girls. That is why I am now addressing the Commission and the Member States of the European Union when I say: that is enough!

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: It is urgent and necessary, first of all, to update existing data on trafficking in human beings. The latest available Eurostat data for 2012. However, developments arising from the worsening economic situation of several countries, notably in eu countries, but also the worsening of destabilisation in several African and Middle Eastern countries, lead us to believe that this reality is now the cruelest and the harshest. A reality that is cruel to women. In 2012, 74% of victims of human trafficking were women and 13% of the total were girls and the figures are unequivocal, 66% of trafficked human beings are victims of sexual exploitation and of these, 96% are women. As recognised by the United Nations Convention on the Suppression of Trafficking in Persons and the Exploitation of The Prostitution of Others, there is a direct link between prostitution and trafficking in women. Without the prostitution business, much of the trafficking ceases to exist. It is therefore necessary to criminalise those who live from the sexual exploitation of women.

name: Daniela AIUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the Mediterranean today has the most serious cases of trafficking in human beings, in which women are unfortunately the main victims. In the face of tragedies with which we are familiar and which have been largely exploited by the chronicles, there are who knows how many other undeclared cases occur. There are many migrant women who are, for example, made to embark pregnant and perhaps in the last weeks of pregnancy, and then ensure their birth in Italy, then in Europe. Who knows how many newborns, for example, have so far died or the births and their bodies thrown into the waves in the indifference of all of us.  Europol also points out that there are at least thirty thousand traffickers who are hiding behind immigration throughout Europe and who have made it an illegal economic activity. We're talking about earnings that today outweigh the revenues that come from selling guns and drugs, so it's the most profitable illegal business there is at the moment. What concrete measures do you intend to take to tackle this problem and to combat those who profit from this, on what is in danger of becoming the most serious trafficking in human beings at the same time?

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that this request to the Commission to monitor the action taken by the Member States is very important. I believe that we as a Parliament must act more and more quickly, work more and more decisively, so that the issue of women's right to self-determination as a whole becomes a key axis of any human rights policy.  However, I would like to raise a number of issues here, including in connection with the debate I have heard. I believe that, for example, the issue of education in affectivity and sexuality that we discussed yesterday and will continue in this House is a subject that is strongly linked to what we are talking about. I do not believe that we can at the same time sow terror over affectivity education and call for a gender dimension of the approach on the issue of trafficking. I think we need to name not only that 68% of women are victims, but also name the sex of those who exploit women: they are largely men. I think that we must not make the mistake – I have finished – of considering those of us too simply as bodies, they are women, they are subjects, they are not just bodies.

name: Kostadinka KUNEVA
text: Madam President, I find the subject of today's debate deeply regrettable. I'd like to share a lead of my own. In the report I am preparing on behalf of the FEMM Commission on domestic staff and care workers, I found with sadness that part of this area of work is fuelled by human trafficking and trafficking. Human souls, who without knowing it, consented to becoming another link in the chain of trafficking, following traffickers who promise them good jobs, souls who ended up victims of sexual or labour exploitation. What is the Commission doing to protect these victims, the majority of whom are women? It is once again behind developments, even delaying to assess the measures it has asked the Member States to take in order to tackle the problem of trafficking in human souls. Of course the Member States themselves have a responsibility, because they allow EU policy to be contradictory, and often hypocritical, on the issue of trafficking. Although the European Union wants to appear 'strict' with regard to victims of trafficking, it does, however, implicitly allow the phenomenon with its immigration policy, as it currently applies. By closing legal immigration routes, we are pushing thousands of women into the arms of illegal traffickers. I am sorry to see this, but the Union has contributed to the rise of the phenomenon of trafficking. But it has an opportunity to stem the phenomenon before it is too late, if it immediately evaluates and revises those measures that will enable it to achieve the objectives set out in the 2012-2016 Strategy. But that's not enough. Without coherence between immigration policy, trafficking policy and gender analysis, we will once again witness incidents of incredible horror ...   (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: – Madam President, I recognise and thank the Commissioner for the efforts and actions being taken in the fight against human trafficking. The Anti-trafficking Directive requires better and more efficient application by Member States. We also urgently need to ensure that victims are protected sufficiently to be enabled in exposing the criminals. Our fight is not with the victims but with the traffickers and those who assist them. Our fight also needs to address traffickers online as they continue to expand their activities through the use of the Internet. We also need to address the capacity of those working in areas of administrative government with whom victims of trafficking come into contact so that they too can identify cases of trafficking, and we cannot leave out the need to address businesses which benefit from the victims.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: – It-traffikar tan-nies hi problema gravi u allarmanti. Eluf ta' nies huma mibjugųa lejn jew ǎew l-Ewropa litter sena u mǎiegųla jaǎdmu b'mod indinjituż. Użati gǎat-traffikar illegali ta' organi u gǎall-adozzjonijiet legali. It-traffikar ta' nisa u tfal gǎal skopijiet ta' esplojtazzjoni sesswali mhux biss qed tiżdied iżda saret l-akbar skop gǎat-traffikar tan-nies. Issa kif qed nitkellmu nisa u tfal qed jgǎixu fi skjavitù f'idejn it-traffikanti kif ukoll qed jitilfu ųajjithom b'mod l-aktar indinjituż u kiefer. Traffikar tan-nisa mhux aǎǎabbli. Traffikar tan-nies hu mod modern ta' skjavitù. Hu delitt versus l-umanità u ksur fundamentali tad-drittijiet tal-bniedem. Gǎal dawn ir-raǎunijiet u elf oǎra nixtieq nappella lill-Kummissjoni u lill-Membri Stati biex ikunu sodi fuq dan id-delitt. Iridu jieųdu inkunsiderazzjoni li hemm problema ta' gender f'dan kollu u l-akbar vittmi huma n-nisa u t-tfal. Dan qatt m'gǎandu jkun aǎǎaabbli.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Thank you, Madam President. Trafficking in and trafficking in human beings is a crime and as such must be punished. The problem has now taken on an important dimension due to migration and refugee flows. Commissioner, we must take seriously the issue of slave trade, which mainly operate in Turkey. It is not possible that one million refugees have been transferred from Syria to the coast of Asia Minor, opposite the Greek islands, so on their own. This has never happened before.  In the summer I went to Kuşadası because I really wanted to see what was going on. While across Samos there were thousands of refugees on the turkish side, there was not a single one on the Turkish side, because there is a lot of organised traffic, because they are providing them with life jackets and boats, because they have them in organised camps. A mission of an investigative delegation should be organised ... (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Madam President, trafficking in human beings is certainly the biggest human rights violation we witness practically every day. Trafficking in human beings, especially the fact that women are the ones most hurt in all of this, shows how much maliciousness and hypocrisy exists in all those who tolerate such a situation. Today we talked about the application of European regulations, the other day about the education of girls, and now we are talking practically about both. Unfortunately, member states have not fully complied with the rules of the European Union. In fact, some Member States have not yet implemented these rules at all. That is why, to put it in the end, I am committed to the Scandinavian model of solving this problem because I believe that in practice it has proven to be the best way to solve the problem.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: –  Madam President, we are discussing an age-old problem: slavery and sexual exploitation. In a world where desperate people are migrating in vast numbers, the environment is perfect for people-traffickers to thrive. We have an obligation to deal with this. We need tough border checks. We need heavy punishment for the evil, criminal traffickers. We need cooperation between sovereign nation states to fight this international crime.  The truth is, the rule of law – and most particularly international law – is better enforced with effective border control. We have an obligation to these people – to these ladies and children who have been trafficked in this evil manner – to make sure that we do everything we can to safeguard their freedom, and give them a better future.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I agree, of course, that the appalling treatment of women, as my colleagues and my colleagues have shown here, must be condemned. Whether it's trafficking in women, whether it's prostitution, modern-day sergoing, internet abuse, smuggling networks, of course, and so on. On the one hand, however, some of my colleagues are also talking about the need for European solidarity precisely in the treatment of refugees, and I was surprised that I pulled their vote this morning on mrs Keller's report. I was surprised they just didn't support her. Yes, even some of my colleagues in my faction, who are talking about the need for European solidarity, did not support it. I find it a great expression of hypocrisy. I do not understand how anyone can exhort European solidarity and then, even as a woman, not support what I think is necessary, and that is to help the countries affected by this refugee wave. I really find that reprehensible.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Madam President, I think we have to recognise that, in fact, we do not know the figures on this trafficking in human beings and, as the rapporteur said, I believe that this figure is much higher than the records we have, because the victims are afraid to speak, and here we must act, Commissioner, and this is my expectation: to see how we are not only monitoring the situation in the Member States , but we find solutions to protect the victims. It clearly requires demanding monitoring, but this is not enough, as I said. If we don't find solutions, let's go to the cause. Strong measures are needed, Commissioner, harsh punishments for those who facilitate and trafficking in human beings. The crime is, in my view, equal to murder. Therefore, new measures must be taken to eliminate this form of violence. We are ashamed to return to slavery by exploiting women in particular. Perhaps you can tell us, however, Commissioner, which are the two states that have not made notifications.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: – Yes, trafficking in human beings constitutes a gross violation of fundamental rights and is a serious form of organised crime. However, we should pay particular attention to its new forms. These include surrogacy. At first, female eggs were traded, today women offer directly their uterus. These are predominantly women from third countries and women socially disadvantaged. It is necessary to point out this modern form of abuse and slavery under the guise of the so-called right to a child. Surrogacy has become a big business, and that has to be said as a clear no. And the trade in organs of aborted children is totally unacceptable. The recently revealed scandalous practices of the International Organization of Planned Parenthood must be properly investigated. In the meantime, I am calling for the suspension of any financial support to this federation by us. After all, the European Union, as a guardian of values and a defender of human rights, cannot turn a blind eye to such a crime. In a developed and civilised Europe, violations of fundamental human rights have no place.

name: Soraya POST
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for If I were a victim of traffickers, it would mean that those who buy sexual services rape me every time. So I'm not just a regular victim. There are several criminal activities going on. What is happening, it is not happening in a vacuum, but it is happening in our societies, which have structures that allow this.  I welcome the Commission's proposals and measures, but we also need to see how this is being complied with in the Member States. Furthermore, it cannot be that if I am raped over and over again, and choose to report it, only get protection during the criminal investigation period, which means that I may not dare to report because then I will be referred back to the same situation. So there must be permanent residence permits in order to avoid this rape slavery.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Madam President, trafficking in human beings is a severe violation of fundamental rights and a serious form of organised crime that we must fight with all means at our disposal. Women, men, girls and boys who are trafficked in different circumstances require gender-specific assistance and support. We must, therefore, incorporate a clear gender perspective and give priority to the rights of victims of human trafficking and their specific needs. Our human rights-based approach must focus on the victims of trafficking and must discourage demand for all forms of human trafficking, including for the purposes of sexual exploitation, which is the most common form of exploitation. The action plan is designed to improve the capacity of the relevant stakeholders to prevent human trafficking. In order to do so, the Member States must respect the deadlines for transposition and compliance, and the Commission should assess, as soon as possible, the adequacy of measures implemented by Member States.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, let me start with something more general. I see that some honourable Members use every opportunity to attack what constitutes a great – and maybe the greatest – achievement of the European Union: freedom of movement in a Europe without internal borders. I will repeat that Schengen is a part of the solution: it is not the problem, Schengen is not the problem. By making full use of Schengen rules we can be more efficient in checking and controlling our borders. Let me now focus on the issue before us. Colleagues, thank you very much for this debate. It was short but very substantial. We obviously share the same view. The gender question in human trafficking needs to be fully taken into account. Let me repeat it very clearly: trafficking is a crime against human rights as expressed in the European Union’s Charter of Fundamental Rights. There are still many victims of trafficking, and that is unacceptable. Ms Björk, as you well know, the criminalisation of users of services who knowingly use victims of trafficking is considered as a measure to reduce demand in the Anti-trafficking Directive. The Directive urges Member States to consider measures for criminalising the use of services with the knowledge that the person is a victim of trafficking. This means that the Directive does not oblige the Member States to criminalise such users of services: it simply obliges them to consider doing so, and some do. However, as I said, we are working on ways to reduce demand. The European Union has already taken strong action. We need to assess our achievements, as we are coming to the end of the Union’s anti-trafficking strategy. I am fully committed to an exchange with Members on this topic, with a view to adopting the new strategy for next year.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. We have repeatedly spoken out against trafficking in human beings as a serious violation of fundamental rights. Unfortunately, the recent Eurostat figures give us a truly dramatic reality: 68% of women, 17% men, 12% girls and 3% boys are victims of trafficking in Europe. It is clear that our efforts are still insufficient, and further assistance and support measures are needed to curb or slow down this phenomenon, complementing gender specificity, as set out in Directive 2011/36/EU.  We therefore call on the Commission to continue to monitor the progress made in implementing this directive in the Member States, for example through the EU strategy for the eradication of trafficking in human beings, which clearly identifies violence against women and gender inequalities as one of the underlying causes of trafficking. But let us go further: we ask that we indicate what concrete measures it intends to take to develop knowledge on the gender dimension of trafficking in human beings and to take stringent measures to condemn delays in the transposition and compliance by Member States of this directive. The current strategy expires in 2016, we can no longer wait!

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Trafficking in human beings is a shameful phenomenon and, regardless of country, continent, religion or culture, it must not only be banned, but also effectively combated. This phenomenon is particularly appalling when it affects minors as well as women. The efforts made by the Member States and the European Union do not have the expected effect of completely eliminating this shameful practice in Europe. I therefore expect the European Commission to assess the implementation by the Member States of Directive 2011/36/EU on preventing and combating trafficking in human beings and the protection of victims, as well as to draw conclusions from the functioning and implementation of the European Union strategy to eradicate trafficking in human beings for the period 2012-2016.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on Russia, in particular the case of Eston Kohver, Oleg Sentsov and Olexandr Kolchenko.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: Author.  – Many of us are wearing a yellow ribbon today to show that we want to see Estonian officer Eston Kohver at home in Estonia as soon as possible. Kidnapping a person from the territory of the neighbouring country, detaining him in breach of international law and fundamental rights and condemning him to an unreasonable prison sentence is unacceptable.  The actions of the Russian authorities are not acceptable. Yet this is becoming more and more daily practice. For example, at least 10 Ukrainian prisoners are being held illegally in Russia. Some were kidnapped, like Nadia Savchenko. Sometimes, as in the case of film director Oleg Sentsov, they face a long prison sentence in bad conditions.  The Kremlin needs to know that we won't ever forget any name. The actions of the Russian authorities are symptomatic of the general deterioration of the human rights situation in Putin's Russia. As far as I am concerned, those responsible for the illegal imprisonment of these people and for violating their rights may be included on the sanctions list.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it seems clear to me that human rights violations against Kohver, Sentsov or Kolchenko must be emphasised and condemned by this Parliament. What I note, however, is that the instrument of discussion on human rights violations is being used in a way that is not exactly efficient, not exactly appropriate; Often and willingly, there is a part of this Parliament that uses it only to make targeted political attacks on certain states rather than others.  This, unfortunately, is what we have noticed this year, apart from the fact that it is often and willingly not possible to follow up the votes on these resolutions, so, in short, what I wonder is whether we can deal with all violations against any state with the same weight and measure and not make continuous resolutions against Russia. , to which nothing follows.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: author. – Mr President, the cases we are debating today can be assessed as a clear and arbitrary violation of international law, and also of elementary standards of justice, by the Russian Federation.  Three weeks ago the Estonian and EU citizen, Eston Kohver, having been abducted last year from EU territory, was sentenced by the Russian courts to 15 years imprisonment. The Ukrainians Nadya Savchenko, Oleg Sentsov, Olexandr Kolchenko and others have been sentenced and kept in prison for opposing the illegal annexation of Ukrainian territory by the Russian authorities. We can see all of them, actually, as political hostages.  I am very much encouraged by the strong cross-party support in Parliament, which is expressed in the form of these yellow ribbons showing solidarity that we are wearing. The message from Parliament to the Russian authorities is very clear and strong – free all of these people immediately and unconditionally.  We call on the Council to establish an EU-wide blacklist of Russian officials responsible for abducting and jailing EU citizen Mr Kohver and these Ukrainian citizens.

name: Merja KYLLÖNEN
text: Author. – Mr President, I come from a country whose own and common European interest has a strong will to find a solution, so that we can also cooperate with Russia in the future. The frozen situation must be resolved so that, even in the longer term, we can cooperate more strongly on human rights issues and issues relating to international law. We cannot close our eyes or turn our backs on these people, such as Eston Kohver, the Epic police officer who was abducted while on duty. Every country simply has to abide by human rights conventions and international law!

name: Kaja KALLAS
text: Author. – In May 2010, a meeting took place in Rostov between representatives of the European Union and Russia, where Russia promised to promote the rule of law on its territory. Five years later, there are several Ukrainian citizens in the same Rostov prison. But Russia has imprisoned not only Ukrainian citizens, but also Eston Kohveri, a Citizen of the European Union who has been in a Russian prison for more than a year.  The violations of the abovementioned international law clearly show that Russia does not keep its promises to its partners. It is our duty to show that this behaviour is not acceptable and will be a bad thing for Europe. Kohver, Sentsov and Kolchenko are not criminals and terrorists, but victims of an unjust and politicized trial.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Author. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the principle of national jurisdiction requires respect for the sovereignty of a State within its borders, and the principle of responsibility to protect requires the State to protect its own citizens and other states to do so, where the sovereign state is unable to do so or does not intend to do so.
