On the basis of this legally envisaged idea of international solidarity, we are now calling on the Russian Government, through this resolution, to release two Ukrainian and one Estonian citizens detained following summary trials that have not complied with the standards of procedural law, including the refusal of a response to the allegations of torture levelled at the officers who carried out the interrogations. In the Kohverla Russia case, she is accused, among other things, of crossing the Estonian border and kidnapping a serving officer. The Kolchenko and Sentsov trials, on the other hand, took place in Crimea, a territory annexed unilaterally by Russia and not recognised by the international community. This would result in territorial incompetence. The accused civilians have also been tried by military courts with a clear lack of competence.  Hence the European Parliament calls for respect for the basic principles of international law and the release of persons who are illegally detained.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, in the context of the cases we are referring to today, we are only constantly confirming the true nature of the current Russian regime. I therefore thank High Representative Mogherini for her clear statement on Eston Kohver. Incredibly, in 2015 we saw an EU citizen abducted from EU territory and sentenced to 15 years by a Member State of the Council of Europe and the ISCE in a court procedure that does not meet the essential requirements of a fair trial. Unfortunately, this is a reality confirmed by other cases of Nadi Savchenko, Oleg Sencov, Alexander Kolchenko and many others.  I am therefore glad that sanctions against Russia have been extended, although I am sorry that they are falling on ordinary Russian citizens – but we are also fighting for their human rights here.

name: Marju LAURISTIN
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I want to draw your attention to the fact that Eston Kohver is not just a citizen of the EU, but an EU police officer whose work is to fight against smuggling and trafficking on the EU Schengen border. He was abducted, arrested and convicted for this work. It is very important to put that into context. We have to understand that this deliberate provocation on the part of Russia concerns the whole system of the rule of law in Europe and the EU. There are other similar cases as well. We want relations between the EU and Russia to continue on the basis of international law and human rights. We have to insist on that in all such cases. However, the case of Eston Kohver is a very special one. It is true that all the Ukrainian cases are along the same lines, but I just want to stress that in this instance we can see how Russia is deliberately provoking the EU.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Dear! I don't have a yellow ribbon plugged in. This is not the case, because I want to include it now as an expression of my solidarity, my people, the Polish people, for our Estonian neighbour. American writer Ernest Hemingway said, "don't ask who the bell beats, it beats you." And this is precisely the case of our neighbours, who are imprisoned by the Russians. I have been in the European Parliament for eleven years. Which is the debate on human rights violations in Russia? Another, next and next. We must show very clearly that Russia is not complying with certain European standards, European values. And it must not be the case that economic considerations, business considerations determine our policy towards Russia. Let us remember that Europe is strong in the values of human rights that we defend, and let us defend them in this situation too.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I wonder which of us would accept a situation in which his or her countrymen were being abducted from their own territory. These are, essentially, gangster methods. This has nothing to do with a society which respects human rights. This requires not only condemnation and strong words, but concrete action.  That is why I propose, dear colleagues, that we approve today an amendment which is in line with my previous amendment and the amendment that has been supported by many, in which we will call for concrete steps and concrete action against those people who are responsible. We cannot just have a resolution with strong political language. We really need to show that there will be repercussions if something like this happens again. It does not take that much, but we need to raise a few hands today to send a clear message and really counter these activities, which are completely unacceptable.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: On behalf of the Group of the European People's Party (Verts/ALE). – Mr President, in the cases of Kohver, Sentsov and Kolchenko, international law has all been blatantly violated in a number of ways. Borders have been violated, the judiciary has been grossly used for political repression. With regard to the proposal for personal sanctions, I would be inclined to support them in this situation. In fact, we must have concrete ways of addressing such very flagrant violations of human rights when we are able to identify individually those who have participated in this activity.  I would like to draw your attention to the fact that in a moment we will be discussing Azerbaijan and there will be very blatant abuse of the judiciary in Azerbaijan for political repression. Remember then also that, as Mr Corrao has just mentioned, we must condemn all serious violations of human rights.  I have heard that the People's Party wants to postpone the vote on the resolution on Azerbaijan. I don't think that's reasonable. We must also condemn the serious violations of human rights in Azerbaijan.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: – Mr President, the Russian commando has kidnapped Eston Kohver from the Estonian border territory. Kohver is a citizen of Estonia. And not only that, ladies and gentlemen, the Russian commando has kidnapped a citizen of the European Union, our fellow citizen, from the territory of the European Union. And not only that, dear colleagues, from the territory of a NATO member, a RUSSIAN commando was abducted to Russia by an agent of the secret service of a NATO member. Eston Kohver was charged with espionage earlier this year and sentenced to 15 years in prison by a Russian court in Pskov. Estonian media are speculating that the kidnapping was orchestrated by Russia's Federal Security Service so that kohver could be traded for Alexei Dresser, a former Estonian intelligence officer who worked for the FSB. Dresser was sentenced to 16 years in Estonia for treason. Apparently, it looks like a duel between two secret services. In fact, we are following another hybrid war fought by the Russian Federation against Estonia and the entire European Union. They are not afraid to use bandit methods such as kidnapping and lying.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, I would like to express the strongest solidarity with Eston Kohver, Oleg Sentsov and Olexandr Kolchenko, whose detention clearly represents a violation of international law as they have been deprived of the right to a fair trial. I call for their immediate release and safe return home. I am especially worried about the fact that there is evidence that Oleg Sentsov and Olexandr Kolchenko have been tortured during their detention. The case against the Ukrainian film-maker seems to be clearly trumped up to gain a conviction and to be a politically inspired action against two Ukrainian activists determined to exercise their legitimate right to protest against Russia’s illegal occupation of Crimea. Russia should release all illegally detained Ukrainian citizens and comply with the means to agreement (international law) and respect the protection and promotion of human rights, fundamental freedoms and the rule of law: all concepts which it has committed to upholding in various international treaties and agreements. Russia has to stop its provocations and return to the international community.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by At present, our focus is primarily on the issue of refugees and, unfortunately, in this context, russia is increasingly being seen as an ally to help resolve the Middle East crisis. President Juncker did not say anything yesterday about the Union's relations with Russia or the human rights situation in Russia. He didn't talk much about Ukraine. Meanwhile, the fate of Eton Kohver, Oleg Seńcow and Alexander Kolchenko shows that Russia disregards international law, that it is guided by the principle of revenge, that it disregards the sovereignty of other countries, that it has human rights for nothing. Kohver is an Estonian citizen, Seńcov and Kolchenko are Ukrainian citizens – all contrary to international law have been transported to Russian territory – kidnapped and tried under Russian law. They were refused contact with consuls. All three were sentenced to many years in prison. We cannot tolerate this kind of behaviour and must condemn it consistently and, moreover, we must also consider concrete steps to prevent this kind of behaviour.

name: Urmas PAET
text: - Thank you. Russia has been abducting for over a year the life of Eston Kohver, an Estonian policeman, who he abducted from Estonian territory on 5 September last year. On the same day that the NATO summit was held in Wales. Eston Kohveri's abduction has been followed by a farce in Russian courts, which have now been sentenced to 15 years in prison with strict regimes. Russia has violated both international law and Kohver's human rights by kidnapping Eston Kohveri. I call on all my colleagues, all the Member States, the European Commission, the European political parties, in their dealings with Russia, to demand the immediate release of Eston Kohver, a citizen of the European Union, so that he can return home to his family, where he is also expecting four young children, after the time he has already lost. Behind the names of both Kohver and Shevchenko, Sentsov and Kolchenko are specific people whose lives are destroyed by the Russian political game.  I also call for support for the amendments to today's resolution, so that the crime is nevertheless followed by an unavoidable consequence and punishment. Thank you.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Dear! I am listening to this debate and I see that we are all in agreement on the facts. This is an extreme audacity on the part of Russia – the kidnapping of a European Union citizen, or a conviction in the farcical trial of Mr Kolchenko and Mr Sencow. Yes, ladies and gentlemen, this is extreme brazenness. We call, and rightly so, only that the language of appeals is understandable to the societies of the European Union, but it is not understood in Russia, which is why I call not only on the European Commission, but above all on the States of the European Union to retaliate. What is it that we will not find a single Russian spy on the territory of the European Union? Yes, we can find him, we can arrest him, and we have to do it because Russia only understands the language he speaks.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: – Once again, we are confronted, ladies and gentlemen, with an authoritarian and Putinist Russia, who, despite resounding words and signatures on international treaties, behaves like a beast. And we're dealing with three people who have been abducted from their homes and imprisoned in Russia today, but if we're not serious, we're going to have to deal with the next people in the next six months, and so on.  That is why I think that the addition of the ECR Group improved our resolution so that the Russian authorities and judges involved can feel the sword of european Union sanctions. And we can say that the judges are not guilty, they only complied with the order, but I recall that in Nuremberg we found that the judges were also guilty, which is when the order came from Adolf Hitler himself. And finally, twenty seconds later, when my grandfather was taken away from his home by the Russian authorities and sentenced to 25 years in prison by a British spy, after Khrushchev had some judge come and apologize, say that sorry, man, we took you, we held you captive, and we didn't really have a basis. Then why did you plead guilty? And he said that if you had beaten and tortured me for forty more days, I would have declared myself emperor of China. So freedom for the three of us!

name: Indrek TARAND
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I am here on behalf and in the name of the High Representative Mrs Mogherini. Around 70 organisations are currently on this so-called ‘foreign agents register’ which carries many negative consequences. Some of those organisations have been forced to close down. The recent law on undesirable foreign and international organisations contributes further to the deterioration of an already difficult environment for civil society organisations.  It is yet another obstacle to the development of a free, strong and well- functioning civil society in Russia. In this repressive climate, members of civil society who do not agree with the authorities are identified as enemies of the State. This is a clear encroachment on fundamental rights.  To name just three recent cases: in June the Grozny offices of the Committee Against Torture were destroyed during a staged demonstration. The police stood by without offering protection; in July, members of the GOLOS electoral observation organisation were harassed by the authorities; in the run up to local and regional elections on 13 September 2015, frequent irregularities in the registration of opposition parties have occurred.  Furthermore, the rights of LGBTI persons are being violated and the Russian authorities have failed to prevent and prosecute homophobic violence which is tolerated under this so-called law on non-traditional sexual relations among minors. Today’s debate focuses on a number of individual cases all involving non-Russian citizens: the Estonian officer Kohver, who was abducted in September 2014 at gunpoint from the Estonian side of the border with Russia. His right to a fair trial was not respected, and he was sentenced to 15 years in prison in August 2015. The Ukrainian military pilot Nadya Savchenko, who was abducted from eastern Ukraine, sent to Russia and charged with trespassing and complicity in the murder of two Russian generals. Her trial resumes next week.  The Ukrainian activists Sentsov and Kolchenko: Sentsov, a film director, was arrested in May 2014 in Crimea and transferred to Moscow for alleged association with terrorist acts in Crimea. He was sentenced in August 2015 to 20 years in prison. At the same trial, Olexandr Kolchenko, a Ukraine activist arrested in connection with Sentsov, was sentenced to ten years in prison. These are flagrant breaches of international law and elementary standards of justice. The European Union has called, and will continue to call, for their immediate release as well as for the unconditional release of all Ukrainian citizens held illegally in Russia. In this respect, I recall this House’s resolution of 30 April this year.  The Russian authorities should live up to their international and European obligations in the field of human rights. The Russian authorities must put an end to the climate of suspicion, hatred and intolerance of diversity of opinion prevalent in Russia today. We must stand behind those who protect human rights in Russia. We will speak out every time clear breaches of human rights occur. We will continue to raise our concerns in international fora: the United Nations, the Council of Europe and the OSCE. We will continue to use our financial instruments to support civil society and we will attend the court trials of human rights’ defenders and opposition figures.  We will do all this because we are committed to supporting human rights and the development of civil society in Russia and lastly, but very importantly, we will continue to discuss those issues directly with the authorities at all levels.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place at the end of the debate. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Algirdas SAUDARGAS
text: Writing. – The unprecedented number of serious violations of human rights and the rule of law in Russia only confirms the alarming fact of an entrenched undemocratic regime. These actions by Russia are directed not only against Russia itself, but also against citizens of other countries. Examples of this behaviour can be seen in the sentences handed down at the end of August against Ukrainian director Oleg Sencov and his colleague Alexander Kolchenko. It should be noted that the case of these persons is obviously political. During the trial, no real evidence of the involvement of these persons in criminal offences was provided, despite the fact that Mr Sencov was sentenced to 20 years and Mr Kolchenko was sentenced to 10 years in prison. This political persecution was condemned by many famous artists around the world in an open letter to Vladimir Putin. The EU and the US have also called for the release of the defendants. The abduction of Estonian security officer Eston Kohver at the border with Russia and the 15-year prison sentence imposed in August on the 15-year prison sentence are an even greater security challenge for the EU. Not only the accusations against him, but also the fact of his detention itself took place unlawfully, in violation of the principle of territorial integrity of Estonia. This requires a special focus on the security problem of eastern members. These and other cases indicate that the situation in Russia is deteriorating, so any debate on normalising relations with Russia, lifting sanctions against it and similar issues must take place in the light of the cases set out above.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on Angola.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: Author. – On April 16, Mount Sumi in Angola turned red with blood. Hundreds of people are believed to have been killed in the arrest of a popular cult leader. The testimonies are shocking. The utter absence of this drama in the Western media suggests that president Dos Santos' regime wants to make events forget. This is not surprising either, because the persecution of human rights defenders in Angola is worrying. Criticism of the president equates to sabotage and terrorism. The possession of a computer is suspicious, reading books is suspicious. I call on Angola to respect the constitutional rights of the imprisoned activists, to cancel the conviction of writer Rafael Marques and to allow an independent investigation into the massacre on Mount Sumi. And, Commissioner, the EU must also look at itself. It seems as if we are facing the limits of the EU approach in the region. Or is it normal for a president who has been in power for 35 years to silence the opposition and lead a reign of terror?

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: Author. I think I can copy a large part of Mr Demesmaeker's words. Whether Mr. Dos Santos is in power for 35 or 36 years, we are dealing here with a totally corrupted country that makes its money from oil, where we have actually looked away for the last few years precisely because of that oil. Now prices have fallen, the country's budget has halved and the misery is growing.  Indeed, the regime feels threatened by people reading a book. The regime is getting grimmer. The news is that Rafael Marques tried to leave the country yesterday, was arrested at luanda airport, released, but is not free to leave the country. My question to the European Commission is: can we monitor the well-being of Rafael Marques in Luanda? Finally, we must help organise an independent investigation into the Huambo massacre in April.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: author. – Mr President, after decades of conflict and instability, Angola continues to face the major challenges of weak governance, human rights abuses and widespread corruption. We are worried by the deteriorating situation when it comes to respect for human rights: persecution of political opponents and journalists is becoming a rule in this country full of contrast, a country which is on the one hand incredibly rich in oil and diamonds, and on the other hand has one of the highest rates of child mortality in the world.  It is the corrupt elites who are depriving the people of Angola of their basic human rights – access to healthcare, food and education – by stealing public money intended for basic social services.  We are seriously concerned about the possible mismanagement of EU development funds by the local authorities, and in this regard we are asking the Commission to review the national indicative programme under the 11th EDF and to ensure that good governance, respect for human rights and the fight against corruption are the main financing priorities for this fabulously rich country, which suffers also from a fabulously corrupt elite.

name: Javier NART
text: Author. – Mr President, the Resolution has for me an essential paragraph, which is paragraph 15, in which it calls on the Member States to have extreme vigilance on the issue of money laundering. We can talk about the brutal anecdote of murder, death and repression, but the category is corruption. And corruption is vehiculated through countries in the European Union that act as washing machines for the rotten rotten Angolan corrupt oligarchy that gravitates on the population. This is the essential point. The conviction is correct. The whole resolution seems to me to be supported, but above all paragraph 15 is decisive.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Author. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, when we talk about Angola, ladies and gentlemen, we are talking about a very strange country, a country where more than 60% of the population lives below the poverty line, where there are some of the worst bins in the world, but which at the same time has a capital like Rwanda, which is once again the trading centre of Africa, and is also the second largest oil producer on the African continent. , is a growing country.  My fellow Members have already mentioned this, the focal point of this resolution revolves around the very high level of corruption, I believe that Angola is in the world's top ten for corruption, it has a government that has been in office for 36 years and jealously guards all state affairs; In fact, those who approach, those who want to put their beaks on these affairs, especially oil and diamond, end up burning and therefore there are these violations of human rights that we are talking about. It is clear that we must be much more careful and much stronger and ensure that our companies, which go to launder money in that country, are properly controlled.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: Author. – Mr President, repression, arbitrary detention, attacks on freedom of expression, violation of freedom of association - in a country that enshrines in its Constitution the right to peaceful demonstration, the right of association, as well as freedom of expression - corruption, unclear business, exhaustion and misappropriation of natural resources by the ruling elite - in a country that has made commitments to fight the money laundering system and corruption - , the way he has treated the activists and, in particular, Rafael Marques, the author of blood diamonds, who just yesterday saw issued an international arrest warrant, well, all this makes the Angolan regime an authoritarian regime. But it's more than that! At the moment when there are deaths and there is a record of these deaths we are already talking about a totalitarian regime.  In this sense, the agreements between the European Union and Angola must be respected. The Commitment of the Angolan Government under the Cotonou Agreement must be respected. Democracy and human rights are to be respected and taken seriously, here and anywhere in the world, and we cannot accept their accomplices either.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Angola has in the past been at the centre of controversy over diamond mining. In 1998, the United Nations imposed sanctions on those countries which had purchased rough diamonds not accompanied by a certificate of origin attesting to the correct extraction procedure, in order to safeguard the safety of miners. Rafael Marques de Morais was convicted of denouncing this already sadly known reality, that is, for a crime of opinion, in clear violation of the right to freedom of thought.  The Angolan Government is using the courts of justice to gag human rights activists in the country. In the de Morais case, international observers who attended the trial behind closed doors denounced serious violations of the principle of fair trial. It is therefore important for the European Union to demand monitoring of diamond mining activities so that it takes place in the utmost transparency and in compliance with safety standards, while at the same time protecting activists who, in exercising their freedom of expression, report serious violations of human rights.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Angola is a country with significant natural wealth and great potential, but after three decades of bad rule by President dos Santos, it is a place where human rights are violated, people are intimidated, and corruption and impunity of power are the order of the day. After winning the parliamentary elections of the People's Liberation Movement of Anga in 2012, the repression of journalists and social activists intensified, as evidenced by the subsequent trials and arrests of Arão Buli Tempa, José Marcos Mavunga and Rafael Marques. It must be emphasised that both the veracity of the accusations and the right to a fair trial in this country are fiction. Power brutally suppresses peaceful anti-government protests, makes arrests, tortures prisons. These abuses by the government of dos Santos should be strongly condemned and the authorities should be called upon to respect the Cotonou Agreement, as well as to ratify the implementation of the four human rights treaties signed by Angola in September 2013, including the Convention against Torture.

name: Ana GOMES
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Since 2002 this Parliament has not ruled on human rights in Angola. This resolution recognizes the growing deterioration of human rights and democracy in this country, with emphasis on four worrying developments this past year: the judicial persecution of journalist Rafael Marques, the arrest and imminent conviction of activist Marques Mavungo in Cabinda, the massacre of a high but undetermined number of people in Huambo in April, and the arrest of 15+1 young activists , in June, which stands, with brutal repression on their families prevented even from speaking out.  We call for the immediate and unconditional release of all human rights defenders, including Marques Mavungo and the 15+1 activists, and that all charges against them be dropped. We support the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights calling for an independent international investigation into the massacre on Mount Sumi. We call for respect for freedom of expression, demonstration and the press, which have been grossly and systematically violated in Angola.  I was last July in Angola and I was able to observe how the economic crisis, because of the fall in the price of oil and rampant corruption, increases social tensions, protests and how the Angolan people are increasingly outraged at the plundering of state resources by the elite around the President, who remains unstoppable.  It is therefore necessary that the European Union does not continue to turn a blind eye to the blatant corrupt practices in Angola. European regulators need to monitor compliance with due diligence and risk analysis duties for large-scale investments of Angolan kleptocracy in European countries, namely mine, Portugal.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I join my colleagues in clearly condemning the current totalitarian regime in Angola. I remember, as an MP for the Czech Republic, in the late 1970s and 1980s, President Santos went to communist Czechoslovakia and hugged the then communist leaders of totalitarian power in Czechoslovakia. Fortunately, communism is no longer in Central and Eastern Europe, but, as has already been said, the absurd situation in Angola remains. President Santos is still in power. His regime is getting worse and worse, and as is typical, he is suppressing human rights defenders, suppressing journalists who point to corruption, crimes, murder and abuse of innocent people.  Also mentioned here was the book "Blood Diamonds", which just described how diamonds are mined and how the natives and people who participate in these activities are repressed there.  This regime must be condemned and the European Commission and all the Institutions of the European Union and the Member States should be called upon to stop cooperating with Angola and to show in all negotiations that we condemn the Angolan regime.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I also want to condemn, of course, a regime that is undoubtedly undemocratic, corrupt and which is Angolan. However, I would like to take the consideration I would like to make here in a slightly different direction. I think these debates, which are urgent debates on human rights violations, should also result in the design of a mechanism so that the European Union can exercise decisions, judgments of international tribunals, if their decisions are recognised by those States concerned. In other words, so that the European Union can better and more effectively enforce human rights where they are violated, if an international authority has already concluded that there are indeed violations.  This also applies to mr. Kohver's previous case. Simply, if the decisions of the Strasbourg Tribunal are international, the European Commission and the European Union and the EU institutions could propose solutions for their enforcement. I think that we should also encourage the Member States to do so.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, I am deeply concerned about the broader deterioration in the environment for freedom of expression in Angola, including the increased use of criminal defamation lawsuits against journalists and routine police abuse. The excessive use of force by the police is absolutely unacceptable, as is the use of violence and arbitrary arrests to stop peaceful anti—government protests and other gatherings. From beating women to unleashing dogs on protesters, it seems that in Angola the corrupt ruling elite hates its own people. The Angolan authorities must immediately put an end to these cases of arbitrary arrest, illegal detention and torture by the police and security forces, and impartial investigations must be carried out of all allegations of human rights violations by police and security forces so that the perpetrators are brought to justice.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: – Mr President, Angola has never been a Western-style democracy, being effectively a one-party MPLA-dominated state, but things have improved with the new Constitution of 2010 and there has been relative political stability after the ceasefire with UNITA in 2002.  But more recently, President Santos’ government has become more intolerant of press freedom by arresting human rights defenders and journalists such as Marcos Mavungo. There are serious allegations of torture and a climate of police repression. Corruption is unfortunately endemic in that country with its vast oil and mineral wealth, with the wealth concentrated in the hands of a very small urban political elite.  Angola has many EU – mainly Portuguese – citizens working there and is a signatory to the Cotonou Agreement which commits it to a high standard of fundamental civil and political rights, and it does need now more transparency in its extractive industries. There is an ongoing military campaign in Cabinda, which is seeking self-determination as a territory, but this must not be an excuse for the crackdown now by the authorities which we are currently witnessing in that vast country.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the case of Angola is a typical case, unfortunately, of Africa: on the one hand, we have poverty, drought, fires, soil destruction, a lack of agricultural diversification, alcoholism and a huge need for development projects, and on the other, a rate of corruption that really reaches very high peaks. Moreover, it must be said that from this point of view the government, instead of taking initiatives to reduce it, is in fact very focused on completely crushing human rights defenders and those who are somehow trying to push for a different Angola and a different future.  For our part, there is perhaps too much lightness towards regimes of this kind. I would remind you that Angola is also one of the signatories to the Cotonou Agreement – as other Members have also said – perhaps we should also remember that if we do not beat the rate of conditionality, we will be less credible when we make fine statements in this House and therefore the Commission is expected to take concrete measures against the Angolan Government as well.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, aontaím leis na cainteoirí atá ag cáineadh cad atá ag tarlú le hAngóla, go háirithe le déanaí. Is trua seo. Mar a dúradh, is tír shaibhir í Angóla; ar a laghad tá acmhainní saibhre aici ach tá an saibhreas seo ag dul go dtí an mionlach, agus 60% de na daoine ag maireachtaint i mbochtanas.  Dá bhrí sin, caithfimid gach brú is féidir linn a chur ar údaráis Angóla saoirse a thabhairt do na daoine, i.e. saoirse an phreasa, saoirse reiligiúin agus saoirse cruinnithe a bheith acu, agus deireadh a chur go háirithe le foréigean de gach saghas agus le pionós corpartha i gcoinne a ndaoine féin.  Dá bhrí sin, aontaím leis an tuarascáil seo agus tá súil agam gur féidir linn rud éigin a dhéanamh chun feabhas a chur ar an tír seo ar mhaithe leis na saoránaigh féin.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, despite the official end of the civil war in 2002, the situation in several parts of Angola remains in a state of decline while a large part of the population lives in poverty. Although the country has a rapidly growing economy, based on the exploitation of stocks of oil, diamonds, minerals, most of the wealth is concentrated in the hands of a disproportionately small part of society. In addition, the Angolan government has been repeatedly accused of corruption, depletion and misuse of state resources and violation of the rule of law. This corruption of the regime has caused great social discontent expressed in 2011 with large protest rallies, which were violently suppressed by the police. In the face of the violation of human rights in Angola, the arrests of journalists and political and social activists, the European Union must call on Angola to respect the Cotton Agreement and to respect and protect human rights. Otherwise, we must send the message that the European Union will take action.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the European Union is following the human rights situation in Angola closely, and we are working hard with the government to raise our concerns about the deterioration which is taking place. The right to freedom of association, assembly and expression are guaranteed by Angola’s national and international laws and human rights obligations. However, we have seen from recent events in Cabinda and Luanda that, on several occasions, individuals have been prevented from peaceful assembly and peacefully demonstrating in Angola. In some cases, the authorities have refused to allow demonstrations to take place, used excessive and unnecessary force or arrested and detained demonstrators. During the first European Union-Angola ministerial meeting, in October 2014, we also highlighted that a free, pluralistic media was an essential component of a multi-party democracy. We have already made various démarches in dialogue with Angola to decriminalise defamation, since the defamation laws can be a threat to investigative journalism. It is in exactly this context that the European Union delegation in Luanda has been following closely the case against journalist Rafael Marques, as well as the case against the Cabinda human rights activist José Marcos Mavungo, by monitoring trials and being in contact with their lawyers. During the most recent Article 8 political dialogue with Angolan Minister of Foreign Affairs Chikoti, on 11 August 2015, a long and frank discussion took place. The European Union delegation, together with the Member States represented in Luanda, expressed concern at recent developments. These include the detention of 15 young activists, the recurrent denial of freedom of assembly, the case of the Cabinda human rights defender Mr Mavungo and the lack of transparency surrounding events in Monte Sumi, where an unknown number of members of the religious cult Kalupeteka were killed in a confrontation with the police in April. On a positive note, the government has accepted to implement the majority of the Universal Periodic Review recommendations and has made good progress on women’s rights, in particular with the enactment of the law on the participation of women in political life. We also welcome the recent accession by Angola to the Convention of the Rights of Persons with Disabilities and the protocol to prevent trafficking in persons. The European Union will continue to call on Angola’s government to fully respect the effective exercise of the rights of freedom of peaceful assembly and of freedom of expression and the right to a fair trial, in line with Angola’s constitution and international conventions and the regional human rights instruments that Angola is a party to. The human rights situation will also be discussed at the forthcoming EU-Angola ministerial meeting, scheduled to take place before the end of the year in Luanda.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place at the end of the debate.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on Azerbaijan.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: author. – Mr President, in the Eastern Partnership Azerbaijan has unfortunately become the country with the worst human rights record. Even Belarus has recently released six political prisoners.  So, given that human rights are, and must be, at the core of relations of the European Union with third countries, we need to stand up together for those who defend human rights, the rule of law and the freedom of the media. We cannot have double standards, for example countries that have oil and gas and others that do not. This resolution calls for the immediate release of all political prisoners. It also welcomes that the Azeri authorities have allowed a medical team to visit Leyla and Arif Yunus. On Tuesday, the UN Commissioner for Human Rights also criticised the ongoing crackdown on civil rights and independent voices in Azerbaijan and called for their immediate release. Let me also – and I hope the Azeri authorities will also read this and listen to it – say one last sentence. This resolution also demands that all European Court of Human Rights rulings need to be complied with, including that of 16 June 2015, which confirms Armenia’s responsibility for the occupation and military presence in the territories of Azerbaijan.

name: Sajjad KARIM
text: author. – Mr. President, allow me to start with a quote from an old – but not that old – Strasbourg speech from 14 years ago: ‘Azerbaijan has definitely chosen the road of integration into Europe, getting orientated towards its humanistic and democratic values’ – wise words indeed from President Heydar Aliyev in 2001.  And yet EU-Azerbaijan relations are a story of disappointments, and – let us be honest – probably mutual disappointments. We know, for instance, that Azerbaijan is frustrated with the lack of progress over Nagorno-Karabakh. We also know that it feels that, far too often, the international community disregards the challenges it has had to face in the aftermath of this war in terms of refugees and internally displaced persons. It is true that the international community has probably not been as active as it could have been in solving this protracted conflict which is still, as we speak, claiming lives. But two wrongs do not make a right, and when Azerbaijan joined the Council of Europe our hope was that it shared our attachment to human rights and fundamental freedoms. As we see today, this hope has been replaced by, to put it mildly, strong concerns. As a friend of Azerbaijan and its people, on a principled position, it is simple and clear: we want Azerbaijan to return to its path towards a European future.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: Author. Mr President, on behalf of the EPP Group, I would like to say two things: first of all, we have expressed in our resolution our concern about the health of Leyla and Arif Yunus and we call for their release as soon as possible. We are very pleased that silent diplomacy, as it is called, has had its effects. We were able to help them from a medical point of view. Moreover, we did not sign the joint resolution because we cannot accept the Strategy of the Greens to come to the plenary to ask it to take a decision - without going through the Committee on Foreign Affairs - on the instruments of neighbourhood policy, on the investigations carried out, it is said, by the Union institutions on President Aliyev , who had signed agreements with President Tusk so that he could also make progress in the area of rights. This strategy of the Greens is therefore unrealistic, we cannot accept it. We will also ask, moreover, not to put to a vote today this resolution, which is simply evidence of a radicalism that does not produce only contrary effects.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Author. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, a little by chance, somewhat coincidentally, in this part-session, we have found ourselves talking about both Belarus and Azerbaijan, and it is wonderful to see how this Parliament approaches with double standards with regard to two countries that geographically belong to the same area and that if they were placed in a human rights ranking , probably, if you like – to make such a ranking – probably the violations in Azerbaijan are worse than those in Belarus.  However, we are imposing sanctions in Belarus, we are doing business with Azerbaijan, because it is clear that in the logic of this strategy that Mr Preda has suggested, Azerbaijan serves us because it supplies us with hydrocarbons and we want to free ourselves from Russia's dependence and therefore 'Who cares if Azerbaijan violates human rights? Who cares if he tortures journalists and defenders? The important thing is that we do business!" This type of attitude is absolutely wrong, as the PPE is having, which does not even want to vote for it because, in my opinion, if we are talking about human rights here, we are putting human rights before the business we want to do with Azerbaijan, so it is good to vote for it today.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: Author. Mr President, Mr Preda has not been displeased with this Parliament for several months, denouncing the situation in Azerbaijan. In its 2015 monitoring report, the Commission stated that the democratic human rights situation in that country has deteriorated significantly. The EU and Azerbaijan are bound by a partnership agreement and the Commission and the Council are pushing for an association agreement. As the process is stalled, a protocol for participation in the European Union programme is being implemented and Mr Tusk visited Mr Ilham Aliyev last July. We dream...  So, no, Mr Preda, instrumentalisation is not on this side of the Chamber. You're in no position to teach us lessons. Stop it! The context of tensions with Russia and the country's high hydrocarbon reserves undoubtedly explain the behaviour of the European authorities and yours in particular. How can we make our votes credible so that human rights are not sacrificed once again? These double standards explain that the ruling clan believes it enjoys total impunity at the expense of human rights defenders in this country that deserves our respect.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: author. – Mr President, human rights violations have systematically increased in Azerbaijan with excessive sentences for journalist Khadija Ismayilova and human rights defenders Leyla Yunus and her husband, and there are many more political prisoners. In fact civil society, political opposition figures, human rights defenders and journalists face intimidation, violence and repression.  To those who are now frantically calling for more time for silent diplomacy, I say that the Azeri authorities have had all the time in the world to make sure that human rights were respected in their own country and that they respected commitments they made to implement the rulings of the European Court of Human Rights and their commitments under the OSCE, and to ensure that the Strategic and Eastern Partnerships also include respect for democracy and human rights.  We do not need another kind of Russian scenario in Azerbaijan and therefore we must speak out now. What is the alternative to strong words in the face of the gravest human rights violations, and what good will more silent diplomacy do? Yes, dialogue, but with a strong message, and so far we have not seen that any silent efforts have rendered the results that we needed.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Author. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has This is not the first time Azerbaijan has occupied us here, it is a permanent guest. Azerbaijan would like to be part of Europe. This year it held the European Olympic Games with great pomp. We have economic interests associated with Azerbaijan, and economic interests are always mutual. In such a situation, we have the right to ask to what extent Azerbaijan wants to respect the rule of law, to what extent Azerbaijan wants to respect human rights. Finally, as a member of the Council of Europe, you have also signed the European Convention on Human Rights. It is sad and upsetting that Azerbaijan regularly brushes all our concerns off the table. That is unacceptable. The situation is very serious – we will hear about a few more cases – and I believe that we must not let go in the interests of human rights in Azerbaijan, but also in the interests of European interests.

name: Róża THUN UND HOHENSTEIN
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by There are twice as many political prisoners in President Aliyev's country today as there are in Russia and Belarus combined. And under what conditions did they, the dissidents, sit there, hear from my speakers. President Aliyev does nothing about international obligations and notoriously violates the European Convention on Human Rights. This requires clear words from us, it requires decisive action from us! I remember very well that when we, in the countries ruled by communist dictatorships in the 1970s and 1980s, fought against those governments that took away our freedom, then the hope and reassue for us were strong words, the involvement of this very High House – the European Parliament. Today, I very much regret that my political group has not signed a joint resolution on Azerbaijan, because human rights are not a matter of party politics. In the name of solidarity with the persecuted in Azerbaijan, I ask you colleagues to vote in favour of this resolution.

name: Kati PIRI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. A year ago, we also stood here and spoke in shame about the arrests of well-known human rights activists, journalists and lawyers in Azerbaijan. This Parliament even nominated one of them, Leyla Yunus, for the Sakharov Prize last year. And although Baku is an important partner of the EU, none of this criticism has been attracted to date. Last summer I attended the start of the mock trial against Leyla and Arif Yunus. They were in a glass cage and couldn't consult with their lawyers. Both have serious health problems. Arif Yunus even had to be taken away by ambulance during the process. It was clear to everyone that it was an absurd indictment and not a fair trial. Imposing a prison sentence of eight and six-and-a-half years respectively on sick people in their 60s is equivalent to a death sentence. This is today's Azerbaijan! It is therefore incomprehensible to me that the diplomatic service of the European Union and the Commission have so far not been more firm about this state of affairs in Azerbaijan. After the sentencing of Leyla and Arif, the call for release finally came. However, this was not the case in the cases of Intigam Aliyev, Rasul Jafarov and Khadija Ismayilova. They too are innocently detained. The European Parliament is clear today. We call on the Azeri government to release all political prisoners immediately.  An important part of the EU neighbourhood policy is the more for more principle. The more democratic reforms a country implements, the more support it receives from the EU. As far as I am concerned, the opposite should also apply: less for less. We call on Azerbaijan to fulfil its obligations as a member of the Council of Europe. Until then, my group is calling for targeted financial sanctions and a visa ban on all politicians and officials who have been involved in political persecution.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Rapporteur, – Looking at the human rights and the rule of law in the world, especially in countries with which we have partnerships and therefore also more means and channels of communication, is, clearly, a permanent task for this House. We deal with Azerbaijan often, and today we have a new, very sharp resolution on the table, with some very good reasons. I wish it had a positive effect, but I'm afraid that's not going to happen. In Baku, they believe that we are accusing their country more often than others comparable – for example, neighbouring Armenia, which occupies one fifth of their territory with Russian troops on its territory and which has expelled almost all the indigenous people of Nagorno-Karabakh, and we, the European Union, are doing nothing to change the situation. Azerbaijan, a complicated and strategically important country, certainly deserves criticism, but also a more comprehensive and balanced treatment in the European Parliament.

name: Jordi Vicent SEBASTIA TALAVERA
text: verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, once again we meet to discuss the human rights situation in Azerbaijan.  In 2009, this Parliament already set out all alarms about the abolition of fundamental freedoms under President Aliyev's regime. Since then we have continued to warn of the dangerous totalitarian drift with the adoption of resolutions on this subject, and what good has it done? Aliyev's regime not only annihilates the basic rights of Azerbaijanis, but is obstinate in destabilizing the democracies of neighbouring countries: it attacks Armenia militarily on a regular basis and, contradicting its commitments under the Minsk Group, continues to harass Nagorno-Karabakh, the country with the best democratic standards in the Caucasus.  But, as we saw on Monday in France 2, in the Cash Investigation programme, their corruption networks are trying to spread to the European Union by buying the will of corrupt politicians. However, in the European Union, many continue to refer to Azerbaijan as a partner.  How is it possible for such an appalling regime to benefit from Eastern partnership and neighbourhood policy? Not only does he not share our values, but he tries to undermine them. No more statements and let's start acting forcefully and with sanctions. Many there, such as journalists and imprisoned activists, urgently need it.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on the issue of Azerbaijan, I should like to start by saying straight away that I feel like a friend of Azerbaijan, of the Azerbaijanis, and I do not agree at all with what I have heard so far. What is the point of this urgent resolution? It is practically necessary when one maybe has to blow his nose and take the paper handkerchief, here he uses it, period and finished, this resolution counts zero. Do you think that from this resolution, anyone from Azerbaijan is afraid, worried, says something special? Absolutely not! This is the ridicule of the European Parliament, which makes paper that serves absolutely no use other than blowing its nose.  So, talk about Islam and talk about Islam. Moderate Islam is there in Azerbaijan, there are more rights for women than others, yes or no? Is there a moderate Islam, yes or no? That is the case, and when you say 'there are no rights', but, then, dear Europeans, why are you doing business with China? Do they not, for example, do the death penalty, do they not kill – as they have killed in the last year alone – 700 people?  Or, when we talk about Nigeria, but there is oil there too, and so Nigeria must be viewed differently! Or, we are talking about many other countries, but what is the substance? That, as was said before, a colleague said: it is not that there is a weight and a measure, double standards, here there are 100 weights and 100 measures. So, I say 'long live Azerbaijan', 'long live the Azeris', let us go there and talk to them, with a real table, not with the lobbies that then change things. Europe must go there and talk to them and find solutions. This is a serious way to make a decent foreign policy.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I one hundred per cent agree that we need to put every pressure possible on Azerbaijan to respect human rights. That is really what this proposal today is all about.  For that reason, it is unfortunate that the EPP find themselves in the position that they cannot back this resolution, and we have got to take a lesson from that. We have to do everything, prior to coming to Parliament, to try and get a joint resolution that all parties and all groups can sign up to. For us, the suggestion that we should ‘immediately’ break off negotiations with Azerbaijan makes no sense, because if we were to do that and apply it to other countries in the world then we would have negotiations with no-one. If you took that line with Iran, we would not be talking about the nuclear deal right now. So it is for that reason in particular – that of over-extending ourselves and doing things for one country that we do not do for another country – that we find ourselves in the position we are today.  We want to see human rights restored and respect in Azerbaijan, but there is a way we can all do it together.

name: Ramona Nicole MĂNESCU
text: – The European Union and Azerbaijan must continue to work together, as was recently reaffirmed on President Aleev's visit to Brussels. This cooperation benefits both parties not only from the point of view of the energy sector, as was said earlier, but also in terms of respect for human rights.  We certainly express our concern about human rights violations in Azerbaijan and, of course, we ask the authorities to resolve these cases. But at the same time, we draw attention to the fact that such situations only move the country away from democratic values and international agreements to which Azerbaijan is a party.  At the same time, I believe that maintaining dialogue with Azerbaijan and strengthening partnership is, in fact, the path that the European Union must follow, and any attempt to take us to the high court only cools relations and benefits neither the European Union nor the citizens of Azerbaijan.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent work. The Eastern Partnership is very important for the European Union because it not only extends the European Union's influence to the countries east of us, but above all brings it closer to us. However, some of us believe that the Eastern Partnership is an auditorium from which others can be istructed. Well, no – we are not to instruct them – we are to bring them closer, we are to attract them. Sure, you can have reservations about some of the things that are happening in Azerbaijan, but, ladies and gentlemen, let us not instruct! Let's remember that verba docent. That's right, but exempla trahunt!

name: Laura AGEA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, since 2009, the European Parliament has adopted 7 resolutions on the human rights situation in Azerbaijan. The events we have been talking about today in this debate show that, despite 7 resolutions – not a 7 – the Azerbaijani liberticidal regime has eradicated all forms of democracy in Azerbaijan; Moreover, it is no mystery that the constant bombings being carried out by the Azerbaijani regime in neighbouring areas, i.e. Armenia, I am referring to Nagorno-Karabakh, in which a few days ago, a woman and her son were injured.  I think it is our duty to adopt this eighth resolution on human rights, not only to ensure that the resolution that was adopted in 2009 is put into practice, but also to begin, with sanctions, to restore a certain democracy to the Azerbaijani people, because the Azerbaijani people deserve democracy, the Azerbaijani regime simply deserves sanctions that restore freedom to the people.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I listened carefully to the debate that was taking place here, and a colleague here said: what is this resolution for? Nothing will change in Azerbaijan.  I fundamentally disagree. I believe that this resolution, which condemns judicial mischimage in Azerbaijan, makes sense. In fact, we are giving a clear signal to those who are dissidents who are fighting against totalitarianism in Azerbaijan that we support them, and this is clear and significant moral support for them. For example, a journalist like Chadija Ismail, who was recently sentenced to seven and a half years in a completely fabricated trial, for such people, I think it is important to make it clear that the European Union stands behind them, that it supports them and that we are watching and rooting for their fight for democracy and the rule of law in Azerbaijan. I think that is very important, which is why I support the adoption of such a resolution.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: – Mr President, the EU must defend human rights in all situations. I agree with the signatories of this resolution that human rights developments in Azerbaijan have been worrying. But this resolution proposes sanctions, suggests that the development of neighbourly relations should now be made conditional, a visa ban is proposed and so on. I believe that these are issues that should first be carefully prepared in committee and then decided here. Not that there is suddenly a vote here in a small circle and with the power of a few people without good, proper preparation. I do not believe that such a resolution, without good preparation, will produce the result that we want. It may give satisfaction to some that we were able to say, but we should only be interested in making progress in respecting human rights.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I would also like to condemn, of course, this particular case, but also the other cases that have been mentioned here. In my view, it is not possible to say in the present case that human rights have a different quality, a different level, if they concern another particular country.  In this case too, I will support the final motion for a resolution, but At the same time, I would like to call once again on the European Union and its institutions to consider the extent to which binding enforceable decisions of international tribunals can be enforced in the territory of the European Union and its institutions, if recognised by that State. Namely, the Council of Europe in Strasbourg, where the Strasbourg Court of Human Rights is based.  A colleague from Italy asked how Azerbaijan would approach this motion for a resolution. Of course, this motion for a resolution may not force them to do anything at all. But if the European Union finds a mechanism for exercising human rights, I think it will be appropriate and good for the Union as a whole.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, we were 'in the same spectators' play in June when, before the First European Games, there was a debate in the European Parliament on Azerbaijan for purely political reasons and purposes. Today, in view of the parliamentary elections in November 2015, we have tabled a new and politically charged resolution, a resolution that is not balanced but unilateral and has a specific political focus. Unfortunately, the European Parliament has gone into the wrong way, having decided not to even send observers in the run-up to the November parliamentary elections in the country. Azerbaijan's isolation tactics are wrong because it leads to the isolation of a state that is a strategic partner of the European Union and safeguards energy security. This tactic takes Azerbaijan off the European road. Who will benefit if Azerbaijan closes the door to the European Union? Which way will Azerbaijan turn? I am against the resolution and support the proposal to postpone the vote on this resolution.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, Azerbaijan is a close partner in several fields of strategic importance for the European Union, notably energy security and regional stability. Our relations have intensified over the last years under the Eastern Partnership, and we would like to see this relationship prosper and develop further on the basis of common interests and values.  However, there are important issues in our relationship that need to be addressed openly among partners. The European Union is following the human rights situation in Azerbaijan closely. Notably, we observed the trials of Leyla and Arif Yunus, of Khadija Ismayilova and, in the spring, of Rasul Jafarov and Intigam Aliyev, just to mention some of the human rights defenders and journalists in Azerbaijan. We have reacted to these negative developments in statements and direct talks at the highest level. We continue to call for the release of human rights activists and journalists imprisoned without a fair trial. We would like to see Azerbaijan live up to its international commitments as a member of the United Nations, the Council of Europe and the OSCE, notably when it comes to safeguarding freedom of expression and association and applying the rule of law, with an independent judiciary and with access to fair and transparent trials. We do not underestimate the challenges that Azerbaijan faces to further develop its independence and stability in a volatile region. We remain convinced that the only way for a country to ensure its long-term stability and security is to allow space for citizens to contribute freely to the political debate. For this, journalists must be allowed to perform their work freely. We expect more action to be taken in this regard. I understand that the Azerbaijan authorities are actively investigating the recent murder of the journalist Rasim Aliyev. Our delegation works hard to promote human rights and has good contacts with civil society in Baku. Our financial assistance is key in this endeavour since it targets the most vulnerable sectors and makes a difference in people’s lives.  Our delegation also offers concrete support to human rights defenders at risk. We will continue to stand up for our shared values and interests in our bilateral relations as well as through the Eastern Partnership and as fellow members of the Council of Europe.  To achieve sustainable results, we will have to apply a long-term constructive approach based on dialogue and engagement and the intense use of diplomatic channels. In order to put our relations on a new base and to develop their full potential, exploratory talks with Baku on an agreement will start next week.  This will bring new opportunities to engage with Azerbaijan across all fields of common interest and values, in line with our international commitments. In this endeavour of engaging Azerbaijan critically but constructively, we need to work together with you. While we understand that some Honourable Members are not comfortable with the idea of negotiating with Azerbaijan in the current circumstances, we must use this new opportunity to pursue human rights objectives as an integral part of our wider relationship. To miss this opportunity would not help to address the concerns that we all share here.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place at the end of the debate. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: in writing. – Human rights are being systematically and increasingly violated in Azerbaijan. Journalists and human rights defenders are sentenced to prison without fair trials. For example, investigative journalist Hadia Ismayilova was sentenced to 7 and a half years in prison after writing critical articles against President Alyyv and his family. The resolution calls on the Government of Azerbaijan to immediately end the repression against journalists and civil society and calls for immediate suspension of negotiations with Azerbaijan, as long as the government does not take steps to free journalists and respect human rights. I voted for the joint resolution. I would like to stress that I have not been given time to speak in this plenary session in the case of Azerbaijan, because I have expressed in the presence of the coordinator of AFET different views from his and part of the group.

name: James CARVER
text: – Mr President, the House may wish to acknowledge that yesterday was quite an incredible milestone in the United Kingdom when Her Majesty the Queen became the country’s longest-serving monarch. I hope Members – certainly British Members and, I would hope, Maltese and Cypriot Members, given her leadership as Head of the Commonwealth – will join me in generally acknowledging the incredible service this lady has given to the United Kingdom. (Applause)

name: Elmar BROK
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I believe that no one doubts that Azerbaijan must be heavily criticised for human rights violations. Substantial criticism must be made! That is why I think the initiative of this resolution is very good. On the other hand, however, it cannot be the way to record fundamental political positions, whether or not to negotiate, when something is in consultation in committees with ratifications, or if we are involved, for example, whether we have the southern line in energy sectors or not, or whether we leave the entire supply to the European Union to the Russians. These are essential strategic issues which, I believe, require sound consultation within the European Parliament and in the relevant committees.  That is why I would ask you to take note of this and also to say that we are taking these points out of this resolution and that we are deciding on the resolution as always, but that there is decent consultation on this. I don't think we can decide on Thursdaywhether whether or not to negotiate with China. If we introduce standards that we are now introducing with Azerbaijan, we must end all relations with Russia and China. And I don't think that's the professional way we help people and how we serve our interests there. That is why I ask that this be taken off the agenda.  (Applause)

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: Mr Brok has made the suggestion to change the agenda and I ask colleagues who represent political groups if they are against this proposal.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, frankly, I did not understand the proposal: whether the proposal was to delete certain points in the resolution or whether, on the other hand, it was something else. If it is the deletion, there is freedom to vote within the documents that each of us has received. If, on the other hand, it is a question of postponing the vote, as far as we are concerned, we intend to maintain the vote on human rights in Azerbaijan, because we believe that this Parliament absolutely must express its opinion. After that, it is the House that is sovereign.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: – Mr President, two things: firstly, as far as I understand it, changes to the agenda are not possible at this moment, according to the services. This is what I heard before, because I had heard that the PPE wants to postpone the vote.  Secondly, the PPE was part of the shadow negotiations, so it would have been possible to take things out, there are split votes on several issues, so postponing it now is not possible. You can try oral amendments but not anything else. My Group is against postponing the vote and also against taking things out now which, as I understand it, is only possible via an oral amendment.

name: Elmar BROK
text: It would be the simplest thing for us to let the House decide on this. The only thing that has been postponed is the vote, the debate has been held, the agenda has not been changed. This is daily practice in this House, that we postpone votes for certain reasons. I do not know why this is not possible on this issue. The artificial interpretations of the Rules of Procedure do not seem to me to be helpful either. If it is the will of the majority of this House to postpone, then we will postpone it and bring it back in a fortnight, or when it is the next plenary session, or because of me also in September II. Then we will reach an agreement, I am sure. And I think that's the easiest thing in the world to deal with each other and find a solution. Then we will condemn by a large majority the violations of human rights in Azerbaijan. That must be in your interest, because eight days does not matter. I could tell a lot more here, but that would do any harm. That is why I would simply like to ask you to let the House decide, and if it decides against me, I have been unlucky.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: In this situation there are two possibilities: the first possibility would have been to remove this item from the agenda, but this cannot be done because we are discussing urgent matters, the other possibility would have been to amend the agenda, provided that all groups accept this issue. There is at least one group that does not want this.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, the point, from a procedural point of view, is simple because colleagues were not in the debate. Mr Preda, who is one of those who tabled the resolution, said that the EPP would ask for the vote to be postponed. That's the point. Put it to the vote to see whether we postpone the vote on the resolution or not; it is very simple.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: – Mr President, the urgencies must be voted on after discussion. And whenever the Group of the European People's Party refuses to engage in a reasonable and losing negotiation, it does these things.  They've had plenty of time to negotiate. There are many people waiting in Azerbaijan for this Parliament to say something. And we have to vote today.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, for a moment, I would like to reply to Mr Brok, because he says that we should not make it a point of order but that we should make it a political issue. Therefore, it seems absurd to me that a person should come and tell us that this is a sensitive political issue, which must be dealt with in committee and not as a violation of human rights, this one on Azerbaijan, while the one on Russia, which we have just voted on, is fine. We must stop double standards! There are violations in Azerbaijan, we have put it into human rights and we are voting on it, not because we are changing our minds! Just that.

name: Rebecca HARMS
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the On a point of order, I have understood the President that our Rules of Procedure do not allow us to postpone votes on urge ncies when the debate is opened here and the resolution is tabled. If that is true – and Parliament's services have explained this to Members before the vote – then the vote requested by Mr Brok is not admissible under the Rules of Procedure. And that is what you said, Mr President.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: – Mr President, I do not want to take more of your time but this is just a correction to make sure that the ODIHR Mission for Election Observations would not mistakenly be put in a bad light, so it would simply remove the last sentence of paragraph 22.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The oral amendment was retained.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: After the vote on point 10.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: – Mr President, very quickly, I am sure everybody can agree to a very simple amendment to paragraph 11 – that is on the implementation of the common asylum system – adding at the end: ‘taking into account the best interests of the child’.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The oral amendment was retained.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: – Mr President, thank you for clarifying that this is not about Amendment 11. This is about paragraph 11, to which an oral amendment would be added. We are voting on ‘taking into account the best interests of the child’.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: Before the vote on Amendment 1.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: – Mr President, (start of speech inaudible as microphone not switched on) ... the Members for this late intervention. There is intense negotiation. But I am going to ask if you would please consider doing a roll-call vote on Amendment 1. I want to alert Members that this amendment from the ECR Group is a very dangerous one. It talks about two states for two peoples. It is effectively ethnic cleansing. I want to remind Members that 20% of the citizens of Israel are Arab Israeli citizens. I just want to alert Members to this. If we cannot have a roll-call vote, at least Members would know. We should not damage the reputation of this Parliament, and Members should vote against it.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I was happy to support this sixth report on cohesion policy, because, in my opinion, it responds very correctly to moments that are very important in regional policy. Cohesion policy should be aimed at supporting weak regions, especially those economically and otherwise disadvantaged, which are lagging behind in economic indicators, as well as regions in need of our support. That's what I think is necessary. It should focus on supporting core areas with significant population concentrations, but also on structurally affected regions. For the future period, I think it is very important that regional policy and its cohesive part continue to address the promotion of sustainable growth, because this is the most important chapter in regional development for the European Union, because only sustainable growth can underestimate our future.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – I voted in favour of this report on cohesion, of course, because I come from Hungary, one of the countries of the European Union with serious disadvantages, and this report is supposed to make more money available Hungary countries. The question, of course, is how this money will be spent, because Hungary does not feel anything for now that the huge difference between Hungary and the Western countries when we entered the European Union would be balanced. There are two reasons for this. The first is the certain colonialism that we have been constantly getting ready for our entry, and the other is that we are sucking our resources on both sides, on the one hand, the neoliberal globalist forces and the European Union, and on the other hand, our own oligarchs, who, for example, have allocated land and Hungarian land among themselves for the first time in the form of leases, and now they are preparing to sell our last resource, farmland, among themselves. We object to this and ask for the union's support in this.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur Indeed, I was very pleased and pleased to support this report by Mr Deutsch, because I can say that, from latvia's experience, two processes are competing: emptying economically back-by-regions, on the one hand, and implementing cohesion programmes. Unfortunately, cohesion programmes, which are intended to give the future to such regions, are losing this battle for the time being because of the insufficient and severe delay. The European Parliament is asking the European Commission to do everything it can to reduce development inequalities in the European Union. And I hope that this report is another contribution to this very important work.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: – Mr President, this is a particularly important report, which promotes investment for jobs and growth in EU regions. Far too often we see investment concentrated in cities and urban areas without due consideration to balancing development across the EU. Strong countries need strong regions, and a strong EU needs strong regions. The cohesion policy is the main tool that we have to promote strong regions, and it takes up one-third of the budget. If we are to promote jobs and growth in rural areas and in regions, we absolutely have to ensure access to regional and rural broadband. We cannot have a digital union unless there is access to digital technologies throughout the Union. This is absolutely crucial. For example, in Ireland, we do not have access to digital technologies across the country. Therefore words like ‘balanced regional development’ and ‘equality of opportunity’ are meaningless until we ensure that access.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I abstained in the final vote of this report because while it is true that it denounces the unjustifiable delays in payments of cohesion policy funds (amounting to around EUR 25 billion), the low level of absorption (or final receipt thereof), as well as the importance of reindustrializing the European Union and the necessary role of those funds in this regard , the final wording of the text includes congratulations on the new European Fund for Strategic Investments (Juncker Plan), the boost of public-private partnerships, or support for the conditionality of state operational programmes to the objectives of the European Semester and reform programmes. Therefore, without opposing some of the criticisms highlighted in the report, I think it is appropriate not to support a text that enhances political measures of European economic governance aimed at constraining the political capacity of public investment of administrations, thus having generated a very negative social and economic impact on the population.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
