text: in writing. ‒ Investment for jobs and growth should be the preserve of the Member States, not the responsibility of the EU. Member States are best placed to understand the unique challenges faced by each country. This is another example of subsidiarity being ignored.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this important report, because the Cohesion policy remains an essential instrument for maintaining investment levels in various EU Member States and a tool to overcome new challenges and threats facing the EU. Moreover, we shouldn’t forget that the primary goal of Cohesion policy ought not to be regarded only to reinforce economic, social and territorial Cohesion in all EU regions, particularly of less developed and the least favoured but also as an investment policy in the territories. Thus, I believe, that this report which encourages investment for jobs and growth in EU regions is of great significance and corresponds with the core aims of the cohesion policy.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 According to the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, the Commission is to present every three years a cohesion report on progress towards economic, social and territorial cohesion...". The report shows that cohesion policy under cohesion policy during the 2007-2013 programming period has mitigated the impact of a sharp decline in public investment, which in some Member States was more than 60% and the EU average by 20%. Investment in cohesion has ensured stability for the regions, providing funding when national public and private investment has decreased or even been discontinued.  I agree that it is necessary to think about cohesion policy after 2020 and to make cohesion policy post-2020 the most important for communities and citizens and to ensure the well-being of each individual.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. I voted against this report of complacency and self-promotion. Who can believe today that the European Union is synonymous with jobs and growth?

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. This report, which I approved, stresses that it is essential to encourage investment to break the vicious cycle of which Europe is trapped: low inflation and low growth, which limit government revenues, and a high unemployment rate that increases its spending. We must now focus on implementing investment projects in the real economy. The strategic issue of flexibility for voluntary participation and national co-financing and the quality of investments to finance long-term projects are essential to the reorientation of Europe. These projects should support the convergence of economies, ecological transition, innovation in SMEs, infrastructure, digital, education and social, and accelerate the creation of decent jobs.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as promoting the economic, social and territorial cohesion of the Union is fundamental to Europe's growth. Austerity plans have left very harsh realities in various member states and territorial cohesion through policy development at the local and regional levels can improve the current situation of some member states.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This report on investment in jobs and growth aims to promote the economic, social and territorial cohesion of the European Union. These cohesion policies aim to reduce regional disparities and competitiveness gaps in the Union. However, it is already forgotten that these disparities are largely fuelled by the existence of a single currency resulting in a divergence in productive capacities. In fact, under the guise of 'cohesion', this text aims to increase the Union's constraints on the eligibility of investments and to give more prerogatives to large regional communities at the expense of nation states. The Union is still trying to divest the states of their sovereignty a little more... The Commission wants to increase the mobilization of European funds to reduce regional disparities even though it is its policies that are responsible for the competitiveness gaps. In addition, I challenge the use of funds to promote Roma integration. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I do not agree with the positions expressed in this resolution.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. I've dropped my voice. The report supports and wants to develop cohesion policy and the various types of funds associated with it. The consequence of this will be further EU central governance and integration. Unfortunately, this is also an area where most fraud and fraud takes place in the EU. That is why I choose to abstain.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. Every three years, the Commission presents a report on progress towards economic, social and territorial cohesion in the EU. In the context of the crisis and austerity policies, when public and private investment at the national level ceased/decreased, this report shows that cohesion policy gave stability to regions, ensuring a flow of funding. The report also notes the importance of investment during the 2014-2020 programme in areas such as innovation, ICT or the low-carbon economy, employment and SMEs, where the potential for sustainable job creation, especially for young people, is promising. Among other issues, the report denounces payment problems and arrears at the beginning of the current cohesion policy cycle, the need to improve the administrative capacity of public authorities, the lack of analysis of the problems of cross-border cooperation and calls for a view to post-2020 cohesion policy. Finally, I find the approach to macroeconomic conditionality balanced. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this Parliament's report on Investment in Jobs and Growth – promoting economic, social and territorial cohesion in the Union. The primary task of cohesion policy is to promote economic, social and territorial cohesion and reduce regional disparities by providing specific support to less developed regions. By their nature and the initial structure set out in the Treaty, this policy naturally contributes to the achievement of the Union's objectives, in particular the Europe 2020 objectives for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth and the treaty's main objective of strengthening territorial cohesion. For this reason, Parliament calls on the Commission to carefully assess the cases in which financial corrections or suspensions of payments will be applied, in the light of the potential consequences for growth and job creation.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 The report deals with cohesion policy, the EU's premier investment policy, which is the most audited and valued expenditure area of the EU budget with a budget of more than EUR 350 billion for the period 2014-2020. The report contains ideas with which I strongly agree.  One of the central ideas of the report is that the effectiveness and credibility of cohesion policy can only be maintained if we eliminate the very significant payment arrears and preserve the scale of the EU's budgetary resources for cohesion policy.  The report will focus on unemployment, in particular youth unemployment and the ability of small and medium-sized enterprises to create jobs. In order to promote job creation, the rapporteur calls for a coordinated use of the European Social Fund and the European Regional Development Fund, while proposing to reduce the administrative burden on the attneffied in order to increase efficiency.  The report reaffirms the original objective of cohesion policy, reducing development gaps, while emphasising its contribution to achieving the Europe2020 Strategy's smart, inclusive and sustainable growth goals and its role in mitigating the devastating effects of the crisis. Therefore, as a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. Solidarity is a key European value. And it is cohesion policy that is the best example of solidarity between countries, solidarity between different regions. That is why I supported my colleague Deutsch's report, because cohesion policy is one of the most important generators of investment activity. We must be aware that in the years of the worst economic crisis, cohesion projects accounted for between 20 and 80% of investment activity in less developed EU countries, i.e. net recipient of cohesion funds. Cross-border projects, which we also promote through the common cohesion policy, connect countries at project level, there is more cooperation, more exchange of good practices, knowledge exchange. It is also necessary and fair that, in all this, we are providing appropriate high pre-accession assistance also for candidate countries on their way to the EU family, and that they can start drawing on regional development as soon as possible. Only in this way can they eliminate the current development backlog, thus also facilitating political stability in the region.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ I support the Jobs and Growth Investment Report. I believe that cohesion policy needs to be considered already in 2020 and above all how the administrative capacity of the institutions of government needs to be improved, especially at regional and local level, with partnerships on both sides. We aim for jobs and growth, i.e. reducing unemployment in the European Union of 9.9%, or even 24.1% among the younger population.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. Regional disparities and competitiveness gaps are not the main cause of the difficulties faced by developed European countries. They existed long before the creation of the European Union and had never created any obstacles to the development of trade between states, on the contrary. It is the imposition of a single currency, notwithstanding these differences between states, that has created a decisive advantage for the best performing country at the expense of others, thus exacerbating disparities. One of the objectives of the single currency was to force Member States to harmonize their policies, standards, and conditions of employment. Despite the unwavering commitment of the actors in this direction, this did not happen, because each country had built over the years, a lasting balance between all these elements. To touch one of them in order to harmonize with one's fellow human beings in other countries is to create insurmountable imbalances within each country, sometimes generating social unrest.  The only solution is to stop this adventure of the single currency and restore for each country the freedom of its monetary policy and sovereignty, which will revive trade and eventually restore full employment. I voted against it.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that cohesion policy is the European Union's main instrument for reducing economic, social and territorial disparities between European regions, for improving their competitiveness, and for combating climate change and energy dependency, while contributing to the achievement of the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy. I also believe that cohesion policy is one of the flagships of the Union's policies and that investment in this area has enabled many disadvantaged areas of the EU not to succumb to the crisis.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 The economic and financial crisis has put a strain on europe's economic and social fabric. In order to emerge from the crisis and ensure a solid recovery, we cannot repeat the mistakes of the past. Market surveillance and market dynamics must be monitored, with the Union providing the Union with the necessary instruments to act quickly. The logic of austerity and rigour alone has not brought the continent out of the pockets of stagnation. It is important to note that one of the few economic areas in which EU policy has produced results is that of regional development funds which, although limited, have represented a modest but important injection of liquidity into the territories that have benefited from it, to which credit should be due for the creation of 594,000 new jobs. Without investments coordinated and managed by a central government, there can be no solid recovery, and therefore the progress of the European integration process and the investments that will have to be focused on sectors that can have multiplicative effects on employment and growth, such as innovation or education, must be strongly supported, together with the strengthening of regional funding for SMEs that are the regional engine in job creation and progress towards a digital and eco-sustainable economy.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. The report is a pretext for the growing competitiveness gaps in Europe to strengthen the Union's cohesion policy, which would reduce regional disparities by replacing the lack of public investment. This will put 350 billion euros in investment to combat youth unemployment, to facilitate the financing of SMEs and to promote the energy transition.  These laudable goals hide a very sad reality. Strengthening this cohesion policy will increase the Union's constraints on the eligibility of investments and will give more prerogatives to regional communities, to the detriment of the Nation States. The philosophy of this text runs counter to the ideas we stand for. The Commission plays the role of the arsonist firefighter.  At the same time, it calls for greater mobilization of Eu-largest funds to reduce these regional disparities. Moreover, the solutions provided are derisory and even counterproductive. It is indeed impossible to simplify procedures by strengthening administrations just as it is impossible to create synergies with other funds if the means are not pooled.  That is why I voted against this text.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The economic crisis had a negative impact on the economic, social and territorial cohesion of the Union and slowed the objective of reducing disparities between regions, so that at the beginning of the new programming period, progress was particularly low. Some Member States face serious problems due to the lack of administrative capacity and the load of the bureaucratic apparatus, which is reflected in the low level of implementation of the funded projects and the low performance of the absorption of Community support, so that the risk of decommitment of funds at the end of the programming period cannot be avoided. Structural reforms are required at the level of Member States which at the end of the previous period experienced a particularly low degree of absorption in order to avoid the emergence of similar scenarios in the future. The increasing efficiency of cohesion policy lies in the ability to adapt and flexibilize its instruments to local and regional specificities, but also to the ability of regions to turn them into development opportunities. The Commission should take into account all economic and social aspects arising from the suspension of commitments or payments pursuant to Article 23(15) of the Common Provisions Regulation. I therefore believe that the suspension of payments should be avoided when minor errors are found.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 The essence of the report is: to promote economic, social and territorial cohesion in the EU it takes more ... European Semester. I am voting against!

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 After careful consideration and discussion in plenary, I voted today in favour of the report on the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on 'investment in growth and job creation: promoting economic, social and territorial cohesion in the Union' on the basis of the following considerations: - regional disparities have increased and the increase in employment since 2000 and the competitiveness of many Member States have been lost , in particular in the southern Member States; - the original role of cohesion policy and its instruments as defined in the Treaty make it in themselves the main policy instrument for achieving smart, sustainable and inclusive growth across the EU;  I therefore agree with the rapporteur on the welcome of the new EU investment plan for Europe aimed at completing structural investment and cohesion and the whole of his report.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. Cohesion policy is a public investment policy of the Union that highlights European solidarity. These two main funds: the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) and the European Social Fund (ESF) have enabled many citizens to go through with their projects. FEDER has created 660,000 jobs and financed numerous projects and SMEs. The ESF has found employment for 5.7 million inactive people. In this time of crisis, these are the kinds of instruments we need. Many say that it is Europe that is responsible for all the evils, but yet we can see with these results that this is far from the case. I voted in favour of this report.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ Investment for jobs and growth should be the preserve of the Member States, not the responsibility of the EU. Member States are best placed to understand the unique challenges faced by each country. This is another example of subsidiarity being ignored.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ This report highlights the unquestionable success of the Cohesion Funds, namely the European Social Fund (ESF) and the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) on jobs and growth in the EU. It lists some very encouraging figures in this domain and the effect is ongoing as Member States are able to tap into these funds until the end of the year. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report analyses the Commission's sixth cohesion report (of July 2014) and sets out the macro objectives of cohesion investments for the seven-year year 2014-2020. Although it is generally well-designed, some points remain undead. In particular, the reference to the need for sound economic governance in relation to the Juncker plan and the affirmation of complementarity between it and the Structural Funds give cause for concern. I have therefore chosen to abstain.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it calls for a strong mobilization of European funds to reduce these regional disparities. In particular, it proposes to use these funds for the purpose of welcoming Roma. This philosophy of cohesion policy goes against my principles.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 Cohesion policy is the European Union's main tool to reduce economic, social and territorial disparities in European regions, boost their competitiveness, tackle climate change and energy dependency, while contributing to the achievement of the Europe 2020 objectives. Our assessment is that cohesion policy measures play an essential role in reducing internal competitive inequalities and structural imbalances in the regions most in need. The Commission is rightly asked to consider pre-financing in order to facilitate the full use of funds by Member States in the period 2014-2020.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I fully agree with the rapporteur who stressed the great success of cohesion policy. In fact, it has made it possible to achieve important objectives that have helped citizens in this difficult period of crisis: firstly, the European Regional Development Fund, thanks to the investments made, has created a great many jobs and supported important projects to reduce the main economic, social and territorial disparities between European regions, contributing to the development of many areas where public and private investment had fallen drastically. In addition, this cohesion policy has proved to be the only proven instrument of growth and development that can help Member States combat unemployment. I also fully agree with the rapporteur that the effects of the investments made as a result of this policy are still increasing in recent years. In fact, the Member States still have at their disposal the funds with which they can increase employment, create new jobs, and support those who do not have a job.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. Cohesion policy is the European Union's main instrument to reduce economic, social and territorial disparities between European regions, fostering their competitiveness, addressing climate change and energy dependency while contributing to the achievement of the Europe 2020 objectives. It is therefore important to proactively strengthen and support the principles of competitiveness, sustainability and regulatory reliability to promote jobs and growth in Europe. I welcome the fact that the Council, the Commission and Parliament have reached an agreement to reduce the level of unpaid bills at the end of the year, particularly in cohesion policy, i.e. to pay expenses that were authorised but have not yet been settled. I support the need for Member States and the Commission to continue to improve and extend the EURES platform as an effective tool for promoting the mobility of workers in Europe. I welcome the creation of the new European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) and its potential leverage effect. It is imperative to start implementing the operational programs as soon as they are approved. This is the only way we encourage job creation, increase productivity and contribute to the Union's climate and energy objectives.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 Cohesion policy has been and remains the main instrument for reducing economic and social disparities between the various European regions. It has also demonstrated its ability to react quickly to changing times and needs, through more flexible measures, especially in the field of employment, by redirecting 13% of its budget for this purpose. The problems associated with its - hopefully - increasingly effective implementation and payments must certainly be addressed. I agree with the need for a mid-term review to monitor the achievement of set objectives and, if necessary, to assess new and additional needs. I voted in favour because the content of the own-initiative report, drawn up in detail and in detail, contains all the guidelines that I believe should be implemented.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I abstained in the final vote of this report because while it is true that it denounces the unjustifiable delays in payments of cohesion policy funds (amounting to around EUR 25 billion), the low level of absorption (or final receipt thereof), as well as the importance of reindustrializing the European Union and the necessary role of those funds in this regard , the final wording of the text includes congratulations on the new European Fund for Strategic Investments (Juncker Plan), the boost of public-private partnerships, or support for the conditionality of state operational programmes to the objectives of the European Semester and reform programmes. Therefore, without opposing some of the criticisms highlighted in the report, I think it is appropriate not to support a text that enhances political measures of European economic governance aimed at constraining the political capacity of public investment of administrations, thus having generated a very negative social and economic impact on the population.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report, even beyond its good content, is an opportunity to return to the debate on cohesion policy and the Structural Funds. It is, to say the least, paradoxical that while everyone in all the Member States, albeit at different speeds, is taking shape and concretely the projects that will shape the next six years and which, as has already happened, will help to change the face of regions and cities, in Parliament the debate is languishing. We are tarded in long and often old discussions, always overtaken by the instiling of facts. It is a contradiction, almost a paradox, that as a democratic institution we have repeatedly asked to be involved in the main decisions that are taken and that characterise the good design and spending of the funds and, at the same time, we are incapable of taking initiative and keeping up with the times. I feel that there is a terrible time scale, that if it is not filled, it will put Parliament even more marginally in a position; making cohesion policy a two-Member Commission-State affair. These reports are welcome. Above all, however, let us intensify the debate and bring it back to reality without delay, by intercepting and making a real contribution to the local institutions involved in the use of the funds.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Deutsch report on cohesion policy. According to the number, the sixth Cohesion Report assesses the situation in the area of cohesion policy and provides guidance on the future management and possible development of cohesion policy. Eu cohesion policy, which plays a major role in reducing the disparities between regions, is of particular importance for our region. It affects small and medium-sized enterprises, innovation, education, many areas of life. The report also rightly points to shortcomings in the need to remedy the difficulties associated with payments and to address the need to assess the cohesion of european cross-border regions in the future. The report's long-term essential idea is that it should also be planned for the post-2020 period, with citizens and collaborative communities at the heart of cohesion policy.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, which illustrates that, during the recent crisis and austerity measures, cohesion investments gave stability to the regions by ensuring the flow of funding when national public and private investments declined or ceased altogether. The report focuses on implementation payment problems, governance and territorial dimensions. It is important also to see a focus on cohesion policy in the long—term perspective, calling on institutions to already think about the shape of the Cohesion Policy post-2020.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This 6th report on economic, social and territorial cohesion provides an overview of the current situation of the Union's cohesion policy. Through an analysis of the results over the past and present period, the Rapporteur highlights the undeniable successes of cohesion policy, particularly in terms of job creation (600,000 through the ERDF) and support for start-up projects (via the ESF). Considering that this report is balanced on the one hand, and that it pays particular attention to the support of the real economy, to the development of more targeted regulation and to the reduction of the administrative burden within the framework of the future cohesion policy of the Union on the other hand, I voted for this text.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. \u2012 Cohesion policy is the European Union's main instrument, which aims to reduce economic, social and territorial disparities in European regions, boosting their competitiveness, combating climate change and energy dependency, while contributing to the achievement of the Europe 2020 objectives. I believe that, despite the difficulties faced by some Member States and regions in co-financing them, investments under cohesion policy have significantly mitigated the negative effects of the economic and financial crisis and helped to ensure stability within the regions by ensuring funding flows at a time when national and regional public and private investment has fallen sharply , cohesion policy funds equivalent to 21 % of public investment across the Union and 57 % in cohesion fund beneficiaries countries as a whole.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text on investments in jobs and growth. Today, cohesion policy is an essential investment strategy in the real economy at EU level and is an instrument of growth and employment. I support this policy, the Main Instrument of the European Union aimed at reducing economic, social and territorial inequalities.

name: Philippe DE BACKER
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report because I strongly believe that all parties in Europe need to be looking in the same direction if we want to achieve growth and jobs; local, regional, national and European. The report highlights that regional disparities remained high and that the cohesion policy objective to reduce economic, social and territorial disparities, had not yet been reached everywhere. We need to coordinate and create consistent regional policies to avoid being counterproductive at a European level. Vice-versa European initiatives such as the EFSI should not undermine regional coherence. In addition governance is key to ensure effective and efficient implementation with the involvement of local and regional levels. In this respect we called for a substantial in-depth medium-term review of objectives and funding levels. Last but not least we called for the commission to come up with a favourable regulatory framework for SMEs (with a key role in job creation) to promote smart-growth, digital and low carbon economies and to focus on youth unemployment.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. \u2012 According to the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, the European Commission is required to submit a cohesion report every three years on "progress in achieving economic, social and territorial cohesion". The publication of the Sixth Cohesion Report was delayed due to the adoption of the new legislative framework for cohesion policy 2014-2020 and its structure has been modified to reflect the Europe 2020 strategy. I believe that the Sixth Cohesion Report is a good one, as it shows that, during the 2007-2013 programming period, cohesion policy clearly mitigated the negative impact of the decline in public investment. Investment in cohesion has, in fact, given stability to the regions by ensuring the flow of funding at a time when national public and private investment has decreased or even stopped. In addition, the report sets out in perspective the key objectives of cohesion investment for the period 2014-2020, including energy efficiency, employment and SMEs.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I voted in favour of the report by Tamás Deutsch, which deals with the EU's premier investment policy, cohesion policy, which is the most controlled and valued expenditure area of the EU budget with a budget of more than EUR 350 billion for the period 2014-2020. The Deutsch report contains ideas with which I strongly agree.  One of the central ideas of the report is that the effectiveness and credibility of cohesion policy can only be maintained if we eliminate the very significant payment arrears and preserve the scale of the EU's budgetary resources for cohesion policy.  The report will focus on unemployment, in particular youth unemployment and the ability of small and medium-sized enterprises to create jobs. In order to promote job creation, Tamás Deutsch calls for a coordinated use of the European Social Fund and the European Regional Development Fund, while also proposing to reduce the administrative burden on the at-risk in order to increase efficiency.  The report reaffirms the original objective of cohesion policy, reducing development gaps, while emphasising its contribution to achieving the Europe2020 Strategy's smart, inclusive and sustainable growth goals and its role in mitigating the devastating effects of the crisis. The Deutsch report is one of the most important regional policy documents of the 2014-2020 cycle, which received overwhelming support in the plenary vote.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. – As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I voted in favour of the report 'Investing in jobs and growth - promoting economic, social and territorial cohesion in the Union'. The report, quoted by Tamás Deutsch, deals with the EU's premier investment policy, cohesion policy, which is the most audited and valued expenditure area of the EU budget with a budget of more than EUR 350 billion for the period 2014-2020. The Deutsch report contains ideas with which I strongly agree.  One of the central ideas of the report is that the effectiveness and credibility of cohesion policy can only be maintained if we eliminate the very significant payment arrears and preserve the scale of the EU's budgetary resources for cohesion policy.  The report will focus on unemployment, in particular youth unemployment and the ability of small and medium-sized enterprises to create jobs. In order to promote job creation, Tamás Deutsch calls for a coordinated use of the European Social Fund and the European Regional Development Fund, while also proposing to reduce the administrative burden on the at-risk in order to increase efficiency.  The report reaffirms the original objective of cohesion policy, reducing development gaps, while emphasising its contribution to achieving the Europe2020 Strategy's smart, inclusive and sustainable growth goals and its role in mitigating the devastating effects of the crisis. The Deutsch report is one of the most important regional policy documents of the 2014-2020 cycle and has received overwhelming support in both the Commission and plenary votes.

name: Diane DODDS
text: in writing. ‒ The European Structural and Investment Funds hold inherent potential for organisations in my constituency in Northern Ireland, many of whom work with disengaged sections of the community, including young people, women and those living with a disability. The merits of these funds toward promoting skills, employment and entrepreneurship in particular have been well publicised. However, it is equally as beneficial that all necessary steps are taken to ensure that the application and claims processes are conducive to maximising the impact that this support can provide to projects in EU regions. In this sense, this report is right to highlight that suspensions in payments must come as a last resort. In Northern Ireland, delays in payments for claims under the last European Social Fund Programme continue to mar the amicable closure of several transformative skills and training projects carried out in the last programming. This is quite frankly unacceptable and does not inspire confidence for potential applicants. Managing authorities should therefore be given clear guidance on auditing procedures to ensure that these delays do not happen in the new programme. In turn, managing authorities must use the flexibility given to them to leverage the greatest benefits possible from the Structural Funds for Northern Ireland.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. The proposed report is an illustration of the Eu's devious method of increasing its action and regulatory grip. Indeed, after destroying the economic barriers between European states to the disadvantage of workers who have suffered from the competitiveness gaps - distortions reinforced by European trade, monetary and economic policies that have weakened Europe - the Union wants to allocate European funds to combat these disparities at the regional level. In addition, this report suggests using these funds for the integration of Roma populations, as the broad outlines of the European Social Fund point out. It is not conceivable to fall into the trap of a European Union which claims to be the doctor of the diseases of which it is the origin, which is why I voted against this report.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We are voting against, because the report talks about growth and job creation but, at the same time, proposes continuing the policies that have yielded the exact opposite results.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. – As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I voted in favour of the report 'Investing in jobs and growth - promoting economic, social and territorial cohesion in the Union'. The report, quoted by Tamás Deutsch, deals with the EU's premier investment policy, cohesion policy, which is the most audited and valued expenditure area of the EU budget with a budget of more than EUR 350 billion for the period 2014-2020. The Deutsch report contains ideas with which I strongly agree.  One of the central ideas of the report is that the effectiveness and credibility of cohesion policy can only be maintained if we eliminate the very significant payment arrears and preserve the scale of the EU's budgetary resources for cohesion policy.  The report will focus on unemployment, in particular youth unemployment and the ability of small and medium-sized enterprises to create jobs. In order to promote job creation, Tamás Deutsch calls for a coordinated use of the European Social Fund and the European Regional Development Fund, while also proposing to reduce the administrative burden on the at-risk in order to increase efficiency.  The report reaffirms the original objective of cohesion policy, reducing development gaps, while emphasising its contribution to achieving the Europe2020 Strategy's smart, inclusive and sustainable growth goals and its role in mitigating the devastating effects of the crisis. The Deutsch report is one of the most important regional policy documents of the 2014-2020 cycle and has received overwhelming support in both the Commission and plenary votes.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 The decisive role of EU cohesion policy in reducing regional disparities, promoting economic, social and territorial cohesion between member states' regions and supporting job creation is undeniable. The latest figures for 2013 show that long-term unemployment in the Union has reached a historically high level of 5.1 % of the working population. I agree that cohesion policy is the European Union's main instrument to reduce economic, social and territorial disparities between European regions, fostering their competitiveness, responding to climate change and energy dependency while contributing to the achievement of the Europe 2020 objectives.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution because it aims at European territorial integration and breaks the mechanisms of national solidarity.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 The express recipe is absolutely wrong. In order to promote economic and social cohesion in the EU, they propose greater European coordination.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on investment in jobs and growth and the promotion of economic, social and territorial cohesion in the Union, because it talks about growth and job creation, but at the same time proposes a continuation of the policies that have yielded the exact opposite results.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ During the recent crisis and austerity conditions, cohesion investments gave stability to the regions by ensuring the flow of funding when national public and private investments declined. During the 2014-2020 financing programming, in areas such as innovation, digital and low carbon economy, employment and SMEs, clearly showed potential for creating sustainable jobs, especially for youth. I agree with the rapporteur on the fact that a late start of the current cohesion policy cycle and backlog in payments are not acceptable. Moreover, we must improve administrative capacity of public authorities, especially at regional and local level and increase cooperation with all stakeholders.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I voted in favour of the report "Investing in jobs and growth - promoting economic, social and territorial cohesion in the Union". The report, quoted by Tamás Deutsch, deals with the EU's premier investment policy, cohesion policy, which is the most audited and valued expenditure area of the EU budget with a budget of more than EUR 350 billion for the period 2014-2020. One of the central ideas of the report is that the effectiveness and credibility of cohesion policy can only be maintained if we eliminate the very significant payment arrears and preserve the scale of the EU's budgetary resources for cohesion policy.  The report will focus on unemployment, in particular youth unemployment and the ability of small and medium-sized enterprises to create jobs. In order to promote job creation, Tamás Deutsch calls for a coordinated use of the European Social Fund and the European Regional Development Fund, while also proposing to reduce the administrative burden on the at-risk in order to increase efficiency.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution 'Investment in growth and employment: promoting economic, social and territorial cohesion in the EU', because, in these years of crisis and austerity, with the spiralling fall in investment, cohesion policy has been the main source of investment, and in the future it may be a significant source of support for recovery. Cohesion policy has a key role to play in reducing disparities in Europe, in the sense that cohesion funds, if well spent, can be the driving force for attracting further investment. However, it is of fundamental importance to improve the effectiveness of this policy, particularly in some European regions and in some Member States, which have shown considerable delays in the absorption of funds, or have not been fully used because, as a result of the crisis, it was not possible to guarantee the share of public cofinancing, initially planned. It is also necessary, therefore, for cofinancing to be allocated to the calculation of the deficit, in order to release as many resources as possible, for the cohesion funds to reach the territories, and finally for a new dynamism to be restored in the long term to cohesion policy, linking it effectively and effectively with the EU 2020 strategy, resulting in a new multiannual financing framework.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the report on 'Investing in employment and growth: promoting economic, social and territorial cohesion in the Union', as I consider the social dimension of regional development to be very crucial, although I would have liked to see greater attention paid to the role and needs of the family.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. Cohesion policy is central to reducing regional inequalities and promoting economic, social and territorial cohesion between member states' regions. Against this background, I welcome the focus of cohesion policy 2014-2020 on effectiveness, efficiency and performance.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Deutsch report, which outlines key steps that are vital to a strong cohesion policy: improving public authorities’ administrative capacity, improving cross—border cooperation and thinking about the post—2020 policy. However, a lot depends on how Member States use these funds. In my country, the government tends to blame the EU when there is bad news about the economy. What they don’t mention is that EU cohesion investments helped maintain stability in our regions during the economic crisis, when national public and private investments declined.  Take the West Midlands, where the GBP 640m in ERDF and ESF funds invested between 2007 and 2013 have been key for some parts of the region, where public sector cuts had a disproportionate and adverse impact, and have helped 12,000 people to get a job.  What the government also doesn’t mention is that it caused huge delays in getting the funding agreed, stealing valuable time for local businesses to apply for money. And although 750 000 young people are out of job in the UK, the government chose not to implement the Youth Guarantee, instead using EU funds for a Youth Contract that delivered less than 13% of 160 000 promised work placements.

name: Juan Carlos GIRAUTA VIDAL
text: In writing. Europe's regions are experiencing a wide variety of economic, social and territorial situations. While some regions are very dynamic and have excellent research, education and training infrastructure, others face high unemployment rates that particularly affect young people. That is why I have supported this report, which is in line with the strengthening of the EU's cohesion programmes.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: in writing. ‒ While recognising the importance of the gender dimension in job creation, I strongly oppose the idea of job creation being either an EU or government activity. Job creation comes from governments supporting business development, innovation and industry development and supporting SMEs; not from direct governmental interference. I do not therefore condone any increase in interference from the EU in areas such as childcare. In my view, the EU should focus on job creation as an objective; working to foster a more supportive and therefore more beneficial, environment to assist with the achievement of this goal. Indeed, despite notable progress in recent decades, women still face significant challenges in the labour market and if one considers the impending skills shortages, particularly in the UK, such challenges have the potential to negatively impact society more broadly. It is important that gender issues are treated seriously in the area of cohesion policy, because this represents a very significant slice of EU expenditure. Women are essential to the success of any regional policy.  It is for these reasons that, on this occasion, I abstained from voting.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of a report setting out the main objectives of cohesion investments during the period 2014-2020: energy efficiency, employment and SMEs, areas where the potential for sustainable job creation seems promising. The report points to the need to increase and accelerate EU investment for the promotion of European cohesion. Its author denounces that in recent times, as a result of the crisis and austerity policies there has been a 15% drop in public investment in the EU. The object of the cohesion investments that Deutsch calls for to increase must be twofold: to alleviate the territorial and social inequalities within the continent, both of which are also related to each other, since the most impoverished regions are also the ones with the highest rates of unemployment and poverty. In this regard, it urges the EU to increase funds to combat youth unemployment, those aimed at the labour insertion of groups with difficulties in entering the labour market.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ In the plenary I, along with my fellow Labour MEPs, voted for this report. I welcome the new investment plan for Europe: it complements its structural and cohesion investments. Areas which are promising, as pointed out in the report, include the core targets of cohesion investments 2014-2020, which are: energy efficiency, employment and small and medium—sized enterprises, areas which are of importance to the North West of England.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the report on the Cohesion Policy that includes the notion for the investment for jobs and growth. Primarily, the core targets of cohesion investments as the digitalisation, energy efficiency, employment and SMEs are the key areas that promise the creation of job places. On the note of effectiveness and investment, I agree with the rapporteur that some flexibility is needed for the regions, depending on their local situation, especially in the context of the severe crisis. Above all, as we can see the results, the Cohesion Policy has mitigated the decline of public investments in many member states during the crisis. Therefore, it should be requested to fully use the simplification possibilities within the Cohesion Policy regulation as well as increase the synergies with the other EU programmes and financial instruments.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I voted in favour of the report "Investing in jobs and growth - promoting economic, social and territorial cohesion in the Union". The report, quoted by Tamás Deutsch, deals with the EU's premier investment policy, cohesion policy, which is the most audited and valued expenditure area of the EU budget with a budget of more than EUR 350 billion for the period 2014-2020. One of the central ideas of the report is that the effectiveness and credibility of cohesion policy can only be maintained if we eliminate the very significant payment arrears and preserve the scale of the EU's budgetary resources for cohesion policy.  The report will focus on unemployment, in particular youth unemployment and the ability of small and medium-sized enterprises to create jobs. In order to promote job creation, Tamás Deutsch calls for a coordinated use of the European Social Fund and the European Regional Development Fund, while also proposing to reduce the administrative burden on the at-risk in order to increase efficiency.  The report reaffirms the original objective of cohesion policy, reducing development gaps, while emphasising its contribution to achieving the Europe2020 Strategy's smart, inclusive and sustainable growth goals and its role in mitigating the devastating effects of the crisis. The report is one of the most important regional policy documents of the 2014-2020 cycle.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I voted in favour of the report "Investing in jobs and growth - promoting economic, social and territorial cohesion in the Union". The report, quoted by Tamás Deutsch, deals with the EU's premier investment policy, cohesion policy, which is the most audited and valued expenditure area of the EU budget with a budget of more than EUR 350 billion for the period 2014-2020. The effectiveness and credibility of cohesion policy can only be maintained if we eliminate the very significant payment arrears and preserve the scale of the EU's budgetary resources for cohesion policy.  The report will focus on unemployment, in particular youth unemployment, and the ability of small and medium-sized enterprises to create jobs. In order to promote job creation, Tamás Deutsch calls for a coordinated use of the European Social Fund and the European Regional Development Fund, while also proposing to reduce the administrative burden on the at-risk in order to increase efficiency.  The document confirms the original objective of cohesion policy, to reduce differences in development. It also underlines its contribution to achieving the Smart, Inclusive and Sustainable Growth Goals of the Europe2020 Strategy and underlines its role in mitigating the negative effects of the economic crisis. The Deutsch report is one of the most important regional policy documents of the 2014-2020 cycle and has received overwhelming support in both the Commission and plenary votes.

name: Mary HONEYBALL
text: in writing. ‒ Overall, I supported this report, which points to the core cohesion investments 2014-2020, which include energy efficiency, employment and the promotion of SMEs. The long-term, integrated and multilevel governance approach provides essential added value to the implementation of EU measures. This report also highlights the role of the European Parliament in scrutinising economic governance procedures relating to cohesion policy.

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. ‒ While this report is about promoting cohesion in the EU, the constitutional position of Scotland makes cohesion very difficult. The people of Scotland have clearly expressed at the ballot box a dislike for right-wing austerity politics, yet we have a right-wing austerity—driven UK government. Economic, social and territorial cohesion within Scotland can only be delivered by Scottish independence.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of a report setting out the main objectives of cohesion investments during the period 2014-2020: energy efficiency, employment and SMEs, areas where the potential for sustainable job creation seems promising. The report points to the need to increase and accelerate EU investment for the promotion of European cohesion. Its author denounces that in recent times, as a result of the crisis and austerity policies there has been a 15% drop in public investment in the EU. The object of the cohesion investments that Deutsch calls for to increase must be twofold: to alleviate the territorial and social inequalities within the continent, both of which are also related to each other, since the most impoverished regions are also the ones with the highest rates of unemployment and poverty. In this regard, it urges the EU to increase funds to combat youth unemployment, those aimed at the labour insertion of groups with difficulties in entering the labour market.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ Every three years the European Commission presents a cohesion report on the progress made towards achieving economic, social and territorial cohesion. The report underlines that the potential for creating sustainable jobs, especially for youth, is promising taken into account the investments during the 2014-2020 financing programming (in areas such as innovation, employment and SMEs). The report pays special attention to the future of cohesion policy after 2020. However, an analysis of the 2007—2013 period is necessary.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Jobs and Growth Investment Report: promoting economic, social and territorial cohesion in the Union, as I think cohesion policy is extremely important, both for urban and rural areas and for various sectors of the economy.  It is particularly important to point out that cohesion policy is extremely important for some Union countries by providing the funds necessary for investments. Cohesion Policy is the main instrument of the European Union aimed at reducing economic, social and territorial disparities across European regions. Cohesion policy investments have significantly mitigated the negative effects of the economic and financial crisis.  For all the reasons outlined in the report, I conclude that Europe needs more cohesion policy and needs to be discussed more in the European Parliament.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report by my colleague Tamas Deutsch, which takes stock of the implementation of cohesion policy in recent years. I welcome the adoption of this balanced text, which underlines the role that the Structural Funds have played in the face of the crisis and the fall in investment, while pointing out the many challenges that still need to be met. The adopted text also reinforces our fight for a profound simplification of regional policy, but also for a solution to the delays in payment and implementation in the european Union's regional policy. Small project owners such as SMEs are the most vulnerable to unfulacted commitments and the administrative burden that is too often excessive.

name: Josu JUARISTI ABAUNZ
text: in writing. The Deutsch report is clearly not 'our' report, as it does not reflect, inter alia, our firm position against the attempt to link cohesion policy to macroeconomic conditionalities. Despite this, the work carried out in recent months by the GUE/NGL team and our delegation as shadow rapporteur for this report has paid off, so the final text contains not a few of our views and amendments on the main objectives of cohesion. Our contributions have focused in particular on underlining the importance of cross-border cooperation, which is fundamental to Euskal Herria and one of the central points of our action in the European Parliament from the Committee on Regional Development.  The inclusion of these points has led EH Bildu to vote in favour of the Deutsch report which also criticises the serious problem of late payments. Of course, the question is whether the Commission and the Council are really going to be involved in a policy that instead of patching effectively combats regional disparities, which, rather than decrease, increase by the economic system and austerity policies.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I supported this report, which allows, among other things, a simplification of procedures for access to European funding. It is important to support all initiatives that are moving towards more jobs and more growth.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. The report argues, in Keynesian-like manner, that growth slumps are best offset by increased remittances to Brussels. I reject central Keynesian demand management, and hence the report.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report. Cohesion policy cannot be considered a mere instrument for other sectoral strategies. On the contrary, its long-term integrated and multilevel governance approach provides essential added value to the implementation and ownership of EU measures that a purely sectoral policy approach cannot deliver.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Mr Deutsch's report. The report sets out the key objectives of cohesion investment for the period 2014-2020, based on long-term, multi-level and integrated governance that delivers real European added value. The time has come to focus on energy efficiency, employment and support for SMEs in order to accelerate the exit from the crisis and create a job offer, especially for our young people.

name: Gabrielius LANDSBERGIS
text: Writing. \u2012 Cohesion policy has undoubtedly contributed to maintaining investment in less attractive regions in times of crisis, helping to address the challenges of sustainable, smart and sustainable growth, job creation and youth unemployment. More than EUR 350 billion have been allocated to the cohesion policy targets by 2020. the budget of eur 100 million. It is important that the new European Fund for Strategic Investments complements the objectives of cohesion policy, so that projects are not concentrated solely on highly developed areas, otherwise there is a risk that the gap between well-developed and less advanced regions, cities and rural areas can only widen. The problem of late payments, which complicates the implementation of projects, especially in the case of small beneficiaries, is necessary to address delays in the financing of project activities.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution on "investments in jobs and growth". Officially, cohesion policy would aim to reduce regional disparities and competitiveness gaps in the European Union. According to the rapporteur, it would be one of the only bulwarks against the current economic crisis, characterized by rising social inequalities and a massive decline in public investment. The Commission plays the role of the arsonist firefighter. At the same time, it calls for greater mobilization of Eu-largest funds to reduce these regional disparities. The rapporteur sometimes has good intentions, in particular in order to combat youth unemployment. But the solutions provided are derisory or even counterproductive: we want to simplify the procedures, but strengthen the administrations. We want to create synergies between services, but not pool their resources, etc.

name: Andrew LEWER
text: in writing. ‒ The decision of the British Conservatives to abstain on the Deutsch report reflects a mixed view of a text that contains both positive and negative elements. We welcomed, for example, the Rapporteur’s support for measures to cut red tape, improve ESI fund absorption, tackle the payments backlog (some EUR 28.4 billion by the end of 2014) and support the vital role of SMEs in creating jobs and growth. However, key paragraphs lacked clarity on budgetary consequences, suggested new legislative measures and inferred a level of EU involvement in some areas of national competence that UK Members were unable to support. In addition, though most British Conservatives support the European Fund for Strategic Investment, we do not believe that its main objectives should be economic, social and territorial cohesion. EFSI, in our view, should be firmly focused on granting a guarantee to economically viable projects likely to make a return.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I abstained in the final vote of this report because while it is true that it denounces the unjustifiable delays in payments of cohesion policy funds (amounting to around EUR 25 billion), the low level of absorption (or final receipt thereof), as well as the importance of reindustrializing the European Union and the necessary role of those funds in this regard , the final wording of the text includes congratulations on the new European Fund for Strategic Investments (Juncker Plan), the boost of public-private partnerships, or support for the conditionality of state operational programmes to the objectives of the European Semester and reform programmes. Therefore, without opposing some of the criticisms highlighted in the report, I think it is appropriate not to support a text that enhances political measures of European economic governance aimed at constraining the political capacity of public investment of administrations, thus having generated a very negative social and economic impact on the population.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. This is a report detailing different aspects of cohesion in economic, social and territorial matters. Among others, it is estimated that among the achievements of this policy is the stability achieved by different regions thanks to investments that have ensured a flow of financing at a time when national public and private investment has fallen and even ceased.  The main investment objectives for the period 2014-2020 include energy efficiency, employment and SMEs, areas where the creation and promotion of sustainable employment have a lot of potential. On the other hand, it also highlights the important contribution that European territorial cooperation can make to the integration of the continent.  Thus, the impetus that cohesion policies have given to the jobs and growth of European economies deserves to be strengthened and constantly promoted, which is why I am in favour of this report.

name: Krystyna ŁYBACKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I supported the report on investment for growth and jobs, promoting economic, social and territorial cohesion in the Union.  Modernising and strengthening cohesion policy will further reduce regional disparities and contribute to achieving the EU's employment and education growth targets. Cohesion policy should focus more on the renewal of Union industry, innovation, employment, education and entrepreneurship support.  We need new initiatives to combat youth unemployment and quality new jobs. In this context, we should link the fight against unemployment to the digital agenda, the European Structural and Investment Funds and Horizon 2020.  Furthermore, the role of education and training should be strengthened, paying particular attention to ensuring equal access to and guaranteeing quality education and promoting lifelong learning, vocational training and dual teaching.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 Economic growth cannot be lifted by subsidies and regulation of the economy. The only workable solution is the opposite. Low taxes, cutting red tape, and eliminating unfair subsidies at the expense of others.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒Cohesion Policy investments have significantly mitigated the effects of the economic and financial crisis and enabled stability in the regions. According to the latest Commission figures, cohesion funding has contributed to the creation of more than 700,000 jobs, the construction of nearly 4,000 kilometres of roads and 5 million people have gained internet access. I supported a report highlighting the importance of cohesion policy as the main instrument for reducing economic, social and territorial disparities between European regions with a view to sustainable development and competitiveness and for investing in the real economy with a budget of €350 billion. The report calls for the proper implementation of structural and investment funds, but meeting the purpose of the funds and mitigating negative trends is only possible through active action by Member State governments. What is worrying is the delay in the implementation of cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020, and we are in the second year of the financial perspective. I would like to recall that Member States need to be aware that the first unused funds are being deducted at the end of 2017 and these losses due to this delay will be large. Croatia lacks economic growth due to the Government's lack of knowledge of European policies, proper economic governance and administrative capacity, and I call on both our Government and the governments of other Member States to regularly discuss cohesion policy instruments and ensure a stable fiscal and economic environment for possible policy action.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing ‒ Channelling EU resources in co-financing projects during the financial crisis helped to cover shortfalls in Member States' public finances, which had a positive impact on job creation. Given the possibility of using these resources by the end of 2016, these beneficial effects may be further increased. Despite cohesion policy, which mitigated the impact of the economic and financial crisis, the reduction in regional disparities has not been achieved, as has been demonstrated in the poorest regions of the Union. Local and regional actors have to bear the brunt of late payments from Union resources, the most noticeable being the impact of the outstanding payments of EUR 24.8 billion at the end of 2014, in the programmes of the European Social Fund, the European Regional Development Fund and the Cohesion Fund. The Commission must therefore take measures to mitigate the negative impacts, while taking into account local problems and specificities in the granting of aid. At the same time, the revision of the measures taken is an opportunity to reassess the EU's priorities and assess their budgetary impacts.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on 'Investment for jobs and growth: promoting economic, social and territorial cohesion in the Union', for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 8/9/2015.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I vote AGAINST this cohesion policy that goes against our ideas. The European Cohesion Policy consists of distributing a 'Cohesion Fund' to reduce disparities between regions, this cohesion fund coming directly from Member States' contributions.  The Commission, which is the direct cause of these gaps in wealth and development, is therefore raising awareness by distributing more and more money.  Even if some good ideas are worth noting, among other things the fight against youth unemployment, most solutions are derisory, even counterproductive: the simplification of procedures but with a strengthening of administrations, the creation of synergies between services but without pooling resources...  Moreover, the mechanisms of control over the actual use of these funds remain limited or non-existent: this is one of the major problems of this policy.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Achieving social and territorial economic cohesion is an integral part of the Europe 2020 strategy. Investments in cohesion, such as energy efficiency and SMEs, sectors that promote economic and financial growth, are resources made available by social policy in order to increase job creation. It is therefore necessary for the EU to focus on the correct implementation of social cohesion policy which, it has demonstrated its ability to implement the negative impact of the economic and financial crisis on investment levels in the Member States.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. The need to promote economic, social and territorial cohesion in the Union is essential for the EU and we need to assess from time to time how this objective is achieved. The report on investment for jobs and growth, which we have supported, is a great job on the sixth cohesion report that has been presented and highlights the importance of the Investment Plan for Europe drawn up by the Commission. As on previous occasions, from Parliament we are making contributions to the need to ensure agility and efficiency in policies and in accessing and managing funds, and we call for action to help the sectors that have had the worst time with the crisis, such as young people, to succeed.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. The report argues that growth dips should be offset by increased use of funds from Brussels. Problems such as late payments, etc., are not addressed, central demand management from Brussels must be rejected. The call for Member States to ensure coherence between national programmes and cohesion policy must also be rejected, just as I reject the whole report.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. Cohesion policy, which is the EU's main investment policy and the MAIN instrument of the European Union, aims to reduce economic, social and territorial disparities. This 6th report on this subject shows that during the period 2007-2013, the crisis exacerbated the gaps between regions but that cohesion policy helped to mitigate its effects. But the weak point of this policy remains the conditionality of these funds in compliance with "macro-economic" rules. The report timidly criticises this conditionality in a way that is highly questionable for the sovereignty of peoples "refuses to allow regions, localities and citizens to be punished for decisions taken by national governments on macroeconomics". The report also denounces delays in payment which undermine the implementation of programmes (approximately EUR 25 billion for the 2007-2013 programming period). I abstain on this text to encourage awareness of the effects of austerity and cuts in public investment.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The European Cohesion Policy consists of distributing a 'Cohesion Fund' to reduce disparities between regions, with this cohesion fund coming directly from Member States' contributions.  The Commission, which is the direct cause of these gaps in wealth and development, is therefore raising awareness by distributing more and more money.  Even if some good ideas are worth noting, among other things the fight against youth unemployment, most solutions are derisory, even counterproductive: the simplification of procedures but with a strengthening of administrations, the creation of synergies between services but without pooling resources...  Moreover, the mechanisms of control over the actual use of these funds remain limited or non-existent: this is one of the major problems of this policy. I voted against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 The decisive role of EU cohesion policy in reducing regional disparities, promoting economic, social and territorial cohesion between member states' regions and supporting job creation is undeniable. Cohesion policy is the main EU-wide investment policy in the real economy and a recognised instrument of growth and jobs in the EU, with a budget of over €350 billion by 2020. During the economic crisis, cohesion policy is proving to be a key instrument for maintaining investment levels in several Member States. In some Member States, this policy is the main source of public investment.  Such incentives are already being noted in certain Member States, we must continue in these mechanisms to grow the economy. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in support of the report. This year’s report highlights great progress made by the EU’s cohesion policy in the categories of regional development, entrepreneurial incentives and investment, and reduction of red tape in the execution of policy to this end. I look forward to future progress on bringing about greater cohesion in economic and social matters across the EU.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this report which underlines that cohesion policy is the main instrument of the European Union aimed at reducing the economic, social and territorial disparities across European regions, boosting their competitiveness, tackling climate change and energy dependence, while at the same time contributing to the achievement of the Europe 2020 Strategy goals. It also underlines that even though they have been difficult for some Member States and regions to co-finance, cohesion policy investments have cushioned significantly the negative effects of the economic and financial crisis, and have given regions stability by ensuring the flow of funding when national and regional public and private investments have fallen sharply. It further underlines that cohesion policy funding was equivalent to 21% of public investment in the EU as a whole and to 57% in the cohesion countries taken together.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. Growth must not be an objective at all costs, resulting in unsustainable policies, excessive debt levels, undermining employment and social protection. Giving everyone the means to work, create and undertake is our responsibility. Reform of the labour market is therefore essential to create more and better jobs. We live in an increasingly competitive world that requires quality education. The manufacture of mid-range products will no longer find opportunities and low-skilled people will be increasingly marginalized. We need to act now and offer qualification programs to unskilled people. Businesses and social organizations must anticipate change.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. \u2012 Cohesion policy investments have long provided stability to regions by ensuring the flow of funds, even during the sharp decline in national public and private investment that accompanied the financial crisis. I am therefore very concerned about the significant delay in the implementation of cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020 and the non-use of appropriations already for 2014 for the European Structural and Investment Funds. Such unpreparedness and complications show that we must continue to simplify procedures at both EU and Member State level and reduce bureaucracy in order to increase accessibility and improve the absorption of EU funds.  In this context, I stress that public procurement should be a means of good governance and should be legislatively set up to allow for the rapid and flexible absorption of EU funds.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on investment for jobs and growth, which is very important in promoting economic, social and territorial cohesion in the EU.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 In accordance with the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, the European Commission prepares every three years a cohesion report on "progress in achieving economic, social and territorial cohesion..." Looking back at the 2007-2013 programming period, the Sixth Cohesion Report reports that cohesion policy has successfully dampened the impact of a significant fall in public investment of 20% on average in the EU. However, regional disparities have recently deepened and employment has fallen again and competitiveness has deteriorated, particularly in the southern Member States, following improvements since 2000. Looking to the future, the report marks an increase in energy efficiency, improved employment and support for SMEs for investments to be made in 2014-2020 as promising directions for the creation of sustainable jobs. The rapporteur welcomes the EU's new Investment Plan for Europe, which will complement structural and cohesion investments, but points out that this should not adversely affect the cohesion policy budget and its long-term strategic programming, as the regions most in need of investment incentives often have less administrative and absorption capacity and are therefore not eligible to participate in the new investment plan.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This report on investment in jobs and growth aims to promote the EU's economic, social and territorial cohesion. These cohesion policies aim to reduce regional disparities and the EU's competitiveness gaps. However, it is to forget that these disparities are largely fuelled by the existence of a single currency resulting in a divergence of productive capacities. In fact, under the guise of 'cohesion', this text aims to increase the EU's constraints on the eligibility of investment and to give more prerogatives to large regional communities at the expense of nation states.  The Commission, which is responsible for widening the competitiveness gap, intends to increase the mobilization of European funds to reduce regional disparities, thus acting as an arsonist firefighter. Finally, I challenge the use of funds to promote Roma integration. So I decided to vote against it.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 I endorse the relevant role of the European Union's cohesion policy for reducing regional disparities, in promoting economic, social and territorial cohesion between the regions of the Member States and in fostering job creation. I would point out that cohesion policy is the main investment policy at EUROPEAN union level and in the real economy and a recognised instrument of growth and jobs in the EU, with a budget of over €350 billion by 2020. I would point out that cohesion policy has been the one in recent years to mitigate the negative effects of the economic and financial crisis by enabling levels of public investment in the Member States to be maintainable. I cannot but warn of significant structural delays at the beginning of cohesion policy programming periods resulting from the delay in the adoption of operational programmes. I reiterate the original role of cohesion policy to promote economic, social and territorial cohesion and reduce regional disparities, in particular by supporting less developed regions.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. Looking forward, the report points to the core targets of cohesion investments 2014-2020: energy efficiency, employment and SMEs – areas where the potential for creating sustainable jobs is indeed promising.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on investment and growth. This text follows the publication of the European Commission on progress in cohesion policy. It underlines the urgent need to simplify procedures for access to European funding. The aim is to create growth levers to support employment in a context marked by the crisis and declining investment.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which highlights the undeniable successes of cohesion policy, particularly with regard to the European Social Fund (ESF), of which I am the permanent rapporteur in the European Parliament.
