The ESF supported 68 million project participations and ensured that 5.7 million unemployed or inactive people found employment. The ESF also reports that the number of cases of start-ups and self-employed workers is more than 400,000. The report stresses that the effects of these investments will be greater and greater over the next few years, as Member States have until the end of 2015 to make use of these funds from the 2007-2013 programmes. We must continue the effort for more social, economic and territorial cohesion in all the states of the European Union.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 We strongly support this measure as during the last few years experienced in crisis and austerity conditions, cohesion investments have given stability to the regions, ensuring a certain flow of funding, at a time when national public and private investment has faded and stopped altogether. The report also highlights how promising 2014-2020 programming investments are, in areas such as innovation, the digital and green economy, employment and SMEs, where the potential for sustainable job creation, particularly for young people. We have expressed our support for this measure, despite the fact that territorial cohesion policies still show considerable room for improvement, so that the Commission can already start work on post-2020 programming, on the basis of the indications received from the period 2007-2013.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report that includes new measures to increase effectiveness and result orientation, thematic concentration in particular on innovation, the digital and low carbon economy, education and SME support.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report in support of one of the European Union's most important policies, namely cohesion policy, which aims to reduce regional disparities, promote economic, social and territorial cohesion between the regions of the Member States and support job creation.  It is clear that by ensuring a stable fiscal and economic environment (as well as an efficient institutional, administrative and regulatory environment), the effectiveness of cohesion policy is guaranteed. In this respect, as the document suggests, Member States must regularly conduct high-level political debates in national parliaments on the effectiveness, efficiency and prompt implementation of funds, as well as on the contribution of cohesion policy to achieving the objectives undertaken.  Cohesion policy must be the fundamental instrument for maintaining the level of investment in the various Member States, and I am convinced that the objectives and means proposed will make my country, Romania, receive fair treatment.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I voted against this report because this report calls on the Member States to ensure coherence between national programmes and cohesion policy. I call for an improvement in the effectiveness of cohesion policy and for more quality of expenditure.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The previous programme did not achieve all the objectives of cohesion policy. The new policy programme 2014-2020 is aimed at employment and the promotion of SMEs, and for young people and education.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that a driving force for cohesion policy is needed, which plays a decisive role in reducing regional disparities and promoting economic, social and territorial cohesion between the different regions of the Member States. Cohesion policy is the most effective instrument for job creation at this time of economic crisis in the euro area. It is, in fact, the main investment strategy in the real economy. We need solidarity between the Member States in order to grow together. Cohesion policy needs clear progress assessment indices in order to determine possible implementation strategies at all levels. The imperfect functioning of this policy leads to structural delays which weaken its effectiveness. The EU's credibility is at stake because of backpayers for European Social Fund programmes. Europe needs a policy with simplified management procedures for the new funding period that is effective, efficient and leads to smart and inclusive growth.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – Cohesion policy is one of the most significant policies of the European Union. Thanks to it, Member States have been able to cope with the huge burden of the economic crisis we have witnessed in recent years. I voted in favour of my colleague Tamás Deutsch's report on investing in jobs and growth: promoting economic, social and territorial cohesion in the EU, because it adequately takes into account what has been done so far and sets out new policy guidelines in this area that will help overcome the challenges we face today.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Cohesion policy is one of the pillars of the EU MFF. Although we are still at the beginning of the 2014-2020 programming, it is important to call for the correct use of these funds for post-2020 now, as they are necessary for the homogeneous growth and development of Europe. I would also like to stress the importance of these funds for SMEs, which are particularly close to my heart, and I hope that we can create greater synergies between the Structural Funds, the COSME programme and Horizon 2020.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ In a time when we are facing chronic unemployment and an extremely poor economic situation, we must do everything we can to invest in creating new jobs that will create new conditions and perspectives for our citizens. Promoting and investing in economic, social and cohesion policies in the European Union is therefore of utmost importance. These are the main instruments that will help reduce the differences that exist between European regions, strengthen their competitiveness and create some new opportunities that will contribute to reducing unemployment and creating new jobs, which must be one of our priorities.  Investing in these policies and implementing them effectively will have long-term positive consequences. I therefore support this report, considering that we must make its implementation a priority, but also subordinate the further development of these policies to the needs of the citizens of the European Union.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This report on investment in jobs and growth aims to promote the EU's economic, social and territorial cohesion. These cohesion policies aim to reduce regional disparities and the EU's competitiveness gaps. However, it is to forget that these disparities are largely fuelled by the existence of a single currency resulting in a divergence of productive capacities. In fact, under the guise of 'cohesion', this text aims to increase the EU's constraints on the eligibility of investment and to give more prerogatives to large regional communities at the expense of nation states.  The Commission, which is responsible for widening the competitiveness gap, intends to increase the mobilization of European funds to reduce regional disparities, thus acting as an arsonist firefighter. Finally, I challenge the use of funds to promote Roma integration. So I decided to vote against it.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ The decisive role of EU cohesion policy is in reducing regional disparities, promoting economic, social and territorial cohesion between regions of the Member States and supporting job creation, as cohesion policy is the main policy of investing in the real economy at EU level and has proven a means of growth and employment in the EU with a budget of more than €350 billion by 2020.  I therefore support the rapporteur's proposal to introduce measures to invest in growth and jobs, as there has been a recent real 15% drop in public investment in the Union, and whereas in many regions, in particular those with demographic challenges, failed to contribute adequately to the Europe 2020 targets, in particular the main objective of achieving 75% employment by 2020, the target of reducing the number of poor people by 20 million and the objective of combating early school leaving. I also see the importance of this proposal in its fostering of strategic objectives with the potential of improving growth, job creation, social inclusion, environmental potential and climate change potential. High growth rates and regional economic convergence cannot be achieved without good governance given the need for more effective involvement of all partners at national, regional and local level.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. - Cohesion has always been a pillar of the European Union. The economic crisis affecting the Union has affected both each Member State and the European Union as a whole. The latest cohesion report, published every 3 years by the European Commission to measure progress made towards the economic, social and territorial cohesion of the Union, showed that we face a number of challenges in achieving our European policy objectives. There has been a drop in public investment by up to 60% in some Member States and around 20% at Union level. Unemployment has risen, with a particularly worrying percentage of youth unemployment reaching 4.85 million, accounting for 20%.  Nevertheless, in recent years, cohesion policy's ability to mitigate the negative effects of the crisis has been demonstrated, and I would particularly stress the importance of the Investment Plan drawn up by the Commission, as this is the first step towards addressing the shortcomings of public and private investment in the Union.  I support my colleague Deutsch's report and also agree with the recommendation on the need for further efforts to simplify procedures that will increase access and absorptice of funds, thereby balancing the Union's economic and social priorities on the one hand and social inclusion, education and sustainable development on the other.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: in writing. ‒ I am proud that the Parliament will continue with the cohesion policy to continue to grow the European economy. In the past, the cohesion policy has been the main tool used to help reduce economic, social and territorial inequalities across the European regions. I am satisfied that it has been able to react quickly with flexible measures to help tackle the investment gap between certain regions. However, I am warry about the significant delays in some of the programming periods, and am worried that theses postponements may hinder our economic growth. It is important that we continue to increase the efficiency and effectiveness so that our success may continue. Moving forward, we need to focus on SMEs, as the account for a vast majority of the economy in the Union, and also to look to education so that we can help create a strong, well-educated labour force so that our economy will remain strong.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 Energy efficiency, employment and SMEs, i.e. sectors with promising potential for sustainable job creation, are all key elements of the new cohesion policy 2014-2020. I agree with the rapporteur's line that the original role of cohesion policy and its instruments, as defined in the Treaty, make it in themselves the main policy instrument for achieving smart, sustainable and inclusive growth across the EU. Cohesion policy cannot be seen as a simple instrument for other sectoral strategies. In my opinion, its approach must be based on long-term governance. A governance that is possibly integrated and multi-level.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Cohesion policy is invariably the EU's main investment policy, also in the 2014-2020 budget. Investments in cohesion have undeniably helped mitigate some of the effects of the crisis by providing a significant proportion of public investment in some Member States. The main objective of this policy continues to be to reduce regional dissece and eradicate poverty in the poorest regions of the EU. In view of the above, and noting my opposition to the EC-imposed thematic concentration, limits and macroeconomic conditionality, I supported the report.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. The European Union's cohesion policy plays a key role in reducing regional inequalities and promoting economic, social and territorial cohesion within the Union and between different regions and states. Given the importance of this instrument, the European Parliament adopted an initiative report commenting on progress in cohesion policy but also pointing to possible areas for improvement. It also stresses the need to simplify procedures for access to finance. I have spoken in favour of this report and I support this European policy, a key tool for local and regional development.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union's cohesion policy, with a budget of more than EUR 350 billion by 2020, plays a decisive role in reducing the disparity between the levels of development of the most developed and less developed regions and the backwardness of the less favoured regions. In the report on investment, growth and employment, for the promotion of social cohesion, the rapporteur is of the opinion that cohesion policy has proven to be effective in responding to the economic and financial crisis, and to addressing the deficit in public investment in the Union. Flexible cohesion policy measures have enabled direct support for economic activity and employment, and have also promoted the stability of regions by ensuring the flow of funding for public and private national investments, either by reducing national co-financing or through additional advances in payments. In the future, the rapporteur believes that it will be vital to maintain efforts to simplify procedures and reduce red tape by increasing accessibility and absorption of funds. I voted in favour.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 I understand that the best way to integrate is to create jobs. The figures are clear: unemployment in the European Union has been increasing, with a higher incidence of long-term unemployment, reaching historical levels of around 5.1% (2013 data). With a budget of over €350 billion by 2020, cohesion policy is the main instrument for employment growth in the EU. But we still need more. I believe that the original function of cohesion policy – promoting economic, social and territorial cohesion in less developed regions – should be consolidated. In any case, and taking into account the opinions and suggestions of the various Committees, in particular the REGI Commission, the CULT Commission and the FEMM Commission, I am voting in favour of this report.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. Every three years, the Commission presents a report on progress towards economic, social and territorial cohesion in the EU. In the context of the crisis and austerity policies, when public and private investment at the national level ceased/decreased, this report shows that cohesion policy gave stability to regions, ensuring a flow of funding.  The report also notes the importance of investment during the 2014-2020 programming in areas such as innovation, ICT or the low-carbon economy, employment and SMEs, where the potential for sustainable job creation, especially for young people, is promising. Among other issues, the report denounces payment problems and arrears at the beginning of the current cohesion policy cycle, the need to improve the administrative capacity of public authorities, the lack of analysis of the problems of cross-border cooperation and calls for a view to post-2020 cohesion policy. Finally, I find the approach to macroeconomic conditionality balanced. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. Today I voted in favour of the report on 'investments in jobs and growth: promoting the economic, social and territorial cohesion of the Union'. An important vote on a policy aimed at reducing regional disparities and with a budget of 350 billion by 2020.  One criticism I would like to make about this policy is the delay in payment by the Commission. Putting in place a large-scale policy with a large budget only makes sense if aid comes in on time. I therefore strongly encourage the Commission to do everything possible to honour these outstanding invoices.  The new principle of governance is that funding can now be suspended if a Member State does not comply with the recommendations made in the economic governance process. In this regard, I am of the view that this means of pressure should only be considered as a last resort.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. Every three years, the European Commission shall report on progress in economic, social and territorial cohesion every three years.  The Sixth Report highlights, above all, the success of cohesion policy, in particular on investment and job creation under the European Regional Development Fund (600,000 jobs created and investment in 200,000 SME projects and 80 000 start-ups) and the European Social Fund (€68 million to support individual projects and more than €400,000 for the creation of start-ups and self-employed people). As the rapporteur points out, the effects of these investments are still expected to increase over the coming years, and member states will have until the end of 2015 to use the funds for the 2007-2013 programme. The core objectives of cohesion investments for the period 2014-2020 - energy efficiency, employment and SMEs - are also well highlighted in the report which, when complemented by the Investment Plan for Europe, will contribute positively to achieving the europe 2020 objectives for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth across the EU.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report setting out the achievements and key objectives of cohesion investment for the period 2014-2020: energy efficiency, employment and SMEs. Cohesion policy should not be seen as a mere tool for other sectoral strategies.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against because I consider the current European investment policy in favour of growth to be totally inadequate.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted in favour of a report setting out the main objectives of cohesion investments during the period 2014-2020: energy efficiency, employment and SMEs, areas where the potential for sustainable job creation seems promising. The report points to the need to increase and accelerate EU investment for the promotion of European cohesion. Its author denounces that in recent times, as a result of the crisis and austerity policies there has been a 15% drop in public investment in the EU. The object of the cohesion investments that Deutsch calls for to increase must be twofold: to alleviate the territorial and social inequalities within the continent, both of which are also related to each other, since the most impoverished regions are also the ones with the highest rates of unemployment and poverty. In this regard, it urges the EU to increase funds to combat youth unemployment, those aimed at the labour insertion of groups with difficulties in entering the labour market.

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. ‒ My vote in favour of this motion is conditioned by the following considerations. In all the interventions that are carried out at regional level, no matter what their scope, source of funding or sectoral placing, it is crucial to ensure that they fit into a strategy that attempts to counter the regional (and national) divergences that for systemic reasons are growing within the eurozone. The mechanisms that define the eurozone, including the absence of centrally funded Treasury mechanisms and of mutualised instruments for tapping financial markets, plus the wide range of endowments characterising the separate territories of the zone, are leading to transfers of resources from ‘south’ to ‘north’. It is crucial to ensure that cohesion funding is also analysed in terms of this phenomenon. It should be ensured that they contribute on a micro basis as well as within a macro-regional framework, to counter, or compensate for, this transfer of resources. It should also be ensured that cohesion funding and similar proposals do not unintendedly serve to further stimulate divergences by increasing a dependency of south to north over the medium to long term, leading to an increase in counter-productive resource transfer, rather than its reduction.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Cohesion policy undoubtedly has a positive impact on closing the gap between Member States, more and less economically efficient regions, increasing their competitiveness and creating jobs. At the same time, it has reduced its effects in times of crisis. Given the initial delay in approving operational programmes in the framework of the implementation of cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020, the cohesion policy should be considered as soon as possible after the end of this period. Lessons must also be learned from the mistakes of the previous period, as incorrect administration and the problem of outstanding payments lead to disproportionate burdens on the budgets of both beneficiaries and Member States.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I abstained in the final vote of this report because while it is true that it denounces the unjustifiable delays in payments of cohesion policy funds (amounting to around EUR 25 billion), the low level of absorption (or final receipt thereof), as well as the importance of reindustrializing the European Union and the necessary role of those funds in this regard , the final wording of the text includes congratulations on the new European Fund for Strategic Investments (Juncker Plan), the boost of public-private partnerships, or support for the conditionality of state operational programmes to the objectives of the European Semester and reform programmes. Therefore, without opposing some of the criticisms highlighted in the report, I think it is appropriate not to support a text that enhances political measures of European economic governance aimed at constraining the political capacity of public investment of administrations, thus having generated a very negative social and economic impact on the population.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: in writing. \u2012 Cohesion policy is one of the pillars on which European construction is based. Solidarity is its underlying principle that is being put to the test in the context we are experiencing financial and economic contraction. We must make every effort not to neglect this principle of solidarity and translate it into policy options that reflect it through the redistribution of resources and opportunities. More cohesion means providing more access to better living conditions for people and regions suffering from geographical, social and economic constraints. This concern must be present in all sectoral policies of the European Union, especially in times of crisis, such as the current one. Otherwise, we run the risk of cutting down, in a short time, the path of years already taken in favour of territorial balance and this with social and economic consequences that are hardly reversible without generational costs.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ In the plenary today I voted for this report. I welcome the new investment plan for Europe: it complements its structural and cohesion investments. Areas which are promising, as pointed out in the report, include the core targets of cohesion investments 2014-2020, which are: energy efficiency, employment and small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing ‒ I voted in favour of the draft legislative resolution on investment in jobs and growth by promoting economic, social and territorial cohesion in the Union. Cohesion policy is an important tool for achieving the objectives of Horizon 2020. The present report appropriately assessed the overview of the positive impacts of this policy, but at the same time also named its problematic areas and highlighted the objectives of its future direction.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ The aim of cohesion investments is to provide stability to regions by ensuring the flow of financial resources when national, public and private investments are absent. However, if we look at it from today's perspective, the differences between the regions deepened after the economic crisis and the gap is particularly noticeable in relation to the northern and southern regions of the Union.  I believe that the quality development of cohesion policy faces several problems. The first problem is related to non-payment and implementation of policies. This is due to a significant structural delay in the launch of cohesion policy programming periods, which was due to delays in the signing of partnership agreements and in the adoption of operational programmes for which Member States are responsible. Another problem, which should also be a long-term goal, is to improve the governance of cohesion policy at several levels where local and regional authorities must also assume administrative responsibility. The third problem he would like to highlight is too little initiative towards developing stronger territorial cooperation, in particular by developing cross-border cooperation.  I want to stress that the performance of Europe's border and cross-border regions in terms of dealing with the crisis needs to be improved with smarter, more inclusive and sustainable growth. The detection of key problems and objectives of cohesion policy is also essential in the current period 2014-2020 due to better preparation for the next programming period.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ Although the presentation of the sixth cohesion report has been delayed, I voted in favour of the report because it not only provides an overview of developments to date, but also presents a forward-looking perspective and highlights the main objectives of cohesion policy investments in the period 2014-2020. In particular, in the report, I welcome the fact that cohesion policy investments have provided stability to regions by ensuring the flow of funds in a situation where national public and private investment has fallen or even stopped altogether. On the contrary, I find it very worrying that the disparities between regions continue to widen and that many of the jobs created after 2000 are being lost. I consider very positive measures to be directed at supporting SMEs and improving the youth employment situation. However, I believe that if we really want to help small and medium-sized enterprises, we must create conditions for them that will not only simplify procedures and eliminate unnecessary bureaucracy, but will help them, in particular, in drawing on funds.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. Cohesion policy plays a decisive role in reducing disparities between regions, promoting economic, social and territorial cohesion between Member States and creating jobs. Cohesion policy is the main investment policy at EU level and in some Member States the main source of public investment, which has unfortunately decreased by as much as 15% recently. The Commission's sixth cohesion report shows that cohesion policy eased the impact of a sharp decline in public investment in the period 2007-2013, in some Member States by 60% and in the EU by an average of 20%, as it ensured the flow of funding at a time when national investment had fallen or dried up. Despite the very welcome positive effects of the cohesion policy to date, there is a need to go a step further in the future. The report calls for an even more targeted and profitable future cohesion policy, which can be achieved by shifting attention from the absorption criteria to the quality of spending and the high added value of co-financed projects. I, too, welcome the increased focus on results and the increased thematic focus of cohesion policy, in particular on innovation, education and support for SMEs, and I am therefore all the more pleased that members of parliament overwhelmingly supported the report in the vote.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ The apparent success of cohesion policy and its funds is evident in the many examples presented in this report. Adequate allocation of funds has allowed progress in some Member States as far back as they struggled with the recession.  The existence of unused parts of the fund, which are due in 2015, shows that countries in cohesion policy funds have had a constant friend through a difficult economic period. I support the report because Croatia, as the newest member of the European Union, quickly saw the advantage of accessing such funds. Croatia also expects improvements once the European Regional Development Fund is distributed by the end.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: I did not support the report in writing ‒ because I fundamentally disagree with how cohesion policy is perceived in it. According to the report, cohesion policy has prevented a slump in public investment in the EU as a result of member countries' cuts and has also helped to reduce unemployment. However, this view considers cohesion policy funds to be 'free money', which is not true. All money under cohesion policy comes from member countries' budgets and, ultimately, from taxes on employees and entrepreneurs. Cohesion policy has therefore not brought any new investment or increase in employment, but has only replaced part of the more efficient and genuinely required investments and jobs in the private sector with less efficient investments and jobs for which there was no real demand on the market.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ I support this report because of the facts that say that previously adopted cohesion policy is delivering results. For example, the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) has recently created almost 600,000 jobs, invested money in 200,000 SMEs and their projects, and 80,000 start-ups. He financed 22,000 projects dealing with research and cooperation of the business sector.  Likewise, the European Social Fund supported 68 million project participations, ensured that 5.7 million unemployed or inactive people became employed and made 400 000 start-ups and people engaged in them independently employed. However, which is also important to point out, the effects of these investments continue to grow and are expected to grow in the coming years as Member States use money from programme funds that were current from 2007 to 2013 by 2015.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report on a new EU Investment plan for Europe as it will complement structural and cohesion investments.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on investment in jobs and growth: promoting economic, social and territorial cohesion in the EU. Cohesion policy is the main investment capital and aims at creating jobs, competitiveness, economic growth, sustainable development and improving the quality of life of citizens. We can't give that up. In this day and age, we must look at cohesion policy in the context of the economic crisis and in the context of achieving the Europe 2020 objectives. I support strengthening the initial role of cohesion policy, namely the increase of economic, social and territorial cohesion in all regions of the EU, especially in the less developed and those with the least favoured, as the report also points out.

name: Kay SWINBURNE
text: in writing. ‒ I can welcome a number of aspects of this report of the Committee on Regional Development. It rightly calls for simplified procedures and the removal of red tape, in order to increase accessibility to these funds. It also recognises the important role SMEs play in creating jobs and growth, highlighting the need to deliver access to finance and also access to support programmes and training, which will promote the development of entrepreneurial skills. Finally, I am pleased to see it calling for greater efforts to manage payment backlogs, given the significant impact these delays can have on the ground. However, I maintain concerns about some elements of this report. In particular, I do not fully share its interpretation of the role of the new European Fund for Strategic Investment and I am disappointed to see the report making calls for European Commission action in areas outside of EU competence, such as the provision of childcare facilities.  For these reasons I was unable to give this report my full support at the vote and I therefore opted to abstain.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The economic crisis has a very serious impact on EU cohesion.  However, in order to solve the problems, we must admit that the neoliberal measures of harsh austerity have contributed to the deindustrialisation of the South, to the deregulation of industrial relations, to the dissolution of the social state, to the sell-off of public wealth, to the closure of many SMEs and to the increase in unemployment of young people in particular.  New policies are therefore needed in order to truly achieve economic, social and territorial cohesion in the EU. The real economy must be boosted, growth promoted and new quality jobs created. It is equally important to support public investment. Particular emphasis should not be placed on the states most affected by the economic crisis. Many of these are mentioned in the opinion of the ITRE Committee but unfortunately they are not taken into account in the report of the committee responsible for development. However, the report has some positive references. For example, it recognises the significant problems of unemployment, refers to the need to tackle disparities in the regions and stresses the important role played by SMEs and the need to support them. That is why we have abstained.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The report talks about growth and job creation, but at the same time proposes a continuation of policies that have yielded the exact opposite results.

name: József SZÁJER
text: Writing. \u2012 The report by Tamás Deutsch deals with the EU's premier investment policy, cohesion policy, which is the most audited and valued expenditure area of the EU budget with a budget of more than EUR 350 billion for the period 2014-2020. The Deutsch report contains ideas with which I strongly agree.  One of the central ideas of the report is that the effectiveness and credibility of cohesion policy can only be maintained if we eliminate the very significant payment arrears and preserve the scale of the EU's budgetary resources for cohesion policy.  The report will focus on unemployment, in particular youth unemployment and the ability of small and medium-sized enterprises to create jobs. In order to promote job creation, Tamás Deutsch calls for a coordinated use of the European Social Fund and the European Regional Development Fund, while also proposing to reduce the administrative burden on the at-risk in order to increase efficiency.  The report reaffirms the original objective of cohesion policy, reducing development gaps, while emphasising its contribution to achieving the Europe2020 Strategy's smart, inclusive and sustainable growth goals and its role in mitigating the devastating effects of the crisis. The Deutsch report is one of the most important regional policy documents of the 2014-2020 cycle and has received overwhelming support in both the Commission and plenary votes. As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report as I consider it an important task to promote economic, social and territorial cohesion in the European Union. I am pleased that the importance of this has finally been articulated from the Hungarian pro-government side and that the European Union (and its financial support) is essential. I am also pleased that the report also welcomes the creation of a European Fund for Strategic Investments, which can once again contribute a significant source of development to developments in the territory of the Member States. It should be noted, however, that since it is a direct and transparent resource, fortunately it will not be possible to allocate it to the government's political allies without public procurement. Climate change and energy dependency are one of the objectives of cohesion policy. However, I find it contradictory that while some Member States, in particular Hungary, spend EU funds naturally and with great pleasure, they impose a special tax on certain renewable energy sources. The report calls on all relevant actors, in particular the main authorities, to develop multi-level governance and coordination mechanisms to support CSD recommendations. The ethos of this proposal can also be interpreted as a country-specific recommendation where each proposal is assigned to a single political leader. I believe that, in order to promote cohesion, the development of complex programmes should focus more on local communities, to which the report refers in several places.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 If we want to have a competitive 21st century labour market in Europe, we need to manage both supply and demand policies for employment accordingly. It is important that young people starting their careers have the right qualifications and are aware of the need for continuous education or retraining. The European Parliament's report draws attention precisely to increasing the competitiveness of the EU labour market m.in. through efficient cooperation between universities, businesses, public and private employment services as well as workers, and the constant monitoring of future labour market trends and anticipating the need for skills and qualifications. I have chosen to vote in favour of the report because I believe that it adequately emphasises the problems and seeks solutions for them.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The economic, social and territorial cohesion of the Union is one of the strategic objectives of the European project. To achieve it, the European institutions have invested and invest considerable amounts of money, even in the context of the austerity regime imposed by the recent economic crisis.  The main areas covered by these investments in the current Multiannual Framework (2014-2020) are innovation, the digital and low-carbon economy, the creation of new sustainable jobs (especially for young people), small and medium-sized enterprises. However, there are also problems with late payments, the reduced administrative capacity of public authorities at local and regional level or insufficient cross-border cooperation. In the long term, there is a need for a serious debate on the issue, in particular on cohesion policy after 2020, including the lessons of the latest multiannual frameworks, both on the positive aspects and on the shortcomings.  The current document is only one step in this important process, the very purpose of which is to defend the interest of the European citizen. It must therefore be supported, in order to give further impetus to the cohesion policy of the European Union and the coordinated economic development of the Member States.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on investments promoting job creation and growth within the context of Cohesion Policy. The reports proposes different measures such as a thoroughgoing examination of the objectives and co-financing rates for the fund, enhanced action in developmentally disadvantaged regions and administrative simplification.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. As shadow rapporteur, I am satisfied with the final version of the report.  In accordance with the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, the Commission has an obligation to present every three years a progress report on the progress made in reaching the economic, social and territorial cohesion of the Union. Accordingly, on 23 July 2014, the European Commission adopted a report assessing the previous generation of cohesion policy implementation (2007-2013) and notes that it has mitigated the impact of severe cuts in public investment following the emergence of the financial and economic crisis. Nevertheless, regional inequalities due to the crisis have deepened further. The rapporteur primarily analyses the successes and challenges of cohesion policy in the context of the economic and financial crisis, and points out that the crisis has further highlighted the role of the Commission's cohesion policy in overcoming the crisis and combating the decline in public investment and a significant increase in unemployment.  I agree with the notion that multi-level governance, supported by partner principles, as well as the sectoral and territorial approach are the main strength and lever of this policy. I am pleased that the report also incorporates many ECR amendments that highlight the need to build a stronger and more effective administration, especially in those Member States that are least developed. Also, the report emphasizes the importance of focusing on efficiency and focusing on results and emphasizes the importance of avoiding politicization in the selection process. So I voted in favor.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. \u2012 Investment report for jobs and growth: promoting economic, social and territorial cohesion in the Union highlights the uneasy successes of cohesion policy. The European Regional Development Fund has created almost 600,000 new jobs, invested in 200,000 SMEs and supported 80,000 start-ups. It funded 22,000 projects for research and collaboration in the business sector, liading with 5.5 million people. At the same time, the European Social Fund supported 68 million individual participation projects, providing 5.7 million unemployed and inactive employment. It also recorded 400,000 reported cases of start-ups and people becoming self-employed. I supported the report because it emphasises that the effects of these investments are still increasing. This will be the case in the next few years, as Member States have until the end of 2015 to use the funds from the 2007-2013 programmes.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of a report setting out the main objectives of cohesion investments during the period 2014-2020: energy efficiency, employment and SMEs, areas where the potential for sustainable job creation seems promising. The report points to the need to increase and accelerate EU investment for the promotion of European cohesion. Its author denounces that in recent times, as a result of the crisis and austerity policies there has been a 15% drop in public investment in the EU. The object of the cohesion investments that Deutsch calls for to increase must be twofold: to alleviate the territorial and social inequalities within the continent, both of which are also related to each other, since the most impoverished regions are also the ones with the highest rates of unemployment and poverty. In this regard, it urges the EU to increase funds to combat youth unemployment, those aimed at the labour insertion of groups with difficulties in entering the labour market.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ With such large disparities in employment and unemployment between European countries, the role of cohesion policy of the EU in reducing regional disparities, promoting economic, social and territorial cohesion between regions and Member States and supporting job creation is essential. That is why I support this measure to strengthen this programme.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The philosophy of cohesion policy runs counter to the ideas we stand for. The Commission plays the role of the arsonist firefighter.  At the same time, it calls for greater mobilization of Eu-largest funds to reduce these regional disparities.  The rapporteur sometimes has good intentions, in particular in order to combat youth unemployment. But the solutions provided are derisory or even counterproductive: - they want to simplify procedures but strengthen administrations - they want to create synergies between services but not pool their resources Finally we strongly dispute the use of funds to promote roma integration. I vote AGAINST this text.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted in favour of a report setting out the main objectives of cohesion investments during the period 2014-2020: energy efficiency, employment and SMEs, areas where the potential for sustainable job creation seems promising. The report points to the need to increase and accelerate EU investment for the promotion of European cohesion. Its author denounces that in recent times, as a result of the crisis and austerity policies there has been a 15% drop in public investment in the EU. The object of the cohesion investments that Deutsch calls for to increase must be twofold: to alleviate the territorial and social inequalities within the continent, both of which are also related to each other, since the most impoverished regions are also the ones with the highest rates of unemployment and poverty. In this regard, it urges the EU to increase funds to combat youth unemployment, those aimed at the labour insertion of groups with difficulties in entering the labour market.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ The report is the EP response to the 6th Cohesion Report from July 2014 and the first positioning after the adoption of the new legislative framework. There continues to be broad support for Cohesion Policy as such and its Treaty objective of reducing regional disparities. Therefore, my vote was positive.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – I support this initiative. The creation of new jobs is one of the priority criteria. To create the basic conditions for the widest possible progress of society, to enable everyone to work, to work well and culturally.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. This report points out the role that regional development funds have played in Europe's economic crisis. The rapporteur also rightly addresses several of the most important issues to be reflected on the management and implementation of funds for the revision of the period 2014-2020 as well as the future configuration for the next multiannual financial framework. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour of that report.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 In a context of declining investment, as a consequence of the crisis, it is very appropriate to bring this cohesion issue which represents an eloquent response to all those who continue to believe, naively to believe that this European Union still has in its programmatic matrix values such as solidarity, cohesion or human rights. In this sense, the report's calls to ensure that cohesion investment should continue in 2014-2020, while stressing that there is no great margin for any optimism. Another relevant aspect of the report is the need to simplify administrative procedures for access to finance; promoting social inclusion, gender equality and the development of education and training; reducing unemployment and supporting SMEs, as well as establishing partnerships and developing public services.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The report argues that growth dips should be offset by increased use of funds from Brussels. Problems such as late payments, etc., are not addressed, central demand management from Brussels must be rejected. The call for Member States to ensure coherence between national programmes and cohesion policy must also be rejected, just as I reject the whole report.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing. \u2012 Cohesion policy aims to develop smart growth, to be pursued through energy efficiency and the creation of new jobs in the sustainable economy sector. Cohesion policy also has a duty to counterbalance the sharp decline in public investment, which has in some cases reached 60%, particularly affecting the southern regions. It is therefore essential that a long-term perspective be considered which supports SMEs, promotes employment, implements resources for young people and education, pay particular attention to the territorial dimension and promote homogeneous and constant regional development. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I rejected the European Parliament's resolution on 'Investing in jobs and growth: promoting economic, social and territorial cohesion in the Union'. The time for EU cohesion policy is now over. Cohesion has served to unite the Member States, cities and regions of the EU. To this end, the EU is setting up programmes, the five funds which together form the 'European Structural and Investment Funds'. In total, the EU has already spent more than EUR 500 billion on this. None of this has been of use, except that bridges without roads, airports without air traffic and illuminated motorways without cars have been built. The EU has failed mercilessly in its own task of helping to reduce economic, social and territorial inequalities between European regions.  I recognise the report's efforts to improve some things here, but I do not think this is actually possible. Only the abolition and rethinking, i.e. a complete change of policy, will help here. Inequality is a good thing – between people and also between regions. One should not try to equate people or regions. This can only end in central planning mismanagement and absurd incentives. And you can see that.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. – I voted for my own-initiative report on 'Investment for employment and growth: promoting economic, social and territorial cohesion in the European Union' by my colleague Tamás Deutsch. I welcome its initiative to produce this report, all the more so as the decisive role of EU cohesion policy in reducing regional disparities, promoting economic, social and territorial cohesion between the regions of the Member States and supporting job creation is undeniable. Cohesion policy is the main instrument for investment in the real economy throughout the Union and is an established instrument for growth and job creation in the EU, with a budget exceeding EUR 350 billion by 2020.  I welcome the fact that the rapporteur has invited the EC to pay particular attention to the situation of minority groups across the Union, as they face different forms of social exclusion and are therefore more likely to be affected by structural unemployment. The same report also highlights the key role played by SMEs in the context of job creation and highlights their potential to promote smart growth.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. \u2012 This report essentially analyses the Commission's sixth cohesion report and, in the future, sets out the key objectives of cohesion investment for the period 2014-2020: energy efficiency, employment and SMEs, i.e. sectors with promising potential for sustainable job creation. The rapporteur rightly focuses on strengthening the administrative capacities of public authorities, especially at local and regional level, and on the digital and low-carbon economy, education and support for SMEs. It also reiterates the delay in approving operational programmes and a backlog of payments for the 2007-2013 programming period. Mention should also be made of the worrying employment situation of young people. However, there are serious misgivings about the need for 'healthy' economic governance, as well as a particular paragraph welcoming the Juncker plan and its potential leverage effect, and stressing the need for the 'famous' complementarity between the latter and the European Structural and Investment Funds.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported this report because increasing EU cohesion is important and investment in employment is one of the main instruments. If we do not support youth employment, especially in less developed regions, people will leave these regions, resulting in depopulated regions in which we will have to invest far more money in a few years. From my point of view, it is therefore necessary that the use of the European Social Fund, the European Regional Development Fund and the Cohesion Fund and the Youth Employment Initiative should focus on this very problem.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 The report assesses the implementation of the 6th EU Cohesion Report, framing the schedule in the period 2007-2013 and the beginning of the period 2014-2020. The issue of Union Cohesion is an ever-changing discussion, as an objective which the EU has always expressed but has been constantly subaltern. It attaches importance to the 2014-2020 framework as a way of ensuring continued investment for cohesion – and stresses, in view of the delays in establishing member states' operational programmes, that there should be compensation for such delays and that such funding should not be lost. Like other positive factors, the report underlines the need to reduce regional disparities; the need to simplify administrative procedures for access to finance; promoting social inclusion, gender equality and the development of education and training; unemployment reduction and support for SMEs; partnerships and the development of public services. However, the report maintains that cohesion policies should be framed within the framework of the Europe 2020 strategy, the Specific Recommendations, the Macroeconomic Constraints and the European Semester. However, these policies are totally contradictory to the objective of cohesion. We voted against it.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: in writing. The Deutsch report analyses the Commission's Sixth Cohesion Report and sets out the key objectives of cohesion investment for the period 2014-2020: energy efficiency, employment and SMEs, i.e. sectors with promising potential for sustainable job creation. There are many positive elements, such as governance aspects; the need to strengthen the administrative capacities of public authorities; new measures to increase effectiveness and performance orientation, in particular on innovation, the digital and low-carbon economy, education, employment and support for SMEs. It also condemns delays in the approval of operational programmes and payments for the 2007-2013 programming period. However, there are serious concerns both about the need for 'healthy' economic governance and about the appreciation of the Juncker plan and its potential leverage, as well as the need for complementarity between the latter and the European Structural and Investment Funds. These reasons have already been reiterated by the M5S and which led me to abstain.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I supported this report, which concerns the evaluation of the European Year of Active Ageing. I believe that the elderly are an extremely important group of our population that will continue to strengthen, and the European Union needs to devote its support to active ageing, to support the expansion of our elderly's abilities, e.g. increasing their computer literacy, in order to support families who are able to integrate their elderly.  I think this is terribly important and that you can see the difference between countries as they look after their elderly. And that care is not just about what benefits we give seniors, how high pensions are, but just about what active benefits we allow them to enjoy. I therefore hope that the year of active ageing 2012 will continue and that the programmes will not end by evaluating the report and more or less forgetting this important material.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: – The European Year of Intergenerational Solidarity highlighted the importance of seniors in an ageing European society. In this context, my colleague Kukan's report also drew attention to the situation of mothers whose pensions are negatively affected by motherhood and unpaid childcare and family members. I have consistently stressed that this problem needs to be addressed with concrete measures. It is neither fair nor right that our society punishes mothers financially, even though its prosperity depends directly on the new generations of citizens who bring these mothers into the world and bring them to account and solidarity with others. I supported this report and I believe that concrete proposals will soon be on the table. At the same time, I appreciate that the European Parliament has adopted my proposal at the time and extended the year of active ageing by a year of solidarity between generations.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, honourable colleagues, i would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work. I was very pleased to support my colleague Kukan's report, because active ageing is a reality in the European Union. And so the question of intergenerational solidarity becomes like never before. According to the European Commission's estimates, the average age of Europeans will be higher than 50 in 2050. European countries must be prepared to make a difference, both in the economic, social, medical and educational areas. In principle, the scenes of fiction have become a reality when we answer the question of how to prolong a person's working capacity, how to enable them to adapt to the demands of the labour market. These and other issues are becoming more topical every year, especially in my country – Latvia, where the nation is also actively ageing. And to prepare for these changes, I believe that we need to start now– to take active action at European Union level. Thank you!

name: Marian HARKIN
text: – Mr President, I voted in favour of this report on active ageing and solidarity between the generations. Active ageing refers to many things: to health, anti-discrimination, access to adult education, transport, long-term care, also to the burden on family carers, and to employment and pensions. But this report is not just about active ageing. It is also about solidarity between the generations. We sent a very strong signal from this Parliament when we called on the Commission to assess the feasibility and added value of a new EU financial instrument to provide a minimum income for all EU citizens living below the poverty line. While I fully accept that minimum income is a Member State competence, nonetheless, if there is added value to an EU instrument, then at least Parliament needs to know.  Finally, we also referred to the fact that we deplore a situation where people’s patterns of employment are becoming more insecure. While this affects all citizens, it particularly affects young people.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I also supported Mr Kukan's report, because intergenerational solidarity is, in my opinion, one of the most fundamental ways of promoting the good development of society or of recoimizing the challenges facing European society. Ageing is a fact, demographic development is simply the reality as it is, and in my opinion, if many of us are emulicing support for young families, then in this context it is also necessary to sign up to support older families. And I subscribe to that. In other words, so that families can live together as much as possible. In order to develop even such stationary facilities, when you do not need to place your parent, grandparents in an institution with all-day care, but you can only place it there for a short time and then always pick it up. I think they are examples of good practice and good solidarity. I subscribe to it.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. The objective of the report is to extend the promotion of active ageing and to develop a positive social image of old age, facilitating the social inclusion of the elderly. While these are objectives with which I agree, their practical consequences are unclear - with one exception: pensions, the main source of income for older generation. The rapporteur's position is in favour of reforms of the pension system which, under the mantle of sustainability, reduce solidarity between generations and even within each cohort, by developing private pensions and reducing distributive progressiveness in the calculation and financing of public pensions. That's why I voted against it.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This report assesses the initiatives experienced to combat age discrimination. It lays down the concept of "active ageing" which consists of improving the health and quality of life of older people, by promoting their autonomy and participation in social life. To this end, they intend to develop the "Silver Economy", a sector of activity that meets the needs of the over-50s with adapted products and services. This text also encourages intergenerational solidarity and recalls the obligation to accompany the elderly with dignity.   Camouflaged behind good intentions, the report hopes that seniors will retire more and more later. The question would be the viability of our pay-as-you-go pension system, a model of intergenerational solidarity. Keeping seniors in the labour market as long as possible is about deferring the problem. This will only increase tensions in the labour market. Social accounts must not rebalance at the cost of an explosion in the unemployment rate. Finally, common sense dictates that seniors can fully enjoy the end of their lives after so many years of work.  So I voted against it.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I cannot support calls for further EU funding in matters which should be within the remit of individual nations.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. The year 2012 was declared the European Year for Active Ageing and Solidarity between Generations. The overall objective is to raise awareness of the value and various aspects of active ageing, to stimulate debate, exchange information and develop mutual learning, and to promote actions to eliminate age discrimination, overcome age-related stereotypes and remove barriers. I agree that the initiatives launched in 2012 for the European Year should be continued and implemented further. It is important to highlight the important achievement of the future convention on demographic change. I agree that the Commission should provide funding for this future convention, which is an open and large network, with more than 270 local and regional authorities, scientists and civil society organisations committed to tackling Europe's demographic change by promoting an environment conducive to older people.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. The "active ageing" as promoted by the EU seems to be only a wobbly and disguised way of combating unemployment by keeping older people in employment. I voted against this report, which aims to give the Commission new powers.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. In view of the major challenges posed by the active ageing of the European population, strong political commitments followed by concrete actions must be taken to ensure social inclusion, active participation and the well-being of all generations. The viability of public pension schemes, unemployment among the over-50s and discrimination against the elderly are all aspects related to the phenomenon of active ageing that must be at the heart of our concerns. Sharing the view that the European Commission needs to make more concrete progress towards the goals set in the wake of the 2012 European Year of Active Aging and Intergenerational Solidarity, I support this report and the initiatives to establish new networks of sharing of resources, projects and ideas between the private sector, the public sector and civil society.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This report aims to promote "active ageing" by keeping working seniors as long as possible by encouraging lifelong learning and imagining new forms of relationship with the employer, developing the silver economy, combating age discrimination or reforming tax policies on work... If the development of the "silver economy" is indeed to be taken into account and encouraged by the ageing of society and there is considerable research potential in this sector (Japan or South Korea have understood this), I will be vigilant as to the direction that the Commission wishes to give on this subject...

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Kukan report is acceptable and balanced, so I wanted to support it with my vote.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. Among the main challenges facing Europe is undoubtedly the demographic challenge posed by ageing. The aim of the European Year of Active Ageing and Intergenerational Solidarity was to increase awareness of the value of active ageing, stimulate information exchange, promote active ageing policies and create a framework for concrete actions by the Union, its Member States and all public and private sector stakeholders. The adopted report insists that demographic changes should be seen as an opportunity. Specifically, it is welcome that it has become clear that older people are not a burden, but, because of their experience, productive life and knowledge, they represent a benefit to society. It regretted, however, that new networks could not be established to share resources, projects and ideas between the public, private and civil society sectors and that companies would not be meaningfully reached. It also calls on the Commission to carry out a study on demographic decline and to draw up a communication on this problem and on the measures that could be taken at all levels to address it.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. The European Year of Europe 2012, due to solidarity between generations and active ageing, was very important for our people, as it provided a strong impetus not only for intergenerational solidarity, but also for the formulation of active ageing policies in the Member States. I think we can summarise that the European Year of Active Ageing has been a success ˗ the events and initiatives of the 2012 European Year have confirmed that older people are not a burden on the economy and society, but rather an asset because of their experience, achievements and knowledge. We must therefore continue to work to change false stereotypes about the ability of older people to work. Qualifications, experience, wisdom, loyalty to the employer must be no less valuable than a dashing youth, knowledge of foreign languages and computer skills. Discrimination on grounds of age, which may result from an unmotivated refusal to take up employment or a strong proposal to give up their place of work for younger people. There is also a need to encourage employers to adopt and retain older workers, to help improve their qualifications and adapt working conditions.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 2012 was declared the European Year of Active Ageing and Solidarity between Generations. The main objective was to facilitate the creation of a culture of active ageing in Europe, based on a society open to individual people of all ages. The different LEVELS of the EU have made a significant contribution to achieving these objectives. However, not everyone was able to fully exploit its potential due to delays in the implementation schedule. The EU website has been widely praised for its cost-effectiveness, but its hits have fallen short of previous European years. Social media activity also appeared to be limited by participants and stakeholders, at least at EU level. At EU level, the 2012 European Year and other ongoing policy activities, such as the White Paper on Pensions, the Demographic Forum, the European Innovation Partnership on Active and Healthy Ageing and the planned Accessibility Act, complemented each other well. I therefore voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. \u2012 The year 2012 was set for the European Year of Active Ageing and Solidarity between Generations and presented an excellent opportunity for the exchange of good practices within the EU. One of the main objectives of this European Year is to raise awareness of the importance of active ageing and its dimensions. Active ageing enables us to exploit the great potential that older people represent in society, enriched by exceptional experience and wisdom. I believe that the demographic change facing Europe should be seen as an opportunity to improve the quality of life in the ageing process and make society more friendly, rather than a burden on European society. Recognising the contribution of older people and strengthening the positive role they play in society and working to improve intergenerational dialogue is key to achieving this objective. Intergenerational solidarity can only be achieved through mutual respect and cooperation between individual social groups. Solidarity among the elderly, too! An excellent example of this is the Slovenian project "Old for the Old", which is based on assistance among the elderly with the support of local communities as well as the non-governmental sector. I am therefore happy to support solutions at European level that will enable older members of society to live their age and be better integrated into society.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ If we take into account that, according to estimates in 2050, the average age of Europeans will be above 50 years, it is necessary to develop certain goals for the sake of sustainability of the demographic situation. This is one of the reasons why 2012 declared itself the year of active aging. The concept was conceived very well: in addition to lifelong education and employability of the elderly, great attention was paid to the positive role they play in society.  This report assesses the results achieved in detail and in real terms, and that is why I support it.

name: Louise BOURS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report because it was a complete and abject failure. Far from lauding the success of the year’s communication campaign, nobody in the real world has ever heard of it, nor did it help anyone in genuine need. It was just another propaganda exercise for the EU and a complete waste of taxpayers’ money.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report. The report’s title suggests it is an assessment of the EU’s Year of Active Ageing, but that is only one element of it and it goes well beyond. There is a lot of good content in the report that I would support in terms of preventing discrimination against older people, ensuring participation in public life, at-work inter-generational mentoring and more. But a major element of the report focuses on raising the Member States’ retirement ages, which it frames as being mandatory and inevitable, and also contains a proposal that would have the effect of reducing the pension for long-term unemployed people. I voted against this report on the basis of the calls to raise the retirement age and pension issues.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this text because I am convinced that the European Year of Active Ageing and Solidarity between Generations 2012 has achieved a number of important results, although some issues remain unaddressed. The involvement of the population over 50 must be a central objective of the Union's policy, which would have immense positive repercussions on the entire economy of the continent.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 The balance sheet of the European Year of Active Ageing is broadly positive. In most countries, the planning envisaged in the national programmes at the beginning of the European Year 2012 has been widely respected. The most satisfactory results have been achieved in raising awareness through initiatives and events at EU and national level. The European Year achieved the intermediate objectives of strengthening existing networks, creating synergies and partnerships between different administrative levels and strategic areas, promoting long-term policies and strategies and accessibility of technological, organisational and social innovations. However, the objective of setting up new networks has rarely been achieved. The development of global policies, strategies and programmes at national level on active ageing in a number of countries demonstrates the political impact of the European Year 2012. The objective of mobilising stakeholders on the theme of active ageing and intergenerational solidarity has been achieved and this can be a stimulus to improve the next Thematic Years and implement a more effective organizational and communication policy.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This report assesses the initiatives experienced to combat age discrimination. It lays down the concept of "active ageing" which consists of improving the health and quality of life of older people, by promoting their autonomy and participation in social life. To this end, they intend to develop the "Silver Economy", a sector of activity that meets the needs of the over-50s with adapted products and services. This text also encourages intergenerational solidarity and recalls the obligation to accompany the elderly with dignity.  Camouflaged behind good intentions, the report hopes that seniors will retire more and more later. The question would be the viability of our pay-as-you-go pension system, a model of intergenerational solidarity. Keeping seniors in the labour market as long as possible is about deferring the problem. This will only increase tensions in the labour market. Social accounts must not rebalance at the cost of an explosion in the unemployment rate. Finally, common sense dictates that seniors can fully enjoy the end of their lives after so many years of work. So I voted against it.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 It is obvious that older people should not be a burden on society. In this respect, capacity-building is necessary in order to promote their active participation in society. Unfortunately, there are large differences between regions in addressing the involvement of third-age citizens in society, which needs to be changed through social protection, support infrastructure and budgetary resources. There is a need to develop strategies for active ageing that are more targeted and more effective in order to ensure social inclusion, active participation and the well-being of all generations. I voted in favour of the Report on implementation, results and overall evaluation of the European Year of Active Ageing and Solidarity between Generations (2012), because older people must be given the opportunity to play an important role in society and promoting active ageing must continue to be a priority for the EU.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Balanced and responsible text. I am voting in favour

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 After careful reflection and discussion in plenary, I voted today in favour of the report on the implementation, results and overall assessment of the European Year of Active Ageing and Solidarity between Generations (2012).  I agree with the rapporteur that the sustainability of the results obtained is of the utmost importance, as are the two results of active ageing and solidarity between generations and the active ageing index. I am also convinced that demographic changes in Europe should be seen as an opportunity, rather than a burden on European society, as expressed by the rapporteur. I therefore agree with the motion for a resolution and the call for the development of a 'silver economy' on the basis of the economic opportunities arising from public and consumer expenditure linked to the ageing of the population.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report. The report’s title suggests it is an assessment of the EU’s Year of Active Ageing, but that is only one element of it and it goes well beyond. There is a lot of good content in the report that I would support in terms of preventing discrimination against older people, ensuring participation in public life, at-work inter-generational mentoring and more. But a major element of the report focuses on raising the Member States’ retirement ages, which it frames as being mandatory and inevitable, and also contains a proposal that would have the effect of reducing the pension for long-term unemployed people. I voted against this report on the basis of the calls to raise the retirement age and pension issues.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ I will not support calls for further EU funding in matters which, in my opinion, should be within the remit of individual nations.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ The European Year for Active Ageing and Solidarity between Generations (EY 2012) has increased awareness of the contribution that older people make to society. Amongst others, EY 2012 has also given political momentum to policy initiatives and discussions in order to face and adapt to the challenges and opportunities that longer life expectancy presents. It is now my hope that this momentum is kept up by Member States and work on strategies to promote and sustain active ageing in their countries. I concur with the points raised in the report and voted in favour. I believe that older citizens can be active participants in an age-integrated society, both as active contributors as well as beneficiaries of society.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution on the implementation, results and overall assessment of the European Year of Active Ageing and Solidarity between Generations was voted on. I abstained because paragraph 17 of Mr Kukan's report states that Member States should apply incentives for companies to employ more older workers and take measures to facilitate the extension of working life. I don't think it's in the worker's interest.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. According to the rapporteur's logic, the pension problem would be solved by making the elderly work, which is only a disguised attempt to keep older people in employment in order to combat unemployment. So I voted against it.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We recognise and believe that the European Year 2012 has given considerable political dynamism and contributed to the development of a debate on the challenges of active ageing and intergenerational solidarity in Europe. We encourage and recommend that all Member States promote and strengthen, through their social security systems, high-quality public infrastructure for the elderly (nursing homes, day care centres, home care), where the elderly are treated as active participants and not as passive recipients of the initiatives in which they take part.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the assessment of the European Year of Ageing and Solidarity between Generations. Active ageing is the process in which health, participation and safety opportunities are optimized to improve the quality of life of ageing people. The European Year has achieved two main results: the active ageing index and the guiding principles in favour of active ageing and solidarity between generations.
