In addition, Parliament called on the Commission to support the forthcoming Covenant of Mayors on Demographic Change, a comprehensive network that already brings together 270 local and regional authorities, researchers, civil society organisations and which has committed itself to tackling European demographic change by promoting age-friendly environments, in close cooperation with the World Health Organisation.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because, once the objectives of the first report have been achieved in 2012, there will be a need on the one hand for new funds to fill some problems related to understanding strategies and, on the other hand, for new plans for some countries where they have not been better understood. I am convinced that the European Union's proposals to propose measures to combat the unemployment of people over 50, together with increased incentives to employ more adults, are of fundamental importance, especially at a time when we need to get out of the crisis. I therefore consider the European Union to be positive because it aims to defend discrimination against people of age on the edge of the labour market, who are affected by structural changes in the world economy.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this non-legislative and non—binding report because the project was a complete failure. Far from lauding the success of the Year’s communication campaign, nobody in the real world ever heard of it, nor did it help anyone in genuine need. It was just another propaganda exercise for the EU and a complete waste of taxpayers’ money.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU population is ageing as a result of low birth rates and increasing life expectancy. Active ageing allows people to realise their potential for physical, social and political well-being throughout their lives, while giving them adequate protection, security and care. This important topic was the central theme of the European Year 2012, which took shape important long-term projects designed to raise public awareness of the importance of active ageing, promote exchange between generations for mutual learning and provide a favourable framework for the adoption of concrete measures and commitments. Although these preliminary objectives have been achieved at national level overall, I agree with the measure that the policies outlined during the European Year should be the starting point for a common and uniform path to the creation of new networks which, through synergies and partnerships between different administrative levels and policy areas, promote long-term policies and strategies and make technological innovations accessible. , organisational and social. In order to achieve these goals, I think it is essential to follow the active ageing index and the guiding principles in favour of active ageing and solidarity between generations, given the most important results of the European Year 2012.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. The objective of the report is to extend the promotion of active ageing and to develop a positive social image of old age, facilitating the social inclusion of the elderly. While these are objectives with which I agree, their practical consequences are unclear - with one exception: pensions, the main source of income for older generation. The rapporteur's position is in favour of reforms of the pension system which, under the mantle of sustainability, reduce solidarity between generations and even within each cohort, by developing private pensions and reducing distributive progressiveness in the calculation and financing of public pensions. That's why I voted against it.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 2012 was the European Year of Active Ageing and Solidarity between Generations in the EU, and a number of initiatives have been taken at EU level to improve the quality of life in old age and address the new challenges posed by demographic change. The phenomenon leaves almost no EU Member State untouched, it is a social, political and economic issue that needs more and more attention. The parliamentary report assesses the results of the year and states, inter alia, that the initiatives started should be continued.  An important result of the report is the convening of the forthcoming EU Convention on Demographic Change, which could add new dimensions to address the challenges posed by this phenomenon.  The text also encourages Member States to use available EU funding opportunities to achieve active ageing policy objectives: European Structural and Investment Funds, Horizon 2020, the European Programme for Employment and Social Innovation, the Public Health Programme. The Central European region also desperately needs EU funds in this area in order to meet the changing health, educational and economic needs of older generations. In line with the foregoing, I voted in favour of the report by Member Eduard Kukan.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ The report aims to assess the efforts made by the EU in the year 2012 designated as the ‘European Year for active ageing and solidarity between generations’. I agree with the rapporteur that the initiatives launched in that framework should be followed up and continued. He considers it necessary to develop the ‘silver economy’, based on economic opportunities arising from public and consumer expenditure related to population ageing and the specific products, services, innovative solutions and needs of the population over 50 resulting in new jobs and growth. There are indications that the effects of the European Year 2012 are lasting beyond the year itself – for example, Austria, Estonia, Slovenia, Slovakia and the Czech Republic all adopted long term policies on the subject during 2012. I agree with the views expressed in this review and I therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. \u2012 It is regrettable that older people are still often exposed to discrimination on grounds of age, stereotypes and obstacles, and I therefore believe that Member States must implement the Equal Treatment Directive without delay and correctly in terms of employment and employment.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. Following the 2012 European year of active ageing and intergenerational solidarity, this evaluation report gives a positive assessment of this year and indicates that the objectives have been achieved overall despite a reduction in the budget. The rapporteur welcomes the two main results of this year's guidelines on active ageing and solidarity and the active ageing index. The Rapporteur encourages Member States to use these principles more systematically and stresses the need to increase coordination among all stakeholders at different levels. The rapporteur also calls for better targeting of funds in the context of the European years. Considering that this report is balanced and that active ageing and intergenerational solidarity is a major societal issue, I voted for this text.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. The European Year of Active Aging and Intergenerational Solidarity in 2012 was an opportunity for individual Member States to raise public awareness of the importance of this issue. That is why I voted in favour of this text because it is necessary to fight against discrimination and stereotypes. We must therefore continue to support initiatives that go in this direction.

name: Diane DODDS
text: in writing. ‒ I very much welcome the premise of this report: harnessing the skills and meeting the needs of older persons in our society. We all have a role to play to promote a vision in which people’s experience and potential is not lost as we grow older. In the last parliamentary term, I was delighted that the Commissioner for Inclusion, Marianne Thyssen, agreed to lend her official support to my publication Signposts to Older People in Northern Ireland. This advice guide covered many of the aspects identified in today’s report, including the need to support older people in maximising entitlements, obtaining help when in ill-health, staying safe, tackling elder abuse and getting involved in their local communities, be it through employment, education or volunteering. The response, I am glad to say, has been overwhelming. Raising awareness of services and information available is invaluable. This report specifically highlights the rising scourge of dementia, which affects approximately 19 000 people in my own constituency, particularly older people, and which demands increased support from Government and the voluntary sector. It has long been my view that national governments are primarily responsible for leading this fight with direct measures, but raising awareness at all levels is key.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. We are voting in favour: the report does propose measures in favour of the elderly and draws attention to the most critical problem of under-birth.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: in writing. \u2012 2012 was the European Year of Active Ageing and Solidarity between Generations. The report on the implementation of Kukan assesses the results of the various initiatives on active ageing and monitors progress towards these objectives, not least because it is essential that, given Europe's ageing population, tools are developed to support the elderly by promoting an inclusive and sustainable society. Despite the fact that an amendment by my colleague Laura Ferrara has been adopted, which highlights the added value that a new European financial instrument could have to guarantee a citizenship income for citizens below the poverty line, the report provides that Member States must apply incentives for companies to employ more older workers and take measures to facilitate the extension of working life; As a result, I abstained.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 The initiatives launched under the European Year 2012 will be monitored and continued as the sustainability of the results is of the utmost importance. One of the main results for which it is important for the European Commission to make investment available is the impending EU Pact, an open and large network, which already brings together more than 270 local and regional authorities, researchers and civil society organisations committed to responding to demographic change in Europe by promoting age-adapted environments in close cooperation with the World Health Organisation. Another key point to consider would be to recognise the contribution of older citizens and strengthen the positive role they play in society and work to improve intergenerational dialogue. I therefore agree that it is essential to promote age-adapted environments, taking into account impending demographic developments as well as the development of the 'senior economy' on the basis of economic opportunities resulting from public and consumer expenditure related to an ageing population and with certain innovative products, services and solutions and needs of the population over 50 years of age , which generates new jobs and growth.

name: Christofer FJELLNER
text: Written. \u2012 We Moderates have voted in favour of the evaluation of the European Year of Active Ageing. It is good that Member States are exchanging best practices in this area, thereby refineling the various national measures to stimulate active ageing and make better use of the skills of older people. However, issues relating to pensions, the labour market and social security fall within the scope of national competence. We are particularly critical of the call for an evaluation of a new European financial instrument for minimum income. These issues belong in the Member States, and we Moderates do not want to bring them up at European level.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report and commending the two main achievements of the European Year 2012, namely the basic principles of active ageing: solidarity between generations and the active ageing index.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this report because it does propose measures in favour of the elderly and draws attention to the most critical problem of under-birth.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ Active ageing policies shouldn't be considered only as an instrument to maintain the employability of older workers, but as an opportunity for older citizens to enhance the positive role they play in the society. I support the idea stated in the report that linking the retirement age only to life expectancy fails to take account of the importance of labour market trends and is therefore not the only instrument to tackle the challenge of an ageing society; instead, through their employment protection legislation and systems of wage formation Member States should support the recruitment of older workers especially before their statutory retirement age, as unemployment would have further negative effects on their retirement income, and ensure sustainable social protection systems.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Kukan report because, with the significant demographic changes we are facing the coming 10-20 years, it is high time Member States set up a more active ageing culture. The EU should fully support this. In this respect, I believe the European Year for active ageing and solidarity between generations in 2012 was a crucial initiative. Now it is key for Member States to support the recruitment of older workers, especially before their statutory retirement age. These people often have invaluable experience and can help coaching new young colleagues. We cannot afford to lose their experience and know-how, especially given the current difficult economic context. I would ask the honourable Members to think about their own future. We have to see ageing as an opportunity, not a burden. Let us take this message home.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted against the Report for having a partially and fully oriented view of the productive work of the active ageing of older people. Throughout the report, the statement that the well-being of older generations does not lie in perpetuating their connection to the labour market is not incorporated, but that this well-being lies in creating the conditions for them to receive fair pensions after a lifetime of work, which can only be achieved through the development of the countries comprehensive (economic) , human, cultural, social, participatory, n discriminatory, etc.) and with policies that promote stable and safe employment for all generations. Because the Report implicitly but repeatedly sends conflicting messages about the active ageing and role of older people who are regarded as mere labour force, we do not support them because their content can lead to the rise of retirement age, precarious industrial relations and the destructiveness and privatization of social security systems. That is why we are against this report.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ Alongside my friends in the European Parliamentary Labour Party, I voted in favour, so that we ensure that older people who find themselves unemployed, who experience difficulty re-entering the labour market are not left behind or forgotten, and that we show solidarity between generations. I believe that active ageing policies, should not only address how to ensure the employability of older workers, but should also enhance opportunities for older citizens to have a positive role in society.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted favourably on the report on the assessment of the 2012 European Year for active ageing and solidarity between generations. I find it very important to look for the best solution and get the most of the situation of the ageing population, although it seems as an entirely negative circumstance. First of all, we should maintain the optimal conditions of the employability of older workers, as it could be achieved by updating their skills during the training sessions. Also, it is important to promote age-friendly environments that would contribute to the development of equal opportunities. Most of all, I believe that the initiatives launched in the frame of the EY 2012 should be followed-up and continued.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 2012 was declared the European Year of Active Ageing and Solidarity between Generations. The main objective was to facilitate the creation of a culture of active ageing in Europe, based on a society open to individual people of all ages.  I welcome the specific objectives of this initiative, which include general awareness of the value and various areractions of active ageing and the fight against age discrimination, as well as combating age-related stereotypes and supporting activities to help remove barriers. In line with the rapporteur, I believe that the initiatives launched in the framework of the 2012 European Year should be monitored and continued; sustainability of results is key. I welcome the two most important achievements of the European Year 2012: the principles for promoting active ageing and solidarity between generations and the indicator of active ageing, and I urge the Member States to use them more actively and to set targets on this basis through comprehensive strategies for active ageing and to monitor progress towards these objectives.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the report on the implementation, results and overall evaluation of the European Year 2012 for active ageing and solidarity between generations, because I think we can say with good reason that the European Year for Active Ageing and Solidarity between Generations has been a great success throughout Europe. The declared aim of the European Year was to establish a 'culture of active ageing' for Europe that promotes vitality and respects the dignity of all. I believe that this has been achieved thanks to the efforts of many volunteers. Families are the place of a lived solidarity of the generations and the first to make active ageing possible. In this context, i would like to thank you in particular. The broad approach of the European Year 2012 was a concept of success and mobilised the social masses. Similarly, I would like to see this for the European Year 2016. That is why I have proposed making it the 'European Year against Violence'. I hope that this proposal will be supported.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "Ladies and gentlemen, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. The increase in life expectancy is one of humanity's greatest achievements, but it is followed by greater social requirements and the need for additional public services. An ageing European society is, on the one hand, a challenge for public budgets and, on the other hand, a great capital of experience and a wealth of potential mentors for the entering generation.  However, I would like to draw attention to a very important part of this report, namely the coping of older people in a digital society. More and more services are available on the Internet. More and more jobs are being created to digitise societies. However, according to the Scoreboard of the Digital Agenda for Europe, only 20% of people over the age of 55 have sufficient skills to cope in the digital environment and 41% of over-55s have never used the internet. This is due to difficult access to training and a lack of assistance in professional retraining. These two factors should be at the heart of further action if we want older people to be actively involved in the labour market and not be digitally excluded. I congratulate the rapporteur on a well-prepared report and I am pleased that the founding of the European Year of Active Ageing and Solidarity between Generations, which took place in 2012, has been successfully implemented in many senior communities.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. The actions and objectives launched in the context of the European Year for Active Ageing and Solidarity between Generations in 2012 should be continued and further addressed. Older people are not a burden for today's society, but a great opportunity.

name: Mike HOOKEM
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report because the project was a complete failure. Far from lauding the success of the Year’s communication campaign, nobody in the real world ever heard of it, nor did it help anyone in genuine need. It was just another propaganda exercise for the EU and a complete waste of taxpayers’ money.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. We voted against the Report for having a partially and fully oriented view of the productive work of the active ageing of older people. Throughout the report, the statement that the well-being of older generations does not lie in perpetuating their connection to the labour market is not incorporated, but that this well-being lies in creating the conditions for them to receive fair pensions after a lifetime of work, which can only be achieved through the development of the countries comprehensive (economic) , human, cultural, social, participatory, n discriminatory, etc.) and with policies that promote stable and safe employment for all generations. Because the Report implicitly but repeatedly sends conflicting messages about the active ageing and role of older people who are regarded as mere labour force, we do not support them because their content can lead to the rise of retirement age, precarious industrial relations and the destructiveness and privatization of social security systems. That is why we are against this report.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that EU is facing unprecedented demographic, social and structural changes that have to be addressed immediately. The Commission should study the worrying problem of unemployment among people over the age of 50 and the rising level of long-term unemployment. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Proposal for a Resolution of the European Parliament on the Implementation, Results and General Assessment Report of the European Year of Active Ageing and Intergenerational Solidarity 2012, as I believe that during this year citizens' awareness of the physical, social and mental well-being of individuals, but also of the community has been raised through various events, campaigns and activities.  It is also important to emphasise the benefits of exchanging best practices between Member States on active ageing and the problems faced by older people and on the positive impact of intergenerational solidarity and dialogue. I therefore believe that such activities and policies should continue to make the European Union as ready as possible to address demographic change and challenges.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. This report assesses the initiatives experienced to combat age discrimination. It lays down the concept of "active ageing" which consists of improving the health and quality of life of older people, by promoting their autonomy and participation in social life. To this end, they intend to develop the "Silver Economy", a sector of activity that meets the needs of the over-50s with adapted products and services. This text also encourages intergenerational solidarity and recalls the obligation to accompany the elderly with dignity.  Camouflaged behind good intentions, the report hopes that seniors will retire more and more later. The question would be the viability of our pay-as-you-go pension system, a model of intergenerational solidarity. Keeping seniors in the labour market as long as possible is about deferring the problem. This will only increase tensions in the labour market. Social accounts must not rebalance at the cost of an explosion in the unemployment rate. Finally, common sense dictates that seniors can fully enjoy the end of their lives after so many years of work. So I voted against it.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Eduard Kukan's report on active ageing and intergenerational solidarity. 2012 was proclaimed the European Year of Active Aging and Intergenerational Solidarity. This has resulted in European events as well as national programmes, which the report takes stock of. I welcome the adoption of this report, which calls for a study on demographic decline, the accessibility of technologies for ageing European societies and the protection of individual autonomy. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report. One of the great challenges of this century is to cope with the ageing of our populations in Europe. The reason I voted for this report is because it sees it as an opportunity to support ageing economically, through the growth it can generate, but also socially by strengthening the link between generations. Our seniors have a place in our societies and they are a real asset.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. The report highlights the problems for societies at an ever-increasing average age and also makes some constructive suggestions on how to promote active ageing and better perceive and implement the benefits of senior citizens to society. However, the proposal to create a Europe-wide common basic income must be rejected in its own right. That is why I am voting against this report.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ The year 2012 was designated as the ‘European Year for Active Ageing and Solidarity between Generations’. The report concerns the implementation, results, and an assessment of it and solidarity between generations. Through their employment protection legislation and systems of wage formation Member States should support the recruitment of older workers especially before their statutory retirement age, as unemployment would have further negative effects on their retirement income. In order to guarantee that solidarity between generations is maintained, I voted in favour to ensure that older unemployed generations who find it increasingly difficult to reintegrate in the labour market are not left alone.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this proposal. The objective of the European Year 2012 of active ageing and solidarity between generations has been to raise public awareness of the importance of active ageing, to stimulate the exchange of information, to promote policies for active ageing and to create a framework for concrete action by the Union, its Member States and all stakeholders in the public and private sectors.  The European Year 2012 provided a significant political impetus that helped to launch a discussion on the challenges of active ageing and solidarity between generations in Europe. Coexistence between generations must be based on solidarity and must be characterised by respect, responsibilities and mutual attention.

name: Jérôme LAVRILLEUX
text: In writing. As I had already had the opportunity to do so in the Parliamentary Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, I voted in favour of this report on "the implementation, results and overall evaluation of the 2012 European Year of Active Aging and Intergenerational Solidarity". In a century, we have seen a near doubling of life expectancy. It is up to us to decide whether demographic ageing should be an opportunity or a burden on our society.  Properly accompanied, demographic ageing can be a real generator of economic growth. It can also be, through intergenerational exchange, a pillar of social cohesion.  But beware, demographic ageing is also a responsibility. A society is often judged by the way it treats its seniors. In this area, let us be honest, we are suffering from a terrible delay and profound disparities.  While we talk about the adaptations necessary for future demographic changes, we are unable to respond to the current difficulties (health, public pensions, employment, etc.). The European Union therefore has a great responsibility in this area.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution on the report on the implementation, results and overall assessment of the 2012 European Year of Active Aging and Intergenerational Solidarity. The idea of "active aging" which is to improve the health and quality of life of older adults for as long as possible, by promoting their autonomy and participation in social life, is in itself a positive thing. Maintaining professional activity, which is one of these objectives, could be an economic necessity in view of demographic changes in Europe. However, the pension problem will not be solved by making seniors work without thinking that at a certain age, retirement is simply deserved. This proposal is ultimately only a wobbly and disguised way of combating unemployment by keeping seniors in employment.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. The objective of the report is to extend the promotion of active ageing and to develop a positive social image of old age, facilitating the social inclusion of the elderly. While these are objectives with which I agree, their practical consequences are unclear - with one exception: pensions, the main source of income for older generation. The rapporteur's position is in favour of reforms of the pension system which, under the mantle of sustainability, reduce solidarity between generations and even within each cohort, by developing private pensions and reducing distributive progressiveness in the calculation and financing of public pensions. That's why I voted against it.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. The report assesses the results of the European Year of Active Ageing and Intergenerational Solidarity (2012). Its objectives include social awareness of the value of active ageing and its different dimensions, as well as the stimulation of debate, information exchange and mutual learning. In the same line, it is important to combat age discrimination by setting aside existing stereotypes and barriers.  The report offers a very positive note in stressing that there are indications that the effects of the 2012 European Year are going beyond it and that some will remain for a longer period of time. In a context where all statistics point towards a clear global ageing of the population, initiatives and measures such as the European Year of Active And Intergenerational Solidarity are clearly necessary, which is why I am in favour of this report.

name: Krystyna ŁYBACKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 In the context of the evaluation of the European Year of Active Ageing and Solidarity between Generations 2012, I draw attention to the need to continue active ageing initiatives and programmes and to increase their focus on local and regional levels. The need for this type of action is demonstrated by the huge number of volunteers wishing to take advantage of such opportunities. In my region, for example, I regularly organise training courses for seniors, which are very popular. Furthermore, action should be taken to improve intergenerational dialogue so that younger generations learn from the experience of older people, whose contribution and knowledge would thus be properly appreciated and exploited. In the context of demographic change and the growing ageing of the European population, we must also ensure that we create a socio-economic environment conducive to older people. Actions in this area m.in include: combating age discrimination on the labour market, combating poverty, digital exclusion and helping the elderly. Following today's resolution, I hope that the Commission will propose new initiatives to combat unemployment of over-50s and, in cooperation with the Member States, propose solutions to make it more attractive to employ older people.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. In 2012, the European Union declared a year of active ageing and intergenerational solidarity with a view to creating an ageing culture embraced by all generations and increasing awareness of solidarity towards older generations. The large increase in the share of the old population is a characteristic of democratic developments in the Countries of the Union and an issue that we must deal with more actively. In Croatia, more than 15 percent of the population is over 65 years old and we have 1.2 million pensioners who need to be actively involved in society. I consider it important to highlight the World Health Organisation definition, which says active ageing is "a process that increases opportunities for healthy living, participation in society and safety with the aim of improving the quality of life as people get older." I supported Mp Kukan's report, which praised active ageing and intergenerational solidarity initiatives and cited achievements and results thereof. In particular, I welcome two important achievements: the creation of an active ageing index and the guiding principles of active ageing and intergenerational solidarity. It is essential to continue to encourage the acceptance and recognition of the contributions of older people, to ensure quality and dignified care through health programmes, and to foster intergenerational dialogue.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing ‒ The ageing of the population is a fact that the European Union has to deal with. 2012 brought a number of activities coordinated by the Union, showing the possibility of active ageing and ways of involving older people in different activities. Togetherness and solidarity with the older generation will contribute to improving the quality of life of these people and cannot just be a matter of limited earmarking. The experience and knowledge of the older generation can be motivating and inspiring for the incoming generations, and can also contribute to economic development and growth.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the implementation, results and overall evaluation of the European Year 2012 of Active Ageing and Solidarity between Generations for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 8/9/2015.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I am voting AGAINST this report which wants to keep older people in employment as late as possible. This report gives the illusion that making people work longer will solve the pension problem. We forget here that every person, after having worked for many years, has the right to enjoy life and his family.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report which among many good recommendations calls on the Commission to study the worrying problem of unemployment among people over the age of 50 and the ever rising level of long-term unemployment, and, in conjunction with the Member States, regional and local authorities and social partners, to look into the circumstances and personal situations of older people who are unemployed and to develop effective tools for keeping workers who belong to this vulnerable category in the labour market, offering opportunities for lifelong learning and upgrading of skills, in-work training and accessible and affordable learning programmes and promoting intergenerational training and transfer of knowledge at work for all.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the implementation, results and overall assessment of the European Year of Active Ageing and Solidarity between Generations. It is important to raise public awareness of the importance of ageing and to promote activities that help combat age discrimination. The elderly should not be seen as a burden but, on the contrary, they are an advantage for the present generations, thanks to their experiences.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. The Report on the implementation, results and overall evaluation of the European Year of Active Ageing and Intergenerational Solidarity in 2012 recognises that this occasion provided an important political impetus that helped open the debate on the challenges of active ageing and intergenerational solidarity in Europe. This is a debate which we must always have open and hence my support for this work, which calls on the Commission to follow the work in the direction of implementing measures in the EU to deal with this situation.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. The report addresses the problems for society at an ever-increasing average age and makes some constructive suggestions on how to implement active ageing and appreciate the benefits of senior citizens to society; However, the proposal to create a common basic income is problematic, which is why this article is a key vote. Since paragraph 8 has been adopted, this report must be rejected.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. This report advocates "active ageing" and tries to drown fish by defining it as "the economic, social, spiritual, cultural and civic activities of older people who can continue to make a contribution to their families, contemporaries, communities and countries." The rapporteur certainly insists on the maintenance of public pension schemes or on the need for rich and affordable public services. But it is in fact the European Commission's agenda that is being promoted. She speaks of "Silver economy" for "Developing the economy of seniors in Europe". Thus, the rapporteur calls for "facilitating the extension of the working life of those who wish" in particular by "reforming the pension system". It is based on alarmist forecasts: by 2050 the average age of the EU population would be more than 50 years. Under what health conditions according to social classes? And do these predictions take into account the recent arrival of many young migrants and their families? According to the rapporteur, the well-being of the elderly can only be achieved through the perpetuation of their link with the world of work. Vote against this war machine against the right to retire and this hypocritical banter.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. This report assesses the initiatives experienced to combat age discrimination. It lays down the concept of "active ageing" which consists of improving the health and quality of life of older people, by promoting their autonomy and participation in social life. To this end, they intend to develop the "Silver Economy", a sector of activity that meets the needs of the over-50s with adapted products and services. This text also encourages intergenerational solidarity and recalls the obligation to accompany the elderly with dignity.  Camouflaged behind good intentions, the report hopes that seniors will retire more and more later. The question would be the viability of our pay-as-you-go pension system, a model of intergenerational solidarity. Keeping seniors in the labour market as long as possible is about deferring the problem. This will only increase tensions in the labour market. Social accounts must not rebalance at the cost of an explosion in the unemployment rate. Finally, common sense dictates that seniors can fully enjoy the end of their lives after so many years of work. I voted against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 The year 2012 was designated "European Year of Active Ageing and Solidarity between Generations". The overall objective was to facilitate the creation of an active ageing culture in Europe, based on a society for all ages. A number of initiatives have been maintained that have brought good solutions with regard to active ageing, which will be important in the future.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in support of the resolution. 2012 was officially designated as the ‘European Year for Active Ageing and Solidarity between Generations’ which worked to encourage active ageing and combat age based discrimination throughout the EU. This assessment looks at the effects of national efforts in 2012 and how we can continue the successes into the future.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: Written. – In 2060, there will be one pensioner in front of each active employee. If the policy is unchanged, that is. That is why in 2012 "active ageing and intergenerational solidarity" was chosen as the central theme for the European year, with the aim of raising policy makers and opinion-makers aware of the opportunities of, and mobilising them for, an active elderly policy.  People stay fit and healthy longer. This means that this social progress can no longer be seen as a burden but as an enrichment for our society. Older people are a full-fledged population group and their continued participation in public life should be encouraged. Therefore, policies must be taken to address the worrying phenomenon of elderly unemployment and keep this vulnerable but experienced group of workers in the labour market, for example by developing programmes such as 'generational mentorship', but also for maintaining a good quality of life and living standards.  Many citizens are committed to socially valuable causes in addition to or after their professional careers. Therefore, the voluntary work and the social added value of this citizen participation can be valued more. Finally, active ageing also means ensuring people have good access to permanent education, health care and social services.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that active ageing policies should not be considered only as an instrument to maintain the employability of older workers, but as an opportunity for older citizens to enhance the positive role they play in the society. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 2012 was declared the European Year of Active Ageing and Solidarity between Generations. The rapporteur shall evaluate the events and initiatives that have taken place in this period and make recommendations for the further progress made. The two most important achievements of the 2012 European Year are the principles for promoting active ageing and solidarity between generations and the Active Ageing Indicator, and encourages Member States to use them more actively and to set targets on this basis through comprehensive strategies for active ageing. Another important achievement is the forthcoming EU Convention on Demographic Change. It emphasises that demographic changes in Europe should be seen as an opportunity rather than a burden on European society. One of the main elements of this would be the recognition of the social utility of the elderly and their positive role in society, as well as the desire to improve intergenerational dialogue. It also considers it necessary to develop a 'silver economy' to meet the needs of an ageing population on the basis of economic opportunities arising from public and consumer spending linked to an ageing population and to certain products, services, innovative solutions and the needs of the population over 50, resulting in new jobs and growth.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. 2012 2012 was the Year of Active Ageing and Solidarity between Generations, with this initiative aiming to raise awareness of the value of active ageing, stimulate the exchange of information, promote active ageing policies and create a concrete framework for action for the Union and its Member States.  I would point out that the EU is facing unparalleled demographic, social and structural changes and should be the subject of study. The eu's average population age by 2050 is predicted to be over 50 years old. I support that the European Year 2012 has fuelled the debate on the challenges of active ageing and intergenerational solidarity and has made it possible to fully demonstrate that the elderly are not, and cannot constitute, a burden on the economy and society, but on the contrary, they will have to be seen as an added value, thanks to their experience, their achievements and their knowledge. I believe that the initiatives launched under the European Year 2012 should be accompanied and transformed into a political commitment, accompanied by concrete measures to ensure social inclusion, active participation and the well-being of all generations.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This report aims to promote "active ageing" by keeping working seniors as long as possible by encouraging lifelong learning and imagining new forms of relationship with the employer, developing the silver economy, combating age discrimination, or reforming tax policies on work etc.  However, I oppose this vision of ageing where the notion of retirement is swept away to maintain the employment rate of seniors, to perpetuate the pension system, when other solutions, much simpler and fairer, are discarded (make the system tax more progressive, allow better consideration of the penalty etc...). On the other hand, increasing is a disguised desire to push back the retirement age. However, this strategy will only lower the employment rate of seniors and increase unemployment.  I therefore voted against this text, arguing that the EU does not have to deal with this issue.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report in order to guarantee that solidarity between generations is maintained. We must ensure that older unemployed generations who find it increasingly difficult to reintegrate in the labour market are not left alone.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. The year 2012, proclaimed the European Year of Active Aging and Intergenerational Solidarity, has led to European events and the development of guiding principles on active ageing and intergenerational solidarity. I voted in favour of this report which, following an assessment of the achievements of 2012, calls on the Commission to publish country-by-country recommendations on employment, pensions, social inclusion and long-term care for the elderly. The aim is to combat the remaining disparities between Member States and to promote policies in favour of active ageing.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report that will raise general awareness of the value of active ageing and its various dimensions, stimulate debate, to exchange information and to develop mutual learning, offer a framework for commitment and concrete action and promote activities which will help to combat age discrimination, to overcome age-related stereotypes and to remove barriers.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this report because I believe that encouraging active ageing is one of the EU's biggest challenges at the moment. We are all faced with unprecedented demographic, social and structural changes that need to be addressed without delay; whereas the general ageing population is accompanied by a decrease in the birth rate;  In order to address these problems, I believe that it is essential for Romania and the rest of the European countries for the State to promote and strengthen, through social security systems, the public infrastructure (care units, day centres and home care) that are available to the elderly. Also, as the report also mentions, Member States need to improve the allocation of funds for active ageing and ensure the efficiency of the absorption of European funds from this segment. The social role played by older people is crucial for any society, and sharing values and experience with new generations will undoubtedly guarantee the evolution and coherence of the European project.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. – The report takes up the problems that a society with an ever-increasing average age entails. It also mentions constructive proposals on how to implement active ageing. I miss the action and implementation of the constructive proposals. That is because of this, I voted against this report.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The overall objective of an Active Ageing and Solidarity between Generations was to facilitate the creation of an active ageing culture in Europe, based on a society that inclusive all age groups. The project can be considered a success and hopefully a number of initiatives will continue. Examples of estonia's strategy for active ageing 2014-2020 can be given as a positive example.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 One of the biggest challenges facing Europe is the ageing of the population. It is therefore necessary to promote active ageing and solidarity between generations. I have chosen to vote in favour, and I also hope that the Commission will allocate funding to support the Covenant of Mayors on Demographic Change.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the report, prepared with great professionalism by my colleague Eduard Kukan. I find his report astute, informing and presenting a real assessment of the implementation of the European Year of Active Ageing and Solidarity between Generations in 2012. Europe's ageing population is a fact and we have a duty to provide conditions of well-deserved positive environment for the elderly and to fight hard against their discrimination in society. We must make sure that ageing is not seen as a burden by the elderly citizens of the European Union, but as well-deserved prosperity.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: Writing. \ u2012 I welcome my colleague Kukan's report. The European Year of Active Ageing and Solidarity between Generations 2012 has brought an important political boost, which has helped to start a debate on the challenges of active ageing in Europe and has not only brought about a shift in consciousness. It is important that we maintain and encourage the process. Initiatives taken in the context of the European Year must be upgraded and made into a strong political commitment, followed by concrete actions. However, more treatment of the demographic reoeulation of the European population with representatives of civil society and the private sector would also be needed.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ The European Union declared 2012 the European Year of Active Ageing and Intergenerational Solidarity. Given that ageing is a challenge that society has always faced, an active culture of ageing needs to be promoted. Joint cooperation between young people and the elderly population is particularly emphasised in order to foster solidarity between them and mutual understanding.  The European Year of Ageing was to raise general awareness of the values of active ageing and to highlight the contribution of older generations in society in general. It also wanted to highlight the fight against age discrimination, which should overcome all these age stereotypes and remove barriers in society. It is of great importance to instill the right values in society and fight against age discrimination that carries negative stereotypes. Our parents, grandparents, neighbors and all people of older age deserve a dignified age and respect for their human dignity.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This report is completely underpinned by the idea of prolonging working life and leaving workers in the labour market for as long as possible. It is obviously a question of compensating for the failure of pension plans due to an aging population. But that's certainly not the right way. We know that unemployment is a major burden on seniors. What sense does it make to want people working until age 69, who often find themselves unemployed at 55? Only a real recovery of the economy and industry can help to combat unemployment and finance the social system. I therefore vote against this report, which will not be more effective than a cautery on a wooden leg.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ I support the 2012 European Year of Active Ageing and Intergenerational Solidarity implementation, results and overall assessment report, with the aim of creating a culture of active ageing in Europe that must be based on society for all age groups.  One in five Croatian residents is over 65 years old, which poses a challenge to the economy, social welfare, pension funds and the health care system, and in Croatia in 2050 as much as 30% of the population will be over 65 years old, a trend manifested in most member states. The European Year has increased the number of initiatives to promote active ageing in the Member States and has also helped to improve national active ageing policy programmes and encouraged the exchange of good practice between countries.  Active ageing enables people to age with good health and active participation in society, greater fulfillment in the workplace and greater civic inclusion, while adequate protection, safety and care when they need it. The report also highlights age-related prejudice, discrimination and stereotypes, and calls on Member States to take measures to eradicate them.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. - The european year of active ageing and intergenerational solidarity aims to promote awareness-raising of the value of active ageing and active ageing policies at Union and Member State level and all public and private sector stakeholders, as the average age in the EU is expected to be above 50 by 2050.  The report is of utmost importance as the EU faces unprecedented demographic, social and structural changes to be addressed without delay, as the overall ageing population is accompanied by an increase in social care needs, health and care needs for the elderly and their families, and the long-term quality and sustainability of public services in the EU will largely depend on the measures to be taken in the next few years. I agree that active ageing and intergenerational solidarity are essential to achieve the overall and individual objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy and to create a competitive, successful and inclusive Europe.  The success of active ageing policies is strongly linked to the effectiveness of a number of non-discrimination, social protection, inclusion and public health policies that are shaped throughout the lives of EU citizens and workers. In doing so, intergenerational solidarity is one of the basic principles of human society, and achieving the goals of society requires life experience and commitment and ideas of all generations. Therefore, I support colleague Kukan's report.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 European society is increasingly made up of older people. The European Union must work hard to make the elderly increasingly at the centre of social and health planning. The year 2012 has been designated the European Year of Active Ageing and Solidarity between Generations. The overall objective was to facilitate the creation of an active ageing culture in Europe, based on a society for all ages. I believe that the European Year 2012 has been successful, especially as regards the involvement of local authorities. Europe must continue along this path.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 2012 was the European Year of Active Ageing and Solidarity between Generations. It was aimed at facilitating the creation of a culture of active ageing in Europe. I support the idea of active ageing (with one caveat: it must be voluntary, i.e. older people must not be forced to continue working). That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. 2012 was proclaimed the European Year of Ageing and Intergenerational Solidarity. The aim of this theme was to raise awareness of the ageing population and the issues that arise from it, but also to draw the attention of States and citizens to the huge disparities that exist within the Union. EUR 5 million was allocated to promote these themes and organise activities across Europe. The Kukan report assesses this year's results. I voted in favour of this report, which highlights the strengths and weaknesses of this thematic year. In order to promote consistency in the Union's activities, it is important that Parliament monitors the relevant projects or programmes upstream and downstream.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The objective of the European Year of Active Ageing and Solidarity between Generations (European Year 2012) initiative was to raise awareness among the citizens of the European Union of the challenges of ageing, in a context of demographic decline, on the one hand, and increased average life expectancy on the other. It is estimated that the average age of the EU population will be over 50 years in 2050. From this point of view, the Commission invited Parliament to adopt the European Year 2012 in order to raise public awareness of the value of active ageing, promote the exchange of information, combat discrimination and stereotypes on grounds of age and propose a framework of commitment and concrete action, which is taken into account in the development of new legislation on the subject. The report analyses the success of the initiatives launched, and praises the main results of the European Year 2012. According to the rapporteur, the European Year has fulfilled its plan by mobilising relevant actors around active ageing and solidarity between generations. I voted in favour of the report.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 Civilizational progress on the European continent today allows people to live until later. At a time when most EU countries are experiencing a birth crisis, we must harness the potential of this part of the population for society. Active ageing is therefore a challenge for the Union and requires a multidimensional and responsible approach to generations. A society that wants to solve this problem is a society willing to find solutions. In this respect, countries such as Austria, Estonia, Slovenia and the Czech Republic are good examples. I count others from following them. I tell portugal not to forget the elders. I hope that my vote in favour will strengthen the common goal of creating an active ageing culture in Europe.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. Among the main challenges facing Europe is undoubtedly the demographic challenge posed by ageing. The aim of the European Year of Active Ageing and Intergenerational Solidarity was to increase awareness of the value of active ageing, stimulate information exchange, promote active ageing policies and create a framework for concrete actions by the Union, its Member States and all public and private sector stakeholders. The adopted report insists that demographic changes should be seen as an opportunity. Specifically, it is welcome that it has become clear that older people are not a burden, but, because of their experience, productive life and knowledge, they represent a benefit to society.  It regretted, however, that new networks could not be established to share resources, projects and ideas between the public, private and civil society sectors and that companies would not be meaningfully reached. It also calls on the Commission to carry out a study on demographic decline and to draw up a communication on this problem and on the measures that could be taken at all levels to address it.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. Active aging tends to allow older people to stay healthy longer and optimize their participation in society. Improving access to health care, long-term care and social services is essential to this end, despite the desire of some to cut services in order to cope with the crisis.  To raise public awareness of the importance of active ageing, the European Union decided to make 2012 the European Year of Active Ageing and Intergenerational Solidarity. Today a report was being discussed in Parliament on the implementation, results and overall assessment of this 2012 European year of active ageing.  On the positive side, this report highlights the mobilization of stakeholders around this issue and the increase in the number of initiatives promoting active ageing. On the other hand, the establishment of new networks for sharing resources, projects and ideas between the public sector, the private sector and civil society has rarely been achieved according to this report. Sharing these considerations, I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The "European Year of Active Ageing and Solidarity between Generations" took place in 2012, with the main objectives being public awareness of the value of active ageing, the debate and exchange of information for the sharing of experiences and mutual learning, the fight against age discrimination and a commitment to concrete actions in this area.  The report notes that the objectives of the 2012 European Year were overall achieved, despite the small budget that was made available, with the results of the principles of Active Ageing and Solidarity between Generations, as well as the Active Ageing Index, worth mentioning.  I support the rapporteur's analysis, in particular on the raising of the retirement age and the need to reduce discrimination in access to the labour market, as well as for better integration of lifelong learning policies for all, and I therefore voted in favour.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I support the desire to create a culture of active ageing in the Member States based on a society that guarantees the best standard of living at all ages. The results of the report on the European Year 2012 take into account the index of active ageing and the principle of solidarity between generations, and on this basis urge the European Union to examine these data scrupulously in order to activate appropriate policies. The resolution also highlights the need to provide funding for the Covenant of Mayors on Demographic Change.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted against the Report for having a partially and fully oriented view of the productive work of the active ageing of older people. Throughout the report, the statement that the well-being of older generations does not lie in perpetuating their connection to the labour market is not incorporated, but that this well-being lies in creating the conditions for them to receive fair pensions after a lifetime of work, which can only be achieved through the development of the countries comprehensive (economic) , human, cultural, social, participatory, n discriminatory, etc.) and with policies that promote stable and safe employment for all generations. Because the Report implicitly but repeatedly sends conflicting messages about the active ageing and role of older people who are regarded as mere labour force, we do not support them because their content can lead to the rise of retirement age, precarious industrial relations and the destructiveness and privatization of social security systems. That is why we are against this report.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Europe's population is ageing significantly and must therefore respond to the demographic changes that this trend brings. It is not enough just to extend life expectancy, the quality of life of the elderly is essential. In the last parliamentary term, I was shadow rapporteur on the report on this subject. I believe that the European Year of Active Ageing and Intergenerational Solidarity has highlighted this serious societal issue. I would therefore like to thank my colleague Kukan for the evaluation report that I voted in favour of. However, initiatives to develop intergenerational dialogue and active ageing should not end with the vote of this report.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. The objective of the report is to extend the promotion of active ageing and to develop a positive social image of old age, facilitating the social inclusion of the elderly. While these are objectives with which I agree, their practical consequences are unclear - with one exception: pensions, the main source of income for older generation. The rapporteur's position is in favour of reforms of the pension system which, under the mantle of sustainability, reduce solidarity between generations and even within each cohort, by developing private pensions and reducing distributive progressiveness in the calculation and financing of public pensions. That's why I voted against it.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as taxpayers’ money was spent on communication relating to the campaign. I am against spending any tax monies on unnecessary projects.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ In order to guarantee that solidarity between generations is maintained, I – with the European Parliamentary Labour Party – voted in favour to ensure that older unemployed people, who find it increasingly difficult to reintegrate in the labour market, are not left alone. Active ageing policies, in my view, should not only consider means of maintaining older workers’ employability, but should also enhance opportunities for older citizens to have a positive role in society.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ This explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ I see the issue of old age and population ageing very positively, especially as I am aware of the value that older people offer us and can still offer for society. I would like to take this opportunity to thank the rapporteur for the report that has been prepared and to acknowledge the progress made in the European Year of Active Ageing and Solidarity between Generations 2012. I was happy to support the resolution, but we certainly agree that there is still much to improve for this population group. I consider this to be important, especially as this target group is the largest but also the riskiest group of the European population, and their problems and needs are still not given sufficient attention at national level. However, I believe that, as in 2012, we will actively approach the problems and needs of older people, thereby contributing not only to improving and improving their lives, but also to creating the conditions for better and better old age for the current young generation.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: in writing. ‒ The European Union faces unprecedented demographic changes, inter alia due to an ageing society, a declining working age population and a rising level of demographic dependency. These negative demographic trends are also coupled with social changes in family structures, such as the rise in single-adult households and the decreasing number of multi-generational family households. The European Year for Active Ageing and Solidarity between Generations was a much-needed initiative to raise awareness concerning these challenges, but also to start exploring the opportunities lying in the silver economy. As the example of several Member States shows, there is a lot that public authorities, healthcare systems and even private companies can do to allow aging people to live dignified, useful and healthy lives and to be full members of our society.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. \u2012 Was the European Year of Active Ageing and Solidarity between Generations, aimed at raising awareness of the importance of active ageing, promoting the exchange of information and active ageing policies, and creating a framework for concrete actions by the Union and the Member States. The EU is facing unprecedented demographic, social and structural changes, and these require an immediate response. The overall ageing of the population is accompanied by an increase in the needs of older people and their families in the field of social welfare and health. The European Year 2012 was successful in terms of promoting relevant actors in this area, but the objective of establishing new networks for the exchange of funds, projects and ideas between the public and private sectors and civil society was rarely achieved. I agree with refusing to treat active ageing policies only as an instrument for maintaining the employability of older workers. Member States should carry out all necessary assessments and make every effort to move towards a life-by-life approach and, if necessary, overhaul the pension system. I believe that the communication, which the report found to be the result of the European Year 2012, that older people are not a burden, but that their experience, life achievements and knowledge are valuable to the economy and society, is extremely important. However, the report in this report is well written, which is why I voted in favour of it.

name: Bart STAES
text: Written. 'I voted with the Greens in favour of the report on the 'European Year for Active Ageing and Intergenerational Solidarity (2012)', because it looked at both shortcomings and successful objectives, which is important to do better in the future.  This enabled the mobilisation of relevant actors, but failed to build new networks between public, private sectors and civil society to share resources, projects and ideas. The involvement of social partners was variable and nil in private companies. The project was approved too late and had only a very small budget. It remains important that older people should not be seen as a burden on the economy and society, but have added value through experience, achievements and knowledge. Policies that only view "active ageing" as an economic tool (employing older workers) are rejected.  Member States must observe the full life cycle and guarantee individual and adequate pensions and the right to a dignified age. The European Commission is called upon to investigate a new EU financial instrument to provide a minimum income for all EU citizens living below the poverty line.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ I support the report because the objectives of the European Year of Active Ageing and Intergenerational Solidarity have been achieved. The objectives for this European Year, which was 2012, are set: raising general awareness of the value of active ageing and its different dimensions, stimulating debate in order to exchange information and to develop mutual learning, a framework for commitment and concrete actions, and combating age discrimination in order to overcome age stereotypes and to move barriers related to ageing.  It is good that many strategies and plans in different Member States have been adopted and the results are visible. These policies and objectives should continue in the future. The age limit for retirement should only be raised in the event of exceptional situations, while Member States still need to combat age discrimination through various measures, especially in labour markets, and should work towards better social integration of older people and policies that propagate lifelong learning for all.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ In order to guarantee that solidarity between generations is maintained, I voted in favour of this report to ensure that older unemployed generations who find it increasingly difficult to reintegrate in the labour market are not left alone.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. \u2012 Aware of the fact that the population is ageing rapidly, we emphasize this report as very important because of the timely reaction to the issuance of guidelines and in order for the population to adequately combat all possible difficulties that older age brings.  It is very important to offer the population a clear and sincere tendency and attitude that their aging does not mean exclusion from socioeconomic spheres. I support this report, as I would point out that many of the decisions set out in the 'European Year 2012' project have not yet been fully implemented in all EU countries.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: I did not support the report in writing ‒ because it calls on the Member States and the Commission to take measures that will increase the financial and regulatory burden.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the implementation, results and overall evaluation of the European Year for Active Ageing and Solidarity between Generations 2012. The report essentially touches on both 2012 and the future. The fact is that Europe is facing an ageing population. In Slovenia, too, we are witnessing an ageing population. According to data from the Statistical Office of the Republic of Slovenia, in the first half of 2014 17.5% of persons aged at least 65 lived in Slovenia, which is 0.2 percentage points more than at the end of 2013 and 0.5 percentage points more than at the end of 2012. Therefore, the EU must face up to the demographic, social and other changes that an ageing population brings and provide a positive environment for the elderly in which they can develop their potentials.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The EU strategy for active ageing is actually an attempt to link life expectancy with the retirement age, something with which as the Left we disagreed and disagreed vertically. The report did not address the existence or not of active ageing policy but only dealt with its evaluation. This evaluation makes serious and correct observations such as, for example, improving conditions in hospitals, and accessible to all social care. At the very least, the rejection of active ageing as a means of linking life expectancy with retirement age is also proclaimed, but this does not change the nature of active ageing policy. As the policy itself is not being voted on, but comments are being made on it, some of which are positive, we have kept to this report.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The EU must take welfare measures in favour of older people, as well as measures to tackle under-birth.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of this report, because I agree that the possibility of active ageing is important throughout Europe, and the report examined this issue very widely. However, I would like to underline that the regulations in each Member State are at significantly different levels in this area. I, too, consider it important to launch a debate on the challenges of active ageing and intergenerational solidarity throughout Europe. However, I would definitely like to underline an issue which is not explicitly addressed in the report, although its content refers to it factually. This issue is notably the creation of the European Charter for the Elderly. I believe, and the debate on this report, has confirmed that this should be developed effectively and promptly.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 2012 was declared the "European Year of Active Ageing and Solidarity between Generations", with the aim of facilitating the creation of a culture of active ageing in Europe based on the principle of a society open to all age groups. The document voted on was aimed not only at assessing the European year 2012, but also at presenting concrete recommendations aimed at eliminating age discrimination, particularly those relating to the labour market. I believe that, at a time of ageing European Union society, it is necessary to support the so-called silver economy, that is, one that sees an opportunity in the elderly, not a threat. I therefore voted in favour of the document on the evaluation of the European Year of Active Ageing.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The year 2012 was designated the 'European Year of Active Ageing and Solidarity between Generations'. This was not by chance, given that there has been a general trend of ageing population at Union level for some time, which is a challenge for European demographic policies. Beyond considering ageing as an exit from the active population, the process must not lead to the marginalisation of this growing group within society. On the contrary, we need to think of new ways in which older people can be involved in society and after reaching a certain age, formally considered to be the limit of active life. Their experience is a significant resource for the development of our societies. On the other hand, if we think about the labour market, it will also have to undergo changes in form and content to keep up with the new trend. It is therefore necessary to protect employees at an advanced age and to avoid their unemployment, which may affect their pension level and standard of living. For these reasons, this document is a useful tool for the Union's future demographic policies.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which follows the INI report adopted in 2010 on the same topic as well as the 2012 resolution on Swiss quotas on the number of residence permits granted to nationals of Poland, Lithuania, Latvia, Estonia, Slovenia, Slovakia, the Czech Republic and Hungary. The EEA Agreement is considered as an effective instrument to extend the Single Market to third countries. However, we can be concerned about increasing EU rules transposition deficit, which could jeopardize the functioning of the internal market. The report therefore calls third countries to remedy this situation. It also deplores the unilateral measures (administrative fees or obligatory bank guarantees) which restrict the provision of services in Switzerland.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ This report is in response to a 2012 Commission communication created to promote active ageing and intergenerational solidarity. I support the thesis in the report that promote specific, generally acceptable goals such as raising general awareness of active aging, stimulating debate and developing principles of mutual learning, proposaling a framework for future commitments and concrete actions, and promoting activities that help combat age discrimination. However, as the concept of active ageing and intergenerational solidarity intertwines with several policy areas, such as pensions, health and long-term care, employment and adult education, the report unfortunately encroaches on the principle of subsidiarity in many segments. While I strongly support the very idea of active ageing (with the emphasis that the same must be voluntary, i.e. that older people should not be forced to remain in employment), the nature of the report is in certain parts too restrictive and deeply encroachs on the exclusive competences of individual Member States of the Union, for example with a call for a guarantee of adequate pension income or the right to a dignified life in old age, or a call for the European Commission to implement a social investment package. I fully agree with the proposals and objectives of the report, however, what I cannot accept is a disregard for the principle of subsidiarity in how they are implemented. So I voted abstention.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the report on the evaluation of the European Year of Active Ageing and Solidarity between Generations 2012 because I believe that one of the major challenges is the ageing of the population, which will have to be tackled at European Union level. A step forward must be taken towards the integration of older people into society and for their social security.
