By 2020, the world's population over 60 is expected to reach 20% of the total population. We must strive for active ageing, accompanied by the best opportunities for health, cooperation and safety, with a view to improving the quality of life during the ageing process. Active ageing can give older people the potential for physical and mental well-being and social well-being throughout their lives. But it is also important to be involved in society, to ensure adequate protection, security and care. The Horizon 2020 European Structural and Investment Fund as well as the Employment and Social Innovation Programme should be used.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted against the Report for having a partially and fully oriented view of the productive work of the active ageing of older people. Throughout the report, the statement that the well-being of older generations does not lie in perpetuating their connection to the labour market is not incorporated, but that this well-being lies in creating the conditions for them to receive fair pensions after a lifetime of work, which can only be achieved through the development of the countries comprehensive (economic) , human, cultural, social, participatory, n discriminatory, etc.) and with policies that promote stable and safe employment for all generations. Because the Report implicitly but repeatedly sends conflicting messages about the active ageing and role of older people who are regarded as mere labour force, we do not support them because their content can lead to the rise of retirement age, precarious industrial relations and the destructiveness and privatization of social security systems. That is why we are against this report.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ One of the basic principles of human society is intergenerational solidarity, and longer life expectancy increases the importance of intergenerational relationships. Lifelong learning and sports programmes contribute greatly to creating a true culture of active ageing. It was very positive that a European Year was devoted to this topic and I encourage everyone to implement all the relevant good practices.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The idea of "active aging" is to improve the health and quality of life of older adults for as long as possible, by promoting their autonomy and participation in social life. Maintaining professional activity, which is part of these objectives, is in fact a real economic necessity in view of demographic changes in Europe. On the other hand, to think that the problem of pensions will be solved by making the elderly work without working is only a disguised way of combating unemployment figures by keeping seniors in employment for as long as possible. I vote AGAINST this text.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted against the Report for having a partially and fully oriented view of the productive work of the active ageing of older people. Throughout the report, the statement that the well-being of older generations does not lie in perpetuating their connection to the labour market is not incorporated, but that this well-being lies in creating the conditions for them to receive fair pensions after a lifetime of work, which can only be achieved through the development of the countries comprehensive (economic) , human, cultural, social, participatory, n discriminatory, etc.) and with policies that promote stable and safe employment for all generations. Because the Report implicitly but repeatedly sends conflicting messages about the active ageing and role of older people who are regarded as mere labour force, we do not support them because their content can lead to the rise of retirement age, precarious industrial relations and the destructiveness and privatization of social security systems. That is why we are against this report.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report, which gives an important message of the EY2012 events and initiatives was that older people are not a burden on the economy and society, but rather – through their experience, their achievements and their knowledge – an asset.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – Initiatives launched in the 2012 European Year should be continued and implemented further. It is very important to promote an environment that is favourable to older people.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, on which I was shadow for the ALDE Group. The report recognises that active ageing and solidarity between generations are key to achieving the Europe 2020 objectives for a competitive, prosperous and inclusive Europe. The text stresses the need for a holistic approach of ageing, involving all decision-making levels (EU, national, regional and local levels), civil society and the private sector. The report underlines the importance of promoting age-friendly environments for a more inclusive society and acknowledges the benefit that a UN Convention on the rights of older persons would bring to improve the lives of older persons. One of the crucial shortcomings that the report highlights is the need for the Commission to adopt a comprehensive EU Strategy on Demographic Change to coordinate EU action in various areas, in order to tackle the challenges posed by an ageing population.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. We are talking about a vitally important issue. Europe faces the demographic challenge of increasing the life expectancy of the population and the changes it brings. Member States should encourage debate on the role of people over the age of 65 in society and combat possible discrimination against these groups. In this regard, the evaluation and results of the European Year of Ageing are a positive element to incorporate into this debate, so I consider it necessary to vote in favour of this report.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. The expression "active aging" should not mean that people have to work until later. It must rather indicate that the old should not be abandoned, as is currently the case in so many countries. Rather, they must be able to actively participate in social life, they must be able to exercise their citizenship and, in order for this to happen, they must necessarily have access to decent retirement pensions, which guarantee independence, and public services, including public health services. This issue should not be used to, on the pretext of a fair concern - that of keeping the older people active - if it tries to impose the idea of the inevitability of raising the retirement age or privatising social security systems.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The report addresses the problems for society at an ever-increasing average age and makes some constructive suggestions on how to implement active ageing and appreciate the benefits of senior citizens to society; However, the proposal to create a common basic income is problematic, which is why this article is a key vote. Since paragraph 28 has been adopted, this report must be rejected.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on this report, together with my group, the ECR. 2012 was celebrated as the "European Year for Active Ageing and Solidarity between Generations". The aim was to create a culture of active ageing in Europe. According to the rapporteur, the specific objectives included: stimulating the debate on the values of active ageing and developing mutual learning, developing a framework for engagement and concrete action, and promoting activities to counter age discrimination. Although the ECR generally supports the idea of active ageing, it is nevertheless opposed to this report because of its normative nature. It clearly exceeds the competences of the EU and is therefore unacceptable to the ECR and myself.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing \ u2012 The report builds on the results achieved in 2012, which was declared the European Year of Active Ageing and Solidarity between Generations. This year, it aimed to create a culture of active ageing in Europe, and many of its objectives have been met and positively reflected to such an extent that the report calls for the continuation of the concept of active ageing, in particular in promoting longer working lives for people who want and can also work in older age, as well as the principle of age-based non-discrimination and good access to healthcare. I supported the report, as the problem of the ageing population of the European Union is a reality that will become increasingly important in the future, and the concept of active ageing will concern us all in the future, and therefore its possible support and development must be taken into account.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 We consider that the increase in average life expectancy is an achievement of civilization and a factor of social progress and should not be seen as a burden on society, as the report advocates. Now what the expression "active aging" should mean is not that people have to work late, but rather that the older people should not be abandoned, as currently happens in so many countries, but rather must be able to actively participate in social life, they must be able to exercise their citizenship and that, in order for this to happen , they must necessarily have access to decent pension pensions, which guarantee independence, and to public services, including public health services, which guarantee their quality of life, an indispensable condition for them to participate actively in their communities. We refuse to make this theme possible to, on the pretext of a fair concern - that of keeping the older people active - if we try to impose the idea of the inevitability of raising the retirement age or privatising social security systems. We voted against it.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Dear colleagues, i would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work. I supported this report because I believe it is very important, even though it is only about 2011. Because the aim of the White Paper on Transport is, in my view, to create a strategic vision of creating a competitive and efficient transport system in the European Union. This is like a never-at-all issue, both in a globalised world and when we need to warm up the economy, and transport plays a huge role in this process.  I am delighted, and I also supported this report, because the European Parliament is asking the European Commission to propose concrete measures to best implement this strategic vision I have already mentioned, particularly the creation of a trans-European transport network. This would make an important contribution to the development of a future common transport system. Thank you!

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted against this report because I believe that its approach does not sufficiently take into account the effects of liberalisation of transport on working conditions in the sector, nor does it propose an infrastructure policy linked to a productive model that pours and cohesives the European economy, but leaves both in the interests of large companies and private investors. Social dumping in air transport, abuses of cabotage and displacement directives, the devastating effects of railway privatization and basic infrastructure... These are problems which the Commission, with Parliament's endorsement, refuses to address in the context of upward labour harmonisation, greater controls on the conditions of self-employed and dependent workers and strengthening public ownership and management. That's why I voted against it.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. The 2011 White Paper on Transport sets out a future strategy for a competitive transport system, with the aim of increasing mobility, removing significant barriers in key areas and promoting growth and employment. As transport is a complex system that depends on a number of factors, it is important to carry out a regular inventory of its implementation in the form of proposed initiatives and priorities for action, as well as to determine the way forward.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. The 2011 Transport White Paper contains many negative measures. Under spurious pretexts such as global warming, this report calls on the Commission to intervene in road taxation, calls for an increase in EU funds allocated to transport policy and one of the stated objectives is to strengthen the European Union's interventionism in urban transport.   In addition, the report has repeatedly recommended more sanctions and more severity for motorists who commit offences. It borders on persecution. This is particularly scandalous and unfair when we know that real offenders and criminals benefit from a very lax judicial system, especially in France.   As for the passages on global warming, their ridiculous alarmism justifies the promotion of walking, cycling and "gender-ventilated modes of transport" (sic!) as well as the adoption of new regulations against carbon-emitting modes of transport.    For all these reasons, I voted against this report.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the rejection, when the relevant text was considered (paragraph 63, indent 12), of EU interference in Gibraltar. Nevertheless, I cannot support any increase in EU funding, and I voted against the report as a whole.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 In its 2011 White Paper on Transport Policy, the Commission presented an ambitious strategy for the future of a competitive transport system with a view to strengthening mobility, eliminating bottlenecks in key areas and promoting development and employment. At the same time, these proposals will help make Europe much less dependent on imported oil and reduce carbon dioxide emissions from vehicles by 60% by 2050. I agree that the main objectives should be a reliable and competitive global transport system, competition between EU airlines, a transition to a low-carbon transport system, a balance between different modes of transport, and a common European transport area. It is important that the envisaged mid-term review of the Transport Policy White Paper is to follow a long-term vision (2050). The list of initiatives and actions outlines in the White Paper should be regularly adopted and supplemented and their effectiveness in achieving common long-term objectives should be assessed.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which also wants to further expand the Commission's areas of competence.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. Transport accounts for 5% of GDP at European level, with the EU remaining one of the world leaders in the field. I supported the report on the implementation of the 2011 White Paper on transport, which highlights the need to move towards a truly integrated transport system and a European transport area that tends to break the sector's dependence on oil. In this sense, the report calls for the promoting of alternative fuels, while recalling the leading role that the Union has to play in the COP21 conference. I also welcome the proposals that have been made on fair competition in the air transport sector, as well as on the amendment of the Air Passenger Rights Regulation.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This 2011 Transport White Paper prepares the European transport area for the future (post-oil, global warming) and must make the transport system competitive and sustainable while ensuring more efficient use of resources.  The report further explains that the analysis of compliance with the timetable shows that the aviation sector is lagging far behind. It calls on Member States to implement the provisions that have already been adopted and still imposes itself on one as a supranational entity.... It envisages a doubling of urban transport in the coming years, increasing the saturation of networks. To this end, the report calls for an acceleration of integration, particularly in air transport, as well as greater EU intervention in urban transport. Of course, I am opposed to increasing the EU's grip in this sector, even though I think it is all the more necessary to develop public transport in quality public services, quite the opposite of the Commission's ultra-liberal vision. So I voted against it.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because, thanks to the contributions of the S&D Group, it introduces important social recommendations.  In particular, it is committed to ensuring fair and decent working conditions for workers, promoting quality employment, improving training, adopting a social code for mobile road workers, greater participation of women in the sector or measures to reduce social disparities in transport workers between Member States, among others.  In addition, and on the contribution of the Spanish Socialists, it introduces a number of proposals to maintain the level of ambition in road safety, the inclusion of the revision of the directive on cross-border fines or greater attention to vulnerable users, such as pedestrians, cyclists or older drivers.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this Parliament's report on the 2011 Implementation of the White Paper on transport policy, an overview of the results and the development of further actions towards sustainable mobility. Europe's sustainable mobility policy must be based on a range of policies to introduce the least polluting and least energy-efficient vehicles economically. The Commission is invited to update the targets set out in the White Paper as set out in the 5 February 2014 White Paper. Parliament's resolution on the 2030 climate and energy policy strategy and the European Council conclusions of 23 and 24 October 2014 on a 2030 strategy for climate and energy policy, and propose measures to help Member States achieve the "binding EU target of reducing intra-EU greenhouse gas emissions by at least 40% by 2030 compared to 1990".

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 While the report contains many positive and acceptable aspects, such as greater road safety, the use of alternative fuels in public transport, the protection of workers, social and social security conditions; I do not think it has been incisive in relation to aspects that I consider fundamental, such as the fight against social dumping. I would have liked this text to call for a serious revision of the Posting of Workers Directive and the repeal of large-ranging excerpts of the Services Directive in order to finally offer the right protections to our citizens and businesses, but that was not the case, which is why I decided to abstain.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 I believe that an interim reassessment of the White Paper is necessary, since the long-term goals set out in 2011 do not always meet the challenges of today. The aim of the interim revaluation is not to reduce the ambitious targets that we set in 2011, but to strengthen the ambition to achieve them.  It is necessary to make better use of rail and waterborne transport and to support and promote electric and innovative forms of transport, in particular in the field of freight transport. By taking better advantage of opportunities, we can grow our economy, protect our environment and reduce traffic jams on our roads, and create new jobs. At the same time, it is necessary to reduce Europe's dependence on oil. To do so, however, the EU needs to rethink its transport policy. I did not support the points in the so-called social dumping robes set out in the report, which are contrary to the interests of Hungarian entrepreneurs and hauliers and whose primary objective is to protect the jobs of Western companies.  I voted in favour of this report with these exceptions.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP report on the Transport White Paper because the text adopted clearly highlights how investment in a European infrastructure can be a driving force for growth and employment for the union as a whole. The existence of credible greenhouse gas emission reduction targets for 2020, accompanied by investment in clean technologies and innovation, is the EU's only chance to meet its targets. This must be combined with a major modal shift, i.e. more goods by rail and less by road for distances of more than 300 km. It is now up to the European Commission to prepare the regulatory framework to implement these important objectives.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒European Sustainable Mobility Policy must be based on a wide range of policy measures to transition cost-effective to the types of transport that are least harmful to the environment and most energy efficient. However, transport remains almost entirely dependent on fossil fuels and the only sector where greenhouse gas emissions have risen in the past 25 years, with emissions growth, had it not been for the economic crisis, even been higher. I support this report because it reflects the real state of affairs when it comes to implementing EU transport policy.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this text because I believe it is essential for the Commission to adopt a uniform and ambitious transport policy that will enable us to create a competitive, efficient, secure, integrated and interoperable transport system. The positive effects of such an outcome would be immense for both citizens and businesses.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This report lays the groundwork for the strategy that European bodies will adopt in the transport sector, which accounts for 5% of EU GDP and 10 million direct or indirect jobs. Their aim is to develop the trans-European network and eliminate the disparities that exist between the centre and the periphery while promoting the transition to more environmentally friendly and less dependent transport on fossil fuels. It is within this framework that they want to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 60% by 2050. Funding for these projects would be based on public/private partnerships. How often, their goals are laudable but their methods are less laudable. They want to increase the financial allocations devoted to the implementation of transnational transport and strengthen European competences so that they can better manage these projects and better support the local authorities, often in charge of these issues. We are opposed to any transfer of sovereignty and any increase in the EU budget. These projects are interesting but do not require the commission's intervention and may be based on bilateral relations.  So I voted against it.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The transport sector is an important force in the European economy, generating 10 million jobs. In order to remain a leader in growth generation as well as in jobs, it is necessary to take a number of important measures at EU level. In this respect, a change in existing paradigms in transport policy is needed, precisely in order to meet the challenges of the future. At the same time, complementary mutual measures are needed at national, regional and local level of governance, as well as at the level of citizens and the sector. The objective of reducing Europe's dependence on oil imports and reducing carbon emissions in the transport sector by up to 60% by 2015 is highly ambitious and can only be achieved through a series of well-defined interventions. I voted in favour of the report on the implementation of the 2011 White Paper: the assessment of the current situation and the way forward for sustainable mobility because there is a need to transform the European transport system, as well as the creation of well-founded policies for the sustainable development of this sector.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 This report, which, unlike usual, has the merit of including a long analytical and detailed list of requests made to the Commission concerning the legislative action to be taken in the transport sector. Among the positive aspects: more road safety (stricter rules on driving licences, blood alcohol level, road education, etc.); development of alternative fuels and public transport; protection of working conditions, social rights and social security (anti-dumping rules); completion of ten-t. Among the negative aspects: more decarbonisation (menate on the fight against climate change); stronger role of the Commission and the EU in 'harmonising' Member States; timidity with regard to anti-dumping rules: instead of confining ourselves to general invitations, it would be appropriate to explicitly call for the repeal of the Posting of Workers Directive and for large excerpts of the Services Directive to be repealed. Abstention vote.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 After careful reflection and discussion in plenary, I voted today in favour of the report on the 'implementation of the 2011 White Paper on transport: the budget and the way forward for sustainable mobility' on the basis of the following considerations: I agree with what the rapporteur has said and in particular with the need to highlight the aspects of a solid and competitive transport system in a global context; to face up to increasing competition in international aviation; progress towards a low-carbon transport system; shifting the balance between modes of transport; the development of a single European transport area; putting people at the heart of transport policy. It is clear that the achievement of very ambitious objectives is very difficult, since they are not supported by a robust, more detailed design plan, linked to realistic and achievable short- and medium-term objectives, on the path to long-term objectives.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ The European Commission is preparing its update to the White Paper on Transport. This report is the EP’s input into this procedure. The report stresses that the mid-term review of the White Paper should maintain at least the level of ambition of the goals set in 2011. It contains a set of actions that need to be taken to achieve those goals. The report includes good initiatives, e.g. those to improve the energy-efficiency of transport, to promote public transport, the need to abolish environmentally harmful tax subsidies and prevent social dumping in transport sector Europe. It was for these reasons that I voted in favour of this report.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the rejection, when the relevant text was considered (paragraph 63, indent 12), of EU interference in Gibraltar. Nevertheless, I cannot support any increase in EU funding, and I voted against the report as a whole.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ The 2011 White Paper on Transport sets out a strategy for an improved transport system, whose aim is to also increase growth and employment. I voted in favour of this report as I agree with the rapporteur that it is necessary to give priority to the most efficient and sustainable modes of transport.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The contribution of our delegation has been important and significant, as can be seen from the fact that the report highlights, on several points, the need to boost and develop less polluting and energetically more sustainable and efficient means of transport. A negative and essential element, however, is the fact that the report continues to insist on investment in the major projects provided for by the TEN-T networks, financed through the CEF, including the Turin-Lyon HIGH-SPEED TRAIN. I therefore voted against.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 Considering that the transport sector is the driving force of the EU economy, employing around 10 million people and accounting for around 5% of GDP and that it should remain a pioneer in creating further economic growth and jobs and promoting competitiveness, sustainable development and territorial cohesion, we welcome the Commission's intention to carry out a mid-term review of the White Paper with a view to assessing the progress achieved and promoting further actions to fulfil its objectives.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the implementation of the 2011 White Paper on transport. The European Commission has presented an ambitious future strategy for a competitive transport system, with the aim of increasing mobility, breaking down the main barriers in key sectors and promoting growth and employment. The proposed initiatives aim, at the same time, to significantly reduce Europe's dependence on oil imports and to reduce carbon emissions in the transport sector by 60% by 2050. This strategy is very ambitious and has as its main objectives: the need for a robust and competitive transport system in a global context; increasing competition in international aviation; progress towards a low-carbon transport system and a single European transport area.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report. I agree with the rapporteur that a mid-term review of the Transport White Paper is needed not to lower the level of the targets set in 2011, but to complete it, specifying the targets to be achieved in the years to come. In fact, this is necessary in order to increase and rationalise the efforts being made in the very sensitive field of transport with the aim of creating an ambitious competitive and state-of-the-art system. The White Paper aims to improve mobility, promote employment, reduce oil imports and reduce polluting emissions. I very much hope that these important objectives will be achieved in order to improve the entire system, which is very delicate and whose proper functioning is based on several interconnected factors, to the benefit of European citizens and businesses.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. Following the White Paper on Transport, the Commission presented an ambitious strategy for a competitive transport system that increases mobility, promotes growth and jobs while removing key barriers in key areas. I support and agree with Mr Van de Camp's own-initiative report, which reiterates the European Parliament's support for the effective implementation of the targets set out in the White Paper, despite doubts as to the feasibility of its implementation and feasibility within the proposed deadlines. I agree with the Rapporteur's position that a transport policy for the 21st century should be based on sustainable mobility supported by policy instruments enabling it to effectively transition to less polluting and more energy efficient means of transport, which today does not result in a set of isolated and selected acts but an infrastructure interaction approach , vehicles, information technologies, rules and behaviours. This requires the complex and multimodal nature of the transport system. Particular attention should be paid to phenomena of unfair external competition which do not comply with European social, labour and environmental standards and which cause, at a certain level, a diseruption in the internal market.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. The White Paper set an ambitious agenda in 2011 for the transformation of the European transport system with objectives to make it clean, safe, effective and reliable. To date, however, the level of integration of the EU transport market remains low compared to other elements of the economy. In fact, despite the funding made available by EFSI as well as the Connecting Europe Mechanism Instrument, there are few developments to date regarding the improvement of the connections and efficiency of passenger and freight transport, multimodal networks of the different modes and transport services. There is still much to be done in the area of energy efficiency, in order to make transport sustainable and, at the same time, Europe independent of oil and fossil fuels. Concrete measures should also be put in place to ensure the application of the 'user pays' and 'polluter pays' principles. A common vision of change cannot be achieved unless there is cooperation and coordination between all the actors working at level, not only at European level, but at national, regional and local level. Of course, citizens and industries are included in all this.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: Written. In Wednesday, 9 September 2015, Parliament voted on an own-initiative report on the implementation and revision of the 2011 White Paper on sustainable transport in the run-up to the mid-term review of the White Paper and future initiatives in the field of transport. The Conservatives are in favour of the report, which focuses on a competitive transport sector, jobs and growth, and was in favour of the report, which included wordings on stricter rules on sulphur in marine fuels. On the other hand, the Conservatives voted against proposals for a general framework for national road charging systems for passenger cars and a doubling of public transport use by 2030 in urban areas, as the Conservatives believe that this is up to the Member States to decide for themselves. The Conservatives also want to emphasize that new business models like Uber can be developed.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted against this report because I believe that its approach does not sufficiently take into account the effects of liberalisation of transport on working conditions in the sector, nor does it propose an infrastructure policy linked to a productive model that pours and cohesives the European economy, but leaves both in the interests of large companies and private investors. Social dumping in air transport, abuses of cabotage and displacement directives, the devastating effects of railway privatization and basic infrastructure... These are problems which the Commission, with Parliament's endorsement, refuses to address in the context of upward labour harmonisation, greater controls on the conditions of self-employed and dependent workers and strengthening public ownership and management. That's why I voted against it.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission's 2011 White Paper on Transport states the need to increase mobility and employment at EU level; this by reducing Europe's dependence on oil imports and reducing transport CO2 emissions by 60% by 2050. Parliament supports the objectives, but draws attention to the fact that there is a significant gap between the objectives and the means to achieve and finance them.  Parliament states that we must move towards stronger and more competitive, but at the same time more friendly, transport in our policy objectives. The text states that the implementation of trans-European transport networks is also a prerequisite for balancing modes of transport and eliminating infrastructure disparities, which may also be of particular importance in eliminating differences in Central Europe.  Transport policy developments should take greater account of the mobility needs and safety of EU citizens. This should be seen in building safer roads, modernising urban mobility and infrastructure planning, developing smart vehicles and focusing on pedestrians, cyclists and vulnerable road users. I voted in favour of the ideas.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the implementation of the 2011 White Paper on Transport, however, this vote is subject to a number of reservations. I support the fact that measures aimed at reducing GHG from shipping should be established under the auspices of the IMO, however I believe that at this stage efforts should be made to focus on the establishment of a Global MRV instrument. With respect to the modern infrastructure and smart funding which priorities distance-based charging, this is evidently discriminatory for Malta. I further believe that the report should have made a reference to sustainable road transport modes where rail is unavailable.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This initiative report is part of a review at the end of the year and a mid-term review of the transport white paper. While the Commission presented ambitious targets in 2011 by 2020/30 and 2050 to establish a competitive transport system with the aim of increasing mobility, transport remains a complex system requiring coordinated intervention with the national, regional and local levels of government. Considering that this report rightly proposes to rationalise the actions implemented by a regular evaluation of their effectiveness, and that it advocates the use of the most energy efficient and sustainable modes of transport, I voted for this text

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. Environment and growth are the main points of this white paper. Parliament supported the Commission's ambitious project. Rationalization, sustainability and the reduction of carbon emissions are the future for a Europe that is more environmentally friendly and sees this new economy as an opportunity for growth and employment.

name: Philippe DE BACKER
text: Written. I am calling for greater harmonisation of the European transport system with economic growth, sustainability and fairer competition in transport. It is necessary to create a common European airspace and a faster and more efficient rail network through the fourth rail package.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission, with the adoption in 2011 of the White Paper 'Roadmap towards a single European transport area – Towards a competitive and sustainable transport policy', identified the initiatives and measures to be taken in the field of transport policy in the decade 2011-2020. With 40 specific actions to be implemented by 2020, the Commission aims to create a transport system with fewer barriers to market entry, better integration between the various transports, coherent infrastructure design and extensive use of new technologies. I voted in favour of the own-initiative report on the implementation of the 2011 White Paper to call on the European Commission to propose concrete measures and initiatives for better implementation of the strategy and to insist on the need to maintain the levels of ambition set by the 2011 objectives. This report also emphasises the importance of transport for the economy and for citizens' mobility, while highlighting the need to invest in infrastructure. The completion of the trans-European transport network is an essential requirement for a sustainable and efficient European transport system, which needs to be strengthened through the Connecting Europe Mechanism (CEF) as well as the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI).

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of my colleague van de Camp's own-initiative report on the implementation of the 2011 White Paper on transport. I believe that an interim reassessment of the White Paper is necessary, because the long-term objectives set out in 2011 do not always meet the challenges of today. The aim of the interim revaluation is not to reduce the ambitious targets that we set in 2011, but to strengthen the ambition to achieve them. It is necessary to make better use of rail and waterborne transport and to support and promote electric and innovative forms of transport, in particular in the field of freight transport. By taking better advantage of opportunities, we can grow our economy, protect our environment and reduce traffic jams on our roads, and create new jobs. At the same time, it is necessary to reduce Europe's dependence on oil. To do so, however, the EU needs to rethink its transport policy. At the same time, I did not support the points put in the robe of so-called social dumping in the report, which are contrary to the interests of Hungarian entrepreneurs and hauliers and whose primary objective is to protect the jobs of Western companies.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: In writing. On the occasion of this vote, I reiterated my opposition to the generalisation of mega-trucks, with Euro-combis up to 25 metres long and weighing up to 60 tonnes. I also voted against a proposal to establish competitive tenders for public service contracts. I also wanted to support the issue of sustainable transport infrastructure and the completion of the Trans-European Transport Network (TEN-T) through the support of the European Strategic Investment Fund (EFSI). The TEN-T, which is at the heart of the EU's infrastructure policy, aims to complete the missing links between Member States' transport networks, remove bottlenecks and overcome technical obstacles. A number of sections should be able to join the FEIS, such as the LGV Limoges Poitiers, which will reduce a large flow of passengers to South Europe and start a continuous European east-west rail axis. With the FEIS, there is a need to imagine innovative solutions to finance major structuring and development-enhancing works in the territories for the future.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of my colleague van de Camp's own-initiative report on the implementation of the 2011 White Paper on transport. I believe that an interim reassessment of the White Paper is necessary, because the long-term objectives set out in 2011 do not always meet the challenges of today. The aim of the interim revaluation is not to reduce the ambitious targets that we set in 2011, but to strengthen the ambition to achieve them. It is necessary to make better use of rail and waterborne transport and to support and promote electric and innovative forms of transport, in particular in the field of freight transport. By taking better advantage of opportunities, we can grow our economy, protect our environment and reduce traffic jams on our roads, and create new jobs. At the same time, it is necessary to reduce Europe's dependence on oil. To do so, however, the EU needs to rethink its transport policy. At the same time, I did not support the points put in the robe of so-called social dumping in the report, which are contrary to the interests of Hungarian entrepreneurs and hauliers and whose primary objective is to protect the jobs of Western companies.

name: Diane DODDS
text: in writing. ‒ Mr President, in representing Northern Ireland as an MEP, I recognise that we as a region lie on the periphery of Europe as a continent.  That in itself presents inherent challenges for residents of our province in travelling to other EU countries for a range of purposes, whether it be for business or on holiday. I therefore welcome any debate on how transport links can be created that better connect local citizens and businesses with the rest of Europe. However I am not convinced that this report properly brings together outstanding priorities in these areas. The focus on coercing Member States to enforced national road charges for vehicles is unwelcome, as are calls for legislation governing professional driver training to be reopened for review and consolidation.  On many occasions in this chamber I have fought the corner of hard-pressed hauliers in my constituency and I will not support provision that stands to make their lives harder and place added pressures on testing authorities here.

name: Herbert DORFMANN
text: Writing. With the adoption of the report on the implementation of the 2011 White Paper on Transport, we are in favour of a European transport policy that gives priority to sustainable and energy-efficient means of transport, such as rail transport. In doing so, Parliament is sending out a clear signal that the future European transport policy should place even more focus on rail transport. I supported this position, because only in this way can we improve the quality of life of people living along transit routes, while guaranteeing efficient transport of goods through Europe. Parliament is also calling for measures to reduce noise in freight rail transport, which are absolutely necessary. The ban on excessively noisy freight wagons by 2020, which we are calling for, will further strengthen the rehabilitation of old rolling and braking systems for freight wagons, thereby making a significant contribution to reducing noise emissions.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. The 2011 White Paper on transport calls for greater liberalisation of the European area and openness to competition in transport networks. The Union is then called upon to intervene more in areas that are part of the organisation of the territory, the management of networks and structures hosting airport, rail and port services. Once again, this is an interference by the Union in the missions of the Member States and an ultra-liberal momentum which I cannot support. I therefore voted against this report on the implementation of the 2011 White Paper on Transport.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 On the topic of the transport sector, allow me to be a little more critical. I think we're down in regulations and bureaucracy. This has damaged competition in the sector. Small and medium-sized carriers gasp. Moreover, we are creating difficulties for our transport operators, while at the same time keeping the door wide open to third parties who do not comply with our rules. They don't respect them, but they work in our markets. Turkey, for example. Turkish carriers operate on our market, but do not comply with our rules. And something else - there are Member States introducing restrictions to create barriers for transport companies from less developed countries. This own-initiative report is non-legislative, it only makes proposals and I voted in favour because it proposes a set of measures that, I believe, will be useful, such as the development of modern transport infrastructure in Europe, and in particular underlines the need to close the gap between levels of development and maintenance of infrastructure, in particular between eastern and western parts of the Union.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We vote against because, with environmental concerns and global warming, certain provisions serve commercial interests.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution proposes good targets, such as reducing Europe's dependence on oil imports, reducing transport emissions by 60% by 2050, using less polluting and energy-efficient modes of transport, opting for more sustainable solutions. All goals that we can share. However, I voted against this resolution because it calls for the priority approval of infrastructure projects to complement the rail network provided for by the TEN-T central network, with a strengthening of the Commission's role in achieving the effective and rapid completion of these European priority rail corridors. The resolution considers that EU funding should reflect investment needs for the completion of the TEN-T core network, and that the CEF and other means of financing should stimulate investment in transport infrastructure by prioritising sustainable means of transport, such as rail. I am opposed to investing in the major projects provided for by the TEN-T networks, financed through the CEF, because one of these works is the Turin-Lyon High-Speed Train, a work with excessive costs in relation to their usefulness, with a huge environmental impact and damage to human health, which is not necessary to improve the quality of transport between France and Italy and whose documents are inaccessible and managed in a non-transparent manner.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 The simple reading of the ten targets set out in the White Paper, which support the comprehensive vision of achieving a competitive and cost-effective transport system in resources (benchmarks for achieving the target of reducing GHG emissions by 60%) shows that, although work has already begun, the main efforts needed to transform the EU transport system still need to be made. Solving the major problems identified in the White Paper means achieving very difficult targets by 2050 and demanding challenges by 2020/2030. It will not be possible to transform transport and make them more efficient, less polluting and more reliable only through a small number of selected interventions.  I agree with the need to take stock in order to get an overview of the situation with regard to the implementation of the 40 initiatives and 131 actions. On the other hand, the extremely ambitious targets seem very difficult to achieve if they are not supported by a detailed and robust project plan, linked to realistic and achievable short- and medium-term goals towards long-term objectives.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it advocates greater integration of transport policies at the expense of the role of states.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the implementation of the 2011 White Paper on transport because, with environmental concerns and global warming, specific provisions have been infiltrated to serve commercial interests.

name: Ashley FOX
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as it calls for more social legislation at EU level and also calls for the unnecessary creation of a new European Road Transport Agency. On top of these concerns, the report needlessly drags Gibraltar into the matter. It is only Spain’s refusal to accept the Cordoba Agreement which is preventing citizens flying to and from Gibraltar’s airport as regards EU aviation matters.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ Through the adoption of this report, we will provide current and future generations with access to safe, secure, reliable and affordable mobility resources to meet their needs, while minimising undesirable impacts such as congestion, accidents, air and noise pollution, and climate change effects.  I strongly support the inclusion, in the report of important social aspect in all modes of transport such as ensuring equal and fair treatment, good and safe working environment, promoting high quality jobs and working conditions for transport workers and ensuring fair and undistorted competition between transport operators. I welcome the introduction of measures for doubling public transport use in urban areas by 2030; the inclusion of measures for safety, usage in urban areas, elderly or disabled people and cyclist and the shift towards a more sustainable transport mode, less polluting and most energy-efficient mode of transport. These steps are of fundamental importance in the path to define a long-term strategy that would help the EU transport system achieve the overall goal of the Common Transport Policy.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of my colleague van de Camp's report, as it is necessary to make better use of rail and waterborne transport and to support and promote electric and innovative forms of transport, particularly in the field of freight transport. By taking better advantage of opportunities, we can grow our economy, protect our environment and reduce traffic jams on our roads, and create new jobs. At the same time, it is necessary to reduce Europe's dependence on oil. To do so, however, the EU needs to rethink its transport policy. At the same time, I did not support the points put in the robe of so-called social dumping in the report, which are contrary to the interests of Hungarian entrepreneurs and hauliers and whose primary objective is to protect the jobs of Western companies.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. I congratulate the Committee on Transport on the work it has done on this report, which takes very careful account of the possible new stages in the development of the transport sector in Europe. I think it is important to highlight a passage in the text that has just been voted on, which calls on the European Commission to update its strategy in the light of emission reduction targets and new policy proposals on energy and climate, in particular with regard to achieving the binding target of reducing national greenhouse gas emissions by at least 40% by 2030 compared to 1990 levels.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP own-initiative resolution on the implementation of the 2011 White Paper on transport: budget and way forward for sustainable mobility, because I believe that the issue of sustainable mobility is one of the main challenges for the European Union in the coming decades. Indeed, I believe that it is the EU's duty to ensure that its citizens and future generations have safe, modern and efficient transport systems that are also environmentally friendly and road-friendly.  I therefore welcome Parliament's call for a transport policy in line with the 2030 environmental objectives: more public transport, more integrated systems, more weight of rail than road transport, institutionalisation of the 'polluter pays' principle. I believe that transport policy must focus on people, and i therefore supported the call for a 40% reduction in the number of people seriously injured as a result of road accidents, to strengthen road safety and to protect passengers' rights. As transport is a driving force of the European economy in the global market and a primary source of employment, I fully support Parliament's call to ensure safe and dignified working conditions for workers in the sector, promoting quality work.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. I support the implementation of the White Paper on Transport for a competitive and resource-efficient transport system. By shifting freight transport to rail and sea transport, we are protecting our environment and reducing congestion on the roads and in aviation. It will also reduce Europe's dependence on oil imports.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because it is vital we achieve a more extensive, efficient and environmentally-friendly public transport system across the European Union for citizens and businesses alike.

name: Juan Carlos GIRAUTA VIDAL
text: in writing. ‒ First of all, I would like to say that I welcome the rejection of paragraph 63, indent 12 on the case of Gibraltar. Neither the Council nor the EU should interfere in this matter – only the interested parties.  I was pleased to support this report on the implementation of the 2011 White paper on transport that stresses the need to achieve a European integrated transport system and to create a Single European Transport Area. Furthermore, this report also calls for the improvement of access to public transport for people with disability or reduced mobility.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted against this report. A report supporting the Commission's decision to carry out an interim review of the White Paper in order to assess progress made and proposing further action to achieve its objectives with the aim of a more efficient, sustainable, competitive, accessible and user-adapted transport system. However, this report, despite having a good technical approach, contains political aspects related to opening up transport markets that make it questionable. It is clearly aligned with the Commission's market-friendly approach and, consequently, to the progressive privatisation of transport services. There are paragraphs that refer, not to mention, to TTIP and other trade agreements: "It stresses that the creation of a European transport area is an important priority and that (...) continues to depend on international acceptance under globally negotiated agreements with our trading partners for all modes of transport (...)". We cannot allow an acceptable technical report to use a backdoor through which recommendations go by that undermine the viability of the public transport system.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I, and my European Parliamentary Labour Party, colleagues voted for this. This report looks in a detailed way at how we move forward to achieve a more efficient, environmental and extensive public transport system across the EU, that not only meets the needs of citizens but those of businesses as well.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to make all modes of transport in Europe more efficient, cleaner, safer and more reliable. With an improved European transport system we could, for example, significantly reduce Europe's dependence on oil imports. This dependence weakens us geopolitically, as we are currently seeing with the crisis in Russia. In addition, a better European transport system can reduce transport-related carbon emissions by 60% by 2050 and thus support more sustainable European mobility.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the report on the implementation of the 2011 White Paper on Transport. I truly support the stronger harmonisation of the European transport area and a fairer competition in transport. Also, the implementation of the initiatives presented on the 2011 White Paper should be speeded up. I believe it is necessary to achieve the Single European Sky and the 4th Railway Package. Above all, the progress is crucially needed: new models of transport must be created, which would be more effective and sustainable, which would increase the speed of the movement of people and goods within the EU. These are the grounds on which I have decided to vote favourably on this report.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the speeding—up of the implementation of all the initiatives in the report of the 2011 White Paper on transport. The European Commission adopted in 2011 a roadmap of 40 initiatives to build a competitive transport system to increase mobility, remove major barriers in key areas and fuel growth and employment. The review of this paper serves to increase and streamline those 40 initiatives. A stronger harmonisation of the European transport area and a fairer competition in transport must be developed. Of particular importance is the need for achieving the Single European Sky and the 4th Railway Package, and resolving the Anglo-Spanish dispute over Gibraltar.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: Written. In Wednesday, 9 September 2015, Parliament voted on an own-initiative report on the implementation and revision of the 2011 White Paper on sustainable transport in the run-up to the mid-term review of the White Paper and future initiatives in the field of transport. The Conservatives are in favour of the report, which focuses on a competitive transport sector, jobs and growth, and was in favour of the report, which included wordings on stricter rules on sulphur in marine fuels. On the other hand, the Conservatives voted against proposals for a general framework for national road charging systems for passenger cars and a doubling of public transport use by 2030 in urban areas, as the Conservatives believe that this is up to the Member States to decide for themselves. The Conservatives also want to emphasize that new business models like Uber can be developed.

name: Mary HONEYBALL
text: in writing. ‒ I was very pleased to support this report, which looks in detail at how we can achieve a more extensive, efficient and environmentally-friendly public transport system in the EU for citizens and businesses. This report is also strong on improving public transport for disabled people and those with reduced mobility.

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the text in this report calling for an EU framework for road charging, as I believe that this must remain a national competence. In Scotland road transport is vital for the economic and social viability of highland, island and rural communities. I utterly reject the views of urban commentators who regard road transport as an ill which must be eliminated.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. We voted against this report. A report supporting the Commission's decision to carry out an interim review of the White Paper in order to assess progress made and proposing further action to achieve its objectives with the aim of a more efficient, sustainable, competitive, accessible and user-adapted transport system. However, this report, despite having a good technical approach, contains political aspects related to opening up transport markets that make it questionable. It is clearly aligned with the Commission's market-friendly approach and, consequently, to the progressive privatisation of transport services. There are paragraphs that refer, not to mention, to TTIP and other trade agreements: "It stresses that the creation of a European transport area is an important priority and that (...) continues to depend on international acceptance under globally negotiated agreements with our trading partners for all modes of transport (...)".     We cannot allow an acceptable technical report to use a backdoor through which recommendations go by that undermine the viability of the public transport system.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a European Parliament resolution on the implementation of the 2011 Transport White Paper: "Looking at the current situation and the way forward towards sustainable mobility" because it is clear that many progresses have taken place in this sector.  However, changes and reforms are still needed to maintain the competitiveness of European transport and logistics. Air travel, for example, faces challenges and threats from the internal and external markets, while the level of greenhouse gas emissions is still too high. Furthermore, there are major differences in transport infrastructure between eastern and western countries of the European Union.  I therefore believe that it is necessary to insist on an integrated transport system and to invest in new technologies that will help the transport sector and mobility to become safer, more efficient, more reliable and "green".

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. The 2011 Transport White Paper contains many negative measures. Under spurious pretexts such as global warming, this report calls on the Commission to intervene in road taxation and calls for an increase in European funds allocated to transport policy. One of the stated objectives is to strengthen the European Union's interventionism in urban transport.  In addition, the report has repeatedly recommended more sanctions and more severity for motorists who commit offences. It borders on persecution. This is particularly scandalous and unfair when we know that real offenders and criminals benefit from a very lax judicial system, especially in France.  As for the passages on global warming, their ridiculous alarmism justifies the promotion of walking, cycling and "gender-ventilated modes of transport" (sic!) as well as the adoption of new regulations against carbon-emitting modes of transport.   For all these reasons, I voted against this report.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which outlines the main transportation issues for the next few years. We need to find less energy-intensive and cleaner modes of transport in order to support the recommendations of the European Commission, which in its White Paper presented its strategy for a competitive transport system that will aim to increase mobility but also promote growth and employment.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. The report is a good summary of the implementation so far of the 2011 White Paper on Transport and adapts proposals for action to 2015. The transport sector is the only one that has increased its CO2 emissions since 2009, a problem that needs to be addressed. I am therefore voting in favour of this report.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report, as it looks in detail at the way forward to achieve a more extensive, efficient and environmentally-friendly public transport system across the EU for citizens and businesses alike.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this proposal. In its 2011 Transport White Paper, the European Commission presented an ambitious future strategy for a competitive transport system to increase mobility and promote growth and employment. It reiterates its support for the objectives set out in the White Paper to achieve the objective of reducing greenhouse gas emissions by 60%, and stresses that a European sustainable mobility policy must be based on a wide range of policy instruments aimed at the transition to less polluting and energy-efficient modes of transport.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution on the implementation of the 2011 White Paper on transport. This report calls for an acceleration of European integration, particularly in the aviation sector, as well as an even greater eu interventionism in urban transport. Front National MPs, who support the continuation of the principle of subsidiarity, will continue to oppose this.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Mr van de Camp's report reflects many of the assessments, proposals and proposals made by Parliament's Committee on Transport and Tourism. The Transport White Paper requires a significant revision, change and adaptation to the new reality, especially as we are after difficult economic years in many Member States. The financial perspective 2007-2013 brought about significant changes in the infrastructure of the new Member States. However, we are still quite far from the vision of a single European transport space and coherent infrastructure. The TEN-T has still not been developed satisfactorily, which would include interoperability, the development of intelligent transport systems, road, track and air safety. Increasing the efficiency of transport, charging for the use of infrastructure, the role of public, collective passenger transport are another important area in which we make modifications. Drones and their rules of use are a new technical solution, so I welcome the proposal for appropriate regulation. The CEF is an important new financial instrument that, in combination with the Juncker Plan, creates new opportunities; prudent implementation policy of the Commission is needed. With this in mind, I support this report, although I still have reservations about the European Commission's behaviour on the German law on the minimum wage for drivers of cars and buses.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted against this report because I believe that its approach does not sufficiently take into account the effects of liberalisation of transport on working conditions in the sector, nor does it propose an infrastructure policy linked to a productive model that pours and cohesives the European economy, but leaves both in the interests of large companies and private investors. Social dumping in air transport, abuses of cabotage and displacement directives, the devastating effects of railway privatization and basic infrastructure... These are problems which the Commission, with Parliament's endorsement, refuses to address in the context of upward labour harmonisation, greater controls on the conditions of self-employed and dependent workers and strengthening public ownership and management. That's why I voted against it.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒the White Paper on Transport set out an ambitious plan to transform Europe's transport system and create a truly single European transport area. Its main objective is to increase mobility, remove barriers and promote growth and jobs. At the same time, the proposals seek to reduce oil imports to Europe and reduce transport carbon emissions by 60% by 2050. The transport sector is the driving force behind the European Union economy. It employs around 10 million people and accounts for around 5% of GDP and as such should remain at the forefront of creating further economic growth and jobs and promoting competitiveness, sustainable development and territorial cohesion.  I supported the van de Camp report, as it is essential for the self-sustaining development of European transport and promotes the introduction of alternative fuels to reduce transport dependence on fossil fuels, improve air quality and reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Transport is a complex system based on the interaction between infrastructure, vehicles and information technology, rules and behaviors. Only through joint action by citizens and industry at local, national and regional levels can a breakthrough be made.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing ‒ the 2011 White Paper on Transport sets ambitious transport targets in the EU, which should be met by 2050 at the latest. Trends in the global economy require building a strong, competitive and secure system in all areas of transport, while also taking into account the needs of improving the quality of the environment and reducing the need for energy intensity. The transport sector is also an important source of increasing employment. Meeting the objectives of the White Paper and creating a fully integrated Single European Transport Area requires monitoring and reassessment of the achievement of individual tasks, taking into account the ultimate objective and current developments in world transport.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on 'Implementation of the 2011 White Paper on transport: an assessment and a future path towards sustainable mobility', for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 8/9/2015. I would point out that the European Union has not yet promoted sufficient infrastructure to reduce road accidents. At the same time, the European Union must strengthen maritime transport in order for the inhabitants of island regions, especially in the Aegean, to have continuous access to the hinterland.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I vote AGAINST this report calling for an acceleration of European integration in the field of transport. This text wants the Commission to have more powers in the area of urban transport, multi-modal intercity transport and long-distance travel.  This would strengthen the Commission's powers and cause Member States to lose sovereignty over transport policy.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ Stresses that the 2030 reduction target for GHG emissions from transport should be set at a level that will allow the achievement of the long-term target of the White Paper of an at least 60% reduction of GHG emissions from transport by 2050; calls in this context on the Commission to propose a comprehensive strategy for the decarbonisation of transport.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the proposal on the implementation of the 2011 White Paper on transport: budget and the way forward for sustainable mobility. Innovation in the transport sector must be efficient and functional and have a pragmatic and realistic vision. The ultimate aim of the report is to emphasise the need for priority ecological methods for climate environmental aspects and impact, to improve public transport and to make it more eco-friendly.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: in writing. \u2012 What is contained in the 2011 White Paper on transport is clearly the liberalisation of transport. I cannot in any way agree to these objectives so I could not help but vote against it.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. The report prepared by Parliament on the implementation of the 2011 White Paper on transport shows that further work is needed in the EU to address mobility challenges and remove major barriers in key areas to promote growth and employment. My support for the text presented, which points to the need to promote a robust and competitive transport system in a global context, to face increasing competition in international aviation, to achieve a rebalancing of modes of transport, to make people the central objective of transport policy and to continue to work to create a single European transport area.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. Even if the ambitious amendments to reduce CO2 emissions are not adopted, this report still draws a comprehensive conclusion on the implementation of the 2011 White Paper to date. This report also adapts the White Paper to 2015. The rapporteur recognises the need for action in the transport sector, which is the only sector that has increased its CO2 emissions since 2009. In addition to noise reduction in freight rail transport, electric mobility is also to be expanded, as it is of great importance in the public transport system. I therefore agree with this report.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The purpose of this report is to conduct a mid-term review of the white paper with the aim of assessing the progress made since 2011 and proposing other measures to achieve its objectives. The objectives focus mainly on open markets and the complete liberalisation of air, river, road and maritime transport. With the consequences of the abolition of public services and the increase in transport prices, all under the aegis of the concept of "modal transfer". The European Commission has added some greening elements to take environmental requirements into account, but the account is not there at all. I'm voting against it.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The 2011 Transport White Paper contains many negative measures. Under spurious pretexts such as global warming, this report calls on the Commission to intervene in road taxation and calls for an increase in European funds allocated to transport policy. One of the stated objectives is to strengthen the European Union's interventionism in urban transport.  In addition, the report has repeatedly recommended more sanctions and more severity for motorists who commit offences. It borders on persecution. This is particularly scandalous and unfair when we know that real offenders and criminals benefit from a very lax judicial system, especially in France.  As for the passages on global warming, their ridiculous alarmism justifies the promotion of walking, cycling and "gender-ventilated modes of transport" (sic!) as well as the adoption of new regulations against carbon-emitting modes of transport.   For all these reasons, I voted against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 In its 2011 White Paper on transport, the European Commission presented an ambitious future strategy for a competitive transport system with a view to increasing mobility, removing key barriers in key areas and promoting growth and jobs. At the same time, the proposals aim to drastically reduce Europe's dependence on oil imports and reduce carbon emissions in transport by 60% by 2050. Many of these tasks are still to be achieved. We have to work harder to achieve them. Only then will we have sustainable and healthy growth of economies.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in support of the resolution. The 2011 White Paper on Transport established long-term goals to improve transportation systems across the EU. It covers areas of transportation policy from sustainability of the energy used to the actual reliability of the individual lines. This comprehensive approach to transportation policy will serve as a holistic guide to the next several decades.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. The single market must also immediately integrate a dense, modern and efficient, resource-efficient transport infrastructure network at the service of free movement and trade, which is practical for citizens and users, able to meet the challenge of sustainable mobility as well as urban mobility. The development of trans-European transport networks must be accelerated, notably by implementing the mechanisms for interconnection in Europe (MIE). The fourth railway package to complete the creation of a single rail market was adopted by the European Parliament on 26 February 2014. As parliamentarians we have made sure to protect the employment, status and working conditions of staff. If we do not have a problem with the technical chapter aimed at Europeanising the rail network by transferring more competence to the European Railway Agency, the political aspect is much more delicate. It would require transport contracts to be subjected to competition by 2019. An integrated multimodal approach (rail, river and land) should be developed.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on the implementation of the 2011 White paper on transport, which calls to define a long-term strategy that would help the EU transport system achieve the overall goal of the Common Transport Policy, i.e. to provide current and future generations with access to safe, secure, reliable and affordable mobility resources to meet their needs, while minimising undesirable impacts such as congestion, accidents, air and noise pollution, and climate change effects. Even if this is a very positive report and I voted in favour, I could not support certain paragraphs which in my opinion impinge negatively on the policy areas that fall strictly under a competence of the Member States.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 In the 2011 White Paper on Transport, the strategy drafted by the European Commission aimed at making the transport system competitive, with the aim of increasing mobility, removing barriers in key areas and promoting growth and employment. The proposals would also significantly reduce Europe's dependence on oil imports and reduce transport CO2 emissions by 60% by 2050. The rapporteur reiterates the European Parliament's support for the implementation of the White Paper on transport, but points out that, to this end, very difficult targets must be achieved by 2050 and serious challenges by 2020/2030. It underlines that transport is a complex system whose desired transformation and making it more efficient, cleaner, safer and more reliable is not possible through a few minor changes. It considers that there is a significant gap between the objectives and the means to achieve and finance them, and that very ambitious targets are difficult to achieve until more detailed and sound plans are drawn up to achieve them, which include realistic and achievable short- and medium-term objectives and which then lead to the achievement of the long-term (2050) targets. I supported the report.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This 2011 Transport White Paper prepares the European transport area for the future (post-oil, global warming) and makes the transport system competitive and sustainable while ensuring more efficient use of resources. The report further explains that the analysis of compliance with the timetable shows that the aviation sector is lagging far behind. It calls on Member States to implement the provisions that have already been adopted. It envisages a doubling of urban transport in the coming years, increasing the saturation of networks. To this end, the report calls for an acceleration of integration, particularly in air transport, as well as greater EU intervention in urban transport. Of course, I am opposed to increasing the EU's grip on this sector. So I voted against it.

name: Clare MOODY
text: in writing. ‒ I – and my British Labour colleagues – will be voting to remove from the resolution on ‘the implementation of the 2011 white book on transport' the reference to the Council of Ministers being asked to resolve the dispute between the UK and Spain with respect to Gibraltar airport that is preventing the implementation of a number of EU directives regarding air transport.
