First, there is no dispute. This issue was resolved with the Cordoba Agreement, when there was a comprehensive settlement of a number of outstanding issues regarding Gibraltar. The UK and Gibraltar fully implemented their side of the agreement while the incoming conservative government in Madrid subsequently reneged on what had been agreed by the previous Socialist government. Second, there should be no attempt now or in the future to resolve any outstanding issues in Gibraltar in the absence of representatives of the Government of Gibraltar. The European institutions are right to be concerned at the delays to implement sound and sensible regulations regarding air transport and passengers' rights, but the pressure should be firmly applied to those responsible for the current impasse, which is solely the current conservative government in Madrid.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ I was pleased to vote for this report, which looks in detail at the way forward to achieving a more extensive, efficient and environmentally-friendly public transport system across the European Union for citizens and businesses alike.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the implementation of the 2011 White Paper on Transport. Transport is an engine of the European economy, employing nearly 10 million people and accounting for about 5% of GDP. The report reiterates that it is essential that companies in this sector continue to grow, invest and renew themselves in order to maintain their global technological supremacy. It is about retaining and creating jobs in a context of strong international competition.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report that reiterates the European Parliament’s support for the effective implementation of the White Paper on Transport.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the implementation of the 2011 White Paper on transport, because, in my opinion, this is an objective that brings into question the achievements so far, but also the objectives that remain under discussion in this area vital for the European Union. The Commission's interim assessment of the application of the 2011 White Paper on transport is defining for creating a clear perspective on our progress and progress to date. We need to know very precisely which of the objectives have been met, which are to be met and which ones we will not achieve at the current rate. This assessment, as the report also points out, must provide concrete solutions to achieve all objectives, make resource use more efficient and, last but not least, keep up with new developments in the EU, without setting lower targets than in 2011. I believe that the document brings beneficial assessments and analyses to the EU and transport policies, which are so important for our societies and for the economic development of European states.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU's transport policy faces considerable challenges in the form of the transition to more sustainable and energy-efficient modes of transport, the building of modern infrastructure and the completion of the trans-European transport network. In this context, the report on the implementation of the 2011 White Paper on Transport rightly highlights the need to develop a market for electric vehicles and alternative fuels (electricity, hydrogen, natural gas - CNG and LNG, sustainable biofuels, in particular biofuels made from waste and processing residues, including molasses-based ethanol) and the accelerated deployment of the necessary infrastructure for charging vehicles and refuelling. Greater efforts are needed to promote the development of sustainable electromobility across the Union. On the other hand, I believe that the report does not include a call on the Commission to take, if necessary, support measures to prevent differences between social conditions in transport between member states in order to prevent so-called social dumping. Social dumping is a concept that is abused for discrimination against Czech car transporters, and I strongly oppose this.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report because it adapts to 2015. The rapporteur also recognises the need for action in the transport sector, which is the only sector that has increased its CO2 emissions since 2009.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. I consider it important to make the transformation of the transport system as efficient, cleaner, safer and more reliable as possible. This is a mid-term review aimed at increasing and coordinating efforts to achieve sustainable mobility.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Considering that the sustainability of transport is one of the greatest challenges facing the urban fabric, I believe it is necessary to implement an accurate approach at European level in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity enshrined in the Treaties. I therefore voted in favour with regard to the Commission's White Paper to promote sustainable mobility over a period of time until at least 2050.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – Transport is an extremely complex system, which is the engine of the fast and mobile world in which we live. Transport is a key economic sector and vital for European and international business. The European Union needs to rethink its policy to meet the near future with a smart, competitive, safe, integrated and modern transport system in place. I voted in favour of Mr van De Camp's report as it highlights all the talking points in depth and detail, offers alternatives to address the many challenges we face and presents us with short, medium and long-term measures for the sustainable development of this sector.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ As the transport sector is the driving force behind the European Union economy, employing around 10 million people, accounting for around 5% of GDP and remaining at the forefront of creating further economic growth and creating and preserving jobs, I supported the implementation of the 2011 Transport White Playbook.  I believe it is necessary to invest even more in the development of European transport, as well as transport infrastructure, in order to maintain the competitiveness of a World-leading Europe in manufacturing and transport. It is also necessary to move to the types of transport that are least harmful to the environment and the most energy efficient, especially to the types of transport that use renewable energy sources.  The Transport White Paper is the backbone for implementing concrete reforms to establish a more competitive and efficient transport system. I therefore supported the implementation report with the hope that it would also open up broader perspectives and contribute to economic growth and employment gains.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This 2011 Transport White Paper prepares the European transport area for the future (post-oil, global warming) and makes the transport system competitive and sustainable while ensuring more efficient use of resources. The report further explains that the analysis of compliance with the timetable shows that the aviation sector is lagging far behind. It calls on Member States to implement the provisions that have already been adopted. It envisages a doubling of urban transport in the coming years, increasing the saturation of networks. To this end, the report calls for an acceleration of integration, particularly in air transport, as well as greater EU intervention in urban transport. Of course, I am opposed to any increase in the EU's grip on this sector. So I voted against it.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒the White Paper on Transport set out an ambitious plan to transform Europe's transport system and create a truly single European transport area. The transport sector represents the driving force of the European Union economy , which employs around ten million people and accounts for about 5 % of GDP . Therefore, I support the rapporteur's proposal, as there is an urgent need to improve the energy efficiency and sustainability of the transport system and reduce dependence on oil and other fossil energy sources in a cost-effective manner, without sacrificing competitiveness and limiting mobility, in line with the White Book objectives.  Measures towards faster mobility would encourage the creation of further economic growth and jobs and the promotion of competitiveness, sustainable development and territorial cohesion, as transport is the basis for the free movement of the people, goods and services underpinning the single market, while free movement is at the same time a powerful driver of Union integration and a key factor in the implementation of European industry and trade.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. - In the year 2011 in the implementation of the Transport White Deal, the Commission presented an ambitious future strategy for the transport system with the aim of increasing mobility, removing major barriers in key areas and promoting growth and jobs. Solving the big problems seen in the White Paper means meeting very difficult targets by 2050.  Transport is a complex system based on the interaction of infrastructure, vehicles, information technology, rules and behaviors. All these elements must be part of a common vision for change. The changes proposed in the White Paper should not only be seen as an opportunity to increase efficiency, but also as a necessary condition for maintaining the competitiveness of the European transport and logistics sector. At the same time, the purpose of the audit is not to lower the level of ambition of the targets set in 2011, but to modernise strategies to achieve a successful result.  Given the fact that the transport sector is the driving force behind the EU economy and employs around 10 million people and accounts for around 5 % of GDP and should remain at the forefront of creating further economic growth and jobs and promoting competitiveness and sustainable development, it is of utmost importance for Member States. Also, taking into account the fact that innovation and intelligent transport systems should play a major role in the development of a modern, efficient, sustainable and interoperable European transport system available for all, I support the Wima van de Camp report.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 White Papers are documents illustrating Community action in a given area. In my opinion, transport is one of the sectors which requires the highest level of integration at European level. In its 2011 Transport White Paper, the European Commission presented an ambitious future strategy for a competitive transport system that can increase mobility, break down key barriers in key sectors and promote growth and employment. The proposed initiatives aim, at the same time, to significantly reduce Europe's dependence on oil imports and to reduce carbon emissions in the transport sector by 60% by 2050. All these initiatives are being implemented and consolidated. Parliament has decided to take a positive view of the implementation of the White Paper and I have also chosen to vote in favour of it.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 Stressing the need to eliminate differences in the level of development and maintenance of infrastructure, in particular between the eastern and western parts of the European Union, and to develop a European transport policy and a free market for transport services, I supported the report on the revision of the White Paper. However, the report also addresses a number of issues, such as decarbonisation, the costly decarbonisation commitment, the reduction of transport dependency on fossil fuels, the creation of a European Road Transport Agency, which directly threaten the Polish economy and against which I voted.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Writing. \u2012 I am staying with this report even though it contains a number of positive elements. In some passages, however, it unacceptably addresses for me issues related to cases, such as the impact of the German minimum wage on Czech carriers and their employees. Competition cannot be regarded as social dumping. Similarly, I have doubts about the requirement to further harmonise driving licences, issue them and to re-vet drivers.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. Transport policy is a crucial issue for the development of territories and trade within the Union. The free movement of goods and citizens in the UNION reinforces the strategic importance of transport and the need for an ambitious, coherent and coordinated European transport policy in this area. With this in mind, the European Commission presented a white paper on transport in 2011. I voted in favour of the report on the implementation of this white paper. The adopted text reiterates Parliament's support for the effective implementation of the measures announced in the white paper. In addition, it calls on the Commission to be realistic and efficient in order to modernise the transport system in the Union. In particular, I support measures to return the competitiveness of the aviation sector, which is largely at risk in Europe.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 This Resolution of the European Parliament takes stock of the incipient implementation of the 2011 White Paper in order to gain an overview of the situation with regard to the implementation of the policies taken since its adoption. Because of the early status of the mid-term review, to be carried out by the Commission in the near future, the rapporteur can only take a full look at transport efforts. The report lists the challenges by organising them on the following axes: competition in international aviation, the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions, the balance between modes of transport and the single European transport area. Once identified, the challenges will be taken into account when drawing up a more efficient, sustainable, competitive, accessible, user-friendly and user-friendly transport plan for European citizens. In order to support the early planning to which the complexity of the transport system and the multiplicity of factors oblige, I supported with my vote the report under consideration.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: In writing. Today, MEPs adopted the report on the revision of the European Transport White Paper. This report aims to take stock of the ten objectives of the white paper adopted in 2011, but also to be a force of proposal to influence the future European transport policy. With this vote, MEPs sent a clear message for the Commission to take action and sanctions against social dumping practices in transport. On the climate front, I welcome the fact that this report calls on the Commission to include a target of a 40% reduction in CO2 emissions in transport by 2030 into the climate and energy package, which will be adopted in this Parliament. Finally, by calling for a new target to double the number of public transport services by 2030, MEPs sent a strong message to promote the role of public transport. Although I voted in favour of the report, I nevertheless voted against three paragraphs calling for the reopening of the Mega-Truck Directive, the liberalisation of rail public service contracts and port services.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree with the review of the objectives set out in the White Paper on Transport. It is important that we continue to evolve in particular in an area that is one of the main drivers of the EU economy, employing around 10 million people. But I also do not forget how important it is to overcome the barriers that persist in relation to dependence on oil and other energy resources derived from fossil fuels. I hope that it will be possible to achieve the goals set out in the White Paper.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because, thanks to the contributions of the S&D Group, it introduces important social recommendations. In particular, it is committed to ensuring fair and decent working conditions for workers, promoting quality employment, improving training, adopting a social code for mobile road workers, greater participation of women in the sector or measures to reduce social disparities in transport workers between Member States, among others. In addition, and on the contribution of the Spanish Socialists, it introduces a number of proposals to maintain the level of ambition in road safety, the inclusion of the revision of the directive on cross-border fines or greater attention to vulnerable users, such as pedestrians, cyclists or older drivers.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. This initiative report on the implementation of the 2011 Transport White Paper that I voted on yesterday calls on the European Commission to adopt measures to help Member States reduce their greenhouse gas emissions and calls for a comprehensive transport 'decarbonisation' strategy to achieve the white paper's objectives. As part of the Commission's mid-term review of European transport policy, the text calls for strengthening co-modality in order to achieve the 2030 targets (a 40% reduction from 1990 levels) and 2050 (60% compared to 1990 levels) to strengthen co-modality by focusing on the cleanest modes of transport. The text also calls on the Commission to submit proposals to internalise the external costs of freight and passenger transport to ensure better application of the user-pay and polluter-pay principles. We also called for an increase in budget allocation, notably through the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI), the European Interconnection Mechanism (MIE) to complete the Trans-European Transport Network (TEN-T) by 2030.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 In the 2011 White Paper on Transport, the Commission presented an ambitious future strategy for a competitive transport system with the aim of increasing mobility, removing key barriers in key sectors, promoting growth and jobs.  The proposals put forward set challenging targets to drastically reduce Europe's dependence on fossil fuels and reduce carbon emissions in the transport sector by 60% by 2050.  It will not be possible to make the complex transport sector more efficient, cleaner, safer and more reliable with only a small number of specific interventions at European level, so it will be necessary to combine with actions at national, regional and local level.  As such, the mid-term review of the Transport White Paper should maintain this long-term vision (2050), complementing it with intermediate targets and objectives for the coming years that can be properly assessed in terms of efficiency, strength and effectiveness. I have shturn the rapporteur's positions on the priority to be given to energy-efficient sustainable modes of transport and the creation of a single European transport area, capable of being strong and competitive on the world stage, and I have therefore voted in a favourable direction.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. The transportation sector is a complex system based on the interaction between infrastructure, vehicles, information technology, rules and behaviour. All of these elements must be part of a common and long-term vision.  I voted in favour of this report, which stresses that the mid-term review of the transport white paper must be complemented by intermediate objectives for the coming years. The sector has a strong potential for profitability.  The list of initiatives and action points proposed in the white paper must be adapted and completed on a regular basis, and assessed for their effectiveness in achieving long-term objectives.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the own-initiative report on the implementation of the 2011 White Paper on transport, which aims at a competitive transport system to promote mobility, development and employment. The aim of the proposal is also to make Europe less dependent on oil imports and to reduce carbon emissions in the transport sector by 60% by 2050. The key points of this project are those relating to the importance of achieving a competitive and effective transport system, of facilitating development and competition in the international aviation sector. Creating a single European transport area where the needs of citizens are met by a transport policy capable of filling existing gaps is what the report calls for in line with my thinking.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted against this report. A report supporting the Commission's decision to carry out an interim review of the White Paper in order to assess progress made and proposing further action to achieve its objectives with the aim of a more efficient, sustainable, competitive, accessible and user-adapted transport system. However, this report, despite having a good technical approach, contains political aspects related to opening up transport markets that make it questionable. It is clearly aligned with the Commission's market-friendly approach and, consequently, to the progressive privatisation of transport services. There are paragraphs that refer, not to mention, to TTIP and other trade agreements: "It stresses that the creation of a European transport area is an important priority and that (...) continues to depend on international acceptance under globally negotiated agreements with our trading partners for all modes of transport (...)".     We cannot allow an acceptable technical report to use a backdoor through which recommendations go by that undermine the viability of the public transport system

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted against this report because I believe that its approach does not sufficiently take into account the effects of liberalisation of transport on working conditions in the sector, nor does it propose an infrastructure policy linked to a productive model that pours and cohesives the European economy, but leaves both in the interests of large companies and private investors. Social dumping in air transport, abuses of cabotage and displacement directives, the devastating effects of railway privatization and basic infrastructure... These are problems which the Commission, with Parliament's endorsement, refuses to address in the context of upward labour harmonisation, greater controls on the conditions of self-employed and dependent workers and strengthening public ownership and management. That's why I voted against it.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this proposal as it is full of contradictions and is unfounded. It calls for the Commission to promote the use of cable cars as an affordable means of transport. Past examples of this such as the Thames cable car prove this to be incorrect. It also calls for a 0.0 driving alcohol limit as a mandatory. I do not recognise the EU to have the power to dictate this to the UK. I also worry that it calls for a major review of previous legislations that the UK has an opt-out of, I do not wish to see us lose this opt-out clause.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ This report looks in detail at the way forward to achieve a more efficient, environmental and extensive public transport system across the EU, for citizens as well as for businesses. This is why I voted for the report in plenary today.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing ‒ I also consider transport and the creation of a single transport area to be very important for economic growth, job growth and the quality of transport services, which is why I voted in favour of adopting this resolution on the implementation of the White Paper on Transport.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ This explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. The 2011 White Paper on Transport set out an ambitious plan to transform the European transport system and create a genuine single European transport area. The strategy for a competitive transport system aims to increase mobility, remove major barriers in key areas and boost growth and employment. At the same time, the proposals aim to significantly reduce Europe's dependence on imported oil and reduce transport carbon emissions by 60% by 2050. In principle, I believe that the White Paper is good, but I am also committed to modernising the emission reduction targets, to ensure the internalisation of the external costs of all freight and passenger transport modes in order to avoid double taxation, to establish the facts about the social, economic and environmental benefits that further support for national and international night rail services and IC services would bring, to prohibit over-loud freight wagons throughout the EU by 2020 , to explore the possibility of extending sulphur limit values for marine fuels for the entire European maritime space and for promoting walking and cycling. The report describes the real picture of the White Paper and draws attention to the necessary assessment of the extent to which the list of measures set out in the White Paper is sufficient to achieve its general objectives, which is why I supported the report.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing ‒ Europe needs a competitive transport system in order to increase mobility and boost growth and jobs. This Commission proposal also aims to reduce Europe's dependence on oil imports and to reduce carbon emissions in transport by 60% by 2050. I support the effective implementation of the White Paper on Transport because I believe that transport needs to become more efficient, cleaner, safer and more reliable.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. \u2012 I support the report because it is necessary that traffic-related issues, strategies and plans are planned in a few years in advance and with vision, since it is a complex system that depends on several factors, which is very important in everyday life.  The 2011 White Paper is an ambitious road plan and strategy for the future for a competitive transport system aimed at increasing mobility, erasing borders in some key areas and promoting economic growth and employment, and these objectives need to continue to be addressed. It is also necessary to reduce Europe's dependence on imported oil and carbon, which are still predominantly used in transport.  Therefore, there should be a tendency towards the use of traffic that is economically and energy efficient and this should be the case in each Member State. This report and strategy maintain the 2011 targets and work to achieve these objectives as soon as possible and better. Therefore, I support the report.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ I was pleased to vote for this report which looks in detail at the way forward to achieve a more extensive, efficient and environmentally-friendly public transport system across the European Union for citizens and businesses alike.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒Holding that transport is a very productive, purposeful and representative branch reflecting the strength of European policies, it is essential to make the necessary changes and upgrades to the national and international road system possible in advance, before European roads become obsolete. I support this initiative to further build systems in order to provide better and faster transport connectivity, more mobile and qualified personnel in charge of maintaining the transport system and to maintain an enviable level of economic viability of this branch of European policy as set out in the '2011 White Paper on transport'. This report is in line with EUROPEAN Union policies and through a holistic approach to the problem supports the growth and development of the transport sector, greater technological advancement and maintenance of transport infrastructures, environmental awareness, valid legal regulations.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: I did not support the report in writing ‒ because I do not agree with many of its proposed measures to support the development of EU transport and infrastructure. The report places too much emphasis on improving social conditions, reducing dependence on fossil fuels and other measures that will increase regulatory burdens and ultimately harm the passengers they are supposed to protect.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the implementation of the 2011 White Paper on Transport: assessment and the way forward towards sustainable mobility. The transport sector in Europe is of paramount importance for the provision of services. We must constantly strive to achieve improvements in various areas: sustainability, innovation, smart transport systems, increasing cleaner transport, decarbonisation, noise, air quality, etc. We also have a lot of work to do in the area of urban transport, but we have to be very careful not to impose solutions that are not suitable for a particular local environment. At European Union level, passengers should be allowed to travel door-to-door without borders. Passengers should be given the fastest or cheapest travel option by a single ticket. They must be able to choose, book and pay online, no matter how many different means of transport the passenger uses.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the own-initiative report on the implementation of the 2011 White Paper on Transport, which assesses the european transport policy strategies to date. The aim of this strategy is to create an area that ensures the free movement of services and the opening up of transport markets, i.e. the so-called single European transport market. Another challenge of this strategy is to achieve a competitive, resource-efficient transport system and the related efforts to reduce emissions. The report also pays close attention to measures to strengthen transport safety, in particular to reduce the number of deaths on European roads. This report underlines the need to build safe and high-quality infrastructure in all modes of transport within the TEN-T network, including the removal of cross-border barriers. Structural changes in transport can improve the quality of life and the environment, while preserving people's freedom to travel and the competitiveness of EU industry.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 With environmental concerns and global warming, specific provisions serve commercial interests.

name: József SZÁJER
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of my colleague van de Camp's own-initiative report on the implementation of the 2011 White Paper on transport.  I believe that an interim reassessment of the White Paper is necessary, because the long-term objectives set out in 2011 do not always meet the challenges of today.  The aim of the interim revaluation is not to reduce the ambitious targets that we set in 2011, but to strengthen the ambition to achieve them.  It is necessary to make better use of rail and waterborne transport and to support and promote electric and innovative forms of transport, in particular in the field of freight transport.  By taking better advantage of opportunities, we can grow our economy, protect our environment and reduce traffic jams on our roads, and create new jobs.  At the same time, it is necessary to reduce Europe's dependence on oil. To do so, however, the EU needs to rethink its transport policy. At the same time, I did not support the points put in the robe of so-called social dumping in the report, which are contrary to the interests of Hungarian entrepreneurs and hauliers and whose primary objective is to protect the jobs of Western companies.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The European Parliament's document on the implementation of the White Paper on Transport outlines an ambitious strategy for future action towards a competitive transport system aimed at increasing mobility, removing existing barriers or reducing pollution produced by this sector of the economy. Despite very good assumptions, as indicated in this document, many of the demands include difficult-to-achieve targets, such as m.in a 60% reduction in greenhouse gases from transport by 2030 or a doubling of the rate of use of public transport in urban areas by 2030, or even harmful demands, completely detached from the realities of doing business, such as the introduction of a weekly rest order for those employed in the transport sector. The European Union should create a law that is not over-regulated and approach the challenges of the present with a rational approach, which is why I have chosen to vote against this report.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on the implementation of the 2011 White Paper on transport. In 2011, the White Paper adopted 40 concrete initiatives intended to build a competitive transport system in the EU. This review report renews the Parliament support to the objectives and sets out proposals to increase the effort to reach the objectives. It contains also an overview of the challenges faced by all modes of transport and calls for better interoperability. In particular, I am calling for a stronger harmonisation of the European transport area to promote a fair competition between all modes of transport, therefore achieving the Single European Sky (which requires solving the Gibraltar issue) and the 4th Railway Package. True competition between all modes of transport is necessary and will encourage investment and innovation as much which will improve the overall quality of transport infrastructures across the EU. Improved transport networks is key to move towards a sustainable transport area.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: In writing. I clashed with my colleagues in the French and British Socialist delegation in the paragraphs of the report promoting the liberalisation of port services, the reopening of the Mega-Truck Directive and the implementation of rail liberalisation through the 4th rail package. Unfortunately, they won the majority.    Nevertheless, this text had its strengths and ambition for sustainable transport. By proposing the addition of a new target of 40% reduction in CO2 emissions in transport by 2030, the revision of the regulation on emissions of new vehicles to subject to heavy goods vehicles and the revision of the Eurovignette Directive for greener taxation, the text responds to the climate emergency. On the social front, the report calls on the Commission to tackle dumping practices in the sector. Insisting on the importance of public transport for social inclusion and territorial cohesion, he sets a target of doubling their attendance by 2030... these are positive elements that I welcome, and which lay a solid foundation for addressing the Paris Conference.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I supported a report analysing and evaluating the implementation of the ambitious Transport White Paper objectives and encouraging the achievement of a more efficient, sustainable, competitive and integrated transport system.  While this analysis and complement has already been initiated halfway through the period envisaged to achieve the objectives of the Transport WhiteBook, I consider this to be a key move in achieving these objectives in a timely way. Given the state of roads in Croatia, I strongly support the emphasis on the need to eliminate the differences between the degree of infrastructure development and maintenance, especially between the eastern and western parts of the European Union.  Thus, it will be extremely useful for countries such as Croatia to promote economic growth and maintain competitiveness in industry and the development of modern transport infrastructure in Europe. In addition, I believe that putting innovation at the service of transport users and putting people at the heart of transport policy should ultimately lead to increased safety and improved quality of transport services.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. \u2012 Transport is a complex system based on the interaction of infrastructure, vehicles, information technology and compliance with the rules. The factors listed must be a common part of our vision for change. Although the European Union has the power to formulate our future transport policy, in many areas, European intervention will not be enough. Complementary activities at national, regional and local government level, as well as citizens and industry themselves. In its 2011 White Paper, the European Union presented a comprehensive road improvement plan that improves mobility, eliminates barriers and promotes growth and employment. Although the European Union has the power to formulate our future transport policy, in many areas, European intervention will not be enough. We also need to work together at the local level. As the report calls for a more frequent and sustainable development-oriented intervention, I supported it.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted against this report. A report supporting the Commission's decision to carry out an interim review of the White Paper in order to assess progress made and proposing further action to achieve its objectives with the aim of a more efficient, sustainable, competitive, accessible and user-adapted transport system. However, this report, despite having a good technical approach, contains political aspects related to opening up transport markets that make it questionable. It is clearly aligned with the Commission's market-friendly approach and, consequently, to the progressive privatisation of transport services. There are paragraphs that refer, not to mention, to TTIP and other trade agreements: "It stresses that the creation of a European transport area is an important priority and that (...) continues to depend on international acceptance under globally negotiated agreements with our trading partners for all modes of transport (...)". We cannot allow an acceptable technical report to use a backdoor through which recommendations go by that undermine the viability of the public transport system.

name: Evžen TOŠENOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the report because I do not agree with european commission officials determining where the direction of development of the automotive industry will take. I also do not like the attempt to unify national road charging systems. I believe that encouraging Member States to reinvest these funds in infrastructure is a violation of the subsidiarity proncipu.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ Taking stock of agreed measures helps us to be more efficient in addressing challenges. The White Paper on Transport established an ambitious programme aimed at the transformation of the European transport system and the creation of a genuine Single European Transport Area. For many years there has been serious under-investment in public transport infrastructure across the EU. I will support any measure that will help to remove all remaining obstacles, technical incompatibilities and burdensome administrative procedures that hinder the realisation of a system of fully integrated transport, and I will oppose any possible new measures by Member States which create obstacles to the free movement goods and services. I would also like to lament the lack of support for a negotiated solution for the Gibraltar conflict between the UK and Spain.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. Here is the list of initiatives for a single European area recorded in the White Paper: - Genuine internal market for rail services - Implementation of the Single European Sky - Capacity and quality of airports - maritime 'Blue Belt' and access to the port market - Framework adapted to inland navigation - Transport of goods by road - Multimodal freight transport: online freight This report signals an acceleration of integration in the sectors. I reject increased European Union interventionism in the urban transport policies of the Member States. I vote AGAINST this text.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted against this report. A report supporting the Commission's decision to carry out an interim review of the White Paper in order to assess progress made and proposing further action to achieve its objectives with the aim of a more efficient, sustainable, competitive, accessible and user-adapted transport system. However, this report, despite having a good technical approach, contains political aspects related to opening up transport markets that make it questionable. It is clearly aligned with the Commission's market-friendly approach and, consequently, to the progressive privatisation of transport services. There are paragraphs that refer, not to mention, to TTIP and other trade agreements: "It stresses that the creation of a European transport area is an important priority and that (...) continues to depend on international acceptance under globally negotiated agreements with our trading partners for all modes of transport (...)". We cannot allow an acceptable technical report to use a backdoor through which recommendations go by that undermine the viability of the public transport system.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: por escrito. ‒ I supported this report which calls on the Commission to update emission reduction targets for transport sector, emission limits for cars and vans beyond 2020, inclusion also of heavy goods vehicles and proposes the internalisation of external costs, abolish environmentally harmful tax subsidies, propose framework for national road charging schemes.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, which welcomes the Commission’s intention to carry out a midterm review of the 2011 White Paper on Transport, to evaluate what progress has been achieved towards reaching the predefined objectives. The paper had set out specific targets and in particular 10 goals to achieve a competitive and resource-efficient transport system. The most important aspects of the text are the ones that call on the Commission to work towards modernising transport infrastructure, to increase and improve urban mobility, to give specific attention to road safety and to place efforts into greater simplification and harmonisation of transport and logistics documents. An essential part of the plan should in my opinion be the successful development of the Trans-European Transport Network (TEN-T), which would effectively link the transport networks of all EU regions.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. It is important to reflect and develop a long-term strategic vision in the area of transport. Europe must bet on effective, sustainable, clean and economical means of transport. This report deals with a number of issues of vital reflection on the subject. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour of that report.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I was pleased to vote for this report which looks in detail at the ways to achieve a more extensive, efficient and environmentally-friendly public transport system across the European Union for citizens and businesses alike. This includes an important recognition that cities that have developed an integrated transport plan should be allocated EU structural funds to aid in the realisation of more forward looking transportation integration. This report also recognises the importance of incorporating the needs of disabled people and those with reduced mobility, to ensure that public transport can meet the needs of those it is intended to serve. Furthermore, the role of the Trade Union movement in the development of public transportation plans was also recognised, this preserves the dignity of those who serve the public by staffing our networks.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. I deeply regret that a very large majority of the European Parliament voted in favour of this report on the Commission's 2011 White Paper on Transport, calling for the completion of the liberalisation of all modes of transport. This report, although it has positive aspects in terms of CO2 reduction, welcomes the implementation of the Commission's 2011 White Paper, which has clear objectives: completion of the high-speed rail network provided mainly by private companies or consortia, which means liberalisation of rail transport of people but also poses a problem of access to rail transport because of the price of rail transport for people , liberalisation of rail freight even though the white paper called for a distribution of freight between different modes of transport, we have recently seen the consequences of this orientation at the French level. In the area of air transport, here too the document calls for the completion of the liberalisation of the sector. Our Group will continue to fight against the liberalisation of transport and we will continue in our respective countries and at European level to fight alongside trade unionists to defend public service and transport accessible to all.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the 2011 White Paper on Transport, the report calls for a set of measures that can boost the transport sector, promoting a better multimodal relationship, better infrastructure, technological development, digitisation and interference-free communications, environmental sustainability of the sector, in particular at CO2eq emissions levels etc. At the same time, it presupposes and affirms the primacy of liberalisation of the sector and greater openness to markets as a touchstone for transport policy. We're not going that way.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. Even if the ambitious amendments to reduce CO2 emissions are not adopted, this report still draws a comprehensive conclusion on the implementation of the 2011 White Paper to date. This report also adapts the White Paper to 2015. The rapporteur recognises the need for action in the transport sector, which is the only sector that has increased its CO2 emissions since 2009. In addition to noise reduction in freight rail transport, electric mobility is also to be expanded, as it is of great importance in the public transport system. I therefore agree with this report.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. – I rejected the European Parliament's resolution on the implementation of the 2011 White Paper on Transport: taking stock and taking a future approach to sustainable mobility.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. – I voted on the report on the implementation of the 2011 White Paper on Transport: the assessment of the current situation and the way forward for sustainable mobility. I welcome the rapporteur's view, which states in the report that the completion of the trans-European transport network remains one of the preconditions for a more sustainable, efficient and continuity-enabled multimodal transport system, as well as for a more balanced distribution of goods and passengers between modes of transport. I agree that the selection of projects eligible for EU funding must focus on the nine core network corridors, the creation of missing connections, particularly with regard to cross-border segments, the removal of bottlenecks, the modernisation of existing infrastructure, innovative transport solutions, interoperability and the creation of multimodal urban terminals and nodes.

name: Janusz ZEMKE
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 I would like to point out that in 2011 the European Commission outlined transport targets up to 2050. These objectives are clear: increased transport mobility, elimination of communication barriers, reduction of carbon emissions. The problem, however, is that in practice, in the last few years, disparities between modes of transport have been increasing in Europe. The scale of road and air transport is increasing, which increases congestion and worsens the environment. This trend should be weakened by allocating relatively more resources and energy to the potential of rail, short sea shipping and inland waterways. Only then will we be able to talk about more sustainable development, a higher level of transport mobility and more effective protection of natural resources.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 The 2011 White Paper on Transport is a necessary and important document. No serious work can be done without a plan, and a task as complex and staggered as the construction of a tightly integrated European transport network requires a specific plan. There is no doubt that such a document must be updated frequently and the objectives formulated modified and revised according to the progress of the work, so that the strategy does not work solely on paper. In the White Paper four years ago, many objectives were formulated too abstractly, as is clear at the stage of the current review. The assumptions made in 2011 for the move away from fossil fuels have not only not been met, but their consumption has also increased slightly. There is no need for better proof that climate policy cannot be built in isolation from economic realities and consumer preferences. In other areas too, the White Paper deserves to be revised. Modern and electrified public transport, the needs of pedestrians and cyclists in building transport infrastructure, the particular importance of the TEN-T network in the context of the creation of the EFSI, the protection of the free market and entrepreneurs in the road transport sector, unfair competition from Asian airlines or the sharing economy – these issues need to be better highlighted in the White Paper and are included in the TRAN report. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Damiano ZOFFOLI
text: in writing. I welcome today's vote on the implementation of the 2011 Transport White Paper with the aim of achieving sustainable mobility. The implementation of the actions provided for in the White Paper is essential for a further reduction in emissions and for decarbonisation in the field of transport. In this respect, priority must be given to the creation of an energy and cost-efficient transport system, so the completion of the Trans-European Transport Network is crucial. Finally, it is essential to promote digitalisation in order to create a competitive, efficient, safe and integrated transport system.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. The report carries out an intermediate evaluation of the implementation of the 2011 White Paper on Transport, containing a series of measures to achieve the objectives of this document. The report, following the White Paper, calls for a set of measures that can boost the transport sector, expressing the intention to promote: better multimodal relationship; better infrastructure; technological development, digitisation and interference-free communications; environmental sustainability of the sector, in particular at co2eq emission levels; support for the development of "light" and impact-scan-large mobility; relationship with passengers and the defence of their rights, etc. However, the report follows the White Paper in the sense that it presupposes and reaffirms the intention to liberalise the sector and to make a greater 'openness to markets'. On the other hand, it refers to the single European area (and the Single European Sky), which we have always opposed. We voted against it.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, I would like to say that I supported Mrs Vozemberg's report because I consider it to be well-crafted and I fully agree with the content of this report. There is constant talk of gender equality, but practice shows us that this equality is far from being fulfilled. Many stereotypes, for example, lead to a low representation of women in so-called STEM fields, i.e. science and technology.  My colleague's report comes up with proposals that aim to contribute to the removal of invisible barriers to women's career progression. She has also taken a very good look at the theme of combining women's professional and family life, for example, in science. It names the specific measures to be taken so that women can return to scientific life after maternity leave without missing the train and they have lost touch with developments in the field. I would like to thank my colleague very much for her work.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted with conviction in support of a text that invites us to reflect on how heavy the glass ceiling still is in the university careers of researchers and scholars. I know from personal experience, being a fixed-term researcher, what you are talking about. I believe that the Union has a duty to remove obstacles of this kind, obstacles that are due and are a representation of how much gender discrimination still affects university institutions.  I also believe that it must be made very clear that the process of insecurity in university work has particularly affected young women, young researchers. I believe that this situation needs to be radically changed and that the Eu ropean Union must take radical action to prevent this form of discrimination by restoring funding to public universities. This is also an important instrument against gender discrimination.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: – Mr President, I voted in favour of this report on women’s careers in science and at university. In particular, I want to refer to the situation in Ireland, where the Equality Tribunal decided in December of last year that, in the case of Micheline Sheehy Skeffington, there was both direct and indirect discrimination against women in the process of promotion to senior lecturer. This is not the only case of gender discrimination in Irish universities in recent years. In fact, in 2009 only 10% of senior academic posts were held by women and, after Malta, Ireland has the second highest glass-ceiling index for women in higher education.  Yes, there has been a response from the third-level colleges, but it remains uneven. In this context, I welcome this motion and some of the things we called for to address gender imbalances in the decision-making process: gender-based budgeting, the increased participation of women in decision-making, and gender equality plans as a precondition for access to public funding in research, science and academia.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – I supported the report on women and research and universities. Why, let me give you a shocking number first. Today, in the European Union, and I think that this is no different in my country, more than half of university graduates are women. We're talking 59%. For rectors, the ratio is 10%. I am talking about the EU ratio. I'm afraid it's even less in Hungary. The other thing I would like to highlight from this report is that, unfortunately, a very high proportion of PhD students and women who have obtained a PhD stop researching and scientific activities when obtaining a PhD, apparently because they fulfil their maternal obligations. However, this is absolutely not natural, just as the very low number of rectors and scientific leaders is not natural. It's time to explore the reasons. I ask that women working in the science concerned share this with us, for example in their letters to me. Thank you in advance.

name: Klaus BUCHNER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Of course, equal treatment and equal esteem between the two sexes is a central concern that no one can oppose. But the Rodrigues and Vozemberg reports certainly do not achieve this. Because a university degree in the natural sciences is not something to decide on, because it is advertised. Such a study is really hard work. It's not a walk, and it's just for people who are gifted about it.  We can see this in the high number of dropouts. The successful completion of a degree in natural sciences requires a high level of commitment, which is certainly not brought to those who are just convinced because they are advertised for it. A degree means the loss of time and a lot of money. That is why I consider the two reports to be irresponsible, something that certainly does not help the young women.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: "Mr. President, I supported this report because it is evident that after so many conversations about creating equal opportunities between men and women, we have not actually moved from the impasse yet. Moreover, women move their own boundaries day by day, break records, create new opportunities, but still get the impression that they are worth less than men. They are closed to the great doors of the business world and progress, although they are often more educated than men who pass through these doors without problems. The glass ceiling was built on prejudice, and these prejudices actually created society in its entirety. Therefore, we should do everything in our power to, first of all, encourage women so that they can regain faith in themselves, create self-confidence because they can achieve a lot, can successfully balance work and family and be in management positions. We need to ensure that for women and men there is a level playing field in terms of employment and work, the wages they receive for their jobs and progression. The solution is not in quotas, but in changing the perception of women's value for the work they do.

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: Written. Today, the European Parliament voted on a report on women's careers in the field of research and academia. Equal opportunities for women and men in academia is a pressing and important issue. That is why I chose to vote in favour of the report. On the other hand, there were certain points in the report which, in practice, involve detailed management of the member states' work on gender equality. I chose to vote against them on the grounds of subsidiarity.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report from the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality whose primary objective is to call for action from the European Commission and the Member States aimed at breaking the so-called "glass ceiling", that is, to achieve access to real equality between women and men in higher academic institutions as well as in science-related jobs in the European Union , where there is obvious vertical segregation as evidenced by the data contained in that report.  For this purpose, it would have been valuable if several of our amendments also appeared in this resolution as a group on democratizing university institutions, improving mechanisms for the control and publicity of vacancies, investing in chairs on gender studies or denouncing that austerity measures and the cuts in public resources have adversely affected the slight progress in university and scientific positions in recent years. However, by voting in favour I believe that I am supporting a report which denounces and calls on the Commission and States to take measures to promote equality in research, academic and scientific careers.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ This report, however well-intentioned, still covers matters which are best left to the Member States.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to support and promote women's careers in science and universities. According to the available statistics, women are poorly represented in most science, engineering and management positions, as well as at higher hierarchical levels, even in sectors where the majority of women work, such as in the education sector. I support the proposals made in the proposal to the Commission to build on existing programmes and initiatives and to develop positive campaigns to encourage girls and women to choose academic and scientific careers in all fields of science, with a particular focus on the engineering and technology sector. The Commission, the Member States and relevant stakeholders need to strengthen initiatives and programmes to encourage women to pursue their scientific and academic careers, to support female researchers, in particular young women, in research programmes and to apply for grants. It is also necessary to create family-friendly universities and research institutes.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. Another report that derives from gender ideology and believes in the virtues of "discrimination" that would be "positive".

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. Despite the progress made, too much inequality still exists today in terms of gender equality. As this report points out, this is particularly true for courses and careers in the science, technology, engineering and mathematics sectors where women are vastly under-represented. Although almost 60% of university graduates are women, they account for less than 20% of university professors in the EU28. I can only support this initiative to promote equal access to scientific and academic careers.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report on equality. There are more women in European universities than men and it is necessary to encourage careers in scientific fields for women. In the same way, I voted in favour of the amendment referring to the ratification of the Istanbul Convention on Gender-Based Violence.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This report on women's scientific and academic careers is an example of a hollow text with 52 articles. We will still remember the desire to teach gender equality even in higher education...  This text is not rewarding for women since they are seen only through gender or affirmative action even though the notions of deserved or freedom of choice are totally absent from the report.  So I decided to vote against it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 Although I agree with many passages, there are just as many unclear and contradictory, so I opted for a vote to abstain.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. U2012 Gender equality is one of the principles on which the EU is based and must be respected in all areas. However, as this report which I have supported shows, despite the progress of recent years, gender equality in the scientific and academic fields has not been achieved and the presence of women in the most responsible academic and decision-making positions in scientific institutions and universities is strikingly low. Women should be regretted that women still do not enjoy equal access to research posts and the funding and publication of their research, including the pay gap, despite the equal treatment and non-discrimination provisions in force in the EU and the Member States. The report therefore urges the Commission and Member States to review existing rules to ensure non-discrimination in universities, research centres and funding contracts. She calls for positive actions and institutional changes to encourage women to continue their scientific and research careers. And it calls on gender equality plans at all levels.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this Parliamentary report, which deals with women's careers in science and universities and the glass ceilings that are being encountered. The European Union is committed to gender equality through academic positions and, although positive developments have been made in recent years, gender equality in science and academia has still not been achieved, and the situation with regard to research and different categories of academics varies from one Member State to another. Parliament encourages the Commission and the Member States to analyse the applicable legal provisions with a view to their proper implementation and, if necessary, to review them in order to ensure equal treatment between men and men. It is necessary to build on existing programmes and initiatives and to develop positive campaigns to encourage girls and women to pursue academic and scientific careers in all fields of science, with a particular focus on the engineering and technology sector, where, despite recent positive developments, women's participation is below average.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the fact that the report makes a number of proposals on how to encourage women to work in scientific and technical fields. Although the proportion of female researchers and learners in Europe is increasing, they are still underrepresented in academy. Our efforts to halt this trend are of the utmost importance, for example through initiatives to make a breakthrough in this area. I also think it is important to ensure equal opportunities in recruitment procedures, to eradicate stereotypes and prejudices about women and to monitor the development of the number of women in the fields of science, mathematics, technology and engineering.  In agreement with the reporter, I am convinced that the Common European Strategy must be strengthened in order to achieve real equality and significant results between women's and men's career prospects in science, education and technology. As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I voted in favour of the report entitled 'Women's career opportunities in science and universities'.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. Although women make up 60 per cent of the highly educated, they unfortunately do not even occupy 10 per cent of the top positions in universities. The objectives we have set for ourselves through Horizon 2020 cannot be achieved without the positive measures proposed by this report.

name: Louise BOURS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this non—legislative and non—binding report as it calls for gender targets. You don’t fight discrimination with discrimination. It calls for ‘gender equality plans’ to be a pre-condition to accessing public funding in research, science and academia. Rather than innovations and scientific breakthroughs being the important reasons for government support, they want to block help for projects if there aren’t enough men or women on the team.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which proposes measures to enable women to progress further in careers in academia and science. While 59% of university graduates in the EU-28 are women, they account for only 18% of university professors. The report calls for implementation of positive measures in order to increase women’s presence at higher levels in academia, science, and the research and technology sector. It urges the European Commission and the Member States to analyse their relevant laws and revise them if necessary in order to enforce equal treatment of women and men. The report states the principle of non-discrimination must be observed in all types of employment contract or funding, and the legal right to equal pay for equal work must be respected. It calls for election and promotion processes to be open and transparent, for the facilitation of better work-life balance and childcare services; and for positive campaigns aimed at girls and women encouraging them to enter academic and research careers in all scientific fields.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe it is essential for society, for the scientific world and for the European economy in general to solve the problem of gender discrimination in science and academia. It is very serious that women, in an evolved continent such as Europe, represent only 18% of ordinary professors, even though they are 59% of graduate students.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 The term "glass ceiling" was connoted in 1986 and refers to invisible, prejudice-based barriers that hinder women's rise to positions of responsibility throughout their careers. Women's academic careers also remain characterised by marked vertical segregation. In 2010 the percentage of female students (55%) and graduates (59%) it was higher than that of their male counterparts, but men outnumbered women among students and doctoral holders (in the case of doctorates the proportion of female students stood at 49% and that of holders at 46%). Women also accounted for only 37% of academic staff. The low representation of women is even more evident in the field of science and engineering. Gender diversity in high-level positions has been shown to produce innovative ideas, increased competitiveness and better performance, as well as more efficient corporate management. Increased female presence in the management sphere also indicates to the market that the company understands the complexity of global dynamics and is ready to compete. We must overcome past prejudices and stereotypes and adopt legislation to ensure gender equity in all aspects of social and working life.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. In its motion for a resolution, the European Parliament is committed to ensuring gender parity in academic positions and scientific careers. MEPs note the existence of a glass ceiling that would prevent women from accessing positions as researchers, university rectors and pursuing scientific careers. Their solution is to encourage affirmative action, thus denying women's personal aspirations and professional abilities. In addition, the text consists of 52 meaningless articles. It should be noted, however, that they wish to teach gender equality even in higher education. At no time does this text promote meritocracy. The objectives of this proposal are at odds with what I consider to be equality between men and women: the acceptance of complementarity by recognising the differences and the wills of each.  That is why I voted against this motion for a resolution.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 Gender equality is one of the principles promoted by the European Union, aiming to eliminate all forms of discrimination against women and reduce gender segregation in the eu's scientific and academic environment, as it is extremely important to ensure that women and men receive equal treatment, have the same rights and obligations and opportunities for work, and their contribution to society is equally appreciated and respected. Despite the positive changes of recent times, Member States still face the low presence of women in the highest academic and decision-making positions in scientific institutions and universities, which confirms the existence of barriers that prevent women from taking up leadership positions. According to statistics, even though 59% of university graduates at European Union level are women, only 18% of them represent the number of university professors, women being under-represented in the fields of science, engineering and management in senior positions. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution, as I believe that immediate action must be taken to remove cultural and institutional barriers that favour the presence of gender segregation in the scientific and academic environment, and that it is necessary to encourage the application of equal and non-discriminatory treatment in the hope of boosting research activities.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Once again calls for men and women to be equalised in terms of rights, regardless of age, religion, civil status and educational path, especially in certain sectors where the presence of women is lacking (scientific field, engineering, management posts, etc.).  In itself, the principles could also be supported, but, as can be seen from the explanations of the RCVs, the whole thing is imposed by the EU on the individual Member State, not taking into account the principle dear to us and essential principle of subsidiarity (e.g. "to consider the creation of gender equality plans as a necessary condition for access to public funding for research, science and academia"). N.B.: The term "glass ceiling" was issued by Wall Street Journal journalists in 1986 and refers to invisible, prejudice-based barriers that hinder women's rise to positions of responsibility throughout their careers. Abstention vote

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. Equality between men and women is fundamental. We need to ensure that women have the same opportunities as men to pursue the career of their choice. That is why it is important to ensure that women have equal access to scientific and academic careers as men. The report finds that women often face various difficulties during their careers such as gender stereotypes or discrimination in relation to motherhood. These barriers to women's professional development must be removed. I voted in favour of this report, which calls on the Commission and the Member States to take concrete action in this area.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 After careful reflection and discussion in plenary, I voted today in favour of the report on the 'professional career of women in science and academia and on the 'crystal ceilings' encountered', on the basis of the following considerations: - I agree with what the rapporteur has said and in particular on the need for radical measures, not just superficial measures; cooperation at collective level is essential and must be undertaken by each of us on an individual and collective basis; - it seems absurd, but we still have to affirm the concept that men and women are different but absolutely must be equal in terms of rights, regardless of age, religion, civil status and educational path; - I agree with those who believe that the concept of equality should already be proposed in schools, where children learn that they are all the same in every aspect of their lives.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which contained a number of positive provisions regarding gender equality. This report highlighted that despite positive changes in recent years, gender equality in science and academia has still not been achieved. Women have an extremely low presence in the highest academic and decision-making positions in scientific institutions and universities. While 59 % of university graduates in the EU-28 are women, they account for only 18 % of full university professors. This is unacceptable in a society that is meant to be based on equality and fairness.  I was very disappointed that this report did not contain the amendments put forward by my Group, GUE-NGL, in relation to the Maternity Leave Directive. This is a very important issue and a matter that my party will continue to pro-actively address both in Ireland and at an EU level.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ Despite the best intentions of this report, it covers matters which, in my opinion, should be decided individually by the Member States.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ Women have faced discrimination in academic and scientific careers for a number of years now. I believe that there is a need to remove these barriers in order to promote equality between men and women in universities and in the world of science. In the report it is being suggested that measures should be taken by both the Commission and the Member States in the framework of the European Research Area and the specific program Horizon 2020. I agree with what is written in the report, thus I voted in favour of this report.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 "crystal ceilings" mean invisible, prejudice-based barriers that hinder women's rise to positions of responsibility throughout their careers. This report takes into account the professional careers of women and, in particular, gender equality in academic positions, the need to reconcile professional and personal life, changes in society and institutional projects, the progress made so far and the actions still to be taken. These are all issues that I support, and I have therefore voted in favour of them.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: in writing. ‒ While I firmly believe women must take leadership roles in the field of research and within universities, I do not believe that quotas are the answer to the inequalities that exist today. A more balanced participation of women in science and research is vital for achieving the EU’s competitiveness and growth aims, but this can only be achieved by creating a social environment that balances work and family. We need a society that has the services needed to allow women to put all efforts into their work. Instead of quotas, let's build a social environment where women do not have to choose between being a good mother and being leaders in their fields.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. I voted against this motion for a resolution because its main objective is to feminise entire sectors to weigh down wages, through an influx of "human capital", and to promote affirmative action.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 It is undeniable that gender equality is one of the principles on which the EU is founded and that it must be respected, inter alia, in the research and academic field. Any form of direct or indirect discrimination against women should be abolished. We also call on the Member States and regions to promote the development of family-friendly universities and research centres.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this own-initiative report because I believe that it fully and comprehensively addresses the problems relating to the obstacles faced by women, especially in scientific careers. Although significant measures have been taken, there are still many barriers, due not only to preconceptions, but also to biological issues. Women are therefore at a disadvantage and services should be provided to help reconcile family and career. In my opinion, the real issue is precisely this: helping women not to have to choose for one or the other would make it possible to realise the potential of women in the round, and society would benefit from a greater contribution made by women in the academic and scientific fields.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. If there were no studies on the subject, empirically it would be possible to perceive the obstacles that many women across Europe still encounter at work. Many are still obliged to choose between family and professional life, too many are still not respected the rights conferred on them by the legislation, others still face new challenges in their workplaces. The academic world and scientific production are a reality that presents specific challenges. Despite the campaigns already carried out, the report rightly denounces that the results are far from satisfactory. Not only does this report make a good diagnosis, but also presents solutions that can be carried out by the Commission and the Member States within the framework of the European Research Area and Horizon 2020. I therefore support this report.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this non-legislative and non—binding report as it calls for gender targets - you don’t fight discrimination with more discrimination. It calls for ‘gender equality plans’ to be a pre—condition to accessing public funding in research, science and academia.
