Rather than innovations and scientific breakthroughs being the important reason for government support, they want to block help for projects if there aren’t enough men or women on the team.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Mr Vozemberg's report because I believe that we all know that women are not only under-represented, and not only in most scientific and engineering positions, but also in managerial and political positions, but also underpaid, discriminated against on the basis of stereotypes, preconceptions and negative and unfounded prejudices. In addition, women are also hampered by the fact that they are forced to take on greater parental or family-related obligations than their male counterparts. Support for and commitment to the right to gender equality is not just a consequence of the action of rules or the definition of objectives; they must also be part of a 'cultural change' aimed at supporting women's ambitions, raising awareness of the specific obstacles women face on their path to professional ascent.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report from the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality whose primary objective is to call for action from the European Commission and the Member States aimed at breaking the so-called "glass ceiling", that is, to achieve access to real equality between women and men in higher academic institutions as well as in science-related jobs in the European Union , where there is obvious vertical segregation as evidenced by the data contained in that report.  For this purpose, it would have been valuable if several of our amendments also appeared in this resolution as a group on democratizing university institutions, improving mechanisms for the control and publicity of vacancies, investing in chairs on gender studies or denouncing that austerity measures and the cuts in public resources have adversely affected the slight progress in university and scientific positions in recent years. However, by voting in favour I believe that I am supporting a report which denounces and calls on the Commission and States to take measures to promote equality in research, academic and scientific careers.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report since it addresses gender equality in academic positions and urges the Commission and Member States to revise the existing legal provisions to ensure non-discrimination in all types of university or research contracts or funding. It also calls for positive actions and institutional changes to encourage women to continue their scientific/research careers and asks Member States to introduce gender-equality plans at all levels. These are positions which I agree with.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. \u2012 In Europe, according to the latest available statistics, the research workforce is ageing. It is therefore urgently necessary to make attractive careers in this field available to young people, especially women, as science plays a key role in the European economy, and science needs as many researchers as possible who can develop exploratory research, thereby contributing to the achievement of the objectives of the 2020 Strategy. One of the main objectives of the strategy is women's careers. I believe that there is a need to better systematise the available data on gender distribution and monitoring the position of women scientists at Member State level in order to promote gender equality in all public or private research institutions, and I also believe that greater flexibility is needed in terms of working conditions for both women and women , as well as for male researchers, to enable them to reconcile work and family life and to eliminate the pay gap between male and female researchers with a view to respecting gender equality. Last but not least, I believe that the Member States should, through the levers available, fight for a better balance between men and women within the bodies responsible for hiring and promoting researchers.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This initiative report analyzes the barriers and biases, taken consciously and unconscious, that women face during their academic and scientific careers. These barriers are numerous and complex because they are based on different factors. The report proposes that action be taken by the Commission and Member States within the framework of the European Research Area (ERA) and the specific Horizon 2020 programme, in order to strengthen equality between men and women in universities and in the scientific world. Considering that this report is balanced, I have spoken in favour of this text.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I supported this text which calls for strengthening equality between men and women in the scientific world. Progress in recent years has not yet been sufficient. Promotion and support strategies with funds such as Horizon 2020 are still needed, both to strengthen equality in universities and the scientific world as well as in the world of work.

name: Philippe DE BACKER
text: in writing. – I voted in favor of this report as we need to do more to get more women in STEM-related (sciences, technology, engineering and mathematics) educational fields and careers. Here women are hugely under-represented accounting for just 24% of science and engineering professionals. It was also important for me to reaffirm that equality between men and women is one of the principles on which the European Union was founded. Unfortunately, women still experience unequal access to research positions, funding, publishing and academic awards. The report asks for the Commission and Member States to look at a number of positive measures such as to analyse legal provisions with the aim to enforce equal treatment of men and women. We also call for more flexible working conditions for both male and female researchers, allowing them to combine work with family life, and for elimination of the gender pay gap in the interests of gender equality. The Commission is to propose a recommendation to Member States containing common guidelines on institutional change to promote gender equality in universities and research institutions.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. – As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I voted in favour of the report entitled 'Women's career opportunities in science and universities'.  I welcome the fact that the report by Elissavet Vozemberg makes a number of proposals on how to encourage women to work in scientific and technical fields. Although the proportion of female researchers and learners in Europe is increasing, they are still underrepresented in academy. Our efforts to halt this trend are of the utmost importance, for example through initiatives to make a breakthrough in this area. I also think it is important to ensure equal opportunities in recruitment procedures, to eradicate stereotypes and prejudices about women and to monitor the development of the number of women in the fields of science, mathematics, technology and engineering.  In agreement with the reporter, I am convinced that the Common European Strategy must be strengthened in order to achieve real equality and significant results between women's and men's career prospects in science, education and technology.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. – As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I voted in favour of the report entitled 'Women's career opportunities in science and universities'.  I welcome the fact that the report by Elissavet Vozemberg (People's Party, Greek) makes a number of proposals on how to encourage women to work in scientific and technical fields. Although the proportion of female researchers and learners in Europe is increasing, they are still underrepresented in academy. Our efforts to halt this trend are of the utmost importance, for example through initiatives to make a breakthrough in this area. I also think it is important to ensure equal opportunities in recruitment procedures, to eradicate stereotypes and prejudices about women and to monitor the development of the number of women in the fields of science, mathematics, technology and engineering.  In agreement with the reporter, I am convinced that the Common European Strategy must be strengthened in order to achieve real equality and significant results between women's and men's career prospects in science, education and technology.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. Finding that women are less likely than men to hold scientific and academic positions is not a reason to consider that women are the targets of organised and well-developed discrimination in the European Union. This report is based on a victimized analysis that advocates affirmative action (which even the United States is coming back from) and promotes "gender equality" from an egalitarian perspective and denying sexual differences. This promotion should also be disseminated in the university course. Furthermore, the report suggests extending the practice of affirmative action far beyond women, to associated claimant minorities based on their sexual orientations, LGBTI groups, as well as to women who are immigrants or immigrants, particularly from europe. For many years I have fought for the women's cause, in France and in Europe, but this report is not glamorous for the struggle of women, on the contrary, it misguides it by associating it with community and ideological demands that tarnish our civilization. So I voted against it.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained on my colleague Venousberg's report on women's professional careers in science and higher education and the existence of the so-called glass ceilings. The term "glass ceiling," introduced in 1986 by journalists, describes the invisible barriers that limit women's progress to higher positions within their careers.  For me and my group, ambiguous messages are addressed through paragraph 48 of the report, which concerns gender balance on boards and specific objectives and quotas. I do not support gender discrimination and I think my colleague has produced an excellent report, but I do not think the introduction of quotas is the solution.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We vote against: this report promotes gender discrimination, removes all notions of meritocracy and undermines the traditional family.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: Written. "This report contained several good elements, and I voted in favour of it in the final vote. However, I would like to point out that I voted against parts of the text, such as those relating to quotas. I do not believe that this is an issue that we solve best at European level.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 In statistics and surveys conducted, women are under-represented in most research, engineering and management positions and at the highest hierarchical levels, even in sectors where they are in the majority, such as education, for example, only 24% of science and engineering professionals. The Commission has already committed to ensuring a 40% representation of under-represented sex in the composition of all its expert groups, panels and committees and even though the proportion of female researchers is growing faster than that of male researchers, in 2009 only 33% of all EU-27 researchers were women. The percentage of women in the Business Organization sector is the lowest, where only 19% of all researchers are women, compared to 40% in the Higher Education sector and 40% in the Government sector. I agree that Member States should promote policies aimed at improving good recruitment practices and the employment of scientists. The notion of equality should start at school where children learn that they are equal in all aspects of their lives. Schools should implement diversity training to support women in professions in science, technology, engineering and mathematics.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it does not highlight the possibility of choice among women and the complementarity between men and women.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against this report because it promotes gender discrimination, removes all notions of meritocracy and undermines the traditional family.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ Gender equality is a fundamental principle of the European Union, a basic precondition for the full enjoyment of human rights by women and girls and is essential for their empowerment and the achievement of a sustainable and inclusive society. Unequal access for women to research positions, funding and publishing still persists, including an unadjusted gender pay gap in the area of science and academia. I believe that we must be keen in pointing out and defeat by all means the low presence of women in the highest academic and decision-making positions in scientific institutions and universities, which indicates the existence of a glass ceiling, an invisible barriers based on prejudices which stand in the way of women accessing positions of responsibility. We have to fight all forms of direct or indirect discrimination against women; otherwise, Horizon 2020 will not be achieved.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Mrs Vozemberg's excellent report, first of all because it makes a precise identification of the factors behind the glass ceiling faced by women in scientific and academic careers, and in particular gender stereotypes which are reproduced consciously or unconsciously by men and women. The report then identifies possible measures to break this glass ceiling. In particular, I welcome the emphasis on awareness campaigns aimed at both men and women, the promotion of women's networking and mentoring schemes and initiatives. The focus on institutional changes, which requires a strong commitment from the Member States and relevant ministries, is also entirely relevant, as is the full integration of the gender dimension within horizon 2020. Finally, I fully support the proposal to create the Women and Science Prize in Europe.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the fact that the report by Elissavet Vozemberg (People's Party, Greek) makes a number of proposals on how to encourage women to work in scientific and technical fields. Although the proportion of female researchers and learners in Europe is increasing, they are still underrepresented in academy. Our efforts to halt this trend are of the utmost importance, for example through initiatives to make a breakthrough in this area. I also think it is important to ensure equal opportunities in recruitment procedures, to eradicate stereotypes and prejudices about women and to monitor the development of the number of women in the fields of science, mathematics, technology and engineering.  In agreement with the reporter, I am convinced that the Common European Strategy must be strengthened in order to achieve real equality and significant results between women's and men's career prospects in science, education and technology.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted against the report on women's science and university careers and existing invisible barriers today, as, unfortunately, it has not been possible to remove from it the demands for mandatory wage transparency, even beyond the tariff-regulated area. I do not think that this makes sense, nor is it a task for the EU.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. We need to overcome the hidden barriers that make careers difficult for many women, especially in scientific and technical professions. Gender equality is an essential principle and we should promote women's science and university careers through concrete actions.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ While nearly 60% of graduate students in the EU are women, they only account for 1 fifth of senior academics.   These numbers demonstrate the loss of talent that happens along the way, and urgently needs to be reversed. That's why I support the Voezemberg report and why I call for: - more measures to help women reconcile work and family life, like child care parental leave, flexible working.  - institutional changes, like the creation of online tools for sharing best practice and increased participation of women in decision-making bodies. - and the application of gender budgeting to all programmes related to science, research and academia.  Sharing knowledge, best practices and resources amongst institutions and member states in the EU will be vital to eliminate gender biases at all stages of recruitment, training and appraisals, and ensure that women and men can balance their work and family lives. Only that way will we be able to tap the full potential of our talent, instead of just half.

name: Juan Carlos GIRAUTA VIDAL
text: in writing. Gender equality is a basic condition for women to fully enjoy their rights and is critical to achieving a sustainable and inclusive society. Such equality requires free access to all careers and professions. Therefore, the low presence of women in academic and decision-making positions of greatest responsibility in scientific institutions and universities is striking. Gender equality must also be respected in academia and research, and all forms of direct or indirect discrimination against women that hinder their access to research posts and the financing and publication of their research should be eliminated.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: in writing. – The UK is fast approaching a major skills shortage – by 2022 we shall need an estimated 1.82 million new engineering, science and technology professionals in order to keep up with the world's technology powerhouses of the US, South Korea and Japan and meet consumer demands. Demands for more intelligent and faster mobile technology, the demand for communications technology 24/7, the need for faster travel and the increasing demand for energy all means that we need more men and women to study science at school and university and become scientists.  This report deals with a number of the big challenges prohibiting women from entering and reaching senior positions in STEM professions and the UK delegation is pleased to able to support the overall aims this report. We have a number of concerns regarding EU interference in paternity leave, EU common guidelines for universities, gender-balanced budgeting for universities and targets and quotas for women in research bodies and boards.  We have voted against these elements and have supported the report overall.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. I voted against the draft resolution on women's scientific and academic careers.  Under the guise of respect and promotion of equality, this report aims to apply quotas in university governing bodies, but also in research teams. However, at no time is there any mention in this report of the number of female scientists who would have encountered difficulties in their careers because of their gender. On the contrary, since Marie Curie, a two-time Nobel laureate, women have increasingly embraced scientific careers. Far from valuing women, this quota policy is imposed by normative means and reduces the possibilities of choice, selection and meritocracy.  Ultimately, this practice is demeaning, with some women suspected of holding their jobs only because of their gender.  Finally, as is customary in the FEMM Committee, this resolution leaves the lion's share to women from minorities, migrants and LGBTI, who must always be more equal than others and favoured in all circumstances.  This text is useless. So I voted against it.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this initiative. This report denounces the under-representation of women at the upper hierarchical levels of the scientific and academic fields as a result of discrimination based, among other factors, on prejudice and stereotypes, despite having an equivalent level of professional performance. And it proposes measures that end up breaking this "glass ceiling" in aspects such as: equal treatment provisions, gender violence, non-discrimination in contracting and financing projects, gender balance perspective in budgets in scientific and academic programmes, transparency in selection and promotion processes, specific attention to LGBTI, outreach and training campaigns on diversity and equality and positive models in science and technology , work and family life balance, maternity, changes in European institutions, gender dimension in scientific and technological content.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I, and Labour MEPs, voted for this report for a simple reason: women and girls have a right to an education. This report demonstrates that there a long way to go on the road to ending gender-related barriers in education, particularly with regards to science and higher education. It makes a series of recommendations which will ensure that women are able to play their full role in science, research and higher education, these are recommendations that are very important. We face a shortfall in skills, especially in science, technology, engineering and mathematics; something we can avoid if we act now and give women and girls more freedom to pursue their careers.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the report on women’s careers in science. Despite the increasing numbers of women participating in the field of research, gender inequality remains a relevant issue. Unequal treatment and discrimination of women is a gross violation of their basic human rights, therefore it is extremely important to improve network opportunities for female scientists. As well as for campaigns to encourage women to pursue scientific careers, especially in engineering and the technology sector. I believe that the balanced participation of both genders in science is the key objective which ultimately will contribute to the EU's competitiveness and growth aims.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. When I read through the template, I couldn't believe my eyes. Many of the proposals put forward in this motion do not have much to do with reality. As a long-time honorary professor at the University of Mannheim and as president of the Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz (WGL) scientific community, I have repeatedly observed that the current instruments to support women's careers in science are still not enough. However, the proposals put forward here are, at least as far as German universities are concerned, in some cases completely unsuitable. In particular, I was surprised that it was seriously proposed that the allocation of research funds should be made conditional on the existence of 'gender plans'. Already today, the girls in the schools show that they perform better than the boys. And the proportion of female professors in universities is also increasing year after year. I suspect that even the professors who are themselves busy raising third-party funds cannot understand such a award criterion. Of course, I voted against. Incidentally, as i am my ceterum censeo, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: Mary HONEYBALL
text: in writing. ‒ This report highlights how far we still have to go to smash the glass ceilings in science and academia, and it makes a number of very important recommendations which will ensure women are able to play their full role in science, research and higher education. Particularly in STEM fields, we face a projected—skills shortfall which will only be averted if we act now to empower more women pursuing their careers. We must ensure that women and men are able to balance their work and family lives and that gender biases are eliminated at all stages of recruitment, training and appraisals.

name: Mike HOOKEM
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report as it calls for gender targets – you don’t fight discrimination with more discrimination. It calls for ‘gender equality plans’ to be a pre—condition to accessing public funding in research, science and academia. Rather than innovations and scientific breakthroughs being the important reason for government support, they want to block help for projects if there aren’t enough men or women on the team.

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. ‒ This report rightly notes the gender inequality in the world of science and academia. The Scottish Parliament called in 2009 for the Scottish government to include in its science strategy specific action to improve the participation and employment of women in the science sector. Work has been done to address this issue and I commend it to this House.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this initiative. This report denounces the under-representation of women at the upper hierarchical levels of the scientific and academic fields as a result of discrimination based, among other factors, on prejudice and stereotypes, despite having an equivalent level of professional performance. And it proposes measures that end up breaking this "glass ceiling" in aspects such as: equal treatment provisions, gender violence, non-discrimination in contracting and financing projects, gender balance perspective in budgets in scientific and academic programmes, transparency in selection and promotion processes, specific attention to LGBTI, outreach and training campaigns on diversity and equality and positive models in science and technology , reconciliation of working and family life, maternity, changes is the European institutions, gender dimension in scientific and technological content.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a European Parliament resolution on women's scientific and university careers and the "glass ceiling" they encounter because I support equality between women and men in all fields, including their scientific and university careers. Further efforts are needed to fully achieve such a thing and to truly bridge the so-called glass ceiling while ultimately overcoming unfounded and incorrect discrimination. I also support programmes, campaigns and activities aimed at promoting gender equality and equal position for women in society.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Elissavet Vozemberg's report on women's scientific and academic careers. The goal of combating glass ceilings, which still affects too many women, could only receive my support. The report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I am abstaining from voting on this report. While the promotion of women in university careers is certainly necessary, this is still a matter for the Member States, on which common directives are not to be grafted.

name: Rikke-Louise KARLSSON
text: Written. I voted against the report "Women's careers in science and in academia and the glass ceilings they encounter" - a report full of good intentions.  Although there are still more men than women in science, the proportion of women has increased over the last 10 years. Twenty-nine per cent of researchers are now women, compared with 26 per cent in the late nineties (study by Boston Consulting Group). However, this situation only applies in the scientific sector. In agriculture, there are 50.1% women, and in health women account for 63.1% of all doctorates. There seems to be a sad tendency to see discrimination everywhere.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report, as it makes a number of very important recommendations which will ensure that women are able to play their full role in science, research and higher education. We must ensure that women and men are able to balance their work and family lives and that gender biases are eliminated at all stages of recruitment, training and appraisals. This is also an area where cooperation at the European level is vital to share knowledge, best practices and resources amongst institutions and member states.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Writing. I voted against the report on women's science and university careers and existing invisible barriers (2014/2251(INI)) because the text adopted sets the wrong tone on the important issue of equality between women and men in science and research. For example, a mandatory quota is not an appropriate, accepted instrument for increasing the proportion of women in middle to senior management of higher education institutions. Opinions on the so-called "gender gap" must be deposited with facts and analysed in detail. Efforts to demand "tariff transparency" beyond the already regulated collective bargaining agreement must be rejected in principle.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on women's careers in science and universities and the glass ceiling they encounter has passed without any problems, but I am still glad that I was able to help her with my voice. The term "glass ceiling" was introduced in 1986 by journalists from the Wall Street Journal. It identifies invisible barriers to prejudice that prevent women from progressing in their careers. Although considerable progress has been made in this area, I believe that further positive developments are needed. However, this should not be limited to the issue of gender. I believe that inequalities linked to a different socio-economic environment need to be perceived and corrected. Higher education, as well as careers in science, must also be accessible to young people who come from disadvantaged and vulnerable groups. I hope that in the near future the European Parliament will also address this issue and start to see the topic of science and higher education more comprehensively. If we do not give disadvantaged groups the conditions to take off, then we cannot complain that they have not moved.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ Gender equality in science and academia is still, unfortunately an on-going issue. The European Commission and Member states still attempt to overcome this inequality. Only few women reach highest posts in research and academia fields. By supporting this report, I  urge the European Commission and Member States to improve and enforce equal treatment between men and women, especially by implementing equal-pay for equal work. Furthermore, the selection process in science should be more open and more transparent. I voted in favour of this report to foster women to enter academic and research careers.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Women make up more than 60% of university graduates in the European Union and occupy almost half of doctoral places. However, the higher the university hierarchy, the smaller the presence of women – for example, only about 20% of women are senior academics, and their participation in university boards is similar. Women on the path of a scientific career are disproportionately likely to face barriers in the form of stereotypes and prejudices about their academic potential, which together form a glass ceiling blocking access to top positions. Despite the high competence at the start of their careers, women are much more likely to fall out of the next stages also due to the disproportionately higher burden on men of caring responsibilities. I voted in favour of the 'report on women working in science and universities and the glass ceiling problem' because it recognises the barriers faced by women seeking to develop their scientific careers and draws attention to the need for institutional and cultural changes to remove them. Only breaking the glass ceiling guarantees women the right to realise their potential on an equal basis and to make full use of women's talents and competences in science and innovation.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. \u2012 Gender equality is a fundamental principle of the EU, enshrined in the Treaty on European Union. The report adopted today notes that, despite the positive changes of recent years, the presence of women is still minority with regard to: management positions and higher hierarchical levels, in the scientific and academic fields. The report points out that this disparity is different within the different Member States and urges the Commission and the Member States to ensure respect for the principle of non-discrimination which, in accordance with the Treaty of Lisbon, is an objective of the European Union.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution on women's scientific and academic careers and glass ceilings. This text is once again a call for affirmative action, denying women's personal aspirations. Paragraph 48 in particular encourages affirmative action in university decision-making bodies. Paragraph 35, on the other hand, wants to condition university funding on gender equality plans. The report also demonstrates Europeanist leadership, as in paragraph 25, which calls for a Commission recommendation to Member States with guidelines.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this text because it seeks to increase positive discrimination for the benefit of women in universities. I am in favour of gender equality and meritocracy, not this kind of discrimination. Women are able to succeed on their own.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report from the FEMM Commission whose primary objective is to request action from the European Commission and the Member States aimed at breaking the so-called "glass ceiling", that is, to achieve access to real equality between women and men in higher academic institutions as well as in science-related jobs in the European Union , where there is obvious vertical segregation as evidenced by the data contained in that report.  For this purpose, it would have been valuable if several of our amendments also appeared in this resolution as a group on democratizing university institutions, improving mechanisms for the control and publicity of vacancies, investing in chairs on gender studies or denouncing that austerity measures and the cuts in public resources have adversely affected the slight progress in university and scientific positions in recent years. However, by voting in favour I believe that I am supporting a report which denounces and calls on the Commission and States to take measures to promote equality in research, academic and scientific careers.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. This report carried out by the EP arises from the need to ensure that women and men have the same rights, responsibilities and opportunities in the scientific and labour field.  To this end, both member states and the Commission should take measures that eradicate vertical segregation by analysing existing legal provisions in order to really reflect the principle of non-discrimination; considered to be one of the main objectives of the European Union by the Lisbon Treaty.  It is considered necessary to implement programmes to ensure that women reconcile their professional and personal lives, continuing their careers after motherhood and providing funding for re-entry programs. It is not advisable to have imbalances in human capital that can curb competitiveness or decrease productivity due to the importance of science in economic terms for Europe. Ening Member States to enjoy equality policies on forms of recruitment and employment is not an easy task. For this reason, I am in favour of this report as it will help to form sound and continuous legislation on the subject that will lead to the disappearance of existing labour barriers.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. I voted against the report on women's science and university careers and existing invisible barriers (2014/2251(INI)) because the text adopted sets the wrong tone on the important issue of equality between women and men in science and research. For example, a mandatory quota is not an appropriate instrument for increasing the proportion of women in middle to senior management of higher education institutions. Some statements about alleged discrimination against women are simply wrong in their flatness. Opinions on the so-called 'gender gap' are not sufficiently substantiated. In principle, measures that favour women over men and thus lead to "reverse discrimination" must be rejected.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. Gender alarmism is typical Eurosmysl. I was elected as a Member of the European Parliament also to speak out against such resolutions. The text calls for further commission activity on this matter.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Glass ceiling is a term introduced 20 years ago by the Wall Street Journal to describe the obstacles women face in advancing their careers that prevent them from reaching the top of the corporate hierarchy. Gender equality is a fundamental principle of the European Union. The latest statistics suggest that women encounter many obstacles in their professional development. Some of these are motherhood and family obligations, differentiating between "male and female" professions, the pay gap, lack of ambition (lack of self-confidence), unequal access to professions and sexual abuse of women. In the fields of science, technology, engineering and mathematics, women are particularly obstacleed because these areas are considered "masculine". As gender equality is a fundamental precondition for the full enjoyment of human rights for women and girls and is fundamental to strengthening them and achieving a sustainable and inclusive society, the EU should encourage Member States to recognise the potential of quality career guidance and training to encourage girls to continue their education in STEM fields. Therefore, I supported Mp Vozemberg's report.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. It is insane that there are still far fewer women than men among top school teachers and, more so, deans. An unwritten rule is that men should be given a way here. It is also, to some extent, discriminating. You all have to fight against this. Overall, the report reflects well the current situation, and I voted in favour. All I can do for women! (Power to women! - ENG)

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing ‒ I fully support all measures that will lead to an increase in women's scientific and university careers. In this area, it is necessary to remove all obstacles, unequal treatment and any discrimination, including prejudices, which are both a brake and a gross violation of fundamental human rights. At the same time, the conditions for the social life and knowledge development of women with regard to their maternal mission must be created in a targeted way.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on women's careers in science and university, and the glass ceiling phenomenon they are faced with, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 8/9/2015. I would point out that the Commission must, through educational programmes and campaigns, break down all stereotypes that exist against women and encourage women to head to the scientific and academic workplace. Finally, Member States should, using the media, help to eliminate the stereotypes that still exist for both sexes. Under these conditions, the problem of gender discrimination in science and education can be reduced.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this report which regrets that unequal access for women to research positions, funding and publishing still persists, including a unadjusted gender pay gap in the area of science and academia, despite legal provisions on equal treatment and non-discrimination on the labour market, including provisions on equal pay, being in place in the EU and Member States.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the resolution on women's professional careers in science and academia and the "crystal ceilings". Gender equality is an essential condition for ensuring a position of equal responsibility for women and girls, who can benefit from the same employment opportunities and fully enjoy their rights to emancipation. Women must be encouraged to pursue careers in science and research, encouraging all Member States to promote the academic university field.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This report calls on the Commission and the Member States to implement positive measures to ensure an increased presence and participation of women in science and university, even asking Member States to review their legislation in order to strengthen and promote non-discrimination between men and women. The report also calls for the principle of non-discrimination to be applied in all types of contracts, whether employment or financing, and calls for respect for equal pay for equal work. However, while calling for the need to legislate to achieve a better reconciliation between work and private life, in particular with regard to childcare and care services, it does not include the issue of the Maternity Leave Directive. Nevertheless, it is a very positive report from the point of view of promoting gender equality, so I voted in favour.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. "U2012 Unfortunately, many obstacles remain today that prevent women from greater access to the scientific field and academia. The European Parliament has also adopted, with my vote, a report on women's careers in the scientific and academic fields and existing glass ceilings which confirms that, to this day, women are underrepresented in numerous scientific, engineering and management positions, and in the most important academic positions is very small.  This report calls for measures to break this glass ceiling and we also need the EU to give a boost to this issue, reviewing and adopting legislation necessary to achieve this.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. As science and university are the competences of each Member State, there should be no common guidelines for the EU level. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The report examines the invisible, prejudice-based barriers that prevent women from accessing scientific and academic careers. To combat these glass ceilings, it proposes positive discrimination measures such as the creation of gender equality plans as a precondition for access to public funding in these largely male-dominated areas. It reminds us of the need for a campaign to raise awareness of stereotypes directed at both men and women. The report also calls on states to provide genuine paternity leave to ensure work-life balance and the pursuit of women's careers. On the other hand, it ignores the directive on harmonisation from the top of maternity leave in Europe, which is blocked by both the States and the Commission. A report that does not make waves and carefully avoids talking about the context of "economic crisis", affecting women in the first place. Nevertheless, I am voting in order to emphasize the importance of gender issues in any policy and particularly in the research community.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 Central point of this report is the fundamental principle that it contains: gender equality, enshrined in the EU Treaties, and which is one of the objectives for which the Union is struggling. It is therefore important that there is a continuous analysis of existing legal provisions. I have presented my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in support of the report. The glass ceiling and its effect on women’s ability to achieve parity with men in the scientific sector, both in terms of employment and income, is clear. The report explores this phenomenon and suggests ways EU states can combat this barrier.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. For too long, inequality between men and women has persisted. I support this report, which encourages women to move more towards the scientific environment, where women are under-represented. Positions of responsibility are all too often favoured by men, most often due to outdated stereotypes and discriminatory implicit norms. It is essential to recognize each other's abilities regardless of gender issues. Even if locks have jumped, the glass ceiling remains but on another level. We must remain vigilant and take the necessary measures to avoid undermining women's careers.

name: Angelika MLINAR
text: in writing. ‒ The figures provided by the European Commission on the proportion of women in science show that, despite positive signs, female researchers are still under-represented, in particular in engineering, technologies and natural science. The lack of gender equality is not solely a women's problem. Both studies and practice demonstrate that gender-balanced working environments deliver better-quality results. Therefore, it is in the interest of the scientific sector to join us in the attempt to abolish all barriers to professional development of women to make science more inclusive.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on women’s careers in science and university because I believe that Horizon 2020 cannot be achieved without gender equality. This report addresses gender equality in academic positions and urges the Commission and Member States to revise the existing legal provisions to ensure non-discrimination in all types of university or research contracts or funding. It calls for positive actions and institutional changes to encourage women to continue their scientific/research careers.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The term "glass ceiling" refers to invisible barriers based on prejudice that limit the advancement of women to higher positions in their careers. The glass ceiling is one of the obstacles facing the women's group, which is why they are unable to take a leading position in science, universities or their professions. Almost all of the many research and surveys carried out in this area come to the same conclusion: measures to break the glass ceiling must be radical and not superficial. Cooperation at Community level is of the utmost importance and we must all participate at both individual and collective level. Men and women are different, but they must nevertheless be equal in terms of their rights, regardless of their age, religion, family situation and educational background. Member States should pursue a better practical policy on the recruitment and use of scientists. The concept of equality should be introduced in schools, where children learn that they are equal in all areas of life. Schools should also provide differentness training to support women in the science, technology, engineering and maths professions.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This report on women's scientific and academic careers is an example of a hollow text, yet long of 52 articles. We still note the desire to teach gender equality even in higher education... In the end, this text demeans the woman, since she is seen only through a theme of gender or affirmative action, when the notions of merit or freedom of choice are absent. So I decided to vote against it.

name: Clare MOODY
text: in writing. ‒ The low presence of women in the highest academic and decision-making positions in scientific institutions and universities has to change. I voted for this report because it calls for a strategy to tackle the barriers and stereotypes faced by professional women in science and academia and aims to break the glass ceiling in order to make science inclusive for women.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ This report highlights how far we still have to go to smash the glass ceilings in science and academia. It makes a number of very important recommendations which will ensure that women are able to play their full role in science, research and higher education. Particularly in STEM fields, we face a projected skills shortfall which will only be averted if we act now to empower more women pursuing their careers. We must ensure that women and men are able to balance their work and family lives and that gender biases are eliminated at all stages of recruitment, training and appraisals. This is also an area where cooperation at the European level is vital to share knowledge, best practices and resources amongst institutions and Member States.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text which calls for supporting women's scientific and academic careers. The report points out that women are under-represented in most fields of science and engineering, particularly at higher levels, even in sectors where they are the majority, such as education. It calls on the Commission, Member States and relevant stakeholders to strengthen initiatives and programmes to encourage women to pursue their scientific and academic careers. It offers coaching and networking programs, including support for the individual careers of women researchers and the advancement of their careers at the highest ranks.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Elissavet Vozembert's report "Scientific and Academic Careers of Women and Glass Ceilings". The draft report analyzes the barriers and conscious and unconscious biases that women face during their academic and scientific careers. These barriers are numerous and complex because they are based on various factors, such as: discrimination because of stereotypes, but also because of the obligations related to motherhood and the family, preventing women from pursuing the professional careers they would like to undertake. The report proposes that action be taken by the Commission and Member States within the framework of the European Research Area (ERA) and the specific Horizon 2020 programme, in order to strengthen equality between men and women in universities and in the scientific world.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 We are voting strongly on this resolution which deals with the issue of gender equality in an area, research, where we still see a great deal of inequality. The resolution stresses, among other things, that the low presence of women in the fields of science and research has had, as a result, the strengthening of an androcentric approach to research and development: this testifies to the fact that a sufficiently representative presence of women at the top of decision-making is not just a quantitative issue but has distorted effects on the choices made, helping to support inequality and the creation of gender stereotypes (remember that , in academia, female rectors make up about 15% of the total). We also appreciate the attention shown to conciliation and the creation of a culture of parenthood that relieves mothers only of the burden of having to manage family and work together (with the frequent consequence of abandoning the latter) through the establishment of appropriate leave and paternity allowances. Finally, the proactive attitude with the idea, among others, of the creation of the 'Women and Science' prize, to be awarded to employers who promote women in an exemplary way in academia and science, support women in managerial positions and guarantee equal pay.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report that will promote gender equality in this field.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this report, because I have always considered that equality of opportunity between women and men is proof of our status as civilised nations, it is a result of all the lessons that history has given us, that discrimination creates unforgettable social dramas. I have worked in the parliamentary committee on women's rights and gender equality in my last term, and I have always been close to the issues that quite a few women still face, not only in my country. I believe that this report correctly highlights a serious problem, discrimination against women in academia and science, where all the data show that they are underrepresented and paid less. With my vote today, I would like to join those who are asking the Commission and the Member States to apply all european legislation in this area in good faith and/or to change it if it is not effective.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on women's careers in science and universities and the glass ceiling they are encountering, because, despite positive changes in recent years, gender equality has not yet been achieved in the scientific and academic spheres, although the situation varies from one country to another, areas of science and academic degrees. The extremely low representation of women in top academic and decision-making positions in scientific institutes and universities may indicate the existence of invisible pre-judgmental barriers that pave the way for women to be held accountable. The Commission, the Member States and research funding organisations should develop programmes that actively encourage women to continue their careers after maternity or parental leave and provide them with support for reintegration into the labour market. Such programmes should include training to keep pace with scientific developments and ensure adequate childcare services.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on this report because I believe that the decision should be taken at national level and should not be decided fundamentally by the EU.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. This report analyses the invisible, unjustified barriers that still mean that women cannot access the same scientific and academic careers as men. I voted in favour of this resolution as I believe it is essential to always strengthen affirmative actions that support women's involvement in scientific and academic careers. The report rightly calls for greater EU commitment to the reduction of 'glass ceilings', through anti-stereotyping campaigns or through measures to better balance work and private life by, for example, introducing paternity leave.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. By limiting the representation of women in science, we are ignoring the significant potential that has reached our universities and undervalued highly skilled people. This will reduce the potential benefits and overall economic development of research and innovation-related entrepreneurship. Member States are invited to fully implement the gender dimension in order to reduce the glass ceiling effect and to support women's participation in research.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to vote in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the professional career of women in science and academia and on the 'crystal ceilings' encountered, i.e. invisible barriers based on prejudices that hinder the rise of women to positions of responsibility. Firstly, I believe that gender equality is one of the EU's founding principles, which must also be respected in the academic, scientific and research fields; all forms of direct or indirect discrimination against women must be effectively eliminated. Furthermore, I believe it is essential to encourage women to apply for positions of decision-making responsibility and, at the same time, action must be taken to combat any kind of barrier that makes such a candidacy difficult or impossible, first and for all the difficulty of reconciling professional and family life. Finally, I note that, in addition to encouraging women's individual careers, institutional changes are needed to overcome barriers to gender equality, in particular with regard to vertical segregation and the participation of women in decision-making bodies; I would draw attention to the need for the institutions to work to support and encourage these changes by defining new rules.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report, as it calls for gender targets. You do not fight discrimination with more discrimination. It calls for ‘gender equality plans’ to be a pre-condition for access to public funding in research, science and academia. Rather than making innovations and scientific breakthroughs the important reasons for government support, they want to block help for projects if there are not enough men or women on the team.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European institutions have a key role to play and have a moral duty to serve as a model for civil society. We are therefore all responsible and obliged to educate on diversity and gender equality, so that there is no longer any glass ceiling in Europe, including and above all in the scientific disciplines (STEM). That is the reason for my vote in favour.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This report aims to improve women's academic careers, but its author seems to think that the best way to achieve this would be to jam the skull. If some problems of discrimination are real and some difficulties are undeniable, it is not incentives for gender education that will solve them. By combating discrimination and affirmative action, individuals are further locked into different hierarchical categories rather than allowing them to work together equally. So I voted against it.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ A clear disproportion in the low percentage of women among university staff, and a high percentage of women among the student population combined with a number of other elements (from the pay gap to the generally small number of women in management positions in the public and private sectors), make it clear that we are far from the society of equality to which the Union aspires. Stereotypes are often a useful tool in getting around the social network more easily, but the moment they pass into prejudices used as justification for underestimating and imposing unjustified expectations, they move into a gray zone that we must vigorously fight. I strongly support Ms. Vozemberg's report, which calls on Member States to provide incentives for scientific institutes and universities to introduce and implement gender equality plans, but also who clearly recognises that this is a struggle in which the private sector, the media, the entire academic community and the civil sector must also get involved. Equality between women, and especially in the space of the academy, which for centuries serves as a progressive force that still holds Europe as the leading social and economic power of the world, must be the goal they aspire to, on which all parts of society work.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: in writing. ‒ I am happy for the Parliament’s vote on the women’s careers in science and universities report. Although we have made great strides when it comes to gender equality, there is still plenty of work to be done. This report has made some good steps in the right direction. We must bring our attention to the disproportionate representation of men and women when it comes to roles in higher education, such as professors, because Europe loses here a lot. I also appreciate that it points out the gender gap when it comes to wages, and how a woman can still be paid less than a man for doing the same job. We call for the creation of programmes to help facilitate women in having a more active place in the work force, especially when it comes to education and the STEM fields. This not only is a benefit in itself, but provides the opportunity for younger generations to see women in positions of power and prominence which will help to bring an end to the unjust system of gender inequality.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament is very careful to monitor the state of the art of equal opportunities with particular regard to the world of work. There is a growing need for a strong female presence in academia and science. Member States should have policies on best practices for recruiting and recruiting scientists, and the concept of equality should already be proposed in schools, where children learn that they are all the same in every aspect of their lives. I supported the rapporteur's proposal because I believe it is important to encourage the constant application of the most advanced European legislation on this subject.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 While it is possible to agree with the general indications of the report, which encourages greater involvement of women in scientific fields, the report refers to the Istanbul Convention and recognises the harmful role of stereotypes about traditional family roles. It is for this reason that I did not support the report in its entirety and abstained from voting.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. Some discrimination against women is still found in the scientific and academic circles. Recalling that equality between women and men is one of the fundamental principles of the Union, Parliament adopted a report encouraging Member States and the Union to take appropriate measures to improve the situation. I voted in favour of this report and stress the importance of promoting equality between women and men. However, I would like to stress that certain competences or areas of action are more within the authority of the Member States and not that of the Union.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The draft resolution under consideration is based on the letter of the Treaty on European Union, in particular Articles 2 and 3, which serve considerations on equality between men and women as a fundamental value, which should be taken into account when applying the rules of the Treaties. The rapporteur notes that, despite the positive developments in recent years, equality between men and women, in accordance with the treaties, has not been achieved. As is the case in this case, the role played by gender bias takes women away from academic research and scientific institutions. For this, it contributes a body of beliefs rooted and generalized, based on stereotypes that, in most cases, condition not only the possibilities of women's career progression, but also their expectations, which are unaffected by social pressure and the limitations of motherhood. Considering that women are fundamentally equal to men in all aspects of their lives and considering that positive action is essential, promoting good practices for recruiting and employment of scientists, I voted in favour of the above-mentioned report.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 Existing legal provisions do not yet guarantee gender equality. Although 59% of EU-28 graduates are women, they represent only 18% of full professors and only 10% of university rectors. According to statistics and surveys conducted, women are still poorly represented in education fields and careers related to STEM (science, technology, engineering and mathematics), making up only 24% of science and engineering professionals. I therefore voted in favour of this report, which supports measures to promote the female presence in management positions, scientific and academic careers and to combat gender segregation.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. U2012 Gender equality is one of the principles on which the EU is based and must be respected in all areas. However, as this report which I have supported shows, despite the progress of recent years, gender equality in the scientific and academic fields has not been achieved and the presence of women in the most responsible academic and decision-making positions in scientific institutions and universities is strikingly low. Women should be regretted that women still do not enjoy equal access to research posts and the funding and publication of their research, including the pay gap, despite the equal treatment and non-discrimination provisions in force in the EU and the Member States. The report therefore urges the Commission and EEMM to review existing rules to ensure non-discrimination in universities, research centres and funding contracts. She calls for positive actions and institutional changes to encourage women to continue their scientific and research careers. And it calls on gender equality plans at all levels.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. This report for which I voted analyses the barriers and "biases" (conscious or not) that women face during their academic and scientific careers. These barriers are numerous and complex because they are based on various factors, such as discrimination because of stereotypes, but also because of the obligations related to motherhood and the family, preventing women from pursuing the professional careers they would like to undertake. In recent years, many campaigns have been launched to combat the problems mentioned above. They have put in place effective strategies to promote equality between men and women. However, the current situation remains largely unsatisfactory. The adopted text proposes that measures be taken by the Commission and Member States within the framework of the European Research Area (ERA) and the specific Horizon 2020 programme, in order to strengthen equality between men and women in universities and in the scientific world.

name: Virginie ROZIÈRE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on women's scientific and academic careers. Women are under-represented in most areas of science and engineering and in positions of responsibility, as well as at senior levels. Elissavet Vozemberg's report calls on the Commission, like the Member States, to implement awareness campaigns as well as programmes and initiatives to combat cultural barriers to women's participation in science. It also advocates the development of solutions to reconcile family and professional life, for example by proposing the recognition of paternity leave. It is also proposed that measures and initiatives be taken to promote better representation of women in senior positions and to encourage women to choose scientific careers. With this report, the European Parliament addresses the Commission and the Member States, but also all academic, media and business actors in order to reduce stereotypes and move towards true gender equality.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 Women still face multiple barriers today in reconciling their family lives with their professional careers, including academic and scientific careers, which are linked, directly or indirectly, to stereotypes, motherhood, family obligations, among others. We are therefore still far from achieving the desired gender equality in this field. That is why this report is well just making a good diagnosis of the current situation, but also presenting concrete solutions that can be implemented by the Commission and the Member States within the Framework of the European Research Area and the Specific Horizon 2020 programme, with the objective of increasing gender equality in universities and in the fields of scientific research. Consensus has been reached around this report, and I too have contributed my vote for its final adoption.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to abstain on Mr Syley's proposal. Mr Vozemberg, who is involved in the professional careers of women in science and academia, called on the Member States to pay more attention to the recruitment and recruitment mechanisms of scientists and a greater sensitivity to gender equality.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this initiative. This report denounces the under-representation of women at the upper hierarchical levels of the scientific and academic fields as a result of discrimination based, among other factors, on prejudice and stereotypes, despite having an equivalent level of professional performance. And it proposes measures that end up breaking this "glass ceiling" in aspects such as: equal treatment provisions, gender violence, non-discrimination in contracting and financing projects, gender balance perspective in budgets in scientific and academic programmes, transparency in selection and promotion processes, specific attention to LGBTI, outreach and training campaigns on diversity and equality and positive models in science and technology , work and family life balance, maternity, changes is the European institutions, gender dimension in scientific and technological content

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Girls make up the vast majority of university graduates. It is therefore unacceptable that, in pursuit of further application not only in academia, it must hit a glass ceiling made up of a number of gender barriers and stereotypes. However, it is equally important to improve the conditions for the in-form of personal and professional life. I therefore voted in favour of this report, which proposes possible solutions to this situation.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report from the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality whose primary objective is to call for action from the European Commission and the Member States aimed at breaking the so-called "glass ceiling", that is, to achieve access to real equality between women and men in higher academic institutions as well as in science-related jobs in the European Union , where there is obvious vertical segregation as evidenced by the data contained in that report.  For this purpose, it would have been valuable if several of our amendments also appeared in this resolution as a group on democratizing university institutions, improving mechanisms for the control and publicity of vacancies, investing in chairs on gender studies or denouncing that austerity measures and the cuts in public resources have adversely affected the slight progress in university and scientific positions in recent years. However, by voting in favour I believe that I am supporting a report which denounces and calls on the Commission and States to take measures to promote equality in research, academic and scientific careers.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: in writing. \u2012 As a scientist in Portugal, I have seen a progressive growth in the number of women in science. And I see this number progress, accompanied by a notorious increase in the quality of teaching and scientific research. In Portugal, the gender balance has been deceitful, but it is coming and with unquestionable benefits.  However, I recognise that this balance is not yet widespread in the different institutions and that there are specific difficulties of the female gender, in particular those related to motherhood, which are not yet properly framed. It is difficult, and often seemingly impossible, to combine a system based on scholarships or other highly instible work regimes with pregnancy. Tools must be created to better protect women by allowing access and especially success in the scientific career at all stages of their lives. There's still work to do.  For this reason, I applaud and support this own-initiative report.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report, I am against any positive discrimination, as it undermines what is sets out to achieve. This report also calls on the Commission to do various things which could equate to quotas, I am against quotas.  While I support the call for more women in the sciences, I cannot support this report.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I believe that every girl and woman has the right to an education. This report highlights how far we still have to go to end gender-related barriers in science and academia. It makes a number of very important recommendations which will ensure that women are able to play their full role in science, research and higher education. We are facing a skills shortfall, especially in science, technology, engineering and mathematics; something we can avoid if we act now and give women more freedom to pursue their careers.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing \ u2012 It is important that we promote the qualified application of women in the labour market. However, I firmly believe that the introduction of quotas determining the number of women in senior positions in the university and scientific spheres is certainly not the right solution to this support. I therefore voted against the EP resolution on women's scientific and university careers.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ This explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ despite the fact that there are more and more university students in Europe, we continue to see that women in scientific and technological fields are not yet sufficiently represented. This is evidenced by statistics showing that in Europe, women currently represent only 33% of researchers, 20% of university professors and are only 15.5% at the head of higher education institutions. Personally, I am very happy that the issue of women in science and higher education is also starting to be given greater attention within the EU. I believe that women also represent a highly educational and intellectual potential for the area under debate, the use of which is proving to be very insufficient. On the other hand, I am glad that flexible organisations are already increasingly recruiting women in their key positions, not only with regard to social justice, but especially because of their real abilities and attitudes. Although women are increasingly asserting themselves in professions that until recently were the domain of men, I continue to see that some still find the connections between women and careers unnatural. I welcome all the actions and measures that address the elimination of stereotypes and prejudices against women and address the under-representation of women in science, technology, engineering and higher education.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: Writing. \u2012 I am particularly pleased with the initiative to promote women in science. At European level, it can be perceived that women are still underrepresented in the academic sphere because of the existence of prejudices and stereotypes against them. According to the European Union's human rights aspirations, it is our task to enforce our existing legal provisions and, where necessary, to make new ones in order to achieve gender equality. Research shows, for example, that both sexes are particularly disadvantaged by the fact that both sexes consider male candids to be more promising for a job requiring mathematical knowledge. Although my country is one of those with positive indicators in this area, it also needs programmes to encourage women to pursue academic careers, while at the same time looking at family as a value.  In this sense, I believe that the Commission and the Member States need to develop programmes to ensure that a favourable environment is created for women's academic careers, taking into account the role of women in families.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. Gender equality is one of the fundamental principles and also one of the EU's objectives and tasks. It is a prerequisite that allows women and girls to fully enjoy human rights and is essential for strengthening their role and building a sustainable and inclusive society. Available statistics and surveys show that women are not adequately represented in most scientific, engineering, management posts and senior management positions. A similar situation is also in situations where women make up the majority, for example in the education sector. Despite the positive changes in recent years, gender equality has still not been achieved in the scientific and academic sphere (the situation varies by Member State, research areas and academic title). The representation of women in the highest academic and managerial positions in scientific institutions and universities is surprisingly low. This points to the presence of the so-called 'glass ceiling' phenomenon – invisible barriers based on prejudices that limit women's progress to held positions of responsibility. The report calls, among other things, on the Commission and the Member States to examine the legal provisions in force and, if necessary, to amend them in order to strengthen equal treatment between women and men, and to ensure that all forms of employment contracts or funding are respected for the principle of non-discrimination, which is why I supported the report.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Writing. I voted against the report on women's science and university careers and existing invisible barriers (2014/2251(INI)) because the text adopted sets the wrong tone on the important issue of equality between women and men in science and research. For example, a mandatory quota is not an appropriate, accepted instrument for increasing the proportion of women in middle to senior management of higher education institutions. Opinions on the so-called "gender gap" must be deposited with facts and analysed in detail. Efforts to demand "tariff transparency" beyond the already regulated collective bargaining agreement must be rejected in principle.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: Written. \u2012 The N-VA delegation defends an inclusive society with equal rights and obligations for all as well as an equal opportunities policy tailored to and with attention to diverse target groups. Violations of this equality, both at work and in private, are not acceptable to us.  We realize that people with STEM skills (Science, Technology, Engineering, Mathematics) make an essential contribution to our labour market and economy. But the causes of the glass ceiling in women's scientific and university careers are more social and deeper in nature. Quotas are not a solution. Because of the call for mandatory quotas for women, we have chosen to abstain from voting on this report.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. I support this report because I believe that every woman should be given equal opportunities in any sphere of social and academic life. We have witnessed a multitude of such campaigns over the past years, but it seems that we still have to fight for women's rights in the business world, as well as here where science and universities are involved, that is, in high academic institutions and institutions.  Despite these campaigns, the current situation in gender equality is still far from satisfactory and therefore strategies that will lead to improved status of women in the business world and environment should continue to be worked on. Because of all of the above, I support the measures in this report and believe that they will lead to an increase in equality between women and men, especially in universities and in the world of science.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ This report highlights how far we still have to go to smash the glass ceilings in science and academia. It makes a number of very important recommendations which will ensure that women are able to play their full role in science, research and higher education.
