Particularly in STEM fields, we face a projected skills shortfall which will only be averted if we act now to empower more women pursuing their careers. We must ensure that women and men are able to balance their work and family lives and that gender biases are eliminated at all stages of recruitment, training and appraisals. This is also an area where cooperation at the European level is vital to share knowledge, best practices and resources amongst institutions and Member States.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. I support this report because I believe it is of utmost importance to promote gender equality in science. As science is essential for the European economy, it needs teams of scientists capable of research that are essential to increase productivity and competitiveness.  Gender equality is key to achieving a sustainable and inclusive society. I also point out that in many countries there is a shortage of women scientists due to inadequate educational system in which the value of women scientists is often ignored. It is necessary to conduct campaigns addressed not only to women, but also to men, since they, consciously or unconsciously, repeat gender stereotypes that make women encounter institutional barriers that prevent them from advancing their scientific careers.  Women are still rarely present in top academic and management positions in scientific institutions and universities, although positive changes have been made in gender equality in the academic world over recent years. We are talking about the existence of a "glass ceiling" – invisible barriers based on prejudices that make it impede the path of women to leadership positions.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: I did not support the proposal in writing ‒ I did not support the proposal. In fact, I do not agree with the measures on the table, many of which increase the regulatory burden, ultimately hurting women more than they will help, are examples of positive discrimination, or interfere with the competences of the Member States. These are things such as quotas on the proportion of women on company boards, a call for children to be taught about 'equality' in schools, a direct call to support women in certain professions and so on.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on women's careers in the scientific and academic fields and the existing glass ceilings, because gender equality is one of the most important elements for ensuring human rights as a whole. Many statistical data show that women are not adequately represented in most scientific, engineering and managerial jobs and senior management positions. In Slovenia, too, we face similar problems, as women in managerial positions are more of an exception than a rule. I support the call in the report for the Commission and the Member States to examine the legal provisions in force in order to implement them correctly and, if necessary, to amend them in order to strengthen equal treatment between women and men.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 This report promotes gender discrimination, removes all notions of meritocracy and undermines the traditional family.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Given that gender equality is a fundamental principle of the European Union, all action must be taken against existing discrimination against women in the field of science. A European Parliament document indicates that women are still under-represented in most science, engineering and management positions, which, in addition to the social and moral dimensions, is of economic importance, as science is essential for Europe and requires an increasing number of teams capable of m.in. to carry out groundbreaking research relevant to the EU's productivity and competitiveness. In addition to highlighting the problems, the EP document sets out the actions to be taken by the Member States and the European Commission to change the current situation, such as m.in. incentives for research centres, the removal of cultural barriers or the establishment of the European Parliament's Women in European Science award. I therefore voted in favour of the report on women working in science and universities. I would point out, however, that I believe that, in view of the introduction of equality between women and men, action should be taken in the various fields and industries of their activity, and not only in one, i.e. in science.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union has come a long way towards adopting an appropriate legislative framework to support gender equality. Currently, the legal provisions in the Member States in this regard are among the most advanced in the world. However, in practice, in many Member States, the situation of women is still precarious, being affected by the persistence of prejudices and stereotypes.  A special case is that of women involved in science and academia: their share is at an alarmingly low level, of only 18% of university professors and 10% of rectors. In order to correct this glaring imbalance, it is necessary for the European institutions to apply gender policies more vigorously, in order to aim as much as possible to equalise the status of women with that of men, both through educational policies, promotion programmes and non-discriminatory practices, and by establishing mandatory quotas in the scientific and academic institutions of the Member States, by ensuring a balance between personal and career life. These measures can also be promoted through Horizon 2020. It is important that these measures are implemented in a concrete manner and properly evaluated. This document is a step forward in this direction.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ While I support the need to enhance a strategy, in order to achieve universal equality between men and women in their respective careers in science, education and technology, I chose to abstain as I could not agree with some of the tools proposed to achieve this goal, and especially the Women on Boards Directive.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I support the report as it analyses barriers to entering women's careers and careers at academic and scientific level. The barriers are numerous and quite complex, as they take various forms, from discrimination on the grounds of stereotypes to maternity obligations and other family obligations. A number of actions to combat the above factors have been launched over the years with effective strategies aimed at promoting gender equality. The current situation is far from satisfactory, and therefore the report proposes measures to be taken between Member States within the framework of the European Research Area and the Specific Horizon 2020 programme.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this initiative. This report denounces the under-representation of women at the upper hierarchical levels of the scientific and academic fields as a result of discrimination based, among other factors, on prejudice and stereotypes, despite having an equivalent level of professional performance. And it proposes measures that end up breaking this "glass ceiling" in aspects such as: equal treatment provisions, gender violence, non-discrimination in contracting and financing projects, gender balance perspective in budgets in scientific and academic programmes, transparency in selection and promotion processes, specific attention to LGBTI, outreach and training campaigns on diversity and equality and positive models in science and technology , reconciliation of working and family life, maternity, changes is the European institutions, gender dimension in scientific and technological content.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ According to the statistics and studies available, women are underrepresented in many scientific jobs, engineering and management, and at senior levels. Science plays a key role in the European economy and requires a growing number of teams that can, among other matters, develop innovative research, which is essential for increasing productivity and competitiveness, and having enough people with skills in science, technology, engineering and mathematics is an essential precondition for implementing the European Agenda for Growth and Jobs and the objectives of Europe 2020. I will support any measure that eliminates all forms of direct or indirect discrimination against women.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. At no time does this text extol noble values such as merit or freedom of choice. Its objectives are opposed to our perception of what gender equality should be: welcoming complementarity through the recognition of differences and the wills of each. I am voting against this text.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this initiative. This report denounces the under-representation of women at the upper hierarchical levels of the scientific and academic fields as a result of discrimination based, among other factors, on prejudice and stereotypes, despite having an equivalent level of professional performance. And it proposes measures that end up breaking this "glass ceiling" in aspects such as: equal treatment provisions, gender violence, non-discrimination in contracting and financing projects, gender balance perspective in budgets in scientific and academic programmes, transparency in selection and promotion processes, specific attention to LGBTI, outreach and training campaigns on diversity and equality and positive models in science and technology , reconciliation of working and family life, maternity, changes is the European institutions, gender dimension in scientific and technological content.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on women's careers in the scientific and academic fields and existing glass ceilings because it clearly advocates gender equality in academic/scientific positions and proposes positive measures to ensure that this equality is respected and that women are equally represented in the scientific and academic fields.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – Despite all efforts to promote gender equality and equal opportunities, women still have unequal access to positions in the research sector, access to finance, publishing services and scientific awards, and are also subject to inflexible promotion and recognition criteria, and lack funding or adequate support policies.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 We consider it important to know the outcome of equality policies in the field of research and in universities in the different EU countries. We believe that the drafting of proposals which each Member State may or may not adopt to achieve gender and wage equality in science, research, technology sectors and universities can be valid.  This report concludes that gender equality in science and universities has not yet been achieved as women have an extremely small presence in the highest academic positions and in decision-making in scientific institutions and universities.  We agree that the principle of non-discrimination should be observed in all types of employment contract or financing, as well as the legal right to "equal work to match equal pay" should also be respected. We follow the need to recognize adequate paternity leave and allowance, so that it is economically feasible for men to take care of a child. We have reservations about the possibility of sanctioning institutions that do not meet the so-called 'targets' of equality, but we agree with the generality of the report, so we voted in favour.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. As science and university are the competences of each Member State, there should be no common guidelines for the EU level. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing. \u2012 Gender equality is one of the key principles of the European Union. However, despite the undeniable improvements of recent years, women experience a situation of under-representation in many fields, especially in the scientific and academic world. There is a clear problem of discrimination which arises through unequal access to research positions, as well as in different salaries, for the same role. Europe has a duty to ensure fair and equal conditions for men and women and to combat all forms of discrimination with every means at its disposal. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. U2012 We are talking about a report that points to the professional barriers that women encounter today in both their scientific and academic careers. It is necessary to continue to point out these barriers in order to continue to fight them and to advance equality between men and women. I therefore consider it necessary to vote in favour of that report.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it highlights how far we still have to go to break through the glass ceilings in science and academia. It makes a number of very important recommendations which will ensure that women are able to play their full role in science, research and higher education. Particularly in STEM fields, we face a projected skills shortfall which will only be averted if we act now to empower more women to pursue their careers without disadvantage. We must ensure that women and men are able to balance their work and family lives and that gender biases are eliminated at all stages of recruitment, training and appraisals. This is also an area where cooperation at the European level is vital to share knowledge, best practices and resources amongst institutions and Member States.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. – I voted on the report on women's careers in science and academia and the 'glass ceilings' encountered. I agree with the rapporteur's request, which urges the Commission and the Member States to analyse existing legal provisions in order to implement them properly and, if necessary, to review them in order to ensure respect for equal treatment between women and men. The Commission and the Member States are also invited to ensure compliance with the principle of non-discrimination, considered in the Treaty of Lisbon as the objective of the European Union, in all types of employment or financing contracts, and to respect the legal right to equal pay for equal work, for all components of the remuneration granted to men and women, including grants and scholarships, by ensuring , for example, wage transparency.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing \ u2012 The report addresses the barriers faced by women in the professions at all levels. It focuses on the field of science, technology, but also on academic careers or management positions, where women's representation is lowest. Women who want to pursue careers after starting a family should be allowed to do so. More crèches and nurseries, adaptation of working conditions, for example, to more flexible working hours, the possibility of splitting parental leave and drawing it up to 12 years of age. These are just some of the many tools that women wouldn't have to choose between careers and family.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 As the report recommends, we consider it important to know the outcome of equality policies in research and universities in the different EU countries, as we believe that the drafting of proposals that each Member State may or may not adopt to achieve gender and wage equality in science, research, technology and universities can be valid.  This report concludes that, despite the positive changes in recent years, gender equality in science and universities has not yet been achieved as women have an extremely small presence in the highest academic positions and in decision-making in scientific institutions and universities. We agree that the principle of non-discrimination should be observed in all types of employment contract or financing, as well as the legal right to "equal work to match equal pay" should also be respected. We agree on the need to recognize adequate paternity leave and allowance, so that it is economically feasible for men to take care of a child. Although we do not agree with the possibility of sanctioning institutions that do not meet the so-called 'targets' of equality, we agree with the general ity of the report's content, so we voted in favour.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, unfortunately, I could not support the report on the empowerment of girls in the EU through education. There are a number of problematic points behind such a good-sounding name, which, moreover, directly contradict the fundamental Treaties on the functioning of the Union. They violate the guaranteed principle of subsidiarity, e.g. on the issue of compulsory sex education. Although the material contains some true and important information, it does not provide any new practical solutions. A reasonable person perceives equality between a man and a woman, but also their significant natural differences. He knows that equal access to education is the basis for a healthy society. There is a lot to improve on the position of girls and women in society. But this is certainly not the path to success.  For example, my colleague proposed the blanket introduction of compulsory sex education, which is precisely the matter for the Member States. I am really glad that this is only non-binding material that member states do not have to automatically accept.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I was very pleased to see the adoption of this report, which I strongly supported, not least because here in the Chamber of the European Parliament we have witnessed a funny crusade, yet another mystification against what is termed in a very general way the theory of gender, gender education.  I believe that this terror is a leap into the Middle Ages and I am very pleased that the report has been adopted, precisely because it allows us to avoid this leap. I believe that gender education, education in affectivity, sexuality, in schools is highly important and must be an integral part of the Union's policy against gender discrimination, against sexism, against transphobia, against homophobia. I therefore welcome the adoption of the report and hope that gender studies of gender issues can be implemented in the training institutions in the European Union.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: – I voted against this report because every family has the right to live freely according to their faith and to choose educational programmes for their children without being discriminated against. Parents are the first and main teachers of their children. This right is recognised by both the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the Convention on the Rights of the Child and the European Treaties. The use of the term 'gender', which is not legally defined and its meaning varies according to context, creates space for different interpretations and is not suitable for labelling discrimination between women and men, as the European Treaties also talk about it. The gender identities referred to in the present report are not supported by the Treaties or in reality and are an ideological social construct and have no place in compulsory education for children. This is just another report from reports that violate the sovereignty of the Member States.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: – Mr President, this report on empowering girls through education should ring bells with all of us in Parliament. Surely we cannot have forgotten Malala Yousafzai and her inspiring speech on how girls are empowered through education. Knowledge is power, and we live in a knowledge economy.  In this report, I supported the proposal that the EU accede to the Istanbul Convention and indeed that Member States ratify the Convention, and also that the EU and Member States work together for gender equality in the EU’s external relations. I am happy to support age-appropriate sex education and relationship education: indeed, I encourage Member States to make such sex education compulsory for secondary and primary school children. I know it is a Member State competence, but that is my view. ‘Age-appropriate’, of course, are the key words here. Most of our young people have access to the internet, to the World Wide Web, with all its pluses and minuses. They need to be armed with age—appropriate sex and relationship education. If not, they are not empowered to deal with what they see and hear.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: " Mr. President, I believe that the adoption of this report represents the defeat of democracy and the rule of law and I voted against it. Ideologies like this should have stayed in some past times, and the Socialists have re-imposed them on us. Worst of all, they did it under the guise of protecting children's rights. This report deprives parents of the right to raise their own children and for Member States to set their own curricula. Therefore, we should rightly ask ourselves what is next. And we must all ask ourselves whether MEPs even know the views and values of their constituents. I voted against this report because it opposes the Europe I believe in. I will continue to stand up for a Europe where there must be room for true human values that this report denies.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 Member States need to pay greater attention to education for gender equality by improving the quality of education systems, thus helping to overcome socio-cultural stereotypes that often lead to unfavourable conditions for professional fulfilment, especially for women. Investing in the principles of inclusive education through specific programmes and targeted actions can serve to combat gender discrimination and ensure equal access from school learning. In order to do this, it is necessary to promote gender equality in the education system at all levels, starting with primary education. Fostering an intercultural and mutually respectful educational approach, interreligious dialogue, is central to the training of balanced, tolerance-oriented, informed and more choice-conscious young people. Education is the main instrument of emancipation capable of defeating marginalization and discrimination through which violence can be combated, which is also hidden behind the phenomena of bullying and cyber-bullying.  The report contains all these aspects and for these reasons I voted in favour. It is in fact essential to promote educational models free of gender stereotypes and linked to sexist prejudices, with a view to the future generations participating freely and consciously in economic and social development.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I firmly believe that gender equality is a fundamental principle that children must learn from a young age.  It is important that Member States implement measures to achieve gender equality at all levels of the education system; incorporating a higher degree of awareness of gender issues into the training of teachers and other school staff (doctors, nurses, psychologists, social workers, educators) and that introduce mechanisms that allow the promotion, implementation, monitoring and evaluation of gender equality in all educational institutions and levels.  I also believe that it is essential that sex education be provided tailored to the age and needs of students, including awareness-raising on LGBT issues.  It is also important that States invest in educational and awareness-raising campaigns that improve career guidance for girls and boys, addressing the stereotypical image of gender roles, as well as gender stereotypes in different careers, particularly in the field of science and new technologies, to reduce gender segregation in the labour market and strengthen women's position.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I supported this text which urges Member States to take measures to raise awareness of gender equality from education. Unfortunately, the final vote withdrew its call on the Commission to be involved in actions on programmes for gender equality, even though it is part of the principles of existing treaties.  However, the text is aimed at requesting resources for educational institutions and educational professionals to develop cross-cutting training and programmes in non-discrimination values that invite gender barriers and stereotypes. It also recalls the duty of States to seek public childcare networks, as well as to ensure quality public education. It also again urges the Commission to begin the EU accession procedure to the Istanbul Convention on Violence against Women. Although improveable, the text denounces that austerity measures have very negatively affected educational resources, for which strong public investment is needed to develop the programmes identified. That is why my vote has been favourable.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. Although more and more women are graduating, they continue to be discriminated against in terms of career opportunities and pay compared to men. I therefore support equality and the empowerment of girls through education, taking into account the principle of subsidiarity. Already in schools the attitudes have to change in this regard. Girls and boys should be treated equally at all levels of the school system, so that unnecessary stereotypes are broken down and girls are given equal opportunities.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. The Rodriguez report aims to subject Girls and Young People in Europe to the EU's dominant ideology through school. In particular, this text aims to make "an education compulsory [...] sexuality [ ...] for all primary school pupils" (from the age of 6). These are positions hostile to the interests of our youth and society as a whole. They are as illegitimate as they are harmful. On the one hand, they run counter to the principle of subsidiarity and on the other hand undermine the traditional values on which centuries have been built during our civilization. So I voted against it.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ The European Union should not be involved with the education systems of Member States.  Interference with sex and relationship education should also not be the role of the European Union.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. Another very dangerous report promoting gender ideology and, therefore, LGBTI communitarian demands. And once again, the rapporteur pretends to ignore that almost all of his proposals do not stand for the European Union.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. Given the potential of education in cultural change, investments at all levels of the education system to advocate for gender equality play a key role. Similarly, the school must contribute to developing an intercultural approach to education with mutual respect and intercultural and interreligious dialogue. I voted in favour of this initiative.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of training young women through education in the European Union despite all the emails we have received in recent weeks against them. In addition to equal access to education for children, regardless of their socio-economic, cultural or religious status, this report calls on Member States to implement educational measures aimed at combating gender stereotypes that often affect the very image of young people, health, skills acquisition , social integration and professional life, encouraging young people to take an equal interest in all subjects beyond gender stereotypes in vocational and professional orientation, contribute to strengthening the awareness of girls and women about the control of their own bodies and a long etcetera.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This report on the emancipation of girls through education in the EU is mainly aimed at conditioning young people in EU Member States to accept minorities through the school system.  It proposes, among other things, to develop specific programmes for Roma girls, to make sexuality education compulsory for all pupils from primary school on or to include objective information on LGBTI issues in school curricula...  The fundamental idea of the report is that "gender stereotypes" must be stopped in order to enable young girls to access all occupations, and also to put an end to all the "discrimination" against women. With this report, the school must be careful not to confine itself to education: it must educate, and in this case modify, the whole human person. I condemn this report for the lack of a legal basis and the violations of "freedom of thought, freedom of expression, privacy" and the right of parents to be their children's first educators. In conclusion, education is not within the competence of the Union, and I voted against this text.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on Parliament's report on the empowerment of girls in the European Union through education. In the European Union, women make up the majority (60%) of graduates in higher education institutions, but their employment rate and trends in promotion do not reflect all their opportunities. The Commission and the Member States must take measures to ensure that gender equality is applied at all levels of the education system and that gender issues are fully integrated into the training programmes for teachers and all school professionals, as well as to ensure that mechanisms are in place to promote, implement, monitor and evaluate gender equality in educational institutions throughout the education system. Member States must ensure that the objectives of their education systems include education based on respect for fundamental rights and freedoms, equal rights and opportunities for women and men.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I did not intend to support this report with my vote because I consider it to be extremely partisan in many of its passages, the focus is on migrants and Roma and forgets, as is all too often the case, the rights of EU citizens.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 By regularly promoting gender mainstreaming, we recognise that girls' education is one of the most lucrative development investments. In this sense, I welcomed the report.  The report includes a number of objectives of particular importance for the People's Party, such as inclusive and equitable high-quality education and teacher training, professional skills development to increase employment, the possibility of lifelong learning, the fight against stereotypes, digital education. We can all see that, despite the Union's strong political commitment to equality, there are still deep-seated social barriers behind gender inequality: not many girls choose science or technology courses, while social care occupations are feminist.  However, I firmly believe that, in order to achieve joint success, towards a report of fruitful and constructive value, it would have been extremely important to respect the subject of the report and not to violate the principle of subsidiarity by hiding under the umbrella of human rights. Of course, we can encourage Member States to take certain measures and actions, but education is, above all, a competence of the Member States, and we must avoid interfering, albeit with good intentions, in areas where we do not have competence. I regret that the report, despite its positive points, goes beyond its powers in several places. I therefore abstained in the vote.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 I support this resolution which aims to encourage efforts at European level to help bridge the gap that still exists for the training and professional development of women. We know that today, although women make up 60% of graduates, their jobs are less well paid for the same qualifications and their presence in top positions is less widespread. In this sense, the world of education plays a central role and can also do a lot to combat stereotypes. Stereotypes which must be contrasted with an eye to both teaching programmes and teacher training.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. The report deals primarily with the fact that 30 million primary school girls worldwide are outside the education system. In order to overcome this situation, a number of positive measures are proposed that would be achieved through European funds and programmes.  Education is seen as a precondition for gender equality, as statistics show, for example, that unschooling girls are more exposed to domestic violence. Lifelong education programmes are supported and aimed at reducing the gender pay gap for the same work. I support this report.

name: Louise BOURS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as it calls for gender quotas on education bodies – you don’t fight discrimination with more discrimination. It called for compulsory sex and relationship classes and for the EU Commission to conduct propaganda campaigns in our schools. The EU Commission has no right to interfere with education, both in principle as it is an unelected and unaccountable body, but also in practice as it is not granted the competence in the treaties.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the emancipation of girls through education in the Union because this text aims to condition young Europeans to accept minorities through school. I cannot support this text on both legal (education) and ideological issues.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this positive report, which focuses on the critical role of the education system in the EU in reaching the goal of gender equality. This is an important issue not only in Ireland but right across the EU, and beyond. The report highlights the role of education in empowering girls to reach economic independence in the future. It calls for a concerted effort to be made against negative gender stereotypes in schools, the media and advertising; for increasing the presence of women in science, technology, engineering and mathematics; and for Member States to provide targeted support for disadvantaged families. It also calls for the Member States to consider making age-appropriate education on sex and healthy relationships compulsory in school curricula. The report points out that formal and informal education programmes must address gender-based violence, gender discrimination, harassment, homophobia and transphobia, in all their forms, including forms of cyber-bullying or online harassment.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I am convinced that education is, if not the only one, the main instrument for empowering girls both through the teaching of respect for fundamental rights and freedoms and equality of rights and opportunities between women and men, and through the possibility of achieving themselves that only a complete education can guarantee.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Gender equality is equal to culture and access to education. The Union must support an extensive programme of education on gender equality in schools, including media literacy, the fight against bullying, including online bullying ( cyber-bullying), homophobic violence, hate speech and civic education. It is therefore necessary to draw up European action plans with resources to invest in gender equality together with the creation of themed education structures, recommending the use of the European instruments available for this purpose, such as the Investment Plan, the Horizon 2020 programme and the EU Structural Funds. Parliament must encourage the exchange of good practice in this area between the various educational institutions and between teachers who play the key role in the formation of educational identities and influence gender-related behaviour in schools. It is therefore necessary to ensure that teachers, at all levels of formal and informal education, have comprehensive continuing training, including peer learning and cooperation with external organisations and agencies, in order to raise awareness of the impact of gender roles and stereotypes on students' self-esteem and choice of course of study. Girls need positive models in schools to exploit their potential without fear of discrimination.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. First of all, it should be stressed that the European Union has no competence in the field of education. Parliament should not even intervene on this issue. Moreover, it is not appropriate to want to subject our young people to the dominant Europeanist ideology and to introduce topics on sexuality and gender into school curricula. The school is a place of knowledge transmission and not of sex education.  The text, put to a vote by Parliament, proposes to develop specific programmes for Roma girls, to make sex education compulsory for all primary school pupils (even for 6-year-olds), to include information on LGBTI issues in school curricula and to monitor the implementation of equality programmes in close collaboration with experts on gender issues. , which imposes external control on member states' education systems. I therefore voted against this unacceptable motion for a resolution.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Apart from a few obvious things, considering that quality public education should be free and guaranteed to all children, without discrimination regardless of their residence status; calls for the European and national authorities to promote gender equality within educational institutions by all possible means and for gender education to be a key element of school curricula; European and national authorities must also ensure that educational material does not contain discriminatory content. Member States are required to provide the active support necessary to ensure that migrant women and their families can be taught the language of their host country in free public education services at local level. Member States are invited to develop specific programmes to ensure that Roma girls and young people continue their primary, secondary and higher education. I am voting against.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I firmly believe that gender equality is a fundamental principle that children must learn from a young age.  It is important that Member States implement measures to achieve gender equality at all levels of the education system; incorporating a higher degree of awareness of gender issues into the training of teachers and other school staff (doctors, nurses, psychologists, social workers, educators) and that introduce mechanisms that allow the promotion, implementation, monitoring and evaluation of gender equality in all educational institutions and levels.  I also believe that it is essential that sex education be provided tailored to the age and needs of students, including awareness-raising on LGBT issues.  It is also important that States invest in educational and awareness-raising campaigns that improve career guidance for girls and boys, addressing the stereotypical picture of gender roles, as well as gender stereotypes in different careers, particularly in the field of science and new technologies, to reduce gender segregation in the labour market and strengthen women's position

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 My vote on the report on the emancipation of girls through education in the EU is favourable because even today 30 million girls of primary school age are excluded from the education system worldwide. Unfortunately, this is also partly the case in Europe, where budget cuts in education, largely resulting from austerity policies, are endangering high-quality free public education and thus helping to exacerbate inequalities. In the EU, the rate of unemployment penalises most women.  Each Member State must work to ensure access to education and training for girls and women in the best possible way. Education and training which represent an important European value and a fundamental human right for all women.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which contained some very progressive and positive provisions. The report calls for implementation and improvement measures to apply gender equality at all levels of education systems, including training of teachers, school professionals and curricula. It sought to address crucial matters such as the recognition of age appropriate sex and relationship education, and awareness about LGBT issues at school in a sensitive and enlightened manner.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ The European Union should not be interfering with the education systems of Member States. Due to the cultural differences between member states, and as matter of faith, I believe that  sex and relationship education should also not be the role of the European Union. Such an approach allows for political correctness to take hold, on such a sensitive subject. Hence, I voted against this report.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I agree with a number of elements in this report as it highlights the significant progress that has been achieved in terms of equal attainments and access to education. It urges gender equality to be applied in the educational system at all levels in order to remove gender stereotype, empower girls and eliminate inequalities between men and women. On the other hand, I abstained as I believe that a number of other elements introduced in the report infringe on the principle of subsidiarity

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 This report addresses the issue of the emancipation of girls through education, with the aim of making greater use of the educational and university education path, for a real affirmation of women in society and in the world of work. I voted in favour of this text because it highlights the need to take more measures to respect fundamental rights and freedoms and to equal rights and opportunities for women and men. The report also seeks to remove the remaining obstacles to effective equality between women and men by promoting the development of self-esteem and professional affirmation in order to encourage girls and women to be autonomous and to take informed decisions.

name: Jean-Marie CAVADA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of Liliana Rodrigues' report on the emancipation of girls through education in the Union, whose main objectives - to end gender stereotypes and bridge the gap between women's education and their professional development - seem to me to be indispensable.  However, I am reserved about the compulsory introduction of sex education programmes from primary school on end.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. I voted against this motion for a resolution because it calls for the introduction of mechanisms in the education system to ensure the submission of all young people in Europe to the dominant ideology of the Union. The ENL Group is the only one to have tabled an amendment, which has also caused high tensions with the EPP group.

name: Nessa CHILDERS
text: in writing. ‒ In the EU, the gap between women’s education and their professional development is still very wide. This needs to be addressed, and not only in order to achieve gender equality. Closing the gap between women's educational attainment and their professional achievement  will help long-term economic growth.  Specific programmes for marginalised communities, for Roma girls for example, should be established in Member States to make sure that primary, secondary and higher education is followed through. We need to do more in order to increase the number of girls and women in education. However, education alone does not cut it. A change of mentality on gender values are what will make our society more fair and just for everyone.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 What we are saying about the least developed countries also applies in the EU, namely that education can be an important instrument of emancipation, particularly for women, at family, cultural, professional and political level, as well as promoting respect, equality and social progress. That is also why it is essential to ensure, through increased investment, quality public education, without social discrimination and regardless of residence status, starting with the preschool system, nursery schools and crèches, up to the highest levels of education. And, at all levels, we need to counter the negative impact that gender-based stereotypes and expectations - promoted by the media, and sometimes in schools themselves - can have on identity building, self-image, health, learning, intellectual development and social integration. The resolution moves in the right direction and also calls for specific measures, such as teaching migrant women and their families the language of the host country through free public education services; programmes to encourage Roma girls to continue their studies; forms of lifelong learning to enable women to return to work or improve their work situation. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We agree and support the position that education is the foundation of responsible citizenship, is an important factor in ensuring gender equality and empowerment of girls and is a fundamental human right and right of every child. We therefore rightly call on the Commission and the Member States to implement and improve measures to implement gender equality at all levels of the education system and to incorporate full measures to raise awareness of gender equality. In addition, Member States should promote the democratisation of education and fulfil other conditions necessary to ensure that education, whether provided in schools or other educational structures, contributes to ensuring gender equality and equal opportunities.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against because I believe that the report still contains some problematic issues that have not been resolved and the amendments proposed by my political group were not adopted. So, although I agree with the general line taken by Mr Beazley, i.e. the fact that the Commission has not yet taken a decision on this issue, i.e. that it is not a question of whether Rodrigues on the emancipation of women, I do not agree with some of the points. Furthermore, I do not agree with the competences assigned to the Member States and with the fact that the principle of subsidiarity is not respected. Although I disagree on these points, I think that the emancipation of girls through education is a very important issue that needs to be well examined in order to combat the gender gap from schools and to enable equality and full fulfilment of every woman. That is why measures are needed to ensure education for all girls, including in an environment that promotes equality and respect for the sexes.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 Education is a necessary tool and a primary resource to reduce gender inequality and discrimination and promote the social, cultural and professional empowerment of women. The education and equal training of young people is also a European value of fundamental importance in order to encourage the Union's economic prospects, and I therefore believe in the need to develop initiatives to increase the motivation and participation of women even in sectors of work traditionally dominated by a strong male presence such as science, engineering, technology, rural and craft industries.  Equality is a concept that must be taught at all different levels of training, thus promoting the abandonment of gender stereotypes and the affirmation of the fundamental right of respect towards the individual, whether it is a man or a woman. In this regard, I reiterate the importance for the States of the Union of adopting and ratifying the Istanbul Convention on the Prevention and Combating of Violence against Women and Domestic Violence, a legally binding international instrument that creates a comprehensive legal framework to protect women against all forms of violence. I voted in favour of this measure because I believe that it is appropriate to make the citizens of the European Union aware of greater respect for and full inclusion of women in the social and economic fabric.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ The report contains proposals on empowering girls through education which I voted in favour of since they seek to address the obstacles girls encounter in accessing education and in progressing towards career paths of their own choice. The proposals focus on addressing gender stereotypes and engaging education and educators in bringing about a culture change, while actually seeking to address the employment-education disparity that exists. This disparity is indicative of obstacles that women encounter in their education and career paths.  Paragraph 29 calls on Member States to consider making age-appropriate comprehensive sex and relationship education compulsory in their school curricula for primary school children. It is this element of the report which I do not support. It is important to teach children about respect for themselves, their bodies and for each other, but with young children more can be gained from being surrounded by role models who themselves value and practise respect, rights and responsibilities. This is where we are failing children since we tell them one thing and what they see is the total opposite. We need role models (teachers, practitioners, parents) and not just to address the children. Consequently, I abstained on the final vote on the report.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on empowering girls through education because access to school to girls is key to equality. To insert gender equality and sexual relations education in school curricula, while respecting national differences, is important to combat stereotypes, discrimination and violence against girls. It helps to create a culture of mutual respect, where boys and girls are aware of their full potential on an equal footing.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I supported this text which urges Member States to take measures to raise awareness of gender equality from education. Unfortunately, the final vote withdrew its call on the Commission to be involved in actions on programmes for gender equality, even though it is part of the principles of existing treaties.  However, the text is aimed at requesting resources for educational institutions and educational professionals to develop cross-cutting training and programmes in non-discrimination values that invite gender barriers and stereotypes. It also recalls the duty of States to seek public childcare networks, as well as to ensure quality public education. It also again urges the Commission to begin the EU accession procedure to the Istanbul Convention on Violence against Women. Although improveable, the text denounces that austerity measures have very negatively affected educational resources, for which strong public investment is needed to develop the programmes identified. That is why my vote has been favourable.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report since it looks towards ensuring all children, irrespective of their gender, receive the same treatment and opportunities. I believe that we should empower our children to believe that both sexes are perfectly capable of doing any job. The report makes proposals to address the gender gap found in many professions including ICT, engineering, banking and finance, among others. This report focuses on tackling homophobia and gender-based violence in schools. Our children deserve to live without fear, but they cannot do that if we do not take action.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. \u2012 The fight for gender equality must be taken by all of us as a priority, and education is an important lever, which we are obliged to use. Teacher training on gender equality, ensuring equal access to education for girls and boys, implementing measures against gender-based violence in schools, and banning the promotion of gender stereotypes in school textbooks are just some of the actions contained in this report that can support girls and women, visibly improving the condition of women in society. We must also take into account that a national education system that promotes gender equality is also a mechanism by which Member States can fight against aggression of any kind against women. Early education of children can also mean a method of preventing domestic violence and sexual assault against women, and cases such as the one in Vaslui, Romania, which has rocked an entire country, could be prevented.  I believe that we must fight for a better life for women within the Union, but also abroad, by implementing the necessary measures to ensure the promotion of gender equality in our education system.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This initiative report calls for the application of gender equality at all levels of the education system as a solution to inequalities in access and educational achievement between boys and girls. Although pursuing a goal that I share, this report is motivated by ideological objectives, the rapporteur's proposals are indeed encroaching on the competence of States in education. In the face of this controversial report which goes beyond the European Union's framework of action, I have decided to abstain in the vote, considering, however, that inequalities in the education system constitute unfair discrimination between people and against which we must fight.

name: Philippe DE BACKER
text: in writing. – I voted in favor of this report as I believe that every child has the right to the same non discriminative education. Unfortunately this is not the case everywhere, especially for girls. Here we need to improve measures to apply gender equality at all levels of the education system throughout the EU. We call for Member States to ensure that their education authorities guarantee an equal right to education for women and men by actively incorporating the principle of equal treatment into educational goals and actions, thus preventing the emergence of inequalities between women and men as a result of sexist conduct and associated social stereotyping. The Commission is urged to ensure that this recommendation be put to the national institutions responsible for implementing central, regional and local education policies, school management bodies and regional and local authorities.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing. I abstained on the vote on this resolution. The Rodrigues report is a step forward for equality between men and women, it opens up free and indiscriminate education more broadly. However, I remain convinced that in order to develop quality education, member States' competences must be respected in relation to certain issues, particularly with regard to education on ethical or sexual rights issues.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. – By regularly promoting gender mainstreaming, we recognise that girls' education is one of the most lucrative development investments. In this sense, I welcomed the report by mrs Rodrigues (Portuguese, Socialist).  The report includes a number of objectives of particular importance for the People's Party, such as inclusive and equitable high-quality education and teacher training, professional skills development to increase employment, the possibility of lifelong learning, the fight against stereotypes, digital education. We can all see that, despite the Union's strong political commitment to equality, there are still deep-seated social barriers behind gender inequality: not many girls choose science or technology courses, while social care occupations are feminist.  However, I firmly believe that, in order to achieve joint success, towards a report of fruitful and constructive value, it would have been extremely important to respect the subject of the report and not to violate the principle of subsidiarity by hiding under the umbrella of human rights. Of course, we can encourage Member States to take certain measures and actions, but education is, above all, a competence of the Member States, and we must avoid interfering, albeit with good intentions, in areas where we do not have competence. I regret that the report, despite its positive points, goes beyond its powers in several places. I therefore abstained in the vote.

name: Diane DODDS
text: in writing. ‒ It will come as no huge shock to those in the chamber that my comments on this report are based around the principle of subsidiarity. It is my view that the European Parliament should have no say on how the UK or any other country in Europe educates its young people or indeed upholds equality in the classroom.  This Parliament has for many years endured efforts to place more women on business boards or other aspects of employment and civil society without care for the principle of merit. Yes, we need more women in decision-making roles, however this should come as a consequence of empowering girls and women through personal development training and traditional means of education, not by simply placing them in spheres of authority to top up statistics. We must of course ensure that all children have equality opportunities and warrant equal treatment in the classroom, however whether this needs to come in the form of training for teachers and specific slots in school curricula is up for debate.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. The background of this report is most terrifying. We are in the face of intellectual bludgeoning and the establishment of a single thought throughout the Union. All the elements of the destruction of our societies are brought together: communitarianism, through special programmes for young Roma; Gender theory as a tool to monitor the implementation of "equality programmes" and whose compliance will even be rewarded with an award for institutions; the intrusion of LGBTI claims into schools when their first missions are to learn to read, write, count and pass on our heritage. Even more disturbing and worthy of the saddest pages of the Best of Worlds, this report proposes sexuality education from the primary classes! Apart from the fact that these issues are by no means within the competence of the Union, proving the intellectual diktat that hangs over the Member States, these demands and proposals illustrate the tragedy of a political class a thousand miles from reality and committed against our civilisation, which is why I voted against this text.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 My colleague Liliana Rodriguez's report focuses on facilitating access to education and on the differences between boys and girls, in particular in the field of education. Here education is presented as a means of cultural development and for changing gender stereotypes, a means of combating structural discrimination and enhancing girls' participation in fields such as science, technology, engineering, mathematics, culture and art and crafts. Together with my political group, I voted against as I believe that the report goes beyond the remit of the responsible parliamentary committee, proposing measures to be taken in areas that fall outside the mandate given to the EP.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Promotes the preparation of children and young people in the role of worker away from the concept of family. It also promotes the information of children from an early age in the broader concept of human sex (LGBT).

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. – By regularly promoting gender mainstreaming, we recognise that girls' education is one of the most lucrative development investments. In this sense, I welcomed the report by mrs Rodrigues (Portuguese, Socialist).  The report includes a number of objectives of particular importance for the People's Party, such as inclusive and equitable high-quality education and teacher training, professional skills development to increase employment, the possibility of lifelong learning, the fight against stereotypes, digital education. We can all see that, despite the Union's strong political commitment to equality, there are still deep-seated social barriers behind gender inequality: not many girls choose science or technology courses, while social care occupations are feminist.  However, I firmly believe that, in order to achieve joint success, towards a report of fruitful and constructive value, it would have been extremely important to respect the subject of the report and not to violate the principle of subsidiarity by hiding under the umbrella of human rights. Of course, we can encourage Member States to take certain measures and actions, but education is, above all, a competence of the Member States, and we must avoid interfering, albeit with good intentions, in areas where we do not have competence. I regret that the report, despite its positive points, goes beyond its powers in several places. I therefore abstained in the vote.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: Written. \u2012 This report contains several elements that I have doubts about and do not support. These include far-reaching wordings on what curricula should look like, something that does not belong at EUROPEAN level. Nevertheless, I chose to support the report in the final vote, because it as a whole highlights important principles and measures in the field of gender equality.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 The title of the report is misleading: as always, an indisputable title is used to fill the document with radical ideas and proposals. Once again, I condemn this shameful practice.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on empowering girls in the EU through education because it promotes the preparation of children and young people for the role of worker away from the concept of family. It also promotes information for children from an early age on the broader concept of human sex (LGBT).

name: Ashley FOX
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report because I believe it strays into areas that are not within the EU’s competence, but rather stray within the competence of Member States. I am a committed advocate of universal education, but the Commission does not have power, and should never have the power, to prescribe the contents of textbooks in the UK’s curriculum. This report does not respect the principle of subsidiarity and therefore I cannot support it.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that we have to take into account, when drafting policies and initiatives to increase for education, also the complexity of the influential factors, such as poverty and socio-economic status. Education improves economic empowerment for women and girls but only if they are able to access similar levels and types of education. Incorporating gender equality into all levels of education will have a positive outcome in promoting, among women and men, the values of justice and citizenship in both public and private spheres. I strongly agree with the necessity of conducting impact studies to provide qualitative and quantitative instruments for the assessment of this impact, and revise existing education laws in accordance with gender equality principle. I would also like to encourage the creation of an Annual European Award for Gender Equality for educational institutions which have excelled in attaining this objective.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I firmly believe that gender equality is a fundamental principle that children must learn from a young age.  It is important that Member States implement measures to achieve gender equality at all levels of the education system; incorporating a higher degree of awareness of gender issues into the training of teachers and other school staff (doctors, nurses, psychologists, social workers, educators) and that introduce mechanisms that allow the promotion, implementation, monitoring and evaluation of gender equality in all educational institutions and levels.  I also believe that it is essential that sex education be provided tailored to the age and needs of students, including awareness-raising on LGBT issues.  It is also important that States invest in educational and awareness-raising campaigns that improve career guidance for girls and boys, addressing the stereotypical picture of gender roles, as well as gender stereotypes in different careers, particularly in the field of science and new technologies, to reduce gender segregation in the labour market and strengthen women's position

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. \u2012 With this vote, Parliament is violating the principle of subsidiarity for the second time during the same plenary session. Here, too, this is a particularly important issue, such as the emancipation of girls, and we are reduced to voting on censorship of teaching materials, school texts, teacher training entrusted to 'local, regional, national and European policy-makers'. Faced with measures that are more reminiscent of the Chinese cultural revolution than our principles inspired by democracy and freedom, we have been able to vote no to this report.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP's own-initiative report on the emancipation of girls through EU education because it is based on the essential assumption that the education of girls and young women is a fundamental human right and an essential European value.  A heated debate between the different souls of civil society preceded the vote but, while respecting the diversity of thought, I felt it necessary to express my strong support for the resolution.  I believe that the transformation of society also involves the independence and cultural and professional self-determination of women, helping to develop a common sense of respect and responsibility. I firmly believe that school, education and learning are a unique tool to enable women to participate in the socio-economic development of the community and to combat violence, bullying and discrimination. I therefore hope for a proactive approach so that school curricula focus on civic, relational and gender education.  I agree with the call for Member States to promote policies for universal, inclusive and free education, accompanied by ambitious investments in public education and training that eliminate gender discrimination, to combat early school leaving of girls and to direct them to the world of work.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. Education is the exclusive responsibility of the Member States. It would be too far to prescribe the content of the curriculum to them, especially if they constitute an ideological interference with the right of parents to educate their children.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ Some may be surprised to learn that many of the first IT programmers during the early 20th century were female. As were trailblazers in medicine and many other fields.  Yet female role models are easily forgotten, and as a result girls remain severely underrepresented in science, maths and technology. Not because of a lack of talent. Because of a lack of the right tools and context.  This is not just these girls' loss. It is ours. That is why I supported the Rodrigues report and call on the commission to:  - widen participation of women in STEM - promote equal representation among education leaders and managers  - ask Member States to provide our youngsters gender-sensitive sex and relationships education appropriate for their age  Of course all of this will require governments to reverse austerity policies that have meant severe cuts for the education budget.  I ask them to listen to the words of Malala Yousufzai, Nobel peace prize winner and a student in my region of the West Midlands, who calls on leaders to finally get their priorities straight ... and invest in education.

name: Juan Carlos GIRAUTA VIDAL
text: in writing. Education can transform a society and contribute to social, economic, political equality. To do this, it is necessary for all citizens to have access to quality education. However, thirty million girls of primary school age worldwide are excluded from the education system. From the European Parliament we want to call for all States to implement measures aimed at achieving gender equality at all levels of the education system. In addition, we want to emphasize the potential of education to defend gender equality and address the fight against gender-based violence.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: in writing. – The UK delegation expects nothing less than full and equal opportunity for both girls and boys to education in school. Girls and boys should have equal access to good primary and secondary school teachers and opportunities to study a variety of subjects regardless of sex. We recognise that bullying and homophobia are problems facing young people at school, and national governments must work with schools and teachers to stop all forms of bullying, harassment and violence at school and we have supported those relevant paragraphs.  The UK delegation is however disappointed that this report goes far beyond the remit and responsibilities of and the European Parliament, particularly; EU interference in teacher training, educational pedagogy, how schools are funded, the school curricula and sex education and "sexist distortions" in textbooks and teaching materials.  The UK delegation is also concerned that this report calls for the EU to harmonise national qualification rules for professionals coming from outside of the EU and calls on Member States to provide free education services to migrant women; whilst are important issues they are not within the legal competencies of the EU. For these reasons the UK delegation was unable to support this report.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. I objected to the Rodrigues report on the emancipation of young girls through education for several reasons: on form, the European institutions are not competent in education, whether school or family. However, this report is riddled with unacceptable recommendations such as sex education from primary school and awakening to LGBTI culture; on the objective, this report has no other intention but to favour Roma, LGBTI and migrant minorities by exposing our children to an anti-family ideology, all under the strict supervision of gender experts.  I had tabled an alternative resolution, supported by several family advocacy associations. This amendment was a reminder of the founding subsidiarity of the treaties and all enL elected representatives supported it. On the other hand, the elected Socialists and Republicans supported this report by ignoring the concerns of the French.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: In writing. Not a session without its "gender" report. The worst this time is the Rodrigues report. I have had the opportunity to say this dozens of times here: neither the family nor the educational programmes are the responsibility of the European Union. Even less so when it comes to organizing propaganda and skull stuffing of our children from an early age, in the name of smoky theories and under pressure from ultra-minority lobbies. Like its predecessors, the Rodrigues report itself conveys the worst stereotypes about women, eternal victims, eternally dominated, eternally discriminated against a macho society perpetuating outdated patterns. Are we talking about the plight of women in Daesh-dominated areas? In Saudi Arabia? No, we are talking about the European Union as a whole in 2015. I advise Mrs Rodrigues, in order to get a clear picture of the real causes of the most problematic educational situations in Europe, to go and take a course on gender and tolerance in a college in a sensitive area of France. Failing to leave it intact psychologically and physically, perhaps this would put her back in touch with the reality that thousands of teachers and their female students experience on a daily basis. And real issues.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. The vote cast has been in favour of this Report. It highlights its impact on free public education for all, LGTBI rights and the right to access to education, regardless of place of residence. Although some issues related to the push for self-defense training plans for women are not incorporated, which would increase their level of advocacy, we still believe it is to take a step further in the right direction. Some interesting measures that we support with our vote are: -Fight against gender stereotypes that promote advertising and the media. -Promote professional and vocational orientation outside of gender stereotypes. -Instill the values of equality and human rights. -Educate children in mental health, sexuality and healthy relationships to help them make well-informed decisions. -Reduce maternal-child mortality and prevent the prevalence of sexually transmitted diseases. -Promote the knowledge and control of young women and girls on their bodies. -Combat physical aggression, discrimination and stigma based on sexual orientation, gender identity and individual expression. Fight bullying.

name: Sylvie GOULARD
text: In writing. Discrimination against women unfortunately remains a reality. While equality is enshrined in law, implementation is slow to come: equal work, wages still diverge, many girls are discouraged from embarking on certain careers, and domestic work still weighs heavily on women. It is a question of law and an economic issue: some of the available talent is wasted. That is why I voted in favour of the Rodrigues report on the emancipation of girls through education in the European Union. Although one might think of the term "gender", the principle of gender equality deserves to be reaffirmed: in 2015, it is even high time that it became effective. By combating stereotypes and archaisms, education is one of the tools to achieve this.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I, and Labour MEPs, voted for this report for a simple reason: women and girls have a right to an education. This report makes it clear that education, as a major aspect of socialisation, radically affects our perception of women and girls. Not only do schools play a part in the shaping of our perception of gender, but also contribute massively to attitudes, behaviour, choices and ambitions. If we are to empower girls to achieve their true potential, we must create the appropriate learning environments where attitudes towards gender are firmly challenged – from stereotypes to discrimination. All children must be able to thrive. The need to tackle these inequalities is an urgent one. We must present practical solutions to deal with the very real problems women and girls are facing.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: In writing. While 13 million women are victims of physical violence in the EU, the European Parliament cannot remain silent on this painful reality. That is why I have spoken in favour of Mr Rodrigues' initiative report on the emancipation of girls through education in the EU, which calls on the European Commission to launch the procedure for EU accession to the Istanbul Convention on the Prevention and Combating Violence against Women and Domestic Violence as soon as possible.  It is about saying that we must join forces and means to combat gender stereotypes that have a negative impact on the personal and professional development of children. It is also about encouraging girls and boys to take an equal interest in all school subjects beyond gender stereotypes; Teach equality, dignity and self-esteem to train individuals capable of self-employment; Educate boys and girls about relationship, emotional and sexual life through scientifically based and age-appropriate programs; or promote the emancipation of girls in accordance with the principle of free disposition of their bodies.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour on the report on empowering girls through education in the EU. There is a considerable issue with the gender inequality; while women are more likely to have a higher education degree, they are still under-represented in science, research studies. As the EU is promoting the gender equality within the employment, we should also take into account the importance of education and the situation of gender gap there. It is important to encourage and promote gender equality in education, raise girls’ profiles and skills and ultimately improve their personal and professional development.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I firmly believe that gender equality is a fundamental principle that children must learn from a young age.  It is important that Member States implement measures to achieve gender equality at all levels of the education system; incorporating a higher degree of awareness of gender issues into the training of teachers and other school staff (doctors, nurses, psychologists, social workers, educators) and that introduce mechanisms that allow the promotion, implementation, monitoring and evaluation of gender equality in all educational institutions and levels.  I also believe that it is essential that sex education be provided tailored to the age and needs of students, including awareness-raising on LGBT issues.  It is also important that States invest in educational and awareness-raising campaigns that improve career guidance for girls and boys, addressing the stereotypical image of gender roles, as well as gender stereotypes in different careers, particularly in the field of science and new technologies, to reduce gender segregation in the labour market and strengthen women's position.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 By regularly promoting gender mainstreaming, we recognise that girls' education is one of the most lucrative development investments. In this sense, I welcomed Mrs Rodrigues's report.  The report includes a number of objectives of particular importance for the People's Party, such as inclusive and equitable high-quality education and teacher training, professional skills development to increase employment, the possibility of lifelong learning, the fight against stereotypes, digital education. We can all see that, despite the Union's strong political commitment to equality, there are still deep-seated social barriers behind gender inequality: not many girls choose science or technology courses, while social care occupations are feminist.  However, I firmly believe that, in order to achieve joint success, towards a report of fruitful and constructive value, it would have been extremely important to respect the subject of the report and not to violate the principle of subsidiarity by hiding under the umbrella of human rights. Of course, we can encourage Member States to take certain measures and actions, but education is, above all, a competence of the Member States, and we must avoid interfering, albeit with good intentions, in areas where we do not have competence. I regret that the report, despite its positive points, goes beyond its powers in several places.
