I therefore abstained in the vote, in accordance with the position of the Hungarian delegation to the People's Party.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. The report, which is being voted on today in the European Parliament, seeks to require states to implement gender equality measures at all levels of education. This would mean fully integrating appropriate measures into teacher training, introducing monitoring mechanisms on this, working directly with families and even making gender issues a topic in sport and leisure activities. As much as we affirm women's equality, these plans go far beyond the mark. Moreover, they blatantly exceed the EU's powers. Education policy falls within the competence of the individual EU Member States! In Germany, education policy is even a matter for the Länder. In view of this, it seems absurd for the EU to want to adopt comprehensive rules in the field of education. I therefore reject this report. Incidentally , and this is my ceterum censeo – I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: Mary HONEYBALL
text: in writing. ‒ Education is a transformative tool for challenging gender stereotypes, empowering women and girls and is a driver of the economy. Schools are fundamental in shaping attitudes, choices and ambitions. We need to create learning environments where gender stereotypes are challenged, where no child is discriminated against, and where all children can thrive.  Women are still under-represented in senior leadership positions whilst being over-represented in early years and primary education. As a result, girls often lack role models, particularly in science and technology subjects. I voted for this report because it rightly identifies the urgent need to tackle these inequalities and presents practical solutions.

name: Mike HOOKEM
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report as it calls for gender quotas on education bodies – you don’t fight discrimination with more discrimination. It called for compulsory sex and relationship classes and for the EU Commission to conduct propaganda campaigns in our schools. The EU Commission has no right to interfere with education – both in principle, as it is an unelected and unaccountable body, and in practice, as it is not granted the competence in the treaties.

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. ‒ This report correctly notes the importance of state-funded public education in the empowerment of girls and young women.  The Scottish Government is committed to free education at primary, secondary and tertiary levels and my part will continue to oppose unionist efforts to reduce state funding.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. The vote cast has been in favour of this Report. It highlights its impact on free public education for all, LGTBI rights and the right to access to education, regardless of place of residence. Although some issues related to the push for self-defense training plans for women are not incorporated, which would increase their level of advocacy, we still believe it is to take a step further in the right direction. Some interesting measures that we support with our vote are: -Fight against gender stereotypes that promote advertising and the media. -Promote professional and vocational orientation outside of gender stereotypes. -Instill the values of equality and human rights. -Educate children in mental health, sexuality and healthy relationships to help them make well-informed decisions. -Reduce maternal-child mortality and prevent the prevalence of sexually transmitted diseases. -Promote the knowledge and control of young women and girls on their bodies. -Combat physical aggression, discrimination and stigma based on sexual orientation, gender identity and individual expression. Fight bullying.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a report on the empowerment of girls through education in the EU, as the education and training of girls and women are key factors for their empowerment at the social, cultural and professional level, as well as for the full enjoyment of all other social, economic, cultural and political rights and ultimately for preventing violence against women and girls.  In this regard, I support the general recommendations, as well as those specific recommendations concerning the education of this very well prepared and comprehensive report. Recommendations can contribute to further improving gender equality and respect for human rights. Particular attention should be paid to the implementation and monitoring of the measures proposed.  I agree that on the issue of education, which in some Countries of the Union is underestimated in its importance, independent bodies should monitor and assess progress and it is necessary to regularly inform local, regional, national and European policy makers about all measures taken and progress made in this area.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. I voted against the Rodrigues report, which aims to subject girls and young people in Europe to the eu's dominant ideology through school. In particular, this text aims to make "an education compulsory [...] sexuality [ ...] for all primary school pupils" (from the age of 6). These are positions hostile to the interests of our youth and society as a whole. They are as illegitimate as they are harmful. On the one hand, they run counter to the principle of subsidiarity and on the other hand undermine the traditional values on which centuries have been built during our civilization.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Liliana Rodrigues' report on the emancipation of young girls through education. If the report suffered from certain editorial clumsiness, the general objective of the text, namely the fight against stereotypes and better gender equality through education, could only garner my support. The report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. Although I am personally touched by this issue and everything must be done to promote girls in school, I believe that subsidiarity in the field of education should be taken into account. That is why I am opposed to this report.

name: Rikke-Louise KARLSSON
text: Written. I voted against the report 'Strengthening the position of girls in the EU through education' because education is an area where decisions should be left solely in the Member States. Article 165 does not allow the European Union – and even less the FEMM Committee – to interfere in the training programmes of the Member States.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report, as it sends a very clear message that education will play a critical role in making gender equality a reality. Schools are fundamental in shaping attitudes, choices and ambitions. If we are to empower girls to achieve their true potential, we must create learning environments where gender stereotypes are challenged, where no child is discriminated against, and where all children can thrive.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Writing. The Rodriguez report, which is being voted on today in the European Parliament, seeks to require states to implement gender equality measures at all levels of education. This would mean fully integrating appropriate measures into teacher training, introducing monitoring mechanisms on this, working directly with families and even making gender issues a topic in sport and leisure activities. As much as we affirm women's equality, these plans go far beyond the mark. Moreover, they blatantly exceed the EU's powers. Education policy falls within the competence of the individual EU Member States! In Germany, education policy is even a matter for the Länder. In view of this, it seems absurd for the EU to want to adopt comprehensive rules in the field of education. The principle of subsidiarity must also be respected with regard to equality between men and women. Article 3 of the Basic Law obliges the German State to actively work towards the elimination of existing disadvantages. There is no need for more requirements. I therefore reject this report.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on increasing the use of girls through education in the EU may at first glance seem gender-oriented, but it was not, which is why I was happy to support it. In the text, we come across perhaps banal but important statements that all future governments should carus into their memory. For example, the report mentions that education can transform society and contribute to social, economic, political and gender equality, and that only states can provide free compulsory general education, which is essential to ensure equal opportunities for both sexes. However, there is also criticism of the policy of budget cuts in education, which are largely the result of austerity policies promoted by the EU that threaten free high-quality public education and thus contribute to widening inequalities. Given that poverty has a major impact on equal access to education due to direct and indirect expenditure linked to children's schooling, and that access to education, and especially higher education, is particularly difficult for young people from low-income families, I hope that governments will stick to the fact that quality public education should be free and accessible to all children without any discrimination and regardless of residence status.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report as a whole, although I do not agree with certain parts that went beyond the main issue. It points out that although significant progress has been made in terms of access to education, gender differences are still present. Training is an important tool for challenging inequalities and a driving force for the economy, and I believe that it must be guaranteed at all levels of the education system.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Rodrigues report entitled 'Emancipation of girls through education in the European Union'. Indeed, without denying the role of primary educator of children for parents, I think it is important to point out that investing in education, as this report suggests, is probably the best way to promote equality between men and women whether in schools, in the professional world or in the private sphere. On the other hand, like my colleagues in the EPP Group, I did not support through my votes the ideological delusions of the left which tended to deny The Member States the exercise of powers which are theirs by law, under the principle of subsidiarity. However, such considerations must not cloud our judgment and deviate from our creed: fighting discrimination and for gender equality is a fundamental commitment of the EPP Group, as it is a question of promoting respect for fundamental rights and European values enshrined in the founding project from the outset.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution on the emancipation of girls through education in the European Union, because education is not the competence of the European Union. This dirigiste resolution does not respect the principle of subsidiarity. The ENL Group has tabled an alternative resolution in the form of an amendment referring the Commission, Parliament and the FEMM Committee to their treaty powers, but unfortunately this argument has not been adopted.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this text because it is a delusional plea for the integration of "gender issues" in textbooks, and for compulsory sexuality education in primary schools! Furthermore, I would remind you that education is not the competence of the European Union.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I supported this text which urges Member States to take measures to raise awareness of gender equality from education. Unfortunately, the final vote withdrew its call on the Commission to be involved in actions on programmes for gender equality, even though it is part of the principles of existing treaties.  However, the text is aimed at requesting resources for educational institutions and educational professionals to develop cross-cutting training and programmes in non-discrimination values that invite gender barriers and stereotypes. It also recalls the duty of States to seek public childcare networks, as well as to ensure quality public education. It also again urges the Commission to begin the EU accession procedure to the Istanbul Convention on Violence against Women. Although improveable, the text denounces that austerity measures have very negatively affected educational resources, for which strong public investment is needed to develop the programmes identified. That is why my vote has been favourable.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. The Rodriguez report calls for action on gender equality to be implemented at all levels of education. This would mean fully integrating such measures into teacher training and monitoring their implementation. As much as I am in a case of women's equality, these plans go far beyond the mark. Moreover, they blatantly exceed the EU's powers. Education policy falls within the competence of individual EU Member States. In Germany, education policy is even a matter for the Länder. In view of this, it seems absurd for the EU to want to adopt comprehensive rules in the field of education. The principle of subsidiarity must also be respected with regard to equality between men and women. Article 3 of the Basic Law obliges the German State to actively work towards the elimination of existing disadvantages. There is no need for more requirements. I therefore reject this report.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. Gender alarmism is typical Eurosmysl. I was elected as a Member of the European Parliament also to speak out against such resolutions. The text calls for further commission activity on this matter.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Education and training of girls and women are an important European value, a fundamental human right and a key factor for empowering girls and women at social, cultural and professional levels. Society can be transformed by education, which contributes to the full enjoyment of all other social, economic, cultural and political rights and ultimately prevents violence against women and girls. Education must serve girls to develop into conscious, balanced people who respect other people and who have the capacity to empathy and respect each other, it should be encouraged to prevent discrimination and to reject gender roles during the socialisation phases during childhood and adolescence. While I encourage gender equality, I disagree with the report because it does not respect the principle of subsidiarity as a fundamental principle of the European Union. Likewise, the report violates important international treaties, such as the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms and, ultimately, does not fall under femm's jurisdiction.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 Girls still cannot get equal education with young people. The problem exists. We need to help not only make education more accessible to girls at all levels, but also to integrate them well into the EU labour market and to develop their careers. I support this orientation, I voted in favour.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing ‒ I have no doubt about the importance of eduing citizens in the EU. The education of girls in particular certainly requires special attention. The lack of education often has consequences in their worse social and social status. However, the present report encroaches on the exclusive competences of the Member States. It also addresses the issues of educate and educate children in schools, the inclusion of LGBTI issues in educational curricula and other sensitive issues that member countries have to solve in the light of their conditions, development, culture and history. This requires mutual tolerance, respect and understanding of EU countries.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the empowerment of girls in the EU through education, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 8/9/2015. Furthermore, I would point out that all Member States should contribute to the democratisation of education in order to ensure that gender equality is promoted in this way and that men and women are given equal opportunities to participate in social and economic development. In addition, awareness-raising campaigns on discrimination against women should be organised and career guidance services should be improved in order to reduce discrimination on the labour market as well. In all teaching programmes, gender rights education should be included. Any awareness-raising initiative on the issue of gender discrimination should be strengthened. Education should break down gender stereotypes and promote women in all workplaces in order to strengthen society in general.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report which calls on the Commission and the Member States to implement and improve measures to apply gender equality at all levels of the education system, and to fully integrate improving awareness of gender issues into teacher training, but also for all categories of school professionals, e.g. school doctors, nurses, psychologists, social workers and pedagogues, as well as to ensure the creation of mechanisms throughout the education system to facilitate the promotion, implementation, monitoring and evaluation of gender equality in educational institutions.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I am opposed to my colleague's resolution on the emancipation of girls through education in the European Union, as this report highlights issues that are the exclusive competence of each individual Member State of the European Union.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because this report underlines the importance of education as a means of achieving gender equality, not only through access to education itself but also through the culture and curriculum itself and school materials. Despite all the progress that has been made in recent years, the differences between boys and girls are still quite present, and it is undeniable that education should be a key tool for questioning and changing these stereotypes with all the future advantages of this change. The report also calls for gender equality measures to be implemented at all levels of the education system, as well as in teacher training, as well as monitoring and evaluations of gender equality in educational institutions. The report also recommends that Member States integrate sex education into their curricula as compulsory. And it stresses that programmes, both formal and informal education, should address and combat gender-based violence and discrimination, coercy, harassment, homophobia and transphobia in all its forms, including cyberbulling or online harassment.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. The European Parliament should strictly abide by the principles of subsidiarity and the sovereignty of the Member States in the field of education and not, under any pretext, interfere in school programmes with questionable rules on early sexualisation or, more broadly, in all educational activities, whether at school or in the family, or in cultural and sporting activities. This report must therefore be rejected.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. This is a report that paints a good picture of the impact of gender stereotypes on the orientation of young girls and proposes a number of solutions to enable their emancipation. First of all, it stresses "universal, compulsory and free education, an essential condition for ensuring equal opportunities for men and women", especially from disadvantaged backgrounds. He denounces budget cuts and austerity policies. The report reiterates the need to include issues of gender equality, sexuality and gender stereotypes in school curricula, which are relayed in particular by the media and advertising. It also calls for highlighting the role of women in the history and fight against LGBTI discrimination. Women should be valued and promoted access in male-dominated professions and fields such as science, engineering, technology and mathematics. In order to help reconcile family and work life, the report focuses in particular on the development of public childcare networks. I'm obviously voting for it.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. This report aims to subject girls and young people in Europe to the EU's dominant ideology through school. In particular, this text aims to make "an education compulsory [...] sexuality [ ...] for all primary school pupils" (from the age of 6). These are positions hostile to the interests of our youth and society as a whole. They are as illegitimate as they are harmful. On the one hand, they run counter to the principle of subsidiarity and on the other hand undermine the traditional values on which centuries have been built during our civilization. I voted against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the empowerment of young people through education in the European Union. In fact, youth education is one of the most important factors for a country's prosperity and growth. However, I believe that this motion for a resolution does not clarify the importance and role of young people's education in building active citizenship with great impact on the economic, cultural and social development of a country. The proposal put forward by the rapporteur mirrors a confusion of matters, models and data that do not comply with the design of a motion for a resolution by the European Parliament.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: Written. – Gender stereotypes. They still exist. As a result, very specific and limited roles are still attributed to men and women. For example, the labour market still disintegrates into typically male and typically female occupations. Parents, friends and the social environment in which one grows up, but also education and the media play a crucial role in the transmission, dissemination or breaking of these traditional role patterns. In this way, girls are still driven to typically female professions and find it difficult to find their way into the so-called male professions.  Education can play a crucial role in removing barriers to young people's personal development and empathy for mutual respect. The school has an important role to play in empowering girls in the social, cultural and professional field. In order to make progress, this process must start very early in school. In the classroom, the debate on choice of study and professional orientation must be stimulated. Consistent investment in the development of information campaigns and learning programmes to combat gender segregation in the labour market is recommended to increase the number of students and graduate women in scientific and technological fields.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing ‒ The Rodrigues Own-Initiative Report on empowering girls in the EU through education in an unprecedented manner and grossly exceeds the EU's clearly defined competences and encroaches on areas that only matter to member states. In addition to commendable efforts to ensure girls' access to girls, it calls for and calls on EU Member States to recognise compulsory gender-sensitive sex education and so-called sexual and reproductive rights as fundamental human rights of self-determination, including the controversial claim to abortion. It also calls on the Commission to draw up a regulation on the mutual recognition of homosexual marriage, although there is fierce controversy in this area.  I strongly reject the report presented and such European attempts to curse the rights of the Member States and interfere in the private and family affairs of their citizens.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly believe that every girl and woman has right to education and therefore I have voted in favour of the report in order to empower girls through education in the EU

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 Despite numerous legal declarations and political declarations on equal opportunities for women, gender equality has many shortcomings throughout the European Union and especially in some of its Member States. I am convinced, as the report emphasises, that the fight against this must start in education. On the one hand, we need an education system that compensates for the social disadvantage suffered by women in almost all aspects of life, and on the other hand, education must take the fight against the social prejudices that primarily hinder women's well-being. The report details all this and I was therefore pleased to vote for it.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. I believe in the importance of gender equality and the importance of promoting citizenship based on the principle of equality between men and women, boys and girls.  However, I believe that this report presents an ideological and imposing programme that goes far beyond the competence of the Union, intervening in national matters, of each Member State.  For the reasons set out above I abstained in the final vote.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This report on the emancipation of girls through education in the EU is mainly aimed at conditioning young people in EU Member States to accept minorities through the school system.  It proposes, among other things, to develop specific programmes for Roma girls, to make sexuality education compulsory for all pupils from primary school on, to include objective information on LGBTI issues in school curricula...  This text has the merit of revealing (unbeknownst to him) the problems posed by the integration of minorities as a result of the mass immigration suffered by European countries. But rather than advocating assimilation, this text prefers to "educate" "native populations" by asking them to be tolerant.  Finally, education is not under the EU's jurisdiction, and I voted against it.

name: Clare MOODY
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this incredibly important report as a step towards abolishing gender stereotypes and achieving gender equality. It focuses on using the educational system, including teacher training, to advocate respect, equality and self-confidence to young girls so that they can feel empowered. This in turn helps to bridge the barriers faced in their later, professional lives and achieve the bigger picture of gender equality.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ This report sends a very clear message that education will play a critical role in making gender equality a reality. Schools are fundamental in shaping attitudes, choices and ambitions. If we are to empower girls to achieve their true potential, we must create learning environments where gender stereotypes are challenged, where no child is discriminated against, and where all children can thrive. Women are still under-represented in senior leadership and decision making positions whilst being over-represented in early years and primary education. As a result, girls often lack role models, particularly in science and technology subjects. I voted for this report because it rightly identifies the urgent need to tackle these inequalities and presents practical solutions.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the emancipation of young girls in the European Union. This text reminds us that education is a key tool in combating stereotypes and making progress towards better gender equality, which I support. In particular, it proposes measures to combat violence against women and reduce inequalities in education. Of the 17% of adults in the world who cannot read or write, two-thirds are women.

name: Luigi MORGANO
text: in writing. \u2012 It is absolutely right to promote the emancipation of girls in the European Union through proper education. It is a moral imperative, even before it is legal, to combat violence against women, by all means, and to eradicate gender stereotypes.  Despite these deep convictions, I voted against the Rodrigues report. I believe, in fact, that we can achieve these objectives of civilisation without implementing what is called for in this resolution: the obligation to adopt in all schools of all bodies and grades, starting from primary school, school curricula and teaching materials on gender identity, as well as an education in sexuality and an unspecified awareness of one's body, on the basis of the principles of the concept of gender that has been introduced by the Istanbul Convention at international legal level. The emancipation of girls in the EU, which is now 60% of higher graduates, is not achieved through the establishment of new 'independent' supervisory bodies called upon to assess the work of teachers following the adoption of the policies set out in this text, but through education against stereotypes that starts primarily from families, as well as by carrying out concrete support services for them, such as crèches and after-school , in order to ensure that women in the Union can calmly reconcile family and professional life.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: In writing. I voted in favour of Liliana Rodrigues' report, despite some imperfections in the content of this text, on which I have decided to vote against it. The Rodrigues report points out that despite significant progress in equal access to education and success, differences remain between boys and girls. Education should be seen as a means of correcting gender inequalities and gender stereotypes, a tool for empowering girls and women, and a driving force for the economy. The report calls for the application of gender equality at all levels of the education system.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome this resolution which focuses our attention on a key issue in the fight against gender inequality: education. In many respects, it is - in fact - at this level that we must act as a matter of priority in order to change the current situation of inequality in a lasting way, with a medium- to long-term perspective of future generations. In particular, the text we have voted on addresses two important perspectives: on the one hand, the establishment of a specific 'gender education' and a more general gender perspective throughout the teaching offer. This translates into an education in respect for the other and a particular attention to the fact that teaching materials and programs do not support, strengthen or simply "betray" gender stereotypes typical of our society. On the other hand, particular attention is given to bringing young girls closer to scientific subjects (so-called STEM), necessary background for the choice of professional paths traditionally considered male, such as engineering and ICT-related professions. We believe that action is urgently needed, in cooperation between the European Union and the Member States, on this issue and we hope that this can be included in the new Gender Action Plan announced by the European Commission last year.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on the emancipation of girls through education in the European Union is certainly an important leap forward in terms of emancipation in combating gender inequalities, the integration of equality at all levels and in all aspects of the education system into the social environment. Given that violence against women is still the main obstacle to equality between men and women, I believe that the teaching of respect in schools is essential to improve the conditions of women. On the other hand, I do not consider it necessary to include thematic issues based on sexual orientation and gender identity within school curricula. Instead, support desks should be set up in educational institutions. The vote on the report is therefore against.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 It is well known that bloody-handed systems are the biggest opponents of educated girls. Unfortunately, they don't shy away from any means of preventing girls from getting a book. Fortunately, girls born in the UNION do not have to fear what happened to Mala, for example. It is natural for them to go to school, and in theory they have every chance of benefiting from the education system and, consequently, from the labour market according to their abilities. Theoretically. In practice, however, the numbers disprove this. Real gender equality can only be achieved in society through the reform of the education system. This is the primary ground for overcoming stereotypes. The goal is supposed to be clear to all of us. That is why I find the repeated mixing of conversal conscientious and ethical issues outrageous. This is not a forum where we have to deal with teachers' beliefs or personal lives. Nor is it where we have to fight the symbolic battles for separation of state and church. It is time that our education aims at real equality, combating poverty and ending violence against women.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report that should develop and reinforce national regulations with a view to countering the negative influence of stereotyped gender roles.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the empowerment of girls through education in the EU in my vote, because I believe that education remains the most effective weapon in the fight against discrimination and stereotypes. If we want a world where gender discrimination is a thing of the past, we must treat the disease at source, where this discrimination begins, that is, in schools. Our children must be educated in the spirit of gender equality, they must learn about people's fundamental rights and freedoms, and they must be accustomed to rejecting and not accepting different treatment between women and men. Education underpins the evolution of our society and I am convinced that only through education can we change some harmful behaviors with ancient roots in our history.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. This report is an attack on parental education and the design of the education system in the Member States. The report defines the empowerment of girls through education in the European Union. It is also a clear violation of the principles of subsidiarity and of limited individual competence, and the European Union is trying to dictate to the Member States how to organise their curricula, teaching materials and the training of their teachers. In addition, children already of primary school age are to be burdened with sensitive topics such as sexuality in general and manipulated or unsettled by various transgender and intersexual ideologies. On the basis of these worrying facts, I have spoken out against this report.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. I voted for this resolution because I agree with the need to fight, through education, against gender inequalities. I believe that it is right to promote within the Member States the paramount importance of ensuring universal, compulsory and free education. This must involve the establishment of quality public education as a universal necessity. As this report denounces, I regret the cuts in education budgets, which contribute to the increase in inequality.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. I consider it important to ensure equal opportunities at all levels of education. The report foresees a variety of ways to do this, including the inclusion of LGBT people, anti-violence and discrimination issues in the education programme.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to vote in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the emancipation of girls through education in the EU. Firstly, I believe that education is an important instrument for helping women to participate fully in social and economic development; lifelong learning measures are essential to provide skills for women and enable them to enter the world of work or to improve employment, their income and working conditions.  In addition, I believe that particular attention should be paid to gender equality in the content of school curricula and school planning, as well as to the need to assess the role of women in school curricula in the different disciplines, underlining their role in the subjects taught.  Finally, I strongly believe in the transformative potential of education in supporting the cause of gender equality; recognise that formal and informal education programmes must address and combat gender-based violence, gender discrimination, harassment, homophobia in all its forms, including forms of cyberbullying or online harassment; education for gender equality and against gender-based violence depends on safe and violence-free school environments.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The European Parliamentary Group of the Jrc voted against the report "Empowering girls in the EU through education", as it reflects the EU's hostile to the needs of young people and women in education policy. It conceals the core of women's inequality in exploitative societies and the fact that the conditions for women's participation in education, production are determined by the interests of capitalists, presenting solutions supposedly for women's equality, through the distorting lens of the interests, competitiveness and profitability of enterprises. In the report, the acute problems faced by schoolgirls are turning into 'rails' on which the EU strategy, 'their lifelong exploitation', is being promoted more rapidly for the benefit of monopolies. The report's proposals support and broaden the EU's positions on education, which prepares, "educates" young girls to accept the working jungle, the pursuit of "skills" in informal education, mobility from profession to profession and from country to country. The report promotes the evaluation of educational institutions and so-called "entrepreneurship" education. Young girls, in the name of the falsified policy of gender equality, are called upon to accept "new discrimination" at the expense of social recognition of motherhood and their particular biological needs.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report as it calls for gender quotas on education bodies – you don’t fight discrimination with more discrimination. It called for compulsory sex and relationship classes and for the EU Commission to conduct propaganda campaigns in our schools. The EU Commission has no right to interfere with education, both in principle as it is an unelected and unaccountable body, but also in practice as it is not granted the competence in the treaties.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 As has already been said on other occasions, I repeat today with my vote in favour of the importance of education for gender equality and above all the fundamental role that schools and institutions must all play in combating any gender inequality.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – We live in a modern world, and in the modern world everyone is equal, regardless of gender, age, religion and ethnicity. I supported the report on the emancipation of women through education because the situation of discrimination against women is inevitably progressing, but it still exists. We need to take measures to make this process more intensive and to guarantee young women a level playing field and a chance for economic and social independence. It is unacceptable that young women of the European Union face stereotypical barriers to their careers.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: in writing. ‒ Education is a shared competence of the EU, and as such should only be influencing Member States where it can improve best practice. Touching a very important topic, the Rodrigues report mostly promotes gender ideology, which would strip families of their parenting role as a child’s chief educator. It calls for mandated comprehensive sexual education in primary and secondary schooling, oversight and monitoring by the Commission of gender equality in teaching, teachers and curricula. Let us let girls be girls and focus on education to allow their talents flourish. I supported Amendment 1, which proposed an alternative resolution, emphasising subsidiarity principles.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This report is not lacking in paradoxes: it wants the European Union to be concerned with improving the education of girls in its Member States when, on the one hand, girls are already more educated on average than boys and have fewer difficulties in schooling and, on the other hand, education is not the responsibility of the Union. It is therefore a matter of violating the sovereignty of states and the principle of subsidiarity to solve a problem that simply does not exist. The issue of illiteracy, which affects boys much more than girls, seems to me to be of far greater urgency, and I do not think it is by multiplying the courses on the concept of gender that it will be addressed. I therefore vote against this text.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ I support the report on the empowerment of girls through education in the European Union, which mainly deals with the devastating fact that as many as 30 million primary school girls worldwide are outside the education system. As many as 17% of adults in the world, among them two-thirds of women, cannot read or write.  Education is a prerequisite for children to develop into conscious people who respect others and a means of preventing discrimination, aggression and bullying. In order to overcome this situation, a number of positive measures are proposed that would be achieved through European funds and programmes. Education is also a prerequisite for gender equality, because statistics show that unschooling girls are more exposed to domestic violence, but also less inclined to stand up for themselves and their rights, which introduces us to a vicious cycle of discrimination that is repeated from generation to generation.  I support the thesis that education is the foundation of responsible citizenship that guarantees gender equality and girls' empowerment, and most importantly: the human right and the right of every child that should be free and accessible to all children without discrimination, regardless of their residence status.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: in writing. ‒ I am proud of the vote in Parliament on the report on empowering girls though education in the EU. Gender inequality is a significant hurdle that we must overcome. Unfortunately, this inequality starts at a very young age. I feel that measures to create gender equality need to be applied at all levels of the education system. In addition, these systems must foster a spirit of tolerance, and genuine equality. I also share the view that we should have equal gender representation in leadership in organisations that are responsible for education, especially those in the fields of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM ) so as to provide role models for our youth. It is time that we rid our system of gender stereotypes and created an open, gender-equal education system, so that this sentiment can permeate to the rest of society.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 The Rodrigues report stresses that school education must be seen as a tool for challenging inequalities between girls and boys and all gender stereotypes. The report hopes that gender equality will be applied at all levels of the education system. The resolution would like to require all EU Member States to introduce gender education in order to eliminate gender stereotypes, on the basis of considerations that appear misleading and contradicted by the facts. I believe that in this type of subject, which is so sensitive to a large part of European public opinion, Parliament must not go beyond common sense by supporting positions that could be misunderstood and exploited by those who wish to use school to enforce controversial personal convictions. That is why I have chosen to vote against.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The report goes far beyond the re-election of the FEMM Committee. The title of the report indicates that it concerns education, an area in which the European Parliament does not have the necessary powers; in addition, the report recommended changes to curricula in the Member States. The report also calls on the Commission to initiate the eu's process of acceding to the Istanbul Convention. Member States have also been called upon to do so. It is for these reasons that I could not support the report.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. Today, there are still some disparities within the Union regarding the integration of girls into the education and university systems. Some groups of girls are still discriminated against and do not have the same access to education as young boys. The European Parliament has adopted a report observing the progress to be made towards the emancipation of young people through education. I wished to abstain on this report because I believe that the competences concerned fall under the principle of subsidiarity and fall more within the competence of the Member States.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 This Resolution of the European Parliament focuses on the decision-making role of education and its enabling dimension, which actually creates a level playing field for young women. Education has an essential role to play in the future course of professional careers and in the success of socio-economic integration, in parity status with men. In the light of the provisions and supported by the opinion of the European Parliament's Committee on Culture and Education, the rapporteur calls on decision-makers in education policies in the Commission and in the Member States to go beyond statements of principle and political intentions by making efforts and mobilising resources to ensure the right of women, in particular young women, to fair treatment. In this regard, I supported with my vote the recommendations made.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. One of the objectives of my report is to ensure that the educational systems of the Member States have the need to teach children from an early age to live with and respect the difference. It is about combating the stereotypes and prejudices that prevent real gender equality. It is about combating misunderstanding and, in many cases, hatred and violence against the different. I sincerely believe that education is the best way to ensure that in the future everyone has the same rights in all areas of society and life.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I firmly believe that gender equality is a fundamental principle that children must learn from a young age.  It is important that Member States implement measures to achieve gender equality at all levels of the education system; incorporating a higher degree of awareness of gender issues into the training of teachers and other school staff (doctors, nurses, psychologists, social workers, educators) and that introduce mechanisms that allow the promotion, implementation, monitoring and evaluation of gender equality in all educational institutions and levels.  I also believe that it is essential that sex education be provided tailored to the age and needs of students, including awareness-raising on LGBT issues.  It is also important that States invest in educational and awareness-raising campaigns that improve career guidance for girls and boys, addressing the stereotypical picture of gender roles, as well as gender stereotypes in different careers, particularly in the field of science and new technologies, to reduce gender segregation in the labour market and strengthen women's position

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which believes that gender equality measures must apply to all levels of the education system, including in teacher programmes and training, in order to end gender stereotypes and help bridge the gap between women's education and professional development. The text of this non-legislative resolution also calls for more investment to ensure quality public education for all.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This report warns of the still-evident inequalities between male and female children in terms of access to education, so there is still a long way to go with regard to gender equality applicable to all levels of the education system, namely on issues such as combating violence against girls, the ratification of the Istanbul Convention , the principle of subsidiarity in school curricula, the need to challenge gender stereotypes, education as a tool in combating poverty and equal access to science and technology. Although I agree, for the most part, with the proposals contained in the report, I decided to abstain not only on some suggestions from the group with which I agreed not to have been welcomed, but also because I express reservations about compliance with the principle of subsidiarity on some points of the proposal, that the content of school curricula is a good example.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the proposal put forward by Mr Beazley. Rodrigues on the emancipation of girls through education in the European Union. The rapporteur argues that there are major gender differences in terms of access to education in Europe and that gender stereotypes predomibe.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. The vote cast has been in favour of this Report. It highlights its impact on free public education for all, LGTBI rights and the right to access to education, regardless of place of residence. Although some issues related to the push for self-defense training plans for women are not incorporated, which would increase their level of advocacy, we still believe it is to take a step further in the right direction. Some interesting measures that we support with our vote are: -Fight against gender stereotypes that promote advertising and the media. -Promote professional and vocational orientation outside of gender stereotypes. -Instill the values of equality and human rights. -Educate children in mental health, sexuality and healthy relationships to help them make well-informed decisions. -Reduce maternal-child mortality and prevent the prevalence of sexually transmitted diseases. -Promote the knowledge and control of young women and girls on their bodies. -Combat physical aggression, discrimination and stigma based on sexual orientation, gender identity and individual expression. Fight bullying.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Access to education is a fundamental human right and a right of every child, which should be guaranteed to boys as well as girls. Unfortunately, girls are often disadvantaged by gender stereotypes and the situation is even more difficult for those coming from socially disadvantaged backgrounds. On mrs Rodrigues's report, I also appreciate the fact that she is dedicated to these groups, so I supported her with my vote.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I supported this text which urges Member States to take measures to raise awareness of gender equality from education. Unfortunately, the final vote withdrew its call on the Commission to be involved in actions on programmes for gender equality, even though it is part of the principles of existing treaties.  However, the text is aimed at requesting resources for educational institutions and educational professionals to develop cross-cutting training and programmes in non-discrimination values that invite gender barriers and stereotypes. It also recalls the duty of States to seek public childcare networks, as well as to ensure quality public education. It also again urges the Commission to begin the EU accession procedure to the Istanbul Convention on Violence against Women. Although improveable, the text denounces that austerity measures have very negatively affected educational resources, for which strong public investment is needed to develop the programmes identified. That is why my vote has been favourable.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union's mission is to promote equal opportunities. All children must have access to a free and quality public education, without discrimination and regardless of their residence status. In this scenario, moving forward with measures promoting gender equality is increased. The holistic approach advocated by this report is a path that will bring results. It is part of an assertive diagnosis, which recognises that the promotion of the democratization of education has contributed to equal opportunities, gender equality and the overcoming of economic, social and cultural inequalities. It also lists measures capable of being firm steps towards emwith the Union with the appropriate tools and means for a consistent and integrated response.  I am convinced that the development of personality and a spirit of tolerance, solidarity and responsibility will facilitate social progress and democratic participation in life in society.  All these are reasons that have contributed to my positive vote.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as the EU has no place or mandate to get involved in the UK education system. The EU also has no role or mandate to get involved in sex and relationship education in schools in the UK.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ As I stated in my previous explanation, I voted for this report for the same reason: women and girls have a right to an education. And this report makes it clear that education, as a major aspect of socialisation, radically affects our perception of women and girls. Not only do schools shape our perception of other genders, but also contribute massively to attitudes, choices and ambitions. If we are to empower girls to achieve their true potential, we must create the appropriate learning environments where our current attitudes towards gender is challenged; from stereotypes to discrimination. All children must be able to thrive. There is an urgent need to tackle these inequalities and present practical solutions to very real problems girls are facing.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: writing ‒ In the European institutions, we are increasingly faced with repeated attempts to overstepped their competences and with a disregard for the sovereignty of the Member States, as well as the rubbing of the inesucible rights of parents to raise their own children. I am opposed to increasing pressure to promote gender ideology. The proposals for its implementation are directed towards the indoctrination of society and, in particular, in the Rodrigues report, the indoctrination of the smallest, our children. I cannot agree with that, which is why I voted against this resolution.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ This explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: writing \u2012 The education and training of girls and women is an important European value, a fundamental human right and the basis for women's and girls' empowerment at social, cultural and professional level. In the world, 17% of the adult population is unable to read or write, of which up to 2/3 are women. Education is a tool that enables women to gain economic independence. Therefore, measures aimed at mainstreaming gender equality at all levels of the education system must be effective and controllable. Member States must also integrate childcare and early childhood education into education systems in order to enable parents to find a work-life balance. Member States must ensure equal access to education for girls and boys, regardless of age, gender, socioeconomic status, cultural background or religion. The principle of equality between women and men needs to be addressed in the curriculum at all stages of education.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. Education is a fundamental right of all people and is also extremely important for ensuring gender equality and empowering girls. The education and training of girls and women is an important European value and is an essential part of the full enjoyment of all social, economic, cultural and political rights. A study carried out by the EP's Directorate-General for Internal Policy shows that 30 million girls are excluded from the education system at the age of primary school. The report encourages Member States to implement educational measures aimed at combating gender stereotypes, on learning equality, human dignity and self-esteem of girls and boys, so that they can make their important decisions autonomously and sufficiently informed, on the lessons of women's awareness of control of their body, and on tackling homophobic and transphobic bullying and helping to combat discrimination based on sexual orientation and identity. The report proposes measures to ensure the promotion of gender equality, the promotion of girls' professional profiles and competences and, last but not least, the improvement of their personal and professional development in all national education systems, which is why I supported the report on the empowerment of girls in the EU through education.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Writing. The Rodriguez report, which is being voted on today in the European Parliament, seeks to require states to implement gender equality measures at all levels of education. This would mean fully integrating appropriate measures into teacher training, introducing monitoring mechanisms on this, working directly with families and even making gender issues a topic in sport and leisure activities. As much as we affirm women's equality, these plans go far beyond the mark. Moreover, they blatantly exceed the EU's powers. Education policy falls within the competence of the individual EU Member States! In Germany, education policy is even a matter for the Länder. In view of this, it seems absurd for the EU to want to adopt comprehensive rules in the field of education. The principle of subsidiarity must also be respected with regard to equality between men and women. Article 3 of the Basic Law obliges the German State to actively work towards the elimination of existing disadvantages. There is no need for more requirements. I therefore reject this report.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: Written. The N-VA delegation abstained from voting on this report. We are convinced that education is the basis for responsible citizenship, is essential for ensuring gender equality and strengthening the position of girls and is a fundamental human right to be guaranteed for all children. We also defend an inclusive society with equal rights and obligations for all, as well as an equal opportunities policy tailored to and with attention to various target groups. Violations of this equality, both at work and in private, are not acceptable to us.  At the same time, subsidiarity is also important for the N-VA. We have an eye for the different levels of policy and the demarcation of powers. From this point of view, the report is problematic, as education is not primarily eu competence.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒I voted against this report, as the Lisbon Treaty is about the competence of the Member States, and therefore there is no need for the European Parliament to interfere with the competence of individual Member States.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ This report sends a very clear message that education will play a critical role in making gender equality a reality. Schools are fundamental in shaping attitudes, choices and ambitions. If we are to empower girls to achieve their true potential, we must create learning environments where gender stereotypes are challenged, where no child is discriminated against, and where all children can thrive. Women are still underrepresented in senior leadership and decision making positions whilst being overrepresented in early years and primary education. As a result, girls often lack role models, particularly in science and technology subjects. I voted for this report because it rightly identifies the urgent need to tackle these inequalities and presents practical solutions.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the report because it fundamentally interferes with the competences of the Member States in the field of education as well as in other areas.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. I voted against the report on empowering girls in the EU through education. The report touches on important topics such as women's education, women's employment, gender equality, gender stereotypes, ensuring equal access for girls and women for science and technology education programmes. Nevertheless, the report is, for a considerable part, a materially unspoied, flawed and a leap, in some parts of which interferes with areas within the competence of the Member States. I cannot get rid of the feeling that we could produce a significantly better report on the empowerment of girls in the EU through education.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 This report calls for immediate measures to implement gender equality at all levels of the education system and to raise awareness of gender equality in the training of teaching staff, as well as for all professional categories in the field of education. It also calls on the Member States to fulfil all necessary to ensure that education contributes to ensuring gender equality and equal opportunities, eliminating economic, social and cultural inequalities and promoting solidarity. It is also important to mention the need to recognise that a sensitive, age-appropriate and scientifically accurate education on sexuality and relationships is a key tool for empowering girls and boys, which will help them make conscious choices and contribute positively to wider priorities. That is why we voted in favour of the report.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Promotes the preparation of children and young people in the role of worker away from the concept of family. It also promotes the information of children from an early age in the broader concept of human sex (LGBT).

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with the report that education is the basis for responsible citizenship and is key to ensuring gender equality and the empowerment of all citizens. I believe that the Commission and the Member States must ensure that measures are put in place to promote gender equality at all levels of education. I also voted in favour of this report because I believe it is true that education, both for girls and boys, must promote a conscious, balanced personality that respects others, is capable of empathy and mutual respect in order to avoid discrimination, aggression and intimidation.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Empowering girls, as well as other actions to promote equality, are of great importance to the European Union as an organisation based on non-discrimination against people on grounds of gender, age, ethnicity or nationality. However, despite the very legitimate objectives, the document presented contains a number of proposals which are not implementable and significantly interfere with the exclusive competences of the Member States, m.in. in the field of education. Unfortunately, too often the proposed solutions, raised even in the name of lofty objectives but undertaken in an unreasonable way, are counterproductive. Unilateral declarations and objectives and arguments must therefore be very avoided. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote against this report.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 Education is one of the fundamental human rights that can provide better prospects for achievement in life. The way in which education systems give equal opportunities regardless of gender is an issue of the utmost importance to today's society. This stems from a discriminatory curricula for the role of women in society, a trend that must be combated at Union and Member State level. Often, although women constitute a majority in the education system (both as teachers and as pupils), they are taken into account from the position of a minority, associated with membership of other types of minorities (ethnic, sexual, persons with disabilities). This situation needs to change as soon as possible, and the European institutions have a decisive role to play in this regard. This includes, in addition to non-discriminatory curricula and appropriate teacher training, greater focus on vulnerable groups and up-to-date teaching methods, including non-formal education. Such reform implies our solidarity of all, regardless of gender or other affiliations.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report aiming to ensure the equality and empowerment of girls through education. It also calls for fight against gender stereotyping and encourage more women to take up science, technology, engineering and mathematics.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: In writing. Gender inequalities persist in all european Union countries. However, the conservatives and reactionaries denouncing a hypothetical "theory" of gender, all credible sociological studies show that these inequalities are built from an early age, through a differential education between girls and boys.  Taking this reality into account, the Rodrigues report aims to implement and develop an emancipatory education for girls, which would counter the internalization of stereotypes, the basis of inequality. To this end, it calls for action at all levels in education, through the training of teachers and school staff, the upgrading of women's place in school curricula or the implementation of mechanisms for assessing gender equality. The report also proposes the creation of a prize for virtuous institutions in terms of gender equality.      Thus, I support this report because, contrary to what the Conservatives have said, it is not the competence of the States alone. "Equality between men and women must be ensured in all areas," states Article 23 of the European Union's Declaration of Fundamental Rights: it is time to act now!

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒The report deeply encroaches on spheres outside the competence of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality - primarily in education located in the union's individual member states' jurisdiction and in which the Union is only responsible for taking action supporting, coordinating or complementing the actions of individual Member States, but not for harmonisation, which is precisely what this report is trying to do. Once again, under the guise of gender equality, universal and generally accepted principles, such as equal access to education and the fight against discrimination, the school curriculum of all Member States of the Union is once again trying to promote gender ideology in sex education and attempts to make that education compulsory not only in primary but also in tertiary education. The report calls on all Member States to eliminate sexism in school textbooks and to mobilise all teachers by activating them to combat negative gender stereotypes. Member States are also invited to adapt national laws in the areas of media and promotion in order to serve the same purpose as education.  I consider this continuing scandalous practice of imposing a specific ideology extremely undemocratic and dangerous, and accordingly I explicitly oppose such and all past and future similar attempts.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. The Rodrigues report touches on important topics such as education as a tool for combating poverty, ensuring equal access for girls and women to science and technology education programmes, combating violence against girls and women, ratifying the Istanbul Convention. However, the text is not good enough, as it intervenes in some parts in areas within the competence of the Member States and in some cases does not adhere to the title of the report, while at the same time exceeding the limits of its powers. These are the reasons why I did not support the report.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. The vote cast has been in favour of this Report. It highlights its impact on free public education for all, LGTBI rights and the right to access to education, regardless of place of residence. Although some issues related to the push for self-defense training plans for women are not incorporated, which would increase their level of advocacy, we still believe it is to take a step further in the right direction. Some interesting measures that we support with our vote are: -Fight against gender stereotypes that promote advertising and the media. -Promote professional and vocational orientation outside of gender stereotypes. -Instill the values of equality and human rights. -Educate children in mental health, sexuality and healthy relationships to help them make well-informed decisions. -Reduce maternal-child mortality and prevent the prevalence of sexually transmitted diseases. -Promote the knowledge and control of young women and girls on their bodies. -Combat physical aggression, discrimination and stigma based on sexual orientation, gender identity and individual expression. Fight bullying.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Writing. The Rodriguez report, which is being voted on today in the European Parliament, seeks to require Member States to implement gender equality measures at all levels of education. This would mean fully integrating appropriate measures into teacher training, introducing monitoring mechanisms on this, working directly with families and even making gender issues a topic in sport and leisure activities. As much as we affirm women's equality, these plans go far beyond the mark. It is also becoming increasingly clear that in many cases boys and young men are the disadvantaged sex today. It is high time to give you fair opportunities in training again. Moreover, the provisions of the Rodriguez report blatantly exceed the powers of the EU. Education policy falls within the competence of the individual EU Member States! In Germany, education policy is even a matter for the Länder. In view of this, it seems absurd for the EU to want to adopt comprehensive rules in the field of education. The principle of subsidiarity must also be respected with regard to equality between men and women. Article 3 of the Basic Law obliges the German State to actively work towards the elimination of existing disadvantages. There is no need for more requirements. I therefore reject this report.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The main purpose of this text is to condition young Europeans to accept minorities through the school system. This "emancipation" through school and the need to keep girls in school are never just the side effects of mass immigration, important customs and values that are not ours, on the one hand, and the power of LGBTI lobbies on the other.  As education is not within the EU's competence, we have proposed an alternative resolution on two fronts: - a reminder of subsidiarity and the lack of EU competence on education issues; The lack of a real issue since girls' enrolment in Europe is not a problem as shown by the H/F distribution figures for higher education graduates.  It is obvious that I have not been able to support this text, both for legal (non-EU) and ideological issues. I voted AGAINST this text.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. The vote cast has been in favour of this Report. It highlights its impact on free public education for all, LGTBI rights and the right to access to education, regardless of place of residence. Although some issues related to the push for self-defense training plans for women are not incorporated, which would increase their level of advocacy, we still believe it is to take a step further in the right direction. Some interesting measures that we support with our vote are: - Fight against gender stereotypes that promote advertising and the media. - Promote professional and vocational orientation outside of gender stereotypes. - Instill the values of equality and human rights. - Educate children in mental health, sexuality and healthy relationships to help them make well-informed decisions. - Reduce maternal-child mortality and prevent the prevalence of sexually transmitted diseases. - Promote the knowledge and control of young women and girls on their bodies. - Combat physical aggression, discrimination and stigma based on sexual orientation, gender identity and individual expression. Fight bullying.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it emphasizes that education is a fundamental right of girls and women, vital to the empowerment and respect of their social, cultural, economic and political rights. The text also refers to the prevention of violence against women and girls and proposes concrete actions to ensure that all public education systems promote gender equality and implement various measures to combat gender steeds or homophobia/transphobia.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because it addresses a series of key issues related to gender equality. In an effort to close the existing gap between women’s education and professional development, the text calls for equal access measures and the use of information and communication technologies already from pre-school, with the aim of encouraging women to take up science, engineering and mathematics-related study paths. The report also tackles the issue of sexual stereotyping, and calls for awareness to be raised both in formal and informal education. Furthermore, gender education should be included in school curricula and teaching materials should not contain sexist or discriminatory content. Teachers should also be properly trained to promote equality, while curricula and educational materials should be critically reviewed in order to provide stereotype-free education.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. We know the importance of education to ensure gender equality. We understand the need for a school culture of gender equality at all levels of the education system, awareness of gender issues in teacher training, as well as all categories of professionals working in schools, to create mechanisms to facilitate the promotion, implementation, monitoring and evaluation of gender equality in educational establishments.  We agree that only states have the capacity to ensure compulsory and free universal education and that budget cuts in education, many of them derived from the austerity policies advocated by the EU, endanger quality and free public education, thereby contributing to increased inequalities.  We are therefore in complete line with the idea that all children should have access to free and quality public education, without discrimination and regardless of their residence status. In fact, in general we agree with the text of the report, although we do not agree with the idea that access to education should be done through affordable childcare facilities, which is also contrary to what has been said above.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The European Parliament should strictly abide by the principles of subsidiarity and the sovereignty of the Member States in the field of education and not, under any pretext, interfere in school programmes with questionable rules on early sexualisation or, more broadly, in all educational activities, whether at school or in the family, or in cultural and sporting activities. This report must therefore be rejected.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. The motion for a resolution mentions the role of parents and the family only twice in the recitals of this resolution, namely to warn that parents and the family are passing on 'gender roles during the socialisation phases in childhood and adolescence'. This means that the European Parliament opposes fathers and mothers educating their daughters as women and mothers, and their sons as men and fathers. In order to neutralise parental education within the family as far as possible, the public education system should take over the "gender-neutral education in the sense of equality" of children and young people – and especially of girls. This includes the requirement that curricula, teaching methods and teaching materials be constantly monitored by experts on gender issues. Of course, the Women's Committee also insists that sex education be compulsory for all pupils from primary school onwards. The manipulation of adolescents is promoted by the European Parliament. This includes a particular focus on LGBTI lifestyles. In order to achieve this, textbook publishers will now be accompanied by special equality and sexeducation experts. It also calls for an annual European Equality Prize to be awarded to distinguish educational institutions that have excelled in manipulating children and young people. I do not take part in this nonsense, and that is why I am voting against this report.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ This report sends a very clear message that education will play a critical role in making gender equality a reality. Learning environments are fundamental in shaping attitudes, choices and ambitions. If we are to empower girls to achieve their true potential, we must create learning environments where gender stereotypes are challenged, where no child is discriminated against, and where all children can thrive. Women are still under—represented in senior leadership and decision making positions whilst being overrepresented in early years and primary education. As a result, girls often lack role models, particularly in science and technology subjects. I voted for this report because it rightly identifies the urgent need to tackle these inequalities and presents practical solutions. In particular I welcomed the adoption of an amendment on the need to promote sexual and relationship education that I tabled in CULT Committee in my role as shadow rapporteur for the opinion.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. – I voted for the report on increasing girls' capacities through education.
