I welcome the initiative to create such a generous subject in the EP, which calls on the Member States to promote the democratisation of education and the other conditions necessary for education, both in schools and through other means of training, to contribute to the creation of gender equality and equal opportunities, to overcoming economic, social and cultural inequalities , to foster personal development and a spirit of tolerance, solidarity and responsibility, facilitating social progress and democratic participation in community life. I agree that education is an important tool for women to have the opportunity to participate fully in social and economic development, and lifelong learning is essential to give them skills that enable them to return to the labour market or find a better job with better incomes and working conditions.

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: in writing. The report by Meps Rodrigues on training young women through education in the EU is a report with which, if the content is not to be accessed, she could agree. What's the matter? Which has been used as a throwing weapon among the members of this House, severely violent the positions of some Members. The report goes far beyond what the Treaties indicate. This overreach of functions is no longer just going to meddle in the internal affairs of the Member States, this report is intended to get into our homes and schools and say how we should educate our children. Mr President, I find it intolerable that such a report will see the light, we must put an end to these reports which all they do is confront the House and infringe the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The European Parliamentary Group of the Jrc voted against the report "Empowering girls in the EU through education", as it reflects the EU's hostile to the needs of young people and women in education policy. It conceals the core of women's inequality in exploitative societies and the fact that the conditions for women's participation in education, production are determined by the interests of capitalists, presenting solutions supposedly for women's equality, through the distorting lens of the interests, competitiveness and profitability of enterprises. In the report, the acute problems faced by schoolgirls are transformed into 'rails' on which the EU's strategy of 'lifelong exploitation' is promoted more quickly for the benefit of monopolies. The report's proposals support and broaden the EU's positions on education, which prepares, "educates" young girls to accept the working jungle, the pursuit of "skills" in informal education, mobility from profession to profession and from country to country. The report promotes the evaluation of educational institutions and so-called "entrepreneurship" education. Young girls, in the name of the falsified policy of gender equality, are called upon to accept "new discrimination" at the expense of social recognition of motherhood and their particular biological needs.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing. ‒ While the ECR group is a strong supporter of progress in equality of both girls and boys in the area of education, the report goes far beyond the remit and responsibilities of the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality (FEMM) and of Parliament, particularly in the area of education. The main areas of concern for the ECR deal with the prescriptive nature of the ‘Training and curriculum’ section of the report, namely the suggested promotion of gender equality in Member States’ comprehensive sex and relationship education programmes, the consideration of making sex and relationship education compulsory in the school curricula for all primary and secondary school children and the insistence on gender equality as a criterion for production of educational materials and gender-aware tutoring. Some of the recommendations in the report constitute intrusion into the citizen’s beliefs, such as the need to include strategies for reflection on teachers’ own identity, beliefs, values, prejudices, expectations, attitudes and gender representations, as well as on their teaching practices, in teachers training. Considering that neither the FEMM Committee, nor Parliament were given a mandate in the area of education and the fact that the above cited concerns constitute a very significant part of the report, the ECR was unable to support it.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. The report underlines the importance of education to ensure gender equality. It recommends a school culture of gender equality at all levels of the education system, awareness of gender issues in teacher training, as well as all categories of professionals working in schools, to put in place mechanisms to facilitate the promotion, implementation, monitoring and evaluation of gender equality in educational establishments.  We agree that only states have the capacity to ensure compulsory and free universal education and that budget cuts in education, many of them derived from the austerity policies advocated by the EU, endanger quality and free public education, thereby contributing to increased inequalities. We are in complete consonance with the idea that all children should have access to a free and quality public education, without discrimination and regardless of their residence status. In fact, in general we agree with the text of the report, although we do not agree with the idea that access to education should be done through affordable childcare facilities, which is also contrary to what has been said above. We voted for it.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it addresses the issue of the emancipation of girls through education, with the aim of making greater use of the educational path at school and university, for a real affirmation of women in society and in the world of work. The text reiterates the need to take greater measures to respect fundamental rights and freedoms and to equal rights and opportunities for women and men. It also promotes the development of self-esteem and professional affirmation in order to encourage girls and women to be autonomous and to make informed decisions. An established principle is that of the importance of education also as a means of removing women from multiple forms of domestic and non-domestic violence. It also calls for equal access to education regardless of age, gender, socioeconomic status, cultural background or religion, promoting higher quality education that provides equal opportunities for all and at all levels of education.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. This report adequately expresses its concern about the obstacles to worker mobility imposed unilaterally on its European neighbours by Switzerland.  However, the EU itself denies solidarity to its neighbours, closing its external and internal borders and selectively recognizing the right of mobility to its own citizens, as the expulsions of Spaniards and Italians in countries such as Belgium have made clear. That is why I cannot share the interference tone of the report, nor the way in which it matches workers' rights with the pseudo-freedoms of the single market. For all this, I abstained.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. The report follows a referendum on 9 February 2014 calling for the adoption of a law "against mass immigration" in a real attack on Switzerland's sovereignty.  The Swiss people have been very clear in favour of this bill, but the European Union, in retaliation, has rejected the Swiss confederation's request to renegotiate the ALCP (agreement for the free movement of persons), an essential pillar of the single market.  The rapporteur is shockingly ignoring the will of the people, as the European Union is used to.  He clearly asked that the Swiss authorities put pressure on them to review their copy and prevent them from putting too long into practice what they were elected for.  Contrary to the values of sovereignty of the European nations defended by our group in the European Parliament, I have expressed myself in disfavor the against this report.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. – The Agreement for the European Economic Area (EEA Agreement) is the most far-reaching and comprehensive instrument for extending the economic integration of the EU's internal market to third countries. In order for a well-functioning and effective internal market based on a highly competitive social market economy to promote growth and competitiveness, create jobs and give new impetus to the European economy, properly implemented, applied and enforced internal market legislation is essential. I welcome this report because it reiterates, among other things, the existing transposition deficits and the removal of obstacles to cross-border occupational mobility in the countries concerned.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. The vote on a law against mass immigration was held in Switzerland on 9 February 2014. The Swiss people have been very much in favour of this law. Following this vote, the European Union wants to take retaliatory measures and wants to reject the Swiss request to renegotiate the agreement for the free movement of people. The rapporteur clearly calls for pressure on the Swiss authorities, thus showing his contempt for the decision taken by the Swiss people. So I voted against it.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ This report heavily criticises EEA states for not implementing enough Single Market legislation. It also supports the EU’s rejection of a request by Switzerland to renegotiate their Free Movement of People agreement. I cannot support such a report.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to remove obstacles to the full completion of the internal market. The EEA Agreement is one of the main drivers of economic growth and a broad measure extending the single market to third countries. Strong relations between the EEA and Switzerland go beyond economic integration and the extension of the single market, contributing to stability and prosperity, benefiting all citizens and businesses, including SMEs.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. "How? Switzerland has dared to consult its people and respect its decision?" This arouses the ire - and delirium - of the so-called democrats who are currently presiding over the destiny of the EU... I have of course voted against this scandalous text, which is due to a German member of the CDU, Mrs Merkel's Christian Democratic Party.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I supported this report, which highlights the importance of the trading partners of the EEA and EFTA countries and Switzerland, welcomes the large number of EU programmes in which the EEA and EFTA countries participate, while highlighting the transposition deficit in some countries such as Liechtenstein, Iceland and Norway. In addition, the report stresses the strong relationship between the EU and Switzerland, but recalls switzerland's obligations in terms of freedom of movement of people, the pillar of the single market, which requires reciprocity and fairness in its use.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This report follows the referendum held in Switzerland on 9 February 2014 calling for the adoption of a law "against mass immigration" and in which the Swiss people had very clearly voted in favour of this bill.  But the self-righteous technocrats of the European Union, unable to support democracy against the treaties, rejected the Swiss confederation's request to renegotiate the agreement on the free movement of people.  This report is an attack on Switzerland's sovereignty and popular will. The rapporteur Schwab clearly calls for pressure from the Swiss authorities to revise their copy.  It is intolerable for the EU to interfere in the policies of the Member States, but here it is even more intolerable that it wants to dictate its choices to other non-member states. However, it seems that Europe likes to intervene all over the world to spread its "good word" which it often finds difficult to apply itself, especially in terms of respect for democracy and peoples.  So I voted against this report.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I do not agree with the Schwab report at all, for most of the text the analysis positions on the implementation of the EU single market rules in Norway, Iceland and Liechtenstein are balanced and I do not agree with it, but I do not agree with and cannot accept the nipping references to Switzerland due to last year's referendum against mass immigration and the subsequent decisions of the Swiss Federal Council. Swiss citizens have exercised the sacrosanct rights of democracy, voted and expressed their views on immigration, and this has nothing to do with the internal market and the free movement of goods. Once again, this is an act of unlawful interference by the EU towards the will of the people.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. \u2012 The report seeks to put pressure on Switzerland on internal market issues. The background is that Switzerland decided in a referendum not to be part of the EEA. The report is based on a position that does not respect the people's choice in Switzerland. That is why I am abstaining.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The Resolution considers that the four Member States of the European Free Trade Association (Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway and Switzerland) are important trading partners and that the EEA Agreement is a key element of growth. The resolution assesses progress in the adoption of the relevant acquis in the EEA Agreement, as well as the recent agreement on the principles for the transposition of the European Regulations creating the European Supervisory Authorities. However, it expresses certain concerns. With regard to Liechtenstein, because of its transposition deficit and certain restrictions on the recruitment of EEA nationals. With regard to Iceland, because of the transposition deficit, the highest. As for Norway, the increase in the transposition deficit and the need to improve energy cooperation. As regards Switzerland, it urges the Swiss Government to redouble its efforts to advance the institutional framework agreement and insists that the free movement of persons is one of the fundamental freedoms and pillar of the single market, and therefore supports the Community refusal to renegotiate the Agreement on free movement in order to introduce a system of national quotas or preference.  That's why I voted for it.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this Parliament's report, which deals with obstacles to the full completion of the internal market between the EEA and Switzerland. Developments within the EU have shown that the EEA is a strong, efficient and well-functioning agreement that also ensures the long-term integrity of the single market, and calls on EFTA States in the EEA to step up their efforts in close cooperation with the EU to maintain the integrity of the single market, thus circumventing obstacles to the full completion of the internal market.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 The internal market has entered a "critical" phase, partly due to internal shortcomings and untapped potential, partly due to external challenges. In my view, looking at the EU and Switzerland, the differences start with the administrative burden of entry, and the inflexibility of the labour market, I am thinking of the Swiss quota, only reduces the possibility of growth. It is to be welcomed that the integration of financial markets has made great progress in recent years, but in my opinion this was due to global trends rather than the good functioning of integration policies. I voted in favour of this report, because I, too, see that in the development of better regulation it is not only about how uniform its content is, but also how its effectiveness can be achieved and monitored. The proposals contained in the report are of particular importance for integration policies, as they concern several sectors and several policies. The regulatory environment must therefore be simple, consistent and easy to enforce, but it can only be the right solution for a genuine single market.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. ‒ This report was concerned with the position of the Parliament on the current situation in the EEA-EFTA states and the EU regarding the proper functioning of the EEA Agreement (European Economic Area). It was primarily focused on Switzerland and sought to exercise pressure on Switzerland for the conclusion of a framework agreement which is set as a precondition for further agreements on Swiss participation in the internal market. I was particularly concerned with this aspect as this is a matter for the people of Switzerland to decide and not the EU. Moreover, it must be noted that Switzerland’s participation in the EEA Agreement was questioned by its people in a vote in 1992 and therefore the EEA Agreement after that is based mainly on sectorial agreements. However, there were some positive aspects to the report. Specifically amendments, which referred to the latest referendum that took place in Switzerland (popular initiative of 9 February 2014 ‘Against Mass Immigration’) which stated that the result of the referendum in Switzerland, should be respected.  In light of these conflicting aspects of the report, I abstained on the final vote.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. On 9 February 2014, Switzerland held a referendum on mass immigration. The initiative proposed to set annual quotas according to the needs of their economy while reaffirming the principle of national preference. The Swiss voted overwhelmingly in favour of the text. Subsequently, the European Union rejected Switzerland's request to renegotiate the Free Movement of Persons Agreement (ALCP), thus flouting the will of the Swiss people.  Continuing this approach, this report wants to put pressure on the Swiss government to reverse the measures envisaged in the referendum. We are outraged at the democratic contempt of the European institutions. So I voted against this outrageous report.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The Member States of the European Free Trade Association and the European Union have established an agreement establishing equal conditions and non-differentiated treatment, thereby contributing to the expansion of the European single market. The Agreement of 21 June 1999 between the European Community and the Swiss Confederation establishes the free movement of persons, the recognition of professional qualifications, lays the foundations for mutual recognition in the field of conformity assessment and establishes a framework for the application of public contracts. Close economic relations between the EU and Switzerland have a long existence, being factors of growth and stability. However, the implementation of the 'against mass immigration' initiative calls into question the fact that Switzerland still seeks to comply with the agreements in force and that the outcome of that decision can have a major impact on economic relations. Given that cross-border occupational mobility is a major factor in strengthening the internal market, I believe that Switzerland should comply with the conditions of reciprocity laid down in the agreements in force. I have expressed myself in favour of this resolution, because I am convinced that any interference with the free movement of people within the European area means the revision of the agreements between the EU and Switzerland.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I am strongly opposed to the Report of the Committee on the Internal Market. For much of the text, the wording on the implementation of eu single market rules in the EEA countries (Iceland, Liechtenstein and Norway) is fairly acceptable. What I cannot accept, however, are the very critical references to Switzerland because of the 2014 referendum against mass immigration and the subsequent decisions of the Swiss Federal Council. The legitimate, if fair, decisions taken by the citizens and the Swiss Government have nothing to do with the EU's internal market in the movement of goods. Those of the Schwab report are, without doubt, illegitimate interference in the choices of the Swiss people.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the agreement between the European Economic Area (EEA) and Switzerland, which is a valuable incentive for economic growth, as well as an optimal instrument for extending the single market to third countries and ensuring the soundness of the single market in the long term as well. In May 2014, new negotiations were launched to outline an essential institutional framework for concluding further agreements on Switzerland's participation in the internal market, although some issues remain such as the recent Swiss restriction on the free movement of persons or obstacles to cross-border professional mobility, which can generate a major imbalance and significantly undermine the benefits of the agreements for EU Member States. As the report points out, our relations with Switzerland must therefore be deepened in greater depth, so as to achieve mutual benefit and broaden the many common points that already exist.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ This report was concerned with the position of the Parliament on the current situation in the EEA-EFTA states and the EU regarding the proper functioning of the EEA Agreement (European Economic Area). It was primarily focused on Switzerland and sought to exercise pressure on Switzerland for the conclusion of a framework agreement which is set as a precondition for further agreements on Swiss participation in the internal market. I was particularly concerned with this aspect as this is a matter for the people of Switzerland to decide and not the EU. Moreover, it must be noted that Switzerland’s participation in the EEA Agreement was questioned by its people in a vote in 1992 and therefore the EEA Agreement after that is based mainly on sectorial agreements. However, there were some positive aspects to the report. Specifically amendments, which referred to the latest referendum that took place in Switzerland (popular initiative of 9 February 2014 ‘Against Mass Immigration’) which stated that the result of the referendum in Switzerland, should be respected.  In light of these conflicting aspects of the report, I abstained on the final vote.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ This report heavily criticises EEA States for not implementing enough Single Market legislation. It also supports the EU’s rejection of a request by Switzerland to renegotiate their Free Movement of People Agreement. Accordingly, I cannot support such a report and, as such, voted against it.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report 'on the European Economic Area-Switzerland: obstacles to the full implementation of the internal market' because a well-functioning single market, based on a social market economy, is necessary to stimulate our growth.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it represents a real attack on the sovereignty of Switzerland, whose people wanted to fight against mass immigration.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We recognise that close relations between the EU, the EEA-EFTA countries and Switzerland go beyond economic integration and the expansion of the single market and contribute to stability and prosperity for the benefit of all citizens and businesses including SMEs. We stress the importance of ensuring the proper functioning of the single market in order to create a level playing field and new jobs.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal on obstacles to the full implementation of the internal market in the EEA-Switzerland countries. In particular, while noting the outcome of the February 2014 referendum against 'mass immigration' and the decisions taken by the Swiss Federal Council, the proposal notes that these decisions are contrary to the obligations arising from the agreement on the free movement of persons and therefore calls on Switzerland to comply with these obligations; deplores unilateral accompanying measures and calls on the Confederation to remove obstacles to cross-border professional mobility in order to intensify the internal market.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 Switzerland's decision to stay out of the EU is legitimate even if I do not agree with it. However, such a small country, however strong in certain specific sectors, cannot ignore sharing certain policies with the surrounding giants: I am referring in particular to the internal market and free movement. Having said that, I believe that the EU must monitor and demand respect for the four freedoms, in particular that of the movement of workers, so that all parties benefit from the benefits that the agreements bring. My reference, if it is not clear, concerns Italian cross-border workers who are subjected to unacceptable harassment and discrimination, and against whom special information campaigns against the Confederation should be combated. I voted in favour of the overall structure of the report and the appropriate emphasis on this aspect and congratulate the rapporteur on his excellent work.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Member States of the European Free Trade Association (EFTA) are major trading partners of the European Union on the basis of relations with three of these Member States in the European Economic Area - EEA (Iceland, Liechtenstein and Norway). In order to achieve the full completion of the internal market with these countries, through the various agreements, it is necessary to close the gaps and obstacles that still exist and to combat the threats to the implementation of this desideratum, so that the single market works effectively, boosts growth and competitiveness, generates jobs and revitalises the European economy. As regards the EEA States, it should be noted that the number of pending legal acts of incorporation remains worrying, and they should redouble their efforts to preserve the integrity of the single market and combat the increase in the average transposition deficit. With regard to the Swiss Confederation, I regret the results of the popular initiative of 9 February 2014 "against mass immigration" and criticise the consequent request for renegotiation of the Agreement on the Free Movement of Persons. Free movement is a fundamental freedom and pillar of the single market! At issue is the balance in relations with the EU which has manifested itself in unilateral acts contrary to the agreements established.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because the use of the internal market must be based on reciprocity and fairness between the EEA and Switzerland. The rules of the game must apply to everyone, you can't just pick raisins. As a member of the EFTA/EEA, Switzerland is and should remain a close partner of the EU. But restrictions on the free movement of persons are unacceptable.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 This is a very important own-initiative report which I supported with my vote in favour. The European Union has a free trade association (EFTA) with a number of non-EU countries, such as Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway and Switzerland, including the Agreement on the Economic Free Trade Area (EEA).  There is, however, too great a deficit in the transposition of European single market legislation by these states. The backlog of legal acts pending incorporation is still too high and efforts must be made to transpose them on time in accordance with the agreements, with respect for reciprocity and fairness. Furthermore, I share the disappointment at the outcome of the popular initiative that took place in Switzerland on 9 February 2014 against mass immigration and at the decisions taken by the Federal Council on a draft implementing law and new accompanying measures. It is absolutely necessary to respect European law and immediately remove obstacles to cross-border professional mobility in order to intensify the internal market.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. This report adequately expresses its concern about the obstacles to worker mobility imposed unilaterally on its European neighbours by Switzerland.  However, the EU itself denies solidarity to its neighbours, closing its external and internal borders and selectively recognizing the right of mobility to its own citizens, as the expulsions of Spaniards and Italians in countries such as Belgium have made clear. That is why I cannot share the interference tone of the report, nor the way in which it matches workers' rights with the pseudo-freedoms of the single market. For all this, I abstained.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 An important signal was sent by parliament in its report on the EEA and Switzerland to the EFTA States belonging to the EEA, expressing concern about delays in transposing single market legislation. The EP underlines that meaningful single market legislation is applied by EFTA States in the EEA in a timely manner and with the least possible time-out. Among other things, the report makes a request for the removal of barriers to cross-border labour mobility in order to achieve a more complete internal market, in the interests of EU citizens wishing to make use of mobility. Furthermore, it agrees that the EU rejected in July 2014 a request from the Swiss authorities to renegotiate the Agreement on the Free Movement of Persons. I voted in favour of what was stated in the report.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ Any transposition deficit of the internal market regulatory framework by the EFTA members is a missed business opportunity for both sides. I agree with the calls to step up efforts to transpose, fully implement and enforce internal market legislation. I further support the Committee's calls to facilitate the provision of services and dismantle any unnecessary barriers such as the cross-border mobility restriction implemented by the Helvetic Confederation. For these reasons I voted in favour of the resolution put for the vote.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report drawn up by Mr De Clercq. Schwab which presents a significant overview of the state of implementation of single market legislation between the countries of the European Economic Area (EEA) and the Swiss Confederation. The EEA Agreement, if properly implemented, can greatly contribute to the economic growth of the EU, and I hope that countries that are not part of the Eu ropean Union will also properly transpose and implement single market legislation effectively. The report also deals in a balanced way with the state of bilateral relations with the Swiss Confederation, which today is based only on numerous bilateral agreements. I hope that Switzerland will be able to fully respect its commitments to the EU under these agreements, particularly on the issue of the free movement of persons (ALCP agreement) and that it will review the provisions restricting the free movement of workers and student mobility. Only recently, two rules approved by the canton of Ticino affected Italian cross-border workers. I believe that these measures are clearly discriminatory against European citizens, in clear violation of the provisions of the ALCP agreement. The European Union will in no way be able to accept restrictions on the freedom of establishment and movement of persons, which is the founding principle of the single market.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This initiative report aims to remove obstacles to the implementation of the internal market between the European Economic Area (EEA) and Switzerland, including restrictions on the free movement of people in Switzerland and respect for the principle of reciprocity and equity in their use of the single market. The rapporteur points out that the EEA agreement is an essential element of economic growth and is the most ambitious instrument for extending the single market to third countries. Nevertheless, the text remains firm on the ongoing negotiations with Switzerland on the issue of the February 2014 vote, which calls into question freedom of movement within the internal market. Sharing the position that Switzerland cannot benefit from a share of the benefits of the European internal market without accepting the essential rules, a position shared by this report, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. – The internal market has entered a 'critical' phase, partly due to its internal shortcomings and untapped potential, partly due to external challenges. In my view, looking at the EU and Switzerland, the differences start with the administrative burden of entry, and inflexibility in the labour market, in particular the Swiss quota, only reduces the possibility of growth. It is to be welcomed that the integration of financial markets has made great progress in recent years, but in my opinion this was due to global trends rather than the good functioning of integration policies. I voted in favour of this report, because I, too, see that in the development of better regulation it is not only about how uniform its content is, but also how its effectiveness can be achieved and monitored. The proposals contained in the report are of particular importance for integration policies, as they concern several sectors and several policies. The regulatory environment must therefore be simple, consistent and easy to enforce, but it can only be the right solution for a genuine single market.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. – The internal market has entered a 'critical' phase, partly due to its internal shortcomings and untapped potential, partly due to external challenges. In my view, looking at the EU and Switzerland, the differences start with the administrative burden of entry, and the inflexibility of the labour market, I am thinking of the Swiss quota, only reduces the possibility of growth. It is to be welcomed that the integration of financial markets has made great progress in recent years, but in my opinion this was due to global trends rather than the good functioning of integration policies. I voted in favour of this report, because I, too, see that in the development of better regulation it is not only about how uniform its content is, but also how its effectiveness can be achieved and monitored. The proposals contained in the report are of particular importance for integration policies, as they concern several sectors and several policies. The regulatory environment must therefore be simple, consistent and easy to enforce, but it can only be the right solution for a genuine single market.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. Despite the 2014 referendum against mass immigration in which the free and sovereign Swiss people expressed their refusal to endure the massive migratory flows that are passing through Europe, the European Union refused to renegotiate the agreement for the free movement of people. The objective is obvious: to strengthen the single market and to eliminate one of the last islands of popular sovereignty on the European continent. The tone of the report before us is not worthy of a representative that is intended to be democratic and denotes the ideological violence that prevails in the European Union and the contempt for the sovereign peoples. True to the need to listen to my compatriots and brothers in Europe and convinced that common sense can appease our continent for a Europe of nations and freedoms, I voted against this report.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We are voting against because with this report the European Parliament does not respect the legislation of the Swiss State and, even worse, does not respect the will of the Swiss people, as expressed in a referendum, on the issue of cross-border free movement of people.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. Switzerland's participation in the EEA Agreement was rejected in a referendum in 1992 and that relations between Switzerland and the EU are therefore currently based on more than 100 sectoral agreements, which provide for a high degree of integration. The EEA Agreement is an essential factor in economic growth and the most ambitious and complete instrument for extending the single market to third countries. The opening of negotiations in May 2014 for an institutional framework as a precondition for the future development of a bilateral approach was important to encourage the Swiss Government to step up its efforts to advance negotiations on outstanding issues, while regretting that restrictions on the free movement of persons imposed by a referendum in Switzerland risk creating an imbalance and jeopardising the benefits of agreements for EU Member States.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the EEA-Switzerland report, because with this report the European Parliament disrespects the legislation of the Swiss State and, even worse, disrespects the will of the Swiss people, as expressed in a referendum, on the issue of cross-border free movement of people.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The EEA Agreement is a key factor for economic growth and the most far-reaching, comprehensive instrument to extend the single market to third countries; taking into account the internal developments in the EU, it has proven to be a solid, efficient and well-functioning agreement ensuring the integrity of the single market also in the long term. The obstacles to cross-border professional mobility have to be removed in order to deepen the internal market. Cooperation under the Agreement on mutual recognition in relation to conformity assessment is satisfactory, but the functioning of the agreement could be substantially improved if Switzerland were to pledge to update it consistently in line with developments in EU law.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. \u2012 The internal market has entered a "critical" phase, partly due to internal shortcomings and untapped potential, partly due to external challenges. In my view, looking at the EU and Switzerland, the differences start with the administrative burden of entry, and the inflexibility of the labour market, I am thinking of the Swiss quota, only reduces the possibility of growth. It is to be welcomed that the integration of financial markets has made great progress in recent years, but in my opinion this was due to global trends rather than the good functioning of integration policies. I voted in favour of this report, because I, too, see that in the development of better regulation it is not only about how uniform its content is, but also how its effectiveness can be achieved and monitored. The proposals contained in the report are of particular importance for integration policies, as they concern several sectors and several policies. The regulatory environment must therefore be simple, consistent and easy to enforce, but it can only be the right solution for a genuine single market.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. The free movement of persons in the internal market is central to economic growth under the EEA Agreement with Switzerland. The existing relations between the EU and Switzerland already allow sufficient flexibility and contribute to stability and prosperity for the benefit of all citizens and businesses. We will not renegotiate it.

name: Juan Carlos GIRAUTA VIDAL
text: in writing. The four Member States of the European Free Trade Association (Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway and Switzerland) are important trading partners of the European Union, with Switzerland and Norway respectively being the fourth and fifth largest EU partners by volume of trade. While relations between the EU and Iceland, Liechtenstein and Norway are based on the European Economic Area (EEA), relations between the EU and Switzerland, which is not part of the EEA, are currently based on more than one hundred sectoral agreements. The benefits of the internal market explain why this report notes with concern the increase in the transposition deficit in the EEA Member States and welcomes the opening of negotiations on an institutional framework agreement with Switzerland. It is therefore a report which, in a constructive spirit, seeks to contribute to the deepening of the internal market between these countries and the EU and which deserves my vote in favour.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted abstention, since the report, despite giving Switzerland a touch of attention for its policy of free movement and professional recognition, the fact that Switzerland is a tax haven raises doubts about integration into the single European economic area. And this report makes no reference to this fact.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, along with my colleagues in the European Parliamentary Labour Party, because it addresses the obstacles of that Iceland, Norway, Liechtenstein and Switzerland face in regard to the full implementation of the internal market and its governing rules.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the report on EEA-Switzerland full implementation of the internal market. Primarily, the EEA Agreement is considered to be solid and well-functioning in ensuring the integrity of the Single Market, although there is a transportation deficit. Moreover, it is important to achieve the mutual benefit of Switzerland and the EU by implementing the all-encompassing bilateral agreement, which would allow to cope with the new challenges. And, above all, we should ensure that the Swiss authorities would treat the Europeans the same way, without any discrimination.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I vote in favour of this report due to the fact that the EEA Agreement is a key factor for economic growth and the most far-reaching, comprehensive instrument to extent the single market to third countries. Additionally taking into account the internal developments in the EU, it has proven to be a solid, efficient and well-functioning agreement ensuring the integrity of the single market. Lastly the strong relations between the EU, the EEA EFTA countries and Switzerland go beyond economic integration and the extension of the single market but contribute to stability and prosperity to the benefit of all citizens and businesses.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. The report deals with the state of implementation of regulations in the countries of the Common European Economic Area and Switzerland. The Swiss referendum on migration made him particularly explosive. The Commission wants to put pressure on Switzerland by suspending the negotiations of various agreements and force it to give in. The rapporteur has followed this line and has initially chosen very harsh wording. I am in favour of the introduction of referendums and, of course, also of the obligation for politicians to implement their results. States must be able to renegotiate existing agreements which, in their view, are no longer up-to-date. That is why I have opposed the Commission and the large groups in the European Parliament and have pushed for amendments. We have succeeded in getting the verbal sharpness out of the report, as has Mr Schwab's specific call for the electricity agreement, which is particularly important for southern German industry, to be blocked. Unfortunately, however, there is still a general demand for sanctions and blockade positions and little willingness to seek dialogue. That is why I voted against the report. Incidentally - and this is my ceterum censeo - I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. We voted abstention, since the report, despite giving Switzerland a touch of attention for its policy of free movement and professional recognition, the fact that Switzerland is a tax haven raises doubts about integration into the single European economic area. And this report makes no reference to this fact.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the proposal for a European Parliament resolution on the European Economic Area and Switzerland: an obstacle to the full realisation of the internal market, because I believe that the expansion of the single market is essential for the European Union, for its Member States and for third countries, and that the EEA ensures the integrity of such a market.  However, the implementation of relevant single market legislation should be improved and technical adjustments adopted while respecting the principles of fairness and reciprocity. I believe that established relations between EEA Member States, the EU and others go beyond creating a single market and economic prosperity, and also contribute to comprehensive progress and stability.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. Following the referendum on 9 February 2014 in Switzerland on a law against mass immigration, the European Union wants to use retaliatory measures. It rejects the Swiss' request to renegotiate the agreement for the free movement of people. The rapporteur clearly calls for pressure on the Swiss authorities and denies the will of the people, who spoke in the referendum. A staunch supporter of etst sovereignty, I voted against it.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which reminds Switzerland of its obligations following the signing of a partnership with the European Union on free movement (signed in 1999 and in force since 2002). Switzerland must respect its international commitments.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I reject this report because it seeks to put pressure on Switzerland, even though it merely exercises its own rights on its own territory.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Writing. The report deals with the state of implementation of regulations in the countries of the Common European Economic Area and Switzerland. The Swiss referendum on migration made him particularly explosive. The EU Commission wants to put pressure on Switzerland by suspending the negotiations of various agreements and force it to give in. The rapporteur, Mr Schwab (CDU), has followed this line and has initially chosen very harsh wording. As a member of the ALFA, however, I stand for the introduction of Swiss-style referendums and, of course, for the obligation for politicians to implement their results. States must be able to renegotiate existing agreements which, in their view, are no longer up-to-date. That is why I have opposed the Commission and the large groups in the European Parliament and have pushed for amendments. We have succeeded in getting the verbal sharpness out of the report, as has Mr Schwab's specific call for the electricity agreement, which is particularly important for southern German industry, to be blocked. Unfortunately, however, there is still a general demand for sanctions and blockade positions and little willingness to seek dialogue. That is why I voted against the report.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this proposal. The EEA Agreement is a key driving point for economic growth, as well as the broader global instrument for extending the single market to third countries. I fully agree with the principles of this act, as they aim to defend the integrity of the single market and to ensure reciprocity of trade. Restrictions on the free movement of persons imposed following a referendum in Switzerland risk creating an imbalance and undermining the benefits of the agreements for EU Member States. It is therefore called for the existing agreements to be respected, particularly on the free movement of persons.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution "EEA-Switzerland: obstacles to the full implementation of the internal market". A real attack on Switzerland's sovereignty, this report follows the referendum organised by Switzerland on 9 February 2014, calling for the adoption of a law "against mass immigration". The Swiss people have been very clear in favour of this bill, but the European Union, as a great democrat and as a retaliatory measure, has rejected the Swiss confederation's request to renegotiate the ALCP (agreement for the free movement of persons), an essential pillar of the single market. The rapporteur is shockingly ignoring the will of the people, as the European Union is used to. Mr Schwab is clearly calling for pressure from the Swiss authorities to review their copy and prevent them from putting too long into practice what they were elected for. What arrogance!

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution because it is a scandalous text that dares to reproach Switzerland for holding a referendum on immigration. The Swiss have democratically decided to oppose any new immigration and the European Parliament does not have to criticise their choice. Instead, he should ponder Switzerland's lesson in democracy!

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. This report adequately expresses its concern about the obstacles to worker mobility imposed unilaterally on its European neighbours by Switzerland.  However, the EU itself denies solidarity to its neighbours, closing its external and internal borders and selectively recognizing the right of mobility to its own citizens, as the expulsions of Spaniards and Italians in countries such as Belgium have made clear. That is why I cannot share the interference tone of the report, nor the way in which it matches workers' rights with the pseudo-freedoms of the single market. For all this, I abstained.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. The report deals with the state of implementation of regulations in the countries of the Common European Economic Area and Switzerland. The Swiss referendum on migration made him particularly explosive. The EU Commission wants to put pressure on Switzerland by suspending the negotiations of various agreements and force it to give in. The rapporteur, Mr Schwab (CDU), has followed this line and has initially chosen very harsh wording. In doing so, however, the democratically expressed will of the Swiss is being disregarded. This is contrary to the EU's fundamental values. States must be able to renegotiate existing agreements which, in their view, are no longer up-to-date. It is true that we have managed to get the verbal sharpness out of the report, as well as Mr Schwab's specific call for the electricity agreement, which is particularly important for southern German industry, to be blocked. Unfortunately, however, there is still a general demand for sanctions and blockade positions and little willingness to seek dialogue. That is why I voted against the report.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against this report, which criticises the EFTA States for adopting too small a part of the Community acquis. On the contrary, the EFTA model should inspire the European Union and abolish the vast majority of its swelled acquis. The longer the EU is reregulated in this way, the longer it will be in economic trouble.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The purpose of the European Economic Area (EEA) is to expand the EU internal market to the Member States of the European Free Trade Association (EFTA). The EEA Agreement is a major element of economic growth and the most far-reaching instrument for extending the single market to third countries.  It is believed that it has proven to be a stable and effective, well-functioning agreement that guarantees the integrity of the single market in the long term. Strong relations between EU, EEA and EFTA countries and Switzerland are considered to go beyond the economic integration and expansion of the single market and contribute to stability and prosperity for the benefit of all citizens and businesses, including SMEs. Four EFTA Member States (Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway and Switzerland) are important trading partners of the European Union. Norway is the EU's fifth largest trading partner if trade volumes are looked at. Relations between the EU and the three EFTA Member States (Iceland, Liechtenstein and Norway) are based on the European Economic Area (EEA), which allows participation in the internal market.  I supported MeP Schwab's report because it highlights the importance of a proper functioning of the single market in order to achieve a level playing field and create new jobs. I welcome the participation of the Countries of the European Economic Area and Switzerland in the internal market of the European Union, which will contribute to growth, competitiveness and job creation.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 Switzerland is not and will not be a member of the EU in the near future, although Switzerland is in the same economic zone with the EU, .c. All this means that economic integration is possible and must be supported. The creation of an internal market will win all, from eea citizens, citizens of the Swiss Confederation, business and international companies. Free trade must be borderless. I voted in favour.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am abstaining from voting on the report 'EEA-Switzerland: Obstacles to the full implementation of the internal market', because this report is not sufficiently documented.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report which reiterates that the free movement of persons is one of the fundamental freedoms and a pillar of the single market and that it always has been an inseparable part of and precondition for the bilateral approach between the EU and Switzerland; therefore fully supports the EU’s rejection of July 2014 of the Swiss Authorities’ request to renegotiate the FMPA with a view to introducing a quota or a national preference system; notes with concern reports concerning the application by some firms and cantons of a national preference system, and points out that such a practice is at odds with the agreement on freedom of movement.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this report! This aberrant report goes against the freedom of peoples to express themselves democratically. On 9 February 2014 Switzerland voted in a referendum on mass immigration: its people voted in favour of the introduction of immigration quotas and for the implementation of controls. The European Union strongly opposes this result, which it considers contrary to the principle of the free movement of persons. This report proposes to put pressure on the Swiss authorities to change their minds and/or ignore the outcome of this referendum. It seems necessary to recall that Switzerland is not part of the EU and therefore has no reason to submit to the requirements of Brussels. With this scandalous text the EU shows, once again, all its contempt for democracy.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome my colleague's motion for a resolution on the EEA-Switzerland: obstacles to the full implementation of the internal market. I consider this proposal to be a valuable instrument for extending and strengthening further agreements on Switzerland's participation in the internal market. The EEA Agreement, if properly implemented, can greatly contribute to the EU's economic growth.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. As the report is a renewed attempt to put pressure on Switzerland to assert sovereign rights, for example with regard to immigration control, this report must be rejected.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The report states that "there is a need to create a single market (...) to boost growth and competitiveness and create new jobs to revitalise the European economy." It states that, in order for its implementation to be effective, single market legislation must be transposed into the Member States of the European Union, the European Economic Area States and the European Free Trade Association states. However, the 2014 Swiss referendum "Against Mass Immigration" and the decisions taken on 11 February 2015 by the Swiss Federal Council run counter to the obligations resulting from the Agreement on the Free Movement of Persons (ALCP), which hinders the integration of the internal market. The report therefore criticises this Swiss decision and recalls that the free movement of people is one of the fundamental freedoms and a pillar of the single market of which it has always been an inseparable part and an indispensable precondition.  I am voting against this report and the extension of the single market while approving its reservations about Swiss migration policy.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. Following the referendum on 9 February 2014 in Switzerland on a law against mass immigration, the European Union wants to use retaliatory measures. It rejects the Swiss' request to renegotiate the agreement for the free movement of people. The rapporteur clearly calls for pressure on the Swiss authorities and denies the will of the people, who spoke in the referendum. Being for the sovereignty of the peoples, the member voted against.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this European Parliament resolution on the European Economic State and the obstacles to the full completion of the internal market. The EEA Agreement is essential for the creation of a competitive single market that boosts growth, with the capacity to create jobs and the revitalisation of the European economy. I therefore welcome the opening of negotiations with the Swiss Confederation for the development of a future framework for in-depth cooperation. I share the conviction that these relations can be deepened for the benefit of both sides, through a review of existing sectoral agreements and in full compliance with the fundamental principles of the EU, always with benefit to both parties. However, I register displeasure following the interruption of negotiations on Switzerland's participation in the Erasmus+programme, following which transitional arrangements were introduced by Switzerland. I express concern that such measures could affect the mobility of higher education students between the EU and Switzerland.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in support of the report. The question of this report is how effectively the EEA agreement has been in establishing markets between the EU and Iceland, Norway, and Lichtenstein. The report shows that while the overall integration through the EEA Agreement has been positive and expansive.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. Switzerland is an important partner for the European Union. It is therefore essential that these relationships are constantly strengthened. Today, some obstacles persist and hinder this rapprochement. I am particularly concerned about the growing efforts to challenge the free movement of people between the two spaces. This would significantly hinder relationships. I am therefore pleased that the European Union has rejected Switzerland's request to review the current provisions in order to introduce the idea of quotas. More than ever, we must continue to be vigilant while strengthening the dialogue to ensure that this fundamental principle is undeniably in-between-entered at the very heart of relations between Switzerland and the European Union.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on EEA-Switzerland: with regards to the full implementation of the internal market, which calls to step up efforts to transpose, fully implement and enforce internal market legislation.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The report charts the links between the EU, the other EEA Member States (Liechtensten, Iceland, Norway, Andorra, Monaco and San Marina) and Switzerland, which is not participating in the EEA, as obstacles to the implementation of the single internal market in the EFTA area. Among a number of minor problems and obstacles, the main concern is the measures introduced by the Swiss Confederation to prevent the free movement of persons, since the movement of persons is one of the pillars of fundamental rights and the single market, and that it has always been an integral part and a prerequisite for a bilateral approach between the EU and Switzerland. The report calls for steps to remove obstacles to the full implementation of the internal market.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 I would like to point out that the EEA is a key factor in economic growth and the most ambitious and complete instrument for extending the single market to third countries and that, in view of developments in the internal situation in the EU, it has proved to be a sound, effective and functional agreement capable of ensuring the integrity of the single market in the long term. I would point out that relations between the EU, the EEA and EFTA countries and Switzerland go beyond economic integration and the enlargement of the single market and contribute to stability and prosperity, benefiting citizens and businesses. I call on Switzerland to respect the obligations arising from the ALCP, as it is one of the fundamental freedoms and a pillar of the single market and has always been an inseparable part and a precondition for the EU/Switzerland bilateral approach. It is important to note that any restriction on the free movement of persons risks creating an imbalance and jeopardising the benefits of agreements for EU Member States.  I call on Switzerland to make the necessary conditions for full participation of students in the ERASMUS+ programme, ensuring reciprocity of exchanges and non-penalisation of young people.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This report follows the referendum held in Switzerland on 9 February 2014 calling for the adoption of a law "against mass immigration" and in which the Swiss people had very clearly voted in favour of this bill. But European Union leaders, unable to support democracy against the treaties, rejected the Swiss confederation's request to renegotiate the agreement for the free movement of people.  This report is an outrageous attack on Switzerland's sovereignty and popular will. The rapporteur Schwab clearly calls for pressure from the Swiss authorities to review their copy and prevent them from putting too long into practice what they were elected for. The arrogance of this report is finally unbearable. So I voted against it.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report that calls for negotiations to be continued with Switzerland with a view to establishing an institutional framework that will provide greater legal certainty for both Switzerland and the EU and help Switzerland to incorporate the necessary EU legislation.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I have refused to support this report because it is a renewed attempt to put pressure on Switzerland to assert public rights, for example with regard to immigration control.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Switzerland's participation in the European Union's internal market is positive as it promotes growth, competitiveness and job creation. At the same time, it is important to address concerns such as Switzerland's unwillingness to fully comply with the agreed principle of free movement of people and the challenges of student mobility.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the report for two reasons. The first is because I believe that the EU should respect the democratic will of the Swiss people to renegotiate the Free Movement of Persons Agreement (FMPA) with the EU and regain control of their own borders. The second reason is because I do not agree that the EU should criticise EEA states for not transposing all single market legislation into their own national legislation. The EU should respect the will of EEA states when certain aspects of single market legislation are not desired.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to vote in favour of the Swiss Confederation continuing to take policies and actions for the complete removal of obstacles to the full implementation of the internal market.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ The Agreement on the European Economic Area is the most far-reaching and comprehensive instrument for extending the single market to third countries, which has also proven to be a stable and effective and well-functioning agreement that ensures the integrity of the single market in the long term.  Strong relations between EU, EEA and EFTA countries and Switzerland go beyond economic integration and expansion of the single market and contribute to stability and prosperity for the benefit of all citizens and businesses, including SMEs. Relations between the EU and Switzerland have become stronger, better and longer lasting and have contributed to peace, prosperity and growth in Europe over the past decades. These relations can deepen for the benefit of both sides through a comprehensive review of sectoral agreements in full compliance with EU principles and contribute to a number of common features and interests.  However, barriers, such as restriction of freedom of movement (one of the EU's fundamental freedoms), suspensions of negotiations on Switzerland's participation in the ERASMUS+ programme, the belated implementation of the Directive on the recognition of professional qualifications, undermine the strong bilateral relationship that existed and still exists between the EU and Switzerland. Considering it important to continue implementing EU law in order to maintain the strength of the Single European Market, I support this report.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This report follows the referendum held in Switzerland on 9 February 2014 calling for the adoption of a law "against mass immigration" and in which the Swiss people had very clearly voted in favour of this bill. But EU leaders, unable to support democracy against the treaties, rejected the Swiss confederation's request to renegotiate the agreement for the free movement of people.  This report is an outrageous attack on Switzerland's sovereignty and popular will. The rapporteur Schwab clearly calls for pressure from the Swiss authorities to review their copy and prevent them from putting too long into practice what they were elected for. The arrogance of this report is finally unbearable. So I voted against it.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. - The Agreement on the European Economic Area (EEA) is the most important element of the EU's economic growth through the extension of the single market to third countries. In order for this growth to be possible, an efficient single market is needed, which can only be achieved through the implementation of legislation on the same.  The obstacle to the full realisation of the internal market is certainly the outcome of the citizens' initiative in Switzerland and the Decision of the Federal Council of Switzerland of 11 February 2015, which relates to the implementation of draft laws and new accompanying measures and conflicts with the obligations arising from the Agreement on the Free Movement of Persons. The aforementioned agreement between the Swiss Confederation and the EU/EFTA countries on the free movement and residence of persons of those countries, as well as on the recognition of professional diplomas, the right to acquire real estate and the coordination of social security systems, has been supplemented year after year and the latest version also contains a section on the rights of Croatian citizens.  I welcome the introduction of measures, by the Swiss Confederation, that would avoid discrimination against Croatian citizens, but I also support colleague Schwab's report stressing the need to ratify the Protocol on the Extension of the Agreement on the Free Movement of Persons and to the Republic of Croatia in view of the fact that Croatia, now for more than two years, is a full member of the EU and thus must be included in all agreements.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 The issue of so-called "frontier workers" affects hundreds of thousands of European citizens, many of whom are Italian nationals. I believe it is right that the Union should use all the instruments at its possession to put its relations between the European Economic Area (EEA) and the Swiss Confederation in order. The draft report aims, in fact, to give an overall view of the current issues concerning the implementation of the internal market between the EEA countries and Switzerland, underlining the positive effects that a fully implemented and functioning internal market would have on the prosperity and growth of all these countries, and on relations between these countries themselves. Two of the main points of the report are: the negotiation of an institutional agreement with Switzerland and the consequences of the 2014 Swiss referendum (so-called 'Against mass immigration'), as well as the consequent decisions by the Swiss Government regarding the agreement on the free movement of persons. I supported the rapporteur's proposal through a vote in favour in this House.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. Switzerland is a key economic, social and technological partner of the European Union. The agreement between Switzerland and the European Economic Area has facilitated trade between the two areas. However, some obstacles remain and hinder the full implementation of the internal market. I voted in favour of the report, which provided an overview of the situation and proposed some improvements.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The various trade agreements concluded between the European Union and the Swiss Confederation, on the one hand, and the Agreement on the European Economic Area, on the other, make it possible for the free movement of persons, goods, capital and services within the Internal Market of the European Union. Nevertheless, there are still barriers preventing the full completion of the single market between the EU and third countries and which therefore demean the conditions for economic growth. To this end, the rapporteur has identified the constraints that prevent the proper functioning of the agreements, and concluded that the implementation of single market legislation could be improved and accelerated. In order to preserve the integrity of the single market, I voted in favour of the report which calls on the EEA/EFTA States to redouble their efforts to ensure the transposition of the relevant legal acts into national law.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. The resolution considers the four EEMM of the European Free Trade Association (Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway and Switzerland) to be important trading partners and contends that the EEA Agreement is a key element of growth. The resolution assesses progress in the adoption of the relevant acquis in the EEA Agreement, as well as the recent agreement on the principles for the transposition of the European Regulations creating the European Supervisory Authorities. However, it expresses certain concerns. With regard to Liechtenstein, because of its transposition deficit and certain restrictions on the recruitment of EEA nationals. With regard to Iceland, because of the transposition deficit, the highest. As for Norway, the increase in the transposition deficit and the need to improve energy cooperation. As regards Switzerland, it urges the Swiss Government to redouble its efforts to advance the institutional framework agreement and insists that the free movement of persons is one of the fundamental freedoms and pillar of the single market, and therefore supports the Community refusal to renegotiate the Agreement on free movement in order to introduce a system of national quotas or preference.  That's why I voted for it.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. As Switzerland's participation was called into question in a popular vote in 1992, relations between Switzerland and the European Union are now based on more than 100 sectoral agreements that allow a high degree of integration of Switzerland into the internal market. Having said that, since the interruption of negotiations on Switzerland's participation in the Erasmus programme, the European Parliament, through the vote of this report, has expressed concern that these measures are likely to affect the mobility of higher education between the EU and Switzerland and has called on Switzerland and the EU to do everything possible to fulfil the necessary conditions for their participation in the Erasmus programme in order to ensure reciprocity of trade and do not penalize students.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The member states of the European Free Trade Association (EFTA) (Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway and Switzerland) are the EU's main trading partners, and their relations are based on the European Economic Area (EEA), which provides for participation in the internal market. Switzerland's participation in the EEA Agreement was contested by a popular vote in 1992 and therefore relations between Switzerland and the EU are currently based on more than 100 sectoral agreements that provide for a greater degree of integration. In order to achieve the full completion of the internal market, it is essential that, in addition to the improvements in the rapid incorporation of the acquis communautaire and the involvement of the EEA States of the EFTA in European programmes and agencies, rapid and correct transposition, implementation and implementation of single market legislation. I voted in favour of this report which, with regard to the current political reality in the Swiss Confederation, namely the results of the people's initiative of 9/02/2014 'against mass emigration' and the request for renegotiation of the Agreement on the Free Movement of Persons which represents a fundamental pillar of the internal market, presents a number of reservations and concerns with which I agree.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree with Mr Syod's proposal. Schwab, on the implementation of the internal market in the EEA-Switzerland countries, which highlights how the positive effects of an efficient internal market can ensure internal growth in the same countries and increase relations between states. I think it is important for Switzerland to respect the agreements it has concluded with the European Union. That is why I have chosen to vote in favour of this proposal.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted abstention, since the report, despite giving Switzerland a touch of attention for its policy of free movement and professional recognition, the fact that Switzerland is a tax haven raises doubts about integration into the single European economic area. And this report makes no reference to this fact.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. This report adequately expresses its concern about the obstacles to worker mobility imposed unilaterally on its European neighbours by Switzerland.  However, the EU itself denies solidarity to its neighbours, closing its external and internal borders and selectively recognizing the right of mobility to its own citizens, as the expulsions of Spaniards and Italians in countries such as Belgium have made clear. That is why I cannot share the interference tone of the report, nor the way in which it matches workers' rights with the pseudo-freedoms of the single market. For all this, I abstained.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as it heavily criticizes EEA states for not implementing Single Market Legislation. It also supports the EU’s rejection of the Swiss Authorities’ request to renegotiate the Free Movement of Peoples agreement.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution today because it addresses the obstacles of that Iceland, Norway, Liechtenstein and Switzerland have regarding the full implementation of the internal market and its rules.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ This explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Writing. The report deals with the state of implementation of regulations in the countries of the Common European Economic Area and Switzerland. The Swiss referendum on migration made him particularly explosive. The EU Commission wants to put pressure on Switzerland by suspending the negotiations of various agreements and force it to give in. The rapporteur, Mr Schwab (CDU), has followed this line and has initially chosen very harsh wording. As a member of the ALFA, however, I stand for the introduction of Swiss-style referendums and, of course, for the obligation for politicians to implement their results. States must be able to renegotiate existing agreements which, in their view, are no longer up-to-date. That is why I have opposed the Commission and the large groups in the European Parliament and have pushed for amendments. We have succeeded in getting the verbal sharpness out of the report, as has Mr Schwab's specific call for the electricity agreement, which is particularly important for southern German industry, to be blocked. Unfortunately, however, there is still a general demand for sanctions and blockade positions and little willingness to seek dialogue. That is why I voted against the report.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing \u2012 I appreciate the strong and long-term relations between the EU and Switzerland, as well as the EEA EFTA countries. The EEA Agreement is a key driver and has contributed to increasing peace, prosperity and growth in Europe. The European Union should continue to strive to expand the single market, create a level playing field, create new jobs and promote entrepreneurship, including by supporting small and medium-sized enterprises. In order to support the development of EU relations with EEA countries, I supported this report.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. I support this report because Switzerland, as a member of the European Free Trade Association (EFTA), is an important trading partner of the European Union. By trade volume, Switzerland is in fact the EU's fourth most important trading partner.  Also of utmost importance for the European Union is the European Economic Area, i.e. the single market whose creation would lead to even greater economic growth and Europe's recovery from recession and crisis, but this requires the implementation of single single market legislation, in an adequate manner, while quality implementation should be ensured to achieve all the benefits of such a market throughout Europe.  In order to achieve all of the above, the barriers that now exist and should aim to fully realise the internal market should be eliminated, and this report proposes to make this happen, and I have therefore supported it.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
