text: Written. ‒ I support a report that controls the implementation of the regulations of the Agreement on the European Economic Area. The report focuses primarily on Switzerland, but also covers other countries in the Agreement on the European Economic Area. After Switzerland unilaterally conducted a contentious referendum on immigrant quotas, it became clear that they violated the provisions of bilateral agreements with the EU. Since the same referendum took place at a time when it became clear that the Republic of Croatia should approach the boundless space of the European Union, we cannot help but see the unilateralism of the approach towards the citizens of our country. Not wanting to enter into the domestic politics of any country, especially those outside the EU countries, we express our hope that Swiss economic policy will not be set back by implementing this kind of policy. The report also validly covers other countries with which the European Union wishes to have a smooth economic policy and a space of economic cooperation, and insists on removing all obstacles to the smooth transport and mobility of potential labour and citizens within the European Economic Area.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: in writing ‒ I abstained from voting on the report. I agree with many of her observations, but I do not agree with her view on restricting immigration in Switzerland on the basis of the valid result of the referendum. The report shows how reciprocity between the EEA and Switzerland is essential and how reducing migration can bring imbalances and jeopardise the benefits of agreements for EU Member States. Restricting immigration in Switzerland is, of course, unfortunate, but given that it is a democratic decision by the citizens, it must be absolutely respected. Furthermore, all cross-border trade is mutually beneficial and therefore talk of any restriction of reciprocity or the benefit of cross-border trade is not appropriate.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the EEA-Switzerland: obstacles to the full introduction of the internal market, which has two parts. It rates economic relations with Iceland, Norway, Liechtenstein and Switzerland as good, noting, for example, that Switzerland and Norway are the EU's fourth and fifth most important trading partners by volume. However, it also concerns the subject of the free movement of persons, which Switzerland, as a State participating in Schengen cooperation, has undertaken to implement. However, the steps taken by Switzerland at the turn of 2014 and 2015 run counter to the obligations under the Free Movement of Persons Agreement. The issue of migration of third-country nationals cannot be confused with the free movement of persons. The issue of migration is certainly extremely complex, but the current rules on the free movement of people as a fundamental pillar of the single market must be respected and applied in a non-discriminatory manner.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The EU must respect the laws of the States and much more respect the will of the citizens, as expressed through referendums.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 As an alternate member of the delegation responsible for relations with Switzerland and Norway and delegated to the EU-Iceland Joint Parliamentary Committee and the EEA Joint Parliamentary Committee, I agree with the report that the EEA Agreement is a key factor in economic growth and the most far-reaching comprehensive instrument for the expansion of the single market to third countries. I consider it important that meaningful single market legislation is applied in a timely manner and with the least possible time-out by efta states in the EEA, and I share the view that this process can be further improved and accelerated. I also share the view that the strong relations between the EU, the EEA EFTA States and Switzerland go beyond economic integration and the expansion of the single market and contribute to stability and prosperity for the benefit of all citizens and businesses, including SMEs. I believe that the gradual transposition and implementation of internal market legislation, as well as the ever-thriving and time-resistant relationship between the EU and Switzerland, have contributed to peace, prosperity and growth in Europe in recent decades. For all these, I supported the report.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 European countries such as Switzerland, Norway, Iceland, Liechtenstein, Monaco, San Marino, Andorra are very important partners of the European Union, which is why it is so important to constantly monitor their relations and address existing problems. Relations between the Union and the countries mentioned above go beyond economic integration and the enlargement of the single market, and they also contribute to stability and prosperity for the benefit of all citizens and businesses.  Parliament's report indicates that there are still problems in relations between partners, in particular regarding the transposition of EU legislation, but also internal national policies on migration or transport issues that are contrary to EU policy. I have therefore chosen to vote in favour of the EP report because it adequately outlines the existing problems and points to the action that the Commission should take to remove these problems.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Economic Area (SEE) is the opportunity offered by the European Union to conduct cooperation in an institutionalised manner with the Member States of the European Free Trade Association (EFTA). Three of these, Iceland, Liechtenstein and Norway, have become full members of this continental economic structure, supporting the development of European economic relations on the basis of a common market. In the case of Switzerland, non-participation in the SEE has been compensated over the past two decades by the signing of more than a hundred sectoral agreements. In order to harmonise the legislative legislation between the EU and the EFTA States, a number of obstacles related to access to the labour market, disaster avoidance, energy policy and free movement must be overcome.  Many problems persist in the relationship with Switzerland, which has chosen, through referendums, not to cooperate with the EU in a number of important areas, such as education, free movement, transport and agriculture. From this point of view, there is obviously a need for more cooperation and negotiations to overcome existing bottlenecks, rather than populist manipulation of sensitive topics. For these reasons, I support the adoption of this document, which is an important step towards strengthening the European Economic Area.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which follows the INI report adopted in 2010 on the same topic as well as the 2012 resolution on Swiss quotas on the number of residence permits granted to nationals of Poland, Lithuania, Latvia, Estonia, Slovenia, Slovakia, the Czech Republic and Hungary. The EEA Agreement is considered as an effective instrument to extend the Single Market to third countries. However, we can be concerned about increasing EU rules transposition deficit, which could jeopardize the functioning of the internal market. The report therefore calls third countries to remedy this situation. It also deplores the unilateral measures (administrative fees or obligatory bank guarantees) which restrict the provision of services in Switzerland.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. The report primarily refers to obstacles to the full realisation of the internal market between the European Union and Switzerland. While the rapporteur constantly stresses the need for better and stronger relations between the European Union and Switzerland, he expresses concern in particular at the high number of adjustment requirements and exceptions leading to delays and possible fragmentation of the single market. Since the free movement of persons is one of the fundamental freedoms and pillar of the single market, I believe that avoiding the ratification of the Protocol on the Extension of the Agreement on the Free Movement of Persons to Croatia and the introduction of unilateral measures discriminates exclusively against citizens of the Republic of Croatia. Therefore, I consider it unacceptable the Swiss introduction of unilateral measures to avoid discrimination against Croatian citizens, and I agree that the same cannot be accepted as a substitute for the ratification of the Protocol on the Extension of the Agreement on the Free Movement of Persons to Croatia. Although I wholeheartedly and fully support the right of every sovereign state to respect the result of the referendum, i.e. the will of its citizens, in this case unfortunately there has been direct discrimination against exclusively Croatian citizens, which I cannot support. Switzerland could also ensure the result of the referendum by respecting the relevant provisions of the bilateral agreement on the free movement of persons, which it unfortunately failed to do, thereby prolonging direct discrimination against citizens of the Republic of Croatia for an unlimited period of time. Therefore, the report received my support.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. The EU has concluded more than 120 bilateral and sectoral agreements with Switzerland, the most important of which is the FREE Trade Agreement signed in 1972. This is an agreement on the free movement of persons, transport by land and air, technical barriers to trade, public procurement, research and agriculture. The draft of this report focuses on the functioning of the free movement of persons between the European Union and Switzerland, which refers to the agreement mentioned above. I supported the report because it supports the deepening of economic relations.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted abstention, since the report, despite giving Switzerland a touch of attention for its policy of free movement and professional recognition, the fact that Switzerland is a tax haven raises doubts about integration into the single European economic area. And this report makes no reference to this fact.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Writing. The report deals with the state of implementation of regulations in the countries of the Common European Economic Area and Switzerland. The Swiss referendum on migration made him particularly explosive. The EU Commission wants to put pressure on Switzerland by suspending the negotiations of various agreements and force it to give in. The rapporteur, Mr Schwab (CDU), has followed this line and has initially chosen very harsh wording. As a Member of the ALFA, however, I am in favour of the introduction of Swiss-style referendums and, of course, the obligation for politicians to implement their results. States must be able to renegotiate existing agreements which, in their view, are no longer up-to-date. That is why I have opposed the Commission and the large groups in the European Parliament and have pushed for amendments. We have succeeded in getting the verbal sharpness out of the report, as has Mr Schwab's specific call for the electricity agreement, which is particularly important for southern German industry, to be blocked. Unfortunately, however, there is still a general demand for sanctions and blockade positions and little willingness to seek dialogue. That is why I voted against the report and also recommended that the ECR should oppose the adoption of this report.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The report follows the referendum organised by Switzerland on 9 February 2014 calling for the adoption of a law "against mass immigration". The Swiss people have been very clear in favour of this bill, but the European Union, as a great democrat and as a retaliatory measure, has rejected the Swiss confederation's request to renegotiate the ALCP (agreement for the free movement of persons), an essential pillar of the single market.  The rapporteur is shockingly ignoring the will of the people, as the European Union is used to. The German Schwab clearly calls for pressure from the Swiss authorities to revise their copy and prevent them from putting too long into practice what they were elected for.  I am voting against this odious text.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted abstention, since the report, despite giving Switzerland a touch of attention for its policy of free movement and professional recognition, the fact that Switzerland is a tax haven raises doubts about integration into the single European economic area. And this report makes no reference to this fact.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to resolve the freedom of access of Community citizens to Switzerland, after the referendum that Switzerland made in 2014 under the name of "against mass immigration".

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The report criticises the introduction of unilateral measures taken by Switzerland in the context of the Agreement on the free movement of persons; calls for it to continue to implement EU legislation. Despite the emphasis of political interference on Switzerland, but also on the other countries that are part of this Agreement, with which we do not agree, we believe that it should be the decision of the people of each country to agree or not to any agreement. That way, we abstained.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. As the report is a renewed attempt to put pressure on Switzerland to assert sovereign rights, for example with regard to immigration control, this report must be rejected.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. Together with my colleagues from the ECR, I abstained from voting on this report. The ECR supports the free movement of persons as one of the fundamental freedoms and a crucial pillar of the EU's internal market. However, the Group also believes that the free movement of people should be able to respond to the demand and supply of the labour market. The ECR also points out that, while the free movement of persons is an important contribution to the internal market, it is only one of many components of the legal relationship between the EU and Switzerland. As it does not take this into account, the report has shortcomings.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 Broadly speaking, this report analyzes relations with Switzerland on the Agreement on the European Economic Area, which provides for the country's participation in the single market.  The report criticises the introduction of unilateral measures taken by Switzerland in the context of the Agreement on the free movement of persons; calls for it to continue to implement EU legislation. Despite the emphasis of political interference on Switzerland, but also on the other countries that are part of this Agreement, with which we do not agree, we believe that it should be the decision of the people of each country to agree or not to any agreement. That way, we abstained.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I opposed this report because, in my opinion, it is based on the wrong philosophy that Europe will solve the problem of migrants by allocating them according to quotas agreed by the European Commission. He'll calculate it by some not-quite-clear number. I believe that migrants should go to the country where they want, and the state that they want to choose as their own should decide, under international law, whether or not to accept them. And we should support those countries where migrants flow financially and otherwise. But an administrative solution in the form of forced quotas will not solve the problem and will only lead to the future threat to the Schengen area, because I perceive, for example, already in my country, in the Czech Republic, that such sentiments are already slowly rising. As illegal migrants flow through Europe, voices and forces against the Schengen area will grow, and I would very much hate to see that. I therefore believe that Europe should look for a different policy for dealing with migrants than the one we agreed today.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: – Mr President, I have decided to support this report because in the end it has included an amendment which we raised on the example that cities of change have begun to push in the Spanish State — and that we hope will be an example for the rest of Europe — in areas which the States have not normally reached, which our governments have not reached. In the end it was from below, it was the people who built the first humanitarian aid cordon to deal with the refugee crisis we are experiencing right now. It's critical. Yesterday Juncker uttered great words about refugees, about solidarity, about Europe. The problem is that the words, if they do not materialize in political facts and measures, are carried away by the wind and, in the end, all that remains are the fences. And Europe cannot continue to build ever higher fences. What we have to do is implement concrete, real policies, from below, to support welcome and solidarity, in order to build a different Europe.

name: Tatjana ŽDANOKA
text: – Mr President, I also voted in favour of this resolution. I find this text to be a tree with beautiful foliage but without root. Its very first recital says that an unprecedented number of people are seeking protection in the EU as a consequence of persistent conflicts, regional instability and human rights violations. But this regional instability is a consequence of what? Where is the root? It is clear why the resolution does not contain the answer to that question: many of those who – then being ministers or ruling party leaders – created this instability in Afghanistan, Iraq and Syria are now sitting here in this Chamber. They now want to shift personal responsibility onto the shoulders of taxpayers generally. Of course we have to be humane in our attitude towards refugees, but these irresponsible policymakers do not deserve our humanity.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: – Mr President, I supported this resolution on migration and refugees in Europe. This is an emergency response to an overwhelming humanitarian disaster. We cannot turn our backs on these desperate asylum seekers and the EU must reach some kind of coherent position. We thought that the financial crisis was a test for Europe and it was, but this current migrant crisis is an even greater test. Can we dig deep and act in common humanity? I commend the proposal from Pope Francis that each parish take in a refugee family and I commend all of those NGOs, ordinary individuals and local authorities who are welcoming the refugees.  But in the medium term, we need to establish safe and legal routes to the EU, and perhaps a blue card, but also we need to return those economic migrants who arrive illegally. Both actions will help to deter the people traffickers. We need to work with UNHCR to support and manage the refugee camps in North Africa, and we need to establish safe zones there also.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: – The decision adopted on migration demonstrates the European Union's inability to find a solution to the immigration crisis. Moreover, the decision adopted and the declaration of some leaders can be interpreted as an invitation to Europe. It is not thousands of refugees arriving in Europe, but hundreds of thousands of illegal immigrants, and if there is no change, millions. This year, 195,220 people crossed the border illegally in Hungary. This invasion threatens European identity, culture, the tranquility of the population. The Hungarian Government must give up the application of legislation that has lost its function, so that it can fulfil its duty, to defend the sovereignty of the country and also to protect the Schengen borders. In the course of the immigration crisis, humanitarian aspects must, of course, be enforced, but we must not lose sight of one principle: Europe belongs to europeans and Hungary to Hungarians.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: – Sur President, mijiet li mietu ġo Lampedusa u għedna biżżejjed paroli u rridu azzjoni. Mijiet mietu fil-Mediterran u għedna biżżejjed paroli, irridu azzjoni. Miet Aylan u mijiet ta' tfal bħalu li ma rajniex ritratti tagħhom u għedna biżżejjed paroli, irridu azzjoni. U ħadt gost nisma' lil Juncker jgħid l-istess ħaġa fl-ispeech tiegħu. U intant waqt li aħna qegħdin hawn inkomplu nipprodu大u aktar retorika hemm tfal, nisa u rġiel li issa, waqt li aħna qegħdin hawn, qegħdin jissieltu mal-mewt biex aħarbu mill-gwerer u mill-persezzjoni. U hi din l-Ewropa li rridu? L-Unjoni Ewropea li meta niġu għall-fatti nsibu li mhux biss hi tigra bla snien iżda Unjoni fejn 大erti Membri tagħna huma neqsin mill-valur prin大ipali: is-solidarjetà.  Għalhekk nispera li nsibu politika ta' asil u immigrazzjoni komuni biex din l-Ewropa tagħti l-għajnuna u d-dinjità lin-nies bħalna listħoqqilhom din l-għajnuna. Mingħajr ma ninsew però s-sitwazzjoni, fa大ilitajiet u d-daqs tal-Membri Stati li jirie大vu l-immigranti.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur I believe that a comprehensive mechanism for tackling refugees should be established in the European Union. Because the migration phenomenon was, is and will be on the agenda. Dealing with temporary means is short-sighted. It is also very important to build a parallel, both a common EU asylum policy and a common migration policy. The European Union is developing very strangely, as crises became part of Euro-integration. If there is no crisis, it is very difficult for the heads of state to agree. Indecision is a crisis and it is becoming obvious to everyone that it cannot be overcome without reforms.  It was with the financial crisis, now there is a refugee crisis. Gradually, we came to the conclusion that without a common asylum and migration policy, we would not be able to go further. There is no longer time for reflection, we need to take active action. I supported this document.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Mr President, the Commission’s proposal for refugee quotas is not sustainable on either moral or practical grounds.  The moral objection is that the people already in the EU are not those most in need. If we were interested in helping Syrian refugees rather than in trying to prop up Schengen, we would be taking people directly from the camps. When we take people who have already made the journey to relatively safe EU countries, we in effect reward the people traffickers. In fact, we contract out our immigration policy to them.  But there is also a very practical objection, and it is this: you cannot have quotas and, at the same time, the principle of free movement of people. Sooner or later, those refugees will get travel documents and the two things are incompatible in the long run. Schengen, like the euro, was a fair—weather system. Neither has survived its first crisis. They worked perfectly well when the sun was shining. They have crumbled beneath the storms. The EU’s monumental ambitions lie shattered: two vast and trunkless legs of stone stand in the desert.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, I really could not support this report again, because it again contains a recommendation, a request for the introduction of mandatory quotas for the realisation of refugees, and this model should become a standard solution, which, in my opinion, is not acceptable. Member States must always agree themselves, decide according to the possibilities they have. No one from above can dictate it to them.  The Czech Republic is already accepting refugees. It is our duty to be in solidarity and also accountable to the safety of our own citizens. I believe that the realocation of refugees is not the solution. I am therefore glad that the European Commission is finally coming up with another solution that will better secure the external borders of the European Union and help refugees, refugees in places where conflicts arise, and contribute to creating better conditions in the so-called safer countries. I think this is a solution that is more promising.

name: David COBURN
text: – Mr President, no-one – most of all myself – could fail to be moved by a young child dead on a Turkish beach. Members of this House have been tripping over themselves this week with hand-wringing public compassion, but we have to find practical solutions to this problem. By not trying to a halt migration, most of which is economic, we will simply cause more migration and yet more debt. Why are the Gulf States not paying for well-run camps for their fellow Muslims on the Turkish border with Syria, where they could go back to their homes once this present emergency has lapsed? This is forcing people into rubber boats bouncing around in the Mediterranean. It is absolutely atrocious.  I care about the human rights of these migrants very much, but I also care about the human rights of my fellow citizens to jobs. We must deal with this and get the Middle East to pay for itself.

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: – Mr President, every human being has the right to life, food, clothing and shelter. Every human being has the right to freedom of movement and residence within the confines of their own state. Every human, when there are just reasons in favour, should be allowed to migrate and settle in another country. The fact they are citizens of a particular state does not deprive them of membership of the human family.  These principles are as much a part of those like me, who seek to address the complex issues of immigration, asylum and economic migrants by controlled and managed migration, as they are for those who vote for motions in this Parliament today that demand uncontrolled immigration with quotas decided by a select few. The difference is that we seek to find solutions that consider the impact on existing citizens, resources and international problems, rather than throwing abusive and corrosive language, such as ‘racist’, ‘xenophobe’ or ‘extremist’ at those whose views differ to our own.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because it supports the Commission's plan for the emergency transfer of more asylum seekers from Italy, Greece and Hungary to other Member States and because it calls for the launch of a permanent system amending the Dublin regulation, which determines which Member State should process the asylum application. We are in favour of establishing a "fair and binding" distribution mechanism and taking into account the possibilities for integration and the specific situations and needs of asylum seekers.  We want Member States to welcome refugees from third countries through a mandatory resettlement programme, and we consider it a top priority for the EU and its Member States to create safe and legal avenues for refugees, such as humanitarian corridors and humanitarian visas.  In this context, we consider it necessary to amend the Visa Code and include more specific common provisions on "humanitarian visas" and call on countries to do what is necessary to make it possible to apply for asylum at their embassies and consular offices.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I abstained from voting on this resolution, aware that it is an instrument used by the Groups of the People's, Social Democratic and Liberal Party to carry out a face-washing while their governments and the European Commission keep their border policy closed. The resolution is not at the root of the problem and keeps the door open to future military interventions that will only aggravate it, as well as giving its full support to Mogherini's mediterranean militarisation plan (EUNAVFOR Med) and the Commission's insufficient plan to accommodate the small number of 160,000 people, well below the European Union's genuine reception capacity. Moreover, the resolution does not condemn key aspects of the European Commission's migration policy, such as the closure of borders and their outsourcing. We reject the continued separation of asylum seekers from migrants fleeing hunger and misery, and the latter group continues to be condemned to immediate expulsion. For all this, I cannot support an accomplice resolution of criminal policy, but I abstained in recognition of the improvement over previous resolutions that openly criminalized migrants.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this joint resolution as it calls for the European Union to step up its role in conflict resolution and calls for an EU conference to specifically address this issue.  I did not agree with the welcoming of operation support provided by FRONTEX, however, on the whole the report was positive.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. Europe is once again facing a test. Countless refugees are pouring into EU countries every day via the external borders. Instead of insisting on compliance with the Dublin procedure, it is essential to establish a common European asylum system in order to deal with this problematic situation. I welcome the report because it promotes solidarity and responsibility based on a permanent, binding system by which asylum seekers are distributed across all European countries.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. In the face of the massive influx of illegal migrants into Europe, Member States are literally overwhelmed. This report explains that it is necessary to welcome the majority of these immigrants fleeing the conflicts and persecutions of the Islamic State. It calls for quotas requiring each country to take in, house and care for these migrants. The text calls on all European actors to fight against the smuggling networks that organise human trafficking.  We strongly oppose this scandalous report. First, the conflicts in Libya, the Middle East and the Middle East are the result of an absurd foreign policy that has consisted of overthrowing totalitarian regimes for the benefit of Islamists. Secondly, it is necessary to remember that the majority of illegal immigrants are economic migrants who do not flee persecution and therefore have no vocation to stay in Europe. Thirdly, the European Union is complicit in the smugglers by not bringing migrant boats back to their port of origin. The European institutions are therefore responsible for the human tragedy that is taking place in the Mediterranean.   That is why I voted against this text.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I oppose an EU Common Asylum Policy. The situation with Syria is particularly complex, but is not helped by the European Union’s naïve and misguided approach. I had no option but to vote against this resolution, which will in my view prove to be counterproductive.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: in writing. The humanitarian refugee crisis facing Europe is one of the biggest challenges facing the European project. It is well known that the majority of human beings who today arrive traumatized at the external borders of the European Union qualify as asylum seekers, a fundamental right enshrined in international law. Against this backdrop, the only dignified attitude in line with the values and principles on which the EU is based is the reception of these people. The mismatch between the EC plans and the availability expressed by the Member States has caused a huge outage among the majority of European citizens. Although signs of a more generous stance are beginning to show, a number of measures still need to be taken to combat the causes of refugees leaving their countries of origin or an effective common asylum system replacing the ineffective Dublin Regulation, establishing humanitarian corridors or fighting hate speech. This motion for a resolution constructively welcomes these and other aspects, assertively asking the European institutions to tackle the problem with vigour and courage, and that is why I believe i fully deserve my vote.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal to transfer 40 000 people from Italy and Greece to other EU countries over the next two years. asylum seekers. I support the proposed mandatory EU resettlement mechanism and the calls for the necessary funds for the reception and integration of refugees. Better cooperation with third countries, fines for trafficking in human beings and ensuring safe and legal access to the EU asylum system are key priorities for today's refugee crisis.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. The blindness of the Eurocrats is matched only by their stubbornness. Fortunately, our peoples wake up and will not accept the Euro-globalist dictatorship any longer: "where peril grows also grows what saves" to use the famous phrase of the poet Hulderlin.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. The joint resolution, which I have approved, reiterates the need for the Union to base its immediate response on the current migration crisis on the principles of solidarity and equitable sharing of responsibilities and on a comprehensive strategy for safe and legal immigration in full respect of human rights and fundamental values. Through this resolution, a large majority of Parliament welcomes the Commission's initiatives on distribution and resettlement as well as the new emergency proposal for an increased number of asylum seekers in need of international protection covering Italy, Greece and Hungary. It also supports the Commission's announcement of a permanent allocation mechanism that would be activated in the event of an emergency. It also reiterates its commitment to open borders within the Schengen area while ensuring effective management of its external borders and stresses that the free movement of people within the Schengen area is one of the greatest achievements of European integration.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution on migration and refugees in Europe is enthusiastic about the Commission's proposals to deal with the unprecedented influx of migrants. For example, it approves the emergency relocation of more asylum seekers from Greece, Italy or Hungary (120,000) and the permanent mechanism amending the Dublin Regulation...  This proposal therefore requires a fair and mandatory distribution key in defiance of the will of the sovereign peoples who are mostly opposed to the influx of new immigrants contrary to what the media propaganda suggests.  Even though the EU had no money to cope with the misery in Greece and imposed unprecedented austerity on it, it finds money to support those of the inhabitants of third countries...  This text also aims to set up a common European asylum system and, of course, to maintain Schengen. We point to the "extreme right" that would exploit the current situation.  The EU and its leaders refuse to open their eyes to the economic and social situation that affects us and there is an urgent need to radically change the policy of migration and regain our sovereignty, so I voted against this resolution.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution does not propose effective and realistic remedies with regard to mass immigration into Europe, the consequences of which fall on our citizens, the European Union has been turning the other way for too long and is now continuing to propose completely ineffective and belated solutions. I voted against this text.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. I have voted in favour of the resolution/report. The resolution is a major step in the right direction for the European Parliament in refugee and migration policy. The report welcomes resettlement programmes and calls on Member States to increase legal routes into Europe through humanitarian visas and to make it possible to apply for visas in missions. On the other hand, there is no condemnation of Frontex, the return programme and EUNAVFOR MED. That is why I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because it supports the Commission's plan for the emergency transfer of more asylum seekers from Italy, Greece and Hungary to other Member States and because it calls for the launch of a permanent system amending the Dublin regulation, which determines which Member State should process the asylum application. We are in favour of establishing a "fair and binding" distribution mechanism and taking into account the possibilities for integration and the specific situations and needs of asylum seekers.  We want Member States to welcome refugees from third countries through a mandatory resettlement programme, and we consider it a top priority for the EU and its Member States to create safe and legal avenues for refugees, such as humanitarian corridors and humanitarian visas.  In this context, we consider it necessary to amend the Visa Code and include more specific common provisions on "humanitarian visas" and call on countries to do what is necessary to make it possible to apply for asylum at their embassies and consular offices.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 I could not support today's parliamentary resolution on migration and migrants in Europe by my vote because it does not focus on the essential problems that reflect reality. The resolution does not mention, for example, the wars in Syria or Libya as the reason for the present migration, it is not tough enough on the dismantling of trafficking networks. The Current Commission's migration package is not acceptable to the Hungarian People's Party delegation in this way because it has not been able to provide answers to the burning questions that have been ringing for weeks. It does not say unequivocally that our priority is to protect Europe's external borders. The text does not make a clear distinction between genuine refugees and immigrants who risk their own lives and those of their families in the hope of better prosperity, so that they can reach countries that are more socially prosperous and therefore do not want to cooperate with the authorities in other Member States. Nor does the allocation mechanism under the quotas included in the package provide a sufficient solution to the current situation. the majority of immigrants will continue to do so after allocating quotas, as soon as possible, to states where they can expect greater social assistance. And there is no point in talking too much about quotas and distribution, as long as the number of people who enter the EU every day increases by several thousand at Europe's external borders, while only a fraction of them would be eligible for refugee status

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 I support Parliament's report on the European Commission's new proposals on immigration and the review of refugee policies. With the latest proposals, the plan for the emergency transfer of asylum seekers extends to 160,000 people. Finally, there is open and official discussion of a permanent mechanism that goes beyond the current emergency and changes the Dublin rules. We need to move as soon as possible from the current system of full cargo for the countries of first arrival to a system involving a fair and compulsory distribution. It will be important for the legislative proposals announced by the Commission to begin their work soon. In the resolution we reiterate that freedom of movement in the Schengen area is one of the Union's main achievements and must be protected as such. The resolution also stresses the importance of ensuring more effective management of external borders. The efforts made in recent weeks by many European citizens to help manage the emergency are a positive sign, the image of a Europe that does not want to lose its values and its reason for being. Responsibility and solidarity remain the key words for us.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ Some countries in the EU have long faced the problem of refugees and migrants seeking passage to the Union. Their motives and fates are not the same, some fleeing war, some from poverty, some from persecution, but everyone thinks the EU is a promised land. But the EU is not a country, it is a community of countries, some of which are a pit stop for refugees and migrants, and some are a stop. As long as the causes that drive these people to Europe are not remedied, they will come. As long as Libya does not get a stable and functioning government and Syria does peace, they will come in the thousands. At the moment, the EU is dealing with the consequences of these problems, but it should address the causes. The EU and member state governments must always bear in mind that refugees and migrants are people to be treated humanly.  We should respect our own laws and international conventions to shelter those at risk. That is why I support this report and hope that in this crisis we will behave as besee of the community of advanced states.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. In the face of the massive influx of illegal migrants into Europe, Member States are literally overwhelmed. This report explains that it is necessary to welcome the majority of these immigrants fleeing the conflicts and persecutions of the Islamic State. It calls for quotas requiring each country to take in, house and care for these migrants. The text calls on all European actors to fight against the smuggling networks that organise human trafficking. We strongly oppose this scandalous report. First, the conflicts in Libya, the Middle East and the Middle East are the result of an absurd foreign policy that has consisted of overthrowing totalitarian regimes for the benefit of Islamists. Secondly, it is necessary to remember that the majority of illegal immigrants are economic migrants who do not flee persecution and therefore have no vocation to stay in Europe. Thirdly, the European Union is complicit in the smugglers by not bringing migrant boats back to their port of origin. The European institutions are therefore responsible for the human tragedy that is taking place in the Mediterranean.  That is why I voted against this text.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against. This resolution is the result of so many perebenist declarations of intent. At the base there is a logic of managing the migration phenomenon to be rejected.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because it supports the Commission's plan for the emergency transfer of more asylum seekers from Italy, Greece and Hungary to other Member States and because it calls for the launch of a permanent system amending the Dublin regulation, which determines which Member State should process the asylum application. We are in favour of establishing a "fair and binding" distribution mechanism and taking into account the possibilities for integration and the specific situations and needs of asylum seekers.  We want Member States to welcome refugees from third countries through a mandatory resettlement programme, and we consider it a top priority for the EU and its Member States to create safe and legal avenues for refugees, such as humanitarian corridors and humanitarian visas.  In this context, we consider it necessary to amend the Visa Code and include more specific common provisions on "humanitarian visas" and call on countries to do what is necessary to make it possible to apply for asylum at their embassies and consular offices.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. The current humanitarian crisis has no precedents in the history of the European Union. Thousands of migrants persecuted in their countries and fleeing the terror of Daesh arrive every day on European territory. We cannot remain insensitive to this tragedy. Our countries have an obligation in the face of this urgency to put in place a real European asylum policy. I support Jean-Claude Juncker's proposals to set up a permanent relocation mechanism in the event of a humanitarian emergency and a list of safe countries of origin. Solidarity is the basis of the European project. If we want hateful populist discourse to stop, we must show that the European Union is fully capable of responding to this challenge. I voted in favour of the resolution on migration and refugees in Europe.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the motion for a resolution on migration and refugees in Europe, because these issues are about the very founding principles of the European Union and its identity. The humanitarian disaster has been spreading for months, from the coasts of Lampedusa to Budapest station, from the calais networks to the Macedonian barriers. The time has therefore come for our Europe to reverse, even by being self-critical of the inert ness of recent months. A new common policy must now be built with the cement of a sense of responsibility, solidarity and mutual respect. We must recover a European ideal, which does not mean welcoming everyone indiscriminately, which would be an impossible operation, but which means trying to save those fleeing conflicts and war zones, which is a duty for us Europeans. The leaders of the EU and its Member States have an obligation to take a clear stand in favour of respect for human dignity and the rights of asylum seekers, demonstrating that the Union is based not only on economic directives and the internal market but also, and above all, on solidarity.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ I find the concept of a common EU asylum policy unpalatable. Asylum must remain a matter wholly to be decided by Member States. Hence, I voted against this resolution as a matter of principle.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as I believe that President Jean-Claude Juncker’s proposals today, and particularly the admission that the way must involve mandatory burden—sharing, is a crucial step in the right direction. It is the result of the culmination of many years of PN MEPs’ hard work. I also agree that the Dublin Regulation is completely ineffective and must be revised.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution as it contains many proposals with which the M5S Europa delegation agrees. The main ones are: safe and legal access for refugees to the European asylum system such as humanitarian corridors, issuing visas for humanitarian reasons, improving family reunification; solidarity and fair distribution of responsibilities among the Member States and a permanent mechanism for redistributing the quotas of asylum seekers in all European countries.

name: Nessa CHILDERS
text: in writing. ‒ I endorse the  European Commission plan's to relocate 160,000 refugees, and for a complete review the rules governing asylum seeker requests. In contrast to the spontaneous acts of individual citizens’ generosity as this humanitarian crisis unfolds, we have had to shame many EU national governments into behaving with a modicum of decency. Just look at the pressure that poorer neighbouring countries to Syria are bearing from the influx of refugees. The only thing that compares, over here in Europe, is the exaggeration over the magnitude of the inflows we receive. The Dublin asylum system has become a byword for the worst kind of nimybism, where Governments refuse to assume responsibility because of an accident of geography, when the lives of people fleeing war are at stake. We need to issue humanitarian visas for Syrian refugees. We must scrap our current approach in favour of rules that ensure a fair distribution of refugees, while preventing the break-up of families in times of crisis. The Juncker Commission is showing leadership and is willing to address these structural flaws in the long term, yet even these timid steps, in the face of urgent humanitarian needs, are being resisted by many EU Member States.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 It is evident the failure of the (non) European asylum and immigration policy in the face of humanitarian emergencies, the tragedies announced, the continuous increase in flows (alarming the 75% increase, this year, in asylum applications for minors). The resolution once again calls for the Dublin Regulation to be overcome by introducing a permanent and binding system for the distribution of asylum seekers between all states, according to criteria that favour integration and take into account the specific needs and circumstances of applicants. Compliance with the principles of non-refoulement and individual assessment of applications, regardless of origin (Geneva Convention): principles to be paid particular attention to with regard to the role of lists, common or otherwise, of 'safe countries', and to forced return mechanisms, where voluntary return should be given priority. The distinction between traffickers/exploiters and those who help migrants for humanitarian reasons is also important; as well as the contrast of the dangerous xenophobic tendencies that some governments and parties foment; and, of course, intervention on the causes of migration, and a European policy – humane, realistic, non-discriminatory – also for so-called economic migrants. Although not very explicit on this last point, the resolution moves in the right direction and urges the Commission and governments to act. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 It is very important to report that Member States should introduce strict penalties for trafficking and trafficking in human beings to and across the EU. Member States are also called upon to combat criminal networks of traffickers, but not to impose sanctions on those who on a voluntary basis help migrants on humanitarian grounds. We also agree with the point where, both the EU and the Member States and the international community, they must strengthen their role in conflict resolution and contribute to the search for sustainable political solutions in conflict-affected areas.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on migration and refugees in Europe. According to UNHCR data, around 3 000 people died or were missing in 2015 in an attempt to reach Europe and that many of those seeking asylum come from Syria, Afghanistan, Eritrea and Iraq. The resolution welcomes the solidarity shown by many European citizens, welcomes the Commission's relocation and resettlement initiatives and calls on it to amend the existing Dublin Regulation, urges the EU, the Member States and the international community to strengthen their role in conflict resolution and, in particular, to contribute to the search for sustainable political solutions in conflict regions such as Iraq, Syria, Libya and the Middle East, and calls on the Commission and the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy (VP/HR) to convene an international conference on the refugee crisis with the aim of final ing a common and comprehensive humanitarian aid strategy.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that it is important to move with concrete actions in support of Italy, Greece and Hungary. I also think it is appropriate to strongly denounce the fact that the issue of refugees should not only weigh on the shoulders of the states directly affected, but the EU should establish a solid and massive act of cooperation, search and rescue, which is additional to border surveillance and capable of dealing with the humanitarian tragedy taking place in the Mediterranean. In view of the dramatic impact of previous military interventions on the increase in refugees, I believe that the EU and its Member States should be more cautious about participating in conflicts in third countries or providing weapons and support to their actors.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 This refugee crisis poses challenges that test the limits of our project and whose solution will certainly define our future in a crucial way. More than ever, we need an ever closer Union between the peoples of Europe, concrete achievements that create, first of all, de facto solidarity! Europeans have been up to the challenges, it is time for governments to be. This resolution highlights this. We must quickly cope with the drama at Europe's borders, relieve the pressure on Italy, Greece and Hungary. And to do so, we need to implement quickly the agreed measures, such as the Redistribution Mechanism, without prejudice to a permanent solution with mandatory quotas. At the same time, however, the Union must start to act swiftly to address the problems at the root of this mass outreach of people, which involves creating legal migration pathways, targeted development policy, strong foreign policy, strengthening the role of the Front and EASO, among others.  Parliament has long called for these measures, and will undoubtedly continue to do so!

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the resolution on the refugee crisis in the EU. It is a common challenge that needs a European response. We have to move from emergency measures to a permanent crisis mechanism of distribution of refugees. All MS should take their responsibility and fully apply the common asylum package. The best interest of the child should be always respected in all procedures. We need to increase our cooperation in order to be able to save lives and assist Member States under pressure with EASO, Frontex and hotspots. We also need to combat traffickers and smugglers who exploit people's desperation. Europol and Eurojust can play a big role in coordinating action. Reception centres in third countries, however, where asylum procedures would be initiated, are not realistic at the moment. Instead we should increase funding for UNCHR, WFP and humanitarian aid to help refugees in neighbouring countries.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I abstained from voting on this resolution, aware that it is an instrument used by the Groups of the People's, Social Democratic and Liberal Party to carry out a face-washing while their governments and the European Commission keep their border policy closed. The resolution is not at the root of the problem and keeps the door open to future military interventions that will only aggravate it, as well as giving its full support to Mogherini's mediterranean militarisation plan (EUNAVFOR Med) and the Commission's insufficient plan to accommodate the small number of 160,000 people, well below the European Union's genuine reception capacity. Moreover, the resolution does not condemn key aspects of the European Commission's migration policy, such as the closure of borders and their outsourcing. We reject the continued separation of asylum seekers from migrants fleeing hunger and misery, and the latter group continues to be condemned to immediate expulsion. For all this, I cannot support an accomplice resolution of criminal policy, but I abstained in recognition of the improvement over previous resolutions that openly criminalized migrants.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, as it is a reaction to the precarious events that occurred over the summer which need the EU’s pertinent and effective action. The resolution includes important elements needed within a solid migration policy, such as the need to implement a permanent relocation mechanism and the total re-evaluation of the Dublin Regulation. That being said, I voted against the amendment of the visa code due to the strategic location of Malta and the security implications such a proposal would have on the country.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. \u2012 The migration and refugee crisis that has hit the European Union in recent months is a lasting phenomenon that requires immediate concrete responses and actions, but also coordinated long-term strategies. The joint resolution, which I voted in favour of wholely, goes in the desired direction, a direction in which the European Union is finally playing an active role within it and at the forefront of the international stage, and which is capable of defining a holistic approach to asylum and migration. In particular, I welcome the European Commission's awareness and concrete efforts to establish a permanent mechanism for the relocation of asylum seekers that is fairer and more supportive. This measure was strongly desired by the Italian Government at the European Council last July. The emergency of the last few days has finally made it clear that only a coordinated European response that will provide for a radical review of the Dublin Convention will be able to guarantee human standards and hope for the future for those hundreds of thousands of men, women and children fleeing conflict and political instability, on the basis of one of the EU's core values: solidarity.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This resolution comes in the wake of European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker's statement to Parliament on Wednesday on the migration crisis in Europe. At present, it is the Member States with a border with the outside of the European Union - Hungary, Greece and Italy - that receive most of the migrants from the Mediterranean. The Commission proposes the relocation of 120,000 refugees (contained in these three states) to all EU Member States through binding quotas. France would take in 24,000 refugees. The Commission also proposes the installation of "hot spots" or reception and sorting centres in the countries of arrival. These will ensure decent sanitary conditions for refugees and distinguish between people fleeing areas of persecution, entitled to asylum in Europe, and illegal economic migrants, who must be taken back to the border. Considering that the European Union has a duty to provide concrete solutions to this humanitarian crisis, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing. We are now experiencing the worst migration crisis in our history since the Second World War. Since the beginning of the year, 366,402 people have arrived by the Mediterranean Sea, according to the UN High Commissioner for Refugees. In addition, 2,800 people have died or been reported missing. Given the seriousness of the situation, I did not want to obstruct this text, which allows member States to become more aware. But I did not want to support it because I am opposed to this permanent and binding relocation mechanism which encourages the creation of an 'a la carte menu' where the preferences of the applicants would dictate our European asylum policy. That is why I am in support of interim and voluntary measures for those in need of protection.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 I could not support today's parliamentary resolution on migration and migrants in Europe by my vote because it does not focus on the essential problems that reflect reality. The resolution does not mention, for example, the wars in Syria or Libya as the reason for the present migration, it is not tough enough on the dismantling of trafficking networks. The Current Commission's migration package is not acceptable to the Hungarian People's Party delegation in this way because it has not been able to provide answers to the burning questions that have been ringing for weeks. It does not say unequivocally that our priority is to protect Europe's external borders. The text does not make a clear distinction between genuine refugees and immigrants who risk their own lives and those of their families in the hope of better prosperity, so that they can reach countries that are more socially prosperous and therefore do not want to cooperate with the authorities in other Member States. Nor does the allocation mechanism under the quotas included in the package provide a sufficient solution to the current situation. The majority of immigrants will continue to travel to states where they can expect greater social assistance even after they are allocated according to quotas, as soon as possible. In the meantime, there is no point in talking too much about quotas and distribution, as long as the number of people who enter the EU every day increases by thousands at Europe's external borders, while only a fraction of them would be eligible for refugee status.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. I have given unconditional support to the emergency measures proposed by the President of the Commission to better distribute the reception of 160,000 refugees among the Member States. I regret the lack of solidarity of governments towards asylum seekers. The current migration crisis is the worst in the post-war period. That is why I have given my support. I consider this to be a moral and human obligation. Beyond the emergency measures, I am also in favour of a permanent and binding relocation mechanism according to a key of equitable distribution between Member States. I am also in favour of establishing a common list of third countries considered safe, which will speed up the processing of unfounded applications. Finally, I regret that refugees have no option but to resort to smugglers and perilous routes to find protection in Europe. There is an urgent need for an effective and harmonised asylum system for the EU and for Member States to put in place safe and legal channels, including humanitarian corridors and humanitarian visas.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. – I could not vote in favour of today's Resolution on Migration and Immigrants in Europe because it does not focus on the essential problems that reflect reality. The resolution does not mention, for example, the wars in Syria or Libya as the reason for the present migration, it is not tough enough on the dismantling of trafficking networks. The Current Commission's migration package is not acceptable to the Hungarian People's Party delegation in this way because it has not been able to provide answers to the burning questions that have been ringing for weeks. It does not say unequivocally that our priority is to protect Europe's external borders. The text does not make a clear distinction between genuine refugees and immigrants who risk their own lives and those of their families in the hope of better prosperity, so that they can reach countries that are more socially prosperous and therefore do not want to cooperate with the authorities in other Member States. Nor does the allocation mechanism under the quotas included in the package provide a sufficient solution to the current situation. the majority of immigrants will continue to do so after allocating quotas, as soon as possible, to states where they can expect greater social assistance. In the meantime, there is no point in talking too much about quotas and distribution, as long as the number of people who enter the EU every day increases by thousands at Europe's external borders, while only a fraction of them would be eligible for refugee status.

name: Diane DODDS
text: in writing. ‒ While these temporary relocation plans take cognisance of the ongoing migrant crisis in Southern Europe, there can be no suggestion that they represent a template for solving the root causes of the mass build-up of refugees at EU borders. While all developed countries have a moral duty to do their fair share to alleviate the plight of those coming to Europe in pursuit of a chance to live in relative safety, I do not believe a Common EU Asylum System is required to remind national leaders of the humanitarian onus on them to act.  In opting out of this relocation mechanism, the UK Prime Minister has since committed to resettling 20,000 Syrian refugees by 2020. The principle of free movement has led to a situation where economic migrants and refugees are often wrongly considered in the same terms. However, this should be no excuse for governments failing to extend a helping hand and safe haven to those in desperate need on the shores of Turkey and Greece. Most importantly of all is that we in Europe give all necessary focus to supporting peace and stability in the regions from where many of the refugees have been forced to leave in search of a better life for their families.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I am strongly opposed to the European Commission's proposal for mandatory binding quotas for the redistribution of asylum seekers. Quotas are not the solution to the refugee problem, this is a temporary measure that will only prompt even more refugees to seek asylum in the EU. The solution to the internal migration problem must be based on building cooperation on a voluntary basis and trust between Member States, as well as by providing more financial resources in certain areas such as Frontex and the European Refugee Agency. But this is a solution only to the consequences of the immigration wave, not the reasons. The real measures to tackle the refugee problem are only related to the Union's foreign policy. The only way for the EU to tackle the current problem is to establish international cooperation between the US, Russia and Arab countries in order to quell wars in the Middle East and eradicate terrorism in the region. As long as there are wars and terrorist organisations near the EU, we will witness a steady influx of immigrants.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The report makes no reference to the real causes of the problem, so the solutions it proposes do not hit the root of it. The policy of the 'West' must be drastically changed in the countries from which the refugee flows originate, neighbouring Islamic countries (Turkey, Saudi Arabia) must take responsibility and, in general, the EU must stop wasting money on actions that do not combat the root cause of the refugee situation.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 I could not support today's parliamentary resolution on migration and migrants in Europe by my vote because it does not focus on the essential problems that reflect reality. The decision does not mention, for example, the wars in Syria or Libya as the reason for this migration, it is not tough enough on the dismantling of trafficking networks. The Current Commission's migration package is not acceptable to the Hungarian People's Party delegation in this way because it has not been able to provide answers to the burning questions that have been ringing for weeks. It does not say unequivocally that our priority is to protect Europe's external borders. The text does not make a clear distinction between genuine refugees and immigrants who risk their own lives and those of their families in the hope of better prosperity, so that they can reach countries that are more socially prosperous and therefore do not want to cooperate with the authorities in other Member States. Nor does the allocation mechanism under the quotas included in the package provide a sufficient solution to the current situation. Even after the quota allocation, the majority of immigrants will continue to make the journey as soon as possible to states where they can expect greater social assistance. In the meantime, there is no point in talking too much about quotas and distribution, as long as the number of people who enter the EU every day increases by thousands at Europe's external borders, while only a fraction of them would be eligible for refugee status.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. The European Parliament has called on the EU to base its response to the refugee crisis on solidarity and fair division of responsibility. However, the Council's stance has been incoherent and unacceptable because it is based on contradictions, notably by cutting, in the 2016 budget proposal, the instruments to combat the problems of migration and refugees: in the Instrument for Pre-Access Assistance EUR 119 million in payments, in the European Neighbourhood Instrument EUR 100 million in payments and in the Instrument for Development Cooperation EUR 143 million in payments. Solidarity does not live on proclamations. Solidarity is done with actions.   Europe should be a safe and legal place of access to the asylum system, advocating the establishment of a binding quota for the allocation of asylum seekers among all EU countries, as well as contributions to refugee resettlement programmes, enhanced cooperation with third countries and stronger measures against human traffickers and criminal networks of traffickers.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because it supports the Commission's plan for the emergency transfer of more asylum seekers from Italy, Greece and Hungary to other Member States and because it calls for the launch of a permanent system amending the Dublin regulation, which determines which Member State should process the asylum application. We are in favour of establishing a "fair and binding" distribution mechanism and taking into account the possibilities for integration and the specific situations and needs of asylum seekers.  We want Member States to welcome refugees from third countries through a mandatory resettlement programme, and we consider it a top priority for the EU and its Member States to create safe and legal avenues for refugees, such as humanitarian corridors and humanitarian visas.  We call for Member States not to deny the solidarity that citizens do if they want to give to refugees arriving at our borders.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ Regional instability and conflict and the rise of ISIS in neighbouring areas of the conflict have an impact on the mass influx of migrants and the streams of displaced persons and thus on the number of individual attempts to reach the European Union. The European Union and the Member States must find an effective solution and strengthen existing cooperation in order to prevent further loss of life, prevent further departures of smugglers' vessels, speed up and streamline the processing of asylum applications in the Member States, return immediately those who do not meet the criteria, and fully integrate those who have been granted asylum. The European Union must implement a zero-tolerance policy in relation to trafficking in human beings and put pressure on the Member States to work closely with Europol, Frontex, EASO and Eurojust to combat these criminal smuggling networks by identifying how and where they operate and preventing their departure.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 Yet another eu mockery: you don't have a long-term plan and the effects are visible. You are creating, perhaps specifically, this untenable situation. You don't take responsibility for wars caused by you too.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 My vote is negative because the report does not mention the real causes of the problem, so the solutions it proposes do not hit its root. The policy of the 'West' towards the countries from which the refugee flows originate must be drastically changed, neighbouring Islamic countries (Turkey, Saudi Arabia) must also take responsibility, and in general, the EU must stop wasting money on actions that do not combat the root cause of the refugee situation.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The migrant emergency must be solved by a long-term prospective, a vision of the future that we want to build together, imagined by a stronger Europe in which Member States respect and implement common rules on asylum policy. Agreements like the Schengen one have to be respected by all Member States that are part of it. The refugee emergency has to be addressed at its roots, and safe areas must be created into countries affected by conflicts, where refugees could be safe and the EU could bring humanitarian and stabilization aid. I believe we must distinguish between asylum seekers, risking their lives to save their families, and economic migrants. It is counterproductive to impose compulsory quotas of migrants to all EU Member States; it is important to take into consideration each and every country possibilities to accommodate and take care of large number of migrants.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution because Parliament must send a strong signal of support for a genuine, more coherent and comprehensive migration policy, based on a long-term strategy. If solidarity is to be the principle behind our action in this area, it cannot exist without the effective implementation of our common eu-wide standards and effective control of our external borders. Furthermore, the resolution supports the establishment of a permanent and mandatory mechanism for the relocation of asylum seekers and also recalls the need to combat the criminal networks of smugglers. Finally, there is an urgent need to ensure greater coherence of the Union's internal and external policies and to integrate the issue of migration into our foreign policy, which implies regular dialogue and increased cooperation with third countries.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. \u2012 I could not support today's parliamentary resolution on migration and migrants in Europe by my vote because it does not focus on the essential problems that reflect reality. The decision does not mention, for example, the wars in Syria or Libya as the reason for this migration, it is not tough enough on the dismantling of trafficking networks. The Current Commission's migration package is not acceptable to the Hungarian People's Party delegation in this way because it has not been able to provide answers to the burning questions that have been ringing for weeks. It does not say unequivocally that our priority is to protect Europe's external borders. The text does not make a clear distinction between genuine refugees and immigrants who risk their own lives and those of their families in the hope of better prosperity, so that they can reach countries that are more socially prosperous and therefore do not want to cooperate with the authorities in other Member States. Nor does the allocation mechanism under the quotas included in the package provide a sufficient solution to the current situation. Even after the quota allocation, the majority of immigrants will continue to make the journey as soon as possible to states where they can expect greater social assistance. In the meantime, there is no point in talking too much about quotas and distribution, as long as the number of people who enter the EU every day increases by thousands at Europe's external borders, while only a fraction of them would be eligible for refugee status.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I was unable to vote in favour of the Keller report because it does not deal with real problems and therefore does not provide a solution to the current crisis. Mandatory quotas do not help.  The biggest problem today is that a fraction of the refugee influx is now willing to register, cooperate with the authorities and accept, say, refugee status in poorer Member States. Most of them are going to the Member States that promise more social assistance, and they are doing everything they can to get there. It will continue to do so after allocating quotas: as soon as possible, it will make its way to states where it can expect greater social assistance. In the meantime, there is no point in talking too much about quotas and distribution until we can protect Europe's external borders and the number of people who enter the Union increases by thousands every day, while only a fraction of them are entitled to refugee status.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because it supports the Commission's plan for the emergency transfer of more asylum seekers from Italy, Greece and Hungary to other Member States and because it calls for the launch of a permanent system amending the Dublin regulation, which determines which Member State should process the asylum application. We are in favour of establishing a "fair and binding" distribution mechanism and taking into account the possibilities for integration and the specific situations and needs of asylum seekers.  We want Member States to welcome refugees from third countries through a mandatory resettlement programme, and we consider it a top priority for the EU and its Member States to create safe and legal avenues for refugees, such as humanitarian corridors and humanitarian visas.  In this context, we consider it necessary to amend the Visa Code and include more specific common provisions on "humanitarian visas" and call on countries to do what is necessary to make it possible to apply for asylum at their embassies and consular offices.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because it supports the Commission's plan for the emergency transfer of asylum seekers from Italy, Greece and Hungary to other Member States and because it calls for the launch of a permanent system amending the Dublin regulation, which determines which Member State should process the asylum application. We are in favour of establishing a "fair and binding" distribution mechanism and taking into account the possibilities for integration and the specific situations and needs of asylum seekers.  We want Member States to welcome refugees from third countries through a mandatory resettlement programme, and we consider it a top priority for the EU and its Member States to create safe and legal avenues for refugees, such as humanitarian corridors and humanitarian visas.  In this context, we consider it necessary to amend the Visa Code and include more specific common provisions on "humanitarian visas" and call on countries to do what is necessary to make it possible to apply for asylum at their embassies and consular offices.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. \u2012 With the compulsory quota mechanism we are finally moving towards a truly united Europe. The Commission's proposal largely takes up what we have been proposing for a long time and which the PPE group put in writing to the Bureau in Milan in May, and we are very pleased about that. It is now up to the Council to show that it is up to the task and show the same solidarity. Alongside this, we must also be clear and firm in the distinction between refugees and economic migrants, by accepting only those who actually qualify as refugees, we cannot afford to create false illusions that would only fuel further tragedies. We also call for increased foreign policy actions that put an end to the refugee problem, allowing these families not to have to flee and to be able to live in peace in their country of origin.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. Mr Juncker presented us yesterday in this House with very strong and concrete lines of action to respond to the refugee emergency. At last, Europe is moving with proposals of great foresight and humanity, inspired by the values of solidarity and union among the peoples of Europe. I voted with conviction for the resolution presented today, which encourages the European Commission to continue its efforts to reform European asylum and immigration policies, in particular by helping Member States that, like Italy, are at the forefront of the reception of migrants, by permanently and compulsoryly implementing a system of refugee relocation.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution on migration and refugees in Europe as the number of people seeking help continues to be worrying.
