The instability that is affecting the EU is unprecedented, targeted and urgent action must be taken to put an end to the very high number of deaths and missing persons as a result of long inhuman journeys and trafficking. I believe that the Dublin Regulation needs to be reviewed and improved in those parts that have been overtaken by events, highlighting the importance of a fair relocation, including family reunification, especially for unaccompanied minors, children arriving without adults or parents, whose traces are lost and are exploited or incur involved in illegal organ removal and sale practices. It also provides for a permanent and binding mechanism for the distribution of asylum seekers for all Ms, in line with the EU's principle of non-refoulement. Migration is a complex phenomenon, we need to understand the causes, such as poverty, inequality, bad governance and armed conflict.  Therefore, the EU, through greater attention, including by setting criminal sanctions against trafficking and trafficking in human beings, must fulfil, in accordance with the principles of solidarity and with greater cooperation, ensuring protection.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted against this report today because, on the one hand, it makes too little reference to the specific situation and reception performance of Germany and, on the other hand, it ignores the legitimate concerns and perspectives of the municipal level.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The challenges facing the Union have never been as serious and urgent as they are today. Crises – Greek and migration, the fight against terrorism and Europe's security need an immediate and comprehensive remedy.   Since the beginning of the year, almost 500,000 people have made their way into the community. Despite strengthening Frontex's budget by an additional €13.7 million in 2015, it has become clear that the Union is not coping with migrants and is unable to effectively protect its borders or jointly and severally address the problem of the hundreds of thousands of migrants grouped in refugee camps on its territory.  The EC's new proposals for managing migratory waves and their relocation, supported by a single asylum policy for all Member States, supported by the principle of so-called safe countries and legal migration routes to the EU, deserve support. It is also sensible to allow refugees to apply for asylum from outside the European Union. In parliamentary resolutions, we continue to say that the EU must fulfil its role as a promoter of peace and democracy, but the European community, as an economic organisation, has limited economic tools at its disposal. Without a viable EU foreign policy based on the Community method, it will not be possible to counter the exodus of Mediterranean refugees or to resolve the conflicts that cause it.

name: Juan Carlos GIRAUTA VIDAL
text: in writing. According to UNHCR, 2,800 women, men and children have died or disappeared in 2015 while trying to reach a safe place in Europe. In the face of this tragedy, we urge the EU and the Member States in this report to do everything they can to prevent further deaths at sea or on land. We also need a longer-term approach to migration and asylum instead of the current ad hoc decision-making. This involves reflecting on the causes of the current migration crisis and how they can be tackled.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: In writing. Mrs Merkel's announcements - welcoming 800,000 immigrants, suspending Dublin proceedings - are a great invitation to undertake the journey for all applicants for immigration, all nationalities and all motivations. How many more Aylan Kurdi ads will kill? And for what reasons? Because Germany is generous? Or because its demographic catastrophe may soon turn into an economic catastrophe? What kind of eldorado are these people risking their lives for? The violated human rights hell depicted in the Ferrera report voted yesterday? A third-world Europe where 25% of the population is at risk of exclusion, where tens of millions of unemployed people are struggling, where mass immigration has already proved these negative consequences?  You are coldly exploiting the situation to try to take a step forward in communitizing immigration policies. You give a humanitarian veneer to what is, in truth, the cynical human counterpart of your destructive economic policies. Basically, these men and women are not refugees for you, but future consumers, a cheap labour force and, you hope, those who will finance tomorrow's slow agony of ageing Europeans.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this resolution, still understanding that several key elements of it are missing, such as a strong condemnation of the policy being followed with Frontex and the successive eurozone bunkerisation processes. There is also a lack of strong recognition of the responsibility of member states in the generation of these crises in the states that are the source of migration. The positive elements, on the other hand, are sufficient to make a vote in favour; highlights the recognition of civil society's work or direct criticism of far-right efforts to make a stand against migration more environmentally positive. We understand that we must continue to work on a line which, to the positive elements of this resolution, adds those blanks that prevent a firm vote.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I believe in showing solidarity with those facing a crisis. We must show more solidarity between us Europeans who face crisis, and to people across the rest of the world facing crises. I along with my colleagues in the S&D Group, voted for a resolution that allowed for the most effective and humane way of dealing with the migration and refugee crisis currently facing Europe. I hope that by voting this way the crisis will be one step closer to being solved.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because it supports the Commission's plan for the emergency transfer of more asylum seekers from Italy, Greece and Hungary to other Member States and because it calls for the launch of a permanent system amending the Dublin regulation, which determines which Member State should process the asylum application. We are in favour of establishing a "fair and binding" distribution mechanism and taking into account the possibilities for integration and the specific situations and needs of asylum seekers.  We want Member States to welcome refugees from third countries through a mandatory resettlement programme, and we consider it a top priority for the EU and its Member States to create safe and legal avenues for refugees, such as humanitarian corridors and humanitarian visas.  In this context, we consider it necessary to amend the Visa Code and include more specific common provisions on "humanitarian visas" and call on countries to do what is necessary to make it possible to apply for asylum at their embassies and consular offices.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: In writing. I particularly welcome the adoption of this joint resolution endorsed by four political groups. It is indeed an ambitious text that lives up to the dramas and challenges we face. The line set by the European Parliament is clear and demanding, first of all on the question of values, first and foremost solidarity and humanity. The course is also courageous from the point of view of the mechanisms that should be put in place as soon as possible: firstly, a permanent and compulsory relocation mechanism and also, the strengthening and creation of safe and legal migration routes for refugees. Finally, the resolution addresses the root causes of migration. This is one of the reasons why Parliament is asking the Commission and Mrs Mogherini to convene an international conference on the refugee crisis; this conference should include the participation not only of the EU and its Member States but also that of UN agencies, associative actors and the international community as a whole. In the face of fear and hatred, the EU and its Member States must take all necessary measures to ensure a dignified, exemplary and controlled refugee reception.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because it supports the Commission's plan for the emergency transfer of more asylum seekers from Italy, Greece and Hungary to other Member States and because it calls for the launch of a permanent system amending the Dublin regulation, which determines which Member State should process the asylum application. We are in favour of establishing a "fair and binding" distribution mechanism and taking into account the possibilities for integration and the specific situations and needs of asylum seekers.  We want Member States to welcome refugees from third countries through a mandatory resettlement programme, and we consider it a top priority for the EU and its Member States to create safe and legal avenues for refugees, such as humanitarian corridors and humanitarian visas.  In this context, we consider it necessary to amend the Visa Code and include more specific common provisions on "humanitarian visas" and call on countries to do what is necessary to make it possible to apply for asylum at their embassies and consular offices.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 I could not support today's parliamentary resolution on migration and migrants in Europe by my vote because it does not focus on the essential problems that reflect reality. The resolution does not mention, for example, the wars in Syria or Libya as the reason for the present migration, it is not tough enough on the dismantling of trafficking networks. The Current Commission's migration package is not acceptable to the Hungarian People's Party delegation in this way because it has not been able to provide answers to the burning questions that have been ringing for weeks. It does not say unequivocally that our priority is to protect Europe's external borders. The text does not make a clear distinction between genuine refugees and immigrants who risk their own lives and those of their families in the hope of better prosperity, so that they can reach countries that are more socially prosperous and therefore do not want to cooperate with the authorities in other Member States. Nor does the allocation mechanism under the quotas included in the package provide a sufficient solution to the current situation. The majority of immigrants will continue to do so after allocating quotas, and will make their way to states where they can expect greater social assistance as soon as possible. In the meantime, there is no point in talking too much about quotas and distribution, as long as the number of people who enter the EU every day increases by thousands at Europe's external borders, while only a fraction of them would be eligible for refugee status.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. I rejected the European Parliament resolution on the migration and refugee crisis of 10 September 2015. The paper calls almost uncritically for the European acceptance of the German welcome culture and criticises the countries that do not want to follow this line. The report praises this single-handedness and thus causes great resentment in the EU. In view of the EU's major economic problems and the major integration problems of the refugees from Afghanistan, Eritrea, Iraq and Syria, which are specifically referred to in the paper, the bad economic reality of large parts of the EU must not be denied, but a long-term perspective must also be developed. There is no word on the long-term repatriation of asylum seekers and it can be assumed that permanent migration is accepted or even desired. However, the EU must not impose this decision on the Member States. It is also regrettable that the resolution wants to fully uphold the Schengen Agreement, even though the many breaches of the law currently require a great deal of action. Incidentally , and this is my ceterum censeo – I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this resolution, still understanding that several key elements of it are missing, such as a fervent condemnation of the policy being followed with Frontex and the successive eurozone bunkerisation processes. There is also a lack of strong recognition of the responsibility of member states in the generation of these crises in the states that are the source of migration. The positive elements, on the other hand, are sufficient to make a vote in favour; highlights the recognition of civil society's work or direct criticism of far-right efforts to make a stand against migration more environmentally positive. We understand that we must continue to work on a line which, to the positive elements of this resolution, adds those blanks that prevent a firm vote.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ At this point in time, regarding the refugee crisis in Europe, the principle of solidarity is of crucial importance. It is paramount to offer both aid and assistance to the refugees. However, the notions of solidarity and security are not mutually exclusive. Actions should only follow after a comprehensive overview is constructed concerning the ground situation of each individual member state. Actions should also follow after an extensive analysis of the terrorist threat that occurs from the infiltration of radical activists amidst the refugees.

name: Peter JAHR
text: Writing. Tackling the refugee influx on Europe is a task that neither Germany, Hungary, Denmark or Greece can solve on its own. The last few weeks have shown that national solo actions of individual Member States only lead to chaos, and recriminations do not take us any further. Solutions can only be achieved with common European approaches. President Juncker was right to recall our common humanitarian commitment to welcome people fleeing for fear of their lives. It is permanently unacceptable for some Member States to do no help at all and simply leave the burden to others. That is why there is no way around a quota model with a European distribution key. In addition, the existing minimum standards of the Common European Asylum System, for example with regard to the proper accommodation and treatment of refugees, must be applied effectively throughout the EU. In order to really be able to help the people who need our aid most, we also need a uniform definition of safe countries of origin in all Member States. It must be clear to everyone that asylum applications from countries with consolidated democracies, such as the Western Balkans, cannot be accepted.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's resolution on migration and refugees in Europe, as this ongoing, above all humanitarian crisis that is happening, is needed to be discussed and taken decisions at this European level as well. The EU needs to provide swift answers to such problems, to upgrade already adopted good solutions in line with new circumstances and to address implementation at Member State level. The problem of migrants and refugees is a common European problem and solutions need to be sought in this context.  I condemn and oppose all those initiatives that go towards segreging and differentiating migrants and refugees on various grounds or from the EU to create a "fortress" to defend against those seeking first and foremost the possibility of a normal life for their families. Particular attention should be paid to action against criminal groups that have created an opportunity to make money out of this problem. Europe needs more solidarity, more compassion and more joint action.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because it supports the Commission's plan for the emergency transfer of more asylum seekers from Italy, Greece and Hungary to other Member States and because it calls for the launch of a permanent system amending the Dublin regulation, which determines which Member State should process the asylum application. We are in favour of establishing a "fair and binding" distribution mechanism and taking into account the possibilities for integration and the specific situations and needs of asylum seekers.  We want Member States to welcome refugees from third countries through a mandatory resettlement programme, and we consider it a top priority for the EU and its Member States to create safe and legal avenues for refugees, such as humanitarian corridors and humanitarian visas.  In this context, we consider it necessary to amend the Visa Code and include more specific common provisions on "humanitarian visas" and call on countries to do what is necessary to make it possible to apply for asylum at their embassies and consular offices.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I have decided to vote against motion for resolution 2015/2833, as, in my opinion, consent represents not only the emergency redistribution of asylum seekers to all Member States of the Union, but also the creation of a permanent redistribution system. I have long disagreed with these proposals because they go against the logic of granting asylum and can, by their nature, cause a number of serious problems for the Member States and the Union itself.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the migration crisis in Europe. The text fully supports the proposals made by Jean-Claude Juncker and underlines the need for greater solidarity between Member States to better manage the urgency of the massive influx of migrants into the European Union. The introduction of mandatory quotas to process asylum applications is thus one of the first avenues that must be agreed between Member States. While the practical problems posed by the arrival of hundreds of thousands of refugees should not be ignored, it is Europe's duty to welcome those who are victims of war to their countries of origin. This resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Josu JUARISTI ABAUNZ
text: in writing. With the inclusion and approval by the plenary of the amendment establishing 'effective instruments and measures for searching and rescuing at sea, mechanisms of solidarity and family reunification including humanitarian visas and, above all, legal and safe access to migrants and refugees', the most progressive report has been achieved to date by the European Parliament. While it is true that EH Bildu would have liked an express rejection of Frontex and the outsourcing of Community borders, as well as expulsions from the migrant and refugee force and the interventionist military policies of Western powers, EH Bildu sees in the final text the opening of the road or, at least, a clear demand for the reform of Dublin regulation and the establishment of a truly European Union and deserving of that name.  That is why EH Bildu voted in favour of the joint resolution proposal presented today in the European Chamber.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's resolution on migration and refugees in Europe because the principles of solidarity and equitable sharing of responsibilities are cardinal values of the European Union. The current crisis requires emergency measures.

name: Sandra KALNIETE
text: in writing. ‒ The current refugee crisis is the biggest Europe has seen since World War II and a European solution must be found for it. There are conflicts and war in many countries at the European borders. However, I abstained from supporting a this resolution as it overlooks very important elements of a complex solution, among others: properly addressing root causes for people to flee from their countries, the role of a European common foreign and security policy and the development aid policy, security and functionality of the Schengen area, risks for terrorism and huge numbers of internally displaced people in Ukraine.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. As this report calls for a single asylum system and the repeal of the Dublin Agreement, I reject it.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: Writing. – At the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg, I voted against the resolution on migration and refugees in Europe, as it requires the introduction of a mandatory mechanism for the redistribution of refugees and does not propose a solution to stem the uncontrolled flow of refugees. In the specific situation, there is a high risk, with the introduction of an automatic redistribution mechanism, but without closing or strengthening the External Borders of the European Union, that the flow of refugees will only increase and the number of people to be divided between Member States will continue to grow. The European Union must finally address the causes, not the consequences.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ The shocking image of Aylan lying on a beach has brought home the cost of this human tragedy. Earlier this year, I visited refugee camps in Iraq, Jordan and Lebanon and witnessed the unimaginable suffering of refugees first hand. I met a Palestinian family who have struggled for three generations in a refugee camp. It was a heart-breaking indictment of our failure. Refugees are leaving their homes, because they are no longer safe. They are risking life and limb in order to find safe land. We must tackle human traffickers who exploit human misery and we can only do so by creating safe legal channels for refugees. It is wrong that the top 5 countries welcoming refugees are developing countries. It is wrong that the UK offers to take twelve refugees per day whilst Germany takes one thousand. We can only deal with the scale of this crisis by working globally in solidarity. This unfolding human catastrophe tests our very humanity and we must rise up to that challenge.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Writing. I rejected the European Parliament resolution on the migration and refugee crisis of 10 September 2015. The paper calls almost uncritically for the European acceptance of the German welcome culture and criticises the countries that do not want to follow this line. In view of the current figures and the migration potential triggered by the German position and, in particular, Mrs Merkel, this one-sided ideological position must fail in reality. If we want a European solution, we must consult and involve the other Member States, and urgently avoid going it alone. The report praises this single-handedness and thus causes great resentment in the EU. In view of the EU's major economic problems and the major integration problems of the refugees from Afghanistan, Eritrea, Iraq and Syria specifically referred to in the paper, the bad economic reality of large parts of the EU must not be denied, but a long-term perspective must also be developed. There is no word on the long-term repatriation of asylum seekers and it can be assumed that permanent migration is accepted or even desired. However, the EU must not impose this decision on the Member States. It is also regrettable that the resolution wants to fully uphold the Schengen Agreement, even though the many breaches of the law currently require a great deal of action.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 I could not support today's parliamentary resolution on migration and migrants in Europe by my vote because it does not focus on the essential problems that reflect reality. The decision does not mention, for example, the wars in Syria or Libya as the reason for this migration, it is not tough enough on the dismantling of trafficking networks. The Current Commission's migration package is not acceptable to the Hungarian People's Party delegation in this way because it has not been able to provide answers to the burning questions that have been ringing for weeks. It does not say unequivocally that our priority is to protect Europe's external borders. The text does not make a clear distinction between genuine refugees and immigrants who risk their own lives and those of their families in the hope of better prosperity, so that they can reach countries that are more socially prosperous and therefore do not want to cooperate with the authorities in other Member States. Nor does the allocation mechanism under the quotas included in the package provide a sufficient solution to the current situation. Even after the quota allocation, the majority of immigrants will continue to make the journey as soon as possible to states where they can expect greater social assistance. In the meantime, there is no point in talking too much about quotas and distribution, as long as the number of people who enter the EU every day increases by thousands at Europe's external borders, while only a fraction of them would be eligible for refugee status.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: in writing. \u2012 With today's vote, the Chamber has once again shown unity of vision and intent in the management of the migration phenomenon. It is a deep closeness with the people we represent who have mobilized in recent weeks in unprecedented solidarity activities. We continue to oppose any attempt to build fences and operations to secure the external borders and prevent the regular entry of refugees and migrants; For us, the free movement of persons within the Shengen area is an indispensable principle. We welcomed the Commission's move towards a permanent and binding mechanism for the distribution of asylum seekers within European territory and, above all, we called for safe and legal channels of entry. We want humanitarian corridors and humanitarian visas to be opened up, but we also want to strengthen existing mechanisms, such as family reunification or the use of humanitarian visas. The time has come for the Council to shoulder its responsibilities and listen to the voice of democracy.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I have of course voted against the resolution of traditional groups on migration and refugees in Europe. This text perfectly illustrates the gap between the European Union and public opinion in the Member States. As many polls show, the vast majority of voters in Europe want the re-establishment of borders and an end to mass immigration. However, the resolution that was passed in this parliament goes completely in the opposite direction. It advocates the continuation of Schengen, which has abolished internal borders while external borders are no longer controlled. It argues for the distribution of migrants within the European Union, while the problem is not dealt with at source. It wants to promote legal immigration, while member states' absorption capacity has long since been exceeded. It criticizes those who have seen clearly and warned of the problems we face.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because it supports the Commission's plan for the emergency transfer of more asylum seekers from Italy, Greece and Hungary to other Member States and because it calls for the launch of a permanent system amending the Dublin regulation, which determines which Member State should process the asylum application. We are in favour of establishing a "fair and binding" distribution mechanism and taking into account the possibilities for integration and the specific situations and needs of asylum seekers.  We want Member States to welcome refugees from third countries through a mandatory resettlement programme, and we consider it a top priority for the EU and its Member States to create safe and legal avenues for refugees, such as humanitarian corridors and humanitarian visas.  In this context, we consider it necessary to amend the Visa Code and include more specific common provisions on "humanitarian visas" and call on countries to do what is necessary to make it possible to apply for asylum at their embassies and consular offices.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I abstained from voting on this resolution, aware that it is an instrument used by the Groups of the People's, Social Democratic and Liberal Party to carry out a face-washing while their governments and the European Commission keep their border policy closed. The resolution is not at the root of the problem and keeps the door open to future military interventions that will only aggravate it, as well as giving its full support to Mogherini's mediterranean militarisation plan (EUNAVFOR Med) and the Commission's insufficient plan to accommodate the small number of 160,000 people, well below the European Union's genuine reception capacity. Moreover, the resolution does not condemn key aspects of the European Commission's migration policy, such as the closure of borders and their outsourcing. We reject the continued separation of asylum seekers from migrants fleeing hunger and misery, and the latter group continues to be condemned to immediate expulsion. For all this, I cannot support an accomplice resolution of criminal policy, but I abstained in recognition of the improvement over previous resolutions that openly criminalized migrants.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. This summer has shown once again that migration is not a temporary problem and that the refugee wave continues, and that all this highlights the urgent need to do everything possible to save the lives of people fleeing their countries and in danger. Persistence of conflict, regional instability and human rights violations lead to an unprecedented number of people seeking protection in the EU. Coordination between Member States to alleviate and solve this problem is critical. More Europe and more solidarity must replace individual measures. All Member States need to fulfil their international obligations, including the rescue obligation at sea. The number of asylum applications affecting children has increased by 75% since last year. I welcome this resolution in which the European Parliament urges the EU and the Member States to do everything possible to prevent further deaths at sea or on land.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. I rejected the European Parliament resolution on the migration and refugee crisis of 10 September 2015. The paper calls almost uncritically for the European acceptance of the German welcome culture and criticises the countries that do not want to follow this line. In view of the current figures and the migration potential triggered by the German position and, in particular, Mrs Merkel, this one-sided ideological position must fail in reality. If we want a European solution, we must consult and involve the other Member States, and urgently avoid going it alone. The report praises this single-handedness and thus causes great resentment in the EU. There is no word on the long-term repatriation of asylum seekers and it can be assumed that permanent migration is accepted or even desired. However, the EU must not impose this decision on the Member States.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The European Parliament's resolution on migration and refugees in Europe regrets all those who lost their lives on their way to Europe and solidarity with the victims of the conflict. At this point, the European Union faces many challenges, but as European Commission President Jean-Claude Junker stressed in his first speech on the situation in the Union, migration and refugees are the Union's biggest test and must be our priority. I supported a resolution welcoming the European Commission's initiatives to relocate a large number of asylum applicants with operational and financial assistance to Member States. Our obligation is to show solidarity towards refugees fleeing conflict and to take equal responsibility in all Member States. We do not need to close borders, but they need to be effectively managed because people who want to pass them are looking for a safe and democratic society.  We call on all Member States to adapt legislation as soon as possible, implement a common asylum system and strengthen the Union's role in finding a long-term and sustainable solution to the conflict.

name: Thomas MANN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the resolution. It is the EP's response to the impressive speech by Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker. He summed up the situation in a nutshell: humanity is not negotiable, but the basis of our coexistence and our culture in Europe. In order to do justice to it, a historic effort is needed – and a European one! The impression that Europe has not delivered in the refugee crisis is wrong. It is not Strasbourg or Brussels, but many capitals that have failed miserably. The EU, on the other hand, has acted: more than 120,000 people have been rescued since Operation Triton began. EUR 4 billion has been allocated to refugees in Syria, Lebanon, Jordan, Iraq, Turkey and Egypt. The European asylum system, which has been repeatedly called for, has long been a reality. Common standards for the treatment and reception of asylum seekers apply throughout Europe. However, these are not implemented in all Member States, so the European Commission has opened 32 infringement proceedings. People in Germany and other Member States have demonstrated impressively through many voluntary initiatives what helpfulness means. That is exemplary! However, we need the solidarity of the other European partners. The EU Nobel Peace Prize laureate is called upon. The meeting of EU interior ministers on 14 September will show whether all partners have the necessary maturity.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the joint motion for a resolution on migration and refugees in Europe, because the European Parliament is calling, firstly, on the European Commission to finally start amending the existing Dublin Regulation, effectively showing the tendency to abolish Dublin III. Secondly, because the European Parliament calls on the Member States to introduce strict criminal sanctions for trafficking and trafficking in human beings to and throughout Europe. Thirdly, because the European Parliament invites the Commission and the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy to convene an international conference on the refugee crisis, with the participation of the EU, member states, organisations associated with the UN, the United States, relevant international NGOs and Arab states with a view to establishing, inter alia, a common global humanitarian aid strategy.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ We need action for the establishment of humanitarian corridors throughout the countries of transit for refugees (in both the Mediterranean and the Western Balkans), with the aim of providing humanitarian aid and ensuring that the refugees’ most basic needs are covered and their human rights respected. We stress that the humanitarian response to the refugee crisis should be part of a longer-term plan that includes humanitarian aid support for the countries neighbouring the refugees’ countries of origin, strengthens their early recovery and protection capacities, reinforces the role of UN-related agencies and improves the political, social, human rights and economic situation in developing countries of origin and transition.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 As statistical data recorded during the summer show, the number of asylum seekers in Europe has increased by 75%. This situation, exacerbated by the situations of discomfort associated with it, requires the Member States to lay the foundations for joint concrete action, which is sufficiently forward-looking and coherent. It is for these reasons that I have chosen to support with my vote the text of this resolution, which calls for joint action inspired by the principle of solidarity between the Member States.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: In writing. The European Parliament was forced to vote on a resolution on immigration and refugees in Europe. As has often been the case since the beginning of the humanitarian crisis in our continent, parliamentarians have managed to rise to the challenge of making a coherent answer, which is based on a simple observation: migration flows to Europe are not destined to dry up. It is therefore a question of organising themselves, in accordance with the values of solidarity, the Schengen agreements and international conventions, in order to enable asylum seekers to apply for protection without putting their lives at risk.  To do so, the resolution put to Parliament's vote calls for a three-step strategy to which I fully subscribe. In the short term: abandoning the absurd Dublin Regulation and encouraging states to adopt a mechanism for the solidarity and binding distribution of asylum seekers. In the medium term: to build legal and secure access routes to our continent. In the long term: tackling the root causes of migration, such as poverty, inequality and climate change. I obviously voted for this resolution.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. The current situation regarding mass migration to the EU presents the Member States with a fait accompli that the EU is no longer in control of the situation and that some Member States, including the government of my country, are not complying with the rules and laws required by the EU. Instead of reintroducing border controls, respecting the Dublin regulations, protecting the external borders and tackling the root of the problem, open borders and derogations are simply stimulating the problem and not finding a definitive solution. Moreover, there is no clear distinction between clear economic migration and real refugees. For this and other reasons, I voted firmly against this resolution.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. In the face of the massive influx of illegal migrants into Europe, Member States are literally overwhelmed. This report explains that it is necessary to welcome the majority of these immigrants fleeing the conflicts and persecutions of the Islamic State. It calls for quotas requiring each country to take in, house and care for these migrants. The text calls on all European actors to fight against the smuggling networks that organise human trafficking. We strongly oppose this scandalous report. First, the conflicts in Libya, the Middle East and the Middle East are the result of an absurd foreign policy that has consisted of overthrowing totalitarian regimes for the benefit of Islamists. Secondly, it is necessary to remember that the majority of illegal immigrants are economic migrants who do not flee persecution and therefore have no vocation to stay in Europe. Thirdly, the European Union is complicit in smugglers by not bringing migrant boats back to their port of origin. The European institutions are therefore responsible for the human tragedy that is taking place in the Mediterranean.  Therefore, I voted against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. I have voted in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on migration and refugees in Europe. I believe that Europe must be jointly and severally and act responsibly in the face of a serious humanitarian crisis. However, it should not fail to be lucid, distinguishing what is not equal, even for its self-defense. That is why I also argue that the problem that is being availed by welcoming asylum seekers will only be resolved at the origin, eliminating those who allow themselves to try economic benefits, exploiting the horrible circumstances of the tragedy of other people and fighting the inswho kill, destroy and oppress religious fanaticism and medieval prejudice.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this cross-party resolution as it endorses the announcement by the Commission of a permanent relocation mechanism which will be activated in emergency situations. The resolution also underlines the Parliament’s strong support for a binding permanent relocation mechanism for persons in need of protection.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. The monitoring of our borders and the reception of refugees concern us all. We cannot therefore let a few states manage the bulk of the migratory pressure that is our common responsibility. This is a concrete application of solidarity between Member States. In today's humanitarian context, it is imperative to distinguish between refugees and economic migrants. If, on the one hand, we must work urgently and show universal humanist solidarity, we must, on the other hand, in the context of economic migration, work on the basis of strict conditions with a human face. But under no circumstances should we be tempted by a simplistic demonization of immigration. In the face of atrocities in some parts of the world, we must take part in global solidarity. This solidarity must be reflected both externally and internally. Other countries, often close to these conflict zones, are home to the overwhelming majority of refugees. To fail to take our share of responsibility would be to show selfishness unworthy of our humanistic values.

name: Angelika MLINAR
text: Writing. I have voted in favour of today's resolution and see it as an important step towards showing that the European Parliament and the Commission are pulling together. What is needed now is the Council, which has been trying to sit out the problem for far too long. We are in an exceptional situation which requires solidarity between all member states. I also believe that we are facing the greatest political challenge of the coming years and that many people are not yet aware of this. Now is not the time for political hacking. If, for example.B the Federal Government in Austria is calling for a European solution and, among other things, a European quota, then it must also be prepared to accept more refugees in Austria in a humane manner. This also applies to all other countries. Looking ahead, I would like to add that I support the Commission President's call for the right to work for refugees and see it as an important measure. We must now provide short-term assistance and plan for the long term, so as not to be about to face the next social crisis, which could also have social and security implications.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 Seven political groups (PPE, ECR, ALDE, GUE/NGL, Verts/ALE, ENF, S&D) tabled a motion for a resolution on the subject, four of which, including my own group, S&D, reached a compromise proposal. That's what I voted for.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. Europe is experiencing a humanitarian crisis unprecedented in recent history, and the thousands of refugees seeking peace and security on our territory are due to the thousands of refugees seeking peace and security on our territory. Many of those arriving are people fleeing the war in their countries and who must deserve our best welcome and support.  In this sense, it is urgent that necessary measures be taken to address the cultural and humanitarian atrocities that the Islamic State has been committing in these war scenarios. Europe has a great challenge ahead of it. While, on the one hand, it has a moral and humanitarian duty to take in refugees, on the other hand, it must be able to ensure that in the medium/long term it finds the necessary mechanisms and tools to respect the primacy of the human person in a dignified manner and to allow the return to the countries of origin of these people who yearn to live freely on their land.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution is enthusiastic about the Commission's proposals to manage the unprecedented influx of migrants. For example, it approves the emergency relocation of more asylum seekers from Greece, Italy or Hungary (120,000) and the permanent mechanism amending the Dublin Regulation... This proposal therefore requires a key to equitable and obligatory distribution in defiance of the will of the sovereign peoples who will have to suffer an influx of immigrants from countries with very different cultures and traditions. Where the EU had no money to cope with the misery in Greece, it finds money to support those of the inhabitants of third countries... It also aims to establish a common European asylum system, to maintain Schengen, all in 'European solidarity and human dignity'. One text points to the "extreme right" that would exploit the current situation. Considering that the EU's migration policy is a real scourge, I have decided to vote against this text.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. Political crises in the Middle East are generating unprecedented migration flows since World War II, and thousands of migrants have died crossing the Mediterranean. For several months now, the European Union's response has been inadequate: the distribution of migrants within Member States by binding quotas makes no sense within a Schengen area that abolishes internal borders. It is a call for immigration and encourages more and more families who think they will be welcomed in Europe to risk their lives in the Mediterranean. It permanently uproots migrants from their cultural cradle, language and land, making it impossible for them to return and complicating their integration into European countries that are already the most generous in the world and no longer have the means to welcome them with dignity. Moreover, the text addresses only the consequences and not the root causes of the migration tragedy, which will be resolved only at the cost of military intervention in the air but also on the ground, led by an international coalition including Russia and the Arab countries. For these reasons, I voted against this resolution.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 We very much welcome this motion for a resolution, which returns to the subject of the refugee crisis following Parliament's resolution in April and the Commission's proposal for an Immigration Agenda in May. With this text, we approve of the actions presented by President Juncker at his State of the Union address, asking the Commission to monitor and, if necessary, to intervene in the effective implementation by the Member States of the measures it provides for. In addition, we call for a further effort to amend the Dublin Regulation and for the preparation, in addition to reception management measures at this 'emergency' stage, of a longer-term strategy, including a strengthening of the European Union's role in conflict resolution and, in particular, to contribute to the search for sustainable political solutions in conflict regions. , such as Iraq, Syria, Libya and the Middle East.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I turn to President Juncker, while appreciating his intentions and the answers to the enormous problem facing the Member States of the European Union, regarding the constant influx of migrants, I must point out that so far Italy has dealt with this emergency on its own with its own resources, often making up for shortcomings and European support with its own structures. I believe that, although Europe is at last talking about solidarity, there are many problems in Italy, particularly with regard to the application of Dublin III. I therefore believe that we urgently need to address the issue of our borders and the Dublin Treaty in a unified way by amending rules that can no longer apply in the face of this humanitarian tragedy. I expect there to be constant pressure to persuade all Member States to have a single voice and action. I also believe that the unilateral initiative of the French and British raids against Syria is harmful and further increases the flow of migrants to our european coasts and borders. The unity of the Member States in response to this emergency is essential to create stability and credibility of our institutions.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of helping war refugees because we have to deal with this crisis and the European Union has to deal with it. It creates an incentive pressure for Member States to do much more in all three pillars of the problem, namely prevention, that is, in foreign aid, if necessary military, in humanitarian aid for countries where millions of refugees now live, which bear 100 times the burden. The common protection of the external borders should also be strengthened, and I expect further easing of the conditions under which selected countries attract not only refugees but also illegal migrants, and that the separation of refugees from economic migrants will finally begin in time. Just because one part of the resolution talks about uncontested compulsory quotas does not mean that we should leave everything to the old one instead. This would mean the closure of the Schengen borders and perhaps the disintegration of the entire Union. How much we have sacrificed in the last 10 years to get into that European Union.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I decided to abstain to this vote because the document is unclear on the mechanisms that are going to be established by the member states on issues related to migration or refugees. I am a strong believer in solidarity but I support a true solidarity in all cases and concrete solutions to resolve the migration crisis and truly help the refugees.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. A humane and workable solution must be found quickly to the refugee crisis. If this is not achieved or is not done, the risk of european division will increase significantly. The resolution of this crisis will also have a significant impact on the future of the European Union. Recent weeks have shown that the European asylum system is not working as it should. In the current situation, nowhere in Europe has we been able to deal with war refugees humanely. However, the refugee crisis is manageable and the European Union can deal with this humane settlement if all countries help. Some countries are making serious efforts, but many have not made a contribution so far. Such contrasts are also rapidly increasing tensions between EU Member States. Therefore, a humanly significant solution to the refugee crisis should be offered by all Member States.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: in writing. \u2012 Four years after the start of the conflict in Syria, more than 12 million people have been displaced, 4 million of whom are outside the country. Europe has mainly addressed the emergency aspect, through rescue operations at sea, but has not dealt with the needs of the population in conflict zones. The creation of humanitarian channels enabling asylum applications to be made in countries of origin and transit of migratory flows is the only real alternative to illegal travel. The rejection of people arriving at our borders violates the 1951 Convention on refugee status. The 2001 directive on temporary protection must be implemented, but it must not affect the long-term solutions of a permanent and binding relocation mechanism. It also seems inevitable to amend the Dublin Regulation, which imposes excessive and disproportionate efforts on certain countries. A Europe that rejects Syrians reinforces Islamic State propaganda and favors the interests of traffickers. We are taking on the historic responsibility for an inadequate European response to the most serious humanitarian crisis of the last 50 years.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Writing. – The joint resolution strengthens the persecution and repression of refugees and migrants. It insists on the implementation of the Dublin Directive, which, in conjunction with the unacceptable Eurodac Directive on fingerprinting and the Schengen Treaty, prohibits the movement of refugees and migrants to their countries of destination. Accepts the creation of so-called 'hot spots' and the list of so-called 'safe countries', where unacceptable discrimination between refugees and migrants will be made by direct expulsion of refugees and migrants; their imprisonment in concentration camps, up to 18 months, in accordance with the "Directive of Shame" (2008/115), which have voted in favour, military operations, such as EUNAVFOR Med, the reinforcement of FRONTEX and Europolice forces and their conversion into coast guard – border guard forces, which will multiply human tragedies in the Mediterranean. It urges, in imperialist interventions and wars, multiplying the victims, the uprooted of EU criminal activity. The JRC has put forward a comprehensive, in-depth proposal on the issue and calls on workers in Greece and Europe to support it, because it is the only one that can provide substantial relief to the problem, away from the barbarity of repression and exploitation.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: Writing. – The European Union is not only in crisis, but it is also in transformation. Further political and economic consolidation is needed on the basis of the fundamental ideas of the EU Fathers. It is necessary to consider what respect for human dignity means today and how to work together. Political will and reform are therefore needed. It's necessary to dynamite the transformation. The solution is not to renationalise competences, but to more Europe. The refugee crisis is an expression of the need for more Europe. I support a binding permanent mechanism for the relocation of beneficiaries of international protection, as well as the strengthening of security at the EU's borders. It is essential to address the root causes of mass migration flows, including by finding lasting solutions to conflicts in our neighbourhood, which calls for more political integration to establish a true European common security, defence, development and external policy strategy. I also support the fact that Africa needs a new approach that includes better opportunities for trade and development, which will provide opportunities for economic growth.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ The European Parliament talks these days about the refugee crisis, mentioning masses of refugees, migrant infestations, a tumour that metastasizes, there is talk of erecting walls, there is a clear awareness that the issue of positioning towards migrants can affect the outcomes of elections, the cost of helping migrants is added up.  It's like it's a mosquito infestation or like we want to protect ourselves from the waste. We are rightly concerned that there are also fraudsters among the refugees, but this does not diminish our responsibility to people who are on the run in fear for their own lives. And that's what we've forgotten - that it's about people, about people who just want to stay alive, who want a life for their children, want to breathe clean air instead of smoke explosions, want to fall asleep and wake up without fear.  We must provide them with either a new life between us or a safe life in their homeland. But primarily we need to start seeing them as people, not a problem. This is a challenge to our humanity.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution is enthusiastic about the Commission's proposals to deal with the unprecedented influx of migrants. For example, it approves the emergency relocation of more asylum seekers from Greece, Italy or Hungary (120,000) and the permanent mechanism amending the Dublin Regulation... This proposal therefore requires a key to equitable and obligatory distribution in defiance of the will of the sovereign peoples who will have to suffer an influx of immigrants from countries with very different cultures and traditions. Where the EU had no money to cope with the misery in Greece, it finds money to support those of the inhabitants of third countries... It also aims to set up a common European asylum system, to maintain Schengen, all in 'European solidarity and human dignity'. One text points to the "extreme right" that would exploit the current situation. Considering that the EU's migration policy is a real scourge, I have decided to vote against this text.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. - I support the proposal for a resolution on migration and refugees in Europe. The migration crisis is currently the biggest problem facing the European Union. The severity of the crisis is evidenced by figures recently released by the IOM and FRONTEX, with nearly 250,000 migrants arriving in the EU by sea in 2015. The number of illegal crossings of the EU's external borders, via the Western Balkans, stands at 102,342.  Such numbers really require an urgent response from the Union. I therefore welcome the recently presented proposal by the European Commission to implement the urgent redistribution of asylum seekers now in Greece, Italy and Hungary. In addition, I support the idea of establishing a permanent and binding refugee resettlement mechanism that will certainly help us in future crisis situations. These measures by the European Commission are only part of a comprehensive package of programmes and measures, which also includes a proposal to adopt a "Common European List of Safe Countries".  Such a list is necessary for member states to focus their reception capacities on those most in need of protection. The last thing I would point out is the need to find the cause of this migration crisis as well as sustainable solutions to conflicts adjacent to the Union, because the events there are also reflected in us, citizens of the European Union, and this migration crisis has proven it to us.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. The Union is now facing a serious and large-scale migration crisis. It is necessary to act quickly but in a coordinated manner. The European Parliament adopted a resolution following President Juncker's statements on the EU's emergency measures in the face of the migration crisis. However, I abstained on this text because some overly restrictive measures could undermine the stability of the Union. I am against mandatory and permanent quotas. First of all, I believe that the Union needs to rethink its migration policy, that it must regain control of this policy.

name: Emil RADEV
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I supported the migration resolution because I believe that the measures at stake benefit Bulgaria and that a new approach is needed to overcome the migration crisis. First, the European Union must set up centres in third countries to determine whether migrants heading to Europe are actually fleeing conflict or want to immigrate solely for economic reasons. Effectively implemented, this programme will reduce the number of economic immigrants who are a large part of the migration flow to Europe. It is extremely important to strengthen border controls to stop illegal immigrants trying to enter Bulgaria. Only through secure external borders can we guarantee national security and preserve one of the EU's greatest achievements – Schengen. With its extensive experience in successfully protecting the Bulgarian-Turkish border, Bulgaria can only contribute to the Schengen area. A more effective policy of returning illegal economic migrants entering Europe is also needed. The adoption of a pan-European list of safe countries of origin will speed up the examination of their documents and facilitate their return. At the same time, however, the EU must support the economic development of a number of countries in Africa through the proposed trust fund in order to turn from a source of immigrants into a source of prosperity.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: In writing. In this joint resolution, the European Parliament sets out priorities and steps to be taken now to save lives and improve the reception of refugees and asylum seekers on our continent. It reaffirms its support for the Commission's initiative to establish a permanent and mandatory mechanism for the allocation of applicants. It recalls that the best solution to avoid further tragedies is to create safe and legal migration routes for refugees, including through humanitarian visas or the possibility of seeking asylum at the embassies and consulates of the Member States. Finally, because migration is a global and complex phenomenon, MEPs in the European Parliament call on the European Union and its Member States, in conjunction with the international community, to play a leading role in conflict resolution and development aid. While some build walls by fuelling intolerable feelings and discourses against refugees, other Europeans are choosing humanity by showing their support and commitment to help those fleeing death. It is this real message of hope for the future of the Union that our national leaders must forcefully relay.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. We are facing an unprecedented humanitarian crisis that Europe and the Member States must manage with humanism and realism, clearly distinguishing between war refugees and economic migrants. This balance is reflected in the resolution on migration and the refugee situation in Europe adopted this afternoon by the European Parliament and which I have of course supported. The text is in line with Jean-Claude Juncker's State of the Union speech yesterday, stressing the need for greater solidarity.  In addition to the equitable distribution of 160,000 refugees, mainly Syrians, we liberals want a radical reform of the migration and asylum policy based on: - the creation of safe zones in and around conflict zones in combination with safe and legal routes within the Union, - the deepening of the Schengen area by strengthening the external borders of the Union.   More broadly, if Europe is to be effective in economic migration, this time, and to respond to the legitimate concerns of European citizens, it must do so without taboos and take the example of the countries of the new world: Canada, the United States and Australia, which are pursuing a chosen immigration policy.

name: Dominique RIQUET
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this European Parliament resolution on migration and refugees in Europe, which calls for a response as quickly as possible and in the best way to the urgency we are facing. Solidarity between Member States will be necessary to overcome this crisis.   Above all, the legal and budgetary resources available to the Union must be strengthened, notably through its Frontex agency. The phenomenon we are experiencing today is not temporary and cannot be managed without a common European policy in this area.  On the other hand, we need to address the causes of these displacements and therefore probably review our foreign policy with regard to the areas of departure.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. I supported this resolution on the plight of migrants and refugees in Europe. The European Union must respond to this crisis with a comprehensive and coherent immigration and asylum policy.  We need effective implementation of the European asylum system. The Dublin Regulation also needs to be amended so that a binding and permanent scheme for the distribution of asylum seekers is established between Member States, based on a fair and mandatory distribution key. The Commission's new proposal on the emergency distribution of more asylum seekers should also be welcomed. In addition, safe and legal avenues must be put in place to prevent further human tragedies, while an effective fight must be taken against criminal and heinous networks of smugglers. It is a question of solidarity. It is a question of values. It is a question of responsibility. There's an emergency.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because it supports the Commission's plan for the emergency transfer of more asylum seekers from Italy, Greece and Hungary to other Member States and because it calls for the launch of a permanent system amending the Dublin regulation, which determines which Member State should process the asylum application. We are in favour of establishing a "fair and binding" distribution mechanism and taking into account the possibilities for integration and the specific situations and needs of asylum seekers.  We want Member States to welcome refugees from third countries through a mandatory resettlement programme, and we consider it a top priority for the EU and its Member States to create safe and legal avenues for refugees, such as humanitarian corridors and humanitarian visas.  In this context, we consider it necessary to amend the Visa Code and include more specific common provisions on "humanitarian visas" and call on countries to do what is necessary to make it possible to apply for asylum at their embassies and consular offices.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I supported the joint resolution on migration and refugees, because the European Union must go beyond the indignation, albeit legitimate, to put in place a dignified and united migration policy. This is not the time to question Schengen, this is not the time to judge the philosophical or religious convictions of each other, the time has come to open up, to welcome those who are trying to save their lives, to flee war and bloody repression. I welcome the measures proposed by the Commission on the distribution and resettlement of asylum seekers in need of international protection. It is now up to the States to prove that the Union of which they are members bears its name. Refugee status must be sanctified, but the causes of evil must also be acted upon; these deadly conflicts at the gates of Europe. The European Union must contribute to their resolution by playing a more assertive role. We must also strengthen the fight against mafia smugglers, who make the misery of the world a despicable profit. The situation is complex and does not call for a single response, but urgent action is needed. More than a European issue, it is a question of humanity.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. Since the beginning of 2015, the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner has reported that 366,402 people have crossed the Mediterranean to reach the European continent and 2,800 people have lost their lives.  Faced with the urgency of this dramatic situation, the European Union and its Member States must react and show solidarity. This solidarity must not only take place between Member States but also towards refugees. This is a problem facing the European Union and requires a European solution.  On the other hand, the European Union, as a global actor, must act at the international level in order to achieve peace and political solutions to the conflicts that affect the countries from which the refugees come.  I voted in favour of this resolution because more than ever we must show solidarity.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal on migration and refugees in Europe. Member States must take action to take effective emergency measures, but also for the long term. Each individual State will have to assume its responsibilities and must guarantee the principles of solidarity. In order to resolve these problems, it is necessary to establish a balanced division of immigrants, according to compulsory quotas, to be allocated to each country. The report calls on the Commission to make changes to the existing 'right of asylum', including the overshoot of the Dublin Regulation, according to which asylum seekers are obliged to stop in the country where they have been granted status.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this resolution, still understanding that several key elements of it are missing, such as a fervent condemnation of the policy being followed with Frontex and the successive eurozone bunkerisation processes. There is also a lack of strong recognition of the responsibility of member states in the generation of these crises in the states that are the source of migration. The positive elements, on the other hand, are sufficient to make a vote in favour; highlights the recognition of civil society's work or direct criticism of far-right efforts to make a stand against migration more environmentally positive. We understand that we must continue to work on a line which, to the positive elements of this resolution, adds those blanks that prevent a firm vote.

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. ‒ For clear humanitarian reasons, I fully back this resolution. However, we also need a global long-term plan regarding how Europe should deal with the flow of asylum seekers. The plan would set a framework for what needs to be done in the coming years. Such a plan would: - estimate the numbers of genuine asylum seekers that would be arriving in Europe from Syria and other troubled areas in the next three years;  - suggest common accelerated procedures to distinguish them from economic migrants;  - propose clearer methods to ensure their proper reception on arrival;  - suggest EU-level schemes arranging accommodation and daily maintenance;  - propose programmes for their insertion in local communities;  - propose plans for their integration in labour markets without putting European workers and unemployed at a disadvantage;  - estimate the positive contributions which migrants could eventually make to Europe’s economy;  - estimate the costs of the plan over a five-year horizon and suggest ways and means for its financing. Concentrating on the systematic repartitioning of arriving migrants through obligatory quotas among Member States is a short-term response to a crisis that will persist. It could ultimately backfire.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Written. Europe faces a huge humanitarian challenge. A challenge that can only be solved jointly at European level. Leaving each country alone is neither a solution for the EU Member States nor for the thousands of war refugees driven away from homes. This only leads to an unequal distribution between countries and to more sad marches along Europe's motorways. These developments are also being seen in Danish soil these days. On this challenge, the EUROPEAN Union must come up with an answer and a solution. The key lies first and foremost with the Member States. We therefore fully support a pan-European solution, as agreed between the EU Member States. However, how such a solution will work in practice must be a question for the Member States that have to take part in it. Denmark has and will continue to have a clear exception in the area of refugee and asylum policy. That is the way it is today and that will be the future. The Danish exception is also clear in the adopted text.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I abstained from voting on this resolution, aware that it is an instrument used by the Groups of the People's, Social Democratic and Liberal Party to carry out a face-washing while their governments and the European Commission keep their border policy closed. The resolution is not at the root of the problem and keeps the door open to future military interventions that will only aggravate it, as well as giving its full support to Mogherini's mediterranean militarisation plan (EUNAVFOR Med) and the Commission's insufficient plan to accommodate the small number of 160,000 people, well below the European Union's genuine reception capacity. Moreover, the resolution does not condemn key aspects of the European Commission's migration policy, such as the closure of borders and their outsourcing. We reject the continued separation of asylum seekers from migrants fleeing hunger and misery, and the latter group continues to be condemned to immediate expulsion. For all this, I cannot support an accomplice resolution of criminal policy, but I abstained in recognition of the improvement over previous resolutions that openly criminalized migrants.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for a resolution that allowed for the most effective and ethical way of dealing with the migration and refugee crisis currently facing Europe. I hope that by voting this way the crisis will be one step closer to being solved.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ Croatia, like most Southeast European countries, is facing pressure from the refugee crisis in the European Union. The refugee crisis has been affecting neighbouring countries, namely Macedonia, Serbia and Hungary for the past three months, and puts Croatia in a situation where a high level of preparedness is needed. On this issue, I have already acted on 14 August this year as co-signatories of a letter sent by MEPs to the European Commission asking for the immediate activation of the civil protection mechanism with a view to helping the Member States most affected by the wave of immigrants and asylum seekers. I call on the Commission to strengthen and unite the common European asylum system as soon as possible, so that all Member States can properly implement EU legislation and to ensure the application of common effective, coherent and humane standards across the Union.  I also call on the Commission and the Member States to provide significant room for manoeuvre and willingness to allocate funds in the 2016 budget and the provisions of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) with a view to providing better support to the European Asylum Support Office. In conclusion, I think it is necessary to convene an international conference on the refugee crisis, attended by all key international actors, aimed at developing a common global humanitarian aid strategy.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The problem of migration and refugees cannot leave anyone indifferent who follows the stories of people who, in order to save their lives, are fleeing war threats and violence. We have already adopted some important resolutions on this subject in the European Parliament, but the problems with migrants and refugees have deepened. A year ago, we appealed to the Commission, the Council and the relevant security forces to take measures to break up smuggling gangs and smuggling groups and to prevent people from going to the Mediterranean. After a year, we note that smuggling networks have also grown inland, and people are no longer just at sea, but also inland using the Balkan route. I support all the points of the resolution, but I cannot agree with the point where a permanent binding system for the distribution of asylum seekers among the 28 Member States is established, using the mandatory distribution key, the so-called quotas, which is why I did not vote in favour of the motion for a resolution. I cannot imagine how we will redistribute migrants to countries to which they do not want to go. Are we going to redistribute them by force? I can't identify with that. They left their homelands before the violence, and should we use violence again?

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Writing. I rejected the European Parliament resolution on the migration and refugee crisis of 10 September 2015. The paper calls almost uncritically for the European acceptance of the German welcome culture and criticises the countries that do not want to follow this line. In view of the current figures and the migration potential triggered by the German position and, in particular, Mrs Merkel, this one-sided ideological position must fail in reality. If we want a European solution, we must consult and involve the other Member States, and urgently avoid going it alone. The report praises this single-handedness and thus causes great resentment in the EU. In view of the EU's major economic problems and the major integration problems of the refugees from Afghanistan, Eritrea, Iraq and Syria specifically referred to in the paper, the bad economic reality of large parts of the EU must not be denied, but a long-term perspective must also be developed. There is no word on the long-term repatriation of asylum seekers and it can be assumed that permanent migration is accepted or even desired. However, the EU must not impose this decision on the Member States. It is also regrettable that the resolution wants to fully uphold the Schengen Agreement, even though the many breaches of the law currently require a great deal of action.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: Written. For the N-VA, the asylum crisis must be addressed with a balanced overall package of measures with the aim of: a strong border policy coupled with an effective return policy, a Europe that does not put a brake on a firm integration and activation policy and as a key piece a proper dispersion plan. This resolution does not meet the conditions for such a structural approach. That is why the N-VA delegation voted against it. The N-VA defends a Europe that shows realism. Both the EU and the Member States must take responsibility. For the N-VA, there can be no question of a right to buy-back to the compulsory distribution of asylum seekers, which would now be on the table. Exemptions from responsibility guarantee a failed European asylum policy. We need a system in which all Member States show asylum solidarity. This also applies to the Eastern European countries which receive and expect a great deal of socio-economic European support, but have so far stubbornly refused to show solidarity in the reception of asylum seekers. For us, it's clear: for what, hear what.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. We support the creation of a resolution that would address the ongoing issue of refugee admissions, their accommodation and ensuring decent living conditions for all people who see shelter and salvation in Europe any time soon. The issue of migration is testing again the European Union's ability to deal with problems that require quick, immediate solutions.  While the institutions of the European Union are a place where different opinions and proposals can be heard, as leaders of a new, different and better world, we must not let diversity of opinions prevent us from carrying out the tasks we are obliged to do, not only because of the humanitarian and political values we represent, but also because of the moral consequences that the problem of migration and refugees presents. We hope that the resolution will be a step forward in relation to the current situation in the Member States in terms of reception and care for refugees. However, we also hope that the EU institutions will also address the causes of this problem as soon as possible, such as wars and conflicts in the Middle East as well as in Africa, in order to provide refugees from this part of the world with conditions to stay in their homelands and that their migration would be a matter of choice rather than coercion as is the case now.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: I did not support the proposal in writing ‒ because I reject quotas for the mandatory redistribution of migrants among EU Member States. This proposal encourages violations of the existing rules on border protection and, moreover, does not address the whole situation, but only leads to the creation of other new problems.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 This resolution is a serious improvement from previous resolutions. It calls for an amendment to the Dublin Regulation, for a common asylum system to be developed and for measures to be promoted for an equal distribution of burdens between States. However, it has serious shortcomings on fundamental issues. For example, the responsibility of the EU's dominant circles for the dramatic increase in refugees is not recognised because of the military imperialist interventions they have carried out in the countries of migrants, because of the funding and equipment of various groups in Syria and Libya and because of the neoliberal, neo-colonial policies that continue to promote at the expense of the poorest countries on the planet.
