Unfortunately, there is no mention in the report of the need to end EU military operations and redirect the Union's foreign policy. There is also no criticism of the continued reinforcement of the repressive forces, the Frontex forces that make Europe a fortress instead of strengthening humanitarian aid and rescue forces. What needs to be done, but not mentioned in the report, is to create legal and safe access for refugees and to promote additional measures by Member States to support refugees.  For these reasons we have abstained.

name: József SZÁJER
text: Writing. \u2012 I could not support today's parliamentary resolution on migration and migrants in Europe by my vote because it does not focus on the essential problems that reflect reality. The decision does not mention, for example, the wars in Syria or Libya as the reason for this migration, it is not tough enough on the dismantling of trafficking networks. The Current Commission's migration package is not acceptable to the Hungarian People's Party delegation in this way because it has not been able to provide answers to the burning questions that have been ringing for weeks. It does not say unequivocally that our priority is to protect Europe's external borders. The text does not make a clear distinction between genuine refugees and immigrants who risk their own lives and those of their families in the hope of better prosperity, so that they can reach countries that are more socially prosperous and therefore do not want to cooperate with the authorities in other Member States. Nor does the allocation mechanism under the quotas included in the package provide a sufficient solution to the current situation. the majority of immigrants will continue to do so after allocating quotas, as soon as possible, to states where they can expect greater social assistance. In the meantime, there is no point in talking too much about quotas and distribution, as long as the number of people who enter the EU every day increases by thousands at Europe's external borders, while only a fraction of them would be eligible for refugee status.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this decision, especially given that it is the most serious challenge facing the European Union at present, challenging European solidarity, to which the Commission's proposals forthing not only short-term but also long-overdue long-term structural measures. I agree that all Member States should be compelled to participate in the allocation of refugees, and that the governments that have opted out should face EU sanctions. Looking at the whole process, I think it is important that the use of European funds to receive refugees is closely monitored so that they can be used only for the benefit of refugees and not for measures and campaigns against them. I believe that this package of measures is only the first step towards addressing other types of migration through new Community instruments, and I voted to contribute to speeding up this process. I hope that such a clear stand by the European Parliament, in addition to the Commission's proposals, will have an impact on the Member States responsible for the effective measures and on the Council and will result in swift, effective action.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Support for refugees is both a legal and moral obligation for the Member States of the Union. However, the migration problem cannot be solved by responding only to its effects; the causes must also be addressed. Therefore, in addition to supporting genuine refugees, it is also necessary to be able to distinguish from incoming groups of people those who are not refugees. Economic migrants are not entitled to the same support as refugees. The Union and the Member States should establish an effective system for returning these persons to their countries of origin. Never mind, radical action should be taken against the exploitation of human tragedy by organised crime groups. However, any action will not have a positive effect until security is increased in the countries from which citizens flee to Europe. The Union should therefore verify the effectiveness of existing forms of aid to developing countries. Unfortunately, Parliament's resolution did not meet these challenges. Moreover, it proposed an automatic mechanism for the allocation of refugees in individual Member States, which is unacceptable to many countries. It must be borne in mind that each state in the Union is at a different level of economic development and has different economic and infrastructure opportunities and must therefore have the right to determine the number of refugees capable of providing assistance. For these reasons, I abstained from voting on this resolution.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution as it proposes the creation of a permanent redistribution system. Indeed, I believe that that this should only be one potential pillar of a more comprehensive European asylum and migration plan.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. —Europe has a moral duty to help the afflicted crying out for refuge in the escape from the horrors of war. Our leading role in the world must not only be based on economic and scientific achievements, but also on a higher degree of humanity and empathy. That's where I believe we all agree. But I am very dissatisfied with the messages the Union is sending at the moment because I have a feeling that certain political circles are using this appalling situation to promote their policies on importing cheap labour and changing europe's demographic structure. They are obviously unable to comprehend that we would help the citizens of Syria the most if we used all our military-diplomatic capabilities and stopped the war in their homeland and then extended a hand to them in building the kind of society they once had. Everything else is just a firefighting measure that, due to the increased security threat in these chaotic conditions, can very easily backfire on both Syrian refugees and their European hosts.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. According to President Juncker, Europe remains in solidarity with migrants as well as in the case of solidarity between Member States. I supported the motion for a resolution because I support the idea of a list of safe countries and the creation of a special refugee fund. Of course, fences could be built, but until the neighbouring countries are stable, the problem of refugee migration will not be solved, and Europe will still be the refuge of many. It is also of the utmtho is also of the utmtho is of paramount importance to preserve European interests, and legal immigration and the asylum system must be regulated without delay when borders are opened. We are marching in the right direction, but we still have a long way to go. It is worth noting that the EU is still the largest global donor when it comes to development and humanitarian aid, so far we have committed €4 billion to refugees from Syria. I supported the proposal.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this resolution, still understanding that several key elements of it are missing, such as a fervent condemnation of the policy being followed with Frontex and the successive eurozone bunkerisation processes. There is also a lack of strong recognition of the responsibility of member states in the generation of these crises in the states that are the source of migration. The positive elements, on the other hand, are sufficient to make a vote in favour; highlights the recognition of civil society's work or direct criticism of far-right efforts to make a stand against migration more environmentally positive. We understand that we must continue to work on a line which, to the positive elements of this resolution, adds those blanks that prevent a firm vote.

name: Evžen TOŠENOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the resolution on migration and refugees in Europe. I unequivocally reject mandatory quotas for refugees. No one can command sovereign states to grant international protection on their territory, just as refugees cannot be forcibly forced to go where they do not want to go.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Writing. I rejected the European Parliament resolution on the migration and refugee crisis of 10 September 2015. The paper calls almost uncritically for the European acceptance of the German welcome culture and criticises the countries that do not want to follow this line. In view of the current figures and the migration potential triggered by the German position, and in particular Mrs Merkel, this one-sided ideological position fails to achieve reality. If we want a European solution, we must consult and involve the other Member States, and urgently avoid going it alone. The report praises this single-handedness and thus causes great resentment in the EU. In view of the EU's major economic problems and the major integration problems of the refugees from Afghanistan, Eritrea, Iraq and Syria, which are specifically referred to in the paper, the bad economic reality of large parts of the EU must not be denied, but a long-term perspective must also be developed. There is no word on the long-term repatriation of asylum seekers and it can be assumed that permanent migration will be accepted or even desired. However, the EU must not impose this decision on the Member States. It is also regrettable that the resolution fully seeks to uphold the Schengen Agreement, although the many breaches of the law currently mean that there is a great need for action.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ The refugee crisis in Europe has shocked every European heart. There has been a tragic loss of lives of people seeking asylum in the EU. This urges the EU and the Member States to do everything possible to prevent further loss of life at sea or on land. I am in favour of European solidarity and respect for human dignity.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this resolution, still understanding that several key elements of it are missing, such as a fervent condemnation of the policy being followed with Frontex and the successive eurozone bunkerisation processes. There is also a lack of strong recognition of the responsibility of member states in the generation of these crises in the states that are the source of migration. The positive elements, on the other hand, are sufficient to make a vote in favour; highlights the recognition of civil society's work or direct criticism of far-right efforts to make a stand against migration more environmentally positive. We understand that we must continue to work on a line which, to the positive elements of this resolution, adds those blanks that prevent a firm vote.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because, among many other things, it reaffirms the urgent and priority need to create secure channels of entry into the EU for people in need of protection, calls for the creation of humanitarian visas and mentions the need to reform the Berlin system, create a binding refugee relocation mechanism and rethink and address immigration policy more holistically.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. The European Parliament cannot be impassive in the face of the refugee crisis in Europe. That is why we are voting in favour of this motion for a resolution to point out the European Parliament's position on this issue and the need for the institutions and governments of the European Union to take the necessary actions to combat the refugee crisis in Europe.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution to support the Commission's plan for the emergency transfer of more asylum seekers from Italy, Greece and Hungary to other Member States and to the implementation of a permanent system amending the Dublin regulation, which determines which Member State should process the asylum application. We are in favour of establishing a "fair and binding" distribution mechanism and taking into account the possibilities for integration and the specific situations and needs of asylum seekers.  We want Member States to welcome refugees from third countries through a mandatory resettlement programme, and we consider it a top priority for the EU and its Member States to create safe and legal avenues for refugees, such as humanitarian corridors and humanitarian visas.  In this context, we consider it necessary to amend the Visa Code and include more specific common provisions on "humanitarian visas" and call on countries to do what is necessary to make it possible to apply for asylum at their embassies and consular offices.

name: Johannes Cornelis van BAALEN
text: in writing. ‒ VVD abstained on the resolution as a whole for two reasons: Firstly: the proposal that asylum seekers, refugees and labour migrants are entitled to work during the procedures and granting of a definitive status. VVD is of the opinion that only if and when the asylum seeker, refugee or labour migrant has been granted a final and irrevocable status, may that person enter the labour market. Otherwise, expectations will be raised that the person concerned would be entitled to stay anyway. Secondly: the fact that the resolution proposes taking into account the preferences and consent of refugees for the countries they will be allocated to. This would undermine the allocation and quota system, as most refugees prefer in the end to stay in Germany or other countries such as Austria, the Netherlands, Belgium, Denmark and Sweden. VVD did not vote against the resolution because it is of the opinion that a new, integral system for asylum, refugee policy and labour migration, including protection of the EU’s external borders through Frontex and settlement in the region, must be created. Those persons not granted a status to come to or stay in the EU must be expelled.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: Written. 'I abstained from the resolution 'migration and refugees in Europe'. This text identifies a number of good things, such as the mandatory distribution of asylum seekers across Europe in emergency situations, a crackdown on criminal people smugglers and a stricter approach to asylum seekers from safe countries. However, the text goes too far on a number of points, for example in paragraph 13, where it is philosophised about the possibility of submitting asylum applications in embassies and consulates of the European Member States in the source countries. This would, in other time, lead to untenable situations. An important point of the resolution is paragraph 10, which calls on the Council and the Commission to set aside a substantial amount for the refugee issue in the 2016 EU budget. I wholeheartedly agree that money is needed. But this has to be budget neutral. The money must therefore be found elsewhere in the budget.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ With the refugee crisis in the Mediterranean at the forefront of our thoughts it was welcome to vote for a report that begins to look at how we can find a European solution to this issue. Balancing rights and responsibilities is never easy, but this report makes some moves towards this. By taking into account preferences and consent, as well as preserving family life in the allocation of refugees, we can do our utmost both the lives and the dignity of those in such dire need. This aids not only Italy and Greece but also Europe more broadly, by ensuring no state stands alone when dealing with this issue. Inaction in such times is not an act of courage but, an act of betrayal. Europe once again has the chance to lead on a matter of great humanitarian need.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. In the face of the inertia and the mind-blowing procrastination of Member States, the European Parliament was keen to express its position on what European migration policy should be in the face of the global humanitarian crisis. This resolution is the most ambitious that has been voted on by the European Parliament since I was an MEP. I welcome the commission's support for the relocation mechanism and the request for a review of the Dublin Regulation. The need to open legal channels of access to European territory is clearly reaffirmed, as is the possibility that asylum applications could be lodged in embassies.  But this resolution lacks criticism of the draft of a common list of so-called "safe" countries, it supports the establishment of "hotspots" and does not denounce the risks of return policies and enhanced negotiations with transit and origin countries whatever they may be.  If I did not expect a denunciation of the mortal consequences of fortress Europe, a minimum of reserve was necessary. I do not want to deny the progress and the need for Parliament to influence the States, but I want to mix my voice with those of the extreme right, so I have chosen to abstain.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The current situation regarding mass migration to the EU presents the Member States with a fait accompli that the EU is no longer in control of the situation and that some Member States, including the government of my country, are not complying with the rules and laws required by the EU. Instead of reintroducing border controls, respecting the Dublin regulations, protecting the external borders and tackling the root of the problem, open borders and derogations are simply stimulating the problem and not finding a definitive solution. Moreover, there is no clear distinction between clear economic migration and real refugees. For this and other reasons, I voted firmly against this resolution.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: in writing ‒ I did not support the joint resolution tabled because I reject the introduction of a permanent binding system for the distribution of asylum seekers. It is impossible to quickly plug holes in the common European asylum policy by making the crisis mechanism permanent. When a window breaks, adhesive tape is a makeshift, it's not a solution. One-off assistance to Greece, Italy and Hungary is essential so that the registration of asylum seekers does not fail. But we know that tackling the immigration crisis must also include better protection of the external borders, a rapid asylum procedure and the associated effective deportation of failed asylum seekers from the EU.

name: Flavio ZANONATO
text: in writing. \u2012 By voting on this resolution we have sent a strong signal to our national governments. We cannot remain passive in the face of the tragedy that is affecting Europe and we must act immediately to prevent further loss of life. We need to go beyond the Dublin Regulation, which must be replaced by a common European policy on the right of asylum based on solidarity. With this text, we have supported a permanent mechanism for the redistribution of refugees, which will enable Europe not to find itself in the shameful situation of the last six months. It is essential that we continue to work to ensure that migrants are treated with the dignity and respect due by all European countries and to force Member States to apply existing humanitarian visa legislation correctly.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Writing. – The joint resolution strengthens the persecution and repression of refugees and migrants. It insists on the implementation of the Dublin Directive, which, in conjunction with the unacceptable Eurodac Directive on fingerprinting and the Schengen Treaty, prohibits the movement of refugees and migrants to their countries of destination. Accepts the creation of so-called 'hot spots' and the list of so-called 'safe countries', where unacceptable discrimination between refugees and migrants will be made by direct expulsion of refugees and migrants; their imprisonment in concentration camps, up to 18 months, in accordance with the "Directive of Shame" (2008/115), which have voted in favour, military operations, such as EUNAVFOR Med, the reinforcement of FRONTEX and Europolice forces and their conversion into coast guard – border guard forces, which will multiply human tragedies in the Mediterranean. It urges, in imperialist interventions and wars, multiplying the victims, the uprooted of EU criminal activity. The JRC has put forward a comprehensive, in-depth proposal on the issue and calls on workers in Greece and Europe to support it, because it is the only one that can provide substantial relief to the problem, away from the barbarity of repression and exploitation.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 I could not support this joint resolution because it proposes to distribute refugees among the Member States on the basis of binding quotas. In my opinion, the solution is not to pressure the Member States to accept the number of refugees set by the EU, but to the voluntary reception and the possibility of accepting them.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing \u2012 I could not support parts of the resolution that offer quotas as a solution. Solidarity and assistance cannot be forced. However, I agree with many of the appeals in the text, which is why I abstained in the final vote. It is important to create so-called hotspots as quickly as possible and to ensure that they function effectively. I also support updating safe countries of origin, which will allow asylum applications to be processed more quickly and direct our assistance to those who really need it.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution on migration and refugees in Europe, because I believe that the European Union should adopt a longer-term, stronger and comprehensive approach to asylum and migration. The great instability in conflict zones, where the collapse of states and the pressure of terrorism and fanaticism endanger the dignity and survival of millions of human beings, has brought with it an unprecedented number of people seeking protection in Europe. Unfortunately, the current situation shows a regrettable lack of solidarity between governments and asylum seekers, as well as insufficient coordination in European action. The European Union cannot be a barrier and cannot allow physical or political walls to be built inside it. As such, to this political and humanitarian challenge that constitutes the flows of refugees, the European Union must respond urgently, exemplarily and in solidarity, doing everything possible to save the lives of people arriving daily in its territory, expressing its solidarity and compassion for the high number of refugees and migrants and also acting to stabilise the areas of the world that are in conflict.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 In the tragic moment in Europe, with the exodus of hundreds of thousands of human beings who, fleeing war, misery, hunger and death, from countries in the Middle East and the African continent, risk their lives seeking survival on European soil, the European Parliament has discussed and adopted another resolution on the subject. The European institutions and this EP have been forced to look at the problem of migration as unavoidable. The text of this resolution is demonstrative in this regard, with some positive lines of intervention, alongside a more general meaning in a genuine proclamation of intent.  The hypocrisy of the majority of this European Parliament, however, prevents the concrete identification of the causes that motivate such an exodus, omitting the responsibilities that the EU and its powers have in the conflicts that are at its origin. In addition, it maintains the defence of all the policies and instruments of Fortress Europe. The human drama that is being lived, and the urgent need for measures to mitiguate the consequences of this migration flow, have prevented us from voting against. However, in view of the lack of solutions to put an end to the causes of this humanitarian drama, as well as the identification of these same causes, we abstained.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: – The European Union wants to be an active player in the middle east peace settlement process, which can be endorsed. Both the Israeli side and the Palestinian have work to do for peace. However, some important suggestions are missing from the decision adopted. The Union should demand an end to Israel's occupation of the West Bank, gaza strip and East Jerusalem. Condemn the policy of collective punishment israel pursues against the Palestinian people. Ask for the release of Palestinian political prisoners, including members of the Legislative Council. Clearly condemn the escalating violence of the settlers. Although the current decision represents a step forward from the one previously adopted by Parliament on a similar subject, I have not been able to support it because of these shortcomings.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur The European Union consistently supports a two-state solution, the only way from war to peace, that is when the Palestinians and israelis recognise each other, and the borders of 1967. Also, on condition that Jerusalem is the capital of both countries. In my opinion, this is a sensible solution and could provide a solid basis for both countries in the future. Unfortunately, it must be noted that palestine and Israel are currently at another impasse in their negotiations. I would like to note the active role of the High Representative of the European Union, Mrs Mogerini, in trying to revive this negotiation process and wish her the same vigorous and persistent continued support for the peace process in the Middle East. And I would like to state that I am very frightened by the populist slogan that there will now be two countries for two peoples. There will be two countries for all the peoples who want to live in them! Thank you!

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Mr President, all of us, being human, tend to over—estimate our centrality to events. Just as we insist on seeing the migration crisis as being our responsibility, rather than that of Assad or Islamic State, so we tend to assume that the Middle Eastern crisis is somehow for us to solve. The reality is that our ability to exert a positive influence is limited. It is not zero, but it is limited. It is up to the peoples of the region to come to their own deal, and actually they are inching towards a deal. One of the bits of the deal which they do seem to be agreeing on is that there will be some land swaps, some different border.  That is why I think it is a mistake for the European Union, in this report, to come blundering through and assume the 1967 border as the final outcome, because that is the very kind of thing that the negotiations are there to determine. This is not designed to bring the two sides closer together. It is not just about making ourselves feel better. It is not always about us.

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: Written. I chose to vote in favour of the resolution, negotiated by my group, the EPP, together with the other large groups. The resolution is fundamentally well balanced, but there is a lack of clearer condemnation of Hamas' terrorist regime in Gaza, the lack of democracy and freedom in the PLO-ruled West Bank, and the responsibility of the surrounding Arab dictatorships for supporting terrorism and the perpetuating of the refugee problem. Furthermore, the wording on Iran and the agreement on its nuclear programme express optimism which I fear is unfounded. Iran's regime has not changed character: its leadership still wants Israel's annihilation and regards the West as a mortal enemy. The resolution should therefore have contained firm demands that the possible lifting of other sanctions not linked to its nuclear activities should certainly not be lifted unless Iran respects human rights. This is because iran's leadership expressed that the nuclear agreement should be interpreted as a basis for the abolition of all sanctions against the country.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. This resolution focuses primarily on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. In this regard, it reaffirms the European Parliament's support for the solution of two States at the 1967 borders and stresses the need to ensure the viability of the Palestinian state, and also condemns the persistent expansion of Israeli settlements, urging Israel to immediately interrupt them and reverse this policy, while expressing its deep concern at the growing violence of settlers in the West Bank. While the resolution adopted does not at any time criticize the EU's complicity with Israel and its actions, it reflects a very positive element in my view that it is the unequivocal and explicit recognition that the EU-Israel agreements will not apply in the Palestinian Occupied Territories, as reiterated in the Conclusions of the Foreign Affairs Council on 20 July. In this regard, since the resolution also calls for an end to the Israeli blockade of the Gaza Strip and its urgent reconstruction, my vote has been positive.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as it reiterates the EU’s strong support for the two-state solution based on 1967 borders, calls for structured dialogue to this end, calls for the EU to enhance its role in the region, calls for an end to the blockade of the Gaza Strip and its immediate reconstruction.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. The Middle East peace process between Israel and Palestine has stalled. The EU calls for the immediate resumption of credible peace efforts and reiterates its strong support for a two-state solution. I therefore welcome Parliament's resolution, which calls for a new multilateral approach on the part of the EU that takes greater account of the interests of peace and security for both Israelis and Palestinians.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. On the merits, several aspects of this motion for a resolution are positive. It is thereby commendable to wish for a lasting and just peace for the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Moreover, the call to ensure the safety of the civilian population and the demand for the lifting of the blockade of Gaza are quite understandable in view of the current situation in the Middle East.   However, together with my colleagues from the National Front, we believe that the European Union does not have to meddle in foreign policy. It must remain a prerogative of the states. However, this motion for a resolution goes against this principle when it affirms that the Union must develop a comprehensive and coherent vision and be politically involved in the resolution of the conflict. By voting on this text, the European Parliament illegitimately arrogates an exclusively regal jurisdiction. Once again, the Union is uncomplicatedly encroaching on the sovereignty of the Member States.   Therefore, I voted against it.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ The European Union should not be involving itself as a major player in international foreign affairs. It has the potential to be counterproductive, especially given some of the language which has been used in this Chamber concerning sensitive matters in the Middle East.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to strengthen the EU's role in the Middle East peace process. I agree with the urgent need for a convincing resumption of efforts to achieve peace. Israel and Palestine should avoid actions that could lead to further escalation of the conflict. I agree with the calls for the High Representative to make better use of the political relations and best practices of the EU and its Member States in order to play a genuine political role in the Israeli-Palestinian peace process

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. It is one of the most deleterious roles that the European Union has played in the Middle East, in its total submission to the short-term interests of the United States of America and the petromonarchies of the Gulf. We have to totally change our perspective!

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I have endorsed this joint resolution which first calls for the immediate resumption of credible peace efforts and welcomes the Union's commitment to work actively towards a renewed multilateral approach to the peace process Parliament reaffirms its strong support for the two-state solution, on the basis of the 1967 borders, with a mutual agreement on the exchange of territories and Jerusalem as the capital of the two entities. , namely the State of Israel, whose security would be assured, and an independent, democratic, one-sided and viable State of Palestine, living side by side in peace and security, in mutual recognition, under the right to self-determination and in strict respect for international law.  It stresses that non-violent means and respect for human rights and humanitarian law are the only way to achieve a just and lasting peace between Israelis and Palestinians Another important element is that the resolution condemns the uninterrupted expansion of Israeli settlements, which violates international humanitarian law, fuels Palestinian resentment and undermines the viability of a two-state solution , and calls on the Israeli authorities to immediately cease and abandon their policy of establishing

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I have signed and supported this resolution because the Union's role in the Middle East peace process needs to be boosted. The role that the High Representative is playing needs the support of Parliament. I also voted against the two ECR amendments as I do not believe that the two-state solution for two peoples, given that 20% of Israel's population is Arab and would be total discrimination.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution aims to increase the responsibilities of the European Union as a player in the Middle East and to arrive at a peace initiative for the region.  This proposal is nonsense given the huge disparity in the positions of the EU Member States on the issue, but also in view of the fact that it is not the EU alone, with fine declarations, that will succeed in safeguarding peace in the Middle East. By seeking diplomacy, the EU really prevents any resolution of conflict, as it adds cacophony by asking States to find a common position that will produce only a vague declaration of good intentions to satisfy all parties.  So I decided to vote against it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 While the resolution is largely acceptable, especially in the passages stressing that achieving peace in the Middle East remains a key priority for the international community and in the destabilising role for the region due both to the violent crisis in Syria and to the accentuation of radicalism and the spread of terrorism in the Middle East, there are some passages that I found unclear and contradictory That is why I abstained.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. U2012 Achieving peace in the Middle East remains a key priority for the international community and an indispensable element for regional stability and security. By this resolution, which I voted in favour of, Parliament has an impact on its support for the two-state border-based solution of 1967 and the capital of Jerusalem for both States. It also expresses its deep concern at the persistent impasse in the Middle East peace process and calls for credible peace efforts to resume without delay. It also condemns the persistent expansion of Israeli settlements, which violates international humanitarian law, stokes Palestinian resentment and undermines the viability and prospects of a two-state solution, and calls on the Israeli authorities to immediately interrupt and reverse their settlement policy. It also urges the High Representative and the EU Special Representative to make better use of the political relations and institutional expertise of the EU and its Member States in order to play a real political role in the Israeli-Palestinian peace process.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ The Israeli-Palestinian conflict continues to have an impact on the entire Middle East, although it has recently been overshadowed by the crisis in Syria and the rise of the so-called Islamic State. U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry's 2013-2014 initiative and the war in the Gaza Strip in the summer of 2014 were followed by a stalemate in the Middle East peace process between Israelis and Palestinians.  I call on the Vice-President, High Representative Mogherini, to use effectively all existing EU instruments, including positive and negative incentives, which allow for the impact on Israel and the Palestinians in order to reach a two-state solution.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against. The resolution is unbalanced in favour of Palestine.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the motion for a resolution on the role of the European Union in the Middle East peace process because the resolution of the Arab-Israeli conflict is a fundamental interest of the European Union but unfortunately no longer the only one.  ISIS aims to play its part in the Balance of the Middle East, and the Arab-Israeli conflict will not remain immune from this threat. The map of the Middle East is changing, in this part of the world an unprecedented war is being fought. Despite this very serious situation, the European Union must continue to play its role by making its presence in the region felt even more and by working with its partners to tackle the new threats decisively and speed up the peace process. The efforts made in this direction by High Representative Federica Mogherini will be crucial in identifying further points of mediation.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ The EU’s should stop attempting to become a major player in international foreign affairs, as it has the potential to be both repetitive and sometimes counterproductive, as contradictions with the opinions of individual Members States, have the potential to further complicate matters. I voted against this resolution for this very reason, as well as my concerns over the bias and obvious lack of neutrality over the tragic Israel/Palestine issue, in particular.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution to underscore the pressing need to renew the peace process. Parliament called for the resumption of credible peace efforts without delay whilst underlining the fact that any lasting solution to the conflict can only be achieved in a regional context with the involvement of all relevant regional stakeholders and the support of the international community. Parliament reiterated its strong support for the two-state solution.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution reaffirming that achieving peace in the Middle East is a key priority of the international community, reiterating support for the two-state solution according to the 1967 borders and relaunching the EU's desire to facilitate the resolution of the conflict. Of particular importance to the 5-Star Delegation is the paragraph condemning the continued expansion of Israeli settlements which, in doing so, violate international humanitarian law, fuel Palestinian resentment and undermine the feasibility and prospects of a two-state solution. From the point of view of transparency, paragraph 14, which calls on the EEAS and the Commission to report to Parliament on the destruction and damage to EU-funded structures and projects in the occupied Palestinian territories, is particularly important. Finally, paragraph 16 reiterates the call for an end to the blockade of the Gaza Strip following the summer 2014 war. The work of UNRWA is praised, for whose funding crisis is expressed in concern, calling for more EU financial support for it.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 It is very positive that the EU's willingness to provide support to facilitate the resolution of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict as well as the wider Arab-Israeli conflict is stressed by peaceful and constructive means that serve the EU's interests for security, stability, and prosperity in the Middle East. Through the resolution, it again calls for a new EU approach that truly serves the interests of peace and security, both Israelis and Palestinians.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the EU's role in the Middle East peace process. Achieving peace in the Middle East remains a key priority for the international community. The European Union has repeatedly confirmed its commitment to the 1967 two-state solution, which provides for Jerusalem as the capital of both states and the coexistence of the State of Israel and a State of Palestine. In its resolution, Parliament expresses its concern at the deadlock in the peace process, urges the Vice-President/High Representative and the EU Special Representative to make better use of the political relations and institutional competences of the EU and its Member States, which are based on Europe's geographical proximity, historical links and intensive economic exchanges with the Middle East region, expresses its concern at recent events in the West Bank and reiterates its call for an end to the blockade of the Gaza Strip and for the reconstruction and recovery of the area as a matter of urgency following the summer 2014 war.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe it is an further opportunity to boost peace, given the wider context of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, the violent crisis in Syria and the increase in radicalism through the spread of terrorism throughout the Middle East. I am convinced that this process is also necessary in view of the fact that Israel is one of the main trading partners and the largest donor of aid to the Palestinians. I stress that a lasting solution to the conflict can only be achieved in a broader context and with the involvement of all actors in the area, together with the support of the international community. I also welcome the positive role of the EU, which proposes a solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict by peaceful and constructive means, depending on the EU's own interests in terms of security, stability and prosperity in the Middle East.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. Today, more than ever, the achievement of peace in the Middle East is of paramount importance. The violent crisis in Syria, the rise of Daesh, the rise of radicalism and the spread of terrorism in the Middle East are creating significant security threats throughout the region causing great instability. I support this Resolution and express unequivocal support for the solution based on the coexistence of two states on the basis of the 1967 borders and that both Israelis and Palestinians should avoid actions that could aggravate the situation. In this sense, the expansion of Israeli settlements contrary to international law and which fuels Palestinian resentment should be avoided. A just and lasting solution can also only be achieved with the support of the international community. I welcome the initiatives of the UN Security Council to resume peace talks and the work of the European Union Police Mission for the Palestinian territories under the Common Security and Defence Policy.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. This resolution focuses primarily on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. In this regard, it reaffirms the European Parliament's support for the solution of two States at the 1967 borders and stresses the need to ensure the viability of the Palestinian state, and also condemns the persistent expansion of Israeli settlements, urging Israel to immediately interrupt them and reverse this policy, while expressing its deep concern at the growing violence of settlers in the West Bank. While the resolution adopted does not at any time criticize the EU's complicity with Israel and its actions, it reflects a very positive element in my view that it is the unequivocal and explicit recognition that the EU-Israel agreements will not apply in the Palestinian Occupied Territories, as reiterated in the Conclusions of the Foreign Affairs Council on 20 July. In this regard, since the resolution also calls for an end to the Israeli blockade of the Gaza Strip and its urgent reconstruction, my vote has been positive.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with the EU approach that peace in the Middle East is conditional on a comprehensive regional solution. We are also concerned about peace in the region, knowing that the Union is Israel's largest trading partner and the largest donor of aid to the Palestinians. This is why it is important that the EP supports efforts in the UN Security Council to resume peace talks between Israelis and Palestinians. Parliament condemns the continued expansion of Israeli settlements. It is worth noting that in the report the EP calls on the European External Action Service and the Commission to report to Parliament on the destruction and damage to EU-funded facilities and projects in the occupied Palestinian territories. I supported the report.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ Parliament’s joint resolution expresses deep concern at the persisting stalemate in the Middle East peace process, and calls for the resumption of credible peace efforts without delay. It also calls on both Israelis and Palestinians to avoid steps which could spark further escalation, including incitement, as well as unilateral measures which could prejudice the outcome of negotiations and threaten the viability of the two-state solution. Furthermore, the resolution calls on Commission Vice-President Federica Mogherini to increase the EU’s efforts in pushing for and facilitating a resumption of talks. I believe that the resumption of peace talks in the Middle East is long overdue and that the EU should leave no stone unturned in facilitating a two-state solution as soon as possible, therefore I supported this resolution.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. As part of the Middle East peace process, this resolution lists the objectives of the mandate to the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs, Federica Mogherini, in the framework of the peace negotiations between Israel and Palestine. This recommendation sets out a new European Union approach to resolving the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, focusing on political negotiations, the use of non-violent means and the priority given to the rights of civilians. MEPs also reiterate the European Union's position in favour of the option of two sovereign and independent states. In support of this recommendation, I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. I supported the motion for a resolution on the EU's role in the Middle East peace process. This resolution should be the European Commission's roadmap. As it stands, we can only deplore the lack of a comprehensive and coherent vision of the EU's commitment to the peace process. The appointment of a special representative for the peace process to the MO therefore gives relief to the EU's engagement in the region, which can only be encouraged. Europe must make the best use of the institutional and political expertise it has in the region to play a concrete political role in the resumption of a credible and lasting peace process. The aim must be to achieve, through non-violent means and respect for human rights and humanitarian law, a bold initiative that serves the interests of peace and security of Israelis and Palestinians.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the European Parliament resolution on the EU's role in the Middle East peace process, because the text rightly draws attention that there will be no peace in the Middle East until it is resolved, both the conflict between Israel and Palestine and the civil war in Syria and the threat of the spread of Islamic State.  It is increasingly clear that the conflict between Israel and Palestine is becoming an integral part of the much larger clash taking place in the Middle East, namely the conflict between sunni Islam terrorist organizations united and headed by the Organization of Islamic State, which co-operates with all other terrorist organizations, such as Hamas in Palestine, and fights on several fronts. That is why I is deeply concerned about the israeli-Palestinian peace process, because raging conflicts and the spread of terrorism and radicalism pose a direct threat to Israel's security and stability in the region, but also to the security of the EU. Without resolving this problem without resolving this conflict, there is no solution for the other. The EU should not engage in negotiations with entities pleading for the destruction of other nations. Negotiations with Hamas and with The Islamic State cannot and should not be.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We vote against because the solution to this long-standing conflict will not come through new funding to NGOs that often have a controversial role and action.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 Achieving peace in the Middle East remains a key priority of the international community and an indispensable element for stability and security in the region, and therefore require a comprehensive regional solution. The violent crisis in Syria, the rise of Daesh, the rise of radicalism and the spread of terrorism in the Middle East are creating significant threats to the security of Israel and the entire region, exacerbating the suffering of palestinians, but also creating shared interests between Arab states and Israel at the time of the nuclear agreement with Iran , where the EU plays a significant role, provides a unique opportunity for the peace process, which should not be lost. It is with concern that I see the persistent deadlock in the Middle East peace process being crucial in relaunching credible peace efforts without delay. I agree that any lasting solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict can only be achieved in a regional context, with the participation of all stakeholders and the support of the international community.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution on the role of the European Union in the Middle East peace process because I am convinced that peace and stability in this region is a fundamental prerequisite for the security of the international community. The Middle East today is one of the hottest areas in the world and presents multiple challenges that need to be addressed as soon as possible and without hesitation.  The European Union has a duty to exercise its external action to pacify a region that must simultaneously face the advance of the Islamic State, the war in Syria, the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and religious radicalisation. I appeal to the Vice-President - High Representative for Foreign and Security Policy Federica Mogherini to step up diplomatic efforts to achieve a stable solution, always bearing in mind the great cultural, political and geographical links between the European Union and the Middle East. I very much hope for the resumption of peace negotiations between the Israeli and Palestinian authorities and I urge both sides to lower the tone of the confrontation and not to further fuel hatred and resentment among the people who have certainly paid the highest price for this conflict.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted today against the motion for a resolution on the EU's role in the Middle East peace process, which does not take too little account of Israel's particular vulnerability, the recurrent attempt at diplomatic and economic isolation of the country and Iran's difficult role, which is still not to be underestimated.

name: Juan Carlos GIRAUTA VIDAL
text: In writing. The European Union and its institutions should not put pressure on a rule of law like Israel to advance the country process in the Middle East. The State of Israel has mature democratic institutions, and therefore has the institutional and legal capacity to decide and implement the measures it believes are necessary to move the peace process forward, without the EU interfering. That is why I voted against this resolution.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the joint resolution on the EU's role in the Middle East peace process, given that we believe that achieving peace remains a key priority for the international community. Having said that, we reiterate support for the 1967 two-state border-based solution with mutually agreed land exchange and Jerusalem as the capital of both States. This resolution condemns the persistent expansion of Israelis, which violates international humanitarian law, stokes Palestinian resentment and undermines the objective viability of the prospects for a two-state solution, and therefore the prospects for peace. Moreover, this resolution ensures that all agreements between the EU and Israel state unequivocally and explicitly that they will not apply to territories occupied by Israel since 1967.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I along with my fellow Labour MEPs voted in favour of this resolution. The resolution has called for a fresh EU approach that genuinely serves the interests of peace and security of the Palestinian and Israeli people alike. It is time for the EU to stop hiding behind the leadership of the USA on this matter, which has demonstrated a lack of resolve to enable a credible negotiation process based on equality of the parties and respect for international law. The resolution urges the EU to fulfil its responsibilities as an influential player and to take a bold and comprehensive peace initiative for the region, a position I support. It is unusual that MEPs speak with much unity, but I was pleased to see this resolution pass with a significant majority.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: In writing. The EU must play a leading role in the Middle East peace process. Peace between Israelis and Palestinians will only be possible through the peaceful coexistence of two viable states. This is reaffirmed by this resolution for which I voted. I would like, through this vote, to denounce the main obstacles to the peace process: the colonization of Palestinian territories and related human rights violations, the blockade of Gaza, the rocket fire towards Israel, the division of the Palestinian Authority. The resolution calls on the parties to continue their efforts, and welcomes the work of the United Nations, especially for Palestinian refugees. Parliament supports the Commission, the EEAS, Mrs Mogherini and Mr Gentilini, and wants to see the EU firmly assume a role that could be valuable in a situation that, just a year ago, was sinking into the war in Gaza. I am convinced that the EU must deepen a political solution to the peace process, while avoiding certain indirect responsibilities in the conflict. For example, there is a need to study more carefully the destination and use of European funds in the region and to move forward on the labelling rules for products from Israeli settlements.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution. We must do everything we can to achieve a resumption of credible peace efforts without delay. High Representative Federica Mogherini and EU Special Representative Fernando Gentilini must make better use of the institutional and political expertise of EU Member States in the region to play a real political role in the peace process for a two-state solution.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the joint resolution on the EU's role in the Middle East peace process, given that we believe that achieving peace remains a key priority for the international community. Having said that, we reiterate support for the 1967 two-state border-based solution with mutually agreed land exchange and Jerusalem as the capital of both States. This resolution condemns the persistent expansion of Israelis, which violates international humanitarian law, stokes Palestinian resentment and undermines the objective viability of the prospects for a two-state solution, and therefore the prospects for peace. Moreover, this resolution ensures that all agreements between the EU and Israel state unequivocally and explicitly that they will not apply to territories occupied by Israel since 1967.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against because I do not believe that the solution to this long-standing conflict can come through new funding to NGOs that often have a controversial role and action.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I still believe it is very important that, again, we declare our support for a two-state solution with an independent, democratic Palestinian state living side-by-side with Israel and the other neighbours, a pillar of stability and democracy in the Middle East. Security of Israel has to be guaranteed, as well. I welcome the efforts in the UN Security Council, notably the initiative taken by France, to resume peace talks between Israelis and Palestinians through a resolution setting a framework and a timetable for this process and support the call for a comprehensive European Union peace initiative to be presented at an international peace conference. Our priority should be to ensure full respect for the rights of the people living in this area, whose personal safety and living conditions are threatened since decades by conflicts in Middle East.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a resolution on the EU's role in the Middle East peace process, as peacemaking in the Middle East remains a key priority for the international community and a necessary factor for regional stability and security. In particular, today it is evident the impact of events in the Middle East and on the European Union itself. I believe that the role of the EU and the Member States must be stronger in diplomatic terms.  New diplomatic initiatives are needed, such as Oslo 2. The EU, for example, needs to bring together all partners willing to engage in such a new diplomatic initiative in order to achieve results. In this context, the process that would be resolved by the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, as an important part of the overall crisis in the Middle East, should continue with the creation of two states.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. On the merits, several aspects of this motion for a resolution are positive. It is thereby commendable to wish for a lasting and just peace for the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Moreover, the call to ensure the safety of the civilian population and the demand for the lifting of the blockade of Gaza are quite understandable in view of the current situation in the Middle East.  However, together with my colleagues from the National Front, we believe that the European Union does not have to meddle in foreign policy. It must remain a prerogative of the states. However, this motion for a resolution goes against this principle when it affirms that the Union must develop a comprehensive and coherent vision and be politically involved in the resolution of the conflict. By voting on this text, the European Parliament illegitimately arrogates an exclusively regal jurisdiction. Once again, the Union is uncomplicatedly encroaching on the sovereignty of the Member States.  Therefore, I voted against it.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the European Union's contribution to the Middle East peace process. The text thus recalls the need to restart the peace process talks, on the basis of the principle of the coexistence of two states based on the 1967 borders.  The resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Josu JUARISTI ABAUNZ
text: in writing. ‒ The draft joint motion for a resolution prepared by the S&D was a good basis for the negotiations. Despite the fact that the original draft was diluted, significant elements remain in the text, such as: the commitment to a two-state solution on the basis of the 1967 borders, where Jerusalem would be the capital of both states; the raising of the issue of settlements in the soon-to-be-launched EU structured dialogue with Israel on the situation in the West Bank; the call for a multilateral approach to the peace process and the establishment of an international support group; the support for the Arab Peace Initiative and the efforts in the UN Security Council to resume peace talks; the condemnation of Israeli settlement expansion and a call to end and reverse this policy; the clear support for UNRWA; respect for the rights of detainees and prisoners, and the end of Gaza blockade. Although the resolution is still short from the position that we would have liked to have, taking into account the important elements that are still in it and the message this might still send to Palestinians and Israelis who are working towards a solution and peace, EH Bildu voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's resolution in the Middle East peace process calling for the immediate resumption of credible peace efforts and a two-state solution.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I am abstaining from my voice. The situation in the Middle East has now proceeded in such a way that, no matter which side you take, the process will not progress.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report, as it calls for the resumption of credible peace efforts between Israelis and Palestinians without delay. Preserving the viability of the two-state solution must be an immediate priority for the EU and the international community and we have to use all our diplomatic and economic tools to start this peace process in order find a just solution to this dispute.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this proposal. Achieving peace in the Middle East remains a key priority for the international community and an indispensable element for regional security and stability. The EU intends to provide the necessary support and intends to pursue the resolution of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and the wider Arab-Israeli conflict by peaceful and constructive means. It called for the early resumption of credible peace efforts and called on israelis and Palestinians to avoid actions that could undermine the outcome of the negotiations and threaten the viability of the two-state solution.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. This resolution focuses primarily on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. In this regard, it reaffirms the European Parliament's support for the solution of two States at the 1967 borders and stresses the need to ensure the viability of the Palestinian state, and also condemns the persistent expansion of Israeli settlements, urging Israel to immediately interrupt them and reverse this policy, while expressing its deep concern at the growing violence of settlers in the West Bank. While the resolution adopted does not at any time criticize the EU's complicity with Israel and its actions, it reflects a very positive element in my view that it is the unequivocal and explicit recognition that the EU-Israel agreements will not apply in the Palestinian Occupied Territories, as reiterated in the Conclusions of the Foreign Affairs Council on 20 July. In this regard, since the resolution also calls for an end to the Israeli blockade of the Gaza Strip and its urgent reconstruction, my vote has been positive.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The European Parliament's resolution on the Union's role in the Middle East peace process renews its call for enhanced efforts to bring peace to the Middle East and condemns the continuing violence. Peace in the Middle East is even more necessary as conflicts in the region increase and the signed nuclear deal with Iran has created a favourable basis for the resumption of the peace process. European Union support has a solution that recognises the existence of two states with 1967 borders and with Jerusalem as the capital of both countries that recognise each other and coexist in peace and security. Since the Resolution encourages the continuation of the peace process with the aim of implementing such a solution, I supported it.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing – The long-standing conflict between Israel and the Arab states, especially Palestine, not only affects the economies of these countries, but also affects the economic and economic interests of the European Union. Attempts to establish lasting peace are only partial and short-term successes. The situation is also aggravated by political instability in neighbouring countries, especially In Syria. The EU is one of Israel's largest trading partners and is also the largest donor of aid to Palestine. It is this position that the EU must use more intensively and purposefully in the process of peacefully resolving the problems of the Middle East. At the same time, I consider it essential to use all control mechanisms to ensure that trade and aid are used transparently, thus not helping to support terrorist groups and further increase tensions in this area.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I support the Middle East peace process because it contributes to global stability.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this report which reiterates its strong support for the two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, with the State of Israel within secure and recognised borders and an independent, sovereign, contiguous and viable State of Palestine living side-by-side in peace and security and mutual recognition along the 1967 borders, with mutually agreed land swaps, and Jerusalem as capital of both states.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. – The EU has been a broker in the MEPP and pushing for the two state solution to solve that conflict. A two state solution for the conflict in the Middle East means two states for two peoples. The Italian EPP Delegation has requested the group support for an amendment supporting two states for two solutions. Unfortunately, this amendment was refused in the plenary. An honest broker must be coherent with its own policy, therefore it must be impartial and make the same request for both parties. As this was not achieved, the EPP Delegation abstained to support the resolution and I followed my delegation. The current trend regarding the Middle East Peace Process is not in the interest of the European Union, especially taking in consideration the challenges of the southern neighbourhood countries and the fact that Israel is the only stable democracy in the region. The role of the European Union in the MEPP is too important to avoid these small details and it is not in the interest of the EU, or the EPP group, to challenge political relations in the sake a common compromise.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. The Middle East peace process has long been a huge undertaking, which seems to be very difficult diplomatically with regard to the regional problems. It is true that I am concerned that there should be a lasting peaceful solution in this region, and I agree, for example, with regard to Israeli settlement policy. Nevertheless, the resolution seems to me to be too unbalanced and does not offer a real solution-oriented strategy. That is why I abstained from voting.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. On the merits, several aspects of this motion for a resolution are positive. It is thereby commendable to wish for a lasting and just peace for the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Moreover, the call to ensure the safety of the civilian population and the demand for the lifting of the blockade of Gaza are quite understandable in view of the current situation in the Middle East.  However, we believe that the European Union does not have to meddle in foreign policy. It must remain a prerogative of the states. However, this motion for a resolution goes against this principle when it affirms that the Union must develop a comprehensive and coherent vision and be politically involved in the resolution of the conflict. By voting on this text, the European Parliament illegitimately arrogates an exclusively regal jurisdiction. Once again, the Union is uncomplicatedly encroaching on the sovereignty of the Member States.  Therefore, the member voted against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 I think it is possible to understand, in the near future, between the parties. The EU has made its contribution positively and has managed to get the parties closer. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because it calls on the Vice President/High Representative and the EU Special Representative to make full use of the political relations and institutional expertise of the EU and its Member States, in order to play a broader political role in the peace process in the Middle East. The resolution also stresses the importance of a two state solution.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. The Palestinian and Israeli peoples have a deep yearning for peace. They both have the same rights to live in their state, in a territory that belongs to them to develop their country and give a future to their children. This conflict has been going on for decades. Feelings of despair, humiliation and revolt have been etched in many hearts and minds. But everyone knows that this situation cannot last because if poverty feeds despair, injustice and humiliation fuel violence. Political courage is expected in the leader of all. The European Union must act to achieve a lasting solution in a fragile and changing geopolitical context. It is, as John Fitzgerald Kennedy says: "By giving others rights that belong to them, (that) we give ourselves rights."

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the resolution on the EU’s role in the Middle East peace process, which calls on the resumption of credible peace efforts between Israelis and Palestinians without delay.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 Six political groups (ECR, Verts/ALE, GUE/NGL, ALDE, PPE, S&D) tabled a motion for a resolution on the subject, which managed to draw up a joint compromise proposal. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 Achieving peace in the Middle East remains a key priority of the international community and an indispensable element for stability and security in the region. I support that the Israeli-Palestinian conflict should be seen broadly as the Israeli-Arab conflict and that peace in the Middle East requires a comprehensive regional solution. The violent crisis in Syria, the rise of Daesh, the rise of radicalism and the spread of terrorism in the Middle East are creating significant threats to the security of Israel and the entire region, exacerbating the suffering of the Palestinians at a time when the nuclear agreement with Iran, in which the EU plays a key role, provides a unique opportunity for the peace process that we cannot afford to lose.  I record the recommendation to the Israelis and palestinians to avoid actions that could aggravate the situation, including hate speech and unilateral measures, which could undermine the outcome of the negotiations and threaten the viability of the two-state coexistence solution.  I believe that any lasting resolution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict can only be achieved in a regional context, with the involvement of all stakeholders and the support of the international community.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution aims to increase the responsibilities of the European Union as a player in the Middle East and to arrive at a peace initiative for the region. This proposal is nonsense given the huge disparity in the positions of EU Member States on the issue. If the EU is inaudible it is firstly because no one is interested in listening to it because it represents only itself, and secondly because the diversity of the positions of states leads to a real diplomatic cacophony. In the end, the EU prevents its Member States from really influencing the resolution of this conflict as it strives to force them to find a common solution at European level. This is indicative of the sclerosis that the EU has. So I voted against it.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text on the role of the European Union in the Middle East peace process. The report points out that the rise of the Islamic State group, the growing radicalism and the spread of terrorism in the Middle East are creating significant threats to Israel's security. It proposes measures to bring stability and security to the region, including a clear mandate for the High Representative of the Union to engage the EU more in the process of resolving the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome this resolution that has become necessary since US Secretary of State Kerry's 2013-2014 initiative resulted in yet another stalemate in the Middle East peace process. Furthermore, it is becoming increasingly clear, on the one hand, that the conflict between Israel and Palestine has repercussions for the whole area, and on the other hand, that, despite its ambition to play an active role, the EU still does not have a coherent and systemic vision of the role it can play in the peace process. The resolution is useful in reiterating some of the concepts already expressed by this Parliament, which strongly supports the two-state solution and condemns Israel's policy of settlements and blockade of Gaza, as well as the launching of rockets by Palestinian militias. Finally, we support, in line with the resolution, the efforts of the UN Security Council to resume peace negotiations, we call on the EU to take a proactive role in this matter, starting by recognising and encouraging dialogue between the two peoples through civil society organisations, human rights organisations, scholars, opinion leaders and the world of the arts in general.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 It would be nice to see results in this peace process. Somehow, one gets the feeling that for decades we've been walking around with the same problem, and we're not a hair's breadth closer to solving it.  Meanwhile, generations are growing up, terrified of radicalism on one side and hopeless, isolated, in extreme poverty, in refugee camps, without schooling or hope on the other. Recently, the EU has finally taken a stand and committed itself to building a state in Palestine, while acknowledging Israel's legitimate concern for its own security. I believe that's the way to go.  At the same time, in a mediator role, we must promote dialogue between the parties. We must create opportunities for young Israelis and Palestinians, thinkers, teachers and scholars to exchange ideas and get to know each other without political pressure. Let us not forget that syria and Lebanon can play a key role in the peace process.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this resolution that calls on the Commission and the European External Action Service to provide funding to NGOs in the region whose political goals are in line with the overall goals of the Middle East Peace Process.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to abstain on this text as I am a firm believer in a balanced, two-state solution as the only way for all sides in the region to have prosperous, secure populations. The text, in its current form, is not convincing enough that it has understood this need.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The situation in the Middle East is increasingly tense and has consequences that are increasingly affecting the EU and its citizens, including, for example, through the large number of refugees coming to Europe in search of peace. It is important to address the problems in the Middle East, to try to find solutions that will help the region return to normalisation. An active role of the EU, which must be more active and visible, is also important for this.

name: Vincent PEILLON
text: In writing. The European Parliament today adopted by a large majority its recommendations on the role of the European Union in the Middle East peace process.  Negotiations between Israel and the Palestinian Authority have now stalled. France's initiative at the UN, which aims to establish a roadmap for the resolution of the conflict, will not be successful as long as there is doubt about the US veto. That is why the European Union must take its full part in mediation efforts. This is the high representative's priority and it is the role that the Union, as Israel's largest trading partner and the Palestinian Authority's largest donor, must fulfil.  The priority now is to bring both sides back to the negotiating table.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: in writing. ‒ Regarding to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, I strongly support the two-state solution on the basis of the 1967 borders, with the importance that all parties resume negotiations as soon as possible with a view to reaching a just, lasting and comprehensive peace. The stabilisation of this conflict is one of the first necessary blocks for stabilising the whole region.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ In light of the discussion held on the continuation of the Middle East peace process, I would like to point out that I voted for this resolution and that I strongly support the continuation of the peace process.  I regret that no amendment has been adopted that clearly underlines the importance of the concept of two states for two peoples.  It is stated on the track of fulfilling the political aspirations of two peoples - each in their own state. This also applies to the preservation of the full rights of these peoples as minorities in both countries. I believe that including such a solution could have sent a stronger positive message to both sides and strengthened the EU's role as an honest mediator.  Ms Mogherini and the EU have gained authority through committed negotiations that could help resolve this conflict. The peace process must aim to ensure peace and stability for the peoples of Israel and Palestine, as well as to establish trust between them, including through a committed fight against corruption.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution aims to increase the responsibilities of the European Union as a player in the Middle East and to achieve a peace initiative for the region. This proposal is nonsense given the huge disparity in the positions of EU Member States on the issue. If the EU is inaudible it is firstly because no one is interested in listening to it because it represents only itself, and secondly because the diversity of the positions of states leads to a real diplomatic cacophony. In the end, the EU prevents its Member States from really influencing the resolution of this conflict as it strives to force them to find a common solution at European level. This is indicative of the sclerosis that the EU has. So I voted against it.
