name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Writing. \u2012 Peace in the Middle East will bring only a balanced approach to all actors in the conflict. I believe that the peace process should be built on a two-state principle for two peoples – Israelis and Palestinians. Since the proposal did not pass this wording, I abstained in the vote on the resolution as a whole, although I agree with part of its conclusions.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. In the face of the current context in the Middle East region, the European Parliament wished to recall the key role of the European Union as a provider of humanitarian aid and as a trading partner in the region. The resolution also urges the governments concerned to continue the dialogue and to try to stabilise the region in the interests of the local people.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. The European Parliament resolution reiterates its unequivocal support for the two-state solution to resolve the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, which is currently significantly threatening the security of the entire region and aggravating the suffering of palestinians. The report, which I support with my vote, calls on the Commission to renew and intensify the Union's role in the Middle East peace process and recalls all Member States of their duty to contribute to the definition of a united position and, as well, to avoid unilateral initiatives that weaken the coherence of the European position based on the coexistence of two States.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. U2012 Achieving peace in the Middle East remains a key priority for the international community and an indispensable element for regional stability and security. By this resolution, to which I have given my support, Parliament has an impact on its support for the two-State border-based solution of 1967 and the capital of Jerusalem for both States. It also expresses its deep concern at the persistent impasse in the Middle East peace process and calls for credible peace efforts to resume without delay. It also condemns the persistent expansion of Israeli settlements, which violates international humanitarian law, stokes Palestinian resentment and undermines the viability and prospects of a two-state solution, and calls on the Israeli authorities to immediately interrupt and reverse their settlement policy. It also urges the High Representative and the EU Special Representative to make better use of the political relations and institutional expertise of the EU and its Member States in order to play a real political role in the Israeli-Palestinian peace process.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which reiterates that the European Union must continue to affirm its support for the solution based on the coexistence of two States through concrete action and full respect for the rights of the civilian population. The EU is an important player at the international level in achieving the restoration of stability and security in the region. It is urgent and essential to put an end to any escalation of violence and to encourage the resumption of peace talks. Respect for human rights and humanitarian law will lead in particular to a just and lasting peace between Israelis and Palestinians.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I think the role of the European Union is important and fundamental to completing the Middle East peace process. The Member States will have to be constantly activated in order to direct the contracting parties to engage in a stable dialogue over time, based on the principle of tolerance and mutual respect.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the joint resolution on the EU's role in the Middle East peace process, given that we believe that achieving peace remains a key priority for the international community. Having said that, we reiterate support for the 1967 two-state border-based solution with mutually agreed land exchange and Jerusalem as the capital of both States. This resolution condemns the persistent expansion of Israelis, which violates international humanitarian law, stokes Palestinian resentment and undermines the objective viability of the prospects for a two-state solution, and therefore the prospects for peace. Moreover, this resolution ensures that all agreements between the EU and Israel state unequivocally and explicitly that they will not apply to territories occupied by Israel since 1967.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. This resolution focuses primarily on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. In this regard, it reaffirms the European Parliament's support for the solution of two States at the 1967 borders and stresses the need to ensure the viability of the Palestinian state, and also condemns the persistent expansion of Israeli settlements, urging Israel to immediately interrupt them and reverse this policy, while expressing its deep concern at the growing violence of settlers in the West Bank. While the resolution adopted does not at any time criticize the EU's complicity with Israel and its actions, it reflects a very positive element in my view that it is the unequivocal and explicit recognition that the EU-Israel agreements will not apply in the Palestinian Occupied Territories, as reiterated in the Conclusions of the Foreign Affairs Council on 20 July. In this regard, since the resolution also calls for an end to the Israeli blockade of the Gaza Strip and its urgent reconstruction, my vote has been positive.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ This explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Achieving peace in the Middle East is a key priority of the international community and a prerequisite for stability and security in the region. The EU has repeatedly reaffirmed its support for a two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, based on the 1967 borders, where Jerusalem will be the capital of both states. The EU is Israel's largest trading partner and the largest donor of aid to Palestine, so the EU's role in the Middle East peace process must also be dominating. However, both the Israeli and Palestinian parties must refrain from actions that could provoke a further escalation of violence, including hate speech and public incitement. This could jeopardise further negotiations and the EU's efforts for a Middle East peace process.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ Peace processes in the Middle East have been undermined, despite enormous efforts by the European Union-led international community. But those efforts must not stop. There is no alternative to direct negotiations and cooperation between the opposing parties, and the EU must be the engine of these negotiations. In the future, the European Union must also be a stabiliser of relations and a neutral factor with an interest in establishing a support for peace processes.  We support the report, understanding that peace can only be achieved through agreement between opposing parties, and by no means unilateral moves and actions that threaten the safety and life of civilians in the Middle East. I hope that the frequent initiatives of the EU institutions in the near future will change the position and moves of all those involved in security breaches in the Middle East and will encourage clear political engagement in order to establish peaceful coexistence.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because it could also help the European Parliament to play a greater and more meaningful role in promoting the Middle East peace process. I consider this to be an important objective, because this is really a European problem, given the context of the refugee crisis and the rise of anti-Semitism and acts of terrorism in Europe. For this reason, too, I consider it important that, with this decision, the EP has near unanimous support for the active commitment shown by High Representative Mogherini in facilitating the peace process. In my vote, I also considered that credibility is an essential condition for effective EU action on foreign policy; this requires the objectivity and impartiality of our common policy, which we must constantly demonstrate in our common documents and practical steps, such as this decision. I supported the fact that the resolution places great emphasis on the European tasks ahead of us in improving the security, humanity and political situation of the Palestinian population. At the same time, I would have liked to have seen it in the text, and for the future I urge the EU to give similar weight to the prevention of terrorist acts originating in Gaza and other Palestinian territories, to reduce the influence of Hamas and to establish a strong Palestinian administration to ensure this in the wake of the early elections. The exercise of Israel's sovereignty and the legitimate security interests of its citizens should also be a lasting element of a credible and effective EU Middle East policy.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the joint resolution urging the EU’s Special Representative to make better use of the political relations and institutional powers of the European Union and its member states to ensure the EU plays a veritable political role in the peace process between Israelis and Palestinians and also, more broadly, between Israel and the Arab states. I also voted in favour of this text, as I believe that this is time to resume talks between Israel and Palestine. In this respect the EU has to be more influential and propose a global initiative for peace in the region.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. - As the report supports the commitment to a fair and comprehensive solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, I supported it. A two-state solution, negotiated where countries can coexist in peace and security and mutually recognised each other, is possible, according to the EU. The EU's priority is to insist on this viable solution.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the joint resolution on the EU's role in the Middle East peace process, given that we believe that achieving peace remains a key priority for the international community. Having said that, we reiterate support for the 1967 two-state border-based solution with mutually agreed land exchange and Jerusalem as the capital of both States. This resolution condemns the persistent expansion of Israelis, which violates international humanitarian law, stokes Palestinian resentment and undermines the objective viability of the prospects for a two-state solution, and therefore the prospects for peace. Moreover, this resolution ensures that all agreements between the EU and Israel state unequivocally and explicitly that they will not apply to territories occupied by Israel since 1967.

name: Evžen TOŠENOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the resolution because I consider it to be overly critical. I support the peace process and consider the efforts of the State of Israel to be accommodating.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the joint resolution on the EU's role in the Middle East peace process, given that we believe that achieving peace remains a key priority for the international community. Having said that, we reiterate support for the 1967 two-state border-based solution with mutually agreed land exchange and Jerusalem as the capital of both States. This resolution condemns the persistent expansion of Israelis, which violates international humanitarian law, stokes Palestinian resentment and undermines the objective viability of the prospects for a two-state solution, and therefore the prospects for peace. Moreover, this resolution ensures that all agreements between the EU and Israel state unequivocally and explicitly that they will not apply to territories occupied by Israel since 1967.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because it again denounces the situation of the Israel-Palestine conflict by reiterating its position to defend the solution of the two states on the basis of the 1967 borders and, among other things, also condemns the continued expansion of Israeli settlements, that violate international humanitarian law and hinder any viability or prospecting for peace and directly calls on the Israeli authorities to end and reverse this policy of resettlement.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, which I found balanced and an overall good attempt to reiterate the European Parliament’s call for a solution to the Israeli/Palestinian dispute. The resolution acknowledges rights and responsibilities of the two sides and strongly encourages the main parties, regional actors, foreign leaders and international institutions to step up their efforts towards finding a lasting and mutually acceptable solution. I would particularly underline the urgent need for the EU to play a more proactive and decisive role in the process, by coming up with new ideas and strategies to foster mediation.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. After the long negotiations I had with the other groups on behalf of the Liberal Group, we came to a proportionate resolution which I was happy to support with my vote.  The resolution calls for a more active action by the European Union and continues to support the position of a two-state solution.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. The European Union is responsible for the huge wave of refugees that brings to our memories the worst horrors of World War II. It was the European Union, and the majority of this Parliament, that did everything they could to get Libya bombed. It was then said that it was to free the Libyan people. The same, that is, Members representing the interests of large multinationals who are able to control the enormous resources, have enthusiastically supported everyone - regardless of whether they belong to terrorist organisations or not - as long as they fight the Assad regime in Syria. Syrians today say they only want peace; who lived in Libya too. There, as in other African and Middle Eastern countries, NATO and the EU do everything they can to destabilise and sayse. The consequences are the millions of refugees who, trying to survive, face Europe-Fortaleza. Now, if the EU takes in the meagre number of 120,000 refugees, does that mean that it will continue to try to solve only the problem of those who can survive and not drown? When will safe and legal routes be created for migrants and refugees to travel, thereby preventing them from being forced to risk their lives once and for all?

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The Middle East peace process has long been a huge undertaking, which seems to be very difficult diplomatically with regard to the regional problems. It is true that I am concerned that there should be a lasting peaceful solution in this region, and I agree, for example, with regard to Israeli settlement policy. Nevertheless, the resolution seems to me to be too unbalanced and does not offer a real solution-oriented strategy. That is why I abstained from voting.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Resolution to reiterate the call for the resumption of negotiations towards a two-state solution, and for robust EU action on the subject. The Council and VP/HR must clarify how they intend to proceed with dialogue with Israel while settlement expansion and demolitions continue across the West Bank. It is also important to highlight the work of civil society organisations and individuals on both sides who work relentlessly to create people-to-people dialogue, understanding, tolerance and peace. Such grassroots work strengthens democratic institutions and promotes human rights and the rule of law on both sides, and is crucial to active sustainable peace-making.

name: Flavio ZANONATO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the Role of the European Union in the Middle East Peace Process because, while I fully support the role of the UNITED Nations Security Council, I believe that the European Union can play an important role in unblocking the impasse in the peace process. Pursuing the idea of the two states must be a top priority for the European Union and for the international community as a whole. I also believe that the nuclear agreement in Iran can offer a unique moment for the peace process, because a solution to this conflict can only be achieved in a regional context and with the active involvement of all those states that play a key role in the Middle East.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 Despite the fact that some elements of the resolution are recorded which we consider to be positive, and which meet the legitimate aspirations and demands of the Palestinian people, we believe that this resolution, in addition to the obvious limitations with regard to solutions and responsibilities, is part of the hypocritical and demagogic approach that is the assessment of the majority of this European Parliament.  The resolution adopted with the votes of those who have always, in the past, crushed the right to the existence of a State and a people, while expressing support for criminal israeli segregation, war and occupation policies, maintains the usual partial position, which insists on attributing the occupant and occupied equal level of responsibility in the conflict that has been taking place for decades , imposed by the Zionist power of Israel. In view of our solidarity with the struggle for the national rights of the Palestinian people to their independent and sovereign homeland, and some positive elements of the text for this struggle, we abstained.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur Relations between the European Union and Belarus have been improving recently. I would like to note two positive aspects: they are reflected in the resolution. This is the release of the last political prisoners and belarus's constructive position in the conflict in eastern Ukraine. I hope that the improvement in relations will be more sustained this time than on previous occasions. The EU's relations with Belarus are reminiscent of a change in the seasons beyond the Arctic Circle. A long winter changes with a short summer, which, unfortunately, is very similar to late autumn. There is now another thaw in relations between the European Union and Belarus, but I am very afraid that it will be replaced again by winter. In my opinion, both sides want the situation to improve fundamentally and that both sides want a lasting flourishing of positive cooperation. Of course, much depends on the attitude of the Belarusian authorities. But let us see, colleagues, what we can do for our part, the European Union! Because the European Union and Belarus have a bright future in my view.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Mr President, the truth is that Belarus has decided to go in a different direction. As in Ukraine, as in Russia, there is – if I may borrow 19th century terminology – an internal dispute between Slavophiles and Westernisers and the Westernisers are not in the ascendancy. Belarus is a sovereign country and, sadly, it has made a decision to go in the direction of autocracy and central control, rather than of freedom and personal autonomy, but once again we should accept the limits of our ability to influence things. Beyond holding up a better model there is not really very much we can do.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: – Mr President, I supported this resolution on Belarus, but I specifically want to explain my vote on Amendment 1. This amendment expressed concern at the decision to build a nuclear plant in Ostrovets, and called on Belarus to stop its construction until a fully independent environmental impact assessment is carried out. I fully subscribe to the idea that all countries have an absolute right to decide on their energy sources. However, there are two important issues here. First of all, we are not asking them to stop, full stop. We are only asking them to carry out a full independent assessment. Secondly, the building of a nuclear reactor has global implications. It is not like erecting a few wind turbines or building a hydroelectric station. Nuclear reactors have the potential to impact way outside of their borders, and that is why I asked for this caution.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I was unable to vote in favour of this resolution on Belarus which was not scheduled for this plenary session and which was introduced right at the beginning of this plenary session at the request of the European People's Group. This is undoubtedly motivated by the closeness of the elections in the country, to be held on 11 October, with the clear objective of trying to interfere from the outside in the process. Since the text agreed by the other political groups supports the policy of sanctions against Belarus, which in my opinion is clearly counterproductive, and which today implies that the European Parliament does not maintain relations with the Belarusian Parliament and is part of a policy of interference, calling on the European Commission to support the Belarusian opposition with financial and political means , I did not vote in favour of the resolution tabled.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. The report denounces the alleged violation of human rights in Belarus. Freedom of expression and certain individual freedoms would be violated by the government of the day. The country has reportedly not held free elections since 1994. The report therefore calls on Belarus to hold fair elections, stop the application of the death penalty and abolish forced labour.   Although we recognize that Belarus is not respectful of human rights, we oppose any moral condemnation and believe that it is neither our duty nor our responsibility to compel a sovereign country to submit to our definition of democracy. On the other hand, it is quite surprising to see the European authorities indignant at this situation when they are acting against the peoples without worrying about their will.  I therefore objected to this text.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution was not the subject of a roll-call vote, but I believe that my constituents have a right to know how I voted.  In this case, I abstained on the resolution as a whole.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution on the situation in Belarus. It is to be welcomed that the Belarusian authorities have released the remaining political prisoners, but it is worrying that similar actions have taken place in the past, but this was merely a symbolic gesture and did not contribute either to improving the situation of Belarusian society or to better relations with the EU. I support calls for Belarus to hold the next presidential elections in accordance with internationally accepted standards, to give the opposition unhindered access to all government-controlled media. The Belarusian authorities must ensure that democratic principles and human rights are respected under all circumstances.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. If we can only regret seeing the European Union camp on its positions of systematic hostility to the Russian Federation, we must welcome the improvement in our relations with Belarus.   It was time! Especially after Minsk's efforts to secure a lasting ceasefire in Ukraine.  Yes, let us get close to Belarus but do not try to distance it from its Russian neighbour! Belarus can and must fulfil the role that was Ukraine before the crisis: a bridge, a link between the Russian Federation and the European nations! Indeed, at a time when Europe is facing the immense challenge of the flood of millions of so-called refugees on our soil, it is essential that the whole of our continent finally stop tearing each other apart. The reality of this outburst goes beyond the fiction imagined by Jean Raspail in his prophetic Camp des Saints. Then let us cease to divide ourselves or the whole Old Continent will descend into chaos. That is why I voted against this resolution, which puts oil on the fire and claims, in particular, to impose "independent media" on Belarus.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I supported this joint resolution in which Parliament reiterates its deep concern about the situation of human rights and fundamental freedoms in Belarus, as well as the shortcomings of previous elections by independent international observers and the active persecution of opposition leaders after the elections; While Parliament welcomes the recent release of the last political prisoners and may see it as a first step towards improving relations between the European Union and Belarus, Parliament calls for the country to go beyond symbolic gestures.  It also calls on Belarus, the only country in Europe that still applies the death penalty, to join a global moratorium on the execution of the death penalty, which would be a first step towards its permanent abolition.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution on the situation in Belarus is yet another demonstration of European imperialism and its interference in the internal affairs of sovereign states. Even though Belarus is the last "communist dictatorship" in Europe, the EU has no right to interfere in these policies. A presidential election will be held on 11 October 2015 and the EU has put in place a whole bunch of sanctions since the country decided to ally with Russia in a referendum in the 1990s. This proposal seeks to put Belarus in a pro-EU position and contains a range of demands such as the abolition of the death penalty or eu-independent support for the media (see their funding). So I voted against it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 Some passages of this resolution turn out to be undead and may show critical issues, which is why I voted to abstain.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. In this resolution, which I voted in favour of, Parliament stresses its deep concern about the situation of human rights and fundamental freedoms in Belarus, as well as the shortcomings identified during the previous elections by independent international observers and the active persecution of opposition leaders following the elections. The resolution calls on Belarus to hold the next presidential election in accordance with internationally recognized standards and to allow the opposition free access to government-controlled media and participate in elections on an equal footing. It also calls on the Belarusian authorities to stop harassing independent media for political reasons and reiterates its call on the European Commission to support, through financial and political means, the efforts of Belarusian civil society, the independent media and non-governmental organizations in Belarus in favour of the democratic aspirations of the Belarusian people.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 Despite the increase in relations between Belarus and the European Union and the United States of America, human rights continue to be violated in Belarus. Intimidation of human rights defenders, police raids on human rights organisations, confiscation of their equipment and forced expulsions from Belarus are taking place. In Belarus, shortcomings in the electoral process have been noted and the active persecution of opposition leaders after the elections, which have been recorded by independent international observers. For these reasons, Parliament is calling on Belarus to hold the next presidential elections in accordance with internationally accepted standards, to give the opposition unhindered access to all media controlled by the government and to enable its members to participate in elections on an equal footing.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ I want to express my concern about the systematic deterioration of human rights in Belarus, the lack of a right to freedom of expression, assembly and association, and the unfair registration process for civil society organisations. Furthermore, Belarus is the only European country still carrying out the death penalty. Human rights defenders, civil society activists continue to be intimidated and pressured and police raids are carried out there. Given all these undemocratic phenomena and actions, the upcoming presidential election will have an easily predictable and unequivocal outcome.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. The report denounces the alleged violation of human rights in Belarus. Freedom of expression and certain individual freedoms would be violated by the government of the day. The country has reportedly not held free elections since 1994. The report therefore calls on Belarus to hold fair elections, stop the application of the death penalty and abolish forced labour.  Although we recognize that Belarus is not respectful of human rights, we oppose any moral condemnation and believe that it is neither our duty nor our responsibility to compel a sovereign country to submit to our definition of democracy. On the other hand, it is quite surprising to see the European authorities indignant at this situation when they are acting against the peoples without worrying about their will. So I voted against it.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Abstention vote.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the motion for a resolution on the situation in Belarus. Unfortunately, the Republic of Belarus remains in every respect an authoritarian regime despite the calls of the international community. I understand that unexpectedly this country, during the Ukraine crisis, took a position closer to Europe by refusing to follow Moscow in introducing the embargo on European products, even condemning the annexation of Crimea. But that is not enough: belarus remains the only parliament in Europe that has not had an opposition for twenty years. The last elections, held in 2010, were described by the OSCE as 'neither free nor impartial'. Added to this is the knot of political prisoners, which remains one of the reasons for the harshest international criticism. In short, in my opinion, although attempts at dialogue must be facilitated, at least in order to mitigate the difficult political situation and lighten its burden on its citizens, Belarus remains an authoritarian regime and human rights violations pose problems that are difficult for the EU to overcome, which is a community of values based on respect for democratic principles, civil liberties and human rights.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on the resolution as the EU’s recent record on relations with Russia, is, to say the least, somewhat strained. With Belarus being so politically close to Russia, the EU should be mindful of the need for real diplomacy, especially during such worrying times.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ Having regard to the human rights violations in Belarus, I voted in favour of this resolution in order to urge Belarus to comply with the rule of law and fundamental rights.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 Despite the recent release of six political detainees, the human rights situation in Belarus remains worrying and dramatic. The freedom of expression of the independent media continues to be in great difficulty and intimidation continues, so much so that we will most likely see yet another farce electoral process. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution, which supports respect for human rights in Belarus and condemns the dictatorship.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 Support is expressed to the Commission in its policy of "critical commitment" to the Belarusian authorities and the European Parliament also expresses its willingness to contribute through its Delegation for Relations with Belarus. The EU must also remain cautious about where it allocates its resources and make sure that they do not contribute to the worsening situation faced by the opposition and civil society.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the situation in Belarus. The resolution notes that Belarus is the only European state to apply the death penalty and that the human rights situation remains critical. It welcomed the release by Lukashenko's government of some political opponents and called on the Belarusian Government to ensure that the October elections were held freely. Finally, it welcomed the mediation role played by Belarus in the Ukraine crisis and the recent talks with the EU on a number of issues, including human rights, which are important with a view to a possible future rapprochement between the EU and Minsk.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because, despite the intensification of contacts between the European Union, the United States and Belarus itself, human rights violations continue to occur in belarus, including intimidation of the same defenders of these rights, as well as police raids on the headquarters of organisations engaged in the sector. I am convinced that one of the main achievements of cooperation between Belarus and the European Union has been the release of the six political prisoners, including the former presidential candidates, whose existence was even denied for years. Moreover, the new law, in force since 2015, which regulates all the media, definitely improves the correct sharing of information. Finally, I believe that the creation of a national institution in favour of human rights, freedom of expression, assembly and association, as well as for the rights of the child, against the death penalty, torture and ill-treatment is a further step towards respect for democratic principles, in accordance with the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I was unable to vote in favour of this resolution on Belarus which was not scheduled for this plenary session and which was introduced right at the beginning of this plenary session at the request of the European People's Group. This is undoubtedly motivated by the closeness of the elections in the country, to be held on 11 October, with the clear objective of trying to interfere from the outside in the process. Since the text agreed by the other political groups supports the policy of sanctions against Belarus, which in my opinion is clearly counterproductive, and which today implies that the European Parliament does not maintain relations with the Belarusian Parliament and is part of a policy of interference, calling on the European Commission to support the Belarusian opposition with financial and political means , I did not vote in favour of the resolution tabled. .

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 Parliament recalls that human rights violations continue to prevail in Belarus. Progress has been made in some sectors, but much remains to be done until a democratic state is established.Since 1994, there have been no free, democratic or internationally-respecting elections. I would like to point out that the EP calls on the Commission to take action to support the efforts of Belarusian civil society, independent media and NGOs by financial and political means in order to support the democratic aspirations of the Belarusian people.  I supported the report.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ This motion states that while the European Parliament welcomes the recent release of political prisoners in Belarus, it remains deeply concerned by the human rights and fundamental freedoms situation in the country. It calls on the Belarusian Government to rehabilitate the released political prisoners and to fully restore their civil and political rights, while stressing that this could be a potential first step towards improving relations between the European Union and Belarus. Besides condemning the serious human rights abuses by Belarus, this resolution also presents the EU as a potential interlocutor if Belarus steps up and implements the needed reforms, hence I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the European Parliament resolution on the situation in Belarus because it deals in particular with the state and level of respect for human rights in the country.  The progress made in the area of freedom of speech and the media, as well as in respect for the political rights of citizens and opposition activists, has led to a convergence of relations between the EU and Belarus, as well as the implementation of the first official visit by a Delegation from the European Parliament since 2002. But despite these few positive steps in the right direction, the situation remains deeply troubling. There are administrative persecution and harassment of independent media for political reasons, as well as prosecution of young activists. On the eve of belarus' presidential elections, the country's government must give the opposition unhindered access to all government-controlled means of communication and allow it to participate in elections on an equal footing. Only in this way will Belarus be able to ensure that presidential elections are held in accordance with internationally recognised standards.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The Union, once again, is said to be acting as an unsolicited defender of the law, when in fact it is simply trying to influence in its interest the flow of developments in this country which is currently in Russia's sphere of influence.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 Since 2010, ten people have been executed in Belarus in 2014 alone, three people have been executed and a new death sentence has been handed down on 18 March 2015. Belarus is the only country in Europe that continues to apply capital punishment. Cases of human rights violations persist in Belarus, including the intimidation of human rights defenders, police raids and the seizure of equipment from human rights organisations, as well as the forced departure of Belarus, among others, as confirmed by the report by the UN Special Rapporteur on the human rights situation in Belarus. The Commission must therefore call on the Belarusian government to take concrete and firm steps to considerably improve freedom of expression and freedom of the media, respect for the political rights of citizens and opposition activists and respect for the rule of law and fundamental rights. The European Union should remain firmly committed to pursuing the defence of human rights in Belarus, including freedom of expression and the media.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ although progress has been made in cooperation with Belarus in some sectoral policies such as higher education, training, the digital market, energy, food security and culture, human rights violations persist in Belarus, including intimidation of human rights defenders, police raids against human rights organisations and the seizure of their equipment, as well as forced evictions from Belarus. The European Union must ensure that its resources are not used to suppress civil society organisations, human rights defenders, freelance journalists and opposition leaders. The situation of national minorities in the country is critical, because the leaders of these minorities are often replaced by representatives promoted by state authorities, thereby violating one of the fundamental human freedoms, namely freedom of association. The Belarusian authorities must ensure that democratic principles, human rights and fundamental freedoms are respected, in accordance with the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the international and regional human rights instruments ratified by Belarus.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the reports on the situation in Belarus because, once again, the Union appears to be acting as an unsolicited defender of the law, when in fact it is simply trying to influence in its interest the flow of developments in that country, a country that is currently in Russia's sphere of influence.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the progress achieved by Belarus in the areas of higher education, vocational training, the digital market, the energy sector and food safety, among others, that will most certainly lead to increased cooperation between Belarus and Europe. However, I remain concerned by the continued prejudice to human rights and fundamental freedoms, by the serious shortcomings observed during previous elections by independent international observers in Belarus and by the lack of an effective rule of law. I believe the Commission should support, through financial and political means, the efforts and democratic aspirations of Belarusian civil society, independent media and non-governmental organisations in Belarus who are leading the country towards more respect for democratic principles, for human right and for the rule of law.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the situation in Belarus today, as I share the positions of this text and I would like the EU to play a much stronger role in the democratisation process.

name: Juan Carlos GIRAUTA VIDAL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Parliament Motion for a Resolution as it puts pressure on the Belarusian authorities in a constructive but firm way. I welcome the recent release of the six political prisoners as it shows an undeniable improvement in the way authorities there deal with its opposition activists and I sincerely hope it signals a step in the right direction concerning the right to freedom of speech and freedom of the media in Belarus. We simply must witness a genuine attempt in Belarus to engage citizens and activists in the political life of their country and ensure that candidates can conduct a genuine and fair electoral campaign.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted against this resolution. The resolution takes over the ten death sentences since 2010, with three death sentences executed in 2014 and one in March 2015. Belarus is currently the only country in Europe that still applies capital punishment. We understand that a Europe of rights cannot substantiate its criminal system on practices in which the death penalty entails. The report also takes care of concern about the construction of a nuclear plant in Ostrovets, a concern based on insufficient impact reports. We still understand that the purpose of the Report is not sufficiently substantiated to obtain the vote in favour and that its existence responds to agendas not previously clarified.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I alongside my colleagues in the European Parliamentary Labour Party voted in favour of this resolution. The release of political prisoners in Belarus is an important step forward. It is critically important that opposition parties are given equal access to media outlets in the run up to the presidential election in October of this year. It is vital that EU continues in its strategy of critical engagement with Belarus, but that the EU must not contribute by way of its actions worsen the situation of the opposition and civil society.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. We voted against this resolution. The resolution takes over the ten death sentences since 2010, with three death sentences executed in 2014 and one in March 2015. Belarus is currently the only country in Europe that still applies capital punishment. We understand that a Europe of rights cannot substantiate its criminal system on practices in which the death penalty entails. The report also takes care of concern about the construction of a nuclear plant in Ostrovets, a concern based on insufficient impact reports. We still understand that the purpose of the Report is not sufficiently substantiated to obtain the vote in favour and that its existence responds to agendas not previously clarified.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ Belarus has made some efforts on its path to democratization throughout the past couple of years. I also welcome the constructive role that Belarus played in forging the agreement that calls for a ceasefire in Ukraine. However, I am deeply concerned regarding the human rights situation and the harassment of media outlets in the country. Furthermore, I would like to draw attention to the fact that Belarus is the only state in Europe that still carries out capital punishment. As such, it must be recognised that Belarus, although having taken steps towards democratization, still has great lengths to cover.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a resolution on the situation in Belarus, as cooperation relations between the EU and Belarus need to be improved. In this regard, the progress that is gradually taking place in respecting political rights, freedom of speech and freedom of thought, freedom of the media and the activities of the NGO sector should be supported. Improvements have also taken place regarding the release of some political prisoners.  Belarus's role in de-escalation in Ukraine should also be taken into account. The progress also took place in cooperation between the EU and Belarus on the economic front. In this regard, the Commission should be supported in further critically addressing the situation and continuing engagement, which would contribute to further developing democratic processes and increasing the level of respect for various aspects of human rights.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. The report denounces the alleged violation of human rights in Belarus. Freedom of expression and certain individual freedoms would be violated by the government of the day. The country has reportedly not held free elections since 1994. The report therefore calls on Belarus to hold fair elections, stop the application of the death penalty and abolish forced labour.  Although we recognize that Belarus is not respectful of human rights, we oppose any moral condemnation and believe that it is neither our duty nor our responsibility to compel a sovereign country to submit to our definition of democracy. On the other hand, it is quite surprising to see the European authorities indignant at this situation when they are acting against the peoples without worrying about their will. So I voted against it.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. The report draws attention to the situation in Belarus and clearly identifies the problems. However, I am abstaining from voting because it is too inappropriate in some areas and slips into polemics.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I was unable to vote in favour of this resolution on Belarus which was not scheduled for this plenary session and which was introduced right at the beginning of this plenary session at the request of the European People's Group. This is undoubtedly motivated by the closeness of the elections in the country, to be held on 11 October, with the clear objective of trying to interfere from the outside in the process. Since the text agreed by the other political groups supports the policy of sanctions against Belarus, which in my opinion is clearly counterproductive, and which today implies that the European Parliament does not maintain relations with the Belarusian Parliament and is part of a policy of interference, calling on the European Commission to support the Belarusian opposition with financial and political means , I did not vote in favour of the resolution tabled.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing – Despite some progress in some sectoral policies, such as education, training, culture, food, energy, Belarus remains one of the countries where the rule of law is violated and fundamental human rights and freedoms are not respected. Belarus has not yet taken free and democratic elections to help resolve the situation. The state interferes in several spheres, in particular freedom of the press, expression and association, undemocratic laws. The Commission must use all diplomatic, political and financial means to support civil society in Belarus. Financial assistance provided by the EU must be controlled in such a way as not to abuse it.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 Belarus must take measures to protect fundamental rights and respect the rule of law.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome Belarus’s cooperation with the European Union and other relevant parties in finding a solution to the conflict in Eastern Ukraine, including hosting negotiations on ceasefire agreements.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. The situation in the Republic of Belarus is certainly not standard from a democratic point of view and is not satisfactory from a European point of view. Nevertheless, I find the motion for a resolution too inappropriate in some areas. That is why I abstained from voting.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The report denounces the alleged violation of human rights in Belarus. Freedom of expression and certain individual freedoms would be violated by the government of the day. The country has reportedly not held free elections since 1994. The report therefore calls on Belarus to hold fair elections, stop the application of the death penalty and abolish forced labour.  Although we recognize that Belarus is not respectful of human rights, we oppose any moral condemnation and believe that it is neither our duty nor our responsibility to compel a sovereign country to submit to our definition of democracy. On the other hand, it is quite surprising to see the European authorities indignant at this situation when they are acting against the peoples without worrying about their will. So I voted against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 Despite the considerable intensification of contacts between Belarus and the EU and the United States, cases of human rights violations persist in Belarus, including the intimidation of human rights defenders, police raids and the seizure of equipment from human rights organisations.  We are all concerned about the human rights and fundamental freedoms situation in Belarus, the gaps found by independent international observers in previous elections and the active persecution of opposition leaders after the elections.  Belarus must respect human rights again, but it will suffer sanctions from the EU.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this cross-party resolution as it encourages the Belarusian authorities to respect the international and regional human rights instruments ratified by Belarus. Through the resolution MEPs also express their support for the Commission’s policy of ‘critical engagement’ with the Belarusian authorities but also stresses the importance of vigilant monitoring of the resources allocated to Belarus in order to ensure that they do not contribute to worsening the situation of the opposition and civil society in the country.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the resolution on Belarus, which expresses its concern about the human rights and fundamental freedoms situation in the country, as well as by the shortcomings observed during previous elections by independent international observers and the active persecution of the opposition leaders after the elections and calls on Belarus to conduct the upcoming presidential elections in accordance with internationally recognised standards, to give the opposition unfettered access to all government-controlled means of communication and to allow it to participate in the elections on an equal footing, in particular by creating independent election commissions and allowing an adequate representation therein on all levels and a transparent vote count.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 Seven political groups (PPE, ECR, EFDD, GUE/NGL, Verts/ALE, S&D, ALDE) tabled a motion for a resolution, six of which, including my own group, S&D, reached a compromise proposal. That's what I voted for.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution on the situation in Belarus is yet another demonstration of European imperialism and its interference in the internal affairs of sovereign states. While the presidential election will be held on 11 October 2015, the EU has put in place a whole bunch of sanctions since the country decided to ally with Russia in a referendum in the 1990s. This proposal then takes advantage of the current situation to put Belarus in a pro-Western policy seeking to further divide the EU. It includes, for example, a request for the abolition of the death penalty, or even EU funding of "independent" (i.e., Euroatlantist) media. I decided to vote against it.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the situation in Belarus. The text welcomes the efforts undertaken by Belarus to achieve a ceasefire in Ukraine, as well as the recent release of several political prisoners. It highlights progress in higher education, vocational training, the digital market, the energy sector, food safety and culture. Nevertheless, he says that many efforts remain in the area of the rule of law, the protection of human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this resolution that recognises the progress that has been made in sectoral cooperation in the areas of higher education (the Bologna process), vocational training, the digital market, the energy sector, food safety and culture, among others. It also calls on the Commission to support, with financial and political means, the efforts of Belarusian civil society, independent media and non-governmental organisations in Belarus to fulfil the democratic aspirations of the Belarusian people.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution as I believe we need profoundly to engage more with Belarus and not write it off as a lost cause. When it comes to people, there should be no such approaches, and it is indeed disturbing just how alienated the EU is towards Belarus, a country on our very own doorstep. While the language is at time harsher than I would have preferred, I think Parliament is taking the necessary steps in ensuring continued scrutiny and an eventual re-engagement with this country.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The release of six political prisoners from belarusian prisons is a good sign of Belarus's desire to improve relations with the EU. The upcoming presidential elections are a good opportunity for Belarus to demonstrate that its desire is credible. To this end, freedom of the media must be guaranteed, the freedom of opponents to participate in the elections and the fight for elections must be guaranteed on equal terms with others and respect for human rights. OSCE observers must be given access to election observation. It is extremely important that Belarus abolishes the death penalty as the last European country. It is also important to reassess the situation in Belarus after the Presidential elections in October.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 While I welcome the release of the six political prisoners by Belarus, I have decided to support the European Parliament resolution calling on the Belarusian authorities to respect international standards for democratic elections scheduled for 11 October and to cooperate with the OSCE; it deplores the fact that the death penalty still exists in the country and encourages greater respect for human rights, the rule of law and democracy.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒The European Union stands ready to improve relations and cooperation with Belarus when conditions within that country allow for respect for democratic standards, the rule of law and respect for fundamental human rights. A positive sign in this aspect is the recent release of six political prisoners, opposition activists.   Also, freedom of speech and media and enabled participation in the political life of that country are necessary preconditions for democratic development and the full potential of cooperation with EU countries.  Likewise, the EU remains ready to expand business and trade ties with Belarus, and the country's membership in the Eurasian Union is incompatible with such measures.  Negotiations on visa simplification in January 2014 to improve direct people-to-people contacts and foster civil society have also started a positive shift. What is devastating is the existence of the death penalty, which is contrary to European values and human dignity.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This draft resolution is a major impedive in the internal affairs of Belarus and seeks to extend the European Union's grip on a state that is not even a member. The funding of media purportedly independent but which will obviously be subservient to the European Union seems unacceptable to me. Let the Belarusians decide their own destiny, as every people has the right to do. I would also like the peoples of the EU Member States to be able to regain their freedom one day... I am therefore opposed to this report.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution in support of respect for human rights in Belarus, not only because I was one of its co-authors, but also because, unfortunately, the Lukashenko regime proved its need again by detaining the holder of Czech political asylum and former presidential candidate Aleś Mihaljevich on his return to his homeland. I want cooperation with Belarus, but it must be Belarus that respects fundamental human rights.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I spoke in favour of the European Parliament's resolution condemning human rights violations in Belarus. Through this resolution, Parliament urges Belarus to renew contact with the Union and the international community and to stop arrests of human rights defenders or opponents of the regime. While some prisoners have recently been released, the country must continue on this path.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 In view of the forthcoming presidential elections in Belarus and considering that, since 1994, free and fair elections have not been held, in accordance with internationally recognised standards, this draft resolution of the European Parliament, calls on the Republic of Belarus to encourage the participation of the opposition in them. The rapporteur notes the fact that six political prisoners were released on 22 August 2015, stressing that the full rehabilitation of their civic and political rights could be a first step towards improving relations between the EU and Belarus. I supported this Resolution of the European Parliament with my vote, in the expectation that the Commission will be able to support Belarusian civil society in its democratic aspirations.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. In this resolution, which I voted in favour of, Parliament stresses its deep concern about the situation of human rights and fundamental freedoms in Belarus, as well as the shortcomings identified during the previous elections by independent international observers and the active persecution of opposition leaders following the elections. The resolution calls on Belarus to hold the next presidential election in accordance with internationally recognized standards and to allow the opposition free access to government-controlled media and participate in elections on an equal footing. It also calls on the Belarusian authorities to stop harassing independent media for political reasons and reiterates its call on the European Commission to support, through financial and political means, the efforts of Belarusian civil society, the independent media and non-governmental organizations in Belarus in favour of the democratic aspirations of the Belarusian people.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. While deeply concerned about the situation of human rights and fundamental freedoms in Belarus, the European Parliament, in voting on this resolution, welcomed the release at the end of August of the last political prisoners in that country. The adopted text calls on the Belarusian government to rehabilitate released political prisoners and fully restore their civil and political rights and also recalls that Belarus is the last European country to apply the death penalty and that 10 people have been executed since 2010. The non-binding resolution calls on Belarus to conduct the next presidential elections, which will take place in October, "in accordance with internationally recognized standards" and to allow the opposition to participate in the elections on an equal footing. Parliament also reiterates its call on the Commission to support, with financial and political resources, the efforts of civil society, independent media and non-governmental organisations to support the democratic aspirations of the Belarusian people.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted against this resolution. The resolution takes over the ten death sentences since 2010, with three death sentences executed in 2014 and one in March 2015. Belarus is currently the only country in Europe that still applies capital punishment. We understand that a Europe of rights cannot substantiate its criminal system on practices in which the death penalty entails. The report also takes care of concern about the construction of a nuclear plant in Ostrovets, a concern based on insufficient impact reports. We still understand that the purpose of the Report is not sufficiently substantiated to obtain the vote in favour and that its existence responds to agendas not previously clarified.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I was unable to vote in favour of this resolution on Belarus which was not scheduled for this plenary session and which was introduced right at the beginning of this plenary session at the request of the European People's Group. This is undoubtedly motivated by the closeness of the elections in the country, to be held on 11 October, with the clear objective of trying to interfere from the outside in the process. Since the text agreed by the other political groups supports the policy of sanctions against Belarus, which in my opinion is clearly counterproductive, and which today implies that the European Parliament does not maintain relations with the Belarusian Parliament and is part of a policy of interference, calling on the European Commission to support the Belarusian opposition with financial and political means , I did not vote in favour of the resolution tabled.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ This explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution on the situation in Belarus. Ahead of the forthcoming presidential elections in Belarus, the EU has an interest in the elections being held in accordance with internationally recognised standards, that the opposition has unrestricted access to all government-controlled means of communication and that it can participate in elections on equal terms, and that transparent counting of votes is ensured. After years of stagnation in COOPERATION between the EU and Belarus, the first official visit of the EP Delegation for relations with Belarus took place in Minsk on 18 and 19 June 2015. Belarus has also played a constructive role in enabling the ceasefire agreement in Ukraine to be positive in the resolution. The progress made in sectoral cooperation with Belarus in the areas of higher education, training, the digital market, energy, food security, culture and others is also positively assessed. On the other hand, we recall that Belarus remains the only country in Europe that still carries out the death penalty.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ I support this resolution because it is important to encourage democratic advances and initiatives in Belarus. So far, many other things that are happening in Belarus are inadmissible and are not in line with european union policy or with the opinions and attitudes of European commoners. For example, the nonfreeness of the media, the death penalty that exists in Europe only in Belarus, isolation, human rights threats and the like.  The situation in Belarus so far is not in line with democratic principles and it can be said that Europe is deeply concerned about Belarus, especially for human and fundamental rights in the country, while many other processes still need to be repaired. Therefore, belarus should continue to work towards the betterment of the country itself and its people, recognise positive developments, such as the recent release of the remaining political prisoners, and point to negativity and omissions, and sanction them together with belarusians.  Belarus should respect un recommendations, international law and national minorities, all for the best possible coexistence of people within the country itself and coexistence with the European Union.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒I support the proposal for a resolution highlighting the state of fundamental human rights in the Republic of Belarus in line with the report of the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. As this country remains the only dictatorship in Europe, as well as the only country still carrying out the death penalty, I welcome the resolution that encourages greater engagement between states and EU institutions towards Belarus.  But without respect for democratic principles, human rights and fundamental freedoms, in accordance with the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, it is impossible to talk about progress in relations with the Republic of Belarus.  I hope that the process of releasing six political prisoners is an indication of the desire of the Belarusian authorities to participate in democratic processes and that such moves are not a gathering of political and international sympathy, but a sincere intention to reform the political environment in Belarus.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: I supported the proposal in writing ‒ as I agree with its calls for greater respect for human rights and democratic principles.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as it calls on the Commission to provide financial and political support to the work of civil society, independent media and non-governmental organisations to support the democratic aspirations of the Belarus people. It also reminds that Belarus is the only country in Europe that still applies the death penalty and that ten people have been executed there since 2010.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. \ u2012 I supported the resolution that was proposed, as I believe that many human rights violations in Belarus are worrying and must be put to an end.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted against this resolution. The resolution takes over the ten death sentences since 2010, with three death sentences executed in 2014 and one in March 2015. Belarus is currently the only country in Europe that still applies capital punishment. We understand that a Europe of rights cannot substantiate its criminal system on practices in which the death penalty entails. The report also takes care of concern about the construction of a nuclear plant in Ostrovets, a concern based on insufficient impact reports. We still understand that the purpose of the Report is not sufficiently substantiated to obtain the vote in favour and that its existence responds to agendas not previously clarified.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ Despite a noticeable intensification of contacts between Belarus and the EU and the United States, violations of human rights persist in Belarus, and we cannot close our eyes on that. Whereas progress has been made in cooperation on some sectoral policies, the EU must make sure, however, that its resources are not used to suppress civil society organisations, human rights defenders, freelance journalists and opposition leaders. I support any initiative that encourages the use of European values beyond our borders.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted against this resolution. The resolution takes over the ten death sentences since 2010, with three death sentences executed in 2014 and one in March 2015. Belarus is currently the only country in Europe that still applies capital punishment. We understand that a Europe of rights cannot substantiate its criminal system on practices in which the death penalty entails. The report also takes care of concern about the construction of a nuclear plant in Ostrovets, a concern based on insufficient impact reports. We still understand that the purpose of the Report is not sufficiently substantiated to obtain the vote in favour and that its existence responds to agendas not previously clarified.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the resolution because it clearly denounces the persistence of human rights violations in Belarus, calls for the authorities to end harassment for political reasons towards independent media and, among many other things, because it also expresses concern about the detention and persecution of 3 young activists.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution on Belarus, which does recognise some positive steps taken by the Belarusian Government, such as the freeing of several political prisoners, but at the same time reiterates its concerns over the persistently worrying human rights situation in the country and the shortcoming observed during the previous elections. It is important that the resolution strongly calls for the respect of media freedom and invites the authorities to grant minorities adequate rights. It is also positive to note that the text underlines the deplorable practice of the death penalty still in use in Belarus, the only country in Europe that still foresees such an extreme and inhuman type of criminal punishment. Substantial improvements on all aspects of human rights are still to be made if our cooperation with the country is to be strengthened in the future.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. It is important that the European Parliament speaks in these terms in the face of the situation in Belarus, as it is very important that democracy and respect for human rights progress in Belarus in the coming years. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. The same European Union which is unable to give a human response to the refugee crisis is now once again seeking to teach human rights lessons to other third countries, in this case Belarus. The same EU, so much in giving political, financial and military support to armed groups aimed at spreading the war in Libya, Syria or Iraq, adopts a resolution condemning a country for simply not bling into the hegemonic power of the EU, the United States and NATO. The same EU that despises democracy within Europe as was the case with referendums in France, the Netherlands or Ireland, or even more recently in Greece, proclaims itself as the guardian of human rights and democratic values. It's unfortunate.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The situation in the Republic of Belarus is certainly not standard from a democratic point of view and is not satisfactory from a European point of view. Nevertheless, I find the motion for a resolution too inappropriate in some areas. That is why I abstained from voting.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. \u2012 Republic Belarus remains an authoritarian regime in every respect, with all that that entails. The country is governed by presidential decrees and minsk is the only parliament in Europe that has had no opposition for twenty years and every time the president is elected there are violent repressions on the streets. The next presidential elections will be in November of this year and it is difficult to imagine a different scenario. The issue of political prisoners remains one of the reasons for the harshest international criticism despite some recent overtures, such as an amnesty granted in July 2014. In the media sector, too, the situation has deteriorated considerably, with the creation of constant bureaucratic obstacles on the part of the system for exercising control. There is also no freedom of association in Belarus, and belarus remains the only European state in which the death penalty is in force: two to nine people sentenced per year. The Belarusian Government is taking concrete steps to improve humanitarian rights and put an end to the repression of peaceful dissidents; a reform of the judicial system and the guarantee of the unlimited right to freedom of speech and assembly are desirable in order to constitute necessary measures towards the achievement of a credible democracy.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: – Mr President, I voted in favour of this report on social entrepreneurship and social innovation. Representing nearly half of all undertakings in the EU and employing about 14 million people, social enterprises make a huge contribution not just to employment but also to social inclusion, to local and to regional development and to environmental protection. However, I believe that social enterprises need greater support. We bailed out the for-profits but we often pay very little attention to the not-for-profits. Social economy enterprises should be integrated into our national reform programmes. I am also calling on the Member States – as the report did – to implement in full the Public Procurement and Concessions Directive, which includes social clauses and criteria to promote social inclusion and social innovation as well as contracts earmarked to foster the employment of the most disadvantaged people in the labour market. Member States also need to set up one-stop shops, or contact points, that will empower social enterprises to access EU funding.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur Unfortunately, in Latvia, the so-called social economy, when the social objectives of a company are placed above the interests of capital, is extremely rare. I must say that there is also no definition in our legislation – which can be called a social enterprise – let alone a strategy for supporting such a company. That is why it is very important for the European Commission to support business incubators for social or solidarity enterprises and to promote the creation of such enterprises throughout the European Union. Colleagues! The creation of a social economy can be stimulated from different sides, but not always an initiative can be expected from countries, especially from eastern European countries, including my own country, Latvia, where both society, civil servants and activists know little about this phenomenon, so it is very logical that we can ask the European Commission to show initiative on this issue, to give its support to social enterprises and to help build common internet platforms for people and businesses those interested in achieving social goals.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it is a new attempt to evade responsibility for the productive system in the very high levels of unemployment faced by European states. Entrepreneurship and social innovation cannot be the vehicle for state deprivation of welfare and social services. In addition, allowing private investment in such instruments will make them a speculative bubble. It is the State that must provide such services and from public investment try to boost them. The fight against unemployment must occur from all fronts, but especially since re-industrialization and large companies must be the first to transform their speculative activity into productive activity to generate quality jobs. That is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. I welcome this report on the promotion of entrepreneurship, skills and competences among young people at all levels of education and training, given the current average level of unemployment. The relationship between schools and businesses must be promoted so that pupils and students can gain practical experience and models at an early stage. In particular, a dual training system introduced throughout the EU, as is widespread in the German-speaking community, would make a significant contribution to this.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I had to vote against this resolution; in particular, paragraph 50 supports the free movement of workers – a principle which has been disastrous for the United Kingdom.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal on social entrepreneurship and social innovation in the fight against unemployment. In its 2020 strategy, the EU has set out guidelines to be followed in the coming years, but as a result of the economic and financial crisis, the EU is moving away from these objectives.  In the short term, the EU must address important challenges such as economic and financial sustainability, social welfare and, in particular, job creation, especially with regard to the most vulnerable groups, such as, among others, young people, women, the elderly, the long-term unemployed, people with disabilities, immigrants or the Roma community. I agree that the social economy has a key role to play in achieving these objectives. Social enterprises have proven to be more resilient to economic shocks and have been able to offer innovative solutions that promote social cohesion, social inclusion or job creation. Social innovation and social entrepreneurship are key factors in the development of the social economy and action should be taken in the areas of education and training, improvement of funding, increased visibility and improvement of the legal environment.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. The "social and solidarity" jobs promoted in this report are very often capped in terms of pay, which contributes to social dumping. On the other hand, there is a real risk of drift as to the beneficiaries of this type of employment. As a result, I voted against it.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. The main goal of social and solidarity-economy enterprises is to achieve their social objective and to primacy the interests of the workforce over the interests of capital. In this sense, they are a key driver in the progress towards the goals set out in the Europe 2020 strategy on employment, innovation, poverty reduction and social exclusion.
