The social and solidarity economy provides jobs for the categories of people most often excluded from the labour market. The introduction of national regulations on the social and solidarity economy in all Member States, as is already the case in countries such as Belgium, would obviously be useful in these respects. I have therefore approved this report

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I support this report and congratulate the rapporteur on her excellent work. It should not be forgotten that many SMEs work in the field of the social economy and generate a very important volume of jobs. That is the case of the Basque Country where we have a very advanced and well located sector. But I did not vote for flexibility in state aid for this sector as it could be discriminatory.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This report on social entrepreneurship and social innovation in the fight against unemployment aims to develop the social and solidarity economy by focusing on five major areas (education/training, access to finance, visibility at European level, improvement of the legal framework, development of the social economy in the EU and member states). Social entrepreneurship includes forms of entrepreneurship whose main purpose is social or environmental and where the majority of profits are reinvested for the benefit of this mission. While this objective is obviously laudable, I note the total contradiction with the competition policies advocated by the EU. Moreover, the social and solidarity economy is a sector that allows to maintain local jobs that are not relocated for people with low qualifications and which sometimes gives birth to great successes such as some SCOPs (example in the context of taking over profitable enterprises by its ex-employees ...) but this remains a largely illusory sector, since the salaries of these jobs are often capped, the scope of these jobs is often narrow and can only help a limited number of people, the state aid granted is poorly monitored and we have no concrete analyses on the long-term economic and environmental effects ...  So I voted against this report.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. Europe has 2 million social economy companies , 10% of European companies - employing more than 14 million people - 6.5% of workers.  Companies in the social economy have proven to be more resilient to the crisis, as well as providing added value in promoting cohesion and social inclusion through job creation.  Through this report, which I voted in favour of, Parliament urges to promote the sector and improve the exchange of practices between sectors and between States. In addition, it calls on public authorities and financial service providers to adapt to the financial needs of such enterprises at all stages of their business development, especially in their creation. In addition, thanks to the contributions of the S&D group, it urges to promote the cooperative model and improve the access of these companies to public procurement systems.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on the report on the use of social entrepreneurship and social innovation in the fight against unemployment. The economic and financial crisis has exacerbated poverty and social exclusion rates, as well as long-term unemployment and youth unemployment and social inequalities. As a result, the most marginalised and disadvantaged groups in the labour market have been the hardest hit, such as people with disabilities, young people, the elderly, women, long-term unemployed and disadvantaged people in the labour market. The Commission is invited to ensure that action is taken at EU level to support all types of social and solidarity-based enterprises. Parliament is sceptical that the EU is lagging behind in achieving the europe 2020 targets, in particular those relating to employment, innovation and poverty and social exclusion, but welcomes the 30% increase in the pre-financing budget of the YEI, which will help to promote social entrepreneurship and innovation.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 The economic and financial crisis has led to an increase in poverty and social exclusion, as well as long-term unemployment, which has led to an increasing risk of poverty for people with disabilities throughout the European Union and, at the same time, a dramatic increase in the number of European citizens unable to find employment for more than a year.  In addition to employment incentives, more attention should also be paid to solutions that can facilitate the reintegration into the labour market of even those with the most basic skills and competitive skills in the short term, so that the benefits of more innovative solutions in the social economy can be exploited later. Any improvement in the economic and financial situation in the Member States should go hand in hand with intensive support for inclusive and sustainable growth and quality job creation.  In order to transfer them to the social economy, Member States should promote lifelong learning among older workers and the long-term unemployed, including people with disabilities, who continue to face physical, information and communication barriers.  Member States should take into account best practices in adjusting national tax systems for the benefit of social enterprises and socially conscious investments and, where appropriate, increase tax incentives and incentives for this type of undertaking with vulnerable groups, such as persons with disabilities.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report, because while it contained many important positive aspects, it also contained certain aspects that I know the Social and Solidarity Economy sector find very problematic. The most significant positive element in the report is that it calls for formal and institutional recognition of the social and solidarity economy sector.  However, the report also calls for the opening up of the SSE sector to facilitate private investment and private profit. Those active in the sector are very wary of moves such as this and have indicated to Sinn Féin that they oppose such measures. Of particular cause of concern were paragraphs 24, 25 and 31, which included a call to bring together potential investors and specialised funds; a call for a European trustmark for ‘social entrepreneurship’ in order to enabling investors to identify funds with an SSE portfolio; and for the use of risk capital funds in financing SSE.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 The ambitious objectives set out in the EU's Europe 2020 strategy must continue to be the guideline for the work of the coming years. The economic and financial crisis that has hit the EU in recent years and led to a departure from these objectives cannot be an excuse. The crisis has led to a reassessment of the socio-economic model so that future growth is not only sustainable, but also based on the principles of economic, social and territorial cohesion that inspire the Union. In the important challenges facing the EU, such as economic and financial sustainability, social well-being and, above all, job creation, paying particular attention to the most vulnerable groups (young people, women, the elderly, the disabled), account must also be taken of the ongoing processes of population ageing and desertification in rural areas. That is why the social economy has a key role to play: social economy enterprises have been shown to be more resistant to economic disruption, they have been able to offer innovative solutions in favour of social cohesion and inclusion or job creation. We must also support them, because they are strongly linked to local and regional reality, they are a solution to the most heterogeneous local needs of citizens (health, social welfare, environmental).

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. Social entrepreneurship brings together all the initiatives that integrate social and environmental responsibility into their activities. These organizations highlight their governance, more respectful of stakeholders, the well-being of their employees and their ecologically responsible approach. These initiatives are part of what is called the social and solidarity economy. The report calls for the development of social entrepreneurship and social innovation as these companies have proven to be more robust in the face of the effects of the crisis. They are job creators, care more about the interests of their employees and are therefore better placed to meet the EU's objectives in Horizon 2020. Although the draft of this report is welcome, it is undeniable that the social and solidarity economy does not create enough jobs to compensate for those that have been destroyed for forty years under the leadership of the European Union. Once again, it is a question of concealing the failure of all European policies in terms of jobs. I voted against it.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Positive vote. The report emphasises the role of the social and solidarity economy in the fight against unemployment.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on social entrepreneurship and social innovation in the fight against unemployment. There are still many major challenges facing Europe, both in the short term, such as economic and financial sustainability, social welfare and, above all, job creation, and problems that are developing over a longer period, such as the ageing of the population or the desertification of rural areas, which are already beginning to show their negative effects. Nor should we forget all the actions to support the most vulnerable groups, for example young people, women and the elderly, the long-term unemployed, the disabled, immigrants or nomadic communities. In this respect, the social economy plays a key role, and it is precisely these types of companies that have shown that they are more resistant to changing economic situations, managing to offer innovative solutions to different problems. To this end, it is essential to pay particular attention to education and training, as it will be essential to be able to instill in young people a great spirit of innovation and entrepreneurship from adolescence.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ While there were some positive elements to this report specifically the provision which called for a formal and institutional recognition of the social and solidarity economy sector, this was counter-acted by a number of paragraphs which, aimed to open up the sector to private investment and private profit. In light of these concerns, I voted against this report.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ As someone who is, in principle, opposed to the free movement of EU citizens, and with particular regard to paragraph 50, which supports the free movement of workers, I voted against this report.  The oversupply of unskilled workers to the UK labour market, makes it increasingly difficult for British citizens seeking employment.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I agree with the rapporteur that there is a need to pay attention to social economy enterprises and also to include them in Member States’ action plans for employment. I believe that social economy enterprises promote growth and jobs thus I voted in favour of this report.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU faces major challenges in the short term such as economic and financial sustainability, social well-being and, above all, job creation, paying particular attention to the most vulnerable groups. While the subjects dealt with in this report are important and reasonable, in Italy social enterprises do not operate in an always transparent and effective way. That is why I preferred to abstain.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The EU has set out the lines to follow in the coming years under the 2020 strategy, with very ambitious targets, from which it should not be sent. The EU faces important challenges in the short term, such as economic and fiscal sustainability, social welfare and, in particular, job creation, taking particular account of the groups in a more precarious position, such as young people, women and the elderly, the long-term unemployed, people with disabilities, immigrants. But to meet these challenges, the EU must take into account future challenges, such as an ageing population and rural abandonment.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report on social entrepreneurship and social innovation. The economic and financial crisis that has hit Europe hard in recent years has confronted the continent with major challenges such as economic and financial sustainability, social well-being and job creation, particularly for the most vulnerable groups. The social economy has an important role to play. Social economy companies have been shown to be more crisis-resistant and able to offer innovative solutions for social cohesion and inclusion. For the future, work needs to be done on a number of fronts: education and training; improvement of funding; increased visibility at European and national level and exchange of information and good practice; promoting the development of the social economy in the Union and the Member States and improving the regulatory environment.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because the objectives in the 2020 Strategy have proven to be able to offer innovative solutions to give a boost to cohesion and social inclusion, but above all to the creation of new jobs during periods of economic stasis. I am convinced that entrepreneurship and social innovation are crucial to the further development of our economy and it remains vital to pay attention to this sector at both national and European level. In addition, the report calls on the Commission to include an entrepreneurial social economy in the action plans to promote employment and social integration, which I believe is essential for the European Union.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU will face, in the short term, important challenges such as economic and financial sustainability, social well-being and, in particular, job creation, taking specifically into account the most vulnerable groups, such as young people, women, the elderly, the long-term unemployed, people with disabilities, immigrants, among others. To address these challenges, the EU should take into account future challenges such as an ageing population or desertification of rural areas. The social economy plays a central role in getting the EU to meet its objectives.  I support this report, because I believe that entrepreneurship and social innovation are fundamental to strengthening the development of the social economy, and it is essential to pay particular attention to education and training, and Europe needs to instill this innovative and entrepreneurial spirit in young people from an early age. I support the need to promote the development of the social economy in Europe and the Member States, as well as the improvement of its legal framework.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 Social entrepreneurship and social innovation deserve proper attention from the European institutions because a stronger and more effective role for them can help to improve unemployment and lead to increased economic development. I voted in favour of this own-initiative report, which identifies the initiatives to be taken in order to move in this direction.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it is a new attempt to evade responsibility for the productive system in the very high levels of unemployment faced by European states. Entrepreneurship and social innovation cannot be the vehicle for state deprivation of welfare and social services. In addition, allowing private investment in such instruments will make them a speculative bubble. It is the State that must provide such services and from public investment try to boost them. The fight against unemployment must occur from all fronts, but especially since re-industrialization and large companies must be the first to transform their speculative activity into productive activity to generate quality jobs. That is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ The parliamentary report deals with social enterprises whose main aim is to achieve social objectives, such as providing jobs for vulnerable people or services with a high social impact, rather than creating profit for shareholders. Although social economy enterprises play an important role when it comes to achieving the objectives of the Europe 2020 Strategy, their level of recognition is rather low. This own-initiative report calls for a better acknowledgement of social economy enterprises and for public procurement procedures to be simplified, so that smaller social economy enterprises could better participate in tenders. As I fully agree with facilitating the running of such important players in our societies, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This initiative report supports the promotion of social entrepreneurship and social innovation, which are an essential driver of economic development, and are in line with the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy. The rapporteur calls on the European Commission to include social economy companies in the employment and social integration action programmes. It also calls on Member States to invest in this area at national level, in particular for the adaptation of national tax systems for social economy enterprises. Considering that the fight against unemployment is a priority in Europe, and that social entrepreneurship is one of the solutions to tackle it, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. The text on social entrepreneurship and social innovation in the fight against unemployment highlights the links between the social economy and local realities. I voted in favour of this text because social enterprises can be promoters of solutions adapted to specific needs. The European Union thus shows its determination in the fight against unemployment and the promotion of social integration.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 The economic and financial crisis has led to an increase in poverty and social exclusion, as well as long-term unemployment, which has increased the risk of poverty for people with disabilities throughout the European Union, while at the same time dramatically increasing the number of European citizens unable to find employment for more than a year.  In addition to employment incentives, more attention should also be paid to solutions that can facilitate the reintegration into the labour market of even those with the most basic skills and competitive skills in the short term, so that the benefits of more innovative solutions in the social economy can be exploited later. Any improvement in the economic and financial situation in the Member States should go hand in hand with intensive support for inclusive and sustainable growth and quality job creation.  In order to transfer them to the social economy, Member States should promote lifelong learning among older workers and the long-term unemployed, including people with disabilities, who continue to face physical, information and communication barriers.  Member States should take into account best practices in adjusting national tax systems for the benefit of social enterprises and socially conscious investments and, where appropriate, increase tax incentives and incentives for this type of undertaking with vulnerable groups, such as persons with disabilities.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. – The economic and financial crisis has led to an increase in poverty and social exclusion, as well as long-term unemployment, which has increased the risk of poverty for disabled people throughout the European Union, while at the same time dramatically increasing the number of European citizens unable to find employment for more than a year.  In addition to employment incentives, more attention should also be paid to solutions that can facilitate the reintegration into the labour market of even those with the most basic skills and competitive skills in the short term, so that the benefits of more innovative solutions in the social economy can be exploited later. Any improvement in the economic and financial situation in the Member States should go hand in hand with intensive support for inclusive and sustainable growth and quality job creation.  In order to transfer them to the social economy, Member States should promote lifelong learning among older workers and the long-term unemployed, including people with disabilities, who continue to face physical, information and communication barriers.  Member States should take into account best practices in adjusting national tax systems for the benefit of social enterprises and socially conscious investments and, where appropriate, increase tax incentives and incentives for this type of undertaking with vulnerable groups, such as persons with disabilities.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. If the social and solidarity economy, which inspires the terms and substance of this report, allows the promotion of social and territorial cohesion in the Union, the fact remains that its entrepreneurial dimension has a minimal influence in the economy. This strategy covers only a small number of jobs and cannot initiate structural change. However, funds are allocated to this strategy and the lack of a pre-assessment and impact assessment provided by the European Commission is a deficiency that deprives the legislator of a long-term vision. Finally, there is a significant risk that the recurrent and permanent beneficiaries of this strategy, which was to be the origin, will develop, a one-off correction for the reintegration and maintenance of the social link. Refusing to put certain jobs in the Union on an infusion and reckless spending, I objected to this report.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We are voting against because this report is also a continuation of the logic that enhances mobility, so it is detrimental to our country.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 The economic and financial crisis has led to an increase in poverty and social exclusion, as well as long-term unemployment, which has increased the risk of poverty for people with disabilities throughout the European Union, while at the same time dramatically increasing the number of European citizens unable to find employment for more than a year.  In addition to employment incentives, more attention should also be paid to solutions that can facilitate the reintegration into the labour market of even those with the most basic skills and competitive skills in the short term, so that the benefits of more innovative solutions in the social economy can be exploited later. Any improvement in the economic and financial situation in the Member States should go hand in hand with intensive support for inclusive and sustainable growth and quality job creation.  In order to transfer them to the social economy, Member States should promote lifelong learning among older workers and the long-term unemployed, including people with disabilities, who continue to face physical, information and communication barriers.  Member States should take into account best practices in adjusting national tax systems for the benefit of social enterprises and socially conscious investments and, where appropriate, increase tax incentives and incentives for this type of undertaking with vulnerable groups, such as persons with disabilities.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. Social economy enterprises have proved more resilient to economic disruption and have been able to offer innovative solutions for social cohesion and inclusion, as well as job creation. In addition, social economy companies have a strong connection with local and regional reality, enabling them to offer solutions appropriate to specific needs. Social entrepreneurship and social innovation are fundamental to strengthen the development of the social economy, and it is therefore essential to pay special attention to education and training. The EU needs to instill this innovative and entrepreneurial spirit to young people from an early age.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ the Great Economic and Financial Crisis, which has been narrowing Europe's regions since 2008, has, among other things, caused it to move away from some of the Europe 2020 targets. However, in addition to the migration problems, the European Union will also have to urgently address the challenges of economic and financial sustainability, social prosperity and job creation for young people under 25 in the near future. In addition to these challenges, the representatives of the European Union must not forget that our continent is ageing permanently, and pay well-deserved attention to the ageing of the population and the depopulation of rural areas. Many of these objectives will only be possible if the social economy works, because social economy enterprises have shown themselves to be more capable and resilient to economic shocks and have a stronger bond with local and regional structures. Social entrepreneurship and social innovation will be essential for the further development of the social economy. It is therefore crucial to pay particular attention to education and training. The European Union must instil this necessary innovation and entrepreneurial enthusiasm in young people from an early age.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this report which praises the role of the social and solidarity economy in the fight against the crisis and unemployment.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against this report because it is a continuation of the logic in favour of mobility and is therefore detrimental to our country.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The EU defined its approach for the coming years in the 2020 Strategy, and it must not turn its back on the ambitious targets set. Nevertheless, the economic and financial crisis that has affected the EU in recent years has meant that we are still far away from achieving these objectives, and we must now rethink the social and economic model to ensure that future growth is not only sustainable but also tallies with the principles of economic, social and territorial cohesion on which the EU is based. The social economy must play a key role in achieving these objectives. Social economy enterprises have proved to be better able to withstand economic turbulence, and have been able to offer innovative solutions to boost social cohesion and inclusion and job creation. Moreover, social economy enterprises have a strong local and regional basis and are able to offer solutions tailored to specific needs. Social innovation and social entrepreneurship are key factors in developing the social economy, and work needs to be done in in order to promote it.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. \u2012 The economic and financial crisis has led to an increase in poverty and social exclusion, as well as long-term unemployment, which has increased the risk of poverty for people with disabilities throughout the European Union, while at the same time dramatically increasing the number of European citizens unable to find employment for more than a year.  In addition to employment incentives, more attention should also be paid to solutions that can facilitate the reintegration into the labour market of even those with the most basic skills and competitive skills in the short term, so that the benefits of more innovative solutions in the social economy can be exploited later. Any improvement in the economic and financial situation in the Member States should go hand in hand with intensive support for inclusive and sustainable growth and quality job creation.  In order to transfer them to the social economy, Member States should promote lifelong learning among older workers and the long-term unemployed, including people with disabilities, who continue to face physical, information and communication barriers.  Member States should take into account best practices in adjusting national tax systems for the benefit of social enterprises and socially conscious investments and, where appropriate, increase tax incentives and incentives for this type of undertaking with vulnerable groups, such as persons with disabilities.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU has set out the way forward in the Europe 2020 strategy and cannot give up its very ambitious objectives The EU must face important short-term challenges such as economic and financial sustainability, social welfare and, in particular, job creation, taking into account, above all, the most vulnerable groups, such as young people, women and the elderly, the long-term unemployed. In order to achieve these objectives, the social economy must play a central role in all this.  However, I think it is important to point out that the social economy should not be confused with CSR. Social innovation and social entrepreneurship therefore play a key role in the development of the social economy, which requires education and training, better funding, better visibility at European and national level, and the exchange of information and best practices, the promotion of the development of the social economy in the EU and the Member States, in order to create a more favourable legal environment.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the report on social entrepreneurship and social innovation in the fight against unemployment, as I share the view that social entrepreneurship is one of the most dynamic sectors of europe's economy, given demographic trends. The EU would do well to promote this more from a social perspective.

name: Juan Carlos GIRAUTA VIDAL
text: in writing. – Today I voted in favour of this report as social entrepreneurship and social innovation offer mechanisms to soften the social and economic challenges Europe faces following the financial crisis. Social economy enterprises offer job creation and social well-being, boosting social cohesion and inclusion.  The fact that this report is placing the spotlight on this type of entrepreneurship, often non-profit, is beneficial but greater emphasise is required on education and training, improved financing and greater visibility at European and National level to exchange information.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because there are companies whose main objective is not profit, but the common good, led by visionary entrepreneurs, but also realists. It is social enterprises, so in fact and in the territory that they invest for the good of all rather than just for the owners. In these years of severe crisis, falling investment and mistrust of the world of finance, social enterprises are important realities to be encouraged and supported in order to create development, employment, solidarity, social justice and equality.  It is important to guarantee access to finance, contributions and public tenders, so that social enterprises grow and increase in the third sector, but above all so that the idea and philosophy that social does not mean poverty, can and must mean well-being can and must mean prosperity. Europe, in addition to developing multiannual strategies on social inclusion, equality or disability, should actually support those who bear direct witness to these principles and work every day to achieve them.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted against this report, which aims to analyse and propose measures to promote social entrepreneurship and innovation in the fight against unemployment. We share with the rapporteur and defend as social entrepreneurship and innovation a fundamental area that needs to be developed and supported and which has a special relevance for more vulnerable groups, such as young people, the elderly and women. In the same vein and in a context of crisis, we also see in the social economy a positive exit that can provide us with solutions to the problems of an aging and depopulated population in rural areas. However, several positive aspects of the report, which were in this line of recognition of the economy and social innovation as positive outlets for the crisis, with the amendments being negatively amended when considering social economy enterprises as a form of investment for profit through private funds. This completely altered the meaning of the report and led to the withdrawal of our support for believing that both issues (social economy and profit from the financial-speculative sector) are incompatible and undesirable.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I along with my fellow Labour MEPs voted in favour of this report. The EU must tackle significant challenges in the short term, including economic and financial sustainability, social well-being and especially job creation. I believe that social enterprises must play a key role in achieving these objectives and offer innovative solutions to boost social cohesion, inclusion and job creation. Furthermore, when it comes to achieving the goals of the Europe 2020 Strategy, their activities should be politically and financially supported. And that is why I voted in favour of this report and for this reason I join my fellow Members in calling on the Commission to propose a legal framework for social economy enterprises by means of a European statute for cooperative societies, associations, foundations and mutual societies.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 The economic and financial crisis has led to an increase in poverty and social exclusion, as well as long-term unemployment, which has increased the risk of poverty for people with disabilities throughout the European Union, while at the same time dramatically increasing the number of European citizens unable to find employment for more than a year.  In addition to employment incentives, more attention should also be paid to solutions that can facilitate the reintegration into the labour market of even those with the most basic skills and competitive skills in the short term, so that the benefits of more innovative solutions in the social economy can be exploited later. Any improvement in the economic and financial situation in the Member States should go hand in hand with intensive support for inclusive and sustainable growth and quality job creation.  In order to transfer them to the social economy, Member States should promote lifelong learning among older workers and the long-term unemployed, including people with disabilities, who continue to face physical, information and communication barriers.  Member States should take into account best practices in adjusting national tax systems for the benefit of social enterprises and socially conscious investments and, where appropriate, increase tax incentives and incentives for this type of undertaking with vulnerable groups, such as persons with disabilities.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. We voted against this report, which aims to analyse and propose measures to promote social entrepreneurship and innovation in the fight against unemployment. We share with the rapporteur and defend as social entrepreneurship and innovation a fundamental area that needs to be developed and supported and which has a special relevance for more vulnerable groups, such as young people, the elderly and women. In the same vein and in a context of crisis, we also see in the social economy a positive exit that can provide us with solutions to the problems of an aging and depopulated population in rural areas. However, several positive aspects of the report, which were in this line of recognition of the economy and social innovation as positive outlets for the crisis, with the amendments being negatively amended when considering social economy enterprises as a form of investment for profit through private funds. This completely altered the meaning of the report and led to the withdrawal of our support for believing that both issues (social economy and profit from the financial-speculative sector) are incompatible and undesirable.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ Since the Commission lunched the Europe 2020 Strategy significant progress has been made, however EU remains far from achieving the targets set, primarily those relating to employment, innovation and the reduction of poverty and social exclusion. The report calls on the Commission to propose a legal framework for social economy enterprises, a European statute for cooperative societies, associations, foundations and mutual societies. Social economy enterprises play an important role and should be adequately recognised.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a European Parliament resolution on social entrepreneurship and social innovation to combat unemployment, as the European Union faces major social and economic challenges further amplied by the economic and financial crisis. I believe it is necessary to improve and improve the current socioeconomic model in order to ensure faster and sustainable growth.  It is primarily necessary to encourage the creation of new jobs, with particular attention to the most vulnerable groups of society and young people. In this context, I believe that social entrepreneurship and social innovation can make a significant contribution to strengthening and growing the social economy, and it is therefore essential to promote education and training and entrepreneurial and innovative access in young people.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Véronica Lopé-Fontagné's report on social entrepreneurship and innovation in the fight against unemployment. The report stresses that too many Member States do not have regulations corresponding to the needs of the structures of the social and solidarity economy and therefore encourages States to take steps to reduce the legal uncertainty suffered by these structures. The report also recommends the introduction of a European label on social entrepreneurship. The report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's resolution on social entrepreneurship and social innovation in the fight against unemployment, supporting better access to public procurement, better funding and the creation of its own legal status under the Europe 2020 strategy for this economy, which employs more than 14 million people in Europe and is therefore particularly important in terms of employment, social and environmental benefits.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. The importance of social entrepreneurship cannot be called into question, but I must reject this report, as it overshoots the mark in terms of labour policy measures and violates the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ There are 2 million social economy enterprises representing 10% of EU undertakings. Their main purpose is to achieve social objectives, such as providing jobs for vulnerable people or services with a high social impact, rather than creating profit for shareholders. I supported the report, as it he calls for a better acknowledgement of social economy enterprises and to propose a legal framework for social economy enterprises by means of a European statute for cooperative societies, associations, foundations and mutual societies.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 The economic and financial crisis has led to an increase in poverty and social exclusion, as well as long-term unemployment, which has increased the risk of poverty for people with disabilities throughout the European Union, while at the same time dramatically increasing the number of European citizens unable to find employment for more than a year.  In addition to employment incentives, more attention should also be paid to solutions that can facilitate the reintegration into the labour market of even those with the most basic skills and competitive skills in the short term, so that the benefits of more innovative solutions in the social economy can be exploited later. Any improvement in the economic and financial situation in the Member States should go hand in hand with intensive support for inclusive and sustainable growth and quality job creation.  In order to transfer them to the social economy, Member States should promote lifelong learning among older workers and the long-term unemployed, including people with disabilities, who continue to face physical, information and communication barriers.  Member States should take into account best practices in adapting national tax systems for the benefit of social enterprises and socially conscious investments and, where appropriate, increase tax incentives and incentives for vulnerable groups, such as those employing persons with disabilities.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it is a new attempt to evade responsibility for the productive system in the very high levels of unemployment faced by European states. Entrepreneurship and social innovation cannot be the vehicle for state deprivation of welfare and social services. In addition, allowing private investment in such instruments will make them a speculative bubble. It is the State that must provide such services and from public investment try to boost them. The fight against unemployment must occur from all fronts, but especially since re-industrialization and large companies must be the first to transform their speculative activity into productive activity to generate quality jobs. That is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. U2012 Companies in the social and solidarity economy, which do not necessarily have to be non-profit organizations, are companies whose main objective is to achieve their social purpose, such as creating employment for vulnerable groups, providing services to their members or, more generally, causing a positive social and environmental impact, and reinvesting their benefits primarily to achieve those objectives. Studies indicate that the social economy can play a key role in meeting the objectives of the 2020 Strategy in the field of job creation. It is true that companies in the social economy have proven to be more resilient to economic shocks and have been able to offer innovative solutions for cohesion and social inclusion or job creation. This report which votes in favour proposes to the responsible entities the measures that need to be taken to enhance the role of the social economy in economic growth and employment.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I supported a report by MEP Lopa Fontagné that encourages Member States to use social entrepreneurship as a tool to combat the high unemployment rate in the Union. The social economy is an important driver of the economy in the European Union, but in Croatia we can say that only in the beginning and accurate data on this form of entrepreneurship do not we have.  According to a recent Survey by the European Commission, the social economy in the European Union generates 10% of GDP. The social economy employs over 14 million people, or about 6.5% of workers in the European Union. Two million companies and SMEs operate socially responsible and represent 10 per cent of EU companies.   These figures should be an incentive for Member States to invest in social entrepreneurship and innovation and to start implementing social economy strategies as soon as possible, especially as it is oriented towards the betterment of society as a whole and very attractive to young people. It is also important to define social entrepreneurship at Union level so that they can better monitor statistics and the impact of the social economy.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: writing – Social entrepreneurship is an important tool for maintaining economic and financial sustainability, promoting job creation and social development. The priority of social entrepreneurship is a broader solution to the social problem of the community and the individual. No one will use the profit from such a business for personal purposes, but invest it in social goals. This increases the durability and value of such a business. In order for this type of business to develop more broadly, it is necessary to create appropriate legislative and economic conditions. The Commission, together with the Council, must therefore launch all the processes necessary to promote and successfully develop such entrepreneurship in all EU Member States.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 As I said in my speech of 9/9/2015 to the plenary of the European Parliament, 'mercely' austerity has filled Europe with armies of unemployed people now amounting to 24 million. Unemployment rates are moving at high levels. At the same time, however, there are large differences in unemployment rates from country to country. In impoverished Greece the figure is 26% while in Germany it is only 5%. Youth unemployment in Greece has exceeded 53% and Spain is following it. At the same time, two million jobs remain vacant in the European Union and cannot be filled due to mismatched qualifications and labour market needs.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this text, which is certainly honourable, but so illusory. This strategy actually applies only to a very narrow range of jobs and therefore to a very limited number of people. The lack of impact assessments and controls does not provide a clear picture of the long-term consequences of these measures. This is, in fact, the latest attempt to cover up the inefficiency and failure of 30 years of employment policy in Europe.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the report on social entrepreneurship and social innovation in the fight against unemployment. Action is needed to improve regional planning, in favour of the economy and social innovation. Public services, such as education and information, must be strengthened, the quality of life of the population must be improved in order to be able to intervene and combat the domination of poverty and social exclusion, which is constantly increasing.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. In the fight against unemployment, entrepreneurship and social innovation, they are becoming increasingly important every day, as my colleague Veronica Lope Fontagne shows in a report that we have supported in the European Parliament. In the text, we show that social entrepreneurship and social innovation will be fundamental to the additional development of the social economy. It is therefore vital to pay particular attention to education and training.  The EU needs to instill in its young people this innovative and entrepreneurial spirit needed, from an early age.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. The text praises social entrepreneurship in the sky, but does not deal with the benefits and importance and is partly outside the scope. I therefore reject the report.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. The social and solidarity economy generates employment for more than 14 million people, equivalent to around 6.5% of EU workers, whereas in the EU there are 2 million companies in the social and solidarity economy, representing 10 % of eu businesses. Social and solidarity-based enterprises, which do not necessarily have to be non-profit organisations, are those whose main objective is the achievement of their social purpose, which may consist in creating jobs for vulnerable groups, providing services to their members or, in general, producing a positive social and environmental impact, and which reinvest their profits for the main purpose of achieving these objectives. These companies have been very important in the economic recovery and in the fight against unemployment.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ This report stresses the importance of the Union to stand by the commitments it made in the 2020 strategy. The rapporteur highlights the fact that the EU should make use of social entrepreneurship and social innovation to tackle both the immediate challenges of youth unemployment and migration and the long term challenges of our ageing population and the depopulation of rural areas. Therefore I gave it my support.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this report but note that the social and solidarity-based economy cannot replace the welfare state and public services.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. Europe has been advocating for a more inclusive society for many years, notably through the creation of social enterprises aimed at the development of activities, for social, societal or environmental purposes. It has also launched an initiative to promote the creation and development of social enterprises, in particular by promoting their access to finance. One in four companies created in Europe and one in three in Belgium are social enterprises. These companies, which reinvest part of their profits in their social or environmental mission, deserve our full support. They are distinguished by a strong commitment from their employees or associates. Productive, supportive and competitive, they have a deep sense of the collective good and offer jobs to more than 14 million Europeans weakened by the consequences of the financial crisis.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the European Parliament's report on social entrepreneurship and social innovation in the fight against unemployment, as the social and solidarity-based economy currently complies 2 million social and solidarity-based economy enterprises, representing 10% of businesses in the Union and providing employment for around 14 million people. I believe that this european Parliament's own-initiative report will lead to increased awareness in this area, because so far, unfortunately, it has been very poorly devoted to the social and solidarity-based economy at European and Member State level.  I support social enterprises primarily because they apply the principles of solidarity and responsibility in practice and combine the interests of members, users and the general or social interest that takes precedence over fierce profit-making or capital raising. I therefore join the appeal to the Commission and the Member States to create a favourable environment for the creation of business incubators for social and solidarity-based economy enterprises, and also to create and effectively promote an internet platform for the exchange of data between social investors and social entrepreneurs, the so-called Social Innovation Europe Platform.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on Social entrepreneurship and social innovation in combatting unemployment because I strongly believe that social economy enterprises play an important role when it comes to achieving the objectives of the Europe 2020 Strategy. Their role should therefore be adequately recognised and their activities politically and financially supported. The Commission should propose a legal framework for social economy enterprises by means of a European statute for cooperative societies, associations, foundations and mutual societies.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The report notes that the social economy must play a central role in achieving the objectives set by the EU. Companies in the social economy have demonstrated that they are more resilient to economic shocks and have been able to offer innovative solutions for social cohesion and inclusion or job creation. In addition, companies operating in the social economy have strong ties to local and regional everyday life, so that they can offer solutions tailored to specific needs. It concludes that social innovation and social entrepreneurship play a key role in the development of the social economy, and that progress is needed to encourage this in the following areas: - education and training, - improving funding, - better visibility at European and national level, and the exchange of information and best practices, - promoting the development of the social economy in the EU and the Member States, - creating a more favourable legal environment.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 I would point out that, following the economic and financial crisis, levels of poverty and social exclusion have increased, as have long-term unemployment, youth unemployment and social inequalities. The most affected by the crisis were the most excluded and disadvantaged groups in the labour market, such as people with disabilities, young people, the elderly, women, the long-term unemployed and disadvantaged workers. I support that the economic and financial crisis should be seen as an opportunity to move towards a more sustainable economic model for the EU. I argue that the social entrepreneurship model often attracts young people, giving them an opportunity to find innovative answers to today's economic, social and environmental challenges.  I believe it is important that social and solidarity economy enterprises should be better integrated by Member States into action plans on employment and social inclusion, as well as in national reform programmes, with a view to capitalising on their potential in terms of job creation and the contribution they can make to meeting the major objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This report on social entrepreneurship and social innovation in the fight against unemployment aims to develop the social economy in solidarity by focusing on five major areas (education/training, access to finance, visibility at European level, improvement of the legal framework, development of the social economy in the EU and member states). Social entrepreneurship includes forms of entrepreneurship whose main purpose is social or environmental and where the majority of profits are reinvested for the benefit of this mission. Social innovation is part of the notion of a social and solidarity economy. While this objective is laudable, it is in complete contradiction with the EU's exacerbated competition policies. Moreover, the social and solidarity economy is largely illusory, since the salaries of these jobs are often capped, which encourages social dumping, the scope of these jobs is often narrow and can only help a limited number of people, the state aid granted is subject to little control, the long-term economic and environmental effects little analyzed etc. Such proposals are a counter-fire aimed at overshadowing the inefficiency and failure of the EU's employment policies. So I voted against it.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ The EU must tackle significant challenges in the short term, including economic and financial sustainability, social well—being and especially job creation. Labour MEPs believe that the social economy enterprises must play a key role in achieving these objectives, offering innovative solutions to boost social cohesion and inclusion and job creation.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the role of companies, cooperatives, associations, mutuals and foundations in the fight against unemployment. The report points out that the social and solidarity economy represents 2 million businesses, or 10% of businesses in the European Union, and employs 14 million people, or 6.5% of workers. The aim of this text is to put in place regulatory frameworks in the Member States to develop these types of enterprises, which create jobs even during the crisis.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report by my colleague Veronica Lopé Fontagné. Indeed, in order to achieve the objectives set out in the Europe 2020 strategy, companies in the social economy have shown their ability to provide innovative solutions to boost social cohesion and inclusion as well as job creation, including during periods of economic downturn. In addition, social economy companies maintain a close link with local and regional reality and offer solutions tailored to specific needs. The social and solidarity economy must clearly be one of the priorities for creating jobs and strengthening social cohesion. In order to do this, all Member States must put in place legal frameworks and push for the creation of a European label for the recognition of these structures, which often suffer from legal recognition.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 The positive vote on this resolution is, ideally, accompanied by the vote on the resolution on promoting the entrepreneurial spirit of young people. It is clear from developments in recent years that social entrepreneurship will, in the future, be one of the cornerstones of the new labour market. This is an increasingly defined reality, as well as a growing one, to which the European Union should devote more attention both in terms of policies and funding. At a time of crisis and reduced public spending capacity, this new sector could provide a sustainable response to the demand for more effective welfare in the face of ever-greater economic availability of public coffers. While the Commission's work on the new public procurement directive, which includes social clauses and criteria to promote social inclusion and social innovation, should be praised, the resolution clearly highlights the lack (if at all) consideration and enhancement of this reality within the strategy for the creation of the digital single market.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report that will promote social innovation and social entrepreneurship in areas like education and training, improved financing, greater visibility at European and national level and exchange of information and best practice, action to promote the development of the social economy in the EU and Member States and Improved legal framework

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: in writing. – I abstained on this report, because while it contained many important positive aspects, it also contained certain aspects that I know the Social and Solidarity Economy sector find very problematic. The most significant positive element in the report is that it calls for formal and institutional recognition of the social and solidarity economy sector. However, the report also calls for the opening up of the SSE sector to facilitate private investment and private profit. Those active in the sector are very wary of moves such as this and have indicated to Sinn Féin that they oppose such measures. Of particular cause of concern were paragraphs 24, 25 and 31, which included a call to bring together potential investors and specialised funds; a call for a European trustmark for 'social entrepreneurship’ in order to enabling investors to identify funds with an SSE portfolio; and for the use of risk capital funds in financing SSE.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly support this report as it marks a turning point in the advancement of social entrepreneurship throughout the European Union. These two terms, perhaps not intuitively compatible with each other, have come to show the value of having your cake and eating it. It means social and solidarity-based businesses and investments can actually turn a profit, benefiting the people involved in many ways. The EU and the Member States need definitely to promote social entrepreneurship programmes, as well as training, to better develop this upcoming market.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I have refused to support the report because it does not provide new and innovative solutions to pressing issues, particularly in the area of combating youth unemployment. Instead of ever-new collections of ideas, I am finally calling for clear and effective measures.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Given that the EU will soon have to address important challenges such as economic and financial sustainability, social well-being and, in particular, job creation, taking into account the most vulnerable groups, such as young people, women and the elderly, the long-term unemployed, people with disabilities and immigrants, it is essential to further develop social entrepreneurship and innovation.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – Unfortunately, the social and solidarity-based economy remains in the shadows when it comes to the economy as a whole. In fact, there are 2 million enterprises and companies in the social and solidarity economy in the European Union. What is remarkable about this type of enterprise is that their main objective is not material benefits, but social support and human assistance, and at the same time they give work to 14 million people, among them the most vulnerable and weak members of our society. These undertakings need deserved attention and specific assistance, especially within a union based on the principle of solidarity. We need a perfect regulatory framework that promotes social entrepreneurship, stimulates innovation in the sector and ensures sustainability and security. That is why I gave my "yes" to my colleague Verónica Lope Fontagné's report.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ I supported this report because the social economy, taking into account its social nature, offers jobs to the most vulnerable and thus contributes to economic growth, solidarity and social cohesion.  Social economy companies are more flexible and innovative and offer favourable working conditions and better adapt to economic and social circumstances. They are characterised by a high degree of involvement of their members in the management of the company and the transparency of their operations. It promotes lifelong learning among older and long-unemployed workers to enable them to be retrained towards the social economy.  It is a way of doing business that is not only aimed at maximising profits, but also enabling safe jobs and social engagement through investing earnings for social purposes, and the figures testify that social entrepreneurship provides 14.5 million jobs, as well as turning around 50 billion euros annually in this sector.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This report on social entrepreneurship and social innovation in the fight against unemployment aims to develop the social economy in solidarity by focusing on five major areas (education/training, access to finance, visibility at European level, improvement of the legal framework, development of the social economy in the EU and Member States). Social entrepreneurship includes forms of entrepreneurship whose main purpose is social or environmental and where the majority of profits are reinvested for the benefit of this mission. Social innovation is part of the notion of a social and solidarity economy. While this objective is laudable, it is in complete contradiction with the EU's exacerbated competition policies. Moreover, the social and solidarity economy is largely illusory, since the salaries of these jobs are often capped, which encourages social dumping, the scope of these jobs is often narrow and can only help a limited number of people, the state aid granted is subject to little control, the long-term economic and environmental effects little analyzed etc. Such proposals are a counter-fire aimed at overshadowing the inefficiency and failure of the EU's employment policies. So I voted against it.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ In an effort to create a fairer European society, social entrepreneurship plays an exceptional role as the goal of social and solidarity economy companies is not only to improve economic, but also social conditions. The social economy is not only a matter of attitude towards economic activities, but it is a question of a holistic approach to life in which the economy is meaningfully and sustainably integrated together with all other aspects of human life.  I support the report and these calls on the Commission as well as national institutions to make further efforts to facilitate access to public funding for social entrepreneurs, as well as to make further efforts to promote and integrate social entrepreneurship into existing educational programmes. Social and solidarity-based economies offer jobs to groups most often excluded from the open labour market, thereby contributing to solidarity, social cohesion and economic growth.  I firmly believe that with the growth of social entrepreneurship, which has proven particularly resilient to gender inequality and the volatile economic conditions present in Europe in recent years, the Union would sooner and more easily achieve many of the more ambitious objectives set by the Europe 2020 strategy.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. - Due to the economic and financial crisis that has hit the EU, the social and economic model set out should be revised to ensure future growth and development that must reflect the economic principles and social and territorial connectivity on which the EU is based.  I agree with my colleague Fontagné and support her report, which states that the social economy should be the backbone of achieving the EU's primary objectives – such as creating jobs, citizens' well-being, taking care of the most vulnerable groups of citizens as well as young people, women, the elderly and the disabled, and finally immigrants who are currently a pressing problem of the European Union.  I see social entrepreneurship as a good answer to the problems left behind by the economic crisis. The purpose of enterprises of the social economy is to achieve their social goals such as creating jobs for the most vulnerable groups, creating a positive impact on society and the environment, etc. Such companies have a strong local and regional rootedness and thus more easily identify the specific needs of the community.

name: Pavel POC
text: Writing. \u2012 Socially beneficial business is still a relatively distant concept for many, wrongly so. The social economy currently employs up to 14 million Europeans. I supported the report on the role of social entrepreneurship and social innovation in the fight against unemployment (2014/2236(INI)), as social and solidarity economy enterprises promote values superior to the interests of capital. They don't focus blindly on profit. They focus on social and often environmental objectives. Moreover, they provide employment to disadvantaged citizens, who are often affected by a health handicap or other factor causing their social exclusion. Also, because social enterprises can help to achieve one of the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy, I supported the request to include these enterprises in member states' employment action plans. I also voted in favour of improving the financial position of these entities, which should have better access to European funds, micro-trusts and other financing instruments. I supported a more flexible application of state aid rules, which should be an aid to them and not an obstacle. Similarly, I have advocated greater European coordination, which is currently lacking, and for the creation of a new legal framework for these actors. I believe that only strengthening social dialogue, sufficient exchange of information and communication with the public will help to raise the necessary profile of the sector and lead to the necessary social innovations.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 To get out of the employment crisis we need to focus on all sectors of the real economy that have proven to be stronger and more responsive. These include, of course, social entrepreneurship. In addition to dealing with disadvantaged sectors of the population, it has shown very positive economic performance. Social economy enterprises have been shown to be more resistant to economic disruption and have been able to offer innovative solutions in favour of social cohesion and inclusion or job creation. Social innovation and social entrepreneurship are therefore essential in the development of the European economy.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. Between May 2012 and May 2015, the unemployment rate in the EU rose from 10.4% to 9.6%. While the unemployment figure has fallen it is still high. The Union must multiply actions to combat unemployment by using different tools and policies. For example, we have adopted in Parliament a report on social entrepreneurship and social innovation in the fight against unemployment. Indeed, these economic activities have real growth potential. They employ more than 14 million people in the EU. The report encourages the EU to promote these economic activities.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The social economy model is inspired by common values, such as solidarity, social cohesion, the primacy of the individual over capital, social responsibility, democratic management and, finally, a guiding principle that promotes social impact, seconding the profits that exist, are reinvested in the company and in society. During the economic and financial crisis of recent years, this model of economy has shown exceptional resistance to economic disruption, taking advantage of traditional companies. Sensitive to the particularities of the model and with a view to moving towards a more sustainable economic paradigm, the rapporteur is of the opinion that the European Union should henceforth pay special attention to education and training, instilling in young people, from an early age, the innovative and entrepreneurial spirit. The report, which I support with my vote, calls on the Member States to promote a business culture and the model of cooperative and social entrepreneurship in education and training programmes - a promotion that strives to lay the foundations for more sustainable economic growth.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. Europe has 2 million social economy companies , 10% of European companies - employing more than 14 million people - 6.5% of workers.  Companies in the social economy have proven to be more resilient to the crisis, as well as providing added value in promoting cohesion and social inclusion through job creation.  Through this report, which I voted in favour of, Parliament urges to promote the sector and improve the exchange of practices between sectors and between States. In addition, it calls on public authorities and financial service providers to adapt to the financial needs of such enterprises at all stages of their business development, especially in their creation. In addition, thanks to the contributions of the S&D group, it urges to promote the cooperative model and improve the access of these companies to public procurement systems.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. Today in the European Parliament was asked to vote on a report on social entrepreneurship and social innovation in the fight against unemployment. As a strong advocate of the social and solidarity economy, this report was particularly important to me.  The social and solidarity economy in Europe affects 14 million workers (6.5% of workers) and two million businesses (or 10% of enterprises) in Europe. The aim of these companies is to achieve their social objective. For example, creating jobs for vulnerable groups, providing services to their staff, or more broadly having positive social and environmental benefits.  Through this report for which I voted, I congratulate the four Member States, including Belgium, which have national regulations on the social economy. However, I think it is important to increase the participation of companies in the social and solidarity economy in the procedures for awarding public contracts. I stress that the social economy could contribute to a significant reduction in youth unemployment by setting up training courses for entrepreneurs in the social sector.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which reminds us that in order to achieve the objectives set out in the Europe 2020 strategy, companies in the social economy have shown their ability to provide innovative solutions to stimulate both cohesion and social inclusion, as well as job creation. It is important to remember that companies in the social economy maintain closeness to local and regional reality and thus enable solutions to be adapted to specific needs: social entrepreneurship and social innovation.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mr Syod's proposal. Fontagné on entrepreneurship and social innovation in the fight against unemployment. The social economy plays a central and important role in economic and financial sustainability and is also useful for promoting employment and social well-being. These policies in times of crisis have been able to guarantee innovative solutions aimed at cohesion and social inclusion, creating new jobs. It is therefore essential to promote and strengthen education and training, to increase funding and to make these activities more visible at European and national level. Good information is needed and the development of the social economy in the Member States must be promoted by improving its regulatory environment.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted against this report, which aims to analyse and propose measures to promote social entrepreneurship and innovation in the fight against unemployment. We share with the rapporteur and defend as social entrepreneurship and innovation a fundamental area that needs to be developed and supported and which has a special relevance for more vulnerable groups, such as young people, the elderly and women. In the same vein and in a context of crisis, we also see in the social economy a positive exit that can provide us with solutions to the problems of an aging and depopulated population in rural areas. However, several positive aspects of the report, which were in this line of recognition of the economy and social innovation as positive outlets for the crisis, with the amendments being negatively amended when considering social economy enterprises as a form of investment for profit through private funds. This completely altered the meaning of the report and led to the withdrawal of our support for believing that both issues (social economy and profit from the financial-speculative sector) are incompatible and undesirable.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Writing. Social enterprises are very important for the implementation of the 2020 European Strategy, as these companies are closely involved with the people: they help and care for those who have a special need in their lives and to deal with problems, and they are usually particularly well established in the region. They thus make a special contribution to social cohesion and social integration. It is important for me to make it clear that these services take into account not only the social component but also the business side. Public budgets must be used efficiently. I believe that we have made this idea clear in our parliamentary report. I also believe that the Commission is called upon to include social enterprises in all action plans for employment and social inclusion and to promote social entrepreneurship and investment in the social economy.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it is a new attempt to evade responsibility for the productive system in the very high levels of unemployment faced by European states. Entrepreneurship and social innovation cannot be the vehicle for state deprivation of welfare and social services. In addition, allowing private investment in such instruments will make them a speculative bubble. It is the State that must provide such services and from public investment try to boost them. The fight against unemployment must occur from all fronts, but especially since re-industrialization and large companies must be the first to transform their speculative activity into productive activity to generate quality jobs. That is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as I do not believe that the EU should be meddling with UK employment. There are also mentions of protecting free movement of people, which I do not support.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ The EU must tackle significant challenges in the short term, including economic and financial sustainability, social well-being and especially job creation. I believe that social enterprises must play a key role in achieving these objectives and offer innovative solutions to boost social cohesion, inclusion and job creation. Furthermore, when it comes to achieving the goals of the Europe 2020 Strategy, their activities should be politically and financially supported. And that is why I voted in favour of this report and for this reason I join my fellow Members in calling on the Commission to propose a legal framework for social economy enterprises by means of a European statute for cooperative societies, associations, foundations and mutual societies.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: writing \ u2012 Social Entrepreneurship and Social Innovation are an important part of the development of the economy across the EU. For this reason, I voted in line with the position of the EKR to adopt a European Parliament resolution dealing with this type of business and its innovations, taking into account its contribution to the fight against unemployment.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ This explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Although social entrepreneurship is becoming an increasingly popular tool for solving unemployment problems, I continue to see that many people are still afraid to start their own business. In my experience, one of the biggest concerns of start-ups is that they do not have the necessary skills, do not have sufficient entrepreneurial education or do not have the appropriate contacts to support their business plans. I am glad that up to 40% of young Europeans are showing an interest in starting small business or self-employment, so I think that it is social entrepreneurship that seems to be the right choice for them. I supported this current report because I believe that innovation in social entrepreneurship creates social value while allowing people to do business, even if they have limited funding. I also consider it important that social entrepreneurship and social innovation create the opportunity to respond in an innovative and entrepreneurial way to social needs, which are often not met either through the market or through the state.
