I expect that, thanks also to this report, social entrepreneurship will become a major challenge for all the Member States that are still lagging behind in this area.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. The economic and financial crisis we are facing has further increased the importance of social and solidarity-based businesses. The current labour market situation points to even greater exclusion and disadvantage for certain groups, such as people with disabilities, young people, the elderly, women, the long-term unemployed and disadvantaged workers. The report highlights the importance of the social economy, as well as the fact that social entrepreneurship proves better in crisis situations than other forms of entrepreneurship. They describe the areas (exclusion from action plans related to the Europe 2020 strategy, public procurement, funding, training and support and promotion) needed to improve the state of the social and solidarity-based economy. This, because of its social and inclusive nature, offers employment to the groups most often excluded from the open labour market, thus contributing to solidarity, social cohesion and economic growth. I supported the report in order to emphasise the importance and serious treatment of the social and solidarity-based economy.

name: Bart STAES
text: Written. 'The EU has limited competence when it comes to social enterprise and social innovation and the Commission tends to underestimate its importance. The Lope Fontagne report therefore emphasises the importance of the social economy in combating (or avoiding) unemployment. Social enterprises often do better in crisis situations. The report emphasises the social objective and more inclusive workplaces, but also on more democratic structures and the fact that the social economy is responding strongly to the general interest of society. With this report, the EP calls on the EU to become more active, to deliver effective results through the Social Entrepreneurship Initiative and to recognise the non-profit sector with its economic actors. A strong link is being established with the EU 2020 targets. I therefore believe it is important to support the alternative of the social economy and social innovation and hopefully to make it more mainstream and voted in favour of the report.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. I support this report because social entrepreneurship, as well as social innovation, is important for the further development of the social economy in Europe. It is therefore essential that this sector of innovation and entrepreneurship in the economy is shown a specific type of attention, at the European and national level of each Member State.  It is also important that social economy companies engage in action plans for employment, development and social integration, and it is the responsibility of Member States to promote healthy and socially responsible entrepreneurship and investments in their social economies.  Businesses and entrepreneurship need to be helped in the ways at their disposal, as they are the backbone of employment and development in Europe. I would also welcome decisions on tax breaks that benefit entrepreneurship, and therefore I support this report.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ The EU must tackle significant challenges in the short term, including economic and financial sustainability, social well-being and especially job creation. EPLP believes that the social economy enterprises must play a key role in achieving these objectives offering innovative solutions to boost social cohesion and inclusion and job creation.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. I support this report, as the problem of unemployment entails many issues such as social exclusion and high poverty. Social entrepreneurship has shown that it can offer innovative solutions to increase social cohesion and inclusion, and to create new jobs even during the economic crisis.  Social entrepreneurship is an important driver of social cohesion and sustainability that can stimulate economic growth while reducing poverty, social exclusion and other social problems. This problem is important to approach from European and national level.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: I abstained in writing ‒ I abstained. While I recognise the benefits of social entrepreneurship, I do not agree that social enterprises should have legislative advantages, that they should be positively discriminated against in other ways, or even that specific financial support programmes be created for them from taxpayers' money. Instead of these measures, there is better legislative and financial assistance that will be across the board – in other words, reducing the regulatory and tax burden for all. As a result, businesses that genuinely meet the needs of customers, rather than businesses enjoying bureaucratic privileges, will be able to succeed.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report on social enterprises contained positive elements such as their definition as enterprises characterised by the primacy of individual and social objectives over the interests of capital, democratic control by their members, and the defence and application of the principles of solidarity and responsibility. There is also a clear reference to the inability of any undertakings to replace the social state, a reference added by our own amendment. But we disagree with the rapporteur's attempt to break down the principles of social entrepreneurship by allowing these companies to enter the stock markets and by allowing financial funds to use them, either to avoid taxes or to multiply their own profitability. Social enterprises should remain committed to their social work and not be used as a gambling vehicle by brokerage groups. We now also have the experience of the current economic crisis caused precisely by this thirst for big profits from banks and big business. Our position is clear. Social enterprises must stay out of any profit race and, in the light of this, we voted against the report.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which comprehensively illustrates the difficulties and benefits of social economies. I agree that social innovation contributes significantly to sustainable growth. In my opinion, this approach can also work for smaller municipalities, in the framework of a so-called social eco-village. I have therefore also initiated a pilot project on this subject. I believe that one subject has been little affected by this issue, namely that these enterprises can play a major role in reducing energy dependency throughout Europe.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on social entrepreneurship and social innovation in combating unemployment. Indeed, it is now time to go beyond the 2012 Social Entrepreneurship Initiative to further support the growth of the social and solidarity-based economy with the introduction of a European trust mark for social entrepreneurship and giving companies holding this trust mark their own legal status.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I supported a report that recognises the social entrepreneurship model as an opportunity for young people to offer innovative responses to current economic, social and environmental challenges, including job creation for groups that are most often excluded from the open labour market but also contribute to economic growth.  I consider that the poor knowledge of financial intermediary managers on the importance of social entrepreneurship is one of the main causes of difficult access to finance, and therefore I support the emphasis on the need to raise awareness of the importance of this entrepreneurship.  As citizens are not sufficiently informed about the social and solidarity sectors, I believe that the education and training of people intending to work in the sector, as well as greater visibility at national and European level, will greatly help its further development.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. In order to achieve the objectives set out in the 2020 Strategy, social enterprises have shown that they can offer innovative solutions and proposals to increase social cohesion. Especially in times of economic downturn, because these companies are particularly resilient to economic fluctuations. At the same time, social entrepreneurship offers a number of solutions tailored to specific needs. It is essential that we pay particular attention to this sector at European and national level. In addition, the report calls on the Commission to include social entrepreneurship in the action plans for employment and social inclusion. It requires Member States to promote social entrepreneurship and investment in the social economy. I supported the report. Social entrepreneurship is particularly important in times of unstable labour market conditions, but like all other areas, the successful implementation of European ideas depends primarily on a particular Member State.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted against this report, which aims to analyse and propose measures to promote social entrepreneurship and innovation in the fight against unemployment. We share with the rapporteur and defend as social entrepreneurship and innovation a fundamental area that needs to be developed and supported and which has a special relevance for more vulnerable groups, such as young people, the elderly and women. In the same vein and in a context of crisis, we also see in the social economy a positive exit that can provide us with solutions to the problems of an aging and depopulated population in rural areas. However, several positive aspects of the report, which were in this line of recognition of the economy and social innovation as positive outlets for the crisis, with the amendments being negatively amended when considering social economy enterprises as a form of investment for profit through private funds. This completely altered the meaning of the report and led to the withdrawal of our support for believing that both issues (social economy and profit from the financial-speculative sector) are incompatible and undesirable.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ As a result of the economic and financial crisis in some European countries, levels of poverty and social exclusion have increased, as well as long-term unemployment and social inequalities. The economic and financial crisis should be seen as an opportunity to work for an economic model giving a more sustainable EU, devoting more attention to economic and social cohesion and environmental sustainability. I agree that social investment is investment in people, designed to strengthen their skills and capabilities, and provide support for full participation in employment and social life: that is why I supported this proposal.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. Although honourable, the strategy described in this text is illusory. There are several complaints: - social and solidarity jobs are very often capped in terms of pay, which contributes to social dumping; - this strategy applies to a relatively narrow range of jobs, and therefore could only help a limited number of people for a major investment; - the lack of means to control the use of funds granted as state aid for the development of these enterprises; - the lack of an impact assessment on the part of the Commission, and therefore information on the long-term economic, social and environmental effects; - the possible (and probable) drift in the privileged beneficiaries of this type of employment, etc. This is, in fact, the latest attempt to cover up the inefficiency and failure of 30 years of employment policy in Europe. I am voting against this text.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted against this report, which aims to analyse and propose measures to promote social entrepreneurship and innovation in the fight against unemployment. We share with the rapporteur and defend as social entrepreneurship and innovation a fundamental area that needs to be developed and supported and which has a special relevance for more vulnerable groups, such as young people, the elderly and women. In the same vein and in a context of crisis, we also see in the social economy a positive exit that can provide us with solutions to the problems of an aging and depopulated population in rural areas. However, several positive aspects of the report, which were in this line of recognition of the economy and social innovation as positive outlets for the crisis, with the amendments being negatively amended when considering social economy enterprises as a form of investment for profit through private funds. This completely altered the meaning of the report and led to the withdrawal of our support for believing that both issues (social economy and profit from the financial-speculative sector) are incompatible and undesirable.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report because it emphasizes the importance and size of the social economy, mentioning that social economy enterprises tend to be stronger in crisis situations. The report also calls for the EU and member states to be more active in this area and to give more support and recognition to this more inclusive form of economy, with more democratic structures and focused on the general interest.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution on ‘social economy’, centred around the principle that enterprises must receive more help to create jobs that benefit vulnerable people and local communities. The resolution calls for better cooperation among social enterprises and especially for an easier access to EU funding in order to boost their development. Such measures (including the idea of creating a special company category for such enterprises and granting them a special legal status of their own) have the main objective of fostering employment among vulnerable groups and contributing to positive social and environmental impact in local communities.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. "U2012 So-called social economy enterprises have shown their ability to provide innovative solutions to stimulate cohesion and social inclusion, while promoting job creation. As the report rightly points out, entrepreneurship and social innovation will be essential to further the development of our economy. The proposals for that report go in this direction, so I consider it necessary to vote in favour of that report.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as the EU must tackle significant challenges in the short term, including economic and financial sustainability, social well-being and especially job creation. I believe that social economy enterprises must play a key role in achieving these objectives, by offering innovative solutions to boost social cohesion, to improve the inclusion of citizens in the work market and job creation. I therefore commend this report on its acknowledgement of these issues. Taking into account the role of the social economy when the Europe 2020 strategy is revised is a crucial step towards recognising the social economy´s role and improving our economy as a whole. By using social enterprises to provide work with dignity we can improve by our common endeavour not only the quantity of jobs available, but also the quality of people’s lives.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which highlights the role of the social economy as an exit from the economic crisis. I regret, however, that it continues to maintain the confusion between the social and solidarity economy and social business. Despite the unprecedented crisis and job destruction, the social and solidarity economy has proven its resilience, far superior to that of other types of enterprises, and its ability to create new jobs in an unfavourable economic context. The EP report stresses that the social economy is an important driver for achieving a more sustainable economic and financial model, creating social and territorial cohesion and respecting the environment, in line with the EU treaties. In particular, it calls on the Commission to put in place a legal framework for all companies in the social and solidarity economy, thanks to the adoption of European statutes, which Member States have still not adopted despite repeated requests from the sector. After the Toïa report (2009), it is another important report showing that the social economy represents a viable alternative to the traditional business model, an economy that serves people, innovative, more responsive to the needs and challenges of society.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The text praises social entrepreneurship in the sky, but does not deal with the benefits and importance and is partly outside the scope. I therefore reject the report.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I did not agree with the European Parliament's resolution on social entrepreneurship and social innovation in the fight against unemployment. The report calls for subsidies and special treatment for companies that primarily pursue social purposes. It is therefore a product of the social worker industry, which is calling on the Commission to launch a subsidy programme. This is certainly not a task for the European level and violates the principle of subsidiarity. I also miss a clear commitment to private nature of charitable behaviour. The report assumes that any social action will only happen if it is supported and subsidised by the state. This is not my worldview. I am convinced that people are doing good without the state threatening them with a stick at the back and a carrot hanging in front of their noses.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ The EU must tackle significant challenges in the short term, including economic and financial sustainability, social well-being and especially job creation. I believe that the social economy enterprises must play a key role in achieving these objectives offering innovative solutions to boost social cohesion and inclusion and job creation offering a sustainable and hopeful future for some of the poorest communities. Therefore I voted in favour of the report.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. – I voted for the own-initiative report on social entrepreneurship and social innovation in the fight against unemployment.  I agree with the proposal calling on the Commission to recognise the diversity of social enterprises and to ensure that measures are taken at EU level to support all types of social and solidarity enterprises. I also agree with the invitation to the EC and the Member States to consistently implement the measures set out in the 2012 Social Entrepreneurship Initiative.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: In writing. This report is perfectly in line with my colleague Michaela 'ojdrov's report on the promotion of entrepreneurship among young people. It highlights the social dimension of entrepreneurship. In order to be competitive in employment while maintaining its specificity of social well-being, the European Union will have to do everything possible to foster innovation among young people and invest heavily in education and training. I therefore wanted to vote in favour of this report.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which aims to promote and improve the position of social and solidarity-based enterprises. These businesses do not primarily look at themselves and their benefits, but they help to improve society as a whole by providing services to people caught up in social events, by creating jobs that are more economically stable in times of crisis, and by providing jobs for those who are disadvantaged in the ordinary labour market. I believe that these are mainly young graduates, old people and women.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 The report refers to companies and organizations in the "third sector", the so-called social and solidarity economy. It proposes the establishment of incentives for "social entrepreneurship", considered a fairer and more structural response to the socio-economic crisis, unemployment or exclusion. Despite the positive work of the organizations of the so-called social and solidarity economy, their socio-economic relevance and the recognition of the proper support and framework that these organizations deserve, the report emphasizes entrepreneurship (not only in this sector) as the solution – absolute! - for the problems of EU societies, and the creation of businesses as the answer to which all systems (economic, educational/training) should be targeted (inclusion in school curricula of entrepreneurship subjects, for example). It also places these organisations as substitutes for public services – a trend towards the public sector being de-responsible for the services (public, free and quality) they must provide to the population. We voted against it.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: – Mr President, I was very pleased to support this very constructive and all-encompassing report – indeed, a very wide-ranging report – on matching skills and qualifications with demand and job opportunities.  The report contains all the pieces of the jigsaw puzzle that are necessary to match skills and jobs. We need to foster a competitive labour market. We need to anticipate future skills needs. We need to strengthen the connection between education and employment. We need to foster fair mobility, and we need to nurture the entrepreneurial spirit. Finally, crucially, we need to support SMEs and micro-enterprises by enshrining the ‘think small first’ principle in our law making.  I was particularly pleased to see that the Parliament voted in favour of that today. As a cross-cutting issue, this report also states that we need to support disadvantaged groups, marginalised groups, be these people with disabilities or younger or older workers, to access decent work.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: – Mr President, I voted against this report because it offers old recipes which we already know do not work, which only create insecurity, instability, labour poverty and inequality.  When we talk about mobility, mobility means emigration, it means that more and more people have to take their bags and leave their country forever. Is that the solution? Can that be the ultimate solution to unemployment? Is it the solution to unemployment that the regions most affected by the crisis lose that hard-to-form human capital? When we talk about flexibility, we are talking about temporary employment, part-hours, instability, precariousness. The problem is not that our citizens are not flexible enough, that they do not have sufficient training, that they are not employed enough. The problem is that we are destroying employment, that we are destroying public investment and we need a radical shift in the economic policies of the European Union.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Dear colleagues, i would like to thank you very much for your work. Given Europe's difficult demographic situation in the ageing population, the only way to develop the economy is to increase productivity. Ambitious reforms are needed to increase productivity. There is a need to stimulate innovation, to strengthen social dialogue, to stimulate the creation of new jobs, to worker mobility, etc. I fully support the proposals made in this report.  Colleagues! With a view to a competitive European labour market, we first need to make a prediction: what will be the technological opportunities, how demand in the labour market will change, what new professions could in principle emerge, what will disappear and what new services might be emerging. Knowing the challenges of the future, we can adapt to them the education, social and transport systems, stimulate innovation and strengthen social dialogue. It is therefore absolutely necessary for the European Parliament to demand that the European Commission act more actively in this direction. Thank you!

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted against this report because I do not consider "competition" to be the remedy for the problems of work in the 21st century. On the contrary, individualism in industrial relations and workers' consciences is the cause of the profound degradation of conquered rights, from the subordination of society to market laws.  The restricted framework proposed to us offers opportunities for improvement: for example in active employment policies. But these policies are fringed when the goal of full quality employment in public policy is abandoned.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. The aim of this report is to take stock of European employment policies in order to find the appropriate solutions that will reduce the unemployment rate without attacking social protection systems. The rapporteur expresses his willingness to tackle the youth and senior unemployment rate and the strong regional disparities.   To this end, they recommend putting in place measures to encourage the unemployed to find a job, to improve the skills of employees, to anticipate the needs of companies, to encourage apprenticeships, to encourage employment of young people and seniors and to develop entrepreneurship.  The guideline of the text is to defend the mobility of employees within the EU to reduce regional disparities in unemployment. As usual, they do not address the roots of structural unemployment, namely unfair international competition, the loss of monetary and legislative sovereignty, and the reduction of fiscal room for manoeuvre. The only path that has been taken by the European authorities so far has been that of competitive disinflation, characterized by lower social charges and a slowdown in wages.    So I voted against it.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I do not believe that the measures contained in this report will have the desired effect; furthermore, it maintains the fiction of a ‘European labour market’, despite the individual needs of 28 diverse nations.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 EU unemployment remains one of the main challenges: in December 2014, the EU's unemployment rate was 1.5% higher than in December 2014. unemployment rate in the EU was 9.9%. Addressing this problem requires ambitious economic policy and labour market reforms that promote smart, sustainable and inclusive growth and create more jobs to tackle distortions in the EU labour market. I agree with the need for reforms that increase the flexibility of the labour market and a person's career, improve the matching of skills and jobs, including greater interaction between education systems and businesses. There is a need to ensure better integration of young people, women and older workers, as well as skilled migrants into the labour market. Investments must be used to actively support job creation and employability. Particular attention should be paid to the importance of continuing education and training in order to create a competitive EU labour market and to promote growth and employment.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. The proposed solution? Opening our borders ever more to the four winds of globalization.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I supported this report and would like to thank my groupmate Martina for her excellent document. Unlike my group, I voted in favour of a paragraph which refers to the establishment of a European minimum wage. I hope that in the future a proposal in this regard will be able to be put on the Commission's agenda.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This report on the creation of a competitive labour market in the 21st century Union aims to take stock of the policies followed in order to make the labour market more competitive while trying to preserve the social protection system.  It is obvious that these two objectives are naturally contradictory, since the more the European Union encourages states to be competitive, the more citizens see their social protection melt like snow in the sun. The report also deplores the high level of unemployment in the EU, particularly among young people and the elderly, but the proposed reform options are criticised and unsymormical. Worse still, this report promotes worker mobility when it is known that it threatens the peripheral countries of the euro area. So I voted against it.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. I have voted against the report. The whole report focuses on flexibility and mobility. According to the report, unemployment is more about the unemployed and mobility. There is no recognition of the EU's own austerity policies as a major cause of mass unemployment. The report also shows a lack of respect for the role of the trade union movement in the labour market. That is why I voted against.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I absolutely do not agree with the positions expressed in this report, which in no way addresses the reality of the situation and skilfully avoids analysing the real causes of the economic crisis and the labour market not only in Italy, but throughout Europe, for which it proposes completely unrealistic solutions, which is why I voted against it.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. 2012 Tackding the unemployment drama is one of the biggest challenges facing the EU. An unemployment rate of 9.5% (with huge divergences between Member States: Germany, 4.7% compared to Spain, 22.2%) and a youth unemployment rate that doubles overall reveals the devastating effects of the crisis on the labour market.  Unfortunately, this report burdens much of the responsibilities of this dramatic situation on the unemployed and does not sufficiently accentuate the need to correct serious labour market defects such as increased forced temporary labour, labour poverty or long-term unemployment. For all this, I voted against it.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on the report on the creation of a competitive Labour market in the European Union in the 21st century and the adaptation of skills and qualifications to demand and job opportunities in order to recover from the crisis. As a result of the European economic and financial crisis and its economic slowdown, many Member States are facing high unemployment rates (9.8% in the EU-28) and public debt, weak economic growth and insufficient investment. Parliament is concerned that in many Member States the youth unemployment rate (20.9% in the EU-28) is much higher, while cases of improvement and lower unemployment are rare. Parliament believes that ambitious economic and social policy and labour market reforms are needed, as well as economically sustainable welfare systems, which include, among other things, the qualifications of the unemployed, the employability of people who are not qualified or who are very low qualified. Parliament proposes to strengthen the existing EU skills panorama in order to better identify skills gaps and weaknesses in specific sectors, occupations and regions, and to ensure that information on changing skills needs is collected, managed and disseminated to decision-makers and public authorities, education and training providers and employers, in order to anticipate future trends more effectively.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 Today, many studies conclude that automation will cause a significant number of existing jobs to disappear or decrease significantly in volume in the future. At the same time, there are significant job creation opportunities in the creation of the Digital Single Market, the construction of the Energy Union, investment in research and development, innovation and the development of transport networks.  It is also necessary to strengthen the employment of those who are not at all or have very low qualifications, including support for persons with disabilities by improving working conditions and conditions, by introducing and supporting appropriate and effective incentives. In order to re-introduce citizens who have been out of work for several years into the world of work, specific employability improvement programmes should be developed and applied. A financial and economic structure should be established that favours continued participation in education and training, including the increasing number of people with disabilities through ageing, who need unhindered access, including reasonable adaptation, in such a way as to ensure that future workers will be highly skilled.  In order to forecast future skills needs, labour market players, including employers' and workers' organisations, as well as industry players at the forefront of IT and robotics developments, should be closely involved at all levels. I voted in favour of the report on the creation of a competitive EU labour market in the 21st century.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 Economic and employment data still present an extremely heterogeneous picture at European level and in the various regional areas, with strong critical points, particularly in the field of youth unemployment. With this resolution, which I support, Parliament wants to highlight the importance of decisive action, both by the Member States and by the Commission, aimed at implementing policies and reforms that will make the European labour market competitive and the professional profiles of our citizens competitive. Ambitious reforms are needed, such as those implemented in Italy, for example, to get a situation that has been severely compromised by the crisis back on track. Among the main points highlighted in the resolution are: strengthening the links between education and employment, the importance of continuing training, the constant updating of training courses in order to keep pace with innovation and digitalisation. At European level, we also encourage the Commission to take the initiative to simplify and facilitate labour mobility, thus increasing opportunities for citizens and the match between supply and demand for labour. By enhancing and developing, for example, the rapid recognition of formal qualifications, and by standardising the European framework for the certification of qualifications and competences.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. The aim of this report is to take stock of European employment policies in order to find the appropriate solutions that will reduce the unemployment rate without attacking social protection systems. The rapporteur expresses his willingness to tackle the youth and senior unemployment rate and the strong regional disparities.  To this end, they recommend putting in place measures to encourage the unemployed to find a job, to improve the skills of employees, to anticipate the needs of companies, to encourage apprenticeships, to encourage employment of young people and seniors and to develop entrepreneurship. The guideline of the text is to defend the mobility of employees within the EU to reduce regional disparities in unemployment. As usual, they do not address the roots of structural unemployment, namely unfair international competition, the loss of monetary and legislative sovereignty, and the reduction of fiscal room for manoeuvre. The only path that has been taken by the European authorities so far has been that of competitive disinflation, characterized by lower social charges and a slowdown in wages.   So I voted against this text

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 Unemployment is a social problem with serious economic implications, a problem that the Member States of the Union face. There are around 2 million jobs for which qualified people cannot be found, and the youth unemployment rate reaches 21.4%. The European labour market poses certain challenges, with strong segmentation, skills mismatches, low labour mobility, as well as problems caused by demographic ageing and technological advances that generate new demands on the highly skilled workforce.  It is therefore necessary to develop coherent economic policies on the labour market in order to foster better integration of young people, women and older workers, and it is necessary to actively support job creation through investment, as well as training and retraining programmes for the unemployed to ensure a correlation between existing skills and demand in the labour market. I was in favour of this report because I believe that a joint effort is needed to reduce the unemployment rate, and a long-term strategy is needed in conjunction with immediate measures to adapt education systems at all levels, particularly at the level of vocational training, to the needs and demands of the labour market.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against. Compendium of praise for EU economic recipes. According to these sorcerer's apprentices, a ILVA worker left at home could convert into an aeronautical engineer, and be sent to Poland if there were any shortages.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. The main consequences of the economic and financial crisis are low growth and a considerable increase in unemployment in Europe. We are in a Union without borders where the labour market is totally open. European citizens are free to move, settle and work in all Member States. We must therefore find a common solution to the problem of unemployment by creating a more competitive labour market. The challenges facing workers are not the same as they were 20 years ago. We must both make progress in terms of flexibility and security in the European labour market. I was also able to reiterate my position in favour of the introduction of a minimum wage in all European Member States. I see this as a first step in the fight against social dumping. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the creation of a competitive labour market in the EU for the 21st century, focusing on adapting skills and qualifications according to demand and employment prospects. Unemployment, and in particular long-term unemployment, is in fact having a negative impact on economic growth and the sustainability of social security systems. In addition, labour market rigidities and the absence of domestic demand and investment are having a negative impact on job creation. At a time when the demand for low-skilled workers is falling, while the demand for highly qualified workers is rapidly increasing, it is therefore essential to intervene in workers' skills and in initial and vocational training. That is why, as the report states, the current European overview of competences needs to be strengthened in order to identify more effectively the skills gaps affecting sectors, occupations and regions and to ensure that information on the evolution of the skills required is designed to enable public authorities to education bodies, and employers, to better anticipate future trends.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ The aim of this report was a better matching of skills and qualifications with demand and job opportunities: the measures proposed to reach this aim were mainly labour market reforms to increase flexibility and mobility. Thus, while the report mentions the need to improve existing training programmes and vocational training, considering the different experiences of EU countries, as well as anticipating future skills, it also treats unemployment as a frictional matter whose fault lies on the insufficient mobility or motivation of workers – for whom strengthened irresponsibility and entrepreneurial education are prescribed. Trade Unions are only mentioned as ‘employee’s organisations’ and all the measures are organised around the ‘needs’ of the market. Causes of unemployment are individualised and workers faulted, while, in contrast, employers are to be provided with a great variety of incentives. As this was very much a market orientated approach as opposed to a citizen approach, I voted against this report.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ The economic slowdown brought with it a high level of unemployment, notably youth unemployment and public debt. The report sets forth the idea that additional reforms will benefit and expand the labour market together with better matching skills. Hence, it will significantly achieve a competitive labour market and also provide benefits to a new generation of Europeans.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report by my colleague takes up all the main aspects of the issue. It recalls the need to facilitate flexibility as a greater capacity to bring together labour supply and demand; reference is made to the need to take action against groups such as young people, the elderly and women and to prepare workers for continuous learning. Furthermore, the mobility and further development of EURES is encouraged in order to facilitate it. I voted in favour of it out of my favour.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 It is acceptable to all that, in the wake of the European economic crisis and the resulting economic slowdown, some Member States face high levels of unemployment (EU-28-9.9%) as well as public debt, low growth and insufficient investment. It is noted that youth unemployment rates in the EU (EU-28-20.9%) is particularly high and does not improve the situation. Thus, in order to consolidate a competitive EU economy and labour market, there is a great need to focus on innovation and digitisation and, therefore, on ensuring the necessary knowledge and skills as well as the incentives and determination of workers to create innovative products and services. This is the only way to address the new challenges in the labour market and the creation of new jobs.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the creation of a competitive labour market in the EU. Unemployment remains one of the Union's main challenges with a rate of 9.9% in December 2014 with significant differences between Member States. Youth employment averaged 21.4% across the Union. Having a competitive labour market requires reforms that increase the flexibility of the labour market and personal careers and foster a better match between skills and jobs, including stronger synergies between education systems and businesses and a flexible approach to working life. The report stresses the importance of labour mobility and calls for greater awareness of jobs at EU level through programmes such as EURES and Erasmus+. Finally, we need to invest in innovation and digitalisation and training and retraining programmes for the unemployed.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because, given the effects of the crisis that has hit and is still affecting labour markets, the reforms and amendments issued by the European Union are necessary to lift the European economy. I am convinced that combating unemployment must be one of the main objectives of the European Union's policies, especially for youth unemployment, which hits Spain strongly at 23.7% and on average does not fall below 9.9%, which is of great concern and which, thanks to the measures suggested, could improve. In addition, these reforms are necessary to increase the flexibility of both markets and people.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. In the aftermath of the European economic and financial crisis, unemployment remains one of the EU's greatest challenges, and continues to present high levels, especially in younger classes. Ambitious economic and social policies are therefore needed in the labour market, alongside those already taken by the EU and Member States, which foster smart, sustainable and inclusive growth and generate jobs and quality jobs. I support the Dlabajová Report for calling for careful attention to this problem, warning of the need to integrate young people, women and older people into the labour market, stressing the importance of continuing education and training for achieving a competitive growth-generating labour market, stressing the importance of sharing best practices between Member States and stressing the importance of innovation and digital transition. The importance of training and requalification programmes for the unemployed, which should be designed and implemented in order to improve the alignment of workers' new skills and labour market needs, should be stressed.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. Although there are some signs of recovery, the effects of the economic crisis on the labour market continue to be a negative variable that can hinder the creation of new jobs. In particular, unemployment remains one of the EU's main challenges: in December 2014 there was a rate of 9.9%, with significant differences between Member States (4.8% in Germany compared to 23.7% in Spain), and youth unemployment rates represented more than double to 21.4% across the Union. In the European Union, there are around 2 million jobs vacant that cannot be filled due to the asymmetry of skills in the labour market and insufficient labour mobility, so we need economic policies and ambitious reforms to overcome distortions in the EU labour market. I therefore believe that reforms should be made that increase the flexibility of the labour market and personal careers, promoting a better match between skills and jobs and promoting stronger synergies between education systems and businesses. In order to achieve these objectives, it will be essential to plan concrete investments that will facilitate the transition from education to the world of work through professional mobility programmes, with more integrated partnerships between institutions, businesses and relevant authorities.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted against this report because I do not consider "competition" to be the remedy for the problems of work in the 21st century. On the contrary, individualism in industrial relations and workers' consciences is the cause of the profound degradation of conquered rights, from the subordination of society to market laws.  The restricted framework proposed to us offers opportunities for improvement: for example in active employment policies. But these policies are fringed when the goal of full quality employment in public policy is abandoned.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ This annual report, which deals with the application of EU law in 2012-2013, is quite technical in nature. However, it also includes some concrete comments on a number of key issues being experienced at institutional level. It express concerns about the effects of austerity measures on the capacity of Member States’ administration and judiciary to assume their responsibility to implement EU law correctly. As I am of the opinion that austerity measures were not, and cannot be, the sole solution to any financial crisis, and as this report proves that there are effects which are more far reaching, having an impact on the implementation of EU laws, I supported Parliament’s position.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This initiative report aims to provide a better match between the abilities of young workers and labour market demands. While in Europe, youth unemployment (21.4%) is twice the European average (9.9%), two million jobs in Europe do not find takers due to a lack of match between the skills of young people and the demands of recruiters. The rapporteur proposes to increase the flexibility of workers and the market by focusing on the active participation of all the main players in the chain, which are training institutes, companies, employers' organisations and job seekers. It makes several recommendations for lifelong learning; inclusion of the unemployed and improved language learning. Particular attention is also paid to SMEs and micro-enterprises. Considering that this report goes in the right direction by pointing out the causes of unemployment, as well as the failures of the European labour market, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 In accordance with the guidelines of the European People's Party, I voted in favour of the report on the creation of a competitive EU labour market in the 21st century.  Today, many studies conclude that, as a result of automation, a significant number of existing jobs will disappear in the future or be significantly reduced quantitatively. At the same time, there are significant job creation opportunities in the creation of the Digital Single Market, the construction of the Energy Union, investment in research and development, innovation and the development of transport networks.  It is also necessary to strengthen the employment of those who are not at all or have very low qualifications, including support for persons with disabilities by improving working conditions and conditions, by introducing and supporting appropriate and effective incentives. In order to re-introduce citizens who have been out of work for several years into the world of work, specific employability improvement programmes should be developed and applied. A financial and economic structure should be established that favours continued participation in education and training, including the increasing number of people with disabilities through ageing, who need unhindered access, including reasonable adaptation, in such a way as to ensure that future workers will be highly skilled.  In order to forecast future skills needs, labour market players, including employers' and workers' organisations, as well as industry players at the forefront of IT and robotics developments, should be closely involved at all levels.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. I voted in this report because it proposes a number of necessary reforms to help create a more competitive European labour market. In Europe, unemployment remains one of our most important challenges. At the end of last year, 24 million Europeans were unemployed. Of these millions, 11.9 million were long-term unemployed and 5 million were under the age of 25. Job creation is a top priority. Unfortunately, despite some signs of economic recovery, it is still too slow and laborious. The labour market needs to be reformed in several Member States and structural reforms must be pursued, as must training efforts, strengthening synergies between education systems and businesses and stimulating entrepreneurship.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. – In accordance with the guidelines of the European People's Party, I voted in favour of the report on the creation of a competitive EU labour market in the 21st century.  Today, many studies conclude that, as a result of automation, a significant number of existing jobs will disappear in the future or be significantly reduced quantitatively. At the same time, there are significant job creation opportunities in the creation of the Digital Single Market, the construction of the Energy Union, investment in research and development, innovation and the development of transport networks.  It is also necessary to strengthen the employment of those who are not at all or have very low qualifications, including support for persons with disabilities by improving working conditions and conditions, by introducing and supporting appropriate and effective incentives. In order to re-introduce citizens who have been out of work for several years into the world of work, specific employability improvement programmes should be developed and applied. A financial and economic structure should be established that favours continued participation in education and training, including the increasing number of people with disabilities through ageing, who need unhindered access, including reasonable adaptation, in such a way as to ensure that future workers will be highly skilled.  In order to forecast future skills needs, labour market players, including employers' and workers' organisations, as well as industry players at the forefront of IT and robotics developments, should be closely involved at all levels.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. The report is built from the outset on a mistake, that of believing that there is a European labour market while Member States have different social, wage and economic practices in this area. It is true that the mobility of the labour factor is low in the Union, but this cannot be solved by employment policies. It is indeed a structural barrier that separates national markets, that of language and the organisation of work. Despite the detachment of workers directive which has created unbearable situations of social dumping, European workers cannot move from one national market to another. Worse still, this report seems to draw a very broad labour market, since it would be to open it up to non-European workers. The intensification of the free movement of workers to the Union and the Union is not the solution to unemployment, it is one of the drivers. Opposed to ultra-liberalism without borders, I voted against this text.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We are voting against because we are against mobility which will turn the weak countries of the Union into dead economic zones.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ unemployment is still a major problem for the European Union. In particular, youth unemployment, which is really alarming in some Member States, because in Spain, for example, more than 21% of people are out of work. These high figures can, on the one hand, be described as the result of the economic crisis, but the problem is that, according to several studies, more than 2 million jobs are vacant in Europe, which employers are unable to fill due to labour market mismatches and a lack of labour mobility. There are also other problems, such as labour market segmentation, the presence of skills mismatches on the labour market, along with the increasing share of long-term unemployment. Reforms are needed to create a competitive labour market that will increase labour market and career flexibility and improve consistency between skills and jobs, including greater synergies between education systems and businesses.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 Wrong recipes that have led to the stagnation of the crisis as well as the praise of the economic recipes that support the single currency. Congratulations.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 In accordance with the guidelines of the European People's Party, I voted in favour of the report on the creation of a competitive EU labour market in the 21st century.  Today, many studies conclude that, as a result of automation, a significant number of existing jobs will disappear in the future or be significantly reduced quantitatively. At the same time, there are significant job creation opportunities in the creation of the Digital Single Market, the construction of the Energy Union, investment in research and development, innovation and the development of transport networks.  It is also necessary to strengthen the employment of those who are not at all or have very low qualifications, including support for persons with disabilities by improving working conditions and conditions, by introducing and supporting appropriate and effective incentives. In order to re-introduce citizens who have been out of work for several years into the world of work, specific employability improvement programmes should be developed and applied. A financial and economic structure should be established that favours continued participation in education and training, including the increasing number of people with disabilities through ageing, who need unhindered access, including reasonable adaptation, in such a way as to ensure that future workers will be highly skilled.  In order to forecast future skills needs, labour market players, including employers' and workers' organisations, as well as industry players at the forefront of IT and robotics developments, should be closely involved at all levels.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: in writing. \u2012 This report outlines the reforms needed to create a competitive labour market. In order to promote a better match between skills and jobs, these should aim to create better integration of young people through policies that develop synergies between school-university education and business. Added to this is the interest in the skilled workforce brought about by migrants. In order to achieve this, we must invest to support job creation and, at the same time, we must succeed in preventing the impoverishment of skills both among the unemployed and among those who no longer seek work precisely because they are disillusioned. One thing I think is positive is that professional life is seen as an evolving path, which therefore allows workers to be more flexible and adapt to changes in the labour market through continuous learning, which enables them to acquire new knowledge and skills. Finally, the report stresses the importance of labour mobility and, consequently, encourages language education, the Erasmus+ programme and the greater development of EURES. I voted in favour.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: Written. \u2012 The competitiveness and well-adapted of the EU labour market for a modern and changing labour market is crucial for the future competitiveness of the EU. This own-initiative report, by a rapporteur from the ALDE Group, was therefore extremely welcome. Calls for training to be closer to the labour market, to ensure that there is mobility in the labour market and a reduction in the tax burden on labour are important and necessary measures that I support.  However, as a Center Party artist and defender of the Swedish model, I could not support paragraph 106 on a European framework for minimum wages. This is something that the social partners in Sweden should deal with, and I therefore voted against that proposal. Through split votes on paragraph 106, it was the case that in the final vote, the issue of minimum wages was considered to be something that should be dealt with in accordance with national practice, which I believe to be to leave the matter to the social partners. That is why I voted in favour of the report because its proposal would represent a radical improvement in the European labour market, which in turn would lead to increased growth and help europe to emerge from the economic crisis.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. Unemployment remains one of the biggest challenges in the EU, with a rate of 9.9 % in December 2014, with very substantial disparities at this level between Member States (4.8 % in Germany, compared to 23.7% in Spain). Youth unemployment rates are more than double, reaching 21.4% at EU level. On the other hand, there are around 2 million jobs in the EU unfilled, due to both skills inadequate needs and the lack of mobility of workers. To tackle this problem, strong partnerships between governments and representatives of employers and workers are needed to find the best solutions to address skills inadequacy to labour market needs in all its dimensions. Member States themselves should share best practices and learn from them, and support initiatives that foster job creation and entrepreneurship, with particular emphasis on SMEs and micro-enterprises as the backbone of the EU labour market.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the mobility that turns the weak countries of the Union into economically dead zones.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ Unemployment continues to be one of the main challenges in the EU, especially among young people. The unemployment rate is still alarming, as well as the significant differences of unemployment rates between Member States. I agree on the emphasis given to the need to achieve a competitive labour market, to the implementation of reforms that can increase labour market and personal career flexibility, to the better matching of skills and jobs, including stronger synergies between education systems and labour markets. The issue of the skills mismatches, however, should not hide the real problems of the labour markets, the need to fight precarious employment and social inequalities, to invest in human capital in order to prepare the labour markets for the future and to foster a comprehensive approach regarding labour mobility, based on the free movement of citizens and workers and the principle of equal pay for equal work. The notion of self-responsibility of the unemployed persons and the call for more flexible labour markets must be counterbalanced with social protection for workers and unemployed people.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. \u2012 In accordance with the guidelines of the European People's Party, I voted in favour of the report on the creation of a competitive EU labour market in the 21st century.  Today, many studies conclude that, as a result of automation, a significant number of existing jobs will disappear in the future or be significantly reduced quantitatively. At the same time, there are significant job creation opportunities in the creation of the Digital Single Market, the construction of the Energy Union, investment in research and development, innovation and the development of transport networks.  It is also necessary to strengthen the employment of those who are not at all or have very low qualifications, including support for persons with disabilities by improving working conditions and conditions, by introducing and supporting appropriate and effective incentives. In order to re-introduce citizens who have been out of work for several years into the world of work, specific employability improvement programmes should be developed and applied. A financial and economic structure should be established that favours continued participation in education and training, including the increasing number of people with disabilities through ageing, who need unhindered access, including reasonable adaptation, in such a way as to ensure that future workers will be highly skilled.  In order to forecast future skills needs, labour market players, including employers' and workers' organisations, as well as industry players at the forefront of IT and robotics developments, should be closely involved at all levels.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. Unemployment remains one of the biggest challenges in the European Union.  Statistics show that the economic and financial crisis is still having an impact. While there are signs of a re-emergement, the labour market has steadily tightened in recent years and the creation of new jobs is also slow.  I therefore welcome the ambitious economic policies and labour market reforms aimed at smart, sustainable and inclusive growth and boosting job creation. The report underlines the need for reforms to increase flexibility in the labour market and career change and to align skills with job opportunities, while strengthening synergies between education systems and businesses in order to create a competitive labour market. I support the report's particular focus on continuous education and training, as it is of great importance in creating a competitive EU labour market, leading to growth and employment improvements.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the 'Report on the creation of a competitive EU labour market for the 21st century: adapting skills and skills to demand and employment opportunities as a way to overcome the crisis', as I share the desire to strengthen the 'labour market' in Europe. At the same time, I stress that this must not be at the expense of tried and tested models such as the German Master Letter.

name: Juan Carlos GIRAUTA VIDAL
text: in writing. ‒ It cannot be denied that unemployment remains one of Europe’s most pertinent challenges. At the end of 2014, 24 million Europeans were without employment. In Spain, the employment rate stands at 22.2%. Therefore, I gave my support to this report today as it places the creation of jobs as a complete priority while stresses the ongoing need for labour market reforms, to teach young people the necessary skills to build their future and the encourage needed to foster entrepreneurship.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. The objective of this report was to better adapt skills and qualifications to demand and employment prospects as a means of recovering from the crisis. However, we voted against it because we believe that the way in which skills and qualifications are addressed is wrong and will deepen and time unemployment. The main problem of the report is its approach, according to which labour market reforms are, especially to increase flexibility and mobility, the solution and the measures necessary to achieve the above objective. While on the one hand the report mentions the need to improve existing vocational training and training programmes, taking into account the different experiences of EU countries - as well as the foresight of future skills - the document treats unemployment as a problem of lack of mobility or worker motivation. It is with this logic of blaming the worker that the report recommends measures to strengthen the responsibility and "entrepreneurial" education of the unemployed without understanding the problem at the structural and systemic level.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ The European Parliamentary Labour Party voted in favour of this report. We voted for a competitive EU labour market for the 21st century that will foster continuous education and training, especially for the most vulnerable groups in our society. This is will have a particularly important impact in the North West, and in order to guarantee this progress we called on the EU to invest in the North West region’s talents, skills and abilities to combat unemployment and provide wider access to high-quality jobs.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 In accordance with the guidelines of the European People's Party, I voted in favour of the report on the creation of a competitive EU labour market in the 21st century.  Today, many studies conclude that, as a result of automation, a significant number of existing jobs will disappear in the future or be significantly reduced quantitatively. At the same time, there are significant job creation opportunities in the creation of the Digital Single Market, the construction of the Energy Union, investment in research and development, innovation and the development of transport networks.  It is also necessary to strengthen the employment of those who are not at all or have very low qualifications, including support for persons with disabilities by improving working conditions and conditions, by introducing and supporting appropriate and effective incentives. In order to re-introduce citizens who have been out of work for several years into the world of work, specific employability improvement programmes should be developed and applied. A financial and economic structure should be established that favours participation in continuous education and training in a way that ensures that future workers will be highly qualified.  In order to forecast future skills needs, labour market players, including employers' and workers' organisations, as well as industry players at the forefront of IT and robotics developments, should be closely involved at all levels.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. The objective of this report was to better adapt skills and qualifications to demand and employment prospects as a means of recovering from the crisis. However, we voted against it because we believe that the way in which skills and qualifications are addressed is wrong and will deepen and time unemployment. The main problem of the report is its approach, according to which labour market reforms are, especially to increase flexibility and mobility, the solution and the measures necessary to achieve the above objective. While on the one hand the report mentions the need to improve existing vocational training and training programmes, taking into account the different experiences of EU countries - as well as the foresight of future skills - the document treats unemployment as a problem of lack of mobility or worker motivation. It is with this logic of blaming the worker that the report recommends measures to strengthen the responsibility and "entrepreneurial" education of the unemployed without understanding the problem at the structural and systemic level.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ We should focus on bringing education, training and labour markets together. The S&D group puts the fight against precarious employment and social inequalities on top of its agenda. We believe in the free movement of citizens and workers and the principle of equal pay for equal work. The investment in human capital is a must and this is important in order to prepare the labour markets for the future and to foster a comprehensive approach regarding labour mobility.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a European Parliament resolution to create a competitive EU labour market for the 21st century: aligning skills and qualifications with demand and job opportunities as a way of recovering from the crisis, as serious labour market and economic policy reforms are needed for the European Union to deliver inclusive, smart and sustainable growth and bridge the effects of the economic and financial crisis.  In this context, rapid adaptation and exploitation of new technologies, greater synergies between education systems, exchange of good practices and strong encouragement of entrepreneurship, self-employment and SMEs are needed. I believe this can create a labour market that will be competitive and sustainable globally.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. The aim of this report is to take stock of European employment policies in order to find the appropriate solutions that will reduce the unemployment rate without attacking social protection systems. The rapporteur expresses his willingness to tackle the youth and senior unemployment rate and the strong regional disparities.  To this end, they recommend putting in place measures to encourage the unemployed to find a job, to improve the skills of employees, to anticipate the needs of companies, to encourage apprenticeships, to encourage employment of young people and seniors and to develop entrepreneurship. The guideline of the text is to defend the mobility of employees within the EU to reduce regional disparities in unemployment. As usual, they do not address the roots of structural unemployment, namely unfair international competition, the loss of monetary and legislative sovereignty, and the reduction of fiscal room for manoeuvre. The only path that has been taken by the European authorities so far has been that of competitive disinflation, characterized by lower social charges and a slowdown in wages.   So I voted against it.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Dlabajova report on the creation of a competitive labour market in the 21st century Union. I believe that the fight against unemployment must remain at the top of the European Union's priorities. In accordance with the principle of subsidiarity and in order for the demand for work to correspond to the supply, I share the tracks developed in the report, particularly in the direction of vocational training or in terms of language teaching.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's resolution to create a more competitive market in the EU in the 21st century because, in view of the situation and the employment issues currently facing Europe, it is necessary to promote the competitiveness of the European market, to strengthen the links between education and employment, the exchange of best practices between Member States , to develop entrepreneurship from an early age, to reduce the lack of skilled labour and finally to develop new skills and jobs, especially in the field of new technologies.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. The report highlights the problems that arise in purely national labour markets. But the proposed solutions are aimed at more state, even though more competition and competitiveness are being pointed out at the same time. Moreover, the report takes little account of the separation of national and European competences. I therefore reject this report.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, as it stresses that for achieving a competitive labour market, reforms are needed in order to increase labour market and personal career flexibility, better matching of skills and jobs, including stronger synergies between education systems and labour markets.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 In accordance with the guidelines of the European People's Party, I voted in favour of the report on the creation of a competitive EU labour market in the 21st century.  Today, many studies conclude that, as a result of automation, a significant number of existing jobs will disappear in the future or be significantly reduced quantitatively. At the same time, there are significant job creation opportunities in the creation of the Digital Single Market, the construction of the Energy Union, investment in research and development, innovation and the development of transport networks.  It is also necessary to strengthen the employment of those who are not at all or have very low qualifications, including support for persons with disabilities by improving working conditions and conditions, by introducing and supporting appropriate and effective incentives. In order to re-introduce citizens who have been out of work for several years into the world of work, specific employability improvement programmes should be developed and applied. A financial and economic structure should be established that favours continued participation in education and training, including the increasing number of people with disabilities through ageing, who need unhindered access, including reasonable adaptation, in such a way as to ensure that future workers will be highly skilled.  In order to forecast future skills needs, labour market players, including employers' and workers' organisations, as well as industry players at the forefront of IT and robotics developments, should be closely involved at all levels.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted against this report because I do not consider "competition" to be the remedy for the problems of work in the 21st century. On the contrary, individualism in industrial relations and workers' consciences is the cause of the profound degradation of conquered rights, from the subordination of society to market laws.  The restricted framework proposed to us offers opportunities for improvement: for example in active employment policies. But these policies are fringed when the goal of full quality employment in public policy is abandoned.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. U2012 In view of the number of unemployed in the European Union; that due to automation, many jobs will disappear within a few years; of the discrepancy between the requirements of the sector, skills and occupation which makes the qualification of workers not always correspond to the job offer; and that the rigidity of the labour market does not correspond to the mobility of European workers; a report detailing the needs and possible means of addressing them is absolutely necessary. In this regard, Member States are requested to ensure market reforms that advance gender equality and the inclusion of labour market-vulnerable groups, and to invest in child education in foreign languages and information technologies. The importance of automation as a trend should also be taken into account, which may diminish the quantitative importance of many work. That is why I am in favour of this report.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Unemployment continues to be one of the Union's main challenges. While there are some signs of recovery, the labour market has been shrinking in recent years and job opportunities remain low. Ambitious economic policies and labour market reforms are needed to foster smart, sustainable and inclusive growth and create new jobs that enable quality and sustainable employment. There are several challenges affecting the European labour market, including globalisation, ageing societies, rapid technological change, skills and jobs mismatches and increasing demand for highly skilled workers, while there is a surplus of supply from low-skilled workers. The report highlights the importance of social investment and recalls the need for geographical and cross-sectoral labour mobility. The role of educational institutions for skills development is very important. It underlines the importance of support and incentive measures for SMEs that are the backbone of the EU economy. I supported Dlabajova's report, as I believe it is necessary to constantly work on linking education, training and the labour market at all levels and fostering smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. Creating jobs in Europe requires a holistic approach that reflects labour market needs, supporting vulnerable groups by improving working conditions and providing incentives.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: writing – The biggest employment problem in the EU is the long-term problem of youth unemployment, which currently stands at an average of 21.4%, despite two million job vacancies. In addition to the lack of mobility, this is mainly due to a mismatch between the required and offered work skills and qualifications. Education and education are underrepresented to the labour market demand, which is causing high unemployment among young people with untapped qualifications. Changes in this area are happening relatively slowly, and as the labour market is subject to rapid changes, the disparity in the skills required and offered may be exacerbated. That is why the Union, in cooperation with the Member States, must urgently analyse the labour market situation and take flexible measures in the fields of education, education and training in order to reverse this unfavourable situation.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 As I said in my speech on 9/9/2015 in the plenary of the European Parliament, in order to create a competitive labour market, a direct correlation between education, training and the labour market is needed. More public and private investment is needed. Investment in innovative sectors and strengthening of social services are needed. But first of all, we need to stop austerity and erase the shameful debt that is the main source of poverty and unemployment in the European Union.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this text! It starts from the wrong observation: unemployment is, according to its author, due to a problem of mobility of people, who do not know how to move where there is work. Reading them, more mobility would miraculously reduce unemployment. Moreover, this text implies that citizens must adapt to the digital economy when the opposite should happen! This project prepares us for a change in migration policy, in order to open up the labour market to non-European citizens.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing.
