The EU needs ambitious economic policies and labour market reforms to drive smart, sustainable and inclusive growth, as well as to create more jobs to overcome distortions in the EU labour market. In plenary, we have adopted a report on the need to adapt skills and qualifications to demand and employment prospects as a means of recovering from the crisis, with a view to creating a competitive labour market in the EU of the 21st century. My support for this work, which advocates reforms to increase the flexibility of the labour market and career, as well as to achieve better correspondence between skills and jobs, including stronger synergies between education systems and businesses.  Investments need to be used to actively support job creation and job insertion capacity, as well as to prevent the decline in skills of the unemployed. In addition, a flexible approach to professional life is needed so that workers can adapt to change and be prepared for continuous training.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. Although there are good points that indicate that SMEs are very important in and for Europe, the report points to the problems that arise in purely national labour markets, but the solutions proposed are in a very etatistic tradition, although it always invokes the importance of competition, competitiveness and skills. It also does not make a clear distinction between the EU and national competences, where labour market measures fall. I therefore reject this report.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The aim of this report is to take stock of European employment policies in order to find the appropriate solutions that will reduce the unemployment rate without attacking social protection systems. The rapporteur expresses his willingness to tackle the youth and senior unemployment rate and the strong regional disparities.  To this end, they recommend putting in place measures to encourage the unemployed to find a job, to improve the skills of employees, to anticipate the needs of companies, to encourage apprenticeships, to encourage employment of young people and seniors and to develop entrepreneurship. The guideline of the text is to defend the mobility of employees within the EU to reduce regional disparities in unemployment. As usual, they do not address the roots of structural unemployment, namely unfair international competition, the loss of monetary and legislative sovereignty, and the reduction of fiscal room for manoeuvre. The only path that has been taken by the European authorities so far has been that of competitive disinflation, characterized by lower social charges and a slowdown in wages.   I voted AGAINST.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. 'Ambitious economic and social policies and labour market reforms are needed to foster smart, sustainable and inclusive growth, as well as to create more jobs and create quality and sustainable jobs. There is also a need for sustainable social protection systems that include updating the skills of the unemployed, fostering the employability of people without qualifications or with very few qualifications, as well as incentives and job opportunities.  Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it is multifaceted in its approach and suggestions to combat the persistently high level of unemployment in the Union. The report focuses on the need to foster the necessary skills and knowhow to create innovative products or services. It also highlights several sectors with significant job creation potential that the Union needs to push ahead, particularly the digital single market and energy union. The issue of youth unemployment is another main focus of this report that underlines specific measures needed to encourage the hiring of young workers.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this report which is deeply concerned about the levels of youth unemployment in Europe and underlines in this regard the importance of dual education such as vocational training and apprenticeships in matching the skills of young people with the demands of the labour market. It calls therefore for a European benchmark on dual education which will highlight the correlation between dual education tracks and youth employment. Data for such a benchmark could be collected yearly through the Labour Force Survey and should, as a minimum, measure the amount or percentage of time spent in a company (apprenticeship) during education and the number of months after graduation before employment.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: Written. – After the financial and economic crisis of recent years, the economy is gradually re-emerging. We also see this in a cautious recovery in employment. Nevertheless, the number of young people and low-skilled workers who are not in employment remains far too high.  This ALDE report sets out concrete policy proposals to eliminate the causes of these high unemployment rates. To do this, structural reforms need to be implemented. The support of young unemployed people should be organised in such a way that young people take their place in the labour market as quickly as possible. In this rapidly changing world of increasing globalisation, digitisation and new technologies, new synergies between education and business can help to better reconcile the gap between the supply of skills among young people and the increasing demand for highly skilled workers. In this way, young people are better prepared for the labour market. Small and medium-sized enterprises are the backbone of Europe's economy. It is advisable to stimulate entrepreneurship by enrolling entrepreneurship classes in the learning programmes. By investing in innovation and new economic sectors and education as a priority, we can accurately anticipate any evolution of future skills needs in the labour market.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted against this report because I am not in agreement with the text of the proposal.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 According to the report, it is important to support self-employment and entrepreneurship initiatives for SMEs and micro-enterprises. Measures are needed to support the finding of skilled workers and the training of prospective workers, as well as measures to encourage entrepreneurs investing in vocational training and apprenticeships. The report also calls for greater emphasis on teaching leadership and entrepreneurship at an early age. It calls for innovation and digitalisation to be prioritised, with the necessary knowledge and skills to be provided and the motivation and determination of workers to create innovative products and services. It underlines that there are significant job creation opportunities in the creation of the Digital Single Market, in the construction of the Energy Union, in investment in research and development, in innovation and in the development of transport networks. It underlines the importance of training and retraining programmes for the unemployed.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that developments in the European labour market need to reflect on the skills of workers, as well as on initial and vocational training, as the demand for low-skilled workers has been decreasing and that the demand for highly skilled workers has increased considerably.  I believe that economic and social policies and labour market reforms are urgently needed to foster smart, sustainable and inclusive growth, as well as to create more quality and sustainable jobs. I would like to address the need for sustainable social protection systems, including updating the skills of the unemployed, fostering the employability of people without or with few qualifications, as well as incentives and job opportunities. I support the measures presented in the report, which are necessary for the promotion of both the hiring of young workers, including support for employers to organise internal training, and the reintegration of older workers, with the establishment of retraining facilities, the updating of the skills of these workers and adequate preparation for the challenges presented by new jobs.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This report on the creation of a competitive labour market in the 21st century Union aims to take stock of the policies followed in order to make the labour market more competitive while trying to preserve the social protection system. These are conflicting objectives, and it is not surprising that the former trumps the latter. While we deplore the high level of unemployment in the EU, particularly among young people and the elderly, as well as the disparity in the level of unemployment, the proposed reforms are criticised and unorthivable. It includes "incentives to return to work for the unemployed" reminiscent of the ultra-liberal nation of "voluntary unemployed", "developing entrepreneurship" (an entire programme), or encouraging the employment of young people and seniors... Worse, this report promotes the mobility of workers when it is now agreed (see Paul Krugman) that it threatens the peripheral countries of the euro area, which see their tax base move abroad, therefore complicating the restoration of public accounts.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ The issue of skills mismatches should not hide the real problems of the labour markets: the need to promote the creation of quality jobs, to fight precarious employment and social inequalities and achieve a labour market based on free movement of citizens and workers and the principle of equal pay for equal work.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text on the creation of a competitive labour market in the 21st century Union. This report calls for more coordination between labour market players to better match the supply and demand for employment. The aim is to foster dialogue between education systems, wage organisations and employers' organisations, with particular attention to SMEs and SMALLOs which represent the most important source of employment in Europe.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to address the European Parliament's recommendations on labour market reform to the European Commission. The effects of the crisis are still noticeable in the labour market and job creation remains weak. The EU has endorsed the objective of combating unemployment, and in particular youth unemployment. At the same time, nearly 2 million jobs remain unfilled in Europe. The report stresses the need for labour market reform to achieve greater flexibility and security to enable better adaptation of the skills of job seekers and the skills required by employers. This will require a better articulation between the academic world and the world of work. We must also focus on the opportunities represented by the EURES network, on lifelong learning, and on the promotion of language learning.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 We vote positively for this report considering that the effects of the economic and financial crisis still persist and, despite some signs of recovery, the labour market continues to lag behind and the creation of new jobs is still slow. Unemployment must therefore be one of the main challenges facing the European Union. Unemployment rates of close to 10% and 21% for young people are unacceptable, not least because the differences between Member States are particularly marked. The issue of the difficulties of meeting skills demanded and offered must not hide the real problems of the labour market: the need to combat precarious work and social inequalities and to invest in human capital, in order to prepare workers for the labour market of the future. Finally, the institutions should promote a systemic approach to work and mobility, based on the principles of the free movement of citizens and workers and the principle of equal pay for equal work, without discrimination on gender, age and geographical origin.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 Strengthening a competitive EU labour market is one of the biggest challenges we face, so I welcome this report, which foresees the coordination of spare capacities and needs. In one pan, the balance sheet has an unprecedented high unemployment rate in many countries, and on the other side there are the almost two million jobs that are simply unable to be filled in some Member States. We have already done a lot for mobility at EU level, but it seems that we need to think even more in new forms, which will also require closer cooperation between education systems and the labour market.  In my opinion, we will also need to get to the point where we can open up the issue of the EU minimum wage. While respecting the principle of subsidiarity, I believe that this should be defined as a percentage of average earnings in relation to the GDP of the Member States and the poverty line.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report that stresses reforms are needed in order to increase labour market and personal career flexibility, better matching of skills and jobs, including stronger synergies between education systems and businesses.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: in writing. – I believe that overcoming the economic crisis and creating a competitive labour market in the EU depends on several main factors. First of all, I believe that in order to achieve smart, sustainable and inclusive growth, we need to invest in education and skills, in developing talent and creating opportunities for realisation in life.  Today, however, we are in a situation where young people are increasingly struggling in the transition from education to work and are often willing to accept positions that do not qualify. That is why we need to invest in skills that keep pace with the needs of the labour market and society. Here, however, I would like to make the following clarification. Education systems should not be fully focused on stimulating skills and competences that meet the needs of business. They must, in particular, bet on building horizontal skills that are necessary for the personal development and growth of young people in order to make them proactive and responsible citizens.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I voted against the report because it risks further expansion of Brussels into national competences. In particular, the regulatory framework of the labour market is, for me, a clear national domain.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Given that 9.9% of the unemployed in the EU was unemployed in December 2014, but unemployment among young people was twice as high, and whereas at the same time around 2 million jobs are unfilled due to labour market inconsistencies and low labour mobility, it is clear that reforms are needed to help eliminate this mismatch. Contributions must be made to the organisation of the education system and to the cooperation between the education system and businesses, as well as to the maintenance of the skills of the unemployed. The suitability of skills and jobs needs to be organize and that the groups currently on the sidelines, such as the elderly, young people, immigrants, etc. must be further integrated.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – It is extremely worrying that there are 25 million unemployed in Europe, but equally worrying is that there are 2 million vacancies that are unemploymented due to the lack of qualified staff for them. It is with this paradoxical imbalance that we must overcome. We need to prepare young people for market needs from an early age. We need immediate and concrete measures to create close cooperation between educational establishments and businesses. It is also essential that digital skills become an integral part of the education system in all Member States of the European Union. I cast my vote in favour of Martina Dlabajová's report because I support the aspects it sets out.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ The effects of the economic and financial crisis continue to remain on the labour market and job creation is slow. Tackling unemployment remains one of the EU's main challenges, where rates vary significantly between Member States (Germany 4.8% compared to Spain 23.7%). Youth unemployment is almost double the eu's average unemployment rate at a high of 21.4%.  At the same time, 2 million jobs within the Union cannot be met due to labour market mismatches and insufficient labour mobility. Therefore, the report says that in order to achieve a competitive market, labour market reforms need to be implemented. In the first place, flexibility in both the labour market and the flexibility of jobseekers should be increased.  It is also necessary to find a way to better align their skills and competences with market needs, including through better cooperation between educational institutions and the right job. These are just some of the recommendations of the report, which are more than necessary in this period of high unemployment and uncertainty for young people across Europe.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. The aim of the report on the creation of a competitive labour market in the 21st century Union is to take stock of the policies followed in order to make the labour market more competitive while trying to preserve the social protection system. These are conflicting objectives, and it is not surprising that the former trumps the latter. While we deplore the high level of unemployment in the EU, particularly among young people and the elderly, as well as the disparity in the level of unemployment, the proposed reforms are criticised and unorthivable. It includes the "incentives to return to work for the unemployed" reminiscent of the ultra-liberal notion of "voluntary unemployed", or the idea that we should "develop entrepreneurship" (a whole programme)... Worse, this report promotes the mobility of workers when it is now agreed (see Paul Krugman) that it threatens the peripheral countries of the euro area, which see their tax base move abroad, therefore complicating the restoration of public accounts.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ There are significant differences between Member States on the European Union labour market in terms of occupations for which jobs cannot be filled due to a lack of skilled workers. According to the Commission, a maximum of 12.4 million people have been unemployed for more than one year and 6 million of them have been unemployed for more than two years, posing a risk to the labour market, as long-term unemployment has a negative impact on the economic growth and sustainability of social welfare systems. I support the rapporteur's proposal for the necessary skills and qualifications to match demand in order to create a competitive labour market, which require action to be taken on the labour market on workers' skills and basic and vocational training.  Labour market inflexibleness and lack of internal demand and investment have a negative impact on job creation, while a competitive Union labour market can contribute to the achievement of employment and poverty and social exclusion targets under the Europe 2020 strategy.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. - Ambitious economic and social policies and reforms are needed to achieve a competitive European Union labour market. The pillars of EU growth and development are smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. The biggest obstacle to achieving these objectives and a competitive market is the high level of unemployment.  At EU level, the unemployment rate is 9.8%, but in some Member States it reaches a high of 25%. Further concerns are caused by youth unemployment rates at EU level 20.9% and in particular in the Republic of Croatia by 43.1%.  This level of unemployment is partly due to an education system that does not teach young people the competences needed on the market, creating unfilled jobs due to a lack of the necessary skills for workers.  Education, training and the labour market at all levels need to be better linked. Another important item on the road to a competitive market is the mobility of citizens within the EU, which remains very low, despite high unemployment rates in individual Member States and unfulbed jobs in others.  Reforms, reducing existing barriers and encouraging citizens to take advantage of the opportunities provided by the EU market also need to be implemented in this field. Consequently, I support my colleague Dlabajova's report.

name: Pavel POC
text: Writing. \u2012 While the level of unemployment of the population has stabilised at relatively low levels in some countries of the European Union, there are still several countries registering a very high value for this economic indicator. The latest statistics highlighting, in particular, the level of youth unemployment in different parts of Europe show that this is not only a phenomenon occurring in southern Europe. On average, it's above 20 percent. That is why I supported some very important sub-provisions of the 2014/2235 (INI) report. In particular, there was a need for cooperation between universities and the private sphere, which should lead to a more flexible response to developments in the labour market. I also supported the role of Erasmus+. I believe that it is programmes of this type that can help the young European generation to gain the experience and knowledge valued by employers. I fully agree that SMEs are an important part of the economy. However, I cannot agree that the legislation governing it should be reduced to the detriment of workers' rights. I therefore voted against the report, which, while giving the green light to entrepreneurs, could lead to a deterioration in the working conditions of all European workers. I believe that the priority problems of the European labour market remain insufficient investment in human capital, uneven pay and lack of mobility. That is what we need to focus on now.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 In order to have a competitive labour market, reforms are needed that increase labour market flexibility and foster a better match between personal skills and jobs, including stronger synergies between the world of education and the world of work. The European Union must refine its action in favour of vocational training, particularly with regard to young unemployed people and those who have lost their jobs as a result of the effects of globalisation. The world of work is constantly looking for new skills and I believe it is essential to find the right tools to strengthen the skills of European workers.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. With an unemployment rate of 9.6% in the EU at 28, unemployment remains one of the EU's major problems. Youth unemployment is all the more worrying, reaching 21.4%. Conversely, almost 2 million jobs in the EU are not being filled because of labour market imbalances and a lack of mobile labour. With this in mind, I voted in favour of the report on the creation of a competitive labour market in the Union. In this text, Parliament encourages the Commission to implement reforms aimed at creating a more flexible labour market and a system of recognition of skills and jobs.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. Eurostat estimates that 23.067 million men and women in Europe out of 28 were unemployed in July 2015. The causes of high unemployment rates are complex and diverse, but in a crisis scenario where the labour market is particularly subject to the negative effects of economic cycles, it is also important to address the structural inefficiencies inherent in the labour market.  In this sense, the rapporteur takes into account the available statistical indicators, which point to significant distortions between workers' skills and labour market needs. Only the establishment of strong partnerships between governments and representatives of employers and workers can address such skills mismatch and help fill the 2 million jobs available in the European Union as a result of this disagreement.  Having said the above, I voted in favour of this resolution, which calls on the Member States to promote the close and systematic involvement of labour market actors (trainers and employers) so that, in a joint effort, future skills needs are anticipated.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. 2012 Tackding the unemployment drama is one of the biggest challenges facing the EU. An unemployment rate of 9.5% (with huge divergences between Member States: Germany, 4.7% compared to Spain, 22.2%) and a youth unemployment rate that doubles overall reveals the devastating effects of the crisis on the labour market.  Unfortunately, this report burdens much of the responsibilities of this dramatic situation on the unemployed and does not sufficiently accentuate the need to correct serious labour market defects such as increased forced temporary labour, labour poverty or long-term unemployment. For all this, I voted against it.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. The European Parliament was speaking today on the report on "the creation of a competitive labour market in the 21st century Union: adapting skills and qualifications to demand and employment prospects, a way out of the crisis". Many EU Member States face high levels of unemployment (9.8% for the EU28). This situation has been going on for too long and to which Europe and its Member States must find solutions.   Unfortunately, it is clear that the current revenues are not working. It is therefore important to look at the revision of our labour market. In an increasingly mobile and flexible labour market, I stress the importance of putting in place a mechanism to secure the career path of European citizens.  Finally, the report urges Member States to introduce a legal or conventional minimum wage, in accord with national practices. This request is fully supported, even though I regret that the European Parliament rejects the definition of a European reference level for this minimum wage.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour, because I am convinced that in order to have a competitive labour market it is necessary to implement reforms that aim to increase the level of flexibility in work and personal careers. It is also necessary to facilitate the encounter between job skills and jobs. Good vocational training and adequate retraining for the unemployed are the fundamental objectives for the development of a competitive and efficient labour market.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. The objective of this report was to better adapt skills and qualifications to demand and employment prospects as a means of recovering from the crisis. However, we voted against it because we believe that the way in which skills and qualifications are addressed is wrong and will deepen and time unemployment. The main problem of the report is its approach, according to which labour market reforms are, especially to increase flexibility and mobility, the solution and the measures necessary to achieve the above objective. While on the one hand the report mentions the need to improve existing vocational training and training programmes, taking into account the different experiences of EU countries - as well as the foresight of future skills - the document treats unemployment as a problem of lack of mobility or worker motivation. It is with this logic of blaming the worker that the report recommends measures to strengthen the responsibility and "entrepreneurial" education of the unemployed without understanding the problem at the structural and systemic level.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Writing. It was long overdue to address the issue of how to create a supply-demand EU labour market, in which the skills that are also in demand are taught in educational institutions.  It was important to me to make it clear that we need to train more in STEM subjects, which are in high demand in the labour market and which can alleviate the looming shortage of skilled workers and help to secure knowledge in these key competences for Europe as a location. In order to arouse an interest in these subjects, one has to start in kindergarten and especially introduce the girls and young women to technology and natural sciences. At the same time, we must bear in mind that we have over two million vacancies in the EU, which we can only fill if we improve labour mobility. In other words, Europe-wide transparency on vacancies, the promotion of foreign languages and the reduction of bureaucratic barriers to cross-border job search. With the revision of the EURES regulation, we have already taken an important step in this parliamentary term. Thank you very much!

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted against this report because I do not consider "competition" to be the remedy for the problems of work in the 21st century. On the contrary, individualism in industrial relations and workers' consciences is the cause of the profound degradation of conquered rights, from the subordination of society to market laws.  The restricted framework proposed to us offers opportunities for improvement: for example in active employment policies. But these policies are fringed when the goal of full quality employment in public policy is abandoned.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that in order to achieve a competitive labour market, reforms are needed in order to better match skills with the jobs available, increase the flexibility of personal careers and promote closer cooperation between businesses and education systems. I have therefore decided to vote in favour of this report, which not only takes stock of the employment shortages of the EU labour market, but also recommends promoting entrepreneurship among citizens and encouraging best practices among Member States. Finally, I believe that we have managed to strike a good balance between national competences and areas in which the European Union can add value in the fight against unemployment.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted for a competitive EU labour market for the 21st century which will foster continuous education and training, especially for the most vulnerable groups. This is particularly important in the West Midlands as higher skilled employment is expected to rise, and in order to guarantee this progress we called on the EU to invest in the region’s talents, skills and abilities to combat unemployment and provide wider access to high-quality jobs.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing ‒ I supported this resolution, which I believe is very well processed proportionally, which is reflected in the balance between member states' competences and an area where the EU can provide high added value. Furthermore, I appreciate the cooperation of the three largest parliamentary groups in preparing this report in committee.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ This explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU is one of the largest exporters of goods and services in the world, and the EU's single labour market brings many benefits and opportunities for businesses and consumers in european communities. Nevertheless, I believe that the EU's European labour market currently has very serious problems related to the slow creation of new jobs. I believe that, in order to maintain and strengthen the competitiveness of the EU labour market, we should move more courageously towards labour market reforms that could contribute to achieving the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy. Although the single labour market has created millions of jobs for Europeans in recent years and allows them to work throughout Europe, I consider the solution to the problem of unemployment, which remains critical, to be a key problem. Although some key points have not been put to the vote, it is important that we continue with the strategy that has been put forward. I join the call for Member States and regional local authorities to report on the best practices on the basis of which they have succeeded in carrying out more ambitious reforms. I expect the creation of a competitive EU labour market to increase inclusiveness, flexibility and mobility and create more jobs.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: in writing. ‒ Standing at only slightly below 10% after several years of recovery from the crisis, the EU unemployment rate includes huge disparities not only among Member States but also between women and men, young, experienced and aged, people with and without disabilities, Roma or non-Roma, etc. The EU will fail to meet the Europe 2020 Strategy target of having 75% of people of working age employed and to have a dynamic and competitive labour market if it does not implement forward-looking structural reforms that would tackle such imbalances. The lack of qualified labour in several areas and increasing skill-mismatches resulting in millions of unfilled jobs in the EU are again strong concerns that have to be addressed. As the report recognised most of these issues, I was glad to vote in favour.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. Austerity and labour market reforms have negative consequences on employment rates and job creation and quality. Young people have been inappropriately hit by the crisis, and their unemployment is twice as high as adult unemployment.  There are 24 million unemployed people in Europe on the one hand (including 7.5 million young people who are not in employment or school) and only 2 million job vacancies.  Unfortunately, this broad structural problem cannot be solved primarily by addressing skills mismatches with labour market needs.  Economic and social policies and ambitious labour market reform are also needed to create a more just, sustainable and inclusive society and quality jobs.  Policies addressing skills should not only focus on meeting labour market needs, but should equip individuals with broad competences so that they can develop into active and responsible citizens.  Unfortunately, the report focuses excessively on meeting the needs of the labour market and places too little emphasis on the development of those skills that are particularly specific to individuals.  The aim of expanding the skills should, in particular, be to improve the situation of individuals in the labour market and their living conditions, rather than meeting the needs of the labour market, which is why I voted against the report.

name: Bart STAES
text: Written. 'This report points to skills by conservatives and neoliberals as the solution to mass unemployment. Skills are the new Trojan horse of the neoliberal market. But by focusing unilaterally on skills, structural unemployment, the wrong economic policies and a lack of good work policies that should create more and better jobs are sidelined. By stating that 'the right skills' will ensure that you do not become unemployed, you only place the blame on the victim (the job seeker). In addition, the EU minimum wage was scrapped, people talked about 'entrepreneurship from kindergarten' (can preschoolers still be toddlers?) and 'incentives to work' (read: saving on unemployment allowance). We Greens see it differently and therefore voted against this resolution. What's more, we tabled an alternative resolution that takes the debate away from supply and demand in the labour market, and opens it up by denouncing the poor economic policies that fuel unemployment and inequality. Our resolution was supported by the Socialists and colleagues on the left, but unfortunately it did not make it.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing \ u2012 Unemployment is one of the main problems of the European Union. Youth unemployment is all the more alarming. This needs to be tackled systemically. It is necessary to ensure that people leaving school get work habits as soon as possible so that they can later become full members of society. However, it is more important for the healthy development of the European economy to create an environment that generates new jobs on its own.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. I support this report because better connectivity and active participation of the main actors - educational institutions, business structures, trade unions and workers - within countries and local communities is needed, but also at the European level in order to be of high quality and competitiveness.  As the financial crisis has left implications for the European labour market and as youth unemployment and unemployment are above the EU average in many Member States, while the creation of new jobs is still slow and on the other hand there are over two million jobs that cannot be filled due to labour market mismatches between different countries and insufficient labour mobility, proposed reforms are needed to increase flexibility in both labour and labour markets to better align skills and competences of workers with market needs, all for the purpose of a better and more competitive European labour market.  Also, the proposed reforms are also needed to better align educational institutions with the needs of the real sector and to appreciate values such as lifelong learning, EURES, individual access to different social groups, linguistic education and similar proposals for this report.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ The issue of the skills mismatches should not hide the real problems of the labour markets, the need to promote the creation of quality jobs, to fight precarious employment and social inequalities and achieve a labour market based on the free movement of citizens and workers and the principle of equal pay for equal work.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: in writing \ u2012 I abstained from voting. While I agree with the problems identified and also with some of the solutions proposed, the number of solutions presented would lead to a further reduction in the competitiveness of the EU labour market, thus hurting precisely those people whom it is supposed to protect. These include, for example, calls for financial support from different population groups – small and medium-sized enterprises, programmes for retraining and placing the unemployed on the labour market, the Youth Guarantee programme, Erasmus for Young Entrepreneurs, incentives for businesses to invest in staff training and apprenticeships, and many more. It should be borne in mind that the financing of all these activities necessarily comes at the expense of higher taxes for entrepreneurs and employees, which ultimately leads to lower overall job creation.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The weight given in the report is limited to the individual skills and mobility of workers by transferring the largest share of responsibility for employment mainly on the shoulders of workers rather than proposing a holistic approach to the phenomenon, with the State also assuming its responsibilities. At the same time, the European Parliament calls for all those facilities that are possible for employers and their organisations to be given to co-shape both the state's labour and education policy according to their own priorities and needs.  The completion of the system of recognition of qualifications (even empirical qualifications) throughout the EU can also be seen as positive if it is placed in the context of the voluntary search for work abroad, rather than the indirect forced migration. The greatest weakness of the text is the placement of unemployment as a social phenomenon. Unfortunately, instead of proposals for public investment, the impetus for reindustrialisation and social development, the report focuses the problem on the lack of mobility of workers and the mismatch of skills. For the above reasons we voted against the text.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 Despite many positive features, I voted not in favour of the report, mainly because it should have painted a more realistic picture of the unemployment situation. In my explanation, I am just mentioning one example. I believe that, perhaps not in all Member States, but in Hungary, for example, the data are highly distorted: the public works system, which provides around EUR 160 per month, is included, in addition to the fact that people who work abroad and people who work up to 1 hour a week are treated as one employee as well as full-time workers. It should also be mentioned that it would also be important to speed up the work of Eurostat at EU level, where data are processed 2-3 years late, so I do not think they reflect topicality. In addition to the statistical data, I am pleased that the report raises a number of important solutions for an efficient labour market. Of these, I consider the concept of a European minimum wage, which I have raised several times, to be very important. The report rightly calls on the Commission and the Member States to introduce a European framework for minimum wages with a view to addressing pay disparities by means of a basic level per Member State in order to guarantee a decent income, either by legal means or by agreement, in accordance with national practice.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report stresses that ambitious economic policies and labour market reforms are required in order to increase labour market and personal career flexibility, better matching of skills and jobs, including stronger synergies between education systems and businesses. The report highlights the importance of mobility of workers for the competitive labour market and calls for further developing tools and better promoting the EU current initiatives in this respect. A special attention is granted to the importance of promoting initiatives which foster self-employment and entrepreneurship, with a particular focus on the SMEs and on micro-enterprises, as backbone of the EU labour market.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: In writing. With the unemployment rate above 9.5% in the European Union and the youth unemployment rate peaking at 25%, the creation of sustainable and quality jobs must be our main concern. I rejected the Dlabajov report and its old liberal recipes which showed their inefficiency. The "flexibilization" of the labour market is not the solution. Far from curbing employment, the rights and protections of workers that the Liberals are attacking are a hindrance to precariousness. While more than 23 million Europeans are looking for work, the report, by advocating "incentive to work" through the abolition of social assistance, feeds the myth of the unemployed volunteer. Thus, I could only oppose its adoption as it stands.  On the other hand, I supported the alternative resolution tabled by the Socialists and the Greens. The resolution stressed the importance of investment, training and accompanying measures, stressed that mobility must be chosen and not suffered, and stressed the urgent need to combat fraud in the Worker Detachment Directive.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a report highlighting the need for reforms to achieve a competitive labour market in order to increase the labour market and the flexibility of personal careers, align skills with available jobs and develop closer synergies between the education system and business needs.  Given that the youth unemployment rate remains high in many Member States, I support highlighting the importance of exchanging best practices between Member States as well as highlighting the need to promote initiatives that will encourage self-employment and entrepreneurship, with a particular focus on SMEs and microenter enterprises.  Removing bureaucratic barriers and reducing the tax burden on labour will greatly help create jobs in the sector. Finally, it is very useful for improving the labour market situation in Member States such as Croatia, as supporting the preservation of traditional skills that create stable jobs and their transfer to future generations, combining them with new knowledge.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. Since the resolution encourages Member States to adopt ambitious economic policies and to reform the labour market, in particular with a view to achieving sustainable and inclusive growth, I supported it. The requirements for knowledge, competences as well as the labour market themselves are changing. The European economic and financial crisis has slowed the economy and led to a high unemployment rate. It is necessary to align skills with real market demand, which definitely poses a major challenge for the whole of the European Union. In many times, education systems do not meet the needs of the economy, so a number of reforms are urgently needed. Both on the economic policy side and on the labour market. Synergy must be found. The fact is that safe jobs are gone today. There are false expectations that without constant training and upgrading their knowledge, someone could spend the same job from their first job to retirement. It is important that we are aware of this as individuals, and the state must also be aware of this and create an encouraging environment for acquiring the skills and competences that are most in demand on the market.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. The objective of this report was to better adapt skills and qualifications to demand and employment prospects as a means of recovering from the crisis. However, we voted against it because we believe that the way in which skills and qualifications are addressed is wrong and will deepen and time unemployment. The main problem of the report is its approach, according to which labour market reforms are, especially to increase flexibility and mobility, the solution and the measures necessary to achieve the above objective. While on the one hand the report mentions the need to improve existing vocational training and training programmes, taking into account the different experiences of EU countries - as well as the foresight of future skills - the document treats unemployment as a problem of lack of mobility or worker motivation. It is with this logic of blaming the worker that the report recommends measures to strengthen the responsibility and "entrepreneurial" education of the unemployed without understanding the problem at the structural and systemic level.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The text aims to allow full free movement within the European Union to address the problem of unemployment, which affects all age groups. This implies that only the lack of mobility leads to such unemployment and that it could be miraculously resolved by this means. The text also calls on citizens to adapt to the economy and to digital change, while the reverse should be the way to make the situation a little more humane. This project prepares us for a change in migration policy, in order to open up the labour market to non-European citizens. For the EU, the simplest solution to Europe's demographic challenges is immigration. This project aims to address the effects, not the causes of unemployment. I am voting against the adoption of this text.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. The objective of this report was to better adapt skills and qualifications to demand and employment prospects as a means of recovering from the crisis. However, we voted against it because we believe that the way in which skills and qualifications are addressed is wrong and will deepen and time unemployment. The main problem of the report is its approach, according to which labour market reforms are, especially to increase flexibility and mobility, the solution and the measures necessary to achieve the above objective. While on the one hand the report mentions the need to improve existing vocational training and training programmes, taking into account the different experiences of EU countries - as well as the foresight of future skills - the document treats unemployment as a problem of lack of mobility or worker motivation. It is with this logic of blaming the worker that the report recommends measures to strengthen the responsibility and "entrepreneurial" education of the unemployed without understanding the problem at the structural and systemic level.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. I voted against this report because I believe that this report is only focused on skills/competences as an instrument for creating a more competitive labour market. Increasing skills/competencies is not enough to combat structural unemployment.  We would need to start talking about labor demand rather than just focusing on supply and focusing on changing those economic policies that increase unemployment and inequality. This also includes investing in creating quality work.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, which deals with ways with which to make the EU economy more competitive. The issue of competitiveness in the global economy is of great importance especially with a view to finding ways out of the crisis. The resolution addresses a number of crucial aspects that are in need of reform, such as the personal career flexibility of employees and the often underestimated relationship and cooperation between education systems and businesses. In relation to this issue, the text also calls for better solutions to ensure that skills and jobs are matched. The resolution also underlines the need for a greater investment in jobs and life-long learning for the unemployed.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. However the issue of the skills mismatches should not hide the real problems of the labour markets. In particular the need to promote the creation of quality jobs, to fight precarious employment and social inequalities and achieve a labour market based on the free movement of citizens and workers and the principle of equal pay for equal work. Without these any attempt to improve our labour market is doomed to exacerbate rather than solve existing problems within the common work market.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 Statistical manipulation around unemployment is widespread. Behind much data on falling unemployment rates is precarious employment, insecurity and the misery of many workers. In Portugal it has been decided that so-called "busy" are not part of unemployment rates.  We are talking about workers who, instead of enjoying an employment contract that corresponds to the permanent job they occupy - often in public institutions - are workers who have a so-called "employment-insertion contract", who attend an internship or a vocational training course.  These workers employed last June in Portugal were already more than 150,000 workers who had this kind of precarious bond, about 50,000 of them with the so-called "employment-insertion contract", in which workers earn below the minimum wage. It is the EU itself that finances this type of labour exploitation. In the previous financial framework there were more than EUR 95 million from the European Social Fund for these pseudo-contracts. It is certainly not with the increased flexibility of industrial relations - which you repeat so much - that a competitive labour market will be built that will improve the lives of workers.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. Although there are good points that indicate that SMEs are very important in and for Europe, the report points to the problems that arise in purely national labour markets, but the solutions proposed are in a very etatistic tradition, although it always invokes the importance of competition, competitiveness and skills. It also does not make a clear distinction between the EU and national competences, where labour market measures fall. I therefore reject this report.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. – I did not agree with the European Parliament's resolution on 'Creating an EU competitive labour market for the 21st century: matching skills and qualifications to demand and employment opportunities as a way out of the crisis'. In it, the European Parliament calls on "the Commission and the Member States to establish a European minimum wage framework based on a base level in each Member State as part of the reduction of the pay gap, in order to ensure adequate incomes by legal means or through an agreement and in accordance with national practice" (paragraph 106). I do not carry any minimum wage in any way, either at national or European level. I find it astonishing that so many of my colleagues are able to see a competitive labour market when the low-skilled are legally excluded from participation in the labour market by means of a minimum wage. It is also very incomprehensible to me that the Commission has competence here. In an EU of competition, each Member State finds its own rules for labour markets. If the EU equals everything, competition will be prevented. One thing is certain in all of this: this report does not show a way out of the crisis.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. – I voted on the report on the creation of a competitive labour market in the EU for the 21st century: linking skills and qualifications with employment demand and opportunities as a means of recovery from the crisis.  I agree with the rapporteur's view that in order to achieve a competitive labour market in the EU, ambitious reforms are needed to increase inclusion, smart flexibility, innovation and mobility, strengthen the role of social dialogue, stimulate the creation of more jobs leading to quality and sustainable employment , increase productivity and contribute to the development of human capital, bearing in mind that labour markets and production patterns are constantly changing.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. \u2012 This report stresses that, in order to have a competitive labour market, reforms are needed to increase the flexibility of the labour market and personal careers and that it is necessary to promote better convergence between skills and jobs, including stronger synergies between education systems and businesses. The importance of using investment to actively support job creation and prevent skills shortages among the unemployed is highlighted, as is the flexible approach to working life that allows workers to adapt to change and prepares them for lifelong learning. Mention is rightly made of the need for reforms to encourage people to return to work and not to opt for the benefits of social systems as well as for the mobility of workers with a particular sensitivity to jobs at Union level. For all these reasons, I have opted in favour of the report.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 Combating unemployment is one of the challenges facing the European Union, when the level of unemployment varies from one country to another. I supported this report because it identifies a fundamental problem that stems from unemployment and thus the inflexibness of both the labour market and those looking for work. Linking the competences and skills of individuals with the needs of the labour market through better cooperation between educational institutions and the labour sphere is therefore a key element. I am also close to the report expressing support for small businesses as the backbone of the economy.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing \ u2012 The resolution adopted provides an overall view of the possibilities of creating a competitive labour market in the European Union. It deals with promoting labour mobility, which is lower than, for example, in the US or Australia, as well as the need to link education and the labour market through cooperation between educational institutions, employers' organisations and employers, for example by exchanging best practices, or by providing traineeships and training so that it can respond better and more quickly to the needs of the labour market. Furthermore, the resolution highlights the importance of public employment services, social investment, as well as the importance of small and medium-sized enterprises for job creation, and also addresses the provision of sustainable employment and quality training for disadvantaged groups of employees. As this resolution has been met in many ways with my priorities in the field of employment, I supported it with my vote.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 The report advocates the creation of what it considers to be greater labour competitiveness in the EU context. The reality is exposed that in many EU countries the unemployment rate is very high, while there are unfilled job vacancies (around 2 million).   The response given by the report to ensure this "competitiveness" is emphasized in the document in two ways: (1) the adequacy of education and training systems to the needs of the labour market, including dual training, and the involvement of the "business world" of the curriculum definition; (2) the promotion of labour mobility, adaptability and flexibility. If the former subalters the educational system (individual law and which must respond to various needs of society) to the needs of the market, the second eternalizes precariousness, with the common excuse of the need for "competitiveness".  We voted against it.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. The objective of this annual report is to identify gaps in transposition, as well as problems arising from the application of Community law in the Member States. It reflects the importance of the application of Community environmental law and identifies the sectors in which problems occur, such as transport, health, the environment or services.  Although in this text the rapporteur, Mr Kostas Chrysogonos, my colleague in my parliamentary group, has failed to maintain his initial proposal that the text recognise the illegality of the Troika, has succeeded in including the harmful effects of cuts on public spending on citizens' legal certainty. Since the report also calls on Member States to fulfil their obligations on economic and social rights, I voted in favour of the proposed text.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. These two annual reports on monitoring the application of EU law detail the legal proceedings against Member States for not transposing the European Commission's directives quickly enough. In this context, the European Court of Justice has issued 31 judgments to the detriment of Member States mainly in areas relating to consumer protection, the environment, transport or the internal market.  The text recalls that States have an obligation to fully transpose and effectively implement the Commission's directives. Otherwise, the Lisbon Treaty provides that the Court of Justice can sanction countries that do not respect European law. The report even calls for tougher sanctions.   We are in the strongestest opposition to the European diktat, which is to impose political and economic orientations on the peoples of Europe that are not their own. The European Union is a totalitarian organisation that flouts individual freedoms and the national sovereignty of member states.  So I voted against it.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the report as a whole, noting that paragraphs 9 and 39 in particular support harmonisation and paragraph 39 relates to the Common Asylum Policy. However, at least there is some recognition of the need to avoid ‘gold-plating’ of EU legislation and the problems caused by EU legislation to SMEs.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, as I believe that the Commission should step up its efforts to effectively transport the EU law to its citizens and simultaneously increase its monitoring capacity in terms of the infringement of the EU law by the Members States.  This should especially be applied to the most problematic areas such as transport, health and consumers protection, protection of the environment, and internal market and services. It is necessary to provide citizens with full information in an accessible and transparent manner, so they are aware which laws are adopted and what national agencies are in charge of their implementation. I believe that, only by ensuring effective application of the EU law EU can meet its policy goals.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to evaluate the 30th and 31st annual report on the application of EU law.  These reports indicate that the main areas where Member States were the most cases of infringements of eu law transposition in 2012 were transport, health and consumer protection, environmental protection and issues relating to the internal market and services, while in 2013 the areas with the greatest problems were the environment, health and consumer protection, the internal market and services and transport. EU citizens have the right to first of all have the opportunity to know in a clear, accessible, transparent and timely manner whether national legislation has been adopted in the transposition of EU law, what has been adopted and which national authorities are responsible for their correct implementation. I support the calls for the Commission to take greater account of the burden that small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) may bear when drafting and evaluating legislation. The Commission and the Member States need to coordinate more closely their efforts at an earlier stage of the legislative process in order to ensure more effective implementation of the final outcome.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. The 30th and 31st annual reports on monitoring the application of EU law for 2012 and 2013 take stock of infringement procedures brought against Member States for delaying transposition or mistrans transposition of EU directives by the Commission, as "treaty guardian" (Article 17, TUE) and its powers defined in Articles 258 to 260 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU (procedure for appealing failure). For example, in 2013, the Court of Justice of the Union issued 52 judgments (Article 258, TFUE) of which 31 were to the detriment of the Member States. This is one of the sad innovations of the Lisbon Treaty: at the request of the Commission, the Court of Justice can impose sanctions for delaying transposition without waiting for a second judgment. I therefore voted against this report despite some positive points, such as the recognition that 'certain policies imposed on Member States, including the privatisation of public goods, constitute a direct violation of the principles on which the Union is based - Article 345, TFUE stipulates that treaties do not prejudge the ownership regime in the Member States'.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. These reports, which closely follow the transposition of the directives by the Member States, show that the most problematic sectors concern transport, health and consumer protection, environmental protection and the internal market. This follow-up is therefore important for the general interest of European citizens. The rapporteur points out two elements which I think are relevant in this follow-up exercise. First of all, it is clear that austerity policies have led to clear cuts in the public administrations and judicial systems of the Member States. This can therefore have a significant impact on their ability to transpose European texts that are important to the daily lives of citizens.  Secondly, we must be extremely vigilant so that the REFIT programme, whose overall objective is to simplify European regulations, does not cause setbacks in the protection of workers' health and safety or the protection of the environment. The Charter of Social Rights itself calls on the Union to protect the health of citizens and the safety of workers.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This report on the 30th and 31st annual reports on monitoring the application of the EU recommends a number of points that I am fighting, such as the full transposition and effective implementation of the common European regime as a top priority, or the fact that the Charter of Fundamental Rights is seen as a treaty like any other. In addition, I strongly condemn the introduction of the ECJ's ability to fine states that have delays in transposition or the call on the Commission to be stricter on this transposition of environmental directives. With fussy standards and new regulations every day, the EU is becoming more and more a cold and bureaucratic monster like the USSR in its day, only ultraliberalism added to it.  Although this report contains some positive measures such as condemning the obligation on states to privatise certain public goods (which runs up against Article 345 of the FUE Treaty) or worrying about austerity measures, I have decided to vote against it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Report of the Committee on Legal Affairs directly attacks the Member States, accusing them of incorrect or uneven application of directives and regulations, but does not take into account the fact that states and regions are faced with the need to adapt and implement legislative texts that pose serious practical as well as political problems, for example the damage done to our production system by the Services Directive. The Commission does not take account of the continuing invasions of the field by law into the prerogatives of Member States and regions with legislative power, which is why I did not support this text with my vote.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. Since 1984, at Parliament's request, the Commission has presented an annual report on monitoring the application of EU law according to information provided by citizens, businesses, NGEs and other stakeholders.  The report, for the years 2012 and 2013, lays down guidelines to be followed by the Commission for a better end result in the application of EU law. These include greater coordination between the Commission and Member States at early stages of the legislative procedure, the adoption of new means to improve the transposition of directives, greater cooperation between the European Parliament and national parliaments or the strengthening of communication between the Commission and Member States with the European Parliament's Committee on Petitions, given its growing importance as a framework for reporting violations of Community rules.  For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on Parliament's report assessing the annual reports on the 30th and 31st annual reports on the application of EU law. Parliament welcomes the Commission's 30th and 31st annual reports on the application of EU law and notes that these reports indicate that the main areas where Member States were the largest cases of infringements of eu transposition in 2012 were transport, health and consumer protection, environmental protection, issues relating to the internal market and services, and in 2013 the environment, health and consumer protection, the internal market and services and transport. The Commission must assist Member States in the proper implementation of EU law, thereby supporting the EU more and trusting its legitimacy.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it particularly welcomes the new provisions introduced by the Lisbon Treaty in Article 260, paragraph 3, of the Treaty on the functioning of the European Union and calls for greater commission severity against Member States in the event of a mistrans transposition or failure to transpose the directives.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. ‒ This report contained a number of very important provisions which specifically spelt out the detrimental effects of austerity on the judicial security of citizens.  The aim of the report is primarily to identify the lack of transpositions and the problems arising in the Members States notably transport services, environment and health. However, a political angle was added to what is generally a very legalistic text by stating that the drastic cuts in public spending have had the effect of significantly reducing the capacity of Member States’ administration and judiciary to assume their responsibility correctly to implement EU law. It also contained a number of other provisions and it was for these reasons that I voted in favour of this report.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. These two annual reports on monitoring the application of EU law detail the legal proceedings against the Member States for not transposing the European Commission's directives quickly enough. In this context, the European Court of Justice has issued 31 judgments to the detriment of Member States mainly in areas relating to consumer protection, the environment, transport or the internal market. The text recalls that States have an obligation to fully transpose and effectively implement the Commission's directives. Otherwise, the Lisbon Treaty provides that the Court of Justice can sanction countries that do not respect European law. The report even calls for tougher sanctions.  We are in the strongestest opposition to the European diktat, which is to impose political and economic orientations on the peoples of Europe that are not their own. The European Union is a totalitarian organisation that flouts individual freedoms and the national sovereignty of Member States. So I voted against it.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The 30th and 31st Annual Commission Report on the Application of EU Law are intended to analyse the extent to which Member States comply with the obligations laid down by EU law. It was noted that the areas where Member States were most frequently subject to infringement procedures in 2012, but also in 2013 were transport, health protection, consumer protection and environmental protection, the internal market and services.  Even if difficulties remain in dialogue between certain Member States, it must be borne in mind that, in a European Union based on the rule of law and the predictability of laws, European citizens must be made aware in a transparent and prompt manner of the national rules adopted as a result of the transposition of EU law, as well as the national authorities responsible for their correct implementation. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that careful monitoring of Member States' actions is important in order to have a rigorous transposition of directives, but also in the process of reducing citizens' complaints, which are increasingly aware of the benefits arising from the proper application of EU rules.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against. The text directly accuses Member States of incorrect application of EU rules without taking into account their contra legem invasions.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of this report on monitoring the application of EU law, as the implementation and correct transposition of EU law by Member States are essential to ensure full respect for citizens' right to good administration, as enshrined in Article 41 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights. In this respect, in order to improve the application of EU law, it is essential to support national parliaments in transposing EU legislation and to further intensify cooperation between MEPs and the European Affairs Committees of national and regional parliaments. Although a great deal of progress still needs to be made, especially in the area of transparency and access to Parliament, Council and Commission documents by the public, freedom of movement, the protection of personal data and environmental protection, the results obtained so far seem very satisfactory, and that is why I have chosen to vote in favour of the text.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ This report contained a number of very important provisions which specifically spelt out the detrimental effects of austerity on the judicial security of citizens.  The aim of the report is primarily to identify the lack of transpositions and the problems arising in the Members States notably transport services, environment and health. However, a political angle was added to what is generally a very legalistic text by stating that the drastic cuts in public spending have had the effect of significantly reducing the capacity of Member States’ administration and judiciary to assume their responsibility correctly to implement EU law. It also contained a number of other progressive provisions and it was for these reasons that I voted in favour of this report.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ Despite some of the language raised in this report, such as concerns over the regulatory burden facing SMEs, which I agree with, I am, in principle, opposed to any legislative intervention by the EU, and accordingly voted against it.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted strongly in favour of the resolution, which I helped to form through the opinion on which I was rapporteur in the Committee on Constitutional Affairs. In particular, this resolution expresses an important new element, which I have personally promoted, which relates to the need to establish an autonomous system within Parliament so that - in the absence of clear information from the Commission and the Member States - it can directly monitor the situation regarding the application of Union law.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 It is correct to point out that late transposition, incorrect transposition and poor application of EU legislation can lead to differentiation between Member States and distort conditions of competition across the EU. It is also noted that citizens who wish to live, work and do business in another Member State face ongoing difficulties in their daily lives due to the different application of EU law in the legal systems of the Member States.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the 30th and 31st annual reports on monitoring the application of European Union law (2012 and 2013). The report welcomes the reports and notes that infringement procedures affected transport, health and consumer protection and the internal market in 2012, while, in 2013, the most problematic areas were the environment, health protection, the internal market and services.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I welcome member states' efforts to resolve infringement cases without recourse to the Court using special procedures, which has led to a decrease in the number of formal infringement procedures. I am convinced that welcoming the Commission's increasing use of implementation plans for new EU legislation directed at states not only reduces the risks to proper and timely implementation but also prevents transposition problems. I would also like to stress that one of the Commission's objectives is to facilitate dialogue on the adequacy of regulation with citizens, Member States, businesses and civil society in general in such a way as to ensure that the quality and social aspects of EU legislation are preserved.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 The transposition and correct application of Community law in the Member States is a European prerogative which aims to reduce the gap and slowness in the procedures for the adoption of European legislative acts by national legislation. The report highlights the greater difficulties in the process of transposition by the national institutions of language problems, excessive bureaucracy and a lack of knowledge about Community legislation. Citizens and businesses must be able to rely on a simpler and more reliable regulatory framework that allows them access to information and documentation concerning the application of European law. I welcome the report on the monitoring and application of Community law, with the prospect of improving its regulation, implementation and uniform implementation. Only in this way will citizens and businesses in the Member States be able to refer effectively and in a reasonable time to Community acts. It is the responsibility of the Member States and the European Commission to improve the transposition of European law into national legal systems correctly and promptly.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ It is true that we monitor the application of European law into national legal orders to ensure respect for the rule of law, certainty and predictability of law. But effective, efficient and timely implementation by Member States is not only there to serve legal concepts but more so to ensure those freedoms the enjoyment of which is fundamental to European citizenship. As citizens of the Union we expect to be able to move freely amongst Member States, to live, work and do business in other Member States. In doing so citizens rightly expect not to get entangled in legislative webs created by late implementation, inaccurate or incomplete application of European law. While recognising the Commission’s efforts in monitoring the application of EU law, citizens need to see stronger and less time consuming procedures. In today’s challenges, there is no time to waste in ensuring that Member States correctly and timely apply EU law on migration, human trafficking and the environment. We can only deliver results to our citizens if legislation lawfully passed is applied. In this regard, we need to ensure stricter, more efficient and quicker procedures that address discrepancies in the application of law more adequately

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. The objective of this annual report is to identify gaps in transposition, as well as problems arising from the application of Community law in the Member States. It reflects the importance of the application of Community environmental law and identifies the sectors in which problems occur, such as transport, health, the environment or services.  Although in this text the rapporteur, Mr Kostas Chrysogonos, my colleague in my parliamentary group, has failed to maintain his initial proposal that the text recognise the illegality of the Troika, has succeeded in including the harmful effects of cuts on public spending on citizens' legal certainty. Since the report also calls on Member States to fulfil their obligations on economic and social rights, I voted in favour of the proposed text.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. The 30th and 31st annual reports on monitoring the application of EU law (2012-2013) refer to infringement procedures for breaches of the obligations to transpose European texts into the national law of each state. I also cannot support the regrets of a misapsed of European law, as I consider that this regulation weighs on our economies, our legal systems, and undermines the independence of States. It turns out that many infringement procedures have been found in the areas of environment, transport, the internal market and consumer protection. In other words, we find that states are finding it difficult to follow the Commission obediently on issues that require flexibility and broad adaptation to accompany the changes.
