So I voted against text.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 In general, I welcome the idea of a review of the application of EU law. Especially when considering the fact that complaints have increased compared to previous years. However, we should not be fooled by numbers. While increasing awareness has increased public scrutiny, there are more factors to consider.  Different processes, such as simplifying EU legislation, often occur together with integration into national systems. Especially countries in the eastern parts of Europe, such as Bulgaria, have had much greater difficulties, as they often do not have the necessary resources, guaranteed stability or know-how. Moreover, we must keep in mind that the sectors concerned are some of the most complex.  Transposition infringements are becoming a major problem and the Commission is obliged to monitor this process closely because more and more citizens are highlighting these problem areas.  However, the report proposes a Common European Asylum System, which me and my group disagree with, which is why I voted against.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 This report does not attribute to its true extent the delegation of member states' national sovereign rights to the EU through the mandatory application of European legislation.  In addition, the EU requires the transposition of laws into the national law of countries on a case-by-case basis and, in the main, in the areas of interest to control Member States and not to help citizens.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: in writing. \u2012 The overall decline in infringement proceedings in recent years is a positive factor. But more needs to be done, especially since a hundred of these concern Italy. The use of the EU Pilot procedure for troubleshooting has proved useful. Nevertheless, the relationship between the number of petitions submitted to this Parliament and the infringement procedures in progress remains proportional. The Commission has availed itself of the help of complaints, which, as in the case of Spain's infringement of the Water Directive, have led to the opening of infringement proceedings. I would like to stress the fundamental role played by active citizens in monitoring the correct application of European law. Given the content of most petitions, it is clear that many citizens feel that they do not receive adequate listening from national authorities and institutions. I voted in favour because the rapporteur points the finger at austerity measures and their effects, with regard to the ability of the administration and judicial system of the Member States, to assume their responsibility for implementing Community law correctly. I therefore repeat the need for greater transparency, legal clarity and access to information on the whole pre-infringement procedure, within the framework of EU Pilot and the annual report.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 According to these reports, the main areas in which Member States were subject to transposition infringement proceedings in 2012 were transport, health and consumer protection, environmental protection and internal market and service issues, while in 2013 the most problematic areas were the environment, health and consumer protection , the internal market and services, as well as transport. The documents also show that disparities continue between Member States in the application and transposition of EU legislation, and that these disparities, combined with language problems, excessive bureaucracy and a lack of knowledge, have led to a Union that is not accessible to citizens. I also highlight the closure of 731 infringement cases on the fact that the Member State concerned demonstrated that it respected EU law and the 52 judgments delivered by the Court of Justice, 31 of which (59.6 %) contrary to the position of the Member States.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ The implementation and transposition of European Union legislation remains uneven in the Member States, which, combined with language problems, excessive bureaucracy and a lack of knowledge, creates a European Union that does not take citizens' needs into account. Citizens wishing to live, work or do business in another Member State face the daily reality of the permanent problems arising from the uneven implementation of European Union law in the legal systems of the Member States. The European Commission must urgently focus on effective problem-solving, effective management and preventive measures, but also consider new ways of improving the transposition and enforcement of European Union law.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against this report, which accuses Member States of incorrect or uneven application but which, for example, does not take into account the continuous invasions of the field that the law makes in the prerogatives of Member States and regions with legislative power.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 My vote is negative because this report does not attribute to its true extent the granting of the national sovereign rights of the Member States to the EU by the mandatory application of European legislation.  In addition, the EU requires the transposition of laws into the national law of countries on a case-by-case basis and, in the main, in the areas of interest to control Member States and not to help citizens.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the Commission’s 30th and 31st annual reports on the application of EU law. According to these reports the four fields in which Member States were mostly subject to transposition infringement proceedings in 2012 were transport, protection of health and consumers, protection of the environment, and issues related to the internal market and services, whereas in 2013 the most problematic areas were the environment, protection of health and consumers, the internal market and services, and transport. However, that this ex-post evaluation does not replace the Commission’s duty to monitor in an effective and timely fashion the application and implementation of EU law. Parliament could assist in reviewing the implementation of legislation through its scrutiny of the Commission.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the Commission's 30th and 31st annual reports on monitoring the application of EU law, which monitor and evaluate misconduct procedures in areas of problem areas such as transport, health, consumer protection, nature protection and the internal market and services. At the same time, I think it is important to point out that this ex-post evaluation should not replace the Commission's task of effectively and timely monitoring the application of EU law, and I also support the proposal that Parliament assist in reviewing the implementation of legislation through the Commission's control.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. – Good application of Community rules is essential to make the action of the European institutions, which are often perceived to be far removed from the daily lives of citizens, concrete and effective. That is why I am voting in favour of the report that the Committee on Legal Affairs has presented to us: European citizens must be put in a position to know in a clear, accessible, transparent and timely manner (including via the Internet) whether and which national rules have been adopted in transposition of EU law and which national authorities are responsible for their proper implementation.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted against today the report on the 30th and 31st Annual Reports on monitoring the application of EU law (2012-2013), as It considers that it ignores many critical areas of non-application of existing EU law.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The European Commission, as guardian of the Treaties, should be the guarantor of the application of Community law. In order to do so in practice, it is necessary to further improve the transposition of the law in the Member States and to ensure that it is duly respected.  In 2013, the Court of Justice delivered 52 judgments under Article 258 TFEU, 31 of which were to the detriment of the Member States. As in previous years, the most common weaknesses were related to environmental protection, health and consumer rights, the internal market, services and transport. The complaints in the area of justice mainly concerned freedom of movement, which is one of the four fundamental FREEDOMS of the Union enshrined in the Treaty.  It should be borne in mind that delays and irregularities in transposition and the incorrect application of EU law lead to inconsistencies between Member States, which consequently negatively affects citizens.  According to the report, greater coordination between the Commission and the Member States at earlier stages of the legislative process is also necessary. In addition, the European Parament could assist in the review of the application of Union legislation by using its powers of scrutiny against the Commission in situations where ex post evaluation proves insufficient.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report given that I share the rapporteur’s concern about the effects of austerity measures on the capacity of Member States’ administration and judiciary to assume their responsibility to implement EU law correctly.

name: Juan Carlos GIRAUTA VIDAL
text: in writing. Parliament, as co-legislator, gives its opinion in this resolution on the European Commission's thirty-first annual reports on the implementation of EU legislation. In a European Union based on the rule of law and the certainty and predictability of laws, it is vital that there be control over compliance with European legislation by Member States. Citizens and businesses also expect a simple, predictable and reliable regulatory framework. We remind the Commission that this ex post assessment does not replace its obligation to effectively and in due course monitor the application of EU law and that, when preparing and assessing legislation, it should take more account of the burden it may place on SMEs.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of chrysogonos' proposed report on monitoring the implementation of EU law. The objectives of the report, which is annual in this regard, are to enforce the application of EU law in the EU. Among the positive points of this report is that it has been able to give a political dimension to a space which in principle the Commission intends to make exempt from policy, namely that of the application of the Law. In this regard, the idea that austerity has harmful effects on the legal certainty of citizens was passed on. Although the result is not optimal, given that this would imply a clear denunciation of the emergence of illegal instances that ended up generating law such as the Troika, we do think that the report finds a space for politicization of the debate on an application of law that is not the same in some places and in others.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I, alongside my colleagues in the S&D Group, voted in favour of this report. The report expresses concern about the effects of austerity measures on the capacity of Member States’ administration and judiciary to assume their responsibility to implement EU law correctly. It points out that some policies are imposed on Member States.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of chrysogonos' proposed report on monitoring the implementation of EU law. The objectives of the report, which is annual in this regard, are to enforce the application of EU law in the EU. Among the positive points of this report is that it has been able to give a political dimension to a space which in principle the Commission intends to make exempt from policy, namely that of the application of the Law. In this regard, the idea that austerity has harmful effects on the legal certainty of citizens was passed on. Although the result is not optimal, given that this would imply a clear denunciation of the emergence of illegal instances that ended up generating law such as the Troika, we do think that the report finds a space for politicization of the debate on an application of law that is not the same in some places and in others.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the proposal for a European Parliament resolution on the 30th and 31st annual monitoring report on the application of EU law (2012 ‒ 2013), as I believe that the legal texts of the European Union must be fully accessible to citizens in a transparent and simple manner, i.e. a reliable and predictable regulatory framework needs to be ensured.  We are witnessing that the transposition and enforcement of EU law is different in some Member States, due to technical and linguistic barriers, as a result of excessive bureaucracy. Such a system is not fully citizen-friendly and lacks a higher dose of efficiency. Member States therefore need greater efforts to apply the European legal framework, simplified procedures and constructive dialogue between Member States and the institutions of the European Union.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. These two annual reports on monitoring the application of EU law detail the legal proceedings against Member States for not transposing the European Commission's directives quickly enough. In this context, the European Court of Justice has issued 31 judgments to the detriment of Member States mainly in areas relating to consumer protection, the environment, transport or the internal market. The text recalls that States have an obligation to fully transpose and effectively implement the Commission's directives. Otherwise, the Lisbon Treaty provides that the Court of Justice can sanction countries that do not respect European law. The report even calls for tougher sanctions.  We are in the strongestest opposition to the European diktat, which is to impose political and economic orientations on the peoples of Europe that are not their own. The European Union is a totalitarian organisation that flouts individual freedoms and the national sovereignty of Member States. So I voted against it.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Commission's 2012 and 2013 Annual Communications Report on the Application of EU Law. These communications focus in particular on the compliance of Member States with their obligations to transpose European directives. I believe that the text has been considerably improved during the negotiations. It shows that effective application of EU law is essential if it is to achieve its political objectives. The report also stresses the importance of respect by the Commission and Member States for their respective competences and responsibilities.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the 30th and 31st annual reports on the control of the application of the law in the European Union because these reports allow the European Commission to monitor the proper implementation of EU primary law by the various Member States while granting essential rights to citizens (complaints and petitions) regarding respect for rights in the Union.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. The report calls on the Commission and the Council to give Member States full access to documents. At the same time, it identifies the only problem with the implementation of EU law among the Member States. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report, as it is a technical report produced annually assessing the transposition and effective application of EU law in the Member States.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. The objective of this annual report is to identify gaps in transposition, as well as problems arising from the application of Community law in the Member States. It reflects the importance of the application of Community environmental law and identifies the sectors in which problems occur, such as transport, health, the environment or services.  Although in this text the rapporteur, Mr Kostas Chrysogonos, my colleague in my parliamentary group, has failed to maintain his initial proposal that the text recognise the illegality of the Troika, has succeeded in including the harmful effects of cuts on public spending on citizens' legal certainty. Since the report also calls on Member States to fulfil their obligations on economic and social rights, I voted in favour of the proposed text.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Effective application of EU rules is necessary in the context of achieving political objectives, which ultimately amounts to respect for the principles of the rule of law. Chrysogonos' report underlines the need for Member States and the Commission to fulfil their duties and responsibilities.  The Commission must help Member States to properly implement EU law to strengthen support and confidence in its legitimacy that citizens have been losing as a result of all the problems in recent years. I supported a report aimed at better structured, transparent and accessible information on the implementation of Union law in the area of freedom, security and justice.  It is pointed out that in addition to the annual monitoring report, other measures could be introduced that would allow Parliament to report more thoroughly on the state of implementation, delays, incorrect transposition, implementation and procedures in the area of justice, but also in other areas.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 A good, well-prepared review, I voted in favour with my political group.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 As I said in my speech on 10/9/2015 in the plenary of the European Parliament, as Professor of Institutions of the European Union at the University, I have given and continue to attach great importance to the role of the Commission, because the Commission is the guardian of the application of Community law. However, there are now a number of serious issues, which arise mainly from the Memoranda applied in certain countries and which result in important elements of European Union law being infringed and, above all, rights relating to social issues being infringed. On these issues, therefore, we have called for the Commission to intervene but, because the Commission is also a member of the Troika, it is in a conflict of interest. The Commission does not apply Community law correctly because it is itself involved, since it is a member of the Troika, in the infringement of Community law. This is a very important issue, which I highlighted the other day when I spoke about the reply given to me by Mr Moscovici, who said that the European Social Charter is not binding within the European Union! Please consider this matter.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report and note the Commission’s use of the term ‘gold-plating’, which refers to obligations that go beyond EU requirements, that is, an excess of norms, guidelines and procedures accumulated at national, regional and local levels interfering with the expected policy goals; calls on the Commission to clearly define the term; stresses that such a definition must make it clear that Member States have the right to set stricter standards where necessary, while taking into account the fact that better harmonisation in the implementation of EU environmental law is important for the functioning of the internal market.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against these reports. They take stock of all infringement procedures brought against Member States by the Commission, for delaying the transposition or mistrans transposition of directives. Basically, we are against the very idea that the EU can condemn the Member States because they have not been able, or unless, to transpose a European text into their national legislation. These reports even make matters worse, since they advocate the use of mechanisms allowing the Court of Justice, at the request of the Commission, to condemn States without even a second judgment. We formally oppose this idea.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. The call for a rapid and complete implementation of CEAS (common European asylum system) is incompatible with the FPÖ's asylum line. It should also be noted that it is not the implementation of the Dublin Regulation that has failed, but its application. This report sees the Member States as the only problem in the implementation of EU law, but the rapporteur calls for the Commission and the Council to ensure full access to documents (whether the rapporteur refers to TTIP cannot be assessed). I shall therefore abstain from voting.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. These two annual reports on monitoring the application of EU law detail the legal proceedings against Member States for not transposing the European Commission's directives quickly enough. In this context, the European Court of Justice has issued 31 judgments to the detriment of Member States mainly in areas relating to consumer protection, the environment, transport or the internal market. The text recalls that States have an obligation to fully transpose and effectively implement the Commission's directives. Otherwise, the Lisbon Treaty provides that the Court of Justice can sanction countries that do not respect European law. The report even calls for tougher sanctions.  We are in the strongestest opposition to the European diktat, which is to impose political and economic orientations on the peoples of Europe that are not their own. The European Union is a totalitarian organisation that flouts individual freedoms and the national sovereignty of Member States. So the mp voted against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the 30th and 31st annual reports on the monitoring of the application of EU law (2012-2013), which integrates the rule of law principle, as well as certainty and predictability in the creation of legislation.  In this sense, the correct and timely transposition of EU legislation helps to avoid differentiation between Member States and the distortion of the level playing field across the EU.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this report as the monitoring of the smooth functioning of a true European area of justice that respects the different legal systems and traditions that exist inside the Union is an important step towards greater cohesion in the sector.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on monitoring and implementation of EU law, which expresses its concern about the effects of austerity measures on the capacity of Member States’ administration and judiciary to assume their responsibility to implement EU law correctly and it points out that some policies are imposed on Member States. It is time to put people at the heart of European Union policy making by identifying problematic areas, dismantling citizens’ barriers and improving implementation in ways which reaps concrete benefits in the daily lives of citizens.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 I point out that citizens and businesses rely on a clear, simple, predictable and reliable regulatory framework. Legal certainty is vital for the full functioning of a genuine European area of justice, while respecting the different legal systems of the Member States, and the full, correct and timely implementation of EU law are essential conditions for achieving this objective. I support that the Commission should treat all Member States on an equal footing, regardless of their size or the date of their membership of the EU, as I recognise that disparities still persist between Member States in the application and transposition of EU legislation, and that these disparities, combined with language problems, with excessive bureaucracy and a lack of knowledge , have led to a Union that is not accessible to all citizens. In a European area that is desired open and comprehensive, we cannot be confronted with the difficulties arising from the unequal application of EU law in the legal systems of the different Member States. I believe that late transposition, incorrect transposition and poor application of EU law can result in differentiation between Member States and distort a level playing field across the EU.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This report on the 30th and 31st annual reports on monitoring the application of the EU recommends a number of points that I am fighting, such as the full transposition and effective implementation of the common European regime as a top priority, or the fact that the Charter of Fundamental Rights is seen as a treaty like any other. But above all, I condemn the introduction by the Lisbon Treaty of the possibility for the EU Court of Justice, at the request of the Commission, to impose sanctions for delaying transposition without waiting for a second judgment or the appeal to the Commission to take stricter measures against the late transposition of environmental directives and to resort more to penalties.  Although this report contains some positive measures such as condemning the obligation on States to privatise certain public goods (which runs up against Article 345 of the FUE Treaty) or worrying about austerity measures, I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, which expresses concern about the effects of austerity measures on the capacity of Member States’ administration and judiciary to assume their responsibility to implement EU law correctly and points out that some policies are imposed on Member States.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ Taking into consideration that implementation and transposition of EU law remain uneven across Member States, I have voted for this report that will better regulate issues related to the internal market and services, transport, protection of health and consumers and protection of the environment.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I abstained because the report takes up some of the criticisms that I share. However, the position and importance of SMEs in our economic system is not adequately presented and sufficient reference is made to a possible burden, nor is the Commission taking into account the complex of excessive regulatory density.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. This is an overview of monitoring the application of EU law, which shows that EU Member States continue to have difficulties in transposing directives in a timely way, while civil society activity has increased to monitor the correct application of EU law.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒Consistent application and respect for the rule of law are the foundations on which the European Union is based, but also of all Member States. It is therefore up to us to ensure a consistent application of the rule of law that will ensure that citizens are informed in a clear and transparent manner and informed in a timely manner about what legal standards have been adopted by the EU and which national authorities are responsible for their proper application.  The main responsibility and duty for the correct implementation and application of EU law lies with the Member States and its institutions. It is the EU's duty to respect EU primary law in deciding, implementing and imposing social, economic and other policies on Member States, as well as assisting Member States in their efforts to respect democratic and social values, and to be guided by the principle of subsidiarity and the powers of the Member States.  On the basis of the rule of law, close monitoring of the actions and omissions of Member States and EU institutions is of utmost importance, and that, in line with the petitions received by citizens, it responds more quickly and clearly to citizens to their notifications of breaches of Union law. Given the importance of applying and respecting the fundamental rights outlined in this report, I support its adoption.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This report contains some positive points such as the recognition that "certain policies imposed on Member States, including the privatisation of public goods, constitute a direct violation of the principles on which the Union is based". He mentions the concern also raised by the austerity measures. But it recalls or advocates many of the points which I absolutely oppose: the equal value of the treaties of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the Union, the full transposition and effective implementation of the common European regime as a top priority, the innovation introduced by the Lisbon Treaty by which the Court of Justice, at the request of the Commission, can impose sanctions for delaying transposition without waiting for a second judgment , the call on the Commission to propose a binding legal instrument on the administrative procedure for dealing with citizens' complaints, the invitation to the Commission to take stricter measures against the late transposition of environmental directives and to make greater use of penalties, etc. That is why I am resolutely voting against this text.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. \u2012 Article 51. The Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union clearly limits member states' obligation to comply with the Charter when applying Union law, but does not provide for a restriction of obligations under the Charter for EU institutions, bodies, offices or agencies.  I would point out that in the European Union, based on the rule of law, legal certainty and predictability of the law, there must be a legal obligation for EU citizens to be the first to be in a clear, accessible, transparent manner (via the internet and other means) and informed in a timely manner about which national legal standards have been adopted as part of the transposition of EU legislation and which national authorities are responsible for their proper application.  I support the report, which underlines that the Commission needs to focus on effective problem solving, effective governance and preventive measures, but also stresses that, in addition to formal infringement procedures, it should also think about new ways to improve the transposition and implementation of EUROPEAN Union law.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. - I support Rapporteur Chrysogonos' report on the proposal for a Council decision on the 30th and 31st annual monitoring report on the application of EU law (2012 -2012 2013) which underlines the application of EU law if the Union fulfils its political objectives, which is ultimately a matter of respecting the rule of law principle. The report underlines the need for Member States and the Commission to fulfil their duties and responsibilities in this regard.  It is of utmost importance, as it underlines that in the EU, based on the rule of law, legal certainty and predictability of the law, there must be a legal obligation for EU citizens to be the first to be informed in a clear, accessible and transparent manner about which national legal standards have been adopted as part of the transposition of EU legislation and which national authorities are responsible for their proper application. In the context of the recent financial crisis, Member States had to take measures that undermine EU primary law, in particular provisions on the protection of social and economic rights.  I believe that EU legislation must be correctly and timely transposed into the legal order of each Member State and that cooperation between MEMBERS of the European Parliament and the Committee on European Affairs of National and Regional Parliaments needs to be further strengthened.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 One of the main tasks of the European Parliament is also to receive and evaluate the annual reports drawn up by the other institutions. The report presented to the House welcomes the Commission's 30th and 31st annual reports on the application of Eu ropean Union law. The text presented notes that, on the basis of these reports, the four areas in which Member States were the subject of infringement proceedings concerning transposition during 2012 were transport, health and consumer protection, environmental protection and issues related to the internal market and services. While, in 2013, the most problematic areas were the environment, health and consumer protection, the internal market and services as well as transport. Together with most of my colleagues, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the follow-up of the 30th and 31st annual reports on the application of EU law. The aim of these reports is to analyse member states' compliance with their obligations to transpose EU directives.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 This report deals with the Commission's 30th and 31st reports on the application of EU law. As it is certain that the EU was created as a Union based on the rule of law, the certainty and predictability of legislation and respect for human rights, it is essential to carefully monitor the acts and omissions of the Member States and the EU institutions in this area. In fact, citizens and businesses should be able to rely on the full, correct and timely implementation of EU law. In this regard, while it is important to welcome the decrease in the number of pending infringement cases, further efforts are needed, and the Commission and the Member States should be thinking of new ways of improving the transposition and enforcement of EU law in order to solve the remaining problems, in particular in the area of justice, the environment and health. I voted in favour.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. Since 1984, at Parliament's request, the Commission has presented an annual report on monitoring the application of EU law according to information provided by citizens, businesses, NGEs and other stakeholders.  The report, for the years 2012 and 2013, lays down guidelines to be followed by the Commission for a better end result in the application of EU law. These include greater coordination between the Commission and Member States at early stages of the legislative procedure, the adoption of new means to improve the transposition of directives, greater cooperation between the European Parliament and national parliaments or the strengthening of communication between the Commission and Member States with the European Parliament's Committee on Petitions, given its growing importance as a framework for reporting violations of Community rules.  For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which notes in particular that the four areas in which Member States have been subject to infringement proceedings for failure to transpose in recent years were transport, health and consumer protection, environmental protection and internal market and services issues. The text of the report also calls on the Commission and Member States to seek consensus at an earlier stage of the legislative process to ensure timely transposition and better implementation of the legislation once enacted.

name: Virginie ROZIÈRE
text: In writing. The European Commission, guardian of the treaties, has published the 30th and 31st reports on the monitoring of the application of EU law, which highlight the shortcomings of transposition by the Member States. Where they exist, these defects cause disparities between states and difficulties for European citizens, especially for companies that aspire to a readable, reliable and predictable regulatory framework. The report by Kostas Chrysogonos welcomes the commission's monitoring work and calls on the Commission to put in place new procedures, promoting problem-solving. The report also affirms the role of the European Parliament in monitoring the application of legislation, including calling for the creation of an autonomous system within its relevant directorates-general to assess the ex post impact of key European legislative acts. Finally, it is concerned about the effect of austerity policies on the ability of states to fulfil their obligation to apply EU law. That is why I supported this report.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Commission's thirtieth and thirty-first annual report on the application of European Union law. The 2012 report points out that the four areas in which Member States have been subject to infringement proceedings have been: transport; the protection of health and consumers; environmental protection and issues related to the internal market in services. In 2013, however, the most problematic sectors were: the environment; the protection of health and consumers; the internal market; services and transport.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted in favour of chrysogonos' proposed report on monitoring the implementation of EU law. The objectives of the report, which is annual in this regard, are to enforce the application of EU law in the EU. Among the positive points of this report is that it has been able to give a political dimension to a space which in principle the Commission intends to make exempt from policy, namely that of the application of the Law. In this regard, the idea that austerity has harmful effects on the legal certainty of citizens was passed on. Although the result is not optimal, given that this would imply a clear denunciation of the emergence of illegal instances that ended up generating law such as the Troika, we do think that the report finds a space for politicization of the debate on an application of law that is not the same in some places and in others.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. The objective of this annual report is to identify gaps in transposition, as well as problems arising from the application of Community law in the Member States. It reflects the importance of the application of Community environmental law and identifies the sectors in which problems occur, such as transport, health, the environment or services.  Although in this text the rapporteur, Mr Kostas Chrysogonos, my colleague in my parliamentary group, has failed to maintain his initial proposal that the text recognise the illegality of the Troika, has succeeded in including the harmful effects of cuts on public spending on citizens' legal certainty. Since the report also calls on Member States to fulfil their obligations on economic and social rights, I voted in favour of the proposed text.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this initiative report; it gives a good overview of what was included in the Commission’s 30th and 31st annual reports on monitoring the application of EU Law from 2012 to 2013.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing ‒ Although the original compromise of the present report looked promising, the final form is in a state in which I cannot agree with it, particularly because of efforts to increase harmonisation of law in the EU and the consequent restriction of member states' sovereignty. That's why I was against it.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ This explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ I supported the motion for a resolution proposing how to ensure better application of EU law in individual Member States. EU citizens must be informed in a timely and transparent manner about how national authorities implement European legislation. At present, there are situations where implementation is insufficient, uneven between Member States. On the other hand, there are cases where Member States create standards and regulations or procedures that go beyond their obligations to the EU and can even be contradictory to the expected results. Then there are cases where harmonised law, which is intended to make life and work easier for citizens, makes them unevenly harmonised. The annual report also highlights the very topical problem of a disparate common asylum policy within the EU, which is causing major problems with the current huge migration wave from countries in the Middle East, Afghanistan and Africa. The report also points to an important role in the application of EU law to citizens, businesses, NGOs and other stakeholders, who have the opportunity to address complaints, petitions and questions to EU institutions and representatives if they find that EU rights are under-applied.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ I support this report because it propagates austerity measures that are still very important for a Europe that has not yet recovered from the financial and economic crisis that has unfolded in the past years.  The application of EU law by Member States is effective, which is a positive thing given that it is an essentially important category for achieving the political goals of the European Union. This is the way it should be in the future, and all Member States and the Commission should fulfil their obligations and duties and be accountable for them, as they have been before.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: I did not support the proposal in writing ‒ because it presents a number of challenges that will damage the economy and employment in the EU, or are wrong for other reasons, such as criticism of austerity measures in countries with high debts, calls for the establishment of a Common European Asylum System, greater 'social dialogue' at REFIT, greater harmonisation of environmental legislation at EU level and so on.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 The full implementation of European Union law by the Member States is one of the conditions for deepening the integration and equalisation of living conditions and the pursuit of economic activities in individual Member States. Unfortunately, not all countries are implementing equally and to an equal extent, and worse still, many of them are adding their additional regulations to already highly regulated EU law. In my opinion, the time has come to review the system of creating European Union law, its scope vis-6 towards citizens and other legal entities, including limiting the impact of EU legislation on the freedom to conduct a business and the freedom of individual citizens of Community countries to take decisions on their own affairs. The more freedom, the more social, civic and business entrepreneurship that drives development.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report covering the 2012 and 2013 Commission’s reports. The report contains a number of good elements. It insists on the need for the Commission and member States should better coordinate their efforts at an earlier stage of the legislative process with a view of ensuing and effective implementation. It also urges the Commission, when drafting and assessing legislation, to take greater account of the burden it may impose on SMEs. Finally, it recalls that EU legislation must be transposed properly and promptly into the legal order of each Member State and urges Members to avoid the practice of ‘gold-plating’.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ While the report underlines the Commission's duty to monitor the application and implementation of EUROPEAN Union law in a timely and efficient way, I consider it to focus on issues that should not be prioritised. Namely, the four main areas in which the largest number of procedures have been initiated are transport, health and consumer protection, environmental protection and internal market and service issues, which have been made priority areas by this report.  Despite the need to encourage law enforcement in these areas, I believe that other problems, such as reducing bureaucratic barriers and increasing competitiveness, should nevertheless be focused. This would allow for a simpler and more effective application of EUROPEAN Union law in the Member States.  In addition, no concrete ways have been clearly expressed for improved implementation of legislation while respecting the principle of subsidiarity. Therefore, I voted against this report.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the report because it encourages the EU institutions to take responsibility for the formulation of rules relating to EU secondary legislation or to respect primary legislation when deciding on policies in different areas. At the same time, they are doing everything possible to assist the Member States of the European Union in their efforts to respect the union's values and principles in times of austerity and budgetary constraints.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of chrysogonos' proposed report on monitoring the implementation of EU law. The objectives of the report, which is annual in this regard, are to enforce the application of EU law in the EU. Among the positive points of this report is that it has been able to give a political dimension to a space which in principle the Commission intends to make exempt from policy, namely that of the application of the Law. In this regard, the idea that austerity has harmful effects on the legal certainty of citizens was passed on. Although the result is not optimal, given that this would imply a clear denunciation of the emergence of illegal instances that ended up generating law such as the Troika, we do think that the report finds a space for politicization of the debate on an application of law that is not the same in some places and in others.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted in favour of chrysogonos' proposed report on monitoring the implementation of EU law. The objectives of the report, which is annual in this regard, are to enforce the application of EU law in the EU. Among the positive points of this report is that it has been able to give a political dimension to a space which in principle the Commission intends to make exempt from policy, namely that of the application of the Law. In this regard, the idea that austerity has harmful effects on the legal certainty of citizens was passed on. Although the result is not optimal, given that this would imply a clear denunciation of the emergence of illegal instances that ended up generating law such as the Troika, we do think that the report finds a space for politicization of the debate on an application of law that is not the same in some places and in others.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of these annual reports on monitoring the application of EU law because I consider it a good report, asking the Commission to propose binding rules in the form of regulation on the basis of Article 298 TFEU which aim to respect citizens for good administration, as set out in Article 41 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights. The report also addresses the consequences and effects of austerity measures towards respect for human and fundamental rights.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 There are certainly positive aspects in this report, particularly when, in the recitals, the rapporteur draws attention to the fact that, in the context of the said financial crisis, Member States were obliged to take measures that called into question the provisions themselves on the protection of social rights. It is clear that the austerity measures imposed on Member States, in particular drastic reductions in public spending, have significantly reduced the capacity of the public administration and the justice system of those countries.  However, we do not agree with this supervisory view, which gives the European Commission the power to initiate infringement proceedings "in order to ensure compliance with EU law" and argues that the Court of Justice may impose sanctions on Member States for late transposition of EU law, which constitutes unacceptable disregard for the sovereignty bodies of the countries.  For those reasons, we voted against it.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The call for a rapid and complete implementation of CEAS (common European asylum system) is incompatible with the FPÖ's asylum line. It should also be noted that it is not the implementation of the Dublin Regulation that has failed, but its application. This report sees the Member States as the only problem in implementing EU law, but the rapporteur calls for the Commission and the Council to ensure full access to documents (whether the rapporteur refers to TTIP cannot be assessed). I shall therefore abstain from voting.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. Together with my colleagues in the ECR Group, I voted against this report. The report focuses on EU law of 2012 and 2013 in policy areas relating to issues such as health and consumer protection, environmental protection, the internal market and services. It calls for better application of EU law and for the Commission to respond more quickly to reports of breaches of EU law. While I was able to support the ECR compromises proposing enhanced dialogue with the national parliaments, the ECR rejects the report in its current form on the grounds of breaches of the principle of subsidiarity. So did I.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 This report analyses the application of EU law by Member States in 2012 and 2013, in particular how the EU directives have been transposed and the entire EU acquis has been implemented. There are some positive aspects that we follow, particularly when, in the recitals, the rapporteur draws attention to the fact that, in the context of the so-called financial crisis, Member States have been obliged to take measures that have called into question the very provisions on the protection of social and economic rights, which are expressed – at least in the field of 'theory' – in the EU acquis. We also agree that the austerity measures imposed on Member States, in particular drastic reductions in public spending, have significantly reduced the capacity of the public administration and the justice system of those countries.  However, we oppose this supervisory view, which gives the European Commission the power to bring infringement proceedings "in order to ensure compliance with EU law" and argues that the Court of Justice may impose sanctions on Member States for late transposition of EU law, which is an unacceptable disregard for the sovereignty bodies of the countries. For those reasons, we voted against it.
